column2: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 -- Adolf Eichmann was officially informed today of the charges on which he will be tried by Israel.

Rangers and others concerned about wildlife in the heavy snows have been manning toboggans loaded with bales of alfalfa and clover to deposit at deer-feeding stations deep in woodlands within fifty miles of the city.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Hubert de Givenchy's spring collection, which premiered this afternoon, was summed up by an American store president as follows:

The continued cold weather throughout the nation last week caused a sharp drop in stocks of light fuel oil, used mainly for home heating. Since the weather handicapped motorists, it brought about a big rise in gasoline inventories.

As one who has lived in Washington for some ten years while serving in various Government posts, and who is most interested in the esthetic quality of buildings and monuments constructed there, I would like to endorse most heartily the imaginative winning design for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial carried out by William F. Pederson, Bradford S. Tilney and their associates.
The City Planning Commission heard civic and parent groups from Queens object yesterday to a proposed highway improvement.

Joel Hunter, president of Crucible Steel Company of America, said yesterday that there was "no hope" of a general price increase in stainless, alloy or Other specialty steels. There probably would be no chance of such an increase for "a long time to come," he remarked.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 -- Earnings of the American Motors Corporation for the quarter ended on Dec. 31 declined from those of a year earlier, despite an increase of 6.2 per cent in sales, George Romney, president, reported today.
If the United States Lawn Tennis Association attempts to take the professionals under its wing it may run into some opposition from the pros, Jack Kramer said yesterday.
The March 16 performance of "Mary, Mary," a play by Jean Kerr at the Helen Hayes Theatre, will be a benefit for the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa said today he was confident trucking employers would repudiate the American Trucking Association's call for compulsory arbitration of the industry's labor problems.
The Wagner administration has ordered experts on medical care to investigate the reposed "chaos" at Harlem Hospital.
Two United States airlines -- American and Eastern -- announced yesterday a liberalization of passenger baggage allowances, effective on March 1, on trans-border routes into Canada.

Men have searched for a practical Northwest Passage from Europe to the Far East since the days of Cabot and Columbus to the successful voyage of the nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus. The adventurers, their heroism and their sacrifices are the subjects of two forthcoming books.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today by the New York State Commerce Department:
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- The biggest attraction in Moscow tonight was an exhibition of textiles.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 1 -- The three-stage Minuteman, intended to become the Air Force's No. 1 weapon, was fired for the first time here today and scored a spectacular success.

The fight that is shaping up for control of Fruit of the Loom, Inc., a company whose principal asset is a trade-mark more than 100 years old, may evolve into a tussle as to who should own the tail that wags the dog.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Automatic, unattended laundries and dry cleaning establishments will be grossing $1,000,000,000 a year within two years -- and this is only the beginning, according to an official of American Laundry Machinery Industries.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 1 -- Ahmed Emin Yalman, 72-year-old Turkish editor, has left the newspaper Vatan, which he edited for twenty-one years, after he was outvoted yesterday at a stockholders' meeting.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- It cost residents of New York an average of $51.78 a person in local taxes for schools in 1959 according to state figures released today. The levies include both property and non-property taxes.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Government announced today that charges under the National Health Service were to be increased.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The American Broadcasting Company bowed today to legislators who are opposed to the way Italian-Americans are depicted on the television crime program, "The Untouchables."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Advertising Federation of America got friendly words from the new Administration today. In a message to the A.F.A. Midwinter Conference at the Statler-Hilton Hotel here, President Kennedy hailed the industry executives' effort to "create a better understanding of advertising as a dynamic force in our economy."
Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller pressed his campaign today to inject culture into the upper regions of New York despite grumblings by some lawmakers that he was trying to "put the state in the ballet business."
St. Bonaventure and Bradley, after battling all season for the No. 2 spot in college basketball rankings, will settle the issue in Madison Square Garden tonight.
RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 1 -- A new controversy swirled around the captured Portuguese liner Santa Maria tonight as she lay anchored about three miles from the sea wall that forms this city's harbor.

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 1 -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of a message sent today by Henrique M. Galvao, leader of the rebels who seized the Portuguese liner Santa Maria, to Admiral Dias Fernandes, commander of Brazil's Third Naval District:
The Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital at Denver has taken over the entire Metropolitan Opera House for the April 22 evening performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Kennedy indicated today that he hoped the passengers aboard the Santa Maria would be landed safely and the ship returned to the Portuguese Government.

Ski Sketch: Through the years Leon (Duke) Elliott has been extolling skiing as invigorating for young and old. This winter he's changed his tune. He has suddenly become a proponent of the "less taxing and more relaxing" school.
NEWARK, Feb. 1 -- A record school budget of $32,215,249 for 1961-62 has been adopted by the Board of Education. The total represents an increase of $1,439,857 over the 1960-61 budget.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The United States has not lost prestige abroad, Gen. Paul Stehlin, Chief of Staff of the French Air Force, said in an interview today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- The appointment of Dillon S. Myer as director of the Emergency Cuban Relief Program in this area was announced today by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Oliver L. Lacey, 44 years old, a professor at the University of Alabama, burned to death today in a fire at his suburban home.

The Federal Maritime Board ordered an investigation yesterday of the proposed merger of American Export Lines and the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc. The merger would combine in one fleet twenty-eight American Export ships and fourteen Isbrandtsen vessels.

Before commending The Times for its forthright stand in denouncing as unconstitutional the proposals now before the Legislature for a modest annual subsidy for students of the stage who may enroll in one of New York's tuition-charging colleges, one feels justified in suggesting a more judicious reading of the facts.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- Last, year's 1,218,911 automobiles in New Jersey, or 44.46 per cent of those tested, failed to meet minimum safety requirements, the State Division of Motor Vehicles announced today.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- A call for reorganization of hospital and medical services to provide the benefits of modern scientific medicine to the general public was made today.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 1 -- Ten Arab states agreed today to speed more arms and volunteers to the Algerian Provisional Government in its struggle against France.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1 -- Queen Elizabeth II received a rousing welcome here today. on the start of a sixteen-day visit to Pakistan.
The Citizens Union yesterday accused Buildings Commissioner Peter J. Reidy of reacting to state charges of corruption in his department with "a diversionary tactic rather than a factual refutation."
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The Democratic legislative leaders called today for radically expanding the state's scholarship program as an alternative to the Rockefeller "scholar incentive" plan.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed in his budget today that the state planned to spend $345,000,000 in the fiscal year starting April 1 for highways, parkways, building and other capital construction work.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 1 -- The Belgian Government announced today it was ready to discuss with leaders of the newly proclaimed Republic of Ruanda the development of political institutions for the country.

The Chase Manhattan Bank obtained approval yesterday for a new Westchester County branch one day after its chairman had complained that the State Banking Department was moving slowly in processing such applications.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Classes were held today at the integrated McDonogh No. 19 elementary school without the two boy's who broke a two-month white boycott.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Stock market prices again showed no decided trend here today and the volume of business was smaller than yesterday's.
PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 1 -- A grand jury presentment calling conditions at the Passaic County Children's Center "intolerable" and "inhumane" has been released by Superior Court Judge Harold Kovolosky.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- The United States dollar slipped slightly on European money exchanges today following an upsurge in value after President Kennedy's State of the Union Message Monday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Yale upset Boston College, 69 -- 65, tonight. Boston College, had been averaging 84 points a game, but trailed, 35 -- 19, at the end of the first half.
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 31 -- The United States' most important Pacific ally is wavering on the issue of recognizing Communist China.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Cold, disgruntled Paris suburban commuters took a leaf from the captors of the liner Santa Maria today and seized a bus.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 1 -- The appointment of F. Rhodes Henderer as vice president of Adelphi College here was announced today. He previously was staff director for public relations research for the United States Steel Corporation in New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A gap in the nation's satellite-detection fence will be plugged this year by construction of one of the world's largest radio transmitters.

ALPHONSE MOYSE, editor of Bridge World, who plays at the Cavendish Club of New York, periodically publishes in his magazine a record of the bridge crimes committed by the noted experts who play there.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 1 -- Congolese leaders exhibited today arms and ammunition of Czechoslovak manufacture that they said had been supplied by the United Arab Republic to the forces supporting Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier.

CARACAS, Feb. 1 -- Venezuela plans to seek a new foreign loan of $50,000,000, Dr. Tomas Enrique Carrillo Batalla, Finance Minister, reported. It will be used for local industries, irrigation, roads and farm projects. The loan must be approved by Congress.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Rockland County Supervisors voted unanimously today to promote preliminary plans for a county sewer system.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that a special stockholders' meeting had been called for Feb. 28 in Kansas City, Mo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Some Southern Democrats who voted against the Rayburn leadership in yesterday's fight over the House Rules Committee failed to get committee assignments of their choice today.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 1 (AP). -- Five former Secretaries of Agriculture agreed today that the farm problem -- stripped to its basics -- was "how to give us our daily bread" at a low price to the producer and consumer.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Chrysler corporation was disclosed today to have adopted new rules to govern relations between officers and employes and supplier concerns that do business with the automobile maker.

David B. Charnay, chairman of the executive committee of Hazel Bishop, Inc., has about doubled his stock interest in that company. In the latest insiders' report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, as disclosed by the American Stock Exchange where Hazel Bishop shares are traded, Mr. Charnay is reported to have acquired an additional 30,600 shares of the stock, increasing his interest to 61,200 shares.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- New York City and its four surrounding counties will get more than half of the state aid in Governor Rockefeller's 1961-62 budget.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The deficit in the United States' balance of international payments last year was approximately $3,800,000,000, according to a preliminary Government estimate made public today.

A pilot program to treat very young school children having emotional problems to avert similar problems in their pre-school brothers and sisters was announced yesterday by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.

The cold weather has had at least one good effect. Because of it the Department of Motor Vehicles will permit motorists to renew their auto registrations through tomorrow without an "FS-1" form, showing their insurance is in force.

The nation's largest stockholder family -- the 1,960,000 of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company -- probably will be asked to vote at the meeting in April on whether they want the secret ballot.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 -- Another tax battle loomed in Michigan today but without the overtones of crisis that racked the state two years ago.

Events tonight: "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Alfred Wallenstein, conductor, Zvi Zeitlin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "The Gondoliers," New York City Center, 8:30; Riverside Chamber Singers, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 1 -- The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn announced today that $761,000 had been raised toward the cost of building Long Island's first graduate engineering center in Farmingdale.
The conservatism of compact-car owners and the lighter impact of their cars in accidents justify the new 10 per cent discount for them on liability insurance, underwriters said yesterday.

The callous comment of Representative Francis E. Walter -- most hostile opponent of liberal refugee and immigration legislation since the late Senator Pat McCarran -- was to be expected, ridiculing a proposal to admit to the United States in the next two years up to 40,000 non-quota refugee-escapees from Communist and other forms of persecution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Administration has retreated from its plan to allow live telecasting of any Kennedy news conference if requested by the networks.
Dan Topping, the president of the New York Yankees, yesterday took what appeared to be the first step toward ending segregation at the American League champions' St. Petersburg (Fla.) training camp.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Kennedy declared today his willingness to engage in a televised debate with a contender for his office in 1964.

Following is an official summary of the major provisions of the Delaware Basin compact as submitted by the Delaware River Basin Advisory Committee to the Governors of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware and the Mayors of New York and Philadelphia:
DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 1 -- Research to make the services of the Department of Commerce mean more to the public was pledged today by Luther H. Hodges, the new Secretary of Commerce.
A workshop on what to do when the siren signal warns of an approaching enemy attack was held yesterday at the New York City Office of Civil Defense, 135 East Fifty-fifth Street.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Two Government columns supported by rocket-firing planes today captured the road junction of Sala Phoukhoung from the Communists, officials here said.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Pacific Coast officials of the Teamsters Union said today that they would not let a new automation agreement between shipowners and longshoremen put members of the union out of work.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 15 points (75 cents a bale) off yesterday. The near months were weakest.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday for 1960 an estimated net income of $182,500,000, or $3.76 each on the average of 48,592,322 shares outstanding during the year.
The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable declines in total and net income for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30.
The off off-Broadway theatre movement incubating in Greenwhich Village continues to grow.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Jan. 31 -- President Sekou Toure's Government nationalized Guinea's two major utility companies today.

Effective this month, the New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program will pass along to hospitals part of the cost of collecting, processing and distributing blood. The hospitals, in turn, will pass the cost to patients.

Opposition to the International Labor Organization -- especially among some leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- because of the I. L.O. report on freedom of association in the U.S.S.R. is most unfortunate. It makes difficulties for an institution that should be generously supported by organized labor, business and the Government -- the three groups represented in the I.L.O.

FIFTEEN days ago, Maureen Forrester, the distinguished Canadian contralto, gave birth to her fourth child. It did not keep her from filling her recital date in Town Hall last night nor from giving what was virtually a perfect performance.

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 1 -- The captive Portuguese liner Santa Maria and the city of Recife stared at each other today across a short stretch of aquamarine water that separated the passengers from the freedom they lost ten days ago.
Net income of Philip Morris, Inc., in 1960 rose 7.1 per cent above the 1959 level on a sales gain of 1.6 per cent, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president of the tobacco products concern, reported yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A testimonial dinner Monday night honored five members of the Orleans Parish school system who have resisted ouster efforts of the State Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Following are the highlights of President Kennedy's news conference today:

The City Center Gilbert and Sullivan Company came through with all colors flying last night when it presented the last of the four works it is doing in its first season. The production was "H. M. S. Pinafore," and it was beautiful.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Leading military figures should not make speeches in conflict with Administration policy, President Kennedy said today.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 1 -- Chinese Nationalist experts on Communist China predicted today that the Communists' food shortage would worsen late this spring when last year's crop is consumed and with new harvests still several months away.

The First Boston Corporation and associates are offering to the public today at par an issue of $6,800,000 of 4 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds due 1986 of Kentucky and Indiana Terminal Railroad Company at 100.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- Ken Mackay and Lindsay Kline held out for 109 minutes in a last-wicket partnership today and saved Australia from what appeared to he certain defeat in the fourth cricket test match against the West Indies.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers sold a catcher, Joe Pignatano, and an outfielder, Chuck Essegian, to different American League clubs today. The new Los Angeles Angels bought a relief pitcher, Tom Morgan, from the Minnesota Twins.
Four persons have been arrested in the recent theft of $30,000 worth of jewelry from the hotel suite of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lawford, brother-in-law and sister of President Kennedy.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The leaders of the Labor and Liberal parties urged Prime Minister Macmillan today to reconsider his refusal to order a Government inquiry into negotiations for a newspaper and magazine merger.
Simon Schuster was awarded the Carey-Thomas award for creative book publishing yesterday for its publication of William L. Shirer's best-seller, "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich."

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. l -- The Government's daily tirades against the Roman Catholic hierarchy abruptly halted yesterday with the Holy See's appointment of Claudius Angenor, a Haitian, as acting administrator of the Port-Au-Prince archdiocese.
"THE ICE IN THE BEDROOM," by P.G. Wodehouse, is a wildly inspiring novel about people struggling against almost incredible odds.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics played their best basketball in the final period tonight when they rallied for a 124-120 National Basketball Association triumph over the New York Knickerbockers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Net income of the Rohm Haas Company in 1960 declined to $21,290,000, or $18.47 a common share, from $23,161,000, or $20.11 a share, in 1959. Sales of the chemical producer rose to $218,198,000 from $215,909,000 a year earlier.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Fe 1 (AP) -- Six golfers, including one who barely missed a $56,000 hole-in-one bonus, shot 65 today and shared the lead the first round of the ninety hole Desert Classic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency will inspect all British Viscount turboprop planes in this country, Representative Samuel S. Stratton reported today.

The Waterways Freight Bureau of Chicago appealed an Interstate Commerce Commission ruling last night that permits new railroad rates to become effective on the annual traffic flow of 400,000 tons of alumina.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration's order to reduce by more than half the nearly 500,000 dependents allowed to accompany service men overseas was revoked today by President Kennedy.

The Government has chosen to mark Ground Hog Day this year in a distinctive manner. It is not a special vigilance committee posted at some likely point in the Eastern ground hog belt to watch for shadows.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Seven patients were burned to death today when flames engulfed a four-story private nursing home for the elderly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy opened the American Heart Association's fund-raising campaign today at the White House. It was the first of many similar appearances she is expected to make.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Two officials of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair called on President Kennedy today and received his assurance of Federal participation.
Mayor Wagner was urged yesterday to move quickly to oust Carmine G. De Sapio as New York County Democratic leader.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Gen. Jean Olie was named today to succeed Gen. Paul Ely as France's top military commander.
VILSECK, Germany, Feb. 1 -- More than 60,000 Allied troops were ready in Bavaria tonight for the beginning early tomorrow of Winter Shield II, the United States Seventh Army field training exercise.
TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- Within ten days the sixty seats in the New Jersey Assembly will be reapportioned for the first time since 1941.

A Lutheran mother who lost custody of her three children to their Roman Catholic father pleaded in court yesterday for their return. She contended that a pre-marital agreement to bring them up as Catholics was unconstitutional
Reports were presented yesterday bearing on two of the most tantalizing mysteries associated with cosmic rays.

After some indecisive churning, the stock market pulled itself together yesterday and moved ahead to a modest gain. Volume contracted somewhat on the New York Stock Exchange but was still above the 4,000,00O-share mark for the seventeenth time this year and for the eighth trading session in a row.
The twenty-second annual American Music Festival sponsored by WNYC, the municipal radio station, will begin on Sunday, Feb. 12, with a concert at Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The nomination of Mortimer M. Caplin as Commissioner of Internal Revenue was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.
The city's 123 departments and agencies have submitted requests for, the 1961-62 expense budget amounting to $2,640,543,074, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday.

All trading in the No. 6 sugar contract was suspended yesterday by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The contract consists of domestic sugar in bags. Henceforth, the domestic sugar will make up the No. 7 contract, or sugar in bulk.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following weather forecast and report on ski conditions today: Fair and continued cold.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Chicago and New Hampshire rinks reached the final of the seventh annual women's Empire State bonspiel for the Hovey-Seibert Medal at the St. Andrew's Golf Club curling rink today.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Alamode Farm's Vapor Whirl showed the way to a field of Flamingo and Kentucky Derby hopefuls today as he scored a neck victory over F.W. Hooper's Crozier in the $29,575 Bahamas at Hialeah.

There was much speculation in broadcasting circles yesterday about a successor to John F. Day, who resigned Tuesday as vice president of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System. Throughout the industry the name consistently mentioned was Blair Clark, a C.B.S. correspondent who has been on the news staff since 1953.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 1 -- "When the west wind blows, the paper tiger wall go away."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee approved an additional total of $1,199,500 today to finance investigations by various Senate committees and subcommittees.

Young Jack Johnson of Los Angeles, one of the heaviest heavyweights to appear in Madison Square Garden since the days of Primo Carnera, was named yesterday as a substitute in one of the three ten-round bouts scheduled there Saturday night.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Another late rally hit soybean futures with a furious burst today on the Board of Trade.

The bond market had another quiet treading session yesterday, with the major interest again commanded by the Short-term investment yields obtainable from the discount bills of the united States Treasury.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 1 -- The Air Force announced today that it had consolidated its search and rescue operations under the Air Rescue Service at Orlando Air Force Base, Fla.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The sale of the Capper Publications, Inc., interest in Home State Publications, Inc., of Cleveland to Harman-Slocum Publishing Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by Oscar S. Stauffer, president of Capper.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The newly elected head of the nation's home-building industry hailed President Kennedy's Executive Order lowering the interest rate on home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
The final design has been completed for the controversial cafe and pavilion the city proposes to build in Central Park with funds provided by Huntington Hartford.
Word from the Soviet Union yesterday confirmed the entries of three Russians in track and field meets scheduled here during the next five weeks. They will arrive on Feb. 14.
New York City high schools have produced ten of the forty national winners in the twentieth annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold asked the Security Council today to widen his powers in the Congo so that he might stop factional fighting among politically motivated groups of the Congolese Army.
Automobile production in the nation last month dropped sharply below the levels of December and January, 1960.
The New York Young Republican Club has repudiated the action of three New York Republican Congressmen in supporting the Kennedy Administration move to enlarge the House Rules Committee.

The first test of President Kennedy's foreign policy and Ambassador Stevenson's diplomacy is now trader way in the United Nations Security Council. This body, entrusted with primary responsibility for international peace and security, is meeting again on the crisis in the Congo which has become a pawn in both the Soviet cold war and African-Asian rivalries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A total of 67,600 college freshmen enrolled last fall in engineering classes, 100 fewer than the 67,700 registered in the fall of 1959, the office of Education reported today.
Scientists at Bell Telephone Laboratories reported yesterday finding a way to create enormously powerful magnetic fields for virtually nothing.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Yale football players want the Ivy League code revised to permit post-season competition and spring practice.
Heavy snows and freezing temperatures dealt a hard blow to retail trade in the New York area last month.
A tentative settlement was reached early today in the day-old strike of wholesale delivery men that has disrupted newspaper circulation in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Kennedy announced steps today designed to counter the recession. He called for food-stamp projects in five particularly distressed communities, accelerated payments of veterans' life-insurance dividends and stimulants for housing and other construction.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 1 -- Czechoslovak economic planners provided a clue today to their country's role in the rapid industrialization of other Communist states and the economic penetration of under-developed areas.
THERE is nothing more depressing than a fantasy that won't take wing, and "Midgie Purvis" is relentlessly earthbound.

In the performance of Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore" given by the Metropolitan Opera last night, Roberta Peters and Mario Sereni made first appearances in their respective roles with the company. Miss Peters was Adina, and Mr. Sereni was Belcore.
Two tenement dwellers went into Lower Manhattan Court yesterday seeking to force their landlord to provide heat and hot water.

A columnist for the Jesuit weekly America declares in the issue dated tomorrow that the Roman Catholic laity "have not contributed much of substance to the cultural and intellectual life of the nation."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 1 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion's return to head the Israel Government depends upon action by his party against Pinhas Lavon, secretary general of Histadrut, the Israel Federation of Labor, an informed source said tonight.
Edward G. Uhl is expected to be elected soon as president and chief executive officer of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.

A group of French lacquer panels inlaid with metals is being exhibited and sold for the first time in this country by Argout Ferguson, Inc., 6 East Seventy-ninth Street. Elegant additions to today's decor, the panels were intricately wrought in France by Regnard-Saladin in the manner of the furniture created by Andre Charles Boulle in the seventeenth century.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy chose today a prosecutor from Suffolk County, N.Y., as his chief lieutenant in a stepped-up national campaign against organized crime.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association opened its annual meeting today, torn by sharp disagreement over how to raise both money and amateur standards.

Having predicted a bumper crop of record performances in tomorrow night's Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden, meet officials and track buffs scanned the list of entrants again yesterday in an effort to forecast the outstanding participant.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Ham the chimpanzee, largest animal ever to rocket into space, completed the round trip today by more mundane transportation.

Governor Rockefeller describes his 1961-62 budget as having been framed in "a mood of cautious optimism." Approaching the two-and a-half billion mark, with appropriations of $2,411,000,000 proposed, an increase of $269,000,000 over the current year, it thus differs measurably from the "budget of restraint" that he wrote a year ago.

"You should pick a dog as you pick a friend," said Dr. Edward M. Vardon of Detroit in partial explanation of why he liked bulldogs. "You want somebody who is quiet and relaxing and doesn't get on your nerves all the time. Bulldogs are relaxing."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A state court jury tonight awarded Mayor Earl James of Montgomery a $500,000 libel Judgment against The New York Times and four Negro ministers.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Indictments against eight pacifists charged with seeking to interfere with the launching of a nuclear submarine were dismissed today by United States District Court Judge Robert P. Anderson.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Kennedy said today that the United States' position in critical world trouble spots "is less satisfactory than it was last fall."
ATLANTA, Feb. 1 -- A committee to study revision of Georgia's controversial county unit election system was proposed today by one of Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver's legislative leaders.
Queens College defeated City College, 62 -- 47, last night for its first basketball victory over the Beavers since the series between the teams began in 1949. C. C. N. Y. had won thirteen times.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Kennedy's news conference went an extra inning today after it had been officially terminated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Two Republicans and a Democrat attacked today a statement by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a Presidential assistant, that the welfare state was "the best security against communism."
A 60-year-old Queens contractor known in Magistrates Court as "The Emperor Scofflaw" surrendered yesterday because he said he had a guilty conscience.

IN Norway, Sweden and Denmark sandwich making is an art. The residents of Scandinavia start with a rich-grained slice of dark bread, slather it with sweet butter, then top it with any of a hundred palatable combinations.

Though the temperature dropped to 2 degrees below zero yesterday morning, an 18-year-old City College co-ed ran on the outdoor wooden track in Lewisohn Stadium. She was preparing for tonight's meeting with Wilma Rudolph and fourteen others in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

POISED, scholarly, articulate, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. is an authority on public finance and tax policy. . . . Reputedly New Dealish leaning, advocates stepping up rate of economic growth. . . .
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Department of Sanitation acted yesterday to take the possibility of "whim, fancy and political maneuvering" out of the department's administration of working conditions.
Columbia and Fordham squeezed in a basketball game last night, interspersing athletic activity among scores of dramatic gestures by the two officials.
The present cold spell appears likely to increase heating bills more than 10 per cent above normal for the winter.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Thruway Authority has hired its former chairman, Bertram D. Tallamy, to develop a "long-range maintenance program" or the 560-mile Thruway.

DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, starting with Frank Mahovlich's forty-first goal, blanked the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 5 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 13,630.

WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The emergency program of food stamps for the unemployed announced by President Kennedy yesterday will make life a little brighter in the triangular tip of southern Illinois.

Although the skies, this strange winter, have been dumping small amounts of snow on such northerly points as the Adirondacks and Canada's Laurentians, a small ski center in Maryland has been more than holding its own.

The estate of Pauline Engel has sold he five-story apartment house on lot 25 by 100 feet at 37-39 Clinton Street, southwest corner of Stanton Street. The property which had been in the Engel family for fifty years, was acquired by the 174 East Third Street Corporation for investment.
KINGS POINT, L.I., Feb. 2 -- New York University swimmers won six of the eleven events in a dual meet with the United States Merchant Marine Academy today and the Violets scored a 51-44 victory.

Nearly 400 alumni of St. Francis College in Brooklyn heard Brother Urban, president of the school, praise yesterday a proposal for $200 in student aid annually. The group was attending a dinner at the St. George Hotel."

Events today: "Tannhaeuser," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Alfred Wallenstein, conductor, Zvi Zeitlin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; "H.M.S. Pinafore," New York City Center, 8:30; Dale Moore, baritone, Town Hall, 5:45; Paul Zukofsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Nicanor Zabaleta, harpist, Town Hall, 8:30; Mary-Louise Brown, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Balenciaga's spring collection today was a repeat of yesterday's Givenchy performance. The audience left filled with admiration for the beauty of it all, but disappointed with the lack of red hot, new ideas.
A distinguished man with iron gray hair, matching mustache and otherwise correct manners, stood at a gate at Grand Central Terminal yesterday stopping young women.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Jan. 28 Were 7 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today the nation's economic woes resulted from excessive power wielded by labor leaders.
The new three-year contract between tugboat owners and their crews will raise charges 15 per cent, according to a consensus of the owners.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 11 points (25 to 55 cents a bale) yesterday. Price fixing increased in the near months at the close.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Sources close to the Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives privately acknowledged today that the party's committee assignments had been made partly on the basis of how members voted in Tuesday's fight over enlargement of the Rules Committee.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Armand Reo tipped in the winning field goal with twelve seconds left tonight as the Notre Dame basketball team upset St. John's of Brooklyn, 64 -- 63.

Madison Square Garden will be backed to the rafters tonight in the fifty-fourth annual Millrose Athletic Association Games. The meet opens what shapes up as an eventful indoor track and field season here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Rail and truck loadings declined again below year-ago levels last week, partly because of continued bad weather.
New York had its coldest day in almost eighteen years yesterday when the temperature sank to 2 degrees below zero at 7:05 A.M. On Feb. 15, 1943, it was 8 degrees below.
Earnings of American Metal Climax, Inc., in 1960 set a record at $38,700,000 or $2.71 a Share, which compared with $30,833,000, or $2.15 a share, a year earlier, it was announced yesterday.
The heavy outflow of gold from the United States that has been experienced recently eased to $9,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1 -- The Laotian Government reported today that its troops had captured Sala Pou Koun, a key road junction 100 miles north of here.

The building of the Australian 12-Meter yacht that will be the challenger for the America's Cup has just started, Sir Frank Packer, head of the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron syndicate, said yesterday. The match against an American defender will be held next year.
The Soviet press has suppressed key passages in a Chinese Communist party resolution laying down Peiping's line on international relations and inter-party unity.

On the coldest day in eighteen years city firemen fought two five-alarm blazes yesterday. One swept a furniture factory in the Bronx and the other destroyed two Harlem tenements. Two men were hurt and thirty-two families made homeless.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Al Mengert of Phoenix took over the second-round lead in the Palm Springs golf classic today. But the most spectacular shot of the hazy afternoon was a hole-in-one that could bring $50,000 to Don January.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The United States cautioned Canada today that it might end the present exemption status of Canadian oil if Canadians attempted to rush too much oil into this country.
This year's Russian Mi-Careme dinner dance has been arranged for Feb. 17 in the St. Regis Roof. The traditional event is among the final fetes before the start of Russian Lent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- C.J. Haggerty, head of the labor federation's Building Trades Department, expressed hope today that "we have now at least a basis" for curbing work stoppages on intercontinental ballistic missile sites.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 2 -- Immediate legislation to provide more state aid for hard-pressed school districts was urged at a public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee on School Financing here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Pentagon has placed orders for fifty-three military cargo and troop transport planes for a speedy build-up of the long-range airlift. The purpose is to give United States forces mobility to meet limited-war situations anywhere in the world.

Rapidly falling prices, resulting from an overnight accumulation of rush sell orders, caused a temporary suspension of trading in cocoa futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. The halt in trading lasted twelve minutes during the opening call to give brokers a chance to check their purchase and sales records.

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 2 -- The Portuguese liner Santa Maria dropped anchor in a brilliant midday sun within a hundred yards of shore, blaring martial music and taking the salute of each braided mariner who came aboard.
THE man who takes charge of the Weather Bureau at New York today, Charles Gerhard Knudsen, first learned meteorology by teaching it.
Aroused commuters intent on saving the Ardsley-on-Hudson station from "retirement" were taken aback here yesterday when the New York Central Railroad seemed to agree substantially.
DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Automotive News, a trade paper, estimated today that United States plants would assemble 102,797 cars this week, or 6.9 per cent more than last week's 96,179.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- The clack of pneumatic nailing machines and the noise of other construction machinery echoed through an eight-acre exposition here as the nation's home builders went into the final day of their annual convention.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 2 -- The West German Government formally made its offer of financial help to the United States today.

In a Jan. 29 dispatch, reference was made to the Cooper-Griffiths bill which will shortly be reintroduced before Congress. The aims of this bill are stated in phrases which are surely noble and universally appealing; for example, "to provide for the humane treatment of animals used in medical experiments * * * by recipients of grants from the United States."
A new Tuesday-evening subscription series will be started by the Metropolitan Opera next season as a result of the company's decision to discontinue its traditional Tuesday visits to Philadelphia.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 2 -- Ship traffic through the Panama Canal was halted for almost four hours last night and early today when a gear-and-shaft failure occurred in the gates of the lower chamber of the west lane at the Gatun Locks.

Stocks moved ahead uncertainly early yesterday as traders waited for President Kennedy's economic message to Congress. Once the President's proposals had been reported and digested, the market advanced briskly to score good gains for the day.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Ridden by Arthur Chambers, Bowie's leading jockey, Fighting Boy captured the Overbrook Purse at Bowie today by five lengths. He paid $19.60 for $2.

The National Investors Corporation has reported a new high net asset share value for a year end of $14.39 on Dec. 31, 1960. This marked a gain of l0 per cent above the $13.41 a share reported at the beginning of 1960.
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- France's Foreign Minister said today that the installation of the new United States Administration provided the occasion for a general revision of international policies by the West.
Rootes Motors announced yesterday it was cutting the prices of its Hillman economy line $50 to $176.

The Rev. Oberia D. Dempsey, associate pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, charged last night that Harlem Hospital conditions followed "the same pattern of neglect" that existed for Negroes in housing and employment.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The attorney for Negroes seeking full racial integration in the public schools here completed legal papers today for new proceedings against officials tomorrow in two courts.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, will accompany Prime Minister Macmillan for the talks with President Kennedy, the Prime Minister's office announced today.

Prices of prime-risk debt securities turned strong yesterday as professional dealers appraised the implications of President Kennedy's economic message and of the Treasury's decision to refund $6,938,000,000 of debt due this month for a term not longer than eighteen months.

"Modigliani of Montparnasse," a French-made drama based upon the life of the famed painter, has been scheduled to follow the current "Make Mine Mink" at the Baronet Theatre, according to Continental Distributing, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Representative Samual S. Stratton today described as "plain, unadulterated bunk" part of a recent Syracuse University report on New York unemployment problems.
DETROIT, Feb. 2 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today that its consolidated net income in 1960 was $427,885,948, down 5.2 per cent from $451,367,367 in 1959.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose by $19, 000,000 to $66,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined by $523, 000,000 from a revised figure the week before to $477,000,000.

St. Bonaventure defeated Bradley, 75 -- 61, at Madison Square Garden last night and left no doubt in the minds of the 15,497 fans that, next to Ohio State, the Olean, N.Y., basketball team is the best in all the fifty states.

Mayor Wagner's warning to his department and agency heads in December to hold their new budget requests to "an absolute minimum" was justified if not honored. These departmental requests for the 1961-62 expense budget are now in hand, and add up to $2,640,543,074, an increase of about $288,000,000 ever the appropriations in the current budget.
Is the endorsement of spring football practice and post-season games by Yale's football players a weathervane of changed thinking in Ivy League circles?

A REFLECTION of the High Renaissance in Venice may now be seen at the Seiferheld Gallery, 158 East Sixty-fourth Street, where, for the first time in America, drawings by members of the famous Bassano family of painters are displayed in a special exhibition.
A STORY of squalor and opulence in modern Hong Kong provided an hour of absorbing television in a filmed documentary on Channel 2 last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Kennedy asked the Mayors of 297 cities today to help stem the recession by speeding urban renewal projects.

John J. Homza, 59 years old, of 77 Myrtle Avenue, Irvington, N.J., was fatally injured at 5 A.M. yesterday when the automobile in which he was a passenger was in a collision with a Sanitation Department truck at Tenth Avenue and Forty-first Street, the police reported.

The New York Heart Fund Drive was opened yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson at Babies Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 West 168th Street. More than 40,000 volunteers are seeking $2,000,000 in the campaign.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 2 -- The United States announced today a prospective increase of $43,700,000 in economic aid to South Korea this year. It said "sympathetic consideration" would be given to any request for additional assistance in the form of surplus agricultural products.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Rejoicing was unanimous today at United States military bases around the world following President Kennedy's reversal of the order to reduce servicemen's dependents abroad.
Orders, prices, margins and employment all have deteriorated since the annual report of Burlington Industries, Inc., last Dec. 5, Spencer Love, chairman and president, said yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- A Spokesman for the hotels that serve as spring training headquarters for two major league baseball teams served notice tonight that Negro players would have to find quarters elsewhere.
Some of the country's leading physicists focused their attention yesterday on the almost infinitely large and the almost infinitely small.

A Committee of Vassar College freshmen, all debutantes of this season, are assisting the Vassar Club of New York in distribution of tickets for "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan Opera on the evening of March 18 for the benefit of the club's scholarship fund.
Moscow, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Speculation that Boris Pasternak may be posthumously rehabilitated by Soviet authorities gained strength today from an article in the newspaper Sovietskaya Kultura.
S. GARTON CHURCHILL of Great Neck is one of the senior prophets of bridge bidding. His theories have had enthusiastic adherents for nearly thirty years.
Net income of the General Electric Company last year fell 29 per cent below the level of 1959 on a sales decline of 3 per cent, Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman, reported yesterday.
EL CENTRO, Calif., Feb. 2 -- The Mexican Government ordered 2,000 Mexican contract workers evacuated from the strike-bound lettuce fields in California's Imperial Valley today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Business inventories were cut by $450,000,000 in December as sales of manufacturers and retailers declined, the Department of Commerce said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Kennedy chose David K.E. Bruce today as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP) -- The soft-coal mining community of St. Michael, about ten miles outside Johnstown, is a desolate town. The mines there shut down about three years ago and, according to one old miner, "not a wheel has turned since."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 2 -- Providence scored three goals within a minute midway through the final period tonight and scored a 4-3 hockey victory over Yale.
Six men were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges connected with the theft of at least $19,000 worth of brassieres over a four-year period.
MIAMI, Feb. 2 -- President Kennedy will shortly receive recommendations for using faculty members of the University of Havana, now in exile, as a major force in strengthening the Western Hemisphere.

The continued survival of the United States depends as much on the country's spiritual and moral growth as on its progress in science, Gen. Thomas D. White, the Air Force's Chief of Staff, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Kennedy announced today that he would discuss world problems informally with Prime Minister Macmillan in Washington during the week of April 2.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 2 -- A special train carrying 300 passengers to the Bowie Race Course derailed today. Six hours later, six bodies had been recovered from the wreckage of seven coaches.

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 2 -- The bizarre eleven-day cruise of the 607 captive passengers aboard the rebel-held Portuguese liner Santa Maria came to an end today when they landed in Recife. But the fate of the ship herself and of her revolutionary masters was in doubt.
TAKISTAN, Iran, Feb. 1 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi denounced his detractors at home and abroad today for opposing his program of gradual reform and progress in Iran.
An industry group urged Federal and state legislation yesterday that "would confine the use of picketing more nearly to the point of dispute and to the parties directly involved."
ROME, Feb. 2 -- Thousands of students staged anti-Austrian demonstrations in several Italian cities today.

ONCE upon a time there was a batting champion whose fluid swing and sharp eyesight at the plate seemed totally unaffected by his distressing habit of consuming vast quantities of whisky each evening. It was no secret. Everyone knew about it, including the manager. But the skipper still was bothered by the fact that his wayward hitter went counter to all known theories of accepted behavior.

BLUNTLY outspoken in his views, he criticized Federal Reserve System in article that appeared a week after his appointment to council. . . . 1957 testified before Joint Economic Committee that President Eisenhower's estimation of Federal spending would be exceeded.

ON leave from economic professorship at Williams College and serving as director of the economic and administration program of Ford Foundation, tapped by President Kennedy last month for economic council . . . Educated Swathmore College, Oxford University, where he was Rhodes Scholar, and Harvard University. . . .
THE theatre arrived last night at a new plateau of achievement: a play suitable for people who read only comic books.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- The Cuban Government said today that a treasury of art masterpieces, table services of gold and silver and cases of fine champagnes, all valued at several million dollars, had been seized at the home of a Spanish countess here.

Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced yesterday that it had added more than one trillion cubic feet of natural gas reserves to its supply through the purchase of leaseholds from Pan American Petroleum Corporation.
BRASILIA, Feb. 2 -- The Administration of President Janio Quadros indicated today that it was willing to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

An issue of $39,000,000 turnpike revenue bonds to finance construction of the Eastern Kentucky Toll Road was placed on the market yesterday by an investment banking syndicate headed by Allen Co., John Nuveen Co., Inc., B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., A.C. Allyn Co., Inc. and The Kentucky Company.

STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 2 -- Delegates to a twelve-nation European conference on space exploration decided tonight to give themselves two months to decide whether to participate in a $200,000,000 satellite-launching program.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The Soviet Union today called on President Kennedy and his deputy in the United Nations, Adlai E. Stevenson, to make a "critical reappraisal" of United States policy in Africa.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain scored 45 points, tonight to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to a 133-118 victory over the Cincinnati Royals before 6,684 fans at Convention Hall in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 --A liberalized social welfare program, ranging from food stamps for the unemployed to improved Social Security benefits for the retired, was proposed by President Kennedy today.
About sixty speakers urged the City Council yesterday to approve bills Sponsored by the Wagner administration to tighten the city's Fair Housing Practices Law.
Thirty angry women pushed their way into two Brooklyn community centers yesterday, imported sleeping bags and food, and announced they would stay all night.

Nothing commonplace has happened in the case of the Portuguese liner Santa Maria since she was taken over on Sunday morning, Jan. 22, by Henrique Galvao, a Portuguese revolutionist. The passengers who embarked on what they thought was a pleasure cruise have not had much fun during the past twelve days, but they will have something to talk about all the rest of their lives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Though movie companies remain in hot competition for film rights to best sellers and hit shows, Jules Verne continues to hold his own as a Hollywood favorite in the space age.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Defense Department maintained strict secrecy today on how the experimental Samos reconnaissance satellite, launched Tuesday at Point Arguelle, Calif., was operating in space.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Exports of civilian merchandise increased by 20 per cent last year to $19,568,000,000, the Bureau of the Census said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Kennedy recieved today about sixty leaders of the Baptist World Alliance going into field service.

A pronounced pick-up in the demand for world-wide oil transport was reported yesterday, along with the substantial scrapping of uneconomic tanker tonnage. This has resulted in a considerable thinning of the ranks of laid-up tankers, according to Addison Outwater Associates, steamship brokers.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Bill Mazeroski, the second basemen and little ElRoy Face, the relief pitcher, two heroes in the 1960 world series victory over the New York Yankees, signed with the Pittsburgh Pirates today. Both received substantial increases in salary.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2 -- The Amateur Rules Committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association today recommended that the suspension of Charles (Chuck) McKinley be continued to May 1.

An error by a new electronic scoring machine and some manmade mistakes that went undetected by the machine have caused confusion and concern over the results of the College Entrance Examination Board tests given last December.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (UPI) -- T.V. Lark made a smashing comeback today in his fifth start of the Santa Anita meeting by capturing the $27,450 Santa Catalina Handicap. Eddie Arcaro rode him.
Bob Fishel, publicity director for the Yankees, intimated in New York last night that the ball club would continue to stay at the Soreno Hotel in St. Petersburg, Fla., this year.
The college professor who directed a revolution in the teaching of high school physics called yesterday for the expenditure of $100,000,000 a year to improve teaching materials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania offered a bill today for the Federal Government to enter into a compact with four states to develop the Delaware River.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The investment of the Commodity Credit Corporation in price-support programs amounted to $9,228,604,000 as of Dec. 31, 1960. This is slightly higher than the total of $9,153,943,000 in the year before.
The Federal Trade Commission has accused E.J. Korvette, Inc., discount department store chain, of a misleading practice in offering apparel with well-known, resort-area labels.

BONALDO GIAIOTTI assumed the role of the Commendatore for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera in last night's performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni." Martin Rich conducted the work for the first time this season, and Ezio Flagello made a season's first appearance as Leporello. Cesare Siepi was in the title role, and the cast further included Eleanor Steber, Lisa Della Casa and Nicolai Gedda, among others.
HAVANA, Friday, Feb. 3 -- Premier Fidel Castro's Government put into effect early today decrees carrying out a broad purge of Cuba's judiciary system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, introduced legislation today to extend the present Sugar Act unchanged for twenty-one months, until Dec. 31, 1962.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Government charged today that Austin J. Tobin had instigated a decision by the Port of New York Authority to withhold subpoenaed documents from House scrutiny.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Justice disclosed today in Washington that it was investigating the fight between Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., and Chance Vought Corporation for control of Chance Vought.

The autobiography of Thubten Jigme Norbu, Tibetan monk, who is the elder brother of the Dalai Lama, will be published Feb. 20 by Dutton, and will be titled "Tibet Is My Country." As a child, Norbu was recognized as the reincarnation of a high Buddhist dignitary and entered the famous monastery of Kumbum, of which be became abbot.
Two of the most fundamental building blocks of all matter appear to be almost perfect mirror images of each other, scientists reported yesterday to the American Physical Society.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller was given a formula today for extending unemployment insurance protection in time of recession.
A power failure that struck the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street yesterday knocked elevator service out for three hours and affected many lights in the building's corridors and offices.
Students at Columbia University's School of General Studies who read for pleasure will be given a chance next week to turn what they have learned into free credits toward a bachelor's degree.
A master locksmith, the fifth suspect in the theft of $30,000 worth of jewelry from the hotel suite of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lawford, was taken into custody Sunday, the police said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that Representative James B. Utt, a Southern California Republican, had more constituents than any other Representative.

PANAMA, Feb. 2 -- An investigation has begun here to determine whether Panama's mails had been used to defraud depositors of the American and Foreign Bank of Tangier, which pulled up stakes in Morocco last June.

Experts on the laws of the sea agreed yesterday that there was hardly a question piracy involved in the seizure of the Portuguese cruise ship Santa Maria by a band of political foes of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar of Portugal.

MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored five second-period goals tonight and went on to defeat the New York Rangers, 7 -- 5. The victory enabled the Canadiens to remain in a tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs for the National Hockey League lead.
Dame Flora MacLeod of MacLeod, "clan mother" of MacLeods, McLeods, Macleods, McLouds and even Machelejds all over the world, will celebrate her eighty-third birthday today in New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- New Jersey Democratic leaders, here for the day, scheduled a meeting for tomorrow night at Morven, the executive mansion at Princeton, to try again to select a candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- It has been a little difficult sorting out all the new men on President Kennedy's New Frontier, but the other day, sitting around with a particularly well informed circle, or big wheel, this corner came up with the real low-down on the men high up in the new State Department.
Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs said last night the city needed "an entire change of administration from top to bottom" in the fall election "if we want to save the city really from financial collapse."
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The "gold crisis" reached a major turning point today as the price of gold in London fell below $35.35 an ounce for the first time since the "gold rush" last October.
A director of the York New Central Railroad, Dr. R. Walter Graham Jr., has thrown his lot in with the Murchison interests in their proxy fight to win control of the Alleghany Corporation.
MIAMI, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Herbert Hinojosa continued his riding streak with three victories at Hialeah today and tied John Sellers for the lead in the jockey standings. Each has twenty victories here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's message to Congress today on economic recovery and growth.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The State Attorney General accused the United States Department of. Defense today of having aided discrimination in the housing of Negro missile personnel.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 2 -- A mass meeting of alumni and friends of St. Peter's High School will be held tomorrow, night at the Recreation Hall. The meeting has been called to discuss a decision this week of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association that placed St. Peter's on probation for the rest of the school year.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A late flurry of selling cancelled out relatively small gains in old crop soybean futures prices today, but most grains maintained moderate advances to the finish.
SIX attractive young men and women, appearing as the Riverside Chamber Singers, sang a stimulating program of a cappella music in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
The United States Time Corporation is taking its $3,500,000 a year in billings away from W.B. Doner Co.
PIQUA, Ohio, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Inland Homes Corporation, a producer of prefabricated houses, has announced, an across-the-board cut in prices of its house packages.
LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 2 -- The controversial sale of the Marshall Field estate to the Long Island State Park Commission is scheduled for tomorrow.

VILSECK, Germany, Feb. 2 -- United States, French and West German troops sloshed through snow in bitter cold today on the first full day of Winter Shield II, the Seventh Army's annual training exercise. The terrain is a hilly section of Northern Bavaria.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 2 -- The Camden City Commission today voted to oppose a Delaware River Port Authority proposal to develop a high-speed rail line through the city on an existing railroad right-of-way.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold its coal-mining operations to John B. Rich of Pottsville, Pa., owner of the Gilberton Coal Company. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed but it reportedly would make about $9,000,000 of additional working capital available to Philadelphia and Reading for expansion and diversification projects.
A major reorganization of the Columbia Broadcasting System news division, which had been expected in the trade for at least two months, is now officially under way.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Kennedy submitted to Congress today a wide-ranging economic program.
The Liberal party recorded its opposition yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's "scholar incentive proposal for aiding private colleges and universities.
