MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The favorites, Deane Beman of Bethesda, Md., and Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone of Mason City, Iowa, were upset in the third round of the national mixed foursome amateur golf championship today by Willie Turnesa, White Plains, N.Y., and Mrs. John Fitton, Hamilton, Ohio.

Mayor Wagner asked Governor Rockefeller yesterday to help him obtain authority from the Legislature to appoint a nine-member Charter revision commission of "distinguished and able" residents of the city.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of a proclamation issued by Henrique M. Galvao, Portuguese rebel commander of the liner Santa Maria, as published today by the newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo:

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 2 (AP) -- The United States' newest nuclear powered submarine, the Sam Houston, slipped down the ways today. She is the Navy's seventh underwater craft capable of firing the Polaris ballistic missile.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Senators seeking to attract tourists and their money to this country blamed Government red tape and rude officials today for having kept foreigners away.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 2 -- Harvard defeated Amherst, 64 -- 62, tonight. With fifteen seconds to go, the Lord Jeffs missed a scoring opportunity, and the Crimson's narrow lead was preserved.
For a few hours last night it was spring -- at least to guests at the White Elephant Party at the Pierre, where the colorful decor belied the icy blasts of winter.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Prices on the stock market moved irregularly again here today, although increased and selective demand gave the principal lists a more cheerful appearance than yesterday's.

JAN BARES, "a reliably unsuccessful" writer until he sold two film scripts for astronomical prices to Hollywood, celebrated his forty-sixth birthday on Nov. 12, 1957. A party was held in Jan's apartment on Riverside Drive and was organized by a group of Jan's best friends, including his former mistress, Milada, who still loved him devotedly.

RECIFE, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- American passengers reported today that conditions were "not too bad" aboard the Santa Maria, although the air conditioning had broken down and made the ship very uncomfortable.
A broad revision of the state's penal law and its code of criminal procedure was urged yesterday by Judge Abraham N. Geller, senior judge of the Court of General Sessions of New York County.
Your article on New Zealand's welfare state was of more than usual interest to a visitor to New York City whose adopted home is in New Zealand.
A plan for more frequent Civil Service examinations for police applicants designed to improve the caliber of the uniformed force was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

What was the stock of the month in January? Book of the Month Club, Inc., is the answer straight from the computing machine at Hemphill, Noyes Co., brokerage house. That stock rose in price by 48 per cent from the start of the month to the close.

Spurred by a strong rise in New York City, check transactions in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation in the week ended last Wednesday exceeded those of the prior week and of the comparable 1960 week Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation reported today record sales, but a decline in net income, in the three months ended on Dec. 31, 1960, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate Aeronautical and Space Sciences Committee unanimously and enthusiastically approved today the selection of James W. Webb to be the new head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

Once upon a time there was a press agent who had an idea. He would hire sandwich men to walk around carrying signs that said only "Make Coney Island the 51st State!" He thought if he did that he would get publicity for his unnamed client and product that tied in with Coney Island.

CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 2 -- President Sekou Toure said today Guinea was willing to accept as much technical aid from Western nations as from the Eastern bloc provided his country's sovereignty was fully respected by the donor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- About 5,060,000 veterans, most of whom served in World War II, will share in the early payment this year of $258,500,000 in dividends on veterans' life insurance policies, the Veterans Administration said today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 2 -- The Venezuelan Congress approved today a Presidential decree suspending constitutional guarantees.
A program to improve the position of the commuter railroads in the New York metropolitan area this year was announced yesterday by the New York-New Jersey Transportation Agency.

A loan-shark operation reputed to involve $1,000,000 a year is under investigation in Queens, District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday. The operation is the work of "a highly organized small group," he said.
The estate of Alfred N. Steele, former head of the Pepsi-Cola Company, is unable to meet its bills, it was reported yesterday.
Carmine G. De Sapio assured two Democratic groups yesterday that he had no intention of giving up his post as the New York County Democratic leader despite Tuesday's setback.
The National Maritime Union served notice on ship operators yesterday that it would demand a thirty-hour basic work week for its seagoing members in contract negotiations this spring.

RICH mildly flavored smelts are sometimes called the king of small fish. They are especially deserving of that accolade when they are split, dipped in flour and sauteed in butter. As small-sized smelts are one of the reasonably priced fish now, at about 39 cents a pound, they might be prepared in that way.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The Chicago Heathers, skipped by Mrs. John Morrissy, won the seventh annual women's Empire State bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club curling rink today.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The Government hinted today that it might support an official inquiry into the situation arising in the newspaper industry as a result of a projected merger.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The secretary general-designate of the new Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development expressed opposition today to a possible merger of the two European trade blocs, the six-nation Common Market and the seven-nation European Free Trade Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Republican Congressional leaders struck out in two directions today in response to the economic proposals of the Kennedy Administration.

HONG KONG, Feb. 2 -- Marshal Chen Yi, Foreign Minister of Communist China, said in Peiping today that the Chinese Communist Government would provide aid if it were requested by the "lawful Laotian Government of Prince Souvanna Phouma."
Cardinal Spellman hailed Governor Rockefeller's plan for state aid to education last night.
ATLANTA, Feb. 2 -- A group of Protestant Episcopal clergymen and laymen in Georgia has lent its support to charges of heresy against the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Government is undertaking new measures to cope with a special financial dilemma that has been posed by the existence of a recession and balance-of-payments troubles at the same time.

The Black Hills Power Light Company announced yesterday a rise in the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from the 37 cents a share distributed in previous quarters. The declaration will be paid on March 1 to holders of record of Feb. 20.

A music publishing executive and a physician, both of whom are not unknown to the world of entertainment, have joined forces to produce a new musical on Broadway next October fashioned entirely by a comparative unknown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A breakdown of political expenditures by Wisconsin labor unions in the 1969 contest for Governor of that state is pertinent to the basic issue in a Georgia railway labor case which was recently argued before the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- President Kennedy and former President Dwight D. Eisenhower have agreed to serve as honorary co-chairman of the Dr. Tom Dooley Tribute Fund for Medico.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 2 -- Australia is in the throes of a debate on economic policy.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- A blueprint for a healthy America was outlined here tonight by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
Union members will vote today on a proposed settlement of the strike of wholesale deliverymen that has disrupted newspaper circulation in the metropolitan area.

The nation will face a "constitutional crisis of first magnitude" if the "nineteenth century men" in the Senate succeed in blocking the efforts of the twentieth century lawmakers there, Senator Joseph S. Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said last night.

THE program offered last night on "C.B.S. Reports" was one of the most hotly controversial in its distinguished series. The presentation delved forthrightly and unhesitatingly into the broad and growing dispute over medical-care plans.
RECIFE, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Debarking passengers told today of rioting, fears and bloodshed aboard the Santa Maria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway obtained today the irrevocable support of holders of more than 50 per cent of the 3,100,000 voting preferred and common shares of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to its plans for (1) immediate unification of the two systems and (2) consummation of a merger as soon as practicable.

After discouraging premature visits by foreign statesmen naturally eager to ascertain his views and policies, President Kennedy has now issued his first invitation to a top-level meeting with the governing head of a major power that is to be more than just a courtesy call. Fittingly this invitation has been extended to the head of a stanchest ally linked to us with special bonds of history, culture and language -- Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Jack Cotton, one of Britain's biggest real estate operators, said today that his City Centre Properties had made a 66,000,000 ($184,800,000) bid for the City of London Real Property Company.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 2 -- A United States consul who is to look after American citizens in the troubled northeastern area of the Congo was barred from a United Nations flight to Stanleyville today.
Stockholders of the H.J. Heinz Company, food processor, approved yesterday a three-for- one stock split and the issuance of 200,000 additional shares.

The temperature was one degree above zero at 2 A.M. yesterday, but inside Basin Street East it was sizzling. The scheduled entertainment, provided by Peggy Lee, the singer, can heat up the room more than adequately, but early yesterday morning she had the impromptu assistance of Jimmy Durante and a couple of his friends.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday totaled 197,830,000 board feet, compared with 200,029,000 board feet the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 247,956,000 board feet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Following are the highlights of proposals in President Kennedy's economic message to Congress today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A bill to permit the sale of the General Aniline and Film Corporation to private enterprise before settlement of litigation concerning the firm was introduced in Congress today by Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York.
MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press) -- A Trans-Canada Air Lines executive said today a third pilot was unnecessary aboard the company's new Vanguards.

The International Cooperation Administration has modified its order halting the payment by the Federal Government of ocean freight costs on foreign aid cargoes shipped on non-American vessels, Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, reported yesterday.
YASSIADA ISLAND Turkey, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Former Premier Adrian Menderes was convicted today of Misusing up to 13,000,000 liras ($4,100,000) in public funds during his ten years in office.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- A move to repeal the 1960 law giving private and parochial school pupils free transportation was begun in the Legislature today.

President Kennedy's "Program for Economic Recovery and Growth," outlined yesterday in the first of his detailed messages to Congress, reflects at once his activist philosophy and his cautious approach. The President is not content to say, "something ought to be done"; he does something. But, if one can judge by his initial steps to combat the present quasi-recession, he intends to refrain if possible from drastic moves.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Jack Cotton, one of Britain's biggest real estate operators, said today that his City Centre Properties had made a 66,000,000 ($184,800,000) bid for the City of London Real Property Company.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 2 -- A United States consul who is to look after American citizens in the troubled northeastern area of the Congo was barred from a United Nations flight to Stanleyville today.

It is a pleasure to salute the United Service Organizations of New York on its twentieth birthday today. The U.S.O. was formed in 1941 in the turbulent and critical pre-Pearl Harbor days of World War II to provide a single coordinated agency for the expression of civilian concern for the welfare of military personnel during their off-duty hours.

The United Service Organizations here held a reception yesterday on the eve of its twentieth anniversary. Representatives of the military forces joined leaders of the U.S.O.'s six member agencies at the party.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Kennedy received a first-hand report today on the situation in Laos from Ambassador Winthrop G. Brown.

Women who have been out of the working world and would like to return to it are the concern of a course that begins Thursday, Feb. 9. The Ballard School of the Central Branch Young Women's Christian Association will hold Thursday, morning discussions through March 30, designed to help mature women find their place in the working world.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 3 -- "For the first time since we got married, my wife wants to see my pay slip," the Congolese post-office clerk confided.

HAVANA, Feb. 3 -- A radio station of 120 kilowatts, which would make it the most powerful in Latin America, is being completed in Cayo la Rosa, a few miles outside of Havana. The Government hopes to put the station into operation by Feb. 15 to broadcast propaganda of the Cuban revolution.
A letter from Boris Pasternak that seems to refute the basis of the criminal charges brought by Soviet authorities against his friend and companion, Mme. Olga V. Ivinskaya, has just come to light.

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 3 -- Brazilian marines carried the luggage, Brazilian admirals beamed with delight and newsmen and United States Navy men mobbed the dock as Henrique M. Galvao and his band of rebels stepped onto land here tonight.
A former official of the Port of New York Authority was indicted here yesterday on charges of bribery and taking unlawful fees.
Two salt companies that had been accused of rigging their prices to the city have sold the city $471,150 worth of rock salt in the last week to aid in snow removal.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 -- The youngest of the Kennedy brothers, Edward M. (Ted) Kennedy, is expected to launch his own political career Monday as an assistant district attorney here.
Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews will put emphasis this month on efforts to alleviate racial tension.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- An exhibition providing a graphic warning that all is not old that glitters with antiquity is being held at the British Museum. The museum is showing some of the world's famous forgeries and copies in art and artifacts.
MAHWAH, N.J., Feb. 3 -- An increase of about 10 per cent in commuter fares on the Short Line System, which operates from New York City to Middletown and Newburg, N.Y., goes into effect tomorrow.

The New Haven Railroad, which has received much advice on how to steer through its financial difficulties, is sticking to the route that was plotted a year ago by its own president -- a series of 10 per cent fare increases.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 3 -- Ca Va II won the thirty-mile Nassau Cup yacht race today but Paper Tiger clinched the championship of the 1961 Southern Ocean Racing Conference. Both yachts were designed in Florida.

WITH Valentine's Day around the corner, lovers from 6 to 60 are, or soon will be, in search of an appropriate expression of their sentiment. Those with a very special card in mind might take a look at the rare collection at The Golden Cockerel, 104 Christopher Street.

ROME, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Students and the police battled in front of the Austrian Embassy today while Deputies came close to fisticuffs during a parliamentary debate on the bitter Italian-Austrian dispute over South Tyrol.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The announcement that Borg-Warner Corporation is going to transfer its Norge Division, manufacturer of refrigerators and freezers, to Fort Smith, Ark., early this summer has struck this town like a disaster.
A 2-year-old girl died yesterday in a fire in a five-room apartment in the Fort Hamilton section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Kennedy Administration is convinced that a new "federalized" government in the Congo, embracing the leaders of all the factions, offers the only hope of preventing that nation from sliding from chaos into civil war.
Cotton futures prices rose 7 to 20 points (35 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.
The discovery of some unusual properties of materials classed as semimetals appears to have opened up a whole new area in the field of electronics, according to a report made here yesterday.
Factions in the New Rochelle school desegragation dispute were invited yesterday to step outside to some neutral spot for a fresh look at the problem.
Driving on the Throgs Neck-Clearview Expressway arterial system calls for a spirit of adventure, or split-second timing, in following directional signs.
Caumsett, the 1,426-acre Marshall Field estate at Lloyds Neck on the North Shore of Long Island, became a Long Island State Park yesterday.

IT will come as no surprise to most parents that scientific research shows that children talk almost incessantly. And it may be little comfort that learned men say the childish chatter is essential to learning English.

Net income of the Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd., declined last year to $13,253,000, or $2.30 a share, from $17,606,000, or $3.05 a share, in 1959, the Canadian steel producer has reported. Net sales declined to $140,876,000 from $162,696,000 a year earlier.

Depressed coffee prices resulting from continued heavy output has caused producing countries to show greater interest in an international agreement designed to regulate the flow of the product and stabilize prices.

The peace that normally prevails over week-ends on Hudson River docks will be broken at Pier 97 today. The West Fifty-seventh Street base for the passenger ship operations of Home Lines will be stirring with unusual Saturday activity.
DARIEN, Conn. -- Darien's four Protestant churches will use various art forms to interpret the Lenten theme this year.
Floyd Patterson saw his little brother take care of another guy last night with no help from him. Well, not much, anyway.
The words were misspelled but it was hard to question the sincerity of the scrawled note placed beside the shivering black and white pointer and her four newborn puppies.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The price of gold on the free bullion exchange fell again today, reaching the lowest price since speculation against the United States dollar touched off a boom in the metal last October.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The states were told today how they will share the $724,000,000 in Federal highway aid that was released ahead of schedule by President Kennedy to stimulate the economy.
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union overwhelmingly approved a strike settlement last night and returned to work.
Another heavy snow storm struck the city and much of the eastern half of the nation yesterday.
The thirty-eight member nations of GATT, officially known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are giving themselves more time before setting a date for their next conference.

Milwaukee County, Wis., borrowed $10,328,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewerage and expressway improvements. The securities were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company and the First National City Bank of New York.
The Oppenheimer Fund, Inc., reported yesterday gains in net assets and share values for 1960.

More than $2,000,000 in United States Savings Bonds were stolen by a large ring in this country last year, and $250,000 worth of these were cashed in the New York area, United States Attorney Morton S. Robson said yesterday.

Representative John V. Lindsay of Manhattan is right in stating that the New York Young Republican Club has done "a grave disservice to the cause of a revitalized and effective Republican party" by repudiating his vote in the House to break the power of the ultra-conservative coalition that dominated the Rules Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of California, formally replied today to charges of heresy and communism that have been made against him recently.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Col. Harry A. Toulmin Jr. of Dayton, Ohio, has invented a flying truck. It is designed to lift its weight from the ground, retract its wheels, and guide itself along a single rail.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- The following ski conditions were reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:

The United States Time Corporation awarded its advertising account yesterday to Warwick Legler, Inc., Robert E. Mohr, vice president and director of sales for United States Time, said that billings would aggregate $3,500,000.

Two buildings containing thirty-two apartments at 319-21 East Seventy-eighth Street have been purchased by Tilton Estates, Inc., from the KNS Realty Corporation, which had owned them since 1940. The structures occupy a plot 50 by 102 feet.
The Dingo family at the Bronx Zoo was receiving congratulations yesterday.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 3 (AP) Hans Peter Lanig, Germany's great skier who now manages a restaurant on the slopes here, whizzed into the halfway lead today at the Broadmoor international slalom derby.

NO American show this season is likely to eclipse in all-round importance the retrospective of Edwin Dickinson's paintings and drawings at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue. Any brief notice such as this can only call attention to it rather than attempt to examine fully the remarkable richness of his art and the great variety of his habits of mind.

A threatened stoppage of Long Island Rail Road passenger service over the week-end was averted last night after a two-hour meeting between officials of the railroad and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 3 (AP -- Two Russian military observers were not invited today as some of the nation's top rocketeers toured one of the country's missile reserach and production centers.

The future strength of the aircraft industry may depend on working agreements among manufacturers if not outright mergers, Donald W. Douglas, Jr., president of Douglas Aircraft Company, said yesterday.

MADRID, Feb. 3 -- Portugal appears to have ridden out the storm raised by Henrique M. Galvao's rebel band. However, cautious observers of Portuguese affairs suspect that the ship of state may have sprung some leaks.

A new edition of John Locke Scripps' "Life of Abraham Lincoln" will be published by Indiana University Press on March 4, the centennial of Lincoln's inauguration. It is considered the most authoritative and influential of the eighteen campaign biographies of Lincoln that appeared in 1860.

SHREVEPORT, La., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Ten business men promised in Federal District Court here today to end what the Justice Department called "economic coercion" against a Negro farmer who tried to vote in East Carroll Parish.
Jacques Piccard, 38-year-old deep-sea explorer, has come to New York to seek $500,000 for building a marine "helicopter" that would hover in the sea depths for scientific observation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Kennedy's forthcoming balance-of-payments message is expected to propose means for paying higher interest rates on foreign-owned dollars than on American funds.
The thirty-nine sit-ins and sleep-ins who spent Thursday night in two Brooklyn community centers in protest against the city Housing Authority got some fresh air yesterday evening.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The so-called power blocs of our era have become complex and extensive. They include on both sides of the ideological fence nations whose political philosophies are strikingly at odds plus co-belligerents from the uncommitted camp.
A QUESTION of an opening lead arose in this deal. The leader's choice was a card that does not conform to the "hook lead" recommended by Charles Goren and other authorities.

A piano recital was played in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Mary-Louise Brown, whose program included two sonatas by Scarlatti, Rameau's Gavotte Varie, Chopin's Sonata in B minor, the Rhapsody in G minor, two Intermezzi by Brahms and Dello Jolo's Sonata No. 3.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ended two and a half days days of hearings today on the charter plane crash Oct. 29 at Toledo, Ohio, that killed twenty-two persons, including sixteen members of the California Polytechnic football team.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 (AP) -- William Hyndman, Philadelphia and Barbara Williams of Richmond, Calif., will meet Willie Turnesa of White Plains, N.Y., and Mrs. John Fitton of Hamilton, Ohio, tomorrow for the National mixed foursome amateur golf championship.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 3 -- Only three states -- South Carolina, Mississippi and Alabama -- still have total racial segregation in their tax-supported schools, Southern School News reported today.
STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Britain raised its financial offer today to get a reluctant Europe to compete in the space race.
The last passenger trains of the Lehigh Valley Railroad left last night on their final runs, marking the end of 115 years of passenger service for the road.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower put in his first working day today at his office on the campus of Gettysburg College.

Forty-three offerings of syndicated real estate securities amounting to about $150,000,000 have been filed since Jan. 1, the effective date of a new state law requiring syndicators to submit prospectuses of their projects, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.
Reflecting the continuance of the unusually cold weather throughout much of the nation, prices of potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose again yesterday in heavy trading.
Nicanor Zabaleta is a harpist who won't admit that the harp repertory is limited.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The formation of a twenty-second county in New Jersey was proposed today as a solution to the redevelopment of much of that state's 30,000 acres of meadowland.
DETROIT, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The automobile industry prepared today to put into effect one-week lay-offs of nearly 80,000 men under slicing of production rates to balance them with unsold 1961 cars.

The Denver Truckers scored their sixth straight victory last night when they defeated the New York Tuck Tapers, 103 -- 101. The National Industrial Basketball League game was played at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 3 (AP) -- An official of the Pennsylvania Railroad said today that excessive speed apparently caused a train derailment that killed six persons and injured more than 100 near here yesterday.
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for the resignation of Carmine G. De Sapio as chairman of the New York County Democratic committee.
Another light week is forecast in the public market for new capital. Some $73,500,000 of fixed-interest issues of major size are to be brought to market.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- Highly placed West German sources said today that consideration was being given to the idea of transforming the meeting of the Atlantic Alliance Council in Oslo into a conference of Western heads of government, including President Kennedy.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Columbia Pictures Corporation of the United States and British Lion Films announced today the formation of a jointly owned company that will be responsible for selling their films in Britain and Ireland.
Thousands of motorists were convinced yesterday that winters are not what they used to be -- they are worse.

Laurence S. Helffrich, the chairman of the tournament committee, has a searching problem on his hands for the national indoor tennis championship starting next Thursday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Conditions for the America's Cup match between an American defender and an Australian yacht were agreed upon yesterday at a meeting in the New York Yacht Club. Present were representatives of the New York club, which holds the world's foremost sailing trophy, and the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron.

MOUNT VERNON, Feb. 3 -- Rabbi Leon A. Jick announced today that 400 members of the Free Synagogue of Westchester had signed a resolution to be sent to President Kennedy, promising the support of their prayers in efforts for peace.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa was reported to have told a policemen's organization dinner the other night that if he were Mayor he would have fired Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy long ago. He also reportedly criticized the rigorous handing out of traffic tickets under Mr. Kennedy's direction. Mr. Gerosa's remarks make us particularly happy that he is not the Mayor.

A man who had not even been reported missing a year after he apparently had killed himself was identified yesterday by the state police as Edward Currie, 52 years old, of 411 East 141st Street, the Bronx.

With the release of "The Secret Ways" slated and with two other projects already on the agenda of Heath Productions, Richard Widmark's independent unit, negotiations are under way for two additional projects.
Four foreign players withdrew yesterday from the national indoor tennis championship starting next Thursday at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The finals are scheduled Monday, Feb. 13.

Entrenched as the nation's second-ranking college basketball team after Thursday night's victory over Bradley, St. Bonaventure yesterday accepted an invitation to the National Collegiate championship tournament.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Profit taking for the week-end stalled an early broad advance in Soybean futures today, but prices rallied near the close and finished with moderate gains. The grains generally were firm.
Four Manhattan College seniors combined last night to produce the only world indoor record of the fifty-fourth annual Millrose Games.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 3 -- The number of undetected brain injuries in children is "far greater than has ever been realized in the past," more than 300 doctors, educators and social workers were told here today.
PARAMUS, N.J., Feb. 3 -- An application for a temporary injunction against the Paramus Sunday Closing Law was denied today by Superior Court Judge John Grimshaw Jr.

USUMBURA, Ruanda-Urundi, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- The Belgian Resident General here, Jean-Paul Harroy accused the United Nations and Belgium's Atlantic Alliance partners today of responsibility for the crisis in this United Nations trust territory.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- This city received a $16,432 check from the Federal Government today to begin planning its first urban renewal project.
A PENNSYLVANIA neighborhood has what seems to be a happy prescription for what to do when snowbound.
The State Lottery Control Commission is moving to stop the development of "bingo palaces" whose operations and profits are so large they threaten "to introduce commercialism into the game."

LINDENHURST, L.I., Feb. 3 -- A 37-year-old welding contractor who accidentally set fire to a house while he was thawing frozen water pipes suffered a fatal heart attack today as he tried to put it out.

In a long-awaited declaration of independence from the Tammany leader Mayor Wagner yesterday demanded that Carmine G. De Sapio step aside as chairman of the Democratic organization in New York County. Mr. De Sapio had said no in a speech the night before; he said it again yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A foreign-aid program spokesman announced today new restrictions on United States payment of shipping costs for foreign-aid supplies transported in foreign-flag vessels.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics used their beach strength tonight in wearing down the New York Knickerbockers for a 123-109 victory. Paced by Sam Jones, Gene Conley and Frank Ramsey, the Celtics drew away in the final period.
HONG KONG, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Hong Kong textile industry is in a dilemma. Industrial authorities describe the situation as a "headache that no industrial aspirin available can cure."

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 3 -- American Jews were urged here today to intensify their financial support to meet the needs of 255,000 distressed Jewish men, women and children in twenty-five nations apart from Israel.

The two United States fliers who were released last week after seven months' imprisonment in Moscow are the only known survivors of at least fourteen attacks on United States planes by Soviet aircraft in the last decade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Kennedy ordered today a nine-point, $4,000,000 program of Federal assistance for Cuban refugees in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Naval officers apparently have smuggled up to 12,000 cases of liquor into the United States from the Guantanamo Bay Navy base in Cuba, the Customs Bureau disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) --The Federal Reserve Board said today installment debts increased by only $76,000,000 in December -- the smallest rise since October, 1958. The figure represents the difference between new credit extended and repayments during the month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy wants to share with the country "some startling things she has learned historically about the White House."

Schoolboy track's smart set -- that legion of loyal followers who will travel anywhere with their binoculars, stop watches and leather lungs to watch the lads in shorts perform -- have a choice of action on two fronts today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- The new United States representative, Adlai E. Stevenson, is holding quiet consultations with several delegates here over policy in the Congo.

Mayor Wagner has charged that "notorious" situations have existed in four state agencies, in pressing a recent statement that some departments were "happy hunting grounds for the chiseler." The Mayor has also asked Governor Rockefeller questions about four other state agencies and a state inquiry.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 3 -- The Middlebury ski team took the lead as the fifty-first Dartmouth Winter Carnival opened in sub-zero weather today. Describe by the college as "the oldest, coldest and biggest college week-end in America," the extensive program lived up to advance billings.
MIAMI, Feb. 3 -- The pari-mutuel handle and attendance have declined at the current Hialeah race meeting, but they should get a lift from tomorrow's McLennan Handicap.
Although Paul Zukofsky is only 17 years old, the violin recital he gave in Carnegie Hall last night was his third in that august auditorium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission (I.C.C.) today to approve previously announced plans to acquire control of the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Food processing could emerge within a decade as India's major industry if quantities of products now wasted were utilized, in the opinion of a United States ex pert who has just completed a one-year technical assistance mission there.

A photographic record of the Civil War and some of its figures by Matthew Brady and others will be on exhibition, beginning Monday, at the I.B.M. Gallery of Arts and Sciences, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Board of Trustees of the University of Rochester voted today to continue the university as a private institution.
CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 3 (AP) -- A $12,000,000 development, including a motel, office building and apartments, has been proposed for a site fronting on Benjamin Franklin Bridge Plaza, here.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 3 -- A West German mission ended a three-day official visit here today with the announcement of a multimillion-dollar aid package to Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- William Lucius Cary, Professor of Law at Columbia University, was named today by President Kennedy to be chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, gave a talk before the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce Wednesday entitled "The Unprofitable Puzzlement."

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- C.V. Whitney's domination of filly and mare races at Santa Anita Park will be at issue tomorrow when the track stages the $50,000-added Santa Margarita Handicap. The race is at a mile and an eighth.
The New York Athletic Club's basketball team posted its twelfth triumph of the season by defeating Wesleyan University, 90 -- 80, at the Winged Foot gymnasium last night.
For the next ten years at least, the New York Football Giants will continue to play their National Football League home games at Yankee Stadium.

PARIS, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- The International Air Transport Association conference on tariffs, in session here since Jan. 23, is trying to reach agreement on trans-Atlantic freight-rate reductions of at least 20 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Virginia will dedicate tomorrow as a part of the Civil War centennial celebration a plaque commemorating a futile effort to avert the clash between the North and the South 100 years ago.
OTTAWA, Feb. 3 (Canadian Press) -- A merger is planned by the Canadian Bank of Commerce and the Imperial Bank of Canada. It would form Canada's second largest bank.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- Jorge Zayas, refugee Cuban Publisher, whose newspaper, the Havana avance, was confiscated a year ago, said today he believed Premier Fidel Castro would try to take over the United States naval base at Guantanamo when resistance to the regime made the move politically expedient.

In the several days that have passed since Federal District Judge Irving R. MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Industry and education will benefit from one of the largest earth-moving projects ever to be undertaken in New Jersey.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Road House, owned by Roger Wilson and Earl Allen, of Texas, spurted past the favored Grand Wizard in the stretch today and scored a narrow victory in the $12,450 Louisiana Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- President Kennedy's words and deeds during his first two weeks in office have evoked widespread approval both among the United States' allies and in the capitals of neutral nations.
TUNIS, Feb. 4 -- President de Gaulle of France has invited President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to visit him in Paris. Mr. Bourguiba revealed the news of the invitation in an interview here.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- Thirteen unionists have been arrested in the dispute, most of which is centered on El Centro, 200 miles southwest of Los Angeles and twelve miles from the Mexican border.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Assemblyman Bessie A. Buchanan, who has long been vexed by the fact that the state has an official flower and an official tree but no official song, this week won the first round in her campaign to correct the cultural oversight.

THE appearance of this five-volume study on the implications of housing discrimination in American cities could not have been more timely. Civic groups are pressing President Kennedy to issue his promised Executive Order banning discrimination in all Federally assisted housing, private and public.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Prof. John Cobb Cooper, legal adviser to the International Air Transport Association, says that "chaos and conflict" will be inevitable in outer space unless every object thrust into outer space is given "nationality."
The Democratic leaders of Kings, Queens, Richmond and Bronx Counties refrained yesterday from taking sides openly in Mayor Wagner's drive to oust Carmine G. De Sapio.
To Judge by his recital in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, Denver Oldham is a pianist with a provocative talent.

In reaction to the thought-provoking "Hope for the Traveler," by Paul J.C. Friedlander, on Jan. 15, I wonder if agency delays are due less to "legal procedures" and more to the inexperience and inability of the personnel involved to conduct adversary-type hearings.

TODAY'S modern seagoing ferry is a sleek smaller edition of an ocean liner, capable of carrying passengers and assorted vehicles across straits, channels and inland seas at a rapid clip and in nigh style.

MY fourth-grade teacher, a handsome Irishwoman named Miss Palmer, frequently advised her pupils to keep an eye on the English. They had kept the Civil War going, she said, by siding with the Southern aristocracy, a class she found indistinguishable from the Protestant ascendancy in Ireland; they had inveigled the United States into saving them in the First World War, and "they'll try and conquer us yet."

WE are apt to feel submerged by the cascade of writing about World War II, by the torrent of documents, of histories -- official and unofficial -- of memoirs and diaries, monographs, reviews and interpretations.

THE sad news is that "Hark Hark, The Lark!" is to be the last of a trilogy of the Larkin family. Readers who know H.E. Bates and his previous "The Darling Buds of May" and "A Breath of French Air" will surely rise in protest.

The final plan of the Army Corps of Engineers for the development of the Delaware River's water and land resources is to be submitted to Congress late this year, Brig. Gen. Thomas H. Lipscomb said yesterday.
The Westminster Kennel Club show will have sixty-five dogs that won breed ribbons last year trying for equal or better honors again. The event will be in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 13 and 14.

ROME, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -- Policemen and demonstrators were hurt today in clashes in Rome and Naples in renewed Right-Wing student protests over Austrian demands that the German-speaking people of Italy's Bolzano Province, which was formerly a part of the Austrian Tyrol, be given more rights.
HENRY DAVID THOREAU'S wit, his metaphysical imagery and his ability to suggest that Nirvana can be found in the North Temperate Zone are all delightful. But can they yield a philosophy of life?

LUANDA, Angola, Feb. 4 -- The Government announced today the crushing of an armed uprising supposedly timed with the seizure of the liner Santa Maria. The uprising was the strongest evidence of African nationalism in this Portuguese West African territory so far.

RUTH SLENCZYNSKA was just about the most extraordinary piano prodigy to astound the gaping world in this century, but her ability to make something of a comeback in recent years was perhaps an even more remarkable achievement.

I was amused by the patronizing tone with which one of your readers, a "psychotherapist," wrote to your drama critic as follows: "I'd like to try to enlighten you on the proper approach to such a play."

DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Fourth-ranked Duke, sparked by Art Heyman's 36 points, snapped fifth-ranked North Carolina's basketball winning streak at twelve games tonight with an 81-77 victory. The tensely fought game ended in a free-for-all among players and spectators.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Officials of the Federal Public Health Service here were notified this week that the old Studebaker plant on the Southwest Side would be headquarters for a study of Great Lakes water diversion and pollution.

THIS is the story of Mr. Lawfence Berra, bowling alley proprietor, vice president of Yoo-Hoo Chocolate Drink Co., and catcher for the New York Yankees. In the world of major league baseball he is known as "Yogi" to his team-mates and friends, and he is often called certain uncomplimentary, unprintable names by pitchers, most of whom are his natural enemies.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 4 -- Despite an all-day snowstorm, Middlebury's skiers sped to victory today in Dartmouth's fifty-first annual winter carnival. It marked the third year in a row that the Panthers have outscored all rivals in this nationally famous competition.
Floyd Patterson has put a price on his head.

At last the dream of a top-level group of representatives of business and labor to deal with labor-management relations is about to become a reality. In the fall of 1958 Labor Secretary Goldberg, then counsel to the A.F.L.C.L O., proposed an assembly under Government auspices with that objective in view. The plan fell through largely because of the lack of business enthusiasm.

RUNNING away from home is not usually a good idea, but it turned out well for Aidan when his crazy uncle started chasing him with a gun. The orphaned lad made some good friends on his travels through the England of a hundred and fifty years ago, including a comical little dog who helped him drum up business for the traveling actors he met.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Navy rallied today for a 58-56 basketball victory over Penn State after the Nittany Lions had surged into a late lead.
This is supposed to be the year for the automated electric power plant.

The Treasury's long campaign to stop mergers undertaken to escape taxes seems to be heading to a successful conclusion -- perhaps too successful. For many tax lawyers are convinced that tax regulations proposed at the end of the Eisenhower Administration would give the Treasury a weapon of awesome power, one that could challenge tax benefits obtained through mergers that took place as long as five years ago.

Mayor Wagner declared an emergency here yesterday as the heaviest snowstorm since 1947 paralyzed traffic in the city. The police were ordered to permit only emergency and public service vehicles on the streets until further notice.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- The Kennedy Administration is off to a good start in attacking the nation's "farm problem," in the opinion of leaders in agriculture on both sides of the political fence.
Cairo, Feb. 4 -- The Ministry of Social Affairs submitted a bill to the National Assembly today for the granting of life pensions to divorced wives.
PARAMUS, N.J., Feb. 4 -- A broad attack on two problems of increasing importance has been started at Bergen Pines County Hospital here.

New York University's center for graduate study in education in Puerto Rico will operate on a year-round resident basis, beginning in April, Dean Waiter A. Anderson of the N.Y.U. School of Education announced yesterday.

WHEN the Bolsheviks in Petrograd and Moscow seized power in 1917, they proceeded to abolish at one stroke the ancient state and empire called "Russia." What the government they set up claimed to represent, instead, was "the workers of the world," a social class that knew no country.

TUNIS, Jan. 31 -- Tunisia's recent purchase of fifteen Czechoslovak and five Soviet motion pictures is regarded by neutral observers here as an almost perfect illustration of the built-in advantages that Communist countries have over free-enterprise countries in the cultural and economic competition in the underdeveloped world.
The president of Manhattan College last night endorsed a proposal for state financial aid to residents attending colleges and universities within the state. The proposal is before the Legislature.

WHEN Gustaf Gruendgens, with the company of Hamburg's Deutsches Schauspielhaus, submits his production of Goethe's "Faust" for inspection at the City Center Tuesday, almost four decades will have passed since a representative troup of German actors -- one guided by that great sorcerer of the stage, Max Reinhardt -- last performed before an American audience.
CHRISTCHURCH, N.Z. -- New Zealand has been described by James A. Michener as probably the most beautiful country on earth. Few travelers to New Zealand will dispute Mr. Michener on that.
Training under sail for Belgian merchant mariners and naval cadets has ended. The Belgian Government has announced that the barkentine Mercator is to be scrapped.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- Despite charges that the British National Health Service is extravagant, Britain probably would have paid more for health care the last few years without the plan than was paid with it.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- The Soviet Union announced today it had put into orbit a huge earth satellite weighing more than seven tons.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg today asked lettuce growers and unions who are embroiled in a dispute to meet with his representative.

A CAREFUL perusal of the paperback section discloses that columnist Lewis Nichols was in error when he said that three Presidents from the last eight, "all naturally Democrats," were in print, in paperback. What about Herbert Hoover's "The Ordeal of Woodrow Wilson"?

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The national women's outdoor speed-skating champion, Jeanne Ashworth, headed toward a sweep in the North American outdoor speed-skating championships today by winning three final events in her division.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- The state of Oregon long has boasted of its mild winters and pleasant summers, but realization has come slowly that its winter snows also deserve some attention. In any catalogue of the state's assets, they cannot be omitted, for they make possible some of the finest skiing in the country.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23 -- The Yugoslav Communists are preparing to battle that hydra-headed enemy of the general public -- the discourteous and inefficient public servant.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- It appeared possible this week that television might bring a merciful end to the coast-to-coast, jet-powered scramble that Presidential campaigning became in 1960.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- The guided missile destroyer John King was commissioned this afternoon at the Boston Naval Shipyard.
PANAMA, Feb. 4 -- A labor contract of importance to the national budget of the Republic of Panama was signed this week.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Dr. William C. Finch, president of Southwestern University, Georgetown, Tex., will become dean of the Vanderbilt University Divinity School here, Chancellor Harvie Branscomb of Vanderbilt said today.

THE author of "Lost Summer," a respectfully regarded first novel published three years ago, now turns his creative eye upon the topical news theme of what happens when a Negro family moves into an all-white neighborhood of a nondescript Midwest town.

But the ever-amazing Yogi has just muscled his way into the literary league. He has written a book. Naturally, it's a home run.

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 4 -- The liner Santa Maria was returned to her owners here today. She raised a clean new Portuguese flag and went under the mop for a clean-up prior to her voyage home to Lisbon late next week.
MADISON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Fairleigh Dickinson University will present an all-day program, "Civil War Centennial, 1861-1961," on the University campus Tuesday.

The New York Rangers, clinging to the hope they can make the Stanley Cup play-offs, will take on the Boston Bruins in Madison Square Garden tonight at 7 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The conservatives flexed their muscles in the House of Representatives this week and demonstrated that they are a force to be reckoned with by the Kennedy Administration.

The American public's overall gifts for voluntary health and welfare agencies last year were more substantial than ever, but there were notable exceptions in the cases of the National Foundation and the American Cancer Society.

In spite of revolutionary developments in physics and an enormous increase in college physics enrollments, no new demonstration text has been published for lecturers in twenty years. Last week's annual meeting of the American Association of Physics Teachers produced two developments designed to remedy the situation.

Nine intrepid weight throwers mushed through the snow to Squadron A Armory yesterday. Two of them, Bob Backus and Stewart Thomson, jointly added a meet record to the six assorted Millrose Games marks set at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

The resignation last week of Paul-Henri Spaak as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization once again emphasizes what has been called perennially "the crisis in NATO."

When on Jan. 23, 1960, the bathyscaph Trieste, carrying Jacques Piccard and Lieut. Don Walsh, came to rest on the bottom there, man knew the farthest limits of his world.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The Sunday Telegraph made its appearance tonight as Britain's first new national Sunday newspaper in forty years.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- An era of expanded nuclear research began this week at the University of California at Los Angeles. The school's first nuclear reactor went to full power.

A fiftieth anniversary dinner, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Roosevelt on Feb. 17, will serve to open the Skidmore College drive for $1,200,000 to construct additions to the college's library and science buildings.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Fairfield County was virtually snowbound today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. -- Two developments at Niagara Falls, one completely new, the other a view from a location inaccessible for three years, will be available to visitors next Friday when the Prospect Point observation tower and elevator to the base of the American Falls are opened to the public.

An emergency milk distribution program was set up by the Metropolitan Dairy Institute yesterday when it appeared that the severity and duration of the snowstorm might interrupt the city's milk supply.

In March, April and May a multitude of corporate managements will either bask in stockholder approval or engage in heated questioning. This year there may be more of the heated meetings than usual because of the downtrend in earnings, conflict-of-interest scandals, a rash of proxy fights and such.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The President needs more help in formulating security policy, a Senate subcommittee said today. But he will not get it by creating "super-Cabinet" positions in the White House, the Senators said.

WARSAW, Feb. 5 -- Forty-seven Communist and Western politicians, meeting as private persons in closed session here for the last three days, called tonight for complete and controlled disarmament as the key to a peaceful world order.
For the fourth week in a row prices of over-the-counter industrial securities soared to a record high last week in active trading.

Replacement of large city water mains in use for fifty years or longer would cost more than $100,000,000 and do little to prevent breaks, according to Commissioner Armand D'Angelo of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
Governor Rockefeller and Republican state leaders are facing a major political decision in the next two weeks: whether to fix a June or September date for this year's primary elections.
BAGHDAD, Iraq., Feb. 5 -- Arab foreign ministers will advise their Governments to use armed force to keep Israel from diverting Jordan River waters, informed sources said today.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 4 -- President Sylvanus Olympio of the republic of Togo in a broadcast to his country yesterday, assailed the heads of the African states who he said, were dividing Africa into blocs. He urged full support of the United Nations.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain scored 55 points today and led Philadelphia to a 136-128 victory over New York in an overtime game in the National Basketball Association.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Pravda joined today in growing Soviet fault-finding with President Kennedy's State of the Union Message. It concluded that he was using double talk.
Ralph Bellamy, president of Actors Equity for three consecutive terms of three years each, has agreed to run for re-election. He was announced yesterday for that post on the regular ticket.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Sam Jones' jump shot with three seconds remaining enabled the Boston Celtics to beat the St. Louis Hawks, 123 -- 121, in a National Basketball Association game at Boston Garden today.
The week-end was tough on basketball winning streaks except for unbeaten Ohio State and two potential challengers that have been coming on like the winter wind, Duke and Cincinnati.
The battle in the compact car field grows more intense.
A PRETTY newcomer has just popped up in the children's world at Best Co. Her name is Miss Best and she is very particular about what she wears.
MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A police sharpshooter wounded an escaped convict with two bullets early today, ending fourteen hours of terror for the convict's woman hostage.
Faith was characterized at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as a gift of God bestowing a means to acquire knowledge and an indispensable key to salvation.

GENEVA, Feb. 5 -- Prices clung firmly last week on the Swiss stock markets to their dizzy heights despite a fairly heavy spate of profit taking.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla, Feb. 5 -- Poverty and progress have loomed large in the life of Joseph Meyerhoff, the new general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, Mr. Meyerhoff, a home-builder and developer of shopping centers, has fought poverty and battled for progress through a multitude of civic and Philanthropic activities since early manhood.
FOR an hour and a half yesterday, the "Sunday Sports Spectacular on Channel 2 presented a report on auto racing.
All public schools in New York City will remain closed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A rocket was shot ninety-four miles high from Wallops Island, Va., today to test the behavior of liquid hydrogen under zero gravity conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP.I) -- Leslie C. Arends of Illinois, the Republican House whip, assured twenty-two Republican Representatives today that they would not be punished for siding with Speaker Sam Rayburn in last week's Rules Committee vote.

President. Sukarno of the Republic of Indonesia is a popular hero in the United States. He has been received in great state and has been honored by citizens and officials. Mr. Sukarno had an interview with the President of the United States and with several Ministers. He was the recipient of money, weapons and ammunition.

The director of the International Cooperation Administration, Henry Richardson Labouisse, yesterday was urged to resist "pressures" to rescind a policy directive on the payment of ocean shipping costs.
Raymond Massey, an actor who may find himself overworked during the Civil War Centennial, will return to his familiar role of Abraham Lincoln in a television play entitled "The Last Full Measure.''
The age-old question in mutual funds seems to be "Why should I commit myself to monthly payment programs if I'm going to lose my shirt if I don't continue them for ten years or more?"
WARSAW, Feb. 5 -- The Polish Communist party has introduced a measure of party democracy in choosing its candidates for the approaching national elections.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- The promise inherent in the English-bred Pomeranian Ch. Pixietown Serenade of Hadleigh was fulfilled tonight. He became best in show at the Eastern Dog Club event in the Commonwealth Armory.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The State Board of Social Welfare criticized today a legislative study that recommended it be stripped of its policy and rule-making powers and reduced to an advisory group.

ILONKA Karasz is an artist whose perceptions of nature and people have produced vigorous design in home furnishings for more than forty years. She also has charmed millions of adult readers by her New Yorker magazine covers and sparked as many young minds by her children's book illustrations.

WHEN the intercity club match played over the Jan. 28-29 week-end by teams from Philadelphia, Boston, and the Cavendish and Regency Clubs of New York, was reported in this department last week, the name of Henry Meyer was inadvertently omitted from the list of players for the Regency Club.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 5 -- The Lavon affair, center of Israel's governmental crisis, will enter another stage when the executive committee of the General Federation of Labor meets Thursday.

February is national heart month and therefore the concentrated campaign for public awareness will reach its peak this month, but there will be no more deaths from heart disease in February than there were in. January or will be in June. For those who have had or will have heart attacks in 1961, every month is heart month.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 -- A Picasso painting on loan from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation of New York to the University of Pittsburgh disappeared tonight.
Long Islanders labored with snowplows and shovels yesterday to extricate themselves from their severest snowstorm since 1947.

The usefulness of tranquilizers in reducing the need for rehospitalization among chronic mental patients has been confirmed by four recent studies, according to Dr. Robert H. Felix, director of the National Institute of Mental Health.
DETROIT, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 7 -- 2, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 13,563 fans at the Olympia.
The formation of President Kennedy's team of tax experts was nearly completed last week with the appointment of Professor Stanley Sterling Surrey as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

IF there's anyone who can make you forgetabout 17.4 inches of snow, it's Elsa Lanchester. Miss Lanchester has a passion for collecting songs -- rare songs, sad songs, bright songs, bawdy songs. She has assembled some of them into a wonderfully entertaining package and she brought them to the Forty-first Street Theatre Saturday in a revue called "Elsa Lanchester -- Herself."
Vice President Johnson, in an address here last night, called for a cutback in armaments in the Middle East.

This is not, the real estate people will say, the best time of year to try to sell a house Winter has a way of showing up all the faults of a house. Trees, standing naked around it, let the pitiless light of winterskies seek out the flaking paint, the cracks in the caves through which icicles now hang.

A second book of essays by Francois Mauriac, called "Second Thoughts," will be published Feb. 20 by World. The volume, subtitled "Reflections on Literature and on Life," has been translated from the French by Adrienne Foulke. On Jan. 25 Farrar, Straus Cudahy published "Memoires Interiers" in an English translation by Gerard Hopkins, which dealt with various aspects of the intellectual and artistic life of the author's times.

By courtesy of your column, Justice Samuel Hofstadter has joined the ranks of those who want to cure our court congestion problem by radical changes in our basic court procedures and our substantive law. Singled out to receive the benefit of these changes are claims from automobile accidents.

At a time when concern is being voiced in many parts of the country about, the adequacy of the nation's future water supply, it is encouraging that the States of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware and the Federal Government have tentatively agreed upon a compact that should assure a fair distribution of the water resources of the Delaware River.
A worrisome downturn in the construction of housing, apparent since mid-1959, has apparently ended in New York State, the State Housing Commissioner said yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- The most striking evening clothes likely to be seen in Berlin these days are Western military dress uniforms. They are worn at theatres and opera houses in East Berlin.
Richard Strauss' "Elektra" will return to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera next Monday, after an absence of nine years.
The sun that beamed upon New York yesterday left puddles on shoveled sidewalks, caused water marks on gray fedoras and reduced the size of countless snowmen.
The Gettysburg College Choir sang a concert of sacred music in Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

The most outspoken criticism to date of a plan to unite four major Protestant bodies was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

Prices of cotton futures ended last week with a show of firmness. At the close Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down one point to up ten points from the close of the previous week.

The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany and the Committee for Jewish Claims on Austria appealed yesterday to the West German and Austrian Governments for an early agreement on compensation measures for victims of Nazi persecution in and from Austria.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Two Marine Corps corporals, Gary Sheffield and Jerry Tennant, members of the No. 1 United States four-man bobsled team, won the right today to represent the United States as the No. 1 team in the two-man world championships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Congress will receive President Kennedy's prescription for the country's ailing international balance of payments tomorrow.

THE automobile had not been able to hold the highway on the hairpin curve. So it leaped over the curbing and there it hung, halfway into the trough of the bobsled run. This was at St. Moritz in Switzerland last summer and was easily the most incongruous sight this tourist spotted in circuitous traveling along the road to Rome and the Olympic Games.
The' city's Department of Air Pollution Control served a record number of violation notices last year, Commissioner Arthur J. Benline reported yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Iskander F. of West Germany, the oldest horse in the field, captured the Prix de France trotting race at Vincennes today and earned an invitation to compete at Yonkers Raceway.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- French political leaders and experts have begun again to reflect publicly on what might happen to France without President de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Northerners and Southerners who joined with Virginia 100 years ago in an effort to prevent the Civil War were honored today in a service at the Washington Cathedral.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals gained the lead late in the first half and drew away for a 129-115 victory over the Cincinnati Royals today in the National Basketball Association.
Despite the adverse conditions under which American Negroes gained their freedom, "they have achieved an amazing degree of economic prosperity and development," Dr. Hans L. Trefousse said yesterday.

GEORGE SZELL and the Cleveland Orchestra brought a new symphony and a new pianist to town last night. The Symphony was the Second by William Walton, who, since the death of Ralph Vaughan Williams, is considered the dean of English composers.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal to give public money to private college students has raised one of the most potentially troublesome political issues before the Legislature in some time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Kennedy Administration is pressing for early Congressional action to amend the Battle Act and open the way for United States loans to Communist countries and some neutral countries now barred.

The Catholic Institute of the Press presented its 1960 award to Phyllis McGinley "for the distinguished manner in which she has exemplified Catholic principles in her daily and professional life."

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 -- Steel order volume slipped back last week to the level it held before the recent meager improvement. Reports from the trade indicate that new business this month will be about on a par with January tonnages.
The noisiest zoo in town yesterday was the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 5 -- Hope was voiced at United Nations headquarters today that the review of the Congo situation by the United States Government would diminish the danger of a large-scale civil war here.
A Protestant journal established to promote the United State's participation in World War II marks its twentieth anniversaries this week with a plea to prevent World War III.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Arnold Uhrlass of Yonkers and Jeanne Ashworth of Wilmington, Mass., today won the senior men's and women's titles, respectively, in the North American outdoor speed-skating championships on Mirror Lake.
BUENOS AIRES, Monday, Feb. 6 -- The Frondizi Administration suffered a double defeat yesterday in Congressional elections in this capital.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 4 -- The devaluation of the South Korean currency this week is regarded by many Koreans as a move forced upon their Government by the United States.

Bach triumphed over snow Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art when Frederic Waldman, nearly all of the orchestra and a good part of the audience braved it through to the hall for a Musica Aeterna program.

Carmine G. De Sapio challenged Mayor Wagner and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday to a televised debate on whether his rule as New York County Democratic chairman constituted "responsible leadership" or "bossism."

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- After four days of steady prices, a surge of buying sent stock market quotations up markedly on Friday.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- The United States national hockey team lost to Norway, 4 -- 3, tonight in an upset at the Jordal Amfi Stadium.

Financial problems continue to badger "How to Make a Man," William Welch's futuristic satire about life in 1991 that was salvaged after foundering in Detroit.

DORTMUND, Germany, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Erich Schoeppner of Germany retained the European light-heavyweight boxing title tonight by stopping Paul Roux of France in the thirteenth round of a scheduled fifteen-round bout. Schoeppner weighed 174 pounds, Roux 173.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Bob Holbert, a foreign-car distributor from Warrington, Pa., won the feature race today of a Sports Car Club of America program.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Einstein once said: "The unleashed power of the atom has changed everything except our ways of thinking. Thus we are drifting toward a catastrophe beyond comparison. We shall require a substantially new manner of thinking if mankind is to survive."
Four young women will be presented at the twenty-sixth annual Colonial Ball Feb, 24 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

A two-year study of teacher-education will be started in September by Dr. James B. Conant, it was announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York. The corporation is providing a $300,000 grant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President and Mrs. Kennedy heard their pastor declare today that Roman Catholics consider the Pope infallible in matters of faith and morality, but know that he can err in other fields.
American-flag tankers are getting well over 95 per cent of the chartering business offered by the Military Sea Transportation Service, according to Vice Admiral Roy A. Gano, commander of the service.

Airline service was resuming slowly here yesterday. It had been shut down since the storm struck Friday. At least 2,650 flights involving 183,000 passengers were canceled during the shutdown.

The Rev. Walter Donald Kring described agnosticism and flexible religions yesterday as healthy beliefs for inquiring college students. But atheism and rigid faiths, he said, are "too doctrinaire" to satisfy a young person or to stand up in the light of evolving religious concepts.

CAIRO, Feb. 5 -- An Egyptian Christian girl from a poor home left Cairo in the summer of 1958 for West Africa to marry a man she had never seen. A public offering of 180,000 Class A shares of Consolidated Airborne Systems, Inc., is being made today at $5 a share by S.D. Fuller Co. and associates.
THE change that took place on the stage of The Playhouse last night is not likely to impede the successful career of "The Miracle Worker" in any way.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 5 -- The new home of the Ministry of Finance is a white stone building next to Golestan Palace. The Ministry's six severe stories rise in sharp contrast to the ornate residence of the Shahs, with its glistening mosaics and reflecting pools.

President Kennedy's recommendation that foreign governments and central banks be given special incentives to retain their foreign exchange holdings in dollars won applause yesterday from the large international New York City banks.
Betty Furness, who closed her last refrigerator door on television three months ago, has decided on a new career. She will become the television counter-part of radio's answer man.

No attention has been directed to two very unfortunate defects in the proposed New York law providing for $200 across-the-board grants to college students and larger amounts for those in graduate work.

AT a time when our relations with the Soviet Union are sour, the Russian film version of "Don Quixote" reminds us of something sweet.

A new college, underwritten by insurance organizations in the city, is being planned by the Insurance Society of New York, Inc.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reported yesterday that its net earnings in 1960 plummeted to $708,850 from $28,544,338 in 1959.

"X-PILOT," the story of the Civilian flier who tasted the Air Force's first manned rocket-powered aircraft, made a vivid half-hour on Channel 7's "Close-Up!" series last night.

Customers intrepid enough to brave snow banks in lower Manhattan discovered yesterday that over the weekend the Chase Manhattan Bank had moved its head office branch from 18 Pine Street next door to 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza in the ground floor of the bank's new sixty-story headquarters.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- The flaming second stage of a Polaris missile sailed over Cape Canaveral today, then crashed to the ground. There were no injuries or serious damage from the failure.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP) -- St. Joseph's College defeated LaSalle, 65-54, tonight in the second game of a doubleheader at the Palestra.

The Brazilian Carnival Ball, a costume gala, will be held Friday in the Plaza. Proceeds will be used by the Brazilian Center Scholarship Fund of New York for a cultural exchange of two American and two Brazilian students next summer.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- More than half the grain futures contracts reached new high prices for the season today on the Board of Trade, hut failed to hold them although the market closed generally firm.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 6 -- Prof. Turban Feyzioglu, submitted his resignation today to Premier Cemal Gursel. The Minister said he would like to free himself from the burdens of administration.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit, reversed today a District Court decision which had dismissed a suit brought against the Studebaker-Packard Corporation in a fight over a proxies voted on a proposal that established a management advisory agreement with the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

Thousands of suburban youngsters prepared to return to school today after the big snow with the prospect of having to attend extra classes on holidays or during vacations to make up for their lost time.
United States steel production last week showed a slight improvement, but operations continued at around half of capacity.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- A Government radio commentator said today that a fire last night that destroyed a big tobacco warehouse was undoubtedly sabotage intended to coincide with bomb explosions in Havana during the night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Quick imposition of quotas on textile imports was urged today by Senate committee witnesses as a necessity to save the United States textile industry. Unless the Government acted soon, witnesses said, the industry would face an impossible competitive situation from a swiftly rising tide of imports.
A Brooklyn resident discovered yesterday that any-portin-a-storm can be pleasantly scenic and economical.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he was not yet prepared to recommend that the Legislature raise the minimum age for drinking alcoholic beverages at bars.

LEE NELSON, a writer going through a period when inspiration failed her, turned to hand work as therapy. The result is Flair, a flourishing boutique in Westport, Conn., where she sells the imaginative separates that she designs and makes up from fabrics old and new.

President Frondizi of Argentina received a stunning setback in the Buenos Aires elections for a Senator and Deputy on Sunday. For Senator, the 80-year-old Alfredo Palacios, Socialist, pro-Castro, anti-Yankee and anti-Frondizi won out against the candidate for the moderate opposition People's Radical party. Dr. Frondizi's candidate, Senator Armando Turano of the Radical Intransigent party, ran a poor third.

The two crucial economic problems that call for the new Administration's immediate attention are the state of the American dollar in international markets and the state of the nation's domestic business. Both problems are subject to quick solution by decisive action.

The captain of the Exodus, the Jewish refugee ship that ran the British blockade of Palestine in 1947, said yesterday Jews would always be "indigestible" in any country but Israel.

THE grand old lady of modern art blew into town last week and may be visited, beginning today, on the second level of the ramp at the Guggenheim Museum. A Brooklyn stockbroker who admitted he had fleeced 140 investors out of $103,000 was sentenced yesterday to a five-to-ten-year term in Sing Sing Prison:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A desk made from the timbers of the British ship Resolute and used by many Presidents has been installed in President Kennedy's office by Mrs. Kennedy. The White House announced this today in a release headed: "Discovery of the Table Desk from H.M.S. Resolute."
Mayor Wagner will maintain his emergency ban on private auto traffic here today, but he lifted the restrictions on commercial vehicles as of last midnight.
Sears, Roebuck Co., giant general merchandise concern, yesterday reported record sales for January and the fiscal year ended with Jan. 31.

Mayor Wagner acted courageously, correctly and decisively in meeting the snow emergency caused by a 17.4-inch fall. Nothing short of a prohibition on all vehicular traffic except the most essential was appropriate to conditions that built up from the Friday-Saturday storm. To allow private automobiles and nonessential commercial traffic to worsen the crisis or impede the snow removal operation would have been absurd.
