They joined Memphis State in entering the Madison Square Garden's annual post-season classic, which will be held from March 16 through March 25.
The Department of Sanitation began an inquiry yesterday to determine which of its employes had used a city plow to clear snow from a private parking lot.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Dr. E. Vincent Askey, president of the American Medical Association, urged today that the present program of medical aid to the aged "not be thrust aside without fair trial in favor of an unsound and dangerous alternative."
A long line of river craft will batter its way up the ice-choked Hudson River this morning to deliver more than 100,000 barrels of gasoline and heating oil to fuel-starved communities.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- The Bowie race track, closed since last Thursday because of snow, will attempt to resume operations tomorrow with a field of nine entered for the first running of the $10,000 added Pocahontas Stakes.
BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The Administration of President Kennedy reiterated today the United States' intention to defend Berlin and to strive for German reunification.
Rodolfo Diaz, an Argentine light heavyweight, worked in the Eighth Avenue Gymnasium yesterday for his ten-round semi-final against Von Clay in Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
The United States Auto Club and the National Association for Stock Car Racing have reached an agreement on driver participation in top international competition in the United States.

Although Charles Francis Adams was an influential legislator and statesman, he was outshone by other members of his family. His grandfather and father had been Presidents of the United States and his three children were distinguished writers and historians. During the Civil War.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 7 -- Constitutional changes for Southern Rhodesia, including admission of Africans to the Legislative Assembly for the first time, were agreed upon today.
ROME, Feb. 7 -- The city of Genoa has given the Leftists a voice in the municipal government.
One of the season's most exciting pro basketball games warmed up Madison Square Garden last night. The Boston Celtics eked out a 96 -- 95 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Feb. 7 -- United States delegates to the first Mexican-United States Parliamentary Conference here will pay a courtesy visit on President Adolfo Lopez Mateos following the closing of the conference tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Circumstances could hardly have appointed a more unlikely warrior than A. Willis Robertson to lead the first charge in the Senate against President Kennedy's new Administration. One of the Senate's gentlest members, for fourteen years he has lived contentedly under the shadow of his Virginia colleague, Harry F. Byrd, with no inclina

THERE is a breed of fashion-conscious New Yorkers that yearns for the kind of clothes it used to buy in Paris or had custom made here. In recent years, little Paris dressmakers and big New York made-to-order departments have become vanishing species, while French couture models have soared in price. What, then, does this customer do?

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- Soviet newspapers reported today that severe punishment was being administered to regional officials found guilty of having covered up falsifications in production figures and "anti-state crimes."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Kennedy called on Congress today for prompt action to increase the national minimum wage from $1 to $1.25 an hour and extend the protection to 4,300,000 workers.

Southbound service on the snow-plagued Brighton line of the BMT subway was halted for forty minutes yesterday morning when a man was struck by a train and killed at the Parkside Avenue station in Brooklyn. He was Murray Getz, 58 years old, of 170 Hawthorne Street, Brooklyn.

The thirty-first floor in the fifty-nine-story Pan Am Building, which is under construction at 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Terminal, has been leased by Walter E. Heller Co., a commercial financing and factoring organization.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Scoring on 54 per cent of its shots from the floor, the Princeton basketball team defeated Penn, 77 -- 55, in an Ivy League contest before a crowd of 2,400 at Dillon Gymnasium tonight.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- Prospects for expanding trade between Japan and Communist China are still dim, although some demand for normalizing economic relations between the two countries has been growing in recent months, according to industrial circles here.

The Government moved yesterday in Federal Court to keep for itself $16,999 in gold that had been seized in two safe deposit boxes rented to an international private banker who died last July in Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A two-day Senate hearing on textile industry problems wound up today on conflicting statements -- one, that imports jeopardized domestic production, the other, that they caused no damage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Industries in New York State are making substantial progress in winning a bigger share of Government defense contracts, Senator Jacob K. Javits reported today. The New York Republican expressed confidence that his state might well again attain the top position as a supplier of military needs.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Sentencing in the Government's antitrust cases against twenty-nine electrical manufacturers and forty-five of these companies' executives ended today.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- At least two vessels sank, others were damaged and one was helplessly adrift in gale-whipped seas off western Europe, reports said today.
ATLANTA, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The police arrested seventeen Negro youths today in a cafeteria in an office building leased to Federal Government agencies.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 7 -- A "state of vigilance" or general alert of the Congolese National Army was ordered today while the United Nations Security Council debates the situation in the Congo.
Speed limits of sixty miles an hour on parts of the Long Island Expressway and Sunrise Highway were authorized yesterday by William S. Hults, state Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
The Commission on Intergroup Relations was told yesterday that the Department of Hospitals had taken steps to remedy a condition of "neglect" at Harlem Hospital.
The Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) announced yesterday that it recorded slightly higher sales during 1960 but sharply lower earnings than in 1959.
Ed Sullivan will present an hour-long tribute to Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe on his Columbia Broadcasting System show Sunday, March 19.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 6 -- The financial and production records of the Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, the Belgium mining company that is the most valuable business enterprise in the Congo Republic, throw some light on why President Moise Tshombe wants to keep Katanga autonomous.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 11 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
ROCK HILL, S.C., Feb. 7 -- Four regional leaders in the student anti-segregation movement chose today to go to jail rather than pay fines on trespassing convictions.
The second of the two New York Assemblies will be held in the ballroom of the Sheraton East on Feb. 24 under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller.

A New York County grand jury indicted three lawyers and four other persons yesterday, accusing them of complicity in tow-car racketeering. In addition, a criminal information was returned against two persons.

THOSE snowbound folks who were unable to get their newspapers had to nibble during a long, white week-end on what morsels were fed to them over the air waves. It made for a most unsubstantial fare. Some was totally unpalatable. One such item was found in paraphrased quotes from Bob Mathias, the Olympic decathlon champion of 1948 and 1952.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Britain's ailing auto industry -- hit by short-time working and falling sales -- got a shot in the arm today from the American-controlled Ford Motor Company, Ltd., of England.

The appointment of Benjamin B. Naumoff as regional director of the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor-Management Reports was announced yesterday by Commissioner John L. Holcombe, head of the bureau.
Two grants totaling $203,500 have been received by the Police Athletic League, Mrs. Weston Vernon Jr., president of the league, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A hearing on the recent "Ship American" order was canceled tonight. Officials said that protests against the order were based on a misunderstanding.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Governors of New York, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island will gather in Albany, N.Y., Feb. 21 to discuss financial relief for the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, Gov. John A. Notte Jr. announced today.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Maj. Robert White, Air Force pilot, streaked through the sky at more than three times the speed of sound today in the X-15 rocket ship.

" Romeo and Juliet," as mounted by the New York Shakespeare Festival, yesterday began a tour of a dozen high schools, where weekly engagements will be played through May 5. The trip started a day late as a result of the school shutdown because of the snowstorm.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's letter to Mayor Wagner on revision the New York City Charter:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 7 -- A German nuclear physicist who worked on research contracts for the United States Air Force in Israel was convicted today of having transmitted security information to a foreign power.
ATLANTA, Feb. 7 (AP) Negro Baptist leader said to that a farm purchase marketing program had be started with the aim of give rural Negroes economic security and independence.

The long agitation to force the Port of New York Authority to go into the commuter railroad business has succeeded in extracting from the authority a firmer, but still conditional, offer to buy, finance, improve and operate the Hudson and Manhattan rail transit system. This would involve a purchase price still to be negotiated, but upward of $20,500,000, improvements including new cars of about $63,000,000 cost, and an annual deficit estimated at $5,000,000.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- Sol A. Dann, who sometimes describes himself as a management "gadfly," is a small, balding, sometimes irascible Detroit lawyer dedicated to the ouster of the top level hierarchy at the Chrysler Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Britain agrees with the United States that a future Congolese government should rest on a broadly based coalition but believes that in the meantime the United Nations must bring a more positive and affirmative approach to the Congo.
MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion returned to Montreal Canadiens National Hockey League action last week and added to his lead in the race for the scoring title.
Tony Jackson became the second highest scorer in St. John's basketball history last night as the Redmen routed Loyola of Chicago, 98 -- 74, at Fordham's gymnasium in the Bronx.
First Deputy Police Commissioner James R. Kennedy, second in command of the city's' police force, announced yesterday his resignation to assume a private position.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Edward M. Kennedy, a brother of the president, was sworn in today as an Assistant District Attorney of Suffolk County. He will be paid $1 a year.

One of the more interesting and potentially valuable forays into the field of Latin-American relations is now taking place in Guadalajara, Mexico. An interparliamentary conference of United States and Mexican Congressmen began on Monday and will continue through tomorrow.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Philippine Government thinks the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization has collapsed and is ready to write it off as an effective anti-Communist force in Asia.
The soft music was gone yesterday from the telephone booth fat WOrth 2-8372 in the Criminal Courts Building.

Mrs. Auguste Redman, a 57-year-old real estate broker who has become known as "the slum queen," was sentenced to 120 days in the workhouse yesterday by Chief Justice John M. Murtagh of Special Sessions Court.
Mayor Wagner pledged yesterday that he would get more state aid for schools from Albany this year or "I'll find out the reason why and tell the people why."
MIAMI, Feb. 7 -- The Columbiana Handicap for fillies and mares will be the stakes race on tomorrow's Hialeah program, and Mrs. Mary Keim's Indian Maid will be favored to win it.
The current blizzard and the Mayor's edict against all but essential moving traffic should emphasize the stupidity of the policy which permits the use of the city's streets for vehicle storage.
MADRID, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- Fernando Herrero Tejedor, a 41-year-old lawyer, became Vice Secretary General of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Falange party in a reshuffle announced today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to extend unemployment benefits in the state from the present maximum of twenty-six weeks to thirty-nine.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The western European financial world gave a strongly favorable reaction today to President Kennedy's gold message of yesterday.
Snowbird patronage swelled revenues of the commuter railroads, subways and buses yesterday, but for most of the lines the extra traffic again contributed to delays.

Bond houses bidding for $45,000,000 of debentures of Consolidated Natural Gas Company -- first major triple-A rated securities offering this year -- set a price to yield investors on reoffering of 4.325. The banking group, led by Morgan Stanley Co. and The First Boston Corporation, stipulated interest coupons of 4 3/8 per cent for the debentures which are due Feb. 1, 1986.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Angry complaints of delaying tactics, outsidet interference and sideline negotiation by Prime Minister Macmillan emanated today from the conference reviewing Northern Rhodesia's Constitution.
The United States Lines yesterday canceled the sailing of the 26,314-ton passenger vessel America. The liner was to have sailed Saturday for Europe.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Sheriff's deputies attached real estate belonging to a Negro minister today while lawyers sought to have the appeal bond reduced in a $500,000 libel suit judgment.

NEARLY any bridge player would like to have played this hand. It ranks among the curiosities of bridge. But it comes from one of the regular matches in the Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League, which is in its twenty-ninth season.

President Kennedy is rapidly putting his own stamp on the highest office in the land by word and deed that have won him much acclaim and but little criticism this far. Now his chief Cabinet officer, Secretary of State Dean Rusk, has likewise presented himself to a wider public at his first press conference.
There is sad news this morning for all those who through the years have grown fond of the gentle and rather bitter sweet popular song "Makin' Whoopee."
HAVANA, Feb. 7 -- Raul Castro, Armed Forces Minister, castigated Cuba's Roman Catholic priests tonight.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Harold Johnson of Philadelphia won the National Boxing Association version of the world light-heavyweight championship tonight by stopping Jesse Bowdry of St. Louis in 45 seconds of the ninth round.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Kennedy Administration is considering plans for more amphibious assault ships in a further effort to prepare for possible limited war situations at remote places in the world.
Charles Ufford of the Harvard Club, the defender, gained the final of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A singles championship last night at the University Club.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he favored a referendum this year on a revised Charter for New York City.

CHILDREN 8 through 14 years old may participate in the fifth semi-annual chess tournament at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Registration is Saturday between 1 and 4 P.M. Play begins at 3:30 P.M. Admission is free. For information, call PResident 4-2900.

Roy Hamey, the general manager of the Yankees, left town yesterday. Before he did, though, Hamey signed three pitchers, the right-handed Jim Coates and a couple of rookie southpaws, Bob Meyer and Hal Stowe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Paul Rand Dixon, counsel of the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee, was named today by President Kennedy as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Some officials of the merged labor movement boycotted today a get-acquainted meeting called by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., chairman of the House Labor committee, because a teamster union official was present.
Following are the texts of statements issued yesterday by the General Electric Company here and the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in Milwaukee in connection with the antitrust cases:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The House Rules Committee declined today to line itself up with the angels, even with the "better angels" on whom Abraham Lincoln placed his reliance.
MIAMI, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- A group of travel-strained Americans, pawns in the saga of the Santa Maria, arrived today by plane from Brazil, weary but happy on their safe return to United States soil.

The battle of the last four months between the Southern Pacific Company and the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company for control of the Western Pacific Railroad Company is fast becoming a real railroad war.
A total of 639 persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was 242 fewer than during the comparable period in 1960.
Revlon, Inc., has named Evan William Mandel to the new position of vice president-marketing services.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- While New York struggles with its worst snow in years, Moscow's "snow squadron" of new machines and old brooms easily defeats the Russian winter.

Navy's swimming team, which accomplished one of the year's notable sports coups last Saturday by snapping Yale's streak of 201 consecutive dual-meet victories, will have to continue moving at flank speed to keep at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate League standings.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Reports received today by the State Department of Commerce: Belleayre Mountain -- 24 inches settled, 18-12 base; skiing good to excellent.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Britain's Attorney General charged today that the Soviet spy system had sent secrets of antisubmarine devices from a bungalow in a suburb of London to Moscow. The Crown's case against five persons arrested early last month presented a bizarre story.

Three eminent American poets, Robert Frost, Carl Sandburg and Archibald MacLeish, have been asked to write a special creed embodying a declaration of purpose for the proposed National Cultural Center in Washington.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal for $200-a-year grants to resident students at private colleges in the state appears headed for rejection by the Legislature unless it is modified substantially.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Directors of American Photocopy Equipment Company proposed today a three-for-one split of the common stock and a rise in the dividend rate.

The executive board of the Protestant film commission has voted to divest the commission of its West Coast office, an official of the group reported last night. The office has been vociferous in asserting there has been too much "sex and violence" in recent Hollywood movies.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Setting three records, Princeton's track team defeated Seton Hall, 76 -- 33, tonight in the opening indoor meet of the season for both squads.

TUNIS, Feb. 7 -- A discreet compromise was reached between Tunisia and the United Arab Republic on the question of a Tunisian dissident, Salah Ben Youssef, during the Arab League meeting in Baghdad last week, according to reliable reports that have reached Tunis.
General Electric Company announced yesterday its entry into the water conversion business with the development of what it described as a radical new distillation process for de-salting sea water.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Almost everybody has given three cheers for President Kennedy's top domestic appointees, but two cheers is about all he is likely to get for his diplomatic appointees if they follow the list as it now stands.
Members here of the Women's Division, Jewish Guild for the Blind, and those wintering in Palm Beach, Fla., are arranging benefits for the nonsectarian organization.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 7 -- Strengthening of the common market between the East African territories of Kenya, Uganda and Tanganyika was recommended in a report published today by the Economic and Fiscal Commission.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Fourteen persons were arrested today on charges of keeping overdue library books for four months to a year, ignoring notices for their return.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would abandon its Imperial assembly plant in suburban Dearborn, Mich., and drastically reduce operations of its Conant stamping plant in Detroit.
A distinguished appraiser of snooty poodles, Dr. Samuel Milbank of the Westminster Kennel Club, yesterday judged eighteen dogs of dubious ancestry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A compromise solution to the snarled Glen Canyon-Rainbow Bridge situation was proposed here today by the Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- President Kennedy has made some exceptionally astute appointments affecting our foreign affairs posture and he has also shown great wisdom in keeping at their posts outstanding officials from the previous Administration.
JEAN ANOUILH'S "Time Remembered," a charming trifle of a play, provided a delightful ninety minutes of television last night.

C.L. Sulzberger, in The Times on Feb. 1, writes again on the proposal for a NATO stockpile of nuclear weapons. None of the numerous discussions of this proposal that I have seen, however, answers certain fundamental questions.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday in Federal Court for dismissal of a complaint charging that his criticism of the best-selling book "How I Made $2 Million On The Stock Market," was unconstitutional.

We spent two weeks in Cuba over the Christmas holidays. Since travel from the United States has been drastically curtailed for the present, we feel it a duty to record our impressions of our stay there. We were not prepared by the American newspapers for what we saw.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7 -- James R. Hoffa instructed his legal staff today to start new action to get rid of the court-appointed monitors who oversee the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

A RARE opportunity to see a German classic presented by one of Germany's leading companies will be at the disposal of New Yorkers in the next fortnight. The Deutsches Schauspielhaus of Hamburg opened its production of Goethe's "Faust" at the City Center last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- The Congolese Government of President Joseph Kasavubu told the United Nations today that the deposed Premier, Patrice Lumumba, would be tried under the Congo's law and by the Congolese people and not under the jurisdiction of the world organization.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Mayor Richard J. Vander Plaat has had enough of snow -- or rather, complaints about it -- to consider withdrawing from politics.
WARSAW, Feb. 7 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka answered today one of the major questions raised in the campaign for the national elections to be held in April.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the nation's largest sales finance company, announced an increase of 1/8 percentage point in some of the shorter maturities of commercial paper it sells directly to investors.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Prime Minister Macmillan, in smiling good humor, let the House of Commons know today that he was not disturbed by the strong attack his son Maurice made on the Government's economic policies yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, said today that he had just been "playing by the rules of the game" when he telephoned Western Representatives to seek their votes during the fight over enlarging the House Rules Committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7--Adlai E. Stevenson reported progress today in his efforts to strengthen the United States delegation to the United Nations.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 7 -- For the second time in a year, a civic group is trying to block a $2,875,000 school conversion project here.

The Department of Sanitation has its snowplows and the New York Central Railroad has its caboose-mounted jet engine to clear snow from where it's not wanted, but one contractor in the city used high-pressure methods yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb 7 (AP) -- Senator Spessard L. Holland said in the Senate yesterday that a recent televised film documentary on migratory workers had played "fast and loose with the truth."
In the manner of indulgent wedding guests, the stock market does not traditionally bother a newly elected President with declining prices until after a reasonably long political honeymoon.

Fairfield University won its second consecutive Tri-State League basketball championship when it defeated Long Island University, 88 -- 83, in an overtime game at the 715th Field Artillery Armory in Brooklyn last night:
Discrimination against mortgages by pension funds could have undesirable results quite apart from the adverse effect on housing, a leading mortgage specialist said yesterday.

WHEN Arthur Miller has a new book out, attention must be paid. His memorable first novel, "Focus," appeared in 1945, and the intervening plays have kept him from this most individual of fiction forms. One way to lick the second novel problem, of course, is to write "Death of a Salesman" instead.

Governor Rockefeller in a letter to Mayor Wagner has declared himself emphatically for giving the people of New York the opportunity to vote on a new City Charter this year. He might better have discouraged or rejected the Mayor's request for authority to create a new, nine-member City Charter Commission, but he did not do so.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 7 -- The abolition of the present city police and fire commissions is favored by the Charter Revision Commission.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 7 -- Luanda, capital of Portuguese Angola, is a city of fear after the unsuccessful revolt last week-end against the Portuguese regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.

Production of paperboard dipped in the week ended last Saturday to 313,152 tons after four successive weeks of advances, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. In the previous week the figure was 313,805 tons and a year ago, 320,887.

Mayor Wagner ordered last night that the city's ban on nonessential private automobiles be continued today because of the possibility of another snowstorm and because many side streets were still unplowed.

With the titleholder, Pancho Gonzales, back in action after a ten-day lay-off, Jack Kramer's touring professional tennis troupe will continue its world championship competition in Madison Square Garden tonight.

Owing to a flurry in low-price stocks, the market had a contradictory appearance yesterday. More stocks rose than fell but those that rose were either not included in the market averages or were too small to carry much weight.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The Rockefeller administration and Republican Senators reached agreement today on a bill to prohibit discrimination in the sale or rental of stone, but far from all, private housing in the state.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- The Kennedy Administration has informed the six-nation European Economic Community or Common Market of the United States' continuing support for the organization and its long-range concept of political integration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The White House branded as inaccurate today reports that the Kennedy Administration had tentatively concluded that there was no "missile gap" favoring the Soviet Union.

David S. Meister, New York realty investor, has bought the two-story store and apartment building at 332 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City, for cash over a first mortgage of $62,000. The property has seven apartments and three stores.
The nation's private shipping industry has urged the Kennedy Administration to affirm a directive by the Eisenhower Administration ordering the Panama Line to cease commercial operations.

The Hat Corporation of America is acquiring Fashion Park, Inc., Rochester, N.Y., manufacturer of men's clothing and owner of the Weber Heilbroner chain of men's wear stores. Bernard L. Salesky, president of Hat Corporation, said yesterday the deal involved several million dollars in cash, with Hat Corporation ready to invest additional funds in future growth of the Fashion Park organization.
A group of executives from the theatre, restaurant and hotel industries told Mayor Wagner yesterday that they were preparing a plan for beautifying the Times Square area.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Republicans and Democrats clashed on the House floor today in a dispute over charges that the new Administration had revived "the spoils system."
Twin developments stirred speculation yesterday among barring factions of the Democratic party in New York State.

Potato futures prices fell 8 to 10 cents a hundred pounds yesterday in active dealings on the New York Mercantile Exchange. There was considerable liquidation as a result of news that cold weather in the Southern growing areas was not as severe as had been expected.

FATHER and son combinations are fairly common-place in the business world, but mother and daughter teams -- such as Laura and Nora Aponte -- are still a relative rarity. Half of this Italian knitwear concern, Nora Aponte, arrived in New York last week chaperoning a new collection designed and made in Rome for Saks Fifth Avenue.
Call both Debbie Reynolds and Stewart Granger "well booked" in advance.
The Treasury's new issue of 3 1/4 per cent notes due in August of 1962 had an auspicious introduction to the public market yesterday.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Two scientists who landed at Cape Adare, Antarctica, have found a wooden building erected in 1899 still standing. It proved servicable after snow was dug out.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 8 -- To attract new capital investments, the Moroccan Government will offer direct subsidy of private investment and will guarantee liberty of capital transfer, the Minister of National Economy declared today.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 8 -- "It's wonderful to be a private citizen," former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today as he began an extended golfing vacation in the California desert. Accompanied by his wife and a small staff, the former President motored here from San Bernardino, where the party left two special cars on the Santa Fe Chief that brought them West.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Two distance runners, Tom Carroll and Bob Mack, led the way as Yale captured a triangular track meet with Brown and Pennsylvania today.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa assailed last night any move to deviate from home rule procedure in the adoption of a new City Charter. He also contended that there was no critical need for a new Charter and asked: "What is the great rush?"
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The increases in National Health Service charges announced last week by the Government were assailed by the Labor party today and vigorously defended by the Conservatives.

The purchase of 15,000 shares of General Dynamics Corporation stock by Rex L. Nicholson, senior vice president of the company, through exercise of a stock option was reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange in its latest insiders' list.
High-speed photography is providing new information for scientists studying the bio-mechanics of a bullfrog leaping to snap prey in midair.

National Airlines, Inc., offered yesterday to sell to Pan American World Airways, Inc., 400,000 shares of Pan Am stock at $19.375 each. National has owned the Pan Am stock for a little more than two years.

The short, stocky man with a mustache usually seen squatting in show rings before winning dogs and sometimes growling at them and throwing things is William Brown of New Hyde Park, L.I. He is one of perhaps half a dozen persons in the country who make a living from photographing dogs.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 10 to 18 points yesterday, except for the July contract which was unchanged.

The election of Robert C. Hill, a former Ambassador to Mexico, as a director of the Investors Diversified Services, Inc., was announced yesterday by W. Grady Clark, president. Mr. Hill is also a director of the United Fruit Company and a member of the New Hampshire Legislature.

Reliable reserves, a zone press defense and a protean attack led by Rod Thorn constitute the principal logic behind the odds favoring West Virginia over New York University in the finale of a college basketball twin bill at Madison Square Garden tonight.

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 8 -- Harvard moved into a tie for first place with Yale in the Ivy Hockey League by scoring an 8-1 victory over Brown tonight. It was the tenth straight triumph for the Crimson and its thirteenth against three losses and a tie.
ATLANTA, Feb. 8 -- A new movement by students who have vowed to break down racial barriers by deliberately going to jail has spread to three Southern cities.
TUNIS, Feb. 8 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia denounced today Moslem traditionalists who, he said, stand for "obscurantism and intellectual under-development."
DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation today merged the field sales forces of its Plymouth and Chrysler-Imperial divisions.
The National Broadcasting Company yesterday gave Carmine G. de Sapio an hour of local television time next Sunday to discuss the issue of Democratic leadership in New York County.
Speaking on the school segregation issue, with especial reference to New Orleans, President Kennedy said yesterday at his press conference:

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad appealed yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission to help it avert bankruptcy. It asked the commission for its immediate guarantee of a $5,000,000 commercial loan.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Export-import traffic handled by twenty United States Great Lakes ports in the St. Lawrence Seaway trade increased 27 per cent in 1960 from a year earlier, the Great Lakes Commission reported today.

Wall Street digested new budget estimates yesterday and decided that a little inflation was inevitable. The result was a rush to buy stocks that might benefit from such a development. Every major group was up, with particular strength in electronics, drugs and nonferrous metals.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8 -- Devastating floods exceeding any in Westchester's history may be expected when the present thick blanket of snow and ice melts, the County Water Agency warned today.

Mayor Wagner's ban on nonessential passenger cars in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx was lifted at midnight last night. But the Mayor continued the prohibition on drivers in Manhattan today to help speed snow removal.
WINDER, Ga., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The missile gap is real, Senator Richard B. Russell said today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A forty-eight-inch water main burst early today at the crest of a hill in an old residential area of north St. Louis. Water surged into a low-lying neighborhood, routing hundreds of residents in 20-degree cold.
Success was reported yesterday for an educational and guidance program for raising the cultural level of children from underprivileged backgrounds.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb 8 -- Army tied its record for goals in one game by defeating Hamilton, 14 -- 0, in hockey today at Smith Rink.

A collection of pieces from the works of the late Albert Camus, whose writings won him a Nobel Prize in Literature in 1957, will be published by Knopf on Monday and will be titled "Resistance, Rebellion and Death."
Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter ruled yesterday that deliquency at the age of 13 was no reason to prohibit a 28-year-old man from joining the Police Department.

Acting very much like Cinderella's starry-eyed prince, investor were searching for a stock this week on the American Stock Exchange. It seems that on the Jack Paar television show Monday night, comedian Lou Holtz spoke about the stock market -- old and new. He said he held a $10 stock, mentioning no name, listed on the American Board and expected it to rise to $1,000 eventually.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb 8 -- Just across from Mount Holyoke College, Romeo Grenier's pharmacy is well known by students and faculty for its large assortment of paper-back classics, coffee, hamburgers, European cigarettes (thirty brands), photographic equipment and Romeo Grenier.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 8 -- South Korea's wobbly economy was pictured this week as the principal security problem of the allied armed forces defending the country against the Communists in the north.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Burgermeister Brewing Corporation today asked $5,250,000 in damages from the Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee.

James B. Carey said yesterday that he found it "hard to believe" that top officials of the electrical industry were ignorant of the price-fixing and bid-rigging activities of subordinates.
The prolonged battle between flight engineers and pilots over union jurisdiction in jet airliner cockpits has flared anew as a result of a National Mediation Board decision issued on Monday.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Governor Rockefeller conceded at a news conference today that he had agreed to a political compromise on a bill to curb discrimination in housing "as an encouragement to get the bill approved."
CLEVELAND, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Pipers coaste to a 102-87 victory over the New York Tuck Tapers tonight in a National Industrial Basketball League game.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The sharp rise of most British Government securities was a highlight in the stock market here today.

The American Heart Association announced yesterday that Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher and chairman of the board of The New York Times, would receive the association's 1961 Heart-of-the-Year Award tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Villanova broke open a tight game in the final eleven minutes tonight to rout Canisius, 108 -- 77, in the second half of a double-header at the Palestra. The Wildcats scored 41 points while limiting the Griffins to 18 in the closing drive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -- An experiment is under way at the Paramount studio that will be watched carefully by other companies. For Paramount has decided to make a picture here that would be generally considered suitable only for the comparatively limited audiences of the art houses.

Carmine G. De Sapio, embattled leader of Tammany Hall, outdrew Mayor Wagner in applause last night as the two appeared together in a public forum for the first time since the Mayor called for Mr. De Sapio's resignation.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached for it to acquire through an exchange of stock the Jennings Radio Manufacturing Corporation of San Jose, Calif. Jennings develops and makes high power vacuum capacitors and switches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, overruling the objections of its staff, has approved for the first time a utility holding company's stock option plan. The company -- Middle South Utilities, Inc. -- must make three changes in its plan before the commission's approval becomes final.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored in every period tonight to defeat the Detroit Red Wings for the sixth time this season, 5 -- 2. The victory gave Chicago a 6-point lead over Detroit in their battle for third place in the National Hockey League race.

General Motors signed up yesterday for an exhibition at the New York World's Fair of 1964-65 that, it hopes, will win more public applause than its famous "Futurama" at the 1939-40 World's Fair.

RICHMOND, Ky., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Eastern Kentucky upset the Louisville Cardinals, 80 -- 74, in basketball tonight, gaining revenge for an earlier defeat. It was the thirty-first home court-victory in a row for the Maroons.
Rare funerary art and other precious objects from one of the most flourishing periods in Chinese history will be exhibited today at Asia House, 112 East Sixty-fourth Street.

The Masters Nursery and the Masters Children's Center will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the April 11 performance of "13 Daughters." Don Ameche will star in the new musical, which opens at the 54th Street Theatre on March 2.
Net income of the Continental Can Company dropped to $27,803,000 last year from $40,009,000 in 1959, Gen. Lucius D. Clay (U.S.A., retired), chairman, reported yesterday.

A Queens Republican group offered its aid free yesterday to any Queens driver wishing to challenge the ban on nonessential motor traffic imposed by Mayor Wagner in the snow clean-up.

Peggy Wood celebrated a double event yesterday -- her birthday (which one she said she could not remember since she had "lied so much about it") and her fiftieth year in the theatre (which she could not forget in the light of what "a wonderful thing" it has meant to her).

TORONTO, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich scored his forty-second goal of the season tonight in leading the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-3 victory over the New York Rangers. The triumph increased Toronto's National Hockey League lead over the idle Montreal Canadiens to 5 points.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday an estimated net income for 1960 of $330,000,000, or $3.20 each on the 103,143,349 shares outstanding. This represented an increase of 14 per cent above $290,467,000, or $2.82 a share, in 1959.

THE spark that was supposed to light the way toward finding a nickname for the new National League team in New York has now become a five-alarm fire. It was ignited innocently enough last week at a family gathering in the home of Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, chief stockholder of the ball club.

George Brezel and Stanley Rappoport, realty investors, have purchased the six-story elevator apartment building at 36-08 Twenty-ninth Street, Astoria, Queens. The building, which is at the corner of Thirty-sixth Avenue, occupies a plot 137 by 100 feet and contains seventy-two apartments.

LOWER HUTT, New Zealand, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- An English all-star cricket team scored 215 runs today and then claimed four Hutt Valley wickets for 91 runs by the close of play on the first day of a two-day match.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Caution was indicated by President Kennedy today on an anti-recession tax cut as he suggested putting the money into "programs which in the long run may be more useful."

The First National City Bank of New York is about to announce plans to acquire the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains. The move would be the fourth consolidation to be proposed by major New York City banks in recent days.

Electric power production slipped to 15,072,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from a record 15,361,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 14,203,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens bombarded the Boston Bruin goalie, Bruce Gamble, with forty-eight shots tonight and scored a 5-1 National Hockey League victory. The Canadiens now trail the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs by 3 points.
The proposed 55,000-seat baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park moved a step closer to realization yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A leader of the New York Legislature cautioned today against "an eager thirst for instant Federal aid" for unemployment insurance, medical care for the aged, and public welfare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

Fluid fast-break patterns highlighted a second-half rally that carried West Virginia to a 75-60 triumph over New York University last night in the wind-up of intercollegiate basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Senator Francis Case said today that Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall had given the impression of a link between Federal projects and the vote of House members in the rules fight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg had agreed to his request to look into the situation created by a strike of Northwest Airlines flight engineers that has grounded the company's planes since October.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate confirmed President Kennedy's nomination of Dr. Robert C. Weaver as Federal housing chief tonight. The action ended three days of Southern opposition.
BRAWLEY. Calif., Feb. 9--The first ViolenCe in the threeWeek-old lettuce ..s'~rike in the imperial Nalley.=resulted in the .injury. of' four nmn today'and ;he arrest of thit'~y-six others.
It is possible to make a person hypersensitive to a substance he has never encountered, according to research described here yesterday.
" The Rich Boy," F. Scott Fitzgerald's short story about the emotional unfulfillment of a wealthy youth during the "jazz age," will be filmed here next summer by Richard Burton and Sidney Lumet.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced today his intention to establish a Royal Commission for investigating the ownership, production and sale of Britain's newspapers and periodicals.
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 9 -- United States military personnel may soon be stationed on Australian soil for the first time since the end of World War II.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Feb. 9 -- A meeting between; PreSident Kennedy and Presi-' dent Adolfo Lopez Matros o M exic0' was suggested today by Senator Mike Mansfield, United: States Senate fnajority leader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The electrical equipment concerns that pleaded guilty to rigging bids on Government contracts were put on formal notice today that the Government was going to sue them for millions of dollars.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 2 -- Two youths are accused of having broken into Mineola High School at the height of the snowstorm early Saturday morning and stolen highly poisonous chemicals and laboratory equipment for their own experiments.
The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad has renewed its wooing of the Chicago and North Western Railway with a merger as its intention, it was learned yesterday from reliable sources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Feed grains and other surplus foods will be offered as inducements to South American countries initiating land reforms as part of a program to improve living conditions.
Stocks boiled furiously yesterday in a move that was variously interpreted as a confirmation of a bull market and a "buying climax" that must soon bring a decline.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art last night gave a boost to Noel Lee and Paul Makanowitzky. It did so by presenting the young piano-violin duo as the fifth and final attraction in its distinguished sonata series.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the dismissal of a $6,000,000 libel and injurious falsehood suit brought by Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., against the American Newspaper Guild and its principal officers.

S. Clark Beise, president of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, said yesterday that he foresaw no substantial change in long-term interest rates for a long time to come.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Commenting on the Federal Trade Commission's anti-trust action against American-Marietta Company, Robert E. Pflaumer, president, said that while no formal notification had been received, the acquisitions complained of were reviewed by legal counsel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Treasury borrowed $400,000,000 of new cash in last Monday's refinancing of maturing debt, according to the preliminary results published today. The Treasury's offer of 3 1/4 per cent, eighteen-month notes to replace a $6,938,000,000 issue of certificates maturing this month drew $18,974,000,000 of subscriptions.

Bedlam will reign this weekend in the normally placid upper New York communities of Potsdam and Canton. The showdown games of the Tri-State Hockey League, modestly described by its fanatical devotees as "the biggest little league in the land," will be played there.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Union of American Hebrew Congregations said today that it would open here next fall a "social action" center to "implement the ethical principles of Reform Judaism."

James-D.-Zellerbach, former United" .qtates ' Ambassador to Italy, charged yesterday that ,,certain of our.partners" in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization' were "lending 'a knife" to the'Soviet Union "to cut our ~Collective~ throats" 'in trade with ~ neutralist countries.'
THE Rev. Mr. Davidson, who reluctantly succumbed to the charms of Sadie Thompson, was not a clergyman after all -- according to a version of the story on television last night.
ATLANTA, Feb. 9 -- Thirty-nine more Negro students went to jail here today after having engaged demonstrations in segregated private restaurants. promised to follow them tomorrow.
SAN JUAN, P. R,, Feb. 9 -- ] Bolivar Pagan, former Resident[ Commissioner of Puerto Rico inI Washington, died today after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

The fund for The New York Times Neediest Codes received $6,303.22 yesterday from forty-nine contributors. So far in this forty-ninth annual appeal, 14,416 contributions have been received for a total of $571,813.10.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) -The rocket ship X-15 set an unofficial speed mark of 2,275 miles an hour Tuesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System drew from the hip last night and blasted away with "Gunslinger," a crisp, slick Western fashioned in the professionally competent tradition of Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -President Kennedy said today that religion should not be viewed as a weapon in the "cold war" but as a "great reservoir of spiritual resources" for meeting the challenges facing the nation.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 9 -King Savang Vathana will meet soon with Premier Boun Oum and other members of Laos' pro-Western Cabinet to discuss proposals for ending the civil war.
DETROIT, Feb. 9 -- Temporary plant shutdowns in the automobile industry next week will make about 67,500 workers idle.
The State of Texas sold yesterday an issue of $12,500,000 of serial bonds to help war veterans finance the purchase of land.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 -- Racial integration took a long step forward here tonight in the field of serious music. Henry Lewis, a Negro, conducted the Los Angeles Philharmonic.
Mayor Wagner lifted his ban on nonessential driving in Manhattan yesterday, but both he and Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy urged motorists to substitute a self-imposed ban.

The bond market largely marked time yesterday. Price fluctuations came to a near impasse as dealers showed reluctance to bid up prices and as institutional investors had little to press for sale in the market.

DOCTORS treat sick people. This amazing news, revealed free as a public service this morning, is the hidden message behind a book of instant psychology called "The Split-Level Trap."* The impression left by this book's shrill warning is that if you live in a house in the suburbs you, your wife and your children may think that you're happy but you're really sick-sick-sick.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Tom Hawkins, the former Notre Dame star playing his second year in the National Basketball Association, turned in his finest game as a professional last night to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 120-103 victory over the St. Louis Hawks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -President Kennedy is reportedly planning to drop the Operations Coordinating Board from the National Security Council.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals spurted in the final period tonight to gain a 119-115 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game at the Arena.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- The Army hockey team spotted Amherst a goal and then poured in eight straight tallies in the first two periods and went on to win, 11 to 1, today at Smith Rink.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (:;AP) --Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jeb~ey, i today introduced a bill tha~ he said would encourage the proper development Of: N~w JerseY!s 30,O00-acre meadowland.
BOSTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -Bernard Goldfine, industrialist, was adjudged mentally competent today to stand trial on charges of evading nearly $800,000 in income and corporate taxes.

President Kennedy has made it plain that in dealing with Soviet Russia he proposes to negotiate from a position of strength. To that end he is taking steps not only to increase our own military power, but also to fortify our alliances. This applies especially to "our central and most important" North Atlantic alliance.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The construction of a block-long boardwalk structure that will include an open roof deck seating 1,400 persons for band concerts and operettas is under way here. It is expected to be ready this summer.

As President Kennedy said in his balance-of-payments message to Congress earlier this week, "a return to protectionism is not a solution." It was of particular importance for him to make that statement at that time, both to put a damper on the superficial and specious arguments to the contrary, and to give needed reassurance on his own intentions in the light of protectionist remarks he himself had made during the campaign.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Rival political party leaders disagreed today on the accuracy of a report by three Democrats that there was no basis for Republican charges of Wholesale election frauds in Chicago last Nov. 8.

The H.C. Bohack Company, the supermarket chain, has leased three properties for new markets in the metropolitan area. Rentals under the leases will aggregate almost $3,000,000, according to John J. Reynolds, Inc., the broker in the deals.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Two Mahopac Curling Club rinks won first-round matches today as the sixth annual Cuthbertson bonspiel began on the St. Andrew's Golf Club indoor ice arena.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Kennedy Administration took issue today with the British Government's view on the question of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
The presidency of Trans World Airlines, Inc., still goes begging.

TALLAHASSE, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI) -- A Florida legislative investigating committee said today it had uncovered plans for a suit seeking to cut off millions of dollars in health, welfare, education and other Federal funds to Southern States practicing segregation.

C.L. Sulzberger's column in your issue of Jan. 30 reports an attack by some American trade union spokesmen upon the International Labor Organization as a result of its two recently published reports on the trade union situation in the U.S.S.R. and in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Defense Department reported today that it had placed its first contracts for jet military transport planes.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 9 -- Pinhas Lavon resigned today as secretary general of Histdrut, the general labor federation of Israel.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer met today in the strictest privacy to thresh out their differences on European questions before tomorrow's summit conference of the six-nation European Community.

M.H. Lamston, Inc., a variety store chain, has leased a store and basement, containing a total of about 11,000 square feet, in the apartment building under construction at 263-77 Third Avenue, on the corner of Twenty-first Street.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Feb. 9 -- Union leaders and officials of the Panama Canal Company expressed approval today of President Kennedy's suspension of the Presidential order directing the Panama Line to halt commercial business after tomorrow.
A Pro-Am Bowl-O-Rama, pitting professional against amateur bowlers, will be added to the National Outdoor Exposition that will start a nine-day run at the New York Coliseum on Feb. 18.
The Chrysler Corporation, faced with law suits and a possible proxy fight this spring, reported yesterday a sharp improvement in sales and earnings for 1960.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- International financial officials said today that Russia was reported to have resumed sending gold to the London market to buy foreign currencies such as dollars and pounds sterling.

THE steady disappearance of natural country before the advance of housing has made it increasingly difficult for field trial clubs interested in running pointers and setters to find suitable grounds in the East.

Raw power failed last night under the relentless pressure of all-court play. Orlando Sirola of Italy was upset by Crawford Henry of Atlanta in the opening round of the national indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Leonard Bernstein's tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic will continue for another seven years, according to the terms of a contract agreed upon recently by the conductor and the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 8 -- Sir Edgar Whitehead, Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, announced tonight that a referendum on constitutional reforms would probably be held in June.

BRANTFORD, Ont., Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Ralph C. Tees, president of the Guardian Trust Company of Montreal, today was elected president of Cockshutt Farm Equipment, Ltd., succeeding Benno Bechhold of New York who resigned earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -Mahomedali Currim Chagla, Indian Ambassador to the United States, said today that his country was fearful of Chinese Communist "expansionism" and therefore was "vitally interested" in a neutral Laos.

Brooklyn's Cadman Plaza slum-clearance project, embroiled in controversy since Robert Moses' days as Title I chief here, moved close to realization yesterday with the designation of Max Mishkin as tentative sponsor of cooperative housing on the site.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved unanimously a proposal to hire paid full-time directors of medical services for Harlem and Morrisania Hospitals.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- The state Department of Public Works exhibited plans today to cut a new superhighway through twenty-nine miles of some of the finest estates and golf club in the East.

Your Feb. 7 Topics was unbelievable, inaccurate condemnation of public servants. It is incredible that The Times would lend its reputable name to a "pipe dream" of a "man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Severe ice and snow throughout much of the East contributed to decreased freight loadings in the week ended on Feb. 4, the rail and truck industries reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Kennedy laid before a divided Congress today a broad program of Federal insurance to provide medical care for the aged.

IN honor of Lincoln's birthday, many of the leading supermarket chains are talking turkey right now -- and in very persuasive terms. Large-size birds are being offered for only 39 cents a pound at a number of outlets, while in a few stores Beltsville turkeys retail for the same price.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The more the Kennedy Administration studies its new responsibilities the more conscious it becomes of the complexity and interconnection of its domestic and foreign problems.

Playboy Magazine, which has scored a success in the publishing field and has been trying to exploit this success in a variety of endeavors -- a syndicated television series, a tourist service, jazz festivals and key clubs -- is planning to start a new magazine early in the fall.

This is a day big in history as Niagara Falls begins generating electricity at the New York State Power Authority's development. The battle had been long and hard fought. But now the first of thirteen huge generators will begin to send out power; on completion date in 1963 installed capacity will be 2,190,000 kilowatts, making this the free world's largest hydroelectric installation.

CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Mobil Oil of Canada, Ltd., an affiliate of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., has announced the appointment of Owen H. Blexrud as president, succeeding A. O. Detmar.

WHAT'S good for tall girls and women with aching backs, vertigo and weary arches has slowly but surely become very high fashion. The shoe with the thick, low heel received the final seal of style approval yesterday when the mannequins showing Mainbocher's spring collection strode across his salon wearing black satin evening pumps with one-and-a-half-inch heels.

LUANDA, Angola, Feb. 9 -- An uneasy calm hangs over this capital of Portugal's largest and richest overseas possession. Sudden riots last week caught the authorities here off guard; they concede that trouble may flare up again.

President Kennedy yesterday presented in his message to Congress a masterly over-all view of the nation's health problems and a challenging, if somewhat staggering, bill of particulars as to how he thinks the Federal Government ought to deal with them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The White House announced today that John O. Crow would be appointed acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs. He will be the first person of American Indian descent to head the Bureau of Indian Affairs since 1871.

This is the time of year when pleasure boating officers, as another season afloat is about to begin, like to review the statistics of last year. They count noses, so to speak, and this tells them what they can expect for 1961.
The Radio Corporation of America has arranged for the private sale to institutional investors of $100,000,000 of promissory notes due May 1, 1986. The interest rate was 5 3/8 per cent.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Willie Mays, baseball's highest paid player, today returned his signed 1961 contract calling for about $85,000, the amount he received in 1960.
Robert A. Low, assistant to Mayor Wagner, said yesterday he would try to unseat State Senator John P. Morrissey as Democratic leader in Yorkville.

Faced with almost certain deficit in the Board of Estimate his plan to abolish all local borough assessments trough amending the board's Queens Borough President John T. Clancy proposed a compromise yesterday.

HARTFORD, Feb. 9 -- Charles Gould Morris, lawyer and business and civic leader for more than fifty years, died here today at the home of a son. He was 90 .years old. His home was in Sandy Hook, Newtown; Conn.
TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- Former Superior Court Judge Richard J. Hughes appeared tonight to be the front-runner for the Democratic organization's designation as candidate for Governor.

Mrs. Dorothy Vincent Jones of Milwaukee, Wis., has receive a Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust fellowship to finish a narrative history of "a backyard experiment in civilization" conducted by the United State Government in the mid-nineteenth century.
DETROIT, Feb. 9 (UPI) -Gordie Howe and Alex Delvecchio sparked the Detroit Red Wings to a 4-2 victory over the New York Rangers tonight in a National Hockey League game before 8,861 at the Olympia.

The United States monetary gold stock declined by $26,000,000 to $17,415,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The latest decline compared with a $9,000,000 loss a week earlier and brought the total outflow since the first of the year to $352,000,000.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Two jazz bands and an estimated total of 10,000 persons bid farewell today to Alphonse Picou, the famed clarinetist who died Saturday at the age of 82.

HARTFORD, Feb. 9 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad plans to introduce a weekly commutation ticket on April 9. It also expects to rehabilitate 100 commuter and long distance cars this year.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 9 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, already the country's biggest union, made plans today to broaden its jurisdiction to take in all unorganized workers in any industry.

The Health Department yesterday padlocked the kitchens and dining rooms of a private school in Brooklyn after an outbreak of at least thirty-four cases of hepatitis among its students. Seven suspected cases also were under investigation.

The closed-circuit television showing at Madison Square Garden of the March 13 heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson will be a benefit for the New York Heart Association. The fight will be at Convention Hall in Miami Beach.
A ten-car IRT train that had just been repaired in an IND yard broke down again as it was leaving the yard and disrupted service on the IND "A" line for thirty-six minutes yesterday.

Members of the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church will start their annual spring party at noon on April 18 in the ballroom of the Pierre. The program for the event includes luncheon, a fashion show and tables for bridge and canasta.
DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 8 -- The leaders of this tiny republic are conducting an unusal experiment.
Futures prices for commodities on the New York exchanges were mixed in rather dull trading yesterday. Six of the major commodities showed price rises, four showed declines, and three were irregular.

BEFORE Franz Kline made his "break-through" into action painting and became, what he is today, one of the leaders of this school, he was a no less determined realist, some rollicking souvenirs of that period, panels painted in 1940 for the Bleecker Street Tavern in downtown New York, have now escaped their honky-tonk origins and may be seen at the Collector's Gallery, 49 West Fifty-third Street.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 9 -Mrs. William E. Waugh, former project manager of the White Plains Housing Authority, pleaded guilty in Westchester County Court today to charges of conspiracy and misappropriation of $45,000.

Directors of the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains, approved yesterday plans to merge with the First National City Bank of New York. The proposal had been approved earlier by directors of the New York City institution.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- An angry session of the House of Commons ended early this morning with the members in dispute over whether a vote had been taken on a preliminary resolution in the Government's plan to raise National Health Service contributions and charges.

Manhattan College gained its sixth basketball triumph of the campaign against five losses by defeating Adelphi, 79 -- 70, at the Jaspers' Riverdale gymnasium last night. Doug Rutlik sparked the Jaspers with 21 points. Joe Woltering led Adelphi with 19.

Jazz is turning up in all sorts of places these days. On Wednesday morning the Benny Goodman Quartet was reviving memories of the Swing Era in the toy department at Macy's. And last night, deep in the nether regions of the Museum of Modern Art, on the far side of an exhibition of movie posters, Dizzy Gillespie's Quintet could be heard mulling over the by gone days of bop.
Sales and earnings of the Borg-Warner Corporation last year were substantially below the high levels of 1959, the company reported yesterday.
THE classic theatre of India, as transmuted by Rabindranath Tagore in "The King of the Dark Chamber," is an unusual experience.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 9 (AP) -Two attorneys filed suit today asking damages of $750 million from General Electric Company, alleging injury to fifty million consumers as a result of price-fixing.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Ralph Boston and Irvin (Bo) Roberson, America's best broad jumpers, will try again for a 26-foot indoor leap tomorrow night in the seventeen annual Philadelphia Inquirer track and field meet.
TWO facets of advanced bidding figured in this deal, which was played in a recent rubber-bridge game in New York -- the redouble of a slam contract and the lead against a doubled slam contract.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The 65,000-member Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, which had feuded with Elwood R. Quesada, former Federal Aviation Administrator, welcomed his successor today with a pledge of cooperation.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The Mayor ordered a halt today to nighttime police raids on residents with overdue library books and assured delinquent borrowers that they would be spared "unnecessary personal indignities" in the future.

Renata Tebaldi and Barry Morell, as Mimi and Rodolfo, headed the cast that performed Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Kennedy Administration has urged the Soviet Union to exercise restraint on critical East-West issues while the new Government is reviewing its global policies.

The State Commission Against Discrimination ordered a Uniondale, L.I., barber yesterday to take down a sign that reads "Kinky Haircut -- S5" and to begin immediately to cut the hair of Negroes without discrimination.
DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -Automobile production this week will be 37.8 per cent below that of the week ended on Feb. 13, 1960, Automotive News said today.
An official of the National Council of Churches said yesterday he could see "no possibility" that the council or any of its agencies would set up a board to review and rate entertainment films.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -Soybean futures reversed direction twice on broad swings today on the Board of Trade. They closed mixed and far below the peaks for the day.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Italian Minister of the Interior, Mario Scelba, ordered an inquiry today into the "commuters' riot" here yesterday in which a mass protest against a sudden bus strike exploded into a three-hour battle with the police.

Gold production in the free world rose 5 per cent in 1960 to 34,300,000 fine ounces, according to Dr. Miroslav A. Kriz of the First National City Bank of New York. The total was 13,200,000 ounces above the level in 1945, the post-war low, but it was 2,400,000 ounces less than that of 1940, the record.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Al Severance, bending under the win-or-else pressure of modern athletics, resigned as basketball coach at Villanova University today, effective at the end of this season.

Drawn by what he called "a long-term contract at a very generous salary" as a sports broadcaster, Frank Gifford, star halfback of the New York Giants, decided yesterday to give up professional football.
The American dream to be one's own boss was put on display at the New York Coliseum yesterday with details, blueprints, specifications and price tags.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, warned today against "proposals to sharply reduce production" of agricultural commodities.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 193,731,000 board feet; compared with 197,830,000 the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure totaled 237,535,000 board feet.

Jack Fugazy, executive director of Feature Sports, Inc., canceled plans yesterday for a May 27 light heavyweight title fight between Archie Moore, recognized in some states as the champion, and Eric Schoeppner of Germany.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Each of thousands of United States servicemen in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East is trying to tell the United Service Organization, in twenty-five words or less, why his girl back home is most qualified for a free trip abroad to visit him -- with her mother.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Three golf pros carded 66's and shared a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $30,000 Phoenix open today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senator Stuart Symington said today that information on the "missile gap" was withheld from President Kennedy by the Eisenhower Administration during the election campaign last fall.
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- A leading Soviet space scientist denied today that there was a man or any animal life aboard the Soviet sputnik launched six days ago.
A novel that caused political and literary controversy in Poland when it was published there several years ago is being adapted for the Broadway stage.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 18 points (25 to 90 cents a bale) yesterday. The volume was estimated at close to 40,000 bales for the day.
JOSEPH ILEO has been a man alone much of his life, a pacifist in a land of violent men, moderate in his views, soft in voice and quiet in behavior.
A Board of Education member said yesterday that he would fight to end the secrecy now surrounding the board's meetings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate and House Republican leaders declared today their personal opposition to President Kennedy's proposal to provide medical care for the aged through Social Security.
TODAY'S crafts collector often is as concerned with the display of his possessions as with the selection. There are only so many table tops and shelves to which a bowl or plaque can be relegated.
BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- East Germany accused the United States Administration today of pursuing a policy on the brink of war over Berlin.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP)-William R. Hopkins, City Manlager of Cleveland during one of the most constructive periods in its history, died last night at his home. He was 91 years old.
A VEGETABLE has caused almost as much stir in Paris as the flapper look in fashion. It is the artichoke that has provided inspiration for the latest hair style by French coiffeur Alexandre.

Encampment for Citizenship has chosen the April 4 performance of "Mary, Mary" for its annual theatre benefit. The new Jean Kerr comedy starring Barbara Bel Geddes is scheduled to open at the Helen Hayes Theatre on March 8.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Profit taking increased in the stock market here today but industrial shares still scored considerably more rises than falls.

William Saroyan, who returned to this country last wek after an absence of two years, will appear on "Omnibus" to discuss and present samplings of avant-garde drama. The program will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on March 5 from 5 to 6 P.M.

The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that continued development costs of its commercial jet transport program had erased profits that the company expected to make in the fourth quarter of 1960.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve Bank System rose by $113,000,000 to $179,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose by $83,000,000 from a revised figure the week before to $627,000,000.
Delays caused by involved Board of Estimate procedures were described last night as having cost the city "scores of millions of dollars" in extra costs for public works since World War II.

Two police lieutenants who had been passed over for promotion to captain as a result of Civil Service Commission procedures won a four-year fight for a review of their Civil Service examinations yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Details of the Dreadnought, a British nuclear submarine whose power plant was provided by the United States, apparently had been obtained by one of five persons accused of espionage by the British Government.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Two serious accidents on the treacherous zigzag curve marred today's final drills before the two-man world bobsled championships open on the Olympic run Saturday.
A 67-year-old fencer collapsed at the New York Athletic Club last evening and, moments later, his heart stopped beating.
