Governor Rockefeller was caught between two pressures yesterday as his aid-to-education plan continued to stir controversy.

GALLON, Ohio, Feb. 9 (AP) -- An Erie-Lackawanna Railroad passenger train collided with a truck just east of this north-central Ohio community today. A woman train passenger was thrown under the diner and killed.
GENEVA, Feb, 9. -- The newspaper Tribune de Geneve questioned today the expected choice of Earl E.T. Smith as United States Ambassador to Switzerland.

A five-story walk-up apartment building at 1596 York Avenue, just off the northeast corner of East Eighty-fourth Street, has been sold by Bernard S. Schwartz. The property, 25 by 98 feet, is a block west of Carl Schurz Park.
IN the winter sunshine the ice that chokes the mouth of the Hudson River glitters and sparkles as if it were the raw material of gems.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he favored the submission of a proposed new Charter to the city's voters at the general election on Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A privilege that Government agencies enjoy in purchasing transportation is one of the prime causes of rate wars and should be withdrawn, the Senate Surface Transportation subcommittee was told today.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Motor Vehicle Department reported today it had ordered fewer driver's licenses revoked or suspended in 1960 than in the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- In one of the largest antimerger cases it ever started, the Federal Trade Commission today accused American-Marietta Company, Chicago, of violating the antitrust laws by acquiring forty-nine corporations from coast to coast.
Charles Ufford of the Harvard Club retained his Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A honors last night at the University Club courts.

A SHOCKING thing happen last weekend. Yale lost a dual swimming meet. If this is not quite so cataclysmic or historic as the defeat of the Persian fleet by the Greeks in the Battle of Salamis, it still ranks as a naval disaster of considerable significance. What makes it so noteworthy is that it marks the first Eli setback in this form of aquatic competition in sixteen years.
NIAGARA FALLS, Feb. 9 -Governor Rockefeller predicted tonight that the new $720,000,000 Niagara hydroelectric project would create at least 6,000 new jobs in this area.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- The Soviet Union protested today against "a bandit attack" by a French jet fighter on an airliner carrying Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet Chief of State, to Guinea on a state visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A bill to provide medical care for all Social Security beneficiaries and 4,000,000 others not covered by Social Security was introduced today by Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens.
Two major highway reconstruction projects in Queens were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Both projests are being expedited for the 1964-65 World's Fair.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. (AP) -- Doris Phillips upset Curtis Cup golfer early today and then played down to the nineteenth hole to win a semifinal berth in the forty-third Palm Beach women's amateur championship.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 -- An engineers' report today indicated that meat and produce wholesalers would be able to make substantial savings through the New Jersey public market scheduled to go into operation here in 1963.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Kennedy Administration expects a budget deficit of $1,000,000,000 this year instead of the hairline surplus that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower predicted three weeks ago.

MIAMI, Feb. 9 -- Staretta, Leonard P. Sasso's 4-year-old filly with a stakes background, won the feature race at Hialeah today. With Jack Yother keeping her in front all the way in the six-furlong sprint, Staretta finished a length ahead of Harold H. Polk's Sunelia.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- A parents' committee today completed efforts to effect a 100 per cent attendance boycott tomorrow at the predominantly Negro Lincoln elementary school.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9 -- Marshal Chen Yi, Foreign Minister of Communist China, hailed tonight the "close friendship and monolithic solidarity" between China and the Soviet Union. He spoke at a dinner in Peiping in honor of a Soviet trade and economic delegation.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Kathy Cornelius of Phoenix, Ariz., care a four-under-par 67 today take a three-stroke lead in $7,500 St. Petersburg women open golf championship.

In the face of a sharp drop in earnings last year, the Robertshaw-Fulton Controls Company cut its quarterly dividend yesterday to 25 cents a share from the 37 1/2 cents a share paid in previous quarters. The dividend will be distributed on March 20 to shareholders of record of March 6.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Oral arguments on motions to dismiss a case against two alleged Russian spies were continued today until March 6.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The new Postmaster General disclosed today he had asked the Civil Service Commission to review the standards now used in selecting the nation's postmasters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Kroger being held in London on spy charges were, in fact, Morris Cohen and his wife, Lola, United States citizens and former residents of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Labor Department reported today that unemployment continued to rise in January, reaching a post-war high for the month. Half the 150 biggest production centers were on the department's depressed list.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prince Frederick of Prussia, a grandson of Kaiser Wilhelm II, won the right today to claim compensation from a British fund for a Silesian castle confiscated by the post-war Polish Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Kennedy's proposals to meet the problem of medical care for those population groups with whom, he told Congress today, the problem is most acute, deviate from his and other previous programs in two important particulars. With these he has sought to meet some of the criticisms which have been made of previous related proposals, including his own of 1960.

Uniform No. 5, officially retired by the Yankees on April 28, 1952, is to be reactivated -unofficially and for a limited time. For its wearer, Joe DiMaggio, the Yankee Clipper, who is enshrined in baseball's Hall of Fame, is returning to the Bombers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga Province, said in a letter to the United Nations today that any attempt to disarm his forces would cause chaos in the Congo.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The president of Eastern Airlines says Florida's winter tourist season is off 5 to 10 per cent from last year's record crop of visitors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Feb. 4 were 5 per cent below the year-earlier level.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 9 -- President Joseph Kasavubu proclaimed the end of the Congo's five-month-old military regime today and named a Provisional Government composed of members of the suspended Parliament.

MAINBOCHER has changed -- but only his address. His gentle and very personal attitude toward fashion is still as indestructible and beautiful as ever. Even his elegant, new salon, which duplicates the white walls, mirrors and caramel-brown carpet of his former one, remains true to the enduring look that is Mainbocher.

The Board of Education yesterday restored the school holiday originally set for Monday in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, but it announced that classes would be held on Feb. 22, Washington's Birthday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 -Senator Thomas H. Kuchel, the Republican whip, criticized the Kennedy Administration here tonight as he delivered the traditional Lincoln Day speech before a partisan audience.

ROME, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The world featherweight champion, Davey Moore of Springfield, Ohio, easily outpointed the Italian champion, Raimondo Nobile, tonight in a ten-round, non-title fight. It was the Italian's first loss in twenty-five professional bouts.

UNION CITY, N.J. -- Feb. 10 -- A general-alarm fire raged out of control in the heart of the shopping district here for three hours tonight. A store owner who had another fire recently died of a heart attack while watching the blaze.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in a mid-winter crop report, said today that recent low temperatures had not caused undue damage to the important fall-sown winter wheat crop.
Elie Siegmeister put more than thirty years worth of his music on display late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Joint Economic Committee of Congress was told today that a temporary tax cut, although potentially dangerous, could be a powerful anti-recession weapon.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The new president of the National Association of Broadcasters called on the radio-television industry today to improve its product voluntarily before the Government steps in.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 10 -- The official radio of secessionist Katanga Province announced today that Patrice Lumumba, the deposed Congo Premier, and two fellow prisoners fled last night while being transferred from one secret place of confinement to another.
MIAMI, Feb. 10 -- The Hialeah Turf Cup will be contested at Hialeah tomorrow, with six foreign-bred horses competing against six American-bred grass runners.
Net income of the Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation declined last year to $18,600,000 from $19,706,022 in 1959, the company disclosed yesterday in a preliminary report.

DIRK UIPKO STIKKER, who was reported yesterday to be the likely successor to Paul-Henri Spaak as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, lives with a legend. It concerns the delicate negotiations he once conducted with the sovereign he honors and ad mires, Queen Juliana of the Netherlands.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Two United States Marine corporals, one of whom saw a bobsled for the first time last year, will carry half of America's hopes in the world two-man bobsled championship that starts on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Run tomorrow.
A dome of the heavens, with the sun, stars and planets in place, hangs over the third graders at the Little Red School House, a private school at 196 Bleecker Street.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The theory that the universe is being created continuously out of new matter has been challenged in the opinion of a famous radio astronomer.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The Theatre National Populaire, which has already adapted works from Greek and German this season, turned last night to the very particular English of Sean O'Casey.
Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that 1960 operating revenues were $276,072,958, against $276,188,799 in 1959.

The Mayor's all-city schoolboy track meet last night had just about everything except the Mayor. It had seven meet records, a tie for the team title between Lane and Boys and a 600-yard race that really was 620 yards.
Jacques Plante, the Montreal goalie who wears a face mask, will be in the nets when the Canadiens face the New York Rangers in Madison Square Garden at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

ATLANTA, Feb. 10 -- While some 100 persons have gone to jail deliberately in a drive to break down racial barriers at Southern lunch counters, a student leader indicated today that the movement might be stopped.

Motors and liquors were the only groups to hold their own in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Three of the five passenger car makers gained small fractions and the others were unchanged.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The following conditions were reported today to the State Department of Commerce:
IRVINGTON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- A storm of protests over prolonged emergency duty of firemen here is matching in intensity the snowstorms that have kept the men on the job.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 10 -- Al Kaemmerlen and Pete Campbell paced Princeton's undefeated Ivy League basketball leaders to a 66-61 victory over Brown tonight.

A raise of about $2,000, putting him in or around the $18,000-a-year category, has made Ralph Willard Terry a happy hurler. The right-hander, who recently married and can make good use of the extra money, yesterday became the twenty-fourth Yankee player to have signed his 1961 contract.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 10 -- Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino today outlined a plan to expand and liberalize the state's student-loan program to provide aid to higher education on a "massive scale."

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- A hearing on a state plan for a $39,000,000 superhighway from Harrison to Brewster ended at 1:50 A.M. today after twelve hours of caustic denunciation of the plan and its designers.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer has received a message from President Kennedy with which he is highly pleased.
A drive for a state law putting all transfers and adoptions of children under court supervision was opened here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 120 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Buerau of Labor Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- President Kennedy gave his full support today to legislation designed to create an office of international travel and suggested that its director be made an Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) Grain futures prices generally continued their downward trend today while soybeans withstood a moderate flurry of profit taking and finished with gains running to more than 3 cents a bushel.
A Long Island City Magistrate refused yesterday to issue warrants for the arrest of three South Carolina white men accused of attempting to kidnap a Negro minister in Queens.
An insurance company was held responsible yesterday for the difference between a policy holder's $10,000 automobile liability limit and a much larger award by a jury.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The heads of government of six European states ended their meeting here tonight with questions as to the degree and kind of political unity they want apparently still unresolved.

The 269-foot Coast Guard icebreaker Westwind, cutting a path for commercial shipping in the ice-filled Hudson River between Albany and here, will reach the city limits today, the Coast Guard said here yesterday.
TUNIS, Feb. 10 -- President Kennedy has indicated his intention to invite President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to visit him in Washington, according to reliable reports reaching here.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- Sufficient time has elapsed since the Kennedy Administration took office to detect certain shifts in foreign policy approaches. Broad strategic lines and aspirations remain unchanged; but tactical methods seem to be altering.
Fairleigh Dickinson held Brooklyn College to 3 points in the first seven minutes and then went on to a 90-57 Tri-State League basketball victory at the Kingsmen's court last night.

DOES the much-discussed desire of the married woman who is a college graduate to return to the job market have a basis in rumor or in fact? A survey being conducted by the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor and the Alumnae Advisory Center, Inc., is aimed at finding out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Treasury bill rates continued their pronounced upward movement in today's sale of next week's issues. The sale was held today because Monday, the regular selling day, will be a holiday in the principal financial centers.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union was probably a sort of gold "speculator" in the last three months, and the experiment has cost it money.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons tonight scored one of their rare victories over the Boston Celtics, defeating the National Basketball Association champions, 137 -- 134.

I have consistently refrained from lodging objections to The New York Times' editorial comments on my activities in the Congress, although your newspaper has quite frequently seen fit to print gratuitously insulting opinions about me.

The American Section of the International Association of Art Critics announced yesterday it had voted last month to censure John Canaday, art critic and art news editor of The New York Times, "for having treated a fellow critic in a manner unbecoming the profession of criticism."
LONDON, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- British newspapers welcomed today a scheduled Government inquiry into the press, but some of their employes were still dissatisfied.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Ten Negro physicians filed suit today against fifty-six nonpublic hospitals and five medical and hospital associations in the Chicago area, accusing them of conspiring since 1938 to keep Negroes off hospital staffs.

HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- The defection of a young Cuban military officer upset a purported plot last month to start revolts in Portugal and Spain, according to an article in the Cuban Government magazine Bohemia.
The American Bar Association is being asked to look into the reasons behind the growing number of consumer bankruptcies during the last decade.
The re-emergence of heavy auto travel on Manhattan's streets combined yesterday with snow-removal operations to create intermittent traffic snarls.

The America Corporation's consolidated net profit rose to an estimated $1,309,804, equal to 32 cents a share, on record sales of $31,588,000 in 1960. This was reported yesterday by Gordon K. Greenfield, president, at a luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
THE weather has not been kind to bridge tournaments lately. Tournaments scheduled to be played in New Jersey and Philadelphia over the last week-end were called off.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Government gave industry authority today to build SNAP generators. These may pump nuclear power someday into the instruments of space ships.

Geisinger Germain, realty operators, have purchased the five-story building on plot 160 by 100 feet at 541-55 West 204th Street, corner of Nagle Avenue. The property contains seventy-seven apartments and six stores.

Colonialism and racism are two features of contemporary life whose end is in sight. Where they persist unchanged, it is because of a refusal to recognize realities. No people are being more stubborn in rejecting the facts of twentieth-century life than the present rulers of Portugal.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 10 -- Attorneys for James R. Hoffa will move next Monday to kill a Federal indictment against the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Transportation Commission today announced the approval of a contract with the New Haven Railroad for summer passenger service between Cape Cod and New York. It also provides for connecting trains from Boston.
Strong activity in the new capital market is expected next week after the last two slow weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Kennedy will ask Congress next week to authorize a five-year program of aid to education that is expected to call for about $1,000,000,000 a year in new Federal outlays.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Mr. Ginn issued the following statement today:
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The price of gold continued to slide on the London bullion market today. It reached the lowest level since early in September.

J. Peter Grace, president of W.R. Grace Co., which has a vast network of businesses and investments throughout Latin America, has sponsored a pamphlet with an intriguing title: "It Is Not Too Late in Latin America."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The American Heart Association's Heart-of-the-Year Award was presented to Arthur Hays Sulzberger today in a White House ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Diplomatic sources said today that Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, former Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, had the backing of a majority of the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for the post of Secretary General.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 10 (UPI) -- State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Molinari today signed an order directing Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York to use $2,500,000 in pension funds of workers for Endicott Johnson Corporation to buy 89,000 shares of company stock now held by the Glen Alden Corporation.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers opened preliminary spring training in chilly and windy weather today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 10 -- The Belgian Senate met late tonight in an effort to finish action on the proposed economic and administrative reforms that evoked a Socialist strike in December and January.
Although the New York Knickerbockers suffered another setback at Madison Square Garden last night, their prestige went up a notch or two.

Pity the poor stockholder. Sometimes he is truly the forgotten man. The example this week of the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and other major electrical equipment companies is a sad case in point.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency outlined to airline and pilot representatives yesterday a proposal to reduce air-ground radio messages.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Two United States Government agencies, a group of private banks and the International Monetary Fund joined today in a multimillion-dollar package of assistance to Chile.
A GOOD many of the issues that bedevil our lives never do get solved, Judge Learned Hand once suggested -- but they do lose relative importance as we go on to other confrontations.
Two Navy transports will spend the next five months shuttling between the Congo port of Matadi and ports in Africa, Europe and Asia as troop carriers for the United Nations force in the Congo.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union was pictured today as agreeable to pursuing a policy of restraint while the Kennedy Administration formulated its foreign policy.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 10 -- Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman will fly to Kuala Lumpur, Malaya, tomorrow to join in "a frank and friendly informal exchange of views" with Prime Minister Tengku Abdul Rahman of Malaya and Foreign Secretary Felixberto M. Serrano of the Philippines.

VALENTINE gifts are more imaginative than ever this year at Bouquets a la Carte, 132 East Twenty-eighth Street. Perhaps the most original creation, picnic or no picnic, is the Valentine basket that contains a loaf of bread, a bottle of wine and a nosegay of flowers ($12.50).

In 1956 a group of distinguished Americans were called together to attempt an assessment of the major problems and opportunities likely to develop in the United States in the next ten years. From the meeting came six Rockefeller Panel reports that were published individually in 1958, 1959 and 1960.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 10 -- An avalanche of books is descending on the Public Library here as an aftermath of the jailing and fining of delinquent borrowers this week.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 10 -- Members of the Ceylon House of Representatives (lower house of Parliament) cautioned the Government today that, unless it lifted the duty on rubber exports as a temporary relief measure, many rubber plantations would have to go out of production.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Westinghouse announced today a two-point program designed "to see that nothing like this ever again happens."

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Industrial share prices turned irregular in the stock market here today. A report by the Federation of British Industries that orders were falling was held responsible for the reluctance of buyers, but selling was little more than routine.

Of late arrived the unhinging intelligence that mayhem may be committed against Paris' Pont des Arts, the best footbridge across the Seine in the heart of the city, cherished not only by the generality of mortals who love Paris but by Immortals, as well.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 10 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg, touring areas of high unemployment, said today: "We are in a full-fledged recession. I think it's time to say this and say it in no uncertain terms."
The Young Masters Series of concerts, in its second season at Carnegie Recital Hall, last night offered a program of chamber music played by Nancy Cirillo, violinist, and Lawrence Smith, pianist.

Millard E. Tydings will go down in the history of the Senate less for the legislation he sponsored, though there was plenty of that and some of it important, than for the two sensational battles -- of totally different kinds -- that he fought a dozen years apart. The first of these was his struggle as a "states' rights" Maryland conservative against the New Deal.
GENEVA, Feb. 10 -- An avalanche in eastern Switzerland struck a party of nineteen Swiss teen-agers and three adults today, killing at least eight of them. Three youngsters were unaccounted for.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The surge of the Niagara River has been used for more than 200 years to produce power, but the great potential of the full drop was tapped by the United States for the first time today.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Officials at the snow-plagued Bowie Race Course today said the horses definitely would run tomorrow for the first time since Feb. 1.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Attendance slumped at the Lincoln elementary school here today when Negroes conducted a day's boycott because of the Board of Education's decision to appeal a desegregation order in Federal District Court.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 10 -- "Musim hudjan the rainy season, has returned to Jakarta and massive equatorial down-pours have had a variety of by-products -- floods, food shortages, power failures, stalled cars, missing streets and even bits of fun.

The all-encompassing nature of Chopin's four Ballades make them both a challenge and a test for pianists. Many have tackled this formidable quartet in recordings. Few have played them consecutively in recital, as Jorge Bolet did last night.

FROM the look of current ski fashions, it might as well be spring. Winter sports enthusiasts have already taken up the call to colors that is in the air for spring clothes. There are a few dedicated skiers who still insist on conventional black and navy, but the ranks are diminishing.
Oddsmakers gave Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., an even-money chance yesterday to defeat Charlie Scott of Philadelphia in their main event in Madison Square Garden tonight.

A decorated war veteran who said he had been beaten by a patrolman after his arrest in Washington Square Park last May was convicted yesterday of disorderly conduct. He received a suspended sentence from Magistrate Walter J. Bayer in Manhattan Arrest Court because he had already spent ten days in jail.

The property formerly occupied by the J.L. Mott Company for the manufacture of porcelain and china plumbing fixtures at Third Avenue and 133d Street has been purchased by Lew and Charles Mauser, New Rochelle builders.

Copper futures prices rose on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday following the example of foreign markets, and new complications in the Congo in connection with the escape of Patricia Lumumba. Another factor was the shutdown of a big copper producer in Chile be cause of a strike.
Organized labor in this state has begun to lobby actively for Congressional approval of President Kennedy's economic program.

INDEPENDENCE, Kan., Feb. 10 (AP) -- A sub-Cabinet official of the Eisenhower Administration accused President Kennedy tonight of "gapmanship" -- playing on fears of a "missile gap" behind the Soviet Union during the campaign but admitting now he could not say whether there was a gap or not.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President and Mrs. Kennedy will get acquainted this weekend with Glen Ora, the estate they have leased in the hunt country of Middleburg, Va.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, will leave Washington next Wednesday on a month-long tour of a dozen African nations, the State Department announced today.

A new issue of $9,850,000 of 6 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Portland Terminal Company, a facility owned jointly by the Maine Central Railroad and the Boston and Maine Railroad, was placed on the market yesterday.

THOMAS SCHIPPERS took over the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon. The young American conductor started the first of his two weeks with the orchestra, and chose a program consisting of Schubert's "Tragic" Symphony, Debussy's Nocturnes and Prokofieff's "Alexander Nevsky."

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 10 -- The sixteenth session of the Conference Commission for Technical Cooperation in Africa, south of the Sahara, ended today with the adoption of five recommendations made by its technical committees.
Cinema 16 has announced new editions to its spring season of screenings, starting March 1.
Lent, the Christian Church's great season of penitence, prayer and fasting will begin on Wednesday. It will continue for forty days, not including Sundays, until April 1, the day before Easter.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey team extended its winning streak to ten games tonight with a 3-2 conquest of Clarkson Tech before 1,900 fans.
Cpl. John M. Cranston, the picture of a recruitment-poster Marine, defeated Ron Holmberg last night and scored the second major upset of the national indoor tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- A movement was pressed today to block the possible end of a steamship line that has provided for some Senators and House members free cruises to the Caribbean.

BREMEN, West Germany, Feb. 10 -- The age of managers and marketing analysts caught up this week with 70-year-old Carl F.W. Borgward, a rugged individualist, a do-it-yourself kind of man who is one of the pioneers of the automobile industry in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Kennedy named four experts on public administration today as consultants on "major issues affecting the structure and operations of government." They are:
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 10 -- Details of the recent death of Elsa, the African lioness raised as a domestic pet by Mr. and Mrs. George Adamson, were given by Mr. Adamson in a newspaper here today.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Dick Groat, the National League batting champion and most valuable player, today signed a 1961 contract with the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 10 points (15 to 50 cents a bale) yesterday.
Transactions in the Treasury's new 3 1/4 per cent notes due in 1962 furnished most of the business in the bond market yesterday.

Shelby County, Tenn., is planning the sale of $11,000,000 of bonds to finance school construction and other public improvements. The sale will take place on Feb. 28. The bonds will come due serially from 1962 to 1986.

In their first change of ownership since they were built in 1936, two six-story apartment buildings at 775 and 787 East 175th Street, the Bronx, have been sold by Loeb Associates, the builders. The houses occupy a plot 300 by 150 feet and contain 177 apartments.
SELDOM has the problem of rejuvenating shoes spoiled by winter snow and slush been more prevalent. Care and cleaning, however, can restore most shoes to more than just usable condition.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The French Government expressed "sincere regrets" tonight for the interception of a Soviet airliner carrying Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet chief of state, to Rabat, Morocco.

The New York Tuck Tapers defeated the Cleveland Pipers, 107 -- 99, last night in a National Industrial Basketball League game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. It was the Tapers' first victory over the Pipers this season.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 10 -- The West Indies Federation signed a treaty today with the United States under which the federation will reoccupy about 80 per cent of the land granted for military bases early in World War II.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that its research offered some hope eventually for narcotics addicts who wanted to get rid of the habit.

Weaver to be Federal Housing Administrator would have to wait ten days until the Senate had delivered itself of some complimentary speeches about Abraham Lincoln. This would have been too bad, because we think of Mr. Lincoln as the man who freed the American Negro from slavery, and Mr. Weaver is proud to have Negro ancestors.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- Istvan Rozsavolgyi eclipsed one of Ron Delany's records by winning the mile in 4 minutes 5.4 seconds tonight in the seventeenth annual Philadelphia Inquirer Games.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 10 -- A nt legislative campaign to ce more sanitary conditions meat distribution was decided upon today by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the Amalgamated meat Cutters and Butcher porkman's Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee said today that the Kennedy Administration had restored "a batch of Dean Acheson retreads" to power in foreign policy posts.
Two men arrested for armed robbery in Brooklyn yesterday admitted slaying a grocer in Manhattan Tuesday, the police said.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Yale, capitalizing on its foul-line accuracy, posted a 60-51 Ivy League basketball victory over Pennsylvania tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Freight tonnage on New York's 524-mile Barge Canal system dropped 8 per cent last year, the Department of Public Works reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Defense Department is planning increased emphasis on non-nuclear weapons and on armored cars, electronics equipment and transport planes in a series of amendments to the Eisenhower defense budget.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Domestic sugar producers and refiners declared their neutrality today on the two thorniest issues arising from proposed new sugar legislation.

Mayor Wagner described as "nonsense" yesterday any implication that he and Governor Rockefeller were partners in an effort to bypass Home Rule procedure in the drafting and adoption of a new City Charter.

Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he and the Board of Education had no reason to believe that its plans to exercise "fiscal freedom" would be opened by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 10 -- General Motors-Holden's, Ltd., announced today that it was dismissing 2,600 workers because of a sharp slump in automobile sales. The Australian press and radio treated the news with the gravity of a national catastrophe.

IT'S carnival time in many parts of the world, so why not in New York City? This may not be New Orleans or Quebec (and New York may not be much of a summer festival right now) but a pre-Lenten carnival is one of the finest tonics for frost bite and winter blues.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The difference in views over the question of Communist China's entry into the United Nations appeared today to present the first real conflict of policies between Britain and President Kennedy's Administration.

A building and permanent first mortgage loan of $3,900,000 has been obtained by the builders of the fourth section of Sherwood Village, a group of three six-story apartment buildings under construction on the blockfront on the east side of Ninety-ninth Street, between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Avenues, Rego Park, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher introduced legislation today that would permit the United States to make loans to Communist-dominated countries.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The international conference on air freight rates broke up without agreement tonight.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 10 -- The National Conference of State Legislative leaders went on record here day against direct Federal aid cities for urban renewal and public education. It said the funds should be distributed through states serving as middlemen.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Two men held in an extortion plot against a Wyckoff doctor retracted pleas of not guilty today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta, the winner of the first two tournaments on the professional women's golf circuit this year, made a bid today to win her third by taking the lead in the $7,500 St. Petersburg women's open.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Last year's victor, the Ardsley No. 1 rink skipped by Richard C. Wells won its first match in the sixth annual Cuthbertson bonspiel today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- The West Indies survived a shaky start and went on to score 252 runs for eight wickets today on the opening day of the final cricket test match against Australia.

The New York Junior League celebrated last night a decade of pre-Lenten benefit party-giving by saluting its home town with a parade of some of its prettiest members dressed in the most elaborate and fanciful costumes to date.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 -- What is believed to be the largest wooden yacht built in the world in the last thirty-two years, the 110-foot Vedersein, has been sold by Mrs. George Lauder, widow of its original owner.

In your editorial of Feb. 2 commenting on the "generous budget which the Governor had dr you inquire whether the Legislative might not postpone additional financial aid to school districts rather than "chip away" at established mula, as happened last year.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- British African policy was under mounting pressure today from two extremes -- those who seek a swift constitutional advance for Northern Rhodesia and those who advocate the "go slow" program laid down for the territory in 1958.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- Two executives sentenced to thirty-day jail terms in antitrust cases started their sentences today. A third won a week's delay to attend his daughter's engagement party.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Sol A. Dann, Detroit lawyer who has two stockholder suits pending against officials of Chrysler Corporation, said today he had been called to appear before the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington Thursday.
WASHINGTON Feb. 10 -- The Kennedy Administration gave its support today to proposals for substantially increasing the number of Federal judges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union has rejected the first overtures by the Kennedy Administration for United States-Soviet cooperation in developing the peaceful uses of outer space, Administration officials disclosed today.

The United States Rubber Company has announced that it will ask its stockholders for permission to retire the 8 per cent first preferred stock through gradual purchases at a top price of $160 a share.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Ten members of the United Nations asked Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to take "all possible steps" to determine the fate of Mr. Lumumba.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. urged yesterday that President Kennedy summon New Orleans business leaders to a White House conference to aid the desegregation of New Orleans schools.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 10 -- A 4-year-old girl was found early this morning after being buried for several hours in a snow slide. She was in fair condition tonight at Middlesex General Hospital, being treated for severe exposure.

Allan P. Kirby, chairman and controlling stockholder of the Alleghany Corporation, lost another round in his battle to repel a proxy contest against his management by John D. Murchison, Texas oil millionaire.

Nickolas Muray, who underwent emergency surgery Thursday in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club, was improving yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 10 -- The results of a referendum approving the incorporation of the community of Atlantic Beach were upheld in the Supreme Court here today.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The highest known rocket thrust ever achieved by the United States -- 1,550 000 pounds -- was producer at Edwards Rocket Base in California today, the Federal space agency announced.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday promoted the former head of his confidential squad to First Deputy Commissioner.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -Switzerland is not happy over the prospect of Earl E.T. Smith as United States Ambassador to Bern.

A SINGLE house plant, some seeds and packaged soil can launch a child on an absorbing hobby for late winter days. Many youngsters find it fascinating to grow a radish to nibbling size or to start an unusual plant for the summer garden. Junior gardeners may prefer to make half a dozen new plants from an old one or create an exotic landscape with vegetables.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30 -- There is nothing blue or beautiful about the Danube River as it swings south and east through the upper corner of Yugoslavia. It is simply an enormous channel for merchandise, on whose leisurely flowing but muddy waters tugs and barges chug busily.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 11 -- St. John's University used a big height advantage to send Syracuse University's basketball team to its fourth loss in a row tonight. The Brooklyn quintet triumphed by 95 -- 60.

THE National Broadcasting Company has visions of establishing a Saturday night cinema -- a series of outstanding motion pictures that would be televised each Saturday from 9 to 11 P.M. Although feature films fill much of the local time on individual stations, such programing has been done only once by a television network on a regular basis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Kennedy prodded a dormant hornet's nest this week when he asked Congress to set up a system of health insurance for the aged tied to Social Security.

DESPITE its record $15,000,000 cost, "Ben-Hur," which is bidding fair to become Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's biggest box office bonanza at Loew's State and elsewhere in the world, will not go on forever at the State, it was learned last week.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- Lehigh's strength in the lower weights today carried it to a 19-14 wrestling victory over Army.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 11 -- The United Nations command in the Congo opened an inquiry today into the reported escape of Patrice Lumumba, the former Premier. The command acted on instructions from Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

The Federal Office of Saline Water estimated last week that nearly a thousand "good ideas" on how to take the salt out of sea water or brackish water and make it fit for human consumption had been received in Washington in the last eight years.

ALTHOUGH traces of snow still remain in the city, visitors will find a hint of spring in the air at the fifteenth annual Spring Garden Show of the Long Island Nurserymen's Association, Inc. The nine-day show opens Saturday at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I.

THE Nikkorex-8, an 8mm movie camera equipped with electric-eye automation for both exposure setting and motorized operation, is announced by Nikon, Inc., 111 Fifth Avenue. Small enough to be carried in a pocket and supplied with the Nikkor 10mm f/1.8 lens, the Nikkorex costs $79.95.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Robert C. Weaver, President Kennedy's most controversial nominee so far, was sworn in today at the White House as administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.

Heavy snows and bitter cold again pared retail sales in this area last week. Despite a letup in the cold late in the week, department store merchants predicted that sales were 20 per cent below the level of the comparable 1960 period.

FIVE new handbooks in the Universal paperback series (New York: Verlan Books, Inc.; Amphoto. $1.95 each) cover information about equipment and offer vocational guidance in the field. The first of these, Les Berry's "Getting Started in Photography" introduces the reader to the various types of cameras and covers accessories, materials and processing.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (Reuters) -- Tottenham Hopsur took another stride nearer the elusive English League and Football Association Cup double by heating Aston Villa, 2 -- 1, today in a league soccer game at Birmingham.

OLD, worn counter tops in a kitchen or bath are not only unsightly, they can also be quite difficult to keep clean. To rejuvenate a surface of this kind, the home handyman can recover the counter top himself, using a heavy duty type of flexible plastic material.
CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 3 -- A desire to help the gifted student in public secondary schools is changing the pattern of summer sessions in some private boarding schools in New England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Negotiations are still going on between Capitol Hill and the Agriculture Department on a program to limit 1961 production of corn and feed grains.
Fairfield University's basketball team won its fifteenth consecutive Tri-State League contest last night by beating City College, 76 -- 47, at the Wingate Gymnasium.

THE great snowstorm of last week-end put many touring musicians in difficult positions. As stories of their travel exploits began rolling in, one was tempted to exclaim, "Postman, move over." The things a number of artists did to keep their engagements, when added to previous annals, should in time give the concert artist as big a reputation as a keeper of appointed rounds as the mailman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- A secret mission, undertaken with knowledge of the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, to block Fidel Castro's Cuban conquest was disclosed today from the files of Senate investigators.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The new hero of ski is 5 feet 6 inches tall, weighs 150 pounds, has won three major downhill and combined titles in a row (Lauberhorn, Hahnenkamn and Coupe Emile Alais) and is being described by experts as "better than Toni Sailer."

THE exhibition of Civil War pictures at the I.B.M. Gallery of Arts and Sciences, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, is a humbling experience for today's photographer. Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that Mayor Wagner finally had agreed to construction of the long-delayed Lower Manhattan Expressway.

Ch. Evo-Wen's Impressario, owned by Mrs. George M. Cowie of El Monte, Calif., took best of breed last night at the eighteenth annual specialty show of the American Boxer Club. The event was held at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Roger Moens of Belgium, the world record-holder at 800 meters, arrived yesterday for the New York Athletic Club indoorl track meet Friday night. Hei will run in the half-mile. Moensi also has entered the 1,000-vardl run in the Amateur Attletic Union indoor championships on Feb. 25. i
The State Supreme Court has told the owner of three East Side buildings he must go into the rooming-house business if the tenant company that now operates the buildings goes out of the business.
Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, author and lecturer, called here yesterday for United States support of Israel as a "matter of self-interest" because of the Soviet Union's backing of the United Arab Republic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The Administration will review the Post Office policy of intercepting assertedly Communist or subversive mail from abroad.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Church bells pealed this morning, formally opening for Alabamans a week of recollection of the days a century ago when the Confederacy was formed and its President inaugurated here.

New ways to determine insanity in criminal cases will be sought by the State Department of Mental Hygiene. It seeks chiefly to shelve the traditional yardstick of whether a defendant can "tell right from wrong."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- While distressed areas around the nation worry about unemployment, the movie industry is going into its special annual distress period. For Hollywood is now in its tax doldrums.

In a letter published Feb. 3 Albert S. Kuperman gave several reasons for his disapproval of the Cooper- Griffiths bill which aims "to provide for the humane treatment of animals * * * by recipients of grants from the United States."
BOSTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Don McKenney scored three goals and set up a fourth tonight in leading the Boston Bruins to an 8-3 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 7 -- Yugoslavia's big problem of the day is changing the peasant, whose knowledge of mechanics includes almost nothing more complicated than the wheel, into an efficient, productive worker in a modern industrial society.
George Bennette's piano program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall was solid and musicianly.
The world's largest commodity exchange -- the Chicago Board of Trade -- has quietly, but irrevocably, entered an important new era.

The Port of New York last month had its poorest collection of customs since last July, but it had an increase in passenger movements.
Net income of the Kroger Company last year declined to $23,478,029 from the record $25,516,920 achieved in 1959, according to the preliminary annual report of Joseph B. Hall, president.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The state Catholic Welfare Committee today endorsed Governor Rockefeller's plan to help finance private college students' education as "reasonable" and constitutional.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Americans for Democratic Action said today that the Kennedy Administration should immediately cut taxes by $100 a taxpayer to get the nation out of the recession.
Four new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Sam Jones left the Boston bench and paced a second-quarter rally that propelled the Celtics to a 136-125 triumph over the Philadelphia Warriors today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The capital had its quietest Sunday today since John F. Kennedy became President.
GENEVA, Feb. 12 -- Price changes were narrow on the Swiss stock markets last week. The high levels reached by Swiss issues induced profit taking, but prices stood up well.

Dick Savitt, the classic stroker, and Whitney Reed who looks as if he had learned tennis at the Actor's Studio, yesterday moved into the final round of the national indoor championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
PARIS, Feb. 12 -- The European Common Market has caused little trade deflection so far, but it is continuing to create an enormous amount of new trade within itself.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12 -- An international center for research and training in the economies of nations will be established at Yale University under a $2,000,000 grant from the Ford Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits called President Kennedy's approach to civil rights "insufficient" today He urged a broad Federal program to insure equal opportunities for all.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Va., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Law enforcement officers announced tonight that they were trying to find four missing children of an itinerant carnival worker and his wife who were being held in connection with the death by malnutrition of a fifth child. The couple were once jailed for illegally disposing of the body of a sixth child.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said yesterday that he would not press for inclusion of a racial discrimination ban in education and housing biffs if he felt that President Kennedy, by Executive Order, would uphold laws against discrimination.
At a special Boy Scout service yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral 505 Scouts received Ad Altare Dei (Unto the Altar of God) awards for "distinguished spiritual advancement."
MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- The Soviet Union fired a rocket toward Venus today. The rocket was launched from a new heavy satellite circling the earth.

As a recent past president I would like to voice my disagreement and disappointment with the action taken by the New York Young Republican Club at its meeting on Jan. 31. In passing a motion to commend the 148 Republican Congressmen who voted against Speaker Rayburn's proposal to enlarge the Rules Committee they in effect condemned Congressman John V. Lindsay's action in supporting the proposal.
The Rev. Vincent J.P. Fox discussed the "sinless self-love and seeming selfishness that make a salt" yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

In his special message dealing with the problems of recovery and economic growth, President Kennedy touched upon a proposal to stimulate business investment in plant and equipment through reform of the Federal tax system. Last week the President's new Secretary of Commerce, Luther H. Hodges, appearing on a popular TV panel discussion, added some needed substance to that proposal.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Profit takers worked the grain futures pits almost without let-up last week and all contracts closed with fairly broad setbacks, while soybeans continued their climb but at a slower pace.
Something will be missing when a lot of Valentine candy packages are handed out tomorrow: The little brown paper cups that hold the candy.
Foreign exchange rates showed a mixed trend in fairly active dealings during the past week. British pound sterling was on the soft side while the Canadian dollar had a strong undertone.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Despite the refusal by the heads of government in the Common Market to include Britain in political discussions, the British expect to continue their "exploratory" talks with individual members of the grouping.
Ch. Vardona Frosty Snowman was judged best of breed yesterday in the Bulldog Club of America specialty show at the Martinique Hotel. Eighty-one dogs were entered.
SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Hemmo Silvennoinen, a 29-year-old paper salesman from Helsinki, Finland, today soared a record 208 feet to clinch the United States Eastern ski jumping championship.

Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney warned last night that he would not support any expanded financial aid for higher education in New York State unless it included both private and public colleges.
Leopold Stokowski will make his Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday, Feb. 24, when "Turandot" will be offered at the Met for the first time in thirty-one years.

NO matter what her preference, Tailored Woman promises to help make almost any bride happy on her wedding day. In a collection of wedding dresses underscored by careful good taste, the informal, the romantic, the regal or the traditional-minded young woman is given a handsome choice.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- The best that could be said for the steel market last week was that it was no worse than of late. Most steel officials had written off March as a recovery month and were now naming April as the most likely month to show an improvement.

The brothers Kennedy have moved with commendable speed and vigor to ease the intolerable congestion in the Federal courts -- a situation for which their own party leaders have been largely responsible. Attorney General Kennedy has sent to the Senate and House a draft bill to create fifty-nine new judgeships and President Kennedy has urged Congress to pass it.

Carmine G. De Sapio's television defense of his Democratic leadership yesterday amounted to a bridge-burning operation. When he had finished he appeared to have destroyed all possibility of any new link between himself and Mayor Wagner.

FRANK GIFFORD was stretched out on the Yankee Stadium turf completely unconscious, his face a ghastly white. Dr. Francis J. Sweeny, the Giant physician, hovered anxiously over him, clucking like an angry mother hen and making threatening gestures in the direction of huge Chuck Bednarik, the Eagle linebacker, whose savage tackle from the blind side had separated the gifted Gifford from his senses.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union yielded today to a French request to publish France's version of the plane incident, but published with it was a Soviet Foreign Ministry statement declaring it false.

Ch. Star Jade of North 'Boro, owned by Mrs. Mary Shipman Pickhardt of the Sabbaday Kennels of Washington, Conn., took best-of-breed honors yesterday in the Pug Dog Club of America annual specialty show at the Governor Clinton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Tomorrow, after its first week of hearings, a Presidential commission is scheduled to decide how to solve the problem of railroad work rules.

TOENSBERG, Norway, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Russian women swept the first three places today as 26-year-old Mme. Valentina Stenina of Moscow retained her women's world speed-skating championship. She won three races and finished second in the fourth event.
Government ship-mortgage insurance and commitments to insure mortgages totaled $441,000,000 at the start of the year, the Maritime Administration reported yesterday.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- The Ardsley Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Richard C. Wells, repeated as the Ardsley Medal champion as the sixth annual Cuthbertson bonspiel ended today at the St. Andrew's Golf Club indoor ice arena.

THE recent snowstorm that isolated many suburban families had few more desperate victims than the women who were forced to stoke the home fires because their husbands had jobs that required them to travel.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- President Kennedy attended mass at the Middleburg Community Center today, then pulled his daughter on a sled around the estate he has chosen for a holiday retreat.

The sincerity of Governor Rockefeller's interest in revision of the city's Charter was questioned yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 12 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga rebuffed today United Nations investigators who sought his cooperation in an effort to establish the circumstances of Patrice Lumumba's disappearance.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- President Kennedy's admirable proposal of a volunteer peace corps for overseas duty has three important aspects. It would provide a reservoir of young people capable of inexpensive and, one hopes, skilled and enthusiastic work.

NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- Ruth A. Lane's Ch. Lane's Prince Rojalio, of Mokena, Ill., captured the best-in-show prize for long-coat Chihuahuas today in the specialty held by the Chihuahua Club of Mid-Jersey at the Continental Ball Room.
Coincidence and quick thinking brought about the arrest yesterday of a brother and sister as a hold-up team.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Clarence Ludwig, Professor of Political Science at the University of Minnesota for twenty-four years until his retirement two years ago, died of a heart attack Friday at his home here.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- The East German police refused entry into the Communist region tonight of prominent Evangelical Church leaders from West Germany, including at least five Bishops.

The week-end, which started so promisingly for the Knickerbockers when they whipped the Celtics in Boston Saturday, ended gloomily in Madison Square Garden yesterday when the Knicks came up with another way to lose a game.
Two hints for the taxpayer: First, last year's return will usually serve as a helpful guide in filling out this year's return; and second, neatness counts.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 12 -- The Indian Government withdrew today the title and privy purse of a Maharaja of a former princely state and recognized his brother as ruler.
CARLISLE, Pa., Feb. 12 -- O.H. Starner, retired president of the Carlisle Shoe Company and a civic leader here, died Friday in his home at the age of 91.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Six women with outstanding careers in government were announced today as winners of the first annual Federal Women's Award.
THE taped showing yesterday afternoon on Channel 4 of "Report From Moscow" was quite possibly the best job that television has done in examining the intricacies of world disarmament and security.

The proclamation by Mayor Wagner on Feb. 14 of the week from Feb. 20 to 26 as Health Careers Week will focus attention on an educational effort to direct the attention of young people to the more than 150 different occupations that are open to them in the health field. Student Commissioners of Health and Hospitals will be appointed during the special week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg returned tonight from a five-state inspection tour of unemployment areas and said that President Kennedy had found his mission "very worthwhile."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Two members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee voiced concern today that many persons in Latin America have exaggerated hopes of a massive United States aid program.

Two astronomical phenomena will occur this week. On Wednesday the sun will be totally obscured by the moon for observers along a narrow path across Europe and Asia. The path extends from the Bay of Biscay, off the French and Spanish Atlantic coasts, to Siberia.

John Singleton Mosby, who did a good deal of riding, raiding and looting for the Confederate cause a century ago, might be startled if he could know what went on at Middleburg, Va., west of Washington, this past week-end. Middleburg was Mosby's "capital." There he mobilized his rangers and there he dispersed them when he came back out of Union territory loaded with spoils of war.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Glenn (Fireball) Roberts of Daytona Beach set a record of 155.440 miles an hour today in qualifying for the Daytona 500-mile race on Feb. 26.

THE unseen partner of Carmine G. De Sapio as he appeared on television screens in New York living rooms yesterday was a Madison Avenue publicist named Sydney Stuart Baron. Trading in over-the-counter stocks was at a hectic pace last week as was trading in listed stocks on the registered stock exchanges. But there was one important difference in the two markets.

CARACAS, Feb. 12 -- The automobile companies of Volkswagen, Fiat, Renault and the Japanese Nissam are planning to establish assembly plants here, it was learned today. Some will make arrangements with plants already established here; others will build their own factories.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 10 -Prices made good progress in the Amsterdam stock market last week in fairly active dealings.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- The four-man bobsled crews tuning up for the world championships to be held Saturday and Sunday bettered the record twice today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman is expected to announce this week an increase in the cotton support price. It could have broad economic implications.

Four children and their 15-year-old aunt were killed early yesterday when a fire swept their frame house in the Richmond Hill section of Queens. The parents and a 5-year-old brother of the four children escaped.

The Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company reported yesterday for 1960 a net income of $41,120,942, or $2.10 each on the 17,914,473 shares outstanding. Gross operating income was at a new peak of $463,678,917.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Northern Rhodesia's leading African nationalist called on Britain today to demand an end to last night's mobilization of territorial troops by the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) -- Defense contractors reportedly testified today that rapid changes in Air Force requirements had been attributable for the wide rise in the cost of United States missile-launching pads.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The stock market was uncertain here today. Buyers seemed reluctant to enter into fresh commitments. Sentiment was also affected by the Federation of British Industries' report last week on adverse business prospects.

In the latest twist in political appeals, the Washington Heights Democratic Association, Inc., the organization club in the Fifteenth Assembly District South, is offering new members a 10 per cent discount on purchases at neighborhood stores.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 13 (UPI) -- Don't Alibi needed no excuses for his performance at Santa Anita today as he won the $28,600 Sun Luis Rey Handicap on the grass. He scored by a length and a quarter.

COOKBOOK authors, by and large, are not known for their pulchritude, but Peggy Harvey of Chicago is a notable exception. The tall and slender woman, formerly a Powers model, visited New York recently to discuss the publication of a forthcoming book on food. It will fill a gap that she feels has long been in need of filling.
A one-time beer salesmen with little education and a prison record for emblezzlement, Patrice Lumumba became a figure of importance in world affairs.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- The Western Allies protested today to the Soviet Union over East Germany's "illegal action" in barring Evangelical Church leaders from entering East Berlin yesterday to attend a religious service there.

THE Duke of Wellington was once asked by the British Government to nominate a general who could fulfill a mission -- the capture of Rangoon -- that seemed desirable at that time. Wellington said: "Send Lord Combermere."
GENEVA, Feb. 13 -- The World Council of Churches warned today that "military rivalries are too dangerous to project into space."
Five Negro and five white Students from the South who came to New York this week to discuss integration with Barnard College students, found that they had learned more by talking to each other.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 13 -Reports from Washington that the United States has cautioned Morocco on the possible consequences of accepting Soviet military aid were received by Moroccan officials today with disbelief and defiance.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Jack Cotton's City Centre Properties withdrew tonight its offer to acquire the City of London Real Property Company.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The state's Office of Atomic Development disclosed today that it was near a decision on a site for the first state-owned depot for storing nuclear by-products and waste.

Herman Frederick Marks, former guerrilla and executioner for Fidel Castro, protested yesterday that he was being held here in solitary confinement and that this interfered with his defense against deportation.

A theatre party to the April 17 performance of "Carnival" will benefit the Roosevelt Hospital's $11,500,000 Progress Fund for the construction of the twelve-story Garrard Winston Memorial Building. The musical based on Paul Gallico's story "Lili" stars Anna Maria Alberghetti and is scheduled to open at the Imperial Theatre on April 13.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Wagner broke a 23-23 tie in the first half tonight and went on to hand Upsala its fourth straight basketball defeat, 85 -- 78.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 14 (AP) -- St. Bonaventure, the nation's second-ranked basketball power, combined Tom Stith and a fast break tonight and trounced Providence, 95 -- 79.

FOR the first time in a dozen years the Yankees opened an advance training camp yesterday without the sharp blue eyes of Charles Dillon Stengel supervising the proceedings. The gravelly voice and the gnarled figure were absent. A new regime took over in St. Pete, the youthfully vigorous regime of Ralph Houk.
BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- Two last period goals enabled Boston College's hockey team to win the Beanpot Trophy tonight on a 4-2 victory over Harvard in the tournament final at Boston Garden.

TORONTO, Feb. 13 (UPI) -- A Canadian-United States common market is almost inevitable and sentiment in favor of one will develop rapidly in the next few years, Neil McElroy, former United States defense secretary, said tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 13 -- It is courtesy to leave footgear at the door in Japan; it is cleanliness to park the brogans on Dutch doorsteps; it is an invitation to shine the leather when shoes are left in places like the corridors of French hotels; it is a mark of reverence to leave foot coverings outside the Pakistani masjid.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 13 -- Seven persons were recently massacred in an Andean Valley in Western Colombia, according to reports that reached here yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 13 -- The Vatican confirmed today that a Pope had been eliminated from the direct line of apostolic succession, but said it was Stephen II, not Stephen VIII. The succession now includes 261 Popes from the Apostle Peter to the reigning Pontiff, John XXIII.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India called today for strong action against those responsible for the death of Patrice Lumumba.
Bonds traded on the New York Stock Exchange edged up slightly yesterday in the quietest trading in three weeks.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- A legislative committee heard today how guards employed by private detectives are able to continue working despite lengthy and lurid criminal records.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 13 (UPI) -- Oscar Robertson scored 40 points tonight and led the Cincinnati Royals to a 104 -- 100 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers in a National Basketball Association game at the University of Dayton fieldhouse.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 13 -- President Tito left Belgrade tonight on the first leg of an extended tour of seven West and North African countries. TRENTON, Feb. 13 -- Former Superior Court Judge Richard J. Hughes was named the Democratic organization's candidate for Governor today.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The Senate approved unanimously tonight a bill extending the Workmen's Compensation Law to employes in concerns with only a single employe.

A 30-year-old laborer admitted yesterday he killed a Bronx grocer during a hold-up in 1952 and fatally beat a woman last year, according to the police.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- The West Indies fought back from a shaky position in the final cricket test match against Australia today. The tourists built a 62-run lead by the close of play with eight second-innings wickets standing.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 13 -South Korea's new economic aid agreement with the United States drew sharp criticism from the Opposition in the South Korean House of Representatives today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Secretary of the Interior indicated today a policy of increased public power under the Kennedy Administration. Secretary Stewart L. Udall issued a memorandum on public power calling for "a vigorous program of full development and maximum utilization of our total energy to meet the nation's growing demands."

THE idea of leading the fourth-highest card from a long suit dates back to the Eighteen Eighties (it was not published until 1889 but it had been played for some years before that), and it remains the backbone of the defensive game.

The small investors' Hit Parade -- better known as the Monthly Investment Plan -- contained some well-known corporate names last year, as usual. Started just seven years ago, M.I.P. was started by the New York Stock Exchange to enable small investors to buy shares periodically by the investment of as little as $40 every three months.
American Cynamid Company cleared $46,820,953, or $2.20 a share, in 1960, compared with $52,284,191 and $2.46 in 1959. Sales last year dipped to $578,389,585 from $583,574,569 the year before.

British airports need the planning and financial touch of an agency patterned on the Port of New York Authority, Anthony H. Milward, chief executive of British European Airways, declared here yesterday.

This is the Year of the Cow in the Chinese calendar and Mott Street will reverberate tomorrow with the din of the Mon Jong, or 10,000 Firecrackers. It also may be called the Year of the Buffalo, or Ox, or Bison, depending upon the part of China where the celebrant originates.
New York was filled yesterday with sidewalk strollers and shoppers taking advantage of the long Lincoln's Birthday week-end and looking ahead to St. Valentine's Day today.

The formation of The Committee for a Democratic Spain, pledged to support foes of Generalissimo Francisco Franco inside and outside Spain, was announced yesterday by Waldo Frank, the chairman.
Cotton futures advanced 4 to 35 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point equals 5 cents a bale. All contracts except old March set new highs for the life of the contracts.

A "recession psychology" has not gripped the nation's consumers, although they have modified their spending plans and are proceeding with caution. That was the finding of the latest survey of consumer buying plans conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board for Newsweek magazine. The survey covers November and December, 1960.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The appearance of a periodical of opinion designed to promote the political fortunes of the Republican party deserves the rating of an event. PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Soccer as played in England is a different game from soccer as played elsewhere. In England team play is the thing; players attempt to be as unobstrusive as possible.
