CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Bradley, behind the shooting of Tim Robinson, Mack Herndon, Chet Walker and Mickey Tieman, beat Notre Dame, 84 -- 81, in overtime tonight.

A syndicate led by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., Blyth Co., Inc., and the Equitable Securities Corporation placed the best bid yesterday for 750,000 common shares of the Southern Company. The bid was $49.31 a share.
The Appellate Division decided yesterday that George L. Rockwell, self-styled American Nazi, was entitled to a permit from the City of New York to make a public speech in a park.

Aircrafts, missiles and steels led the stock market up yesterday in an ebullient session that recovered most of the February losses. Oils, business equipments and chemicals failed to share in the enthusiasm.

Prices of Maine potato futures rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in the heaviest trading of the present season. Futures rose 8 to 14 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in a broad market where 2,365 carlots of 50,000 pounds each changed hands.

Melvin A. Goldberg, director of research for the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, said yesterday that if bad media research went unchallenged then the consequences of Gresham's Law applied to research must be accepted: The bad will certainly drive out the good.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Pauline Lumumba lay grief-stricken in a dark corner of an African house today, amid wails and tears from relatives gathered around to mourn her husband.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14 -- An elaborately equipped housing development for carefully selected elderly and retired persons is being planned here. It would include community meals and an infirmary.
The University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, announced the appointment of Victor Remer as its executive director yesterday.

WHILE it is courageous of them to attempt Strindberg, young companies off Broadway do so at their risk. The group that undertook "To Damascus" at the Theatre East last night was audacious, but it was also borrowing trouble.
Amid charges of "reckless financing," the City Council approved yesterday a bill bringing the 55,000-seat baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park Queens, closer to realization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- At the bottom of an article on Page 375 of Volume VIII of the new Encyclopaedia Britannica, an astute reader can spot the initials: J.F. Ky.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- George M. Smith, 63 years old, shot a five-under-par 67 and took a stroke lead in the first round of the Professional Golfers Association seniors tournament today.

The New York City Ballet, which will open a four-week season at the City Center on March 14, announces a new ballet by George Balanchine employing electronic music by Remi Gassman in collaboration with Oskar Sala.
IN the Nassau-Suffolk tournament played at Long Beach, L.I., last week-end the deal shown produced a variety of results in both bidding and play.
DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., filed legal answers today to antitrust charges brought against it by Chance Vought Corporation in teh concern's stock control fight.
A World War II teaching technique is being used by a New York University professor to help fisherman identify the fish that did not get away.

OTTAWA, Feb. 14 (Canadian Press ) -- Howard C. Green, Minister for External Affairs, indicated tonight that Canada was not prepared under present circumstances to support Communist China for admission to the United Nations.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, appealed yesterday to the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations to urge the Moroccan Government to stop what it termed "repressive action, as well as others dealing country.

The Board of Estimate has moved toward a prompt start on road construction and reconstruction needed for the even heavier than usual traffic that is expected in Queens with the advent of the World's Fair in 1964 and 1965. Even without the fair, however, the roads will be needed to serve a fast-growing area.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- George Washington was unexpectedly tough for St. John's tonight, but the Redmen from New York prevailed, 98 -- 80, for their fourteenth victory in eighteen games.
A 60-year-old Queens contractor who pleaded guilty to 187 unanswered traffic tickets was sentenced yesterday to 185 days in jail plus a fine of $9,550 with the alternative of a year more in jail.
The agreement between the Jacob Ruppert Brewery and its employes represented by three Teamster locals discloses an inventive way to cut labor costs and so to reduce dangerous company deficits.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 14 -- Hofstra's basketball team took command at the six-minute mark in the first half and defeated Moravian, 84 to 63, in a Northern Division game in the Middle Atlantic Conference at Calkins Gymnasium today.
Orlando Cepeda, whose batting average dropped from .317 to .297 last year, received a slight increase from the San Francisco Giants and mailed in his signed contract for 1961 yesterday.
A move to seize the initiative in City Charter revision from Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner was made by the City Council yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Pa. Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A railroad spokesman called today upon President Kennedy to free the rail industry from "economic slavery'' and proposed an "emancipation program."

The Philippine flag was flown at half staff on Feb. 10 by the Philippine Embassy as a tribute to the memory of Millard H. Tydings, who died on Feb. 9. As a member of the United States Senate he co-authored the Tydings-McDuffie Independence Act.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano indicated today that West Germany was beginning to move toward some of the views advanced by the United States in the financial discussions between the countries.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- The injury-crippled Australian cricket team needed 201 runs for victory with nine wickets standing at the close of play today on the fourth day of the final test match against the West Indies.
The market for United States Government securities was strong yesterday, with the scope of activity broadening substantially.

THE most intellectually ambitious novel to come out of Germany since World War II, perhaps since the publication of Thomas Mann's "The Magic Mountain," is "If Thine Eye Offend Thee" by Heinrich Schirmbeck.
A 10,000-gallon wooden water tank atop a ten-story building at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-first Street fell eight floors yesterday to the roof of an adjoining textile company.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- A resolution calling for an investigation of municipally owned docks in New York City is scheduled to be introduced into the Senate tomorrow. Immediate approval is expected.
Relatives of nineteen belligerent imprisoned defendants in a two-month-old narcotics conspiracy trial picketed yesterday for an hour outside the United States Courthouse at Foley Square.

Ohio State and St. Bonaventure continued along their merry ways as the Nation's No. 1 and 2 teams, respectively, in the United Press International college basketball ratings yesterday, with all signs pointing to a possible showdown in the National Collegiate post-season tournament.
BONN, Feb. 14 -- The Daimler-Benz Company of West Germany, maker of what is often called here the automobile of the aristocrat, has pecked an Austrian Socialist to become its general manager.

Joe Haggerty, the top-seeded entrant from the New York A.C., and unseeded Al Englander of the home club gained the final round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A limited tournament last night on the Yale Club courts.

Steel output last week showed an increase for the second consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The nation's steel mills turned out 1,524,000 tons of raw steel, up from 1,492,000 tons the preceding week, and 1,466,000 three weeks ago.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers bought a four-engine DC-6B airliner today for all their flights, breaking the major-league pattern of using chartered planes.

LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet Government statement today on the death of Patrice Lumumba and on Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, as distributed in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency:
A Domestic Relations Justice warned yesterday that two recent legislative proposals on schools and adoptions threatened freedom of religion and conscience.
' Botany' 500 advertising for the spring and summer expects to be more competitive not only with other men's clothing advertising, but with all advertising in every magazine in which it advertises.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, led by Bob Cousy, trounced the Los Angeles Lakers 113-93, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
Frances Reiter, dean of the Graduate School of Nursing at New York Medical College, yesterday proposed a new hospital rank of "clinical staff nurse."

The election of nine new members to the National Institute of Arts and Letters was announced yesterday by Glenway Wescott, the institute president. Among those elected was Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a special assistant to President Kennedy.
Earnings of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for 1960 fell from the 1959 level, but fourth quarter results rose slightly from those of the year before, the company announced yesterday.

Kentucky is planning to sell an issue of $100,000,000 of bonds before the end of March to finance payment of a bonus for war veterans. An additional bond issue of about $36,000,000 will be sold later. The Kentucky bonus will pay $500 to each veteran of the last four wars -- Korea, World Wars I and II and the Spanish American War.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Israel is to have a fur-breeding industry. This was disclosed yesterday by Herman H. Meltzer, Chicago fur executive, who has worked out a plan for developing it.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Italy, which won the two-man championship last week-end, had the two best times in practice today for the four-man world bobsled championships, which will be run next week-end.

The era of deliverance has arrived for the horse racing fan. The ultimate in electronic convenience -- a gadget that will permit him to place a bet virtually from his seat in the grandstand -- is being patented.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Three British Government financiers started a four-day series of conferences with United States and international agency officials today on world money problems.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Temple's Owls defeated a stubborn Bucknell quintet, 78 -- 66, tonight at the Palestra.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Venus shot stresses the ever-widening gap between man's technical ingenuity and man's common sense. Knowledge, in terms of science, is exploding. Knowledge, in terms of politics, stays static.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 14 -- Warm debate flared up at today's session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa over the effect of economic groupings on the African economies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Union's assault against Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations caused apprehension in the State Department today.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today that John Fox, Boston financier, must pay Mrs. Helen D. Grozier $1,161,052, plus interests and costs, under his agreement with her to buy the now defunct Boston Post.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Charles Abrams, United Nations housing consultant, said today United States foreign aid programs were ignoring what he called the world movement to cities.
Louis Goldfarb, realty investor, has contracted to buy the six-story commercial building at 50 East Fiftieth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues. Ruth F. Brown Associates were the brokers.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Can it be the Yankees are getting ready to build a fire under Bill Skowron?
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Wake Forest's Deacons, hitting on 61.1 per cent of their field-goal attempts, upset Duke, 103 -- 89, tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- The American Medical Association announced today an "all-out effort" to prevent passage of President Kennedy's medical-care program.

The Grand Ballroom of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn was decorated with red, white and blue bunting last night for the Mardi Gras Ball, a benefit for the Brooklyn Division of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.
Peter Lawford, the actor, said yesterday he had not signed a complaint concerning a burglary in his hotel suite because the police had not asked him to.
CAIRO, Feb. 14 -- The United Arab Republic announced tonight it had recognized the rebel Government of Antoine Gizenga at Stanleyville as the "legitimate national government of the Congo."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Kennedy congratulated Premier Khrushchev today on the Soviet Union's "impressive scientific achievement" in launching a space vehicle toward the planet Venus.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Demand for grain futures was thin again today and prices drifted generally lower after a firm to strong start on the Board of Trade.

Yesterday's attack on the Belgian Embassy in Moscow recalled one made by tens of thousands of Muscovites July 18, 1958, on the United States Embassy. The mob besieged and stoned the building for several hours, venting anger over the movement of American and British troops into Lebanon and Jordan.
The Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its twenty third annual campaign yesterday.

North Callahan, author of "Henry Knox: General Washington's General," has written the biography of another Revolutionary War hero that will be published next Monday by Holt, Rinehart Winston. Called "Daniel Morgan: Ranger of the Revolution," the book presents a life of the colorful Virginian, once a farm hand who indulged in fist fights as a hobby, but who rose to lead raw recruits to victory over trained British troops.

Foremost Dairies, Inc., reported yesterday that its net income declined last year to $7,254,000! from $10,493,000 in 1959, when the company had nonrecurring income of $623,716 from the sale of operating properties, equal'1
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The most striking fact in Washington today is the sharp contrast between a vigorous young Administration and a cumbersome Congress.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The book-blacklisting activities of the Rhode Island Commission to Encourage Morality in Youth are unconstitutional, Judge William M. Mackenzie ruled in Superior Court today.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Republican legislative leaders decided today at a breakfast conference with Governor Rockefeller to have this year's primary elections on Sept. 7, a Thursday.

Michael E. Lesk, the top scorer in the state Regents examinations, is a 15-year-old scholar and satirist who excels at chess, abhors gym, plays Bach on the piano and possesses an outstanding collection of railroad timetables.
The National Audubon Society and the Nature Centers for Young America, Inc., 10 East Fortieth Street, merged yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Britain announced today a slightly increased defense budget.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the biggest brokerage concern in the world, cleared $13,235,000 last year after paying taxes and making charitable bequests of $13,930,000 and setting aside $10,383,000 for employe profit-sharing and pension programs.

Events today "Martha," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Erich Leinsdorf, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Concert of Chamber Music, Manhattan School of Music, 8:30; Michale Tree, violinist, and Heida Hermann, pianist, Kaufmann Concert Hall, Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:30.
Plans for a cooperative apartment for 224 middle-income families on the southern fringe of Chinatown were made public yesterday by the Housing and Redevelopment Board.
A new technique to catheterize the left ventricle of the heart was described yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that if he ran for a third term he would "not seek or accept the support" of Carmine G. De Sapio.
MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- The failure of two consecutive odds-on favorites at Hialeah this bright, warm day made the form players rule out sending any Valentines.
The owner of a Harlem tenement building sought unsuccessfully yesterday to have his trial moved to Westchester County.
What has Valeri Brumel got that the rest of the world's high jumpers lack? Nothing, apparently, except credit for a competitive leap of 7 feet 4 1/2 inches and confidence that he can do better.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 14 -- The Norwalk Chamber of Commerce is undertaking to attract 5,000 skilled and semi-skilled workers to this city within thee next five years. The chamber estimates that 2,700 of these will be needed within the next two years.

Three significant developments in the conduct of automobile racing in the United States have taken place in the last week. 1. Clarification of the amateur-professional regulations for Sports Car Club of America drivers and car owners.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Louisiana has reinstated about half the 23,500 children ousted from welfare rolls, Commissioner Mary Evelyn Parker said today.

From his native city of Dubuque, Iowa, Richard Bissell, successful novelist, river manner and co-author of the Broadway musical, "The Pajama Game," sends word that his latest novel, "Good Bye, Ava," will become a stage play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today he would let his Business Advisory Council decide whether Ralph J. Cordiner, board chairman of General Electric, should continue as chairman of the group.

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, Montreal, sold more than $1,000,000,000 in insurance last year, George W. Bourke, president, told the annual meeting yesterday. This brought life insurance in force at the end of 1960 to $9,572,801,000 in 1959, Sun Life sold $1,041,997,636 of insurance and at year's end had $8,938,000,000 in force.

The murder of Patrice Lumumba and his two aides in an African village and the payment of $8,000 to the villagers as a reward for a revolting act of violence will profoundly shock and deeply disturb public opinion in the United States. The press will give extensive publicity to the incident and its consequences.
MONTREAL, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Frank Mahovlich of the Toronto Maple Leafs and Glenn Hall of the Chicago Black Hawks took over the lead today in the National Hockey League's scoring and goalie races.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Nineteen modern paintings, which were stolen last March from a famous Riviera inn, were recovered yesterday from a checkroom in a Marseilles railroad station. The paintings have a value estimated at $400,000.

Two new motion picture theatres, combined within a single two-level building, will be constructed on Third Avenue between Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets, it was announced yesterday by Donald Rugoff, president of Rugoff and Becker Theatres.

After discussions at Kuala Lumpur, the Federation of Malaya, Thailand and the Philippines have taken the first steps toward forming a new grouping of Southeast Asian nations. A communiqu states that the aim will be economic and cultural cooperation among the members.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 17 points (15 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday, except the far July, for which a bid price showed a 5-point gain.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 14 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province charged today that the United Nations had bathed the Congo in "fire and blood."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Interior Department ordered today an eighteen-month moratorium, effective at once, on applications to buy public lands.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Pauline Lumumba, widow of Patrice Lumumba, walked bare-breasted through the streets of Leopoldville today to show her mourning for her husband.
Happiness and hope are run-of-the-mill at the Bronx Marriage License Bureau, but yesterday clerks there did a delighted second take when Joe Neiverth and Sara Savith walked in.
Fog and rain cast a warm, wet cloak over the metropolitan area yesterday morning, disrupting air, harbor and road traffic.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Polaroid Corporation reported today that sales were a record for 1960, but earnings, which were affected by business conditions, start-up costs on new products and delays in production schedules, declined sharply.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 14 -- This city's taxpayers learned today that their tax rate for 1961, which was expected to rise to $107 on each $1,000 of property valuation, might reach only $102.50.
The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday began the second round in a legal battle to collect $180,000 from a tugboat union that broke with it in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Kennedy Administration increased today its efforts to push a relaxed Congress into action on the President's anti-recession program.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Following, in unofficial translation from the Russian, is the text of a draft resolution submitted by the Soviet Union tonight for circulation to the Security Council:

ANTOINE GIZENGA, whom the Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic recognized yesterday as the head of the Congo, is a "very quiet, almost subdued" man, according to United Nations delegates who have met him.

The Moderator of the United (Northern) Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. said yesterday that any denomination that backed racial integration would suffer "casualties" in its membership and should prepare for such losses.
TORRINGTON, Conn., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Torrington Board of Education has decided unanimously to reject a demand to discard a high school text containing three stories that use the word "nigger."

The New York Central Railroad apparently spent more than $13,000,000 last month trying to halt the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway in its drive to acquire control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. The Chesapeake and Ohio apparently spent as much money, maybe even more, to assure that it would obtain a majority stock interest in B. O., with which it is planning to merge.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Union withdrew its recognition of Dag Hammarskjold as Secretary General of the United Nations today. It branded the international official "an accomplice and organizer of the murder" of Patrice Lumumba.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A Soviet scientist said today that the Soviet Venus rocket was now expected to reach the area of the planet at least a month earlier than originally expected.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., has purchased, F.E. Compton Co. Trade sources said this would make Britannica the largest company in the encyclopedia field.

Unfortunately, your otherwise excellent editorial of Feb. 12 indicates that minimum wage and child labor measures will not be included in the legislative program which has evolved from the work of the Senate Subcommittee on Migratory Labor.

VALENTINES more than 100 years old are included in an exhibit in the Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Many of the valentines are intricate and bedecked with painted flowers and mirrors.
The head of detectives in the Brooklyn North command, which includes one of two squads being investigated by a grand jury, obtained an application for retirement yesterday.

The lank, precise voice of the late Billie Holiday and the in-volute saxophone of the late Charlie Parker drifted moodily through a law office yesterday as plans were made to try to get royalties for their estates.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 14 -- John Marvin Cook, marketing vice president of Cutler-Hammer, Inc., Milwaukee, joined six other executives of electrical manufacturing companies today in the Montgomery County Prison here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Kennedy reaffirmed today the reliance of the United States on its system of foreign political and military alliances for security against Communist expansion.

The Syracuse Nationals, who have won their last five games, will meet the last-place New York Knickerbockers in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A VISIT to the twelfth floor of 38 East Fifty-seventh Street is bound to make women invent reasons why their chairs, walls, windows and lampshades need recovering. For the fabrics and furnishings showroom that opened there last week is full of captivating English chintzes, fashionable Art Nouveau prints, embossed French velvets and horsehair fabrics.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Union applied an old technique to a new situation in announcing today that it would no longer recognize Dag Hammarskjold as Secretary General of the United Nations.

The annual juggling of the primary election date is apparently now in full swing in Albany. According to a story in The Times on Feb. 6, "Governor Rockefeller and Republican state leaders are facing a major political decision in the next two weeks: whether to fix a June or September date for this year's primary elections."

" KUNG-HO SHIN-NIEN" is the gay greeting awaiting visitors to the home of Lin Yutang, the well-known Chinese author. "Happy New Year," echoes his smiling wife, Tsuifeng Lin. While big parades, punctuated by the staccato snaps of fire crackers, wind their way through Chinatown today, the Lin family will celebrate the commencement of the Year of the Ox quietly with family and friends in their uptown apartment high in the Manhattan sky.
The directors of Haveg Industries, Inc., proposed a 2 1/2-for-1 split of the common stock yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration's school-aid message was delayed after a secret meeting between Secretary of Welfare Abraham A. Ribicoff and Democratic Senators interested in the subject.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Premier Fidel Castro held out an olive branch to the United States today, saying that he had no desire to continue hostility toward Washington and hoped eventually to re-establish friendly political relations between the two countries.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Mardi Gras exploded in a burst of unbridled merriment, color and pageant today that even a river tragedy and past racial woes could not dim.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Donald M. Fleming, Canadian Finance Minister, said today that the new Canadian Government program to export more oil into the United States was "an entirely reasonable one."
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller's program for college student aid is being revised to provide more assistance to undergraduates with lower family incomes.
The McCall Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to acquire Saturday Review, Inc., through the exchange of an undisclosed amount of McCall stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The periodical drive for enlargement of the House of Representatives gained some momentum today with the circulation of word that Speaker Sam Rayburn would go along with a "modest" increase.

Industrial and financial executives representing some of New York's largest concerns today accepted citations awarded to their companies by the Manhattan Chapter of the American Association for the United Nations.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that the Soviet Union was "deeply convinced of the urgent need to put an end to the dangerous and ruinous arms race."
The television special, born, almost seven years ago under the name "spectacular," is going to be a much rarer event next season.

The Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, Inc., recommended yesterday an increase of 106,000 barrels a day in imports of heavy fuel oil for the first quarter of 1961. The increase from the present level of 530,000 barrels a day was described as necessary to avert a shortage by the end of this month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Administration advised the Senate today that an improvement in the international payments deficit demanded either ratification of the new Western economic alliance or a cutback in plans to "reinvigorate" the home economy.

EUGENE ORMANDY, apparently recovered from his injuries in an automobile accident, conducted last night's concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. At the previous New York concert, William Smith, the orchestra's assistant conductor, had to fill in for him.
Supercrete, Ltd., a Winnipeg, Ma, producer of building materials and concrete, has been put into receivership.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Former Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell resigned today as chairman of the Presidential commission seeking solutions to labor-management disputes in the railroad industry.

The Board of Estimate has heeded the advice of city water engineers and authorized an immediate start of work on a $31,100,000 water tunnel from Brooklyn to Staten Island. The board has appropriated $21,000,000 for the first stage of the project, a five-mile concrete-lined pressure tunnel, ten feet in diameter, to be built in deep bedrock.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Feb. 14 (AP) -- A Federal Judge ruled invalid today a patent for all-nylon support stockings held by the Kayser-Roth Corporation of New York.

Archie Moore, recognized as the light-heavyweight boxing champion in New York, Massachusetts and Europe, was threatened yesterday with loss of his crown here unless he signed "forthwith" to defend against Doug Jones or another suitable challenger.

BRANELL, well-known Seventh Avenue manufacturer, and Best Co., well-known Fifth Avenue store, celebrated twelve years of close association yesterday. The occasion, fast becoming a tradition, was the press preview of Branell's spring collection at the store.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today the first Federal subsidy for an all-cargo airline, possibly opening the way for similar aid to other hard-pressed carriers.
State Supreme Court Justice Lewis W. Olliffe yesterday upheld the right of the New York City Housing Authority to close the community centers in two Brooklyn housing projects.

Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad authorized the company yesterday to seek a $5,000,000 bank loan, until Nov. 3, to meet payrolls and other obligations due over the next six weeks.
WASHINGTON, Feb 14 -- Richard M. Scammon, an expert in political statistics, was designated by President Kennedy today as director of the Census Bureau.
tiAnng, appropriate tropical setwith palm trees, aquariums of tropical fish, sea fans and seashells, was created for the second annual Jamaica and Antigua Carnival at the Sheraton-East last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Five Virginia Negroes, declaring their "patience exhausted," asked the Federal District Court today to bar President Kennedy and other officials from granting Federal aid to segregated schools.

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 464 persons had been injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the week of the ban on autos here following the snowstorm. This was a drop of 486, or more than 50 per cent from the period the year before.
The retiring president of the city's Protestant council said last night that Protestantism had become a minority influence in the United States.
A globe 120 feet in diameter will be the symbol of the New York World's Fair of 1964-65.

Ch. Cappoquin Little Sister, a toy poodle sharp as a nail and black as could be, became America's foremost show dog in Madison Square Garden last night. She was chosen best in show in the eighty-fifth Westminster Kennel Club competition to become the second of her variety to gain the honor.

ELISABETHVILLE, Feb. 14 (AP) -- President Tshombe said today that he was unworried by world reaction to the Lumumba slaying and that as for a possible United Nations investigation "I couldn't give a damn."

IS the contemporary American song in such disrepute that it does not interest anyone? Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, Walter Carringer devoted the second in his series of three programs to the works of six native living composers.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Unless state courts get more manpower, a breakdown in the administration of justice in some areas can be expected, the Judicial Conference warned today.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The strides made by the Soviet Union in public education may backfire one day against the Communist regime, the deputy secretary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today.

IN spite of heavy snows, deer in this area and in most of the Northeast are in pretty good shape so far as feed is concerned. But they are being cruelly slaughtered by dogs -- mostly privately owned, collared dogs.

International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it had begun construction of a 58,000-square-foot research laboratory in Ruschlikon, Switzerland. The new building will house I.B.M.'s Zurich research laboratory, replacing an installation that is now leased.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The State Board of Regents has thrown its weight behind a new bill to license chiropractors.

IN spite of heavy snows, deer in this area and in most of the Northeast are in pretty good shape so far as feed is concerned. But they are being cruelly slaughtered by dogs -- mostly privately owned, collared dogs.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The state Education Department announced the winners of 8,681 state scholarships today. Of the scholarships, 7,381 were Regents college awards, 1,000 were Regents science and engineering awards and 300 were nursing scholarships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara left doubts today whether he would back the Eisenhower Administration's proposal to cut the Army and National Guard reserve forces.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 14 -- American shipping unions started a new move today to build a Caribbean federation of maritime labor.
The women's committee of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service has completed plans for a benefit dinner dance to be held in the ballroom of the Pierre next Thursday.
Ashes, the symbol of penitence, were placed on the foreheads of worshipers yesterday in all Roman Catholic and some Protestant churches.

The direct purchase by Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., of 142,650 common shares of the Chance Vought Corporation in January was reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange in its latest insiders' list.

RELATIONS between the Soviet Union and the Columbia Broadcasting System are not likely to be bettered by last night's presentation of "The Spy Next Door," a quasi-documentary on the activities of Russian espionage agents in the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson was briefed tonight by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy on the Harlem organizations involved in today's demonstrations at the United Nations Security Council.
MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- Premier Khrushchev told President Kennedy today that any disarmament agreement should include "strict international control."
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller's student-aid plan came under heavy public fire today from New York City parents' group.
Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, was directed yesterday by Mayor Wagner to take "immediate action" to improve the care and treatment of patients in Harlem Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -John Hay Whitney, recently resigned Ambassador to Britain, reported to President Kennedy today on the successful negotiation of an agreement on bases with the Federation of West Indies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Mayor Raymond L. Telles of El Paso, Tex., has been chosen as Ambassador to Costa Rica.
Your Feb. 10 editorial concerning President Kennedy's health insurance program contains a reference to "* * * the hated 'means test.'"
A week after the independence of the Republic of the Congo was proclaimed last June 30, the Security Council voted unanimously that the nation be granted membership in the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -President Kennedy said tonight that anyone who considered all the available evidence would agree that "it is necessary to take action" to combat the recession.

In the largest financing this year, Morgan Stanley Co. and associates are offering today $150,000,000 of twenty-two-year debentures of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. The debentures are priced at 99 3/8 to yield investors 4.67 per cent to maturity. The price set an interest cost to G.M.A.C. of 4.735 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A sentimental, ceremonial presentation of a 200-year-old christening cup for John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr., first son of the President and Mrs. Kennedy, concluded today with a modern-day television-type commercial plug.

Sales last year of Textron, Inc., amounted to $383,188,000, against $308,202,000 in 1959. Earnings for 1960 were $14,168,000, or $2.93 a share, compared with $16,643,000, or $3.37 a share, the year before.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks, aided by Bobby Hull's twenty-fifth goal and two scores by Ab McDonald, ran their unbeaten string to six games tonight with a 5-2 victory over the New York Rangers.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 -- The leaders of 3,000,000 union construction workers ordered their members today to shun hasty strikes at missile bases.
Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gave Parliament today its first indication of what Britain's 1961-62 budget would look like.
Jackie Wilson, a 26-year-old rock 'n' roll singer, was shot and critically wounded early yesterday in a struggle with a woman fan.
Three jewelry men were robbed of gems valued at $86,000 and $4,000 in cash in hold-ups in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Union City, N.J., last night.

GENEVA, Feb. 15 -- The seven members of the European Free Trade Association agreed today on a new formula that should permit Finland to solve her difficult trading dilemma caused by dealings with both the Soviet Union and Western Europe.
A New York real estate investment concern has made up a list of what it considers the eight best cities in this country in which to buy investment property.
An advisory commission of five persons prominent in education or labor has been organized by the Board of Education to help improve staff relations in the city school system.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Northern Rhodesian Constitutional review conference came to grips in a general session today with the crucial issue of voting rights.

HONG KONG, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Communist China has told Cambodia that it is not against reactivating the international commission for Laos provided such a move is preceded by an international conference of the countries concerned, Hsinhua, the official Communist Chinese press agency, reported today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 15 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China declared today that the "vile murder" of Patrice Lumumba had been committed by "United States and Belgian imperialists and their agents."
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Industrial share prices took a turn for the better in the stock market here today on a modest increase in demand. Gains, seldom more than a shilling (14 cents), outnumbered losses.

Production of electric power fell in the week ended last Saturday to 14,744,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 15,072,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1960 period the figure was 14,178,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
Bryant, Boys High and Columbus were the victors yesterday as the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs began at Madison Square Garden.

TRAGEDY always seems to strike harder when it hits home. The air crash of a jet liner in Brussels yesterday was horrifying as all such disasters must be. It especially rocked the sports world with heavy impact because it erased the entire United States figure skating team, which was en route to the world championships at Prague.

Heartened by President Kennedy's commitment to work for the "ultimate freedom and welfare of the Eastern European people," some of these people, who stand for many more, observe today with new courage and inspiration the forty-third anniversary of their country's independence. They are the people of Lithuania, whether at home or abroad.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- While 5,400,000 Americans are unemployed, specialized jobs in fields ranging from physics to television repair are going begging.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- A Labor party member of Parliament introduced a bill in the House of Commons today that would prohibit British newspaper owners from holding a controlling interest in any television or broadcasting service or investing in such enterprises.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A wildcat strike of checkers and longshoremen at Pier 6, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, slowed the unloading of the Japanese cargo ship Havana Maru yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today the new Administration planned no public projects solely as back-to-work anti-recession measures.

IN the belief that turnabout is fair play, the house of Fontana in Rome is initiating its own reciprocal trade arrangement with the United States. Micol, one of the three sisters who head the Italian couture house, arrived in New York this week to buy the first American fashions for the Fontana Boutique.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the statement of condition of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 8:

MIAMI, Feb. 15 -- Carry Back, the Florida-bred from Jack Price's Dorchester Farm Stable, ran his race again today. That is, he came from way back in the mile-and-an-eighth Everglades to win by a half-length over Jacob Sher's long-priced Sherluck.

The United States imported more steel than it exported during 1960 for the second consecutive year. However, the dollar value of the exports exceeded that of the imported steel, according to figures released yesterday by the Department of Commerce.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 15 -- Brown cashed in on twenty-three of twenty-five free-throw attempts and defeated Yale, 67 -- 61, in an Ivy League basketball game tonight.
Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, yesterday rejected criticisms that the center's theatres and halls would be too small.
The director of the division of nursing of the American Hospital Association yesterday criticized the "changing role" of registered nurses in most hospitals.

The General Electric Company has estimated that at the most $1,500,000,000 of sales over the last five years were involved in possible damage suits that might be filed in the wake of the successful antitrust action brought by the Government against the company and the industry.
A justice of the United States Supreme Court criticized the Court here last night. He said it failed to protect individuals sufficiently against the abuse of power by states in criminal prosecutions.
SUMTER, S.C., Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Sumter County school board announced today that segregated Turkish children would be admitted to white schools in the fall of 1961.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- The American Bar Association's board of governors today offered aid to refugee Cuban lawyers and judges now living in the United States.
HARTFORD, Feb. 15 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey recommended tax increases totaling $129,200,000 today as he submitted a record general fund biennial budget of $589,200,000 to the Connecticut Legislature.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Finishing first in eight track events, the Princeton team defeated Penn and Columbia in the twenty-third annual Polar Bear meet today.

After ripping off five successive victories in the National Basketball Association, the Syracuse Nationals stumbled over the Knickerbockers in an overtime game at Madison Square Garden last night. They dropped a 129-127 decision to the last-place New Yorkers.

A criminal lawyer with thirty-one years' experience charged yesterday that Chief City Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch was unfit for his position and had acted "disgracefully" in a proceeding in which the lawyer was involved.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- In Hollywood, the Lilliputians of show business are those entrepreneurs who seek to produce entertainment live, on a stage, before an audience without popcorn. In most of the world this is known as legitimate theatre.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A fairly strong late rally today gave the grain futures market its first general advance of the week and sent most contracts up a cent or more.
Justice was meted out yesterday at a case-a-minute rate in Manhattan Traffic Court to violators of the Mayor's recent snowstorm ban on passenger automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -The police removed twenty-five Negroes in patrol wagons today after they had pelted the Belgian Embassy with snowballs and eggs for half an hour in a protest against the slaying of Patrice Lumumba, former Premier of the Congo.

Despite the sudden and tragic loss of the entire United States team in the crash of a Sabena airliner, the United States Figure Skating Association asked yesterday that the world championships, at Prague, Czechoslovakia, be held on schedule.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -President Kennedy pledged tonight that the United States would defend the Charter of the United Nations by opposing any attempt by any Government to intervene unilaterally in the Congo.

The "cold war" truce and "quiet diplomacy" sought by President Kennedy have been shattered by a riot-marked head-on clash between the United States and Soviet Russia in the United Nations Security Council. BOSTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Joe Cronin, president of the American League, today announced changes of rules for determining batting, pitching and fielding championships.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa estimated yesterday that the city's general fund would reach a record total of $872,636,000 for the fiscal year beginning next July 1. This, he said, "indicates there will be no need for new taxes of any kind."
Night became day and day was night yesterday in an experiment at the Bronx Zoo involving the biological clocks of two button-eyed African creatures called galagoes, or "bush babies."

Negotiations, are under way to establish the first hydrofoil passenger boat service in this city between the New York World's Fair site and Manhattan.

At the request of Governor Rockefeller and L. Judson Morhouse, the Republican State Chairman, William L. Pfeiffer has agreed to serve as a liaison officer between the city and state Republican organizations for this year's municipal campaign.

The bond market stayed firm yesterday as the successful outcome of Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon's first refunding operation continued to stimulate buying of the new 3 1/4 per cent notes and other Government issues.
Hunter College scored a 56-50 triumph over City College in a Tri-State League basketball game at the Hunter gymnasium in the Bronx last night.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Feb. 15 -- Violence flared in various parts of the Congo last night and today, but on the whole the mood of the country seemed to be one of uneasy calm.

Stop and Shop, Inc., which operates a group of supermarkets in New England, is planning to go into the department store business.
Peruvian textiles of the fifth through fifteenth century will go on display next Wednesday at the Delacorte Gallery at 822 Madison Avenue.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Dick Brennan, chief park engineer of the Adirondack Mountain Authority, has been going through what he calls "Operation Squeezo" in an around-the-clock effort to keep the state-owned $2,500,000 Whiteface area ticking.

The denial of contraceptive advice to city relief recipients is "a special cruelty to children and an irresponsibility to taxpayers," Dr. William Vogt, national director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said yesterday.

The dog fancy buzzed with indignation and bewilderment yesterday over the abrupt way the best-in-show judging at the Westminster Kennel Club event ended in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night. Dr. Joseph E. Redden of East Longmeadow, Mass., required only seven minutes to choose the toy poodle Ch. Cappoquin Little Sister as the main winner.

Jesse Stuart, 53-year-old Kentucky hill poet, has been selected by the Academy of American Poets to receive its $5,000 annual award for "distinguished poetic achievement." The prize is one the largest for poetry in this country.

Although January was 20 per cent colder than the same month a year ago, a new type of draft control is said to have brought a 17 per cent saving in fuel oil in an experiment in a twelve-story office building here.

A public hearing -- the last formality before approval -was held yesterday on a plan to widen part of the Grand Central Parkway in Queens by cantilevering the service roads.

Directors of the American Sugar Refining Company voted yesterday to pay an extra dividend of 15 cents a share, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share, on April 3 to holders of record of March 10.

The Texas Railroad Commission yesterday ordered a ten-day producing pattern for March for the prorated oil wells in the state. If this schedule should be maintained, it would result in an increase of about 200,000 barrels a day in the oil output of Texas next month from the February level. This month, the wells were permitted to produce only eight days.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Despite the greater use of automobiles, the number of persons killed in railroad grade-crossing accidents in the state last year fell to a new low, the state Public Service Commission reported.

PRESIDENT KENNEDY'S choice as Ambassador to Costa Rica is a Spanish-speaking Texan of Mexican ancestry who has had wide experience in dealing with Latin Americans. ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb 15 -- Navy's basketball team scored 12 straight points in the final three minutes to defeat Georgetown, 66 -- 57, today.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15 -- Dartmouth's hockey team scored ten times in the last two periods to rout Brown, 10 -- 2, tonight.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 -- George Meany called today for higher wages as the key to national prosperity and economic growth.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 15 -- The Louisiana Legislature opened its fifth special session since early November today. Gov Jimmie H. Davis' administration introduced measures to allow local elections to close public schools ordered integrated and to replace them with private segregated schools.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru ruled out today the possibility of his going to Peiping for further talks with Premier Chou En-lai on India's border dispute with Communist China. WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Army overpowered Delaware 70 -- 47, in basketball today.
The Corn Products Company achieved record sales and earnings last year, William T. Brady, chairman, announced yesterday.

CHANEL has pinned two gardenias on many of her new dresses as she did in the Twenties; bunches of cherries graced the lapel of a number of Pierre Cardin's suits; Jacques Griffe went in for mock roses twelve inches in diameter on suit revers, and Jean Patou's bertha necklines were accented by the same flower in more true-to-life sizes.

United States paper manufacturers invested an additional $78,000,000 in foreign manufacturing operations last year, increasing their total foreign investments to more than $800,000,000, the American Paper and Pulp Association reported yesterday.
TORONTO, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The second-place Montreal Canadiens snapped the league leading Toronto Maple Leafs' eight-game undefeated streak with a 3-1 victory tonight in a National Hockey League game.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Venezuela's Ministry of Development warned today that the Venezuelan automobile market would be closed to all foreign companies that did not announce before March 31 their decision to set up assembly plants in Venezuela.
PARIS, Feb. 15 -- The French Foreign Ministry expressed its disapproval today over the Soviet attack on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold following the death of Patrice Lumumba.

An American edition of a Japanese navy captain's World War II experiences will be published as a paperback by Ballantine Books on Feb. 27. "Japanese Destroyer Captain," by Capt. Baltimore, Md., borrowed $32,550,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, expansion of water and sewerage systems and other public improvements.

Revision of Governor Rockefeller's so-called "scholar-incentive" program has already been undertaken as a result of the many public protests against this plan to give state aid in a roundabout way to private, including church-connected, colleges. A cooperative union effort to aid 700 Negro Tennessee sharecropper families was started yesterday.

ERICH LEINSDORF led the Boston Symphony for the first time last night at Carnegie Hall. He made a distinct hit and at the conclusion of the program the members of the orchestra joined the audience in applauding him.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company set a price tag of $86 yesterday on shares it will offer to its two million stockholders on Feb. 23. This means that the one-for-twenty stock offering will have a value of about $965,350,000, making it the largest private financing venture in American business history.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 -- President Itzak Ben-Zvi asked David Ben-Gurion today to call on him tomorrow to receive a mandate to form a new government.

Two experienced stage managers, both dedicated to the smooth operation of "My Fair Lady," have decided to become producers. Entering the managerial ranks will be Jerry Adler and his chief, Samuel Liff.
THE impish, urbane turn of writing for which the late Ferenc Molnar was noted is very much in evidence in "There Is a Play Tonight," which had its premiere last night at the Theatre Marquee.

Events today: "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45 P.M.; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Thomas Schippers, conductor, Leon Fleisher, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert MacDonald, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Jeanette Medina, violinist, La Maison Francaise, 16 Washington Mews, 8:30; Zita Carno, pianist, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30.

M. Mac Schwebel, president of Universal Controls, Inc., announced yesterday that he had taken a leave of absence from the company "so that I might attend to an important personal matter, which bears no relation whatever to Universal Controls."

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The First Charter Financial Corporation reported today that net earnings were $12,990,000 for 1960, compared with $10,299,200 for 1959. The earnings were equal to $2.01 a share for 1960, against $1.59 a share for 1959.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 15 -- Premier John M. Chang cautioned the South Korean people today against anti-American agitation by Communist North Korea over the new United States-South Korean economic aid agreement.

Today's new film is "Cimarron," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer color version of Edna Ferber's novel, starring Glenn Ford, Maria Schell and Anne Baxter, at the Radio City Music Hall. Edmund Grainger produced and Anthony Mann directed, from a screen play by Arnold Schulman.

A stockholder filed suit yesterday to block the purchase by the Bates Manufacturing Company, textile concern, of the stock of Fruit of the Loom, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that he had not yet decided whether to go along with the proposed enlargement of the House of Representatives.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia rejected today charges by an Albanian leader that Yugoslavia had plotted with the United States and Greece to overthrow the Albanian regime.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The problem of belligeren statements by high military officers drew some more comment today from President Kennedy.
Except for international oils and building materials, both ragged rather than weak, the stock market made an almost concerted advance yesterday. Aggregate market value rose almost 1 per cent.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the formation of a wholly owned trust affiliate that will open next Monday in Nassau, Bahamas, and will be known as The Chase Manhattan Trust Corporation, Ltd. The stock of the company is held through The Chase Manhattan Overseas Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -The Kennedy Administration is not going to allow the communization of the Congo even if it has to intervene militarily to stop it. That was the clear implication of President Kennedy's warning to Moscow at his news conference this evening.
The Kratter Corporation offered yesterday to buy and lease back to the Jacob Ruppert Brewery the seven and fourtenths acres on which the brewery is situated in Yorkville.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) -- George Taniguchi rode Fun House to victory in the $22,900 Santa Susana Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Santa Anita today.

The effects of a recent virus infection have forced Dame Myra Hess to cancel the remainder of her American engagements for this season. The British pianist's most recent New York appearance was as recitalist at Hunter College on Jan. 28.
TROY, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's hockey team scored five goals in the second period tonight and went on to defeat Yale, 8 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Representative Howard W. Smith put Speaker Sam Rayburn's boiling point to a not-sosubtle test today in a deft stroke of political gamesmanship.

By inadvertence, I am sure, a dispatch to The Times from Albany (Feb. 13) failed to make it clear that there is a sharp difference of opinion within the State Legislature over a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit the leasing to private commercial interests of 230 acres of forest preserve land on Hunter Mountain in the Catskills for the expansion of a large existing ski area.

Madison Square Garden will have ten rows of seats priced at $100 a seat for the closed-circuit television showing of the March 13 title fight, Mrs. Jane Pickens Langley said yesterday. Floyd Patterson will defend his heavyweight crown against Ingemar Johansson in Miami Beach on that night.
A new hormone from the pituitary gland has been found in animal studies at the Goldwater Memorial Hospital. It appears to stimulate the release into the blood of fat stored in the body.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco, reported yesterday that gross operating revenues rose to $647,888,000 in 1960 from $583,425,000 the year before. Net income was $92,565,000, equal to $4.14 a share, compared with $84,737,000, or $3.70 a share, in 1959, according to the preliminary report.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Kennedy pledged the United States tonight to assist the new Government in El Salvador in its efforts to improve that nation's standard of living.

New York University and Manhattan College, continuing a basketball rivalry that dates to 1909, meet in the second game of a college double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The 7:30 o'clock curtain-raiser will send Iona College against Xavier of Ohio.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb 15 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta beat a dozen men professionals today in the $10,000 Palm Beach par-3 invitation golf tournament.

WHAT he doesn't know about love would fill a book," someone once said of a tirelessly toiling novelist. "And as a matter of fact he's already filled seven or eight books with that, heaven help us all."
ATLANTA, Feb. 15 -- Eight ministers were arrested here today in a sit-in demonstration designed to support Negro students jailed in the anti-segregation fight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The major industrial countries of Western Europe pledged today that they would put no discriminatory restrictions on the use of their currencies in world trade.
Manhattan Democrats in Congress sought a showdown on Federal patronage yesterday and were asked by John M. Bailey, the Democratic national Chairman, to "wait a week and see what happens."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Senator Jacob K. Javits asked the State Department today to inquire into reports of persecution of Jews in Morocco.
G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, left by plane last night for Africa to begin a one-month survey of fifteen nations.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Buck White carded a record nine-under-par 63 today and took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the Professional Golfers Association senior championship at the National P.G.A. course.
THERE is some question as to what is the strongest pair tournament of this or any recent year, but it is not one of the official tournaments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A reporter told the President at his news conference tonight that one of his relatives. Bayard Auchincloss, had started a one-man campaign for a sound dollar, and asked Mr. Kennedy for comment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ended hearings today on a convention committing the United States to active membership in a new Western economic alliance.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Fairleigh Dickinson scored an 89-47 victory over Upsala last night to run its winning streak to four. Upsala has lost its last six games.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- President Kennedy pledged the United States today to maintain its full military commitment to the Atlantic Alliance and to work to strengthen Atlantic cooperation in economic, ideological and political spheres.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- Pope John XXIII joined several millions of Italians and many thousands of foreign scientists and tourists in watching today's eclipse of the sun.
The election of James H. Douglas and Elwood R. Quesada as directors of American Airlines, Inc. was announced yesterday by C.R. Smith, president.

A study of the feasibility of staggered work hours south of Chambers Street to relieve the rush-hour strain on transit and building elevators was proposed yesterday by the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -President Kennedy was asked at his news conference tonight if there were prospects for pooling American-Soviet space explorations efforts, a subject he and Mr. Khrushchev discussed in the exchange of messages.
With firecrackers banging underfoot and the clash of cymbals and thunder of drums filling the air, lions danced through the streets and gobbled up money in Chinatown yesterday.
The peak in unemployment may have been reached, if the majority of company officials queried recently by the National Industrial Conference Board are correct in their forecasts.
WARSAW, Feb. 15 -- A mob of young Poles, protesting the death of Patrice Lumumba, sacked the Belgian Embassy today and assaulted diplomats who tried to defend it.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 14 off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale. The far months were weakest.

MISS BERGDORF'S Petite Couture Collection has been designed for the young in heart, figure and fashion attitudes. Virginie and a group of anonymous -- but young -- French designers created the designs that have been adapted by Seventh Avenue Manufacturers in proportions suited to the smaller figure.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 199,949,000 board feet, compared with 193,731,000 board feet the previous week, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 248,556,000 board feet.
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 9 -- "What I like about this country is the lack of pressure," said one of the 17,575 Americans living in Australia. "Even in Sydney it's hard to get ulcers."
DUBLIN, Feb. 16 -- Half of the Sir Hugh Lane collection of pictures, in dispute between Britain and Ireland for thirty-five years, was formally handed over in trust to Dublin tonight.

ROMANTICALLY Spain is the land of glamorous toreros and enraged toros. Gastronomically it offers incomparable sherry and top-grade olive oil. Climatically it is somewhat like Florida -- a land of sunshine and of oranges.

WASHINGTON, Feb 16 -- The White House announced today that Secretary of State Dean Rusk would lead the United States delegation at the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization meeting in Bangkok, Thailand, next month.

The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday slight gains in operating revenues and net income for 1960. It was noted, however, that "reflecting local business conditions," fourth-quarter kilowatt-hour sales were 1.8 per cent below those of the final quarter of 1959, although electric revenues were 2.2 per cent higher.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP) -- William Bufalino, a member of the Teamsters Union's board of monitors, lost today his suit to collect $1,000,000 in damages on the ground that he had been denied the privilege of purchasing a home in a Detroit suburb.

DUBLIN, Feb. 15 -- American and Irish interests are joining to build three hotels in Ireland at an estimated cost of $7,000,000.

Ten nations will be represented in the fencing tourney that gets under way today at the New York Athletic Club.

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico is planning to sell $40,000,000 of public improvement bonds on March 7. Bids on the issue will be received by the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico, fiscal agent, at the bank's office here at 45 Wall Street.

THE homemaker bound for Altman's model rooms, which open today, is in for a walk. But it is worth it. Scattered about the furniture floor are three interiors that star Henredon's new French provincial furniture collection, each piece of which is beautifully made from its cherrywood finish down to the smallest hand-carved detail.

In a 3-2 decision yesterday the Appellate Division invalidated a ruling by the New York State Athletic Commission that had barred Johnny De John and Joseph Netro from engaging in professional boxing activities in this state.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States had a 13 per cent gain in total sales last year, James F. Oates Jr., president, reported. The 101st annual report also noted new records in assets, insurance in force, premium and annuity income and benefit payments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Continued declines in freight loadings, because of ice and snow throughout much of the Eastern sections of the country, were reported today in the weekly reports of both the rail and truck industries.

A new computer system, said to be the first designed specifically for use with the simplest programing possible, was announced yesterday by the Burroughs Corporation.

Pleasure boating's largest membership body grew during the past month to 302 squadrons when petitions from six groups were accepted. These were added at the annual meeting of the United States Power Squadrons at Miami Beach.

THE annual antiques fair at Greenwich House, a small show that has won a large following, opens today with such diverse lures as an old Irish lace wedding veill a six-foot-high ostrich and other more conventional carved carousel figures.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $14,000,000 to $193,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday; the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $120,000,000 to $687,000,000.
The transfer to Mohawk Airlines of eight communities now served by Eastern Air Lines in upstate New York and Vermont was proposed to the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday by the two carriers.

Three generations of membership in the United Order of True Sisters will be represented at the thirty-fifth anniversary luncheon of the order's Loyalty Lodge No. 31 tomorrow at the Sheraton-East.
The new Republican Advisory Council, set up to plan the party's Mayoral campaign, recommended yesterday that Charter revision be made a major issue in this year's election.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- One of the most unpredictable movie sets in town these days is at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, where "Ada" is being filmed. Daniel Mann is the film's director and Dean Martin is the male lead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, indicated today that his Senate Preparedness subcommittee would conduct a preliminary inquiry to determine whether the Government -- like commercial airlines -- paid inflated prices for plane parts.

The outflow of gold from the United States has slowed but not stopped. In the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday, the decline amounted to $16,000,000, reducing the monetary gold stock to $17,398,000,000.

Martin Tananbaum, the raceway president, telephoned this information from Christchurch, New Zealand, today.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 -- Passenger car sales in the first ten days of February continued at a low rate running nearly 30 per cent below the 1960 volume and closely paralleling that in 1958. Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., pharmaceuticals maker, had record sales and earnings last year, it was announced yesterday. World-wide sales rose to $269,376,092 from $253,672,721 in 1959. Earnings in 1960 were $26,183,317, or $1.58 a share, against $24,862,955, or $1.52 a share, the year before.

DECATUR, Ill., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Charles Moody and her 8-month-old daughter, Terry Lynn, escaped death last night when their car was demolished by a freight train at a rural crossing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Kennedy sent his first farm bill to Congress today. It was designed to bolster farm income and to control a developing surplus of corn and other feed grains. The measure would require farmers to reduce the acreage planted to feed grains in order to remain eligible for price supports, which would be increased.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- The Flight Engineers International Association announced today that it would strike against Pan American World Airways this week-end. No specific time was mentioned.

Both old and new rubber futures prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here on reports that tire factories are planning further cutbacks in production. Prices of the old Rex contract fell 45 to 69 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on ninety-four lots of 22,400 pounds each.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Three Democratic members of the Senate subcommittee on problems of the aging said today a Social Security health care program for old persons should have "first priority for 1961."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Two members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee predicted today that Communist China would soon be seated in the United Nations, perhaps at the sixteenth session of the General Assembly next fall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Feb. 11 were 3 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
Two influential members of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations are opposing the recently established social action center in Washington.
TUNIS, Feb. 10 -- Ministers of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government held a final meeting today with Tunisian leaders concerning direct contact with the French Government for peace talks.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 16 -- Belgian university students smashed windows in the embassy of the United Arab Republic today in reprisal for the burning of the Belgian Embassy in Cairo by Egyptian students yesterday.
A luncheon and show of spring and summer fashions will be held in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on March 7 for the benefit of the Metropolitan Chapter of the National Hemophilia Foundation.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 16 (AP) -- President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province declared today that the Communist bloc threatened to create a civil war in the Congo of the kind that had been fought in Korea.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Jimmy Bostwick, three games from defeat in the second set, rallied to beat Charles Petrosky, a New York professional, 7 -- 8, 8 -- 5, 8 -- 3, in the quarterfinals of the United States open court tennis championship today at the Racquet Club.
Because the field goal is mightier than the free throw in basketball, New York University experienced only mild difficulty in downing Manhattan College, 71 -- 65, at Madison Square Garden last night.
Plans were announced yesterday for construction of a forty- four-story office building to occupy the blockfront on the east side of Third Avenue, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets.

MIAMI; Feb. 16 (AP) -- Manuel Ycaza, who will begin an extended suspension tomorrow, rode the favored Popperdopper to a narrow victory in today's feature race at Hialeah before a crowd of 17,573.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 -- The Justice Department expanded its contempt action against Louisiana officials today in a move to release $350,000 in Federal funds for the New Orleans public school system. The money has been withheld during the desegregation controversy here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- In a guessing game on the Administration's new farm program recommendations, grain futures dealers today pushed prices over a broad range both above and below preceding closes on the Board of Trade, but at the finish many contracts were little changed.

Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, announced yesterday the appointment of Russell L. Reed as controller, effective July 1.

A criminal lawyer who had called Chief City Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch unfit was criticized by the magistrate Yesterday for "intemperate language and disregard for the facts" but he was cleared of a charge of unethical practice.

George Lowe, a New Zealander crippled in childhood, became interested in mountain climbing for its therapeutic and sports value. He overcame his handicap to the extent that he was able to accompany Sir Edmund Hillary on the expedition that conquered Mount Everest in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- United States collective bargaining rights were extended today to aliens manning American- owned ships flying foreign flags.

A six-story building containing sixty-one apartments at 319 West Eighteenth Street has been purchased by an investing client of Herbert Felner, lawyer. It was sold by the 319 West Eighteenth Street Corporation in the first change of ownership since the building was erected in 1928.
THE Oedipus story took a turn last night that might have startled Sophocles, if not Freud. It appeared at the Cherry Lane Theatre in the guise of a modern musical called "The Tiger Rag."
Crime in New York City increased in 1960 for the seventh straight year, the Police Department reported yesterday. It said the rise reflected a nation-wide trend.

ROSWELL, N.M., Feb. 16 (AP) -- A thirty-five-ton crane slipped over the edge of an underground missile pit today, fell 172 feet to the bottom and exploded. At least six workmen were killed and fourteen injured. Two of the injured were not expected to live.

NASTY weather in the North Atlantic has hampered fishermen so that they have been able to bring here only moderate supplies of fish rather than the abundance that might be desired during this Lenten period.

A former Republican leader of Oyster Bay, L.I., was accused yesterday of willfully failing to file income tax reports for 1954 and 1955 when he had a gross income of $68,000.

CANADA ranks among other nations as one of the greatest users of modern household conveniences and electrical equipment, according to a recent survey by the Bureau of Statistics.

An intensive inspection of 125 private schools in the city that serve meals has been started in an effort to check the recent rise in cases of infectious hepatitis. Mayor Wagner announced the move yesterday after receiving a report on the disease from Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner.
VIENNA, Feb. 16 -- Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria will relinquish his office April 11, it was officially announced today.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- About 300,000 cheering Portuguese welcomed home the liner Santa Maria today and gave Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar one of the biggest ovations in his long political career.

A new guidance program for teen-agers was announced yesterday by the Children's Aid Society at its annual meeting here.

As Stephen P. Kennedy nears the end of his first full five-year term in office he commands almost unanimous public respect for a job well done. BOWIE, Md., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Alex S. Chris' Bold Scholar won the Frederick Purse at Bowie today after being backed down to even money.

A syndicate of investors has contracted to buy the thirty-four-story store, office and showroom building at 1410 Broadway, southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street, near the Metropolitan Opera House. A play dealing with the romance between George Bernard Shaw and Mrs. Patrick Campbell has caught the fancy of H. Clay Blaney and A.J. Pocock. It is called "A Fig Leaf in Her Bonnet," and it is the work of Jess Torn, a new dramatist.

Earnings of the G.C. Murphy Company last year were sharply below the 1959 level, although sales rose to a new high, officers of the retail variety store chain reported.
Commodities prices on the New York Stock exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Trading generally was listless.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 17 -- Belgian university students shattered windows in the embassies of the Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic today as a retaliation for damage to Belgian embassies in Moscow and Cairo.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Jay Hebert, always a big money-winner on the tour, and unheralded Buddy Sullivan tied for the halfway lead in the $20,000 Tucson open golf tournament today. They posted 36-hole scores of 131.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 17 -Mayor Charles S. Witkowski, today confirmed that his brother would be an independent candidate for Governor in November.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The crash of an Eastern Airlines Electra at Boston last Oct. 4 has been tentatively attributed to its collision with a large flock of starlings.
DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 17 (AP) -- John Milton Addison and five of his associates were convicted today on twelve counts of Securities Act violations and mail fraud.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- A concealed-weapons charge against Frank Robinson, out-fielder-first baseman for the Cincinnati Reds, was referred to the Hamilton County grand jury today.
DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today February car production was "hovering at its lowest level since 1952."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -British and United States officials ended three days of conferences today on their balance-of-payments problems.

The purchase price is 16 1/2 cents a thousand cubic feet at the well-head.

The nation's shipbuilders have urged President Kennedy to consider a "relatively small curtailment" in the country's foreign aid program. The funds thus saved would be devoted to a "modest acceleration" of merchant marine and Navy ship construction programs.

AN unusual combination of inspiration and training goes to form the sculptural style of Noor-Zade Brener, a young French artist of Persian origin and a pupil, successively, of Despiau and Zadkine, who is showing work at the Van Diemen-Lilienfeld Galleries, 21 East Fifty-seventh Street.
