Wrestling is a long way from coming the national pastime, to its growth in recent years the high school level has en remarkable.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 17 -- The widow of Patrice Lumumba, his youngest son and his brother were placed under United Nations protection today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The long-awaited merger application of the Great Northern Railway and the Northern Pacific Railway was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today. It anticipates consolidating four carriers into the world's largest privately owned railroad system in terms of miles of roadway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Kennedy has tentatively picked Thomas D'Alesandro Jr., former Mayor of Baltimore, as head of the Urban Renewal Administration, Democratic party sources said today.
WHERE else but at the Osborne apartment house could you open one closet and hear Blanche Thebom vocalizing and another and listen to Van Cliburn practicing.
MIAMI, Fla. Feb. 17 (UPI) -G.T. Baker, president of National Airlines, rejected today Pan-American World Air-ways' demand that it re-exchange 400,000 shares of Pan-American stock.
BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 17 -- Ocean going commercial traffic through the Panama Canal continued at recent high levels during January, when 893 vessels of this category went through the canal.

The tenth annual Brotherhood Award of the New York County Council of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States will be presented on Tuesday to Morris Morgenstern.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Prospects of House action in about a week on the first of president Kennedy's economic measures opened up today as the Ways and Means Committee ended hearings on an emergency unemployment compensation bill.

A massive steel girder, the biggest of forty that will support the new Port Authority bus station at the east end of the George Washington Bridge, was set in place yesterday, as gently as a candle is set on a birthday cake.

PALISADES, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- A Jewish philanthropic organization has bought one of the show places of this area -- a twenty-two-acre estate -- as a home for the aged.

A man who sought to rescue a youth and who, as a result, was convicted of assaulting a policeman, won a dismissal yesterday in the Appellate Division.
MIAMI, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Ralph Terry of the Yankees scored a 75 today for a 36-hole total of 149 and a one-stroke lead at the halfway point in the baseball players' national golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Kennedy's first farm bill stirred a somnolent Congress into promises of quick action today, but there were signs of gathering opposition.

The board of directors of the Continental Commercial Corporation took no action yesterday on the common stock dividend normally declared at this time. The company has distributed 10 cents a share in recent quarters, the latest on Dec. 15.
Overcrowding in the city school system last term deprived 55,242 pupils of a full school day, the Board of Education said yesterday. This is about 5.5 per cent of the total enrollment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -Average wholesale prices in primary markets averaged unchanged during the week ended last Tuesday at 120 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- A few hours after Mrs. Geiger was sentenced, a Federal grand jury that has conducted a long investigation of the ramifications of the embezzlement returned an indictment. Federal officials would not make a flat statement, but all indications were that the indictment would mean a new chapter in the story of Mrs. Geiger.

Flight engineers struck Pan American World Airways last night. Sympathy walkouts disrupted service on Eastern, Trans World and American.

I HOPE (and believe) that there are some enthusiasts still around who relish the game of wits between the author and the reader of a detective story. CLEVELAND, Feb. 11 -- The outlook for a profitable iron-ore season on the Great Lakes next season is not too encouraging, according to a report issued by the American Iron Ore Association.

THE somewhat forbidding title of Graham Greene's new novel is a term used for those victims of leprosy who can be cured because the disease has eaten about all that it wants -- toes, ears, fingers. They no longer suffer the excruciating pains of those who undergo cure with their bodies intact.

IN Yael Dayan's second novel, "Envy the Frightened," modern Israel is the battleground where new men struggle to break free from old values. Twenty-one-year-old Yael Dayan, the daughter of former chief of the Israeli Army, Gen. Moshe Dayan, leaves no doubt where her own sympathies lie.

Quarles School here on March 1. Proceeds will benefit the league's Community Trust Fund, which helps to support local health and welfare agencies.

On Wednesday European astronomers had the rare treat of a total solar eclipse which followed a path across the locations of several major observatories. Erich Leinsdorf returned to Carnegie Hall with the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon for his second guest-conducting stint and led a handsomely balanced program. It consisted of Mozart's Symphony No. 29, excerpts from Wagner's "Die Goetterdammerung" and Prokofieff's Symphony No. 5.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Prime Minister Macmillan met today with several members of the Cabinet to discuss steps to be taken following the close of the conference on constitutional reforms for Northern Rhodesia.

THE maple sap will soon be running in the Green Mountain State and, to a lesser extent, in the neighboring New England area. Already anxious Vermonters are wondering what this year's crop will be like, but they will have to wait with patience for another few weeks.

Dr. Carmyn J. Lombardo, a former member of the Board of .Higher Education, asked Governor Rockefeller yesterday to "order" the Legislature to investigate charges of racial and religious discrimination at Queens College.

Templeton, Damroth Corporation is the latest to join the ranks of companies whose funds are abandoning the voluntary accumulation plan method of investing as being entirely impractical. Future emphasis will be on contractual plans by which the investor is required to keep up with his "front-end load" payments or suffer potential financial losses in the early years.

The President and the Secretary of State have acted wisely in deciding that Mr. Rusk will go to Bangkok to attend the meeting of the Council of Ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization in late March. The forthcoming SEATO meeting is of such importance that Mr. Rusk is warranted in participating in spite of his intention to limit his trips abroad as much as possible while he heads the State Department.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, which dropped big-money television quiz shows in 1959 in the aftermath of the quiz scandal, will initiate three daytime game programs on March 13.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- The Afghan Ch. Shirkhan of Grandeur, an Old Man River of dog shows, kept rolling along tonight, becoming the main winner in the thirty-ninth event of the Elm City Kennel Club.
A tiny monkey that responds -- sometimes -- to the name Leontiliblis apparently felt the urge of approaching spring yesterday.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Rain, thaw and a decision by a Federation Internationale bobsled toboggan jury gave Eugenio Monti of Italy his second straight four-man bobsled world championship today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Perfectionism, Hollywood learned long ago can be very expensive. But now that Paramount is ready to release "One-Eyed Jacks," it is beginning to appreciate some of the humor in the making of the $6,000,000 Western that was originally budgeted at $1,800,000.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Thirteen skiers turned back the pages of history today in the old-timers' jumping tournament.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (Reuters) The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, guardian of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, this week will be split in two.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg failed yesterday to end the wildcat strike of flight engineers against six major airlines.

ZINO FRANCESCATTI'S recital at Hunter College on Saturday night showed how a virtuoso who is also a shrewd program builder can coax an audience to a point of climactic enthusiasm at precisely the right time.

Readers of this newspaper could learn yesterday that dark-skinned diplomats at the U.N. had a harder time finding homes in New York and its environs than did their lighter-skinned colleagues. Some were aided in their search by three successive American Ambassadors to the U.N.: Henry Cabot Lodge, James J. Wadsworth and Adlai E. Stevenson.

A broken water main on an overpass showered pieces of pavement, water and dirt down onto the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn early this morning. The break occurred at Knapp Street directly over the parkway near Coney Island.
Seventy-two prominent Manhattan residents have lost their designation as honorary commissioners of borough works in the Manhattan Borough President's office.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The capital expects to have its second Presidential inauguration this year after all.
ATLANTA, Feb. 19 -- The three Roman Catholic bishops of Georgia and South Carolina announced today that parochial schools in their states would be desegregated no later than the public schools.

Alan H. Posner, realty investor, has purchased two six-story elevator apartment buildings at 14 and 16 East Seventy-third Street, east of Fifth Avenue. The houses, which occupy a plot 45 by 102 feet, have elevators and are assessed at $225,000.
MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Don Whitt of Borrego Springs, Calif., posted a par 72 today and won the Maracaibo open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 283.

A short time ago few people in Europe would have recognized the name of New York's Mayor Wagner. Now he is both famous and popular, for he had the daring to use a snowstorm to point to the future laws governing automobile use and the way the world's cities can, become habitable for human beings again.
Three terra cotta "Etruscans," exposed last week as impostors, drew knowing smiles yesterday from visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- A man who should know says President Kennedy could shoot golf consistently in the 70's if he played about three rounds a week.

Wladimiro Calarese, a fierce competitor from Italy, won the saber event of the New York Athletic Club's international fencing tournament yesterday. With brutal stroking that dominated the bout, Calarese defeated Claude Arabo, a French Army private, 9-7, in close final match.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 19 -- All Spanish forces are to be evacuated from Morocco by March 2, a dispatch of the Moroccan press agency Maghreb Arab Press said today.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Glenn Fiddes of Fox Hill Farms, Pleasantville, N.Y., was a double winner in national qualifying events at the annual Saddle Tree Farms winter horse show today.
WOMEN are often not aware that their normal hair-care procedure can cause ends to become brittle and split, according to hair stylist John Fonda.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Sales and earnings reached a record high at the Eastman Kodak Company in 1960, Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and William S. Vaughn, president, said in a joint statement today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Charlie Burns' third-period goal enabled the Boston Bruins to tie the Chicago Black Hawks 2 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 11.254.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 19 -- President Kennedy "has not hesitated to grab the bull by the horns" to seek an end of racial discrimination in housing, G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Iranian Oil Consortium today denied reports that a dispute with Iraq over shipping in the Shatt al Arab River would force an immediate shutdown of the giant refinery at Abadan.
The Modern Jazz Quartet fulfilled an engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday night that had originally been scheduled for Feb. 4 but was postponed when the snows came.
The list of the twenty-one governments that have formally agreed to take part in the New York World's Fair of 1964-65 was announced yesterday by Robert Moses, president of the fair corporation.
Statistics are the lifeblood of mutual funds.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Union leaders, gathering for the mid-winter meeting of labor's high command, warned today that President Kennedy's program fell short of the nation's need for economic revival.
The Walrus continued to make trouble for the Carpenter at Coney Island's Aquarium yesterday.

THE piano and the harpsichord ought to be natural enemies. One of their rare displays of amity took place at Saturday night's "Music Forgotten and Remembered" concert under Frederic Waldman at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Supreme Court returns from its midwinter recess tomorrow with many significant cases awaiting decision and more scheduled for argument.
Senator Thruston B. Morton, the Republican national chairman, said yesterday "the eyes of the nation will be on New York City" in the fall mayoral election.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 19 -- Practically the only highlight on the Amsterdam Bourse last week was the advance registered by Philips, which rose to 1,207 1/2 from the preceding week's 1,162 3/4. The gain was scored despite the seizure of Philips' enterprises in Cuba because sentiment was aided by news of the enlargement of Philips' chemical interests in the United States.
Your editorial of Feb. 13 on Federal tax policy on depreciation neglected a number of critical considerations.

In a letter published Feb. 14 Dr. Erich Fromm has commented on President Kennedy's statement that "We must never be lulled into believing that either power [Russia or China] has yielded its ambition for world domination * * *."
GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- For historians, economists and political philosophers, it would be, in a sense, unfortunate if the present division of Europe into two free-trading groups were quickly resolved.
IS it a fact of nature, or Broadway's poor luck this season, that a play with comic Russians turns out to be an untidy affair overrun by stock characters?

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 19 -- An accidental shooting and a death from natural causes revealed today that a Long Island heiress had left an estate of nearly $1,000,000 to her Negro woman companion of many years.

The America Fore Loyalty Group showed a consolidated net operating gain for 1960 of $10,100,000, an increase of $200,000 over the level of 1959, J. Victor Herd, chairman of the Continental Insurance Company, parent company of the group, announced over the week-end.

PRINCE CHARLES' vacations in the Scottish Highlands with James Robertson Justice, who is teaching him hunting, fishing, falconry and other manly arts, should help further their avowed purpose of "making a man out of the boy," a Queens College psychologist suggested recently.
The Rangers beat the Toronto Maple Leafs for a change last night at Madison Square Garden. Humbled by the Leafs on five previous occasions on home ice, the New Yorkers won this one, 4 -- 2.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- When the Congo crisis first began to assume serious proportions, General de Gaulle sent a secret proposal to President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan recommending action by the Western Big Three to prevent chaos and Communist intervention.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 20 -- Newspapers here today attributed six deaths to yesterday's nation-wide strike of physicians and dentists. The medical and dental associations called a day-long halt of their members' services in a demand for higher fees in the Government health insurance program.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Prime Minister Macmillan failed today to assuage the wrath of the African nationalist leaders who have denounced the results of the conference on constitutional reforms for Northern Rhodesia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The tenth anniversary of the celebrated falling out between President Truman and the Federal Reserve Board finds the board and President Kennedy in apparent harmony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- President Kennedy moved today to strengthen White House control over national security and foreign policy actions, and assure that Federal agencies adhere to "the policy of the White House in those fields."
TRENTON, Feb. 19 -- The last remaining covered bridge in New Jersey will be restored.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Henk van der Grift of the Netherlands, a 25-year-old auto mechanic, captured the world speed-skating championship today by holding off Viktor Kosichkin, Soviet Union's European champion, in a dramatic 10,000-meter race.
The amount of automobile exhaust fumes in New York City's air is greater than at any time since measurements began in 1955, the Department of Air Pollution Control announced yesterday.

William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, believes the pursuit of peace "means making the search for fool proof disarmament the first item on the international agenda."
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The New York Knickerbockers prevented the St. Louis Hawks from clinching the Western Division title in the National Basketball Association with a 123-100 victory today.
The U.S. dollar was strong against the British pound and European currencies in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Canadian dollar maintained a firm undertone in moderate dealings.

THE realities of the economic recession recently have been covered regularly on nightly news presentations, but Chet Huntley's half-hour program yesterday was one of the more extended treatments of the downturn in business.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19 -- A California biophysicist has developed a method for monitoring prenatal heart beats.
The first major change in flying regulations resulting from the Dec. 16 collision of two airliners over Staten Island has been issued by the Federal Aviation Agency.

State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, an insurgent Democrat of Manhattan, assailed his party's leaders yesterday for supporting Governor Rockefeller's proposed $200-a-year grants to students in private colleges.

THE annual invitational pair tournament of the Cavendish Club of New York, which was played in three sessions Saturday and yesterday, was an experiment in a different scoring method and the experiment may be said to have failed.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $82,330,611,881. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

MIAMI, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Harry (Peanuts) Lowrey, coach of the Philadelphia Phillies, shot a two-over-par 35, 37 -- 72 today to win the national baseball players' golf championship with a 72-hole total of 295.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 19 -- The future role of Jomo Kenyatta, convicted leader of the Mau Mau terrorist movement, has become a major issue in Kenya's general election. Voting for a new Legislative Council started today.

BUFFALLO, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The most severe drought in Western New York in the last quarter century has dropped the area's water level to a record low and caused extreme hardships for farmers and home owners.
New York was a place in the sun for a short time yesterday. Temperatures rose to 63 degrees -- the warmest reading for the date on record.

The appointment of William Swallow as managing director of Vauxhall Motors, Ltd., was announced yesterday, to take effect April 1. Vauxhall Motors is a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation that makes Vauxhall cars and Bedford trucks in England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The United States welcomed as "constructive and promising" today the move by the King of Laos to establish his country's neutrality and end all forms of intervention by East and West.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- An American who had been ordered by the United States consulate general in Nairobi to leave Kenya denied here today that he had directly tried to recruit persons to fight in the Katanga army in the Congo.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made twelve loans aggregating $292,400,000 in the six months ended on Dec. 31, it reported yesterday. This brought the number of loans made by the bank to 277 in fifty-four countries and raised the gross total of loans signed to $5,473,000,000.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 -- The belief here today is that relations with the United States have been restored, as one of Chancellor Adenauer's associates put it, to their "old friendly basis" by Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano's visit to Washington on Friday.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 19 -- Ansten Samuelstuen, an electronics engineer from Boulder, Colo., captured the national ski-jumping title today. He regained the title he first won in 1957 in Berlin, N.H., on flights of 206 and 200 feet for a total of 224.7 points.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- A week that promises to prove crucial in the search for a solution of the six-year-old problem of the Algerian rebellion opened today with the arrival in Paris of Mohamed Masmoudi, Tunisian Minister of Information and former Ambassador to France.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- A shortage of wind made today's fifth and final race of the annual Lightning Class winter sailing championships more a drifting than a sailing event. Hank Cawthra of Grosse Point, Mich., emerged as the over-all champion.

Park Commissioner Morris has recently been keeping a watchful eye on food purchasing for Gracie Mansion, Mayor Wagner's house, and this vigilance has reaped dividends in lowered costs. According to the food and meat bills for December, 1960, the first month of Mr. Morris' stewardship, these items totaled only $491.20 for the month, as against $2,209.70 for the month of December, 1959.
DETROIT, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens posted their fourth straight victory tonight, a 4-2 decision over the Detroit Red Wings before 14,296 fans at Olympia.

Joseph H. Murphy, State Tax Commissioner, is looking over a seventy-page bill he hopes will be introduced for study in the New York State Legislature, perhaps within the next ten days. Its object is to provide taxpayers with a better means of resolving tax disputes with the state.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Keith Meyer, a former olympian from Glen Ellyn, Ill., and Bob McCarthy, a New York night school student, shared a tie today in the senior men's division of the national indoor speed-skating championships.

UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 19 -- Seven Congolese prisoners recently transferred from Leopoldville to South Kasai may have been killed, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was told today by his representative in the Congo.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 19 -- Smith College and the public schools here will set up a Smith-Northampton Summer School this year, Thomas C. Mendenhall, president of the college, said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Bills on nonresident income taxes and unemployment benefits are scheduled to be passed in one house or both when the Legislature meets this week.

John O'Hara, native Pennsylvanian and author of the best-selling trilogy, "Sermons and Soda-Water," was recently given the gold medal of honorary citizenship of the City of Philadelphia. The award was made by Mayor Richardson Dilworth at Mr. O'Hara's home in Princeton in the author's fifty-sixth birthday.

"LET'S be fair. The only people who are more dreadful than obscure people are celebrities, or near-celebrities. I have never known anybody whose name has appeared in Walter Winchell's column that I'd throw a life preserver to if he was drowning."

Emily Taft Douglas, wife of Senator Paul Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, suggested yesterday that although religious liberty might look easy now, people would do well to reconsider their heritage "in an age when a new dynamic ideology has challenged the very existence of nonmaterial values."
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 19 -- A visitor returning to Leopoldville after a four-month absence finds the European quarter of the city drastically changed.
Prices of stocks in the over-the-counter market generally advanced last week in heavy trading.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Paul Runyan overcame a two-stroke deficit by shooting a 69 for 278 today and won the twenty-second annual Professional Golfers Association senior championship.
"THE Great Challenge" met its own challenge quite nicely on the first of its four Channel 2 telecasts yesterday.

As the long winter evenings linger and it seems that spring is far away, this is the time to send for leaflets, pamphlets, books, maps and price lists for a vacation trip abroad. When you come in from shoveling the snow, this is the time to be warmed by the alluring adjectives of the travel folders.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- A new program to save children from unwittingly committing crimes and stigmatizing themselves for life has been started in Westchester County.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The American Bar Association, which for several years was deep in political controversy, is now concerning itself largely with professional affairs.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The State Department of Commerce reported today the number of persons registering for unemployment insurance benefits in New York rose to 462,000 in the third week of January.
BRAZIL, Ind., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Four persons were injured today, none seriously, in a fire and explosion in the dining car of the Pennsylvania Railroad's Spirit of St. Louis.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- The big man in the box seat looked over the field that was coming out for the fourth at Hialeah, made a notation or two on his program and then said to a companion, "Heck. I don't see anything here I like. I guess I'll skip this race."
GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- The Swiss stock markets perked up at mid-week after a slow start and closed the week on a firm note. The big commercial banks were again the star performers.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 -- Steel makers looked in vain last week for a change in the steel outlook. Most steel people believed that new business would expand in February, at least to the extent that March shipments would show a mild improvement from the February level.
ROCK HILLS, S.C., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Eight of eleven Negro students jailed at the York County prison camp after recent anti-segregation demonstrations are in solitary confinement.
Gladys Kuchta, American soprano, will make her Metropolitan Opera debut on Saturday evening, March 4, as Chrisothemis in Richard Strauss' "Elektra."

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- David Mills of Trinity College won the Apawamis Club invitation squash racquets tournament today by beating Richard Stewart of the Hartford Golf and Tennis Club. The scores were 15 -- 7, 15 -- 4, 17 -- 15.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Trading was slow on the stock market last week, but there were signs of renewed interest as the week ended.
One of the oldest companies n American-flag shipping has been reactivated, according to an announcement yesterday by Clifford D. Mallory Jr., president of the newly reorganized C.D. Mallory Co.
Anyone have a P-47 Thunderbolt plane? Any old one will do.
Michael Redgrave has been signed to star in Graham Greene's comedy," The Complaisant Lover," which scored a successful run in the West End last season.

In allocating the blame to Communists for the unfortunate rioting in the gallery of the United Nations General Assembly, your editorial of Feb. 16, in my judgment, ignores the fact that the majority of those participating in the riot have ample grounds for strong feelings about the Congo.

Alf Alfer, a Swedish tenor, made his New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night singing arias by Donizetti, Mozart, Verdi and Meyerbeer, a group of songs by Schubert, and four songs by Swedish composers. He was accompanied by Richard Woitach, pianist.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The new feed grain bill sent to Congress by President Kennedy this week reversed the trend of futures prices generally on the Board of Trade and most contracts posted their second consecutive weekly setbacks.
Those who question the virgin birth are entitled to a "respectful hearing even if "we cannot accept their findings," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals used a scoring streak by Win Wilfong and Oscar Robertson's over-all excellence in a fourth-quarter rally to beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 112 -- 106, today in a National Basketball Association game.
CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 19 -Dartmouth won St. Lawrence University's annual winter carnival ski meet, which ended today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Kennedy Administration has a powerful hand loaded with aces and face cards for the poker game it ultimately must play with Congress to get its program enacted.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Up to mid-1960 the countries and territories of Asia continued to reflect the rising trend in export earnings, which in 1959 had a marked recovery from the setbacks encountered in 1958.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A delegation of legislators and state officials will fly to Detroit this week to try to persuade the automobile industry to cooperate in a safety-belt campaign.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 -- The Fourth Congress of the Albanian Workers (Communist) party approved today the nation's five-year plan for economic development during the 1961-65 period, the Tirana radio announced.
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, called yesterday for a greater stress on teaching of ethics to youths, along with their technical education.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics shook off the Syracuse Nationals in the last eight minutes today and scored a 116-106 victory in a National Basketball Association game.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19 -- The New York Yankees will do a lot more sliding this year than they have in a long time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A former United States diplomat, in testimony made public today, said that Spruille Braden had been dismissed as assistant Secretary of State in the Truman Administration after being accused of helping Latin-American Communists.
TURIN, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Ken Phelps Jr. of Lyons Falls, N.Y., and Roxann Chamberlin of Mount Mansfield, Vt., won the New York State Alpine ski championships today.
The construction of two off-street truck depots as a pilot project to ease traffic congestion in the garment center has been recommended to the Department of Traffic.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Dave Hill rolled in a twisting, downhill 15-foot putt on the third play-off hole to defeat Tommy Bolt and Buddy Sullivan in the $20,000 Tucson open golf tournament today.
New and increased municipal taxes here are virtually inevitable over the next several years, the Citizens Budget Commission predicted yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Demonstrators protesting the slaying of Patrice Lumumba, former Congo Premier, clashed violently with the police outside the Belgian Embassy here tonight.
The Puerto Rican has adjusted to American city life faster than any previous newcomer, according to a report issued yesterday.
The title of the Haydn Concerto No. 5 for Two Liras does not indicate how much the composer was paid for the work but rather its instrumentation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The tempo of Congress, up to now the slowest on the Washington scene, is expected to quicken this week.

Ohio State's basketball team came closer to losing Saturday night than at any other time during the season. But thievery on two plays saved the Buckeyes' undefeated streak, running it to twenty games this season and twenty-five over two years.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 (AP) -- East German Communist officials have turned over an American soldier missing for the past eighteen months, the United States Army announced today.
Thirty mud-covered runners drew some incredulous stares in the Bronx yesterday as they splashed along in the annual Cherry Tree Marathon.
A blue-eyed, gray-haired woman of quick but gentle answer and sprightly step that belie her years kept company with memories yesterday morning.
MOMBASA, Kenya, Feb. 19 -- Plans to form a Mozambique African National Union to oust the Portuguese from East Africa were drafted at a conference here this week-end.
CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 19 -- The Navy's newest aircraft carrier, the 60,000-ton Kitty Hawk, was given a preliminary inspection today before beginning her sea trials Tuesday.

Adlai E. Stevenson. United States delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday the two "most dangerous realities" in the world were the increasing numbers of nuclear weapons and the enormous gap between wealth and poverty.

Last year, Air France used a campaign that contained the silent endorsement. Celebrities that were so well known that they needed no further identification were shown either on or near an Air France plane.

A sharp increase in Navy re-enlistments and a gradual but steady increase in Army re-enlistments have delighted the Pentagon. The Air Force, exception to the rule, has shown a slight drop in its first re-enlistment rate.
A new alliance for economic cooperation by the United States, Canada and eighteen European nations won support last week by a major business group.

HAVANA, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Ramon Castro Ruz, older brother of Premier Fidel Castro, said today in an interview he had come here from Oriente Province "to defend Cuba's 65,000 small sugar cane growers from economic destruction."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Five United States naval ships are operating in the vicinity of the Gulf of Guinea, ostensibly for goodwill visits to African ports but also for a possible emergency role in the Congo crisis.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 -- V.K. Krishna Menon warned today that the Congo could become another Korea if the United Nations forces withdrew. He defended Dag Hammarskjold, who has been bitterly attacked in the United Nations by the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- President Kennedy saved a seat for a little girl in church today.
The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay told his congregation yesterday that "as baptized members of the Episcopal Church we have accepted the Apostles and Nicene Creeds as fundamental parts of our faith."

Leopold Stokowski will conduct the Symphony of the Air for the third annual Concert for Children on the afternoon of April 15 at Carnegie Hall. The event is being sponsored and planned by the Parents League of New York, 22 East Sixtieth Street.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Mohamed Masmoudi was a difficult child. He cried because his family decided he should not go to school. But, foreshadowing his later, expert skill as a Tunisian diplomat and minister of state, he negotiated his way around the obstacles and found his way, by the time he was 21 years old, to the University of Paris, where he studied philosophy, literature and po litical science.
CIRCUMSTANCES surrounding the assassination of Abraham Lincoln were investigated in "The Lincoln Murder Case," the dramatization on "Show of the Month" over Channel 2 on Saturday night.
CABINDA, Cabinda, Feb. 20 -- Portugal is now developing a new class of administrators in Africa: young men who impress one as able, honest and humane.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- An African nationalist leader from Northern Rhodesia charged today that Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, was provoking Africans and "looking for trouble."
Plans have been announced for a series of Schrafft's Motels to be built along the eastern seaboard and as far west as the Mississippi River.
Interviewed on his return from a recent London trip, Kermit Bloomgarden says he has the inside track on the future Broadway importation of "King Kong."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld an order stripping Frank Costello of United States citizenship.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A contention that state and cities may not constitutionally provide buses for parochial school children was summarily dismissed by the Supreme Court today.

THE Scandia Craft Import showroom, newly located at 166 Lexington Avenue, was recently opened with the flying colors of Scandinavian flags. Formerly at 126 Lexington Avenue, this company now has an entire building -- four spacious floors on which to display its contemporary furnishings.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Governor Rockefeller gave a moderate endorsement today to President Kennedy's farm bill to cut feed grain plantings by 20 per cent. But he warned against continuing the program after the need for it had vanished.

While the aggregate short interest for New York Stock Exchange issues declined by 65,817 shares in the month to last Wednesday to 3,822,699 shares, the number of issues in which there was a short position climbed to 1,021 from 965 in mid-January.
Sales of the nation's leading retail chains in January just managed to exceed the volume of the 1960 month. A survey made yesterday by The New York Times put the advance at one-tenth of 1 per cent.
Prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points up to 5 points off yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Following is a state-by-state breakdown of the number of scholarships and amount of money allocated to the states under the terms of the Administration proposals sent to Congress today. The figures are based on the assumption that the amount for each scholarship will average $700.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Reorganization of the Agricultural Ministry and new incentive payments for workers on state farms to spur flagging production were announced tonight by the Soviet Government.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 20 -- Five Tamil members of Parliament and forty members of the Tamil Federal party were injured today at Jaffna in northern Ceylon when policemen used clubs and tear gas to break up a demonstration against the Government's language policy.

MELBOURNE Australia, Feb. 20 -- Lord Casey, who was Australia's Minister of External Affairs from 1951 until early last year, expressed hope today that the Kennedy Administration was ready to take a new look at the Communist China problem.
Four members of the New York Police Department, two former members and two civilians were indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury on extortion and bribery charges.
The Bell System reaffirmed yesterday its claim as the world's biggest profit maker and largest corporation by most accepted measurements.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Julian Amery, Secretary of State for Air, said today that he thought Britain was safe from premeditated attack.

Jackie Donnelly, a Buffalo lightweight who has lost only once, scored his twenty-third victory last night with a majority decision over Angelo (Chico) Velez of the East Side in the ten-round feature at St. Nicholas Arena.
It was a rather unusual luncheon. A 16-year-old with wide gray eyes and an easy smile passed the coffee and sandwiches. A strapping youth with a plate of mints and nuts in each hand toured the room.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- William J. Clothier 2d defeated E. Newbold Smith, a former all-America Navy football tackle, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in the only match played today in the United States court tennis championship at the Racquet Club.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb, 20 -- Twelve-year-old Bruce Elliot, who learned about artificial respiration at a Boy Scout meeting a week ago, used that knowledge today to save a 2-year-old neighbor.

The first of a series of volumes on world history will be published in April by Doubleday under the general title of "The Mainstream of the Modern World." Scheduled for April 14 is "The Age of Reason," by Sir Harold Nicolson. It is an account of the personalities, philosophies, political upheavals, literature and art of the eighteenth century.

A new neighborhood clean-up group on the lower East Side discovered yesterday that it could get results. Its organizer was reprimanded by the police for one of the very violations the group had set out to correct last month.
Steel production last week spurted to its highest level in eight months. The nation's steel mills produced 1,582,000 tons of raw steel compared with 1,524,000 a week earlier,
Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines called on the United States yesterday to harden its commitment to a democratic direction of development for Asia and Africa.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 20 -- The pioneering days are over industrially as well as historically in this, one of the last outposts of the Old West. ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 20 -- They are still spinning tales in these parts of the incomparable Dazzy Vance as they doubtless will for years to come. The Dazzler, who helped bring fame to Brooklyn as much as Brooklyn brought fame to him, died last week. He was a most extraordinary man.

Paperboard production in the holiday-week ended last Saturday totaled 298,124 tons, compared with 301,286 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 329,793 tons.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- President de Gaulle invited Central and South America tonight to form a "united and renovated Latin world" with France and other Latin countries.
Two reports yesterday on economic developments in Israel indicated strong optimism on continuing progress both by the Mideast nation and the free-world community.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Counsel for E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. urged the Supreme Court today to be guided by "practicality and mercy" in deciding the terms of an antitrust degree against the company.
THE troubled continent of Africa was examined last night by the news department of the National Broadcasting Company in a special program over Channel 4.

In the recent past your columns have repeatedly drawn comparisons between the efficiency of snow removal, mail delivery and other mechanics of life (not to mention rockets) in Europe, especially Russia, of course, and the United States.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 21 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, former neutralist Premier of Laos, left here today in a Soviet plane to visit Xiengkhouang Province, now held by Capt. Kong Le, a rebel leader.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- Thomas E. Millsop, president of the National Steel Corporation, was elected chairman today by the board of directors in a realignment of top officers.

Andy Bathgate, star forward of the New York Rangers, will be out to beat Glenn Hall this afternoon when the Blues meet the big Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. The National Hockey League no televised game will begin at o'clock.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Fears of violence in Northern Rhodesia were intensified here today following bitter criticism of the British Government's proposals for reform of the protectorate's Constitution.

Independent nominees will contest some of the offices in the forthcoming election to be held by Actors Equity Association. Petitions for the independents were submitted Feb. 17, the last day they could be filed, to Angus Duncan, the union's executive secretary.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- A Tunisian emissary said today that the forthcoming meeting between President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia and President de Gaulle offered "the best prospects."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Congressional leaders today promised President Kennedy "full steam ahead" on sixteen legislative measures placed on a priority action list by the White House.
The harbor pilot of a freighter and the master of a cargo ship were unable to agree at a hearing yesterday on exactly where the two ships collided last Friday.

The two-story building at 337-39 Central Average, corner of Lincoln Street, Jersey City, has been bought by Ira Kavanau, New York realty investor. The property, which is about 100 by 100 feet, was purchased from the Sally Ren Corporation in a deal negotiated by the A.F. Roe Company of Jersey City and Frank Hughes of Montclair.

THERE is no official point score in the Olympic Games. But at Rome last summer, as at every previous Olympic assemblage in memory, contrived tallies based on places won -- from first to sixth -- and medals captured -- gold, silver and bronze -- were flashed around the world.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A House Elections subcommittee ordered today a recount of the votes cast in Indiana's Fifth Congressional district, which is without a Representative.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Anatoli Kuznetsov, a Soviet author, has at least part of his suit won against a Lyons publishing house over the translation in French of his novel, "Sequel to a Legend."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Jimmy Bostwick of Old Westbury, L.I., rallied to beat F. Hastings Griffin Jr. of this city, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, in the United States amateur court tennis championship today at the Racquet Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- For the last month Washington has been watching a serial version of "Jack and the Beanstalk" and no one is sure today whether it will be Jack or the giant who will impose his will on the other.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Assemblyman Bentley Kassal, a Manhattan Democrat, has filed a bill to interest the Legislature in promoting an annual international film festival in New York City.
"I MET Mrs. Niarchos when I was in Greece. Mrs. Niarchos sent Mrs. Goulandris, Mrs. Goulandris sent Mrs. Onassis."
Three subjects -- one a carryover from the Eisenhower Administration -- will be studied and emphasized in the Pentagon in the months ahead.
TRENTON, Feb. 21 -- Charles R. Erdman, Repblican state chairman, disclosed tonight that an attempt by top party leaders to unite behind a single candidate for Governor had failed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Guatemala has called on the United States and the Latin-American republics to open formal talks on Communist infiltration of South and Central America through Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic Bishop expressed "keen disappointment" today that President Kennedy had excluded private and parochial schools from his multibillion-dollar program to improve education.

For the second time in five months the United Nations has administered a smashing defeat to Premier Khrushchev in his campaign to rule this world organization or destroy it as an agency for the suppression of aggression and an obstacle to further Communist conquests.

A MARINE fighter ace in World War II and the Korean war . . . . First to fly coast to coast at supersonic speed, in 1957 .... Oldest of the seven selected for the Mercury Astronaut program two years ago, he often acts as group's spokesman. . . .

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Liberia formally asked the Security Council today to take up the situation in Angola, the Portuguese territory on the West African coast where clashed occurred recently between whites and Africans.

In everything except the final statistical record, yesterday gave the impression of strength on the New York Stock Exchange. More stocks rose than fell and they did so for the sixth successive day. Aggregate market value rose a little and Standard Poor's industrial, utility and composite indexes all were up a bit.
Tammany Hall fired the opening shot yesterday in a campaign to crush Democratic district leaders who seek to unseat Carmine G. De Sapio a county chairman.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of the Montreal Canadiens, National Hockey League, has regained the scoring lead from Frank Mahovlich of the Toronto Maple Leafs. Geoffrion scored 10 points last week.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 21 -- The merged labor federation set in motion today a program to speed the investment of more than $1,000,000,000 of union funds in Government-guaranteed mortgages.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 21 (UPI) -- The 1956 automobile of the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy was sold at auction today to help pay off his portion of a $500,000 libel judgment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- The American Bar Association's House of Delegates authorized today the creation of a special eleven-man committee to aid refugee Cuban lawyers and judges in the United States. There are said to be about 300, mostly in Miami, Fla.
MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- A sprint that has been won in past years by an imposing list of horses will be offered at Hialeah tomorrow.

He had reached the age of 56 and had no "wish beyond that of living and dying an honest man on my own farm," but the young nation called him to be its first President. George Washington could no more reject this summons to duty than those answered earlier with such courage, self-sacrifice and talent for leading men in war and peace.

The "inside" political history of Virginia's fight against public school integration is related by Benjamin Muse, onetime Republican nominee for Governor of Virginia, and now director of the Southern Leadership Project of the Southern Regional Council, an organization seeking to end racial discrimination.

Percy Grainger was a direct link to the past -- a link with Grieg and other great musicians. The eminent Australian-born pianist and composer, who is dead at the age of 78, was a refreshing human being who always lived his life as he wanted to. He was an eccentric in the great British tradition. Only Grainger would have trudged from concert to concert, a knapsack on his back.

This is the season for bringing in the vote -- the corporate vote -- which is to have its frantic moments. That is because such a large number of shares are owned by stockholders in "street name" (held by their brokers).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Diplomats here said today that a peace settlement in Laos along lines advanced by King Savang Vathana could result in the withdrawal of all Western military advisers and forces from tile kingdom.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 21 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies yielded today to a storm of criticism over the Government's harsh anti- inflationary measures. He withdrew the recently imposed 10 per cent increase in the automobile sales tax.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The chief executives of four states and of New York City and Westchester County agreed today to support a $54,800,000 emergency program for the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller's bill to extend maximum unemployment benefits in the state temporarily from twenty-six to thirty-nine weeks cleared its first legislative hurdle today.
SYLVESTER COMSTOCK SMITH Jr. learned early from his father that if he wanted to be a good lawyer in a mechanical age he had better study civil engineering. So he studied engineering.

Congratulations to your newspaper and to Nan Robertson for bringing to public attention one of the most crucial problems facing our city -- discrimination in housing. Her article on Feb. 19, concerning the difficulties faced by envoys to the United Nations from African countries, graphically demonstrates how damaging prejudice is to our relationships with nations throughout the world and to our fight for freedom against communism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House Agriculture Committee displayed an unaccustomed unity today that improved the outlook for an emergency feed grams program outlined by Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Kennedy intervened last week to block a $200,000 renovation and expansion of a United States officers club in France.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 21 -- Moroccan Jews were urged today by the Minister of the Interior to remain in their native land and work side by side with Moslems to build a solid and prosperous state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman took an economically significant step today by setting the cotton price-support level for 1961 at 82 per cent of parity.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 21 -- Burmese soldiers used gunfire today to break up the biggest anti-United States demonstration ever seen in this neutral nation.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- For the fifth successive year Japan led the world in 1960 in the number of ships launched.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 21 -- An official of the American Jewish Congress charged today that school boards in the North were perpetuating "de facto" segregation.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is considering televising "Person to Person" and selections from "Playhouse 90" as summer refreshers.

Interest rates on short-term debt instruments sold in the open market were marked up yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve's abandonment of its "bills usually" policy and of the announcement by the First National City Bank of New York that it intended to pay interest on time deposits to its biggest corporate customers.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 -- The Soviet Union will build a second state-owned oil refinery for India under an agreement signed today.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks maintained their home-court jinx over Cincinnati despite 36 points by Oscar Robertson tonight and defeated tile Royals, 126 -- 114.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Camden residents voted today to replace the present City Commission form of government with a Mayor-Council type, breaking the Democrats' thirty-eight-year control of the city.
Both the top command and the rank-and-file of the Fire Department served notice on Mayor Wagner yesterday that they would fight any differential in police salaries over those of firemen.

THE words were French, but the essential language was the international one of ancient farce and a broad playing style. With "Les Fourberies de Scapin" as the principal work on its opening program, the Comedie Francaise had little need of exegetes at the City Center last night.
Your editorial on the "scholar-incentive" program in The Times of Feb. 16 presents one of the most satisfactory definitions I have seen of a true scholarship program.
Golfing officials are slightly confused as a result of the rules "experiments" being conducted by tournament professionals.

"The Mark," a psychological drama with Maria Schell, Rod Steiger and Stuart Whitman, has been chosen as the official British entry in the Cannes (France) Film Festival, opening May 4. Raymond Stross and Sidney Buchman produced and Guy Green directed the Continental Distributing release.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 -- David Ben-Gurion said today that he would not continue beyond next week to attempt to form a new Government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A successful test of a three-dimensional radar unit was reported today by an official of the Federal Aviation Agency.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Legislature voted today to turn an official spotlight on the contract for engineering services awarded by the state Thruway Authority to Bertram D. Tallamy, a former chairman of the authority.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A general and fairly broad late rally lifted the grain futures market out of weakness today on the Chicago Board of Trade and sent most contracts well ahead of yesterday's closing prices.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Patsy V., a 3-year-old filly, won the feature at Bowie Race Course today by a nose.
Compulsory retirement at age 65 is the nation's most wasteful policy, Dr. Howard A. Rusk said yesterday.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 21 -- Denmark bade an affectionate farewell today to Val Peterson, popular Ambassador from the United States.

Events today: "Simon Boccanegra," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Orchestra of America, Richard Korn, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Hyman Bress, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Berl Senofsky, violinist, Judson Hall, 8:30.

While adult New Yorkers sip champagne and dance to a professional orchestra in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, a group of teen-agers in Freeville, N.Y., will dance to phonograph records and refresh themselves with soft drinks and hot dogs.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller defended his college student aid program today on the ground that New York's middlebrow population deserved as much encouragement as its highbrows.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Yale University, which has been the subject of political jokes since early November, struck back tonight.
Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley announced a crackdown yesterday on builders who clutter Manhattan streets with materials and equipment.

William D. Fugazy, the president of Feature Sports, Inc., said yesterday that ticket sales for the third heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson had reached the $300,000 level.

A total of 689 persons were injured ill 510 automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bm'ean reported yesterday. This was a decrease of 187 compared with 1960, when 876 persons were injured in the same period.
The United States mail went through yesterday despite the airline strike.

STREATHAM, England, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Dave Charnley of England retained his European lightweight championship tonight by outpointing the French champion, Ferdinand Nollet, in a fifteen-round bout. Charnley weighed 134 1/4 pounds and Nollet 135.
Directors of the Pet Milk Company yesterday voted a dividend of 25 cents a common share. It is payable on April 1 to holders of record of March 10. The company has been paying 20 cents a quarter.

Previous price reductions should be taken into consideration in determining whether recent increases in heating oil prices along the East Coast were justified, according to the Esso Standard division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Paul-Henri Spaak, retiring Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today after a one-hour conference with President Kennedy that he was "very happy about the President's views on NATO."

TRENTON, Feb. 21 -- President-elect Abraham Lincoln, sad-faced and deep in thought, came here today to address the State Senate and Assembly in joint session. He was en route to Washington for his March 4 inauguration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A dispute over the importation of Japanese baseball gloves went before the Federal Tariff Commission today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Congress reacted to President Kennedy's education bill yesterday as if he had suggested an intelligence test for all Congressmen.

THE current New York art menu, already lengthy and rich, is increased this week by two major entrees and a masterpiece of a dessert. Today the Whitney Museum of American Art opens its Maurice Prendergast Memorial Exhibition.

GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- Improved demand, combined with a cutback in production, reduced by 9,000,000 metric tons last year the unsold stocks at Western Europe's coal mines, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today. A metric ton equals 2,204 pounds.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 21 -- Ambassador William A.M. Burden and Foreign Minister Pierre Wigny signed today a treaty of "friendship, establishment and navigation" between the United States and Belgium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The Administration has asked Congress for authority to deny the Dominican Republic any share of the sugar quota formerly assigned to Cuba.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 21 -- The execution of political prisoners has touched off tribal fighting on a large scale in Kasai Province, according to reliable reports reaching Leopoldville today.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Assembly passed and sent to Governor Rockefeller today a measure giving Mayor Wagner greater freedom in appointing members of the Board of Education. The Senate had passed the measure earlier
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that its scientists appeared to be coming closer to the long-sought goal of igniting a controlled thermonuclear reaction.
The Transit Authority opened an investigation yesterday into Monday night's derailment of an East Side IRT subway express train in the Bronx.

"I CAME into this world on the sixteenth day of the Water-Dog year." So writes Thubten Jigme Norbu, Tibetan monk and eldest brother of His Holiness the Dali Lama, in "Tibet Is My Country,"* which is said to be the first authentic autobiography of a Tibetan ever to be published in the outside world.

TOKYO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The police arrested Bin Akao, an extreme nationalist leader, today on suspicion of incitement to murder. His party has been linked to the slaying of the Socialist party chairman, Inejiro Asanuma, and the stabbing of a Leftist magazine publisher's wife.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- The Soviet Government appointed Pavel S. Kuchumov today to Head its newly created organization for the maintenance and supplying of agricultural machines, fertilizers and technical equipment for the nation's farms.
BAL HARBOR, Fla., Feb. 21 -- American labor deplored today a report by the International Labor Organization asserting that unions had "considerable power and influence" in the Soviet Union.

A site near Oswego, N.Y., has been chosen as the location of a $30,000,000 aluminum hot rolling mill, it was announced yesterday. The plant will be built and owned jointly by Aluminum, Ltd., Bridgeport Brass Company, Cerro Corporation and Scovill Manufacturing Company.
Sales of the B.F. Goodrich Company in 1960 were second only to the record level of 1959, but earnings were down sharply, it was reported yesterday.

HONG KONG, Feb. 21 -- Prince Souphanouvong, leader of pro-Communist elements in Laos, denounced today King Savang Vathana's proposal that a three-nation Asian commission investigate the country's aspirations to neutrality.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Kennedy personally opened today his campaign for American physical fitness, but his brother stole the show.
SUMTER, S.C., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Dozens of Negro student, singing hymns, were jailed today for protesting segregation in a drug store, soda shop and library in this community.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 21 -- The Freedoms Foundation announced tonight the winners in its twelfth annual awards program for outstanding contributions in 1960 to a better understanding of the American way of life.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 21 -- This stubborn, independent-minded country is as concerned as any of our allies with the outcome of today's conversation between President Kennedy and NATO's retiring Secretary General Spaak. For, from their talk will emerge the first clue as to whether our new Administration intends to back the nuclear-sharing program first propounded by General Norstad and tentatively supported by the lame-duck Eisenhower regime.
The last of the potbellied stoves that warmed the waiting rooms of elevated railroads in the city for almost a century were dismantled yesterday for scrap.

The big city equivalent of Kentucky colonels has always been the "honorary" commissioner or deputy. Bestowal of the title was sometimes recognition of citizen devotion to departmental interests. At other times it was political reward. The recipients, with the pride natural to such appointment, wanted other people to know that they were honorary commissioners, so they sometimes advertised it by putting plaques or shields on their automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board, as part of a series of precedent-setting applications of the 1959 Landrum-Griffin Act, ordered two union locals today to end their four-year picketing of the Stork Club in New York City.

BORN April 3, 1926 in Mitchell, Ind. . . . Entered Air Force cadet flying program in 1944 at the age of 18 but the war ended before he completed program . . . . Took a degree in mechanical engineering at Purdue University in 1950, then decided to re-enter the Air Force. . .
NEWARK, Feb. 21 -- The 1961-62 West Essex County regional high school budget of $944,490 was defeated today for a second time in all four member districts.
A small group of prominent New Yorkers has offered $4,000,000 in cash to purchase television station WNTA-TV and convert it to noncommercial and educational programing.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 21 -- President Nkrumah said today that he hoped the contract for the Volta River Project, designed to industrialize Ghana, would be awarded next April. He outlined to Parliament the present stage of negotiations.
James J. Ling, president of Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., which is seeking to take over the Chance Vought Corporation, owned 155,700 shares of Chance Vought stock on Feb. 16.

The first head of government to hold a conference with President Kennedy was Prime Minister Diefenbaker. The first trip the President makes outside of the United States will be to Ottawa. One of our topflight career officers, Livingston Merchant, has been named and confirmed as Ambassador to Ottawa. The last governmental leader President Eisenhower saw also happened to be Mr. Diefenbaker.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Temple University's basketball team defeated Manhattan College, 69 -- 59, tonight.
The amateur Savoyards of the Blue Hill Troupe will present "The Mikado" from April 4 through April 8 at the Hunter College Playhouse. There will be a special children's matinee on the last day.
The net Puerto Rican migration to the mainland was reported yesterday to have fallen to a post-war low of 16,298 persons last year. This was 45.7 per cent below the 1959 level.
TUNIS, Feb. 21 -- The principle of an immediate and direct contact between the French and the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government has been accepted by both sides.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Air France indicated this evening that European air-freight carriers would seek Government protection against any low United States rates on the North Atlantic route.
The United States Plywood Corporation introduced yesterday a new plastic-coated plywood wall panel that, it said, had greater stain and wear resistance than comparable products.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Two witnesses refused today to tell Senate investigators whether a $3,000 check had been used to pay off a Federal income tax employe.
Michael -- H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, said last night he had not tried to bind Democratic members of the State Legislature to vote for Governor Rockefeller's education aid bill.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Jimmy Paul of Delray Beach, Fla., and Larry Beck of Kingston, N.C., today took the first-day lead in qualifying for the national tournament of golf club champions.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 21 -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro decreed a state of siege today.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 21 -- United States Ambassador Charles W. Yost gave a personal message to King Mohammed V today from President Kennedy.

Tickets are still available for the special performance of Bellini's "Beatrice di Tenda" at Carnegie Hall on March 1. The American Opera Society is presenting Joan Sutherland in the opera, which will be a benefit for the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Kennedy's selection of Assistant Secretary of State J. Graham Parsons to be Ambassador to Sweden topped a number of foreign service developments today.

SPRINGFIELD, Vt., Feb. 21 -- Yankee ingenuity is helping the producers of machine tools in this area keep their plants busy and their employes working in the face of lagging orders for their products.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Plans for a memorial fund for members of the United States figure-skating team and coaches who perished in a Belgian airline crash were announced today.

A mother who defied a white boycott of integrated schools in New Orleans by taking her 6-year-old daughter to classes was honored as Woman of the Year yesterday by the Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn.

"A FAMILY visiting New York to see the sights can do so less expensively than in any city in the world." According to Royal W. Ryan, executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, a family of four can spend a three-day week-end in New York quite reasonably.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Diplomatic sources said today that the United States had been putting pressure on Belgium to try to get Moise Tshombe, leader of secessionist Katanga Province, to accept a federated Congo.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 21 -- On the roster of the Yankees is a young pitcher with the proven ability to puzzle not only batters but also doctors, trainers, coaches and managers.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Three candidates were selected today for a one-man flight into space expected within two or three months. The three were chosen from seven trained astronauts.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A pair of satellites launched from Cape Canaveral on a single booster rocket are in orbit, the Defense Department announced early today.

Reports on the traffic crisis caused by the snows of our "good old-fashioned winter" contained frequent references to abandoned cars. It was not always clear whether this meant only cars halted and deserted in transit, or whether parked cars snowed in by the latest blizzard were included.
More than 60 per cent of the single-room tenants in the Morningside Heights area are forced to pay illegally high rents, accra'ding to an unpublished section of a State Rent Commission report.

BONN, Germany, Feb, 21 -- Chancellor Adenauer will fly to London tomorrow with a compromise plan that the West Germans hope will resolve the crisis facing the six-nation European Economic Community, better known as the Common Market.
Cocoa futures prices on the New York Cocoa Exchange rallied yesterday and finished with gains. The rise followed a sharp opening sell-off ill the most active session in seven months.

Columbus High scored 6 straight points in the last quarter and went on to defeat Port Richmond, 55 -- 50, yesterday in the final game of a Public Schools Athletic League triple-header at Madison Square Garden.
The first Fellows Award made in the United States by the Royal Society of Arts was presented yesterday to Prof. Simon Lissim of City College.
President Kennedy named a three-man commission yesterday to try to end the wildcat strike of flight engineers against six major airlines.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was unchanged to 12 points off yesterday, except the new July, which closed 15 points up, on a bid price. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

THE harpsichord, baroque flute and recorder figure prominently in a children's concert to be presented Saturday at 3 P.M. at the New York College of Music, 114 East Eighty-fifth Street. Admission is 50 cents.

Market yields on Treasury bonds due from 1985 to 1998 -- the anchorage of the long-term interest structure -- fell below 3.8 per cent yesterday for the first time in more than two years following the Federal Reserve System's acquiescense to President Kennedy's request that the central bank other than short-term Treasury securities.
Gen. Lucius D. Clay (U.S.A, rtd.) called upon business men yesterday to help stimulate economic recovery by regarding the future with confidence rather than fear.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP) -- H.B. Keck's Nascania, apparently beaten in the last furlong, finished fast and set a turf-course record for about six and a half furlongs in winning the feature at Santa Anita today.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy is permitting patrolmen to use new nightsticks, or batons, two to four inches longer than the older sticks.
The New York Knickerbockers and the Philadelphia Warriors adhered to their season-long script of staging close, exciting games when they battled last night at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Industrial shares continued in demand in the stock market today. Favorable news from the automobile industry and more good company results brought rising prices during the morning in a market still short of stock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A proposal that Congress create a joint committee to study fuels was criticized at a House hearing today as a possible forerunner to Government control.

At the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago, stockhollers of Minneapolis-Moline Company, I farm equipment maker, were told that the company had a loss in the fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 hilt that rising profits iwere expected for the rest of l the fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- World steel production set a record in 1960, as all major producing countries except the United States lifted output to new peaks, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Wintering populations of canvasback and redhead ducks, as well as certain other species of ducks and geese, showed improvement over low levels of last year in the annual midwinter survey of the Atlantic Flyway.

ROME, Feb. 21 (AP) -- An art expert said tonight he had obtained a confession from a man who had helped to make three statues of Etruscan warriors that were displayed for forty years as ancient treasures in New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art.
BUFFALO, N.D., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A Northern Pacific Railroad was derailed near here late today, injuring about forty persons, none seriously.
DETROIT, Feb. 21 -- A prominent stockholder in the Chrysler Corporation announced today that he would lead a drive to limit the number of management members on the company's board.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 21 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, flung down the gauntlet tonight to the British Government.

YONKERS, Feb. 21 -- James R. Hoffa warned an audience of business men here tonight that the Federal ban on secondary boycotts would force unions to join forces, so that "if one strikes, all will strike."

Melville Industrial Associates has purchased 108 acres of land fronting on the Long Island Expressway at a point where the expressway will intersect Route 110 in Huntington, L.I. The tract will be developed as a self-contained industrial community.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Harold F. Haberling, a stock car driver from Phoenix, Ariz., was killed today when his speeding vehicle rolled over several times during a practice run at Daytona International Speedway.

Alice Sabin, a California soprano who has been studying in New York in recent years, made her debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program opened with a mixture of arias and songs by Gluck, Alessandro Scarlatti, Mozart, Armin Knab and Wagner, who was represented by tile rarely heard "Dors, mon enfant."
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 21 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province denounced United Nations plans for the Congo today and ordered general mobilization in his secessionist state.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- The University of Michigan's Symphony Band delighted Muscovites tonight with its youth, smiles and good music.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi opened the twentieth Iranian Majlis (Parliament) today with a call for a new law to insure honest elections.

The Ohio State Buckeyes are within three victories of a perfect regular season while maintaining a firm grip on the top of The Associated Press basketball poll according to the ratings released yesterday.

Sales and revenues of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation were at new highs in 1960, according to a preliminary report released yesterday. Donald C. Power, chairman and chief executive officer, also noted that net assets at $2,200,000,000 at the end of 1960 were at a new high and compared with $1,820,000,000 at the end of 1959.

BRISBANE, Australia, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Dawn Fraser came within eight-tenths of a second of her world 100-meter freestyle record in an attempt to break it at the Malley 50-meter fresh water pool tonight.

The boards of directors of the Midland-Ross Corporation and the Industrial Rayon Corporation have approved "in principle" a merger of the two companies through an ex change of stock. A joint announcement yesterday by Wade N. Harris, president of Midland-Ross, and Frederick L. Bissinger, president of Industrial Rayon, said that stockholders of each company would vote on them merger plan at special meetings late in April.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $34,535,000 at short term yesterday to finance the development of two city-sponsored projects subsidized by tax forgiveness, Luna Park Houses in Brooklyn, and Van Buren Houses in the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Northrup Knox of Buffalo gained the semi-final round of the United States amateur court tennis championship today. He beat Crawford Blagden Jr. of New York, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, at the Racquet Club.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- French spokesmen said today the closer ties between France and Latin America that were advocated last night by President de Gaulle would serve to strengthen Washington's efforts to keep communism in check in the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A principal argument for the necessity of larger and broader subsidy of public education by the Federal Government is that the states cannot be relied on to meet its current deficiencies. Both those who make and reject this argument can cite supporting statistics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Earl E.T. Smith asked President Kennedy tonight to withdraw his name from consideration as Ambassador to Switzerland because of controversy stemming from his previous post in Cuba.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev has voiced apprehension over any prospect of a Russia with insufficient borsch.
Dr. Paul Dudley White of Boston, the world-famous cardiologist, yesterday urged research into the conditions of childhood to find the cause of heart attacks in middle and old age.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Deartment of Agriculture follows:
Picketing by two union locals continued yesterday at the Stork Club despite a ruling by the National Labor Relations Board that forbade it.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 -- Israel presented an indictment against Adolf Eichmann today, accusing the former Nazi of personal responsibility for the murder of European Jews during World War II.

KAISERSLAUTERN, Germany, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -- A United States Army photographic unit here is hard at work turning out 10,000 copies of a photograph of President Kennedy to replace those of President Eisenhower in Army buildings throughout Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Kennedy has sent a personal message to Premier Khrushchev expressing hope for an improvement in United States-Soviet relations.
Eric Bentley, the drama critic, said yesterday that the dramatic schools of American universities were graduating unprofessional and incompetent students.
The first collective bargaining organization of doctors in the United States has been formed by physicians and dentists in the New York City Department of Health.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Is Ralph Houk, the new field commander of the Yankees, revolutionizing spring training? It could be, though in itself the urge to try something different is not exactly new in baseball. More than once in the past, managers have come along with the conviction that the conventional training camp routine can be improved.

Outstanding performances by Ed Duchini of Power Memorial and Bill Boyle of Chaminade highlighted the sectional track championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

Howard C. Sheperd, board chairman of the Greater New York Fund and retired chairman of the First National City Bank, is heading the group of citizens that hopes to purchase television station WNTA-TV and use it for noncommercial educational broadcasts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Thomas C. Sorensen, 34-year-old brother of Theodore C. Sorensen, special counsel to President Kennedy, will become a deputy director of the United States Information Agency.
Stephen P. Kennedy quit as Police Commissioner early today with an angry attack against Mayor Wagner.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Renewed heavy demand for British Government securities developed in the stock market here today and prices responded with gains ranging to 7s 6d ($1.05).
