ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI) -- Geechee Lou, the 3-1 second choice, raced to victory by a length and a half today in the $45,500 Washington's Birthday Handicap on the grass course at Santa Anita Park.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The Rutgers basketball team defeated Fordham tonight, 69 -- 62, and clinched its first winning season since 1948-49. It was the eleventh triumph for the Scarlet in eighteen games.
ATLANTA, Feb. 22 -- The Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the Highlander Folk School have joined forces to train Negro leaders for the civil rights struggle.

Art Heyman of Duke University, a top candidate for sophomore-of-the-year honors, will display his talents when the Blue Devils meet Seton Hall in the third game of a college basketball triple-header in Madison Square Garden tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Zenith Radio Corporation today threw its hat into the color-television ring.

Twice before, Charles Boyer scored handsomely under Paul Gregory's banner in "Don Juan in Hell" and "The Marriage-Go-Round." With that in mind, the star is joining Mr. Gregory again in "Lord Pengo." In S.N. Behrman's comedy, Mr. Boyer will depict the late Joseph Duveen, the fabulous art dealer, who became Lord Duveen.
THE Greater New York Championships, an annual tournament conducted over the Washington's Birthday week-end by the Greater New York Association, began yesterday with a two-session pair contest.

Representative James Roosevelt of California said here yesterday that the House Un-American Activities Committee was itself undermining national security by raising barriers of fear against free debate.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 22 -- Sweeping concessions designed to attract foreign capital that Ghana needs for her Volta River hydroelectric and aluminum smelter project were announced by the Government last night.

In a recent editorial, "Communists Begin to Pay," it was mentioned that Yugoslavia, in the year 1948, was the first Communist country which showed goodwill and the intention to pay claims of American citizens.
Bargain prices on many items and balmy weather lured thousands of shoppers out of their homes and into stores in the Metropolitan area yesterday.
RAS AL-KHAIMA, Trucial Oman States, Feb. 15 -- Five years ago the peasants in this far corner of the Arab world did not know their own word for "cabbage." They had never seen one.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 22 -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover received today the eighth annual Patriotism Award of the senior class of the University of Notre Dame.
TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Japan's highest foreign policy advisory body has come out against the favorite Leftist argument that Japan should recognize Communist China for the sake of trade.
"TAKE A GIRL LIKE YOU,"* by the noted British humorist Kingsley Amis, is a morality play in the form of a novel, a lampoon on manners and morals in contemporary England.

The appointment of a "truly disinterested" group of individuals to make a thorough evaluation of the city's labor relations and personnel policies and procedures was urged on Mayor Wagner yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
Mrs. Shirley Hayes, one of the leaders in the fight to close Washington Square to traffic, aid yesterday that city officials were "reneging on their promise" to make the traffic ban permanent.

A new program announced by King Savang Vathana calling for an end to foreign intervention in Laos and reconciliation between the kingdom's warring factions does not offer very promising prospects of keeping Laos out of Communist control.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 22 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright said here today that it was difficult to comprehend "the unprecedented rise in the strength of the Communist world in relation to our own."
The New York Times announced yesterday that it was undertaking a study of the possibility of establishing a West Coast edition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Five of the six major airlines, grounded by a wildcat walkout of flight engineers, issued a go-back-to-work-or-else ultimatum to the 3,500 strikers tonight. They set noon tomorrow as the deadline.

During the summer of 1942 the Allies mounted "Operation Pedestal," a convoy of much-needed supplies to Malta to prevent the capitulation of the island to the Axis. The convoy consisted of two battleships, four aircraft carriers, twelve cruisers and forty destroyers.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Legislature completed action today in the Rockefeller administration's program to grant tax relief to nonresidents who earn a living in the state. They will be allowed to make the deductions as residents on their income tax returns.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The University of Chicago learned that forty valuable documents and manuscripts were missing from its rare book section only after they were turned over to the San Francisco police.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 22 -- A move to break down the traditional aloofness between the liberal and conservative schools of Protestant theology was started today by one of the country's leading churchmen.
A program to raise the educational, vocational and cultural goals of children in the city's schools has made "substantial progress" in its first year, the Board of Education said yesterday.
Tickets for the Heart Fund benefit, telecast of the March 13 heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson go on sale today at Madison Square Garden and other locations.

Slight gains in demand for two major grades of paper were predicted at industry meetings here yesterday. The forecasts were in line with industry expectations that aggregate production of paper and paperboard this year would be about 2 per cent higher than last year's record of 34,300,000 tons.
Charges of unfair labor practices by the General Electric Company during a nation-wide strike last October have been lodged by the New York office of the National Labor Relations Board.

The Federal Reserve System has taken a step toward compromising, temporarily at least, on a policy that has ranked for nearly a decade among its most basic and most highly controversial. This is its policy loosely referred to as "bills only." Adopted on recommendations made by an ad hoc subcommittee of the board in 1953, it has virtually committed the System to the practice of confining its open market operations to short-term securities, preferably bills.
Julie Harris is having an active year in television. On March 21 (9:30 to 11 P.M.) she will star on the "Du Pont Show of the Month," her third TV drama role this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Kennedy was implicated today in an attempt to lure away the chef of France's Ambassador to London.
Long-range changes in the city's school system that would dramatically alter the present pattern of elementary, junior and senior high schools are being studied.

RICHARD KORN and the Orchestra of America last night presented at Carnegie Hall one of their most ambitious revivals. It consisted of five great chunks from Horatio Parker's "Mona," which was one of the first American operas to be given at the Metropolitan.
Governor Rockefeller's "student incentive" plan for state aid to public and private, including church-connected, higher education has been measurably improved, but the questions remain:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- President Kennedy played golf today on a sodden course dotted with patches of snow.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 22 -- The Government reiterated today that Dr. Walter Guevara Arze escaped arrest yesterday when nearly 100 Opposition political leaders were jailed.
A two-part, sixty-eight-page review of city progress in the last seven years, now being distributed from City Hall, is being widely interpreted as a sure sign that Mayor Wagner intends to run again.
ROME, Feb. 22 (AP) -- An American art expert said today that a supposedly ancient statue displayed by the City Art Museum of St. Louis was made in a Rome studio in 1936-37.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he had found "no evidence of immorality" in the contract that the State Thruway Authority had signed with its former chairman, Bertram D. Tallamy.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 22 -- G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, told Kenyan Africans today that if they wanted to share in twentieth-century prosperity they would have to get down to do some of the manual work now being done by their women.
PARIS, Feb. 22 -- President de Gaulle and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia will meet Monday for what is expected to mark the beginning of the end of the six-year-old Algerian war of rebellion.
IN "Come Blow Your Horn" Neil Simon has put together an old-fashioned Broadway product that seemed to have gone out of fashion -- a slick, lively, funny comedy.
BORGER, Tex., Feb. 22 (AP) -- An explosion and fire killed nine men and injured a tenth today at the Phillips Petroleum Company refinery outside this Texas Panhandle city.
BERL SENOFSKY, one of the solemnest of the younger violinists appearing in public, played a recital in Judson Hall last night without cracking a smile, musically or otherwise.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Foreign Ministry said today that some Mexican migratory workers had been transferred from farms in Imperial Valley, California. But it said there had been no general withdrawal of Mexican contract farm workers from California, Arizona and Nevada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Government is embarked on new interest rate tactics of particular significance to the man who bor rows for a mortgage, the company that borrows for expansion, and the state or city that borrows for construction projects -- if the tactics work.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller indicted today he was not prepared to take a position on an emerging battle in the Legislature on a relaxation of restrictions on the use of the state's 2,400,000-acre forest preserve.

Our attention is focused so sharply on the Cuban revolution these days that it is often forgotten Bolivia is also carrying out a social revolution. It began in 1952 when the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement (M.N.R.) came to power under Victor Paz Estenssoro, who is once again President of Bolivia.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 22 (AP) -- President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province announced today that his government and the United Nations had agreed to freeze all troop movements.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- Northern Biochemical Corporation, the second major financial victim of Mrs. Wallace P. Geiger's embezzlement of two million dollars in Sheldon, Iowa, filed a voluntary bankruptcy petition in the United States District Court here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Two members of the Senate Aviation subcommittee said today some Government agency should have authority to curtail air-traffic flow into crowded regions to minimize the danger of midair collisions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Have the fifty states a wealth of institutional experience and talent that can be tapped in dealing with problems of less-developed nations?
The appointment of Dr. Ray E. Trussell as Commissioner of Hospitals was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

ALTHOUGH most people feel that getting something for nothing is a myth, there is one place in this city that thrives on giving just that. It is the Tourneur Custom Make-up Salon, started by the late Mme. Tourneur in 1926.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- Aleksei Smirnov, a Russian farmer who imbibed too much of his homemade vodka, was in jail today because of a morality lecture read by Premier Khrushchev on the problem of village drunkards.

Time may be running out on the New York Rangers, but they seem determined to finish the season in strong style. Coach Alf Pike's Blues turned in a whale of a job yesterday afternoon as they whipped the big Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 2, in a National Hockey League clash.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and Chancellor Adenauer discussed today ways of easing the economic division of Europe and the political problems attendant upon it.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 22 -- Premier Joseph Ileo warned today that the Congolese Government would use force if necessary to prevent implementation of a resolution approved yesterday by the United Nations Security Council.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The fight for racially integrated housing that is being won in the state is being lost in Westchester because of restrictive zoning, 350 civic leaders of the county were told today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee met in closed session today and began writing a feed-grain bill after hearing farm spokesmen disagree over the Kennedy Administration's 1961 emergency program to cut farm surpluses.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 -- A new conflict developed today between the two most powerful leaders in maritime labor.

LAST month, Hyman Bress used his Town Hall recital for an experiment. He played one of the works in his program while the music was flashed on a screen in front of the audience. The event provoked favorable comment, and it was not surprising when the Canadian violinist announced a similar performance.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -- President Janio Quadros tonight aligned Brazil in favor of United Nations debate on admission of Communist China. Thus he squarely placed his nation against the United States position on a major world issue.
Fifty policemen combed a Chelsea neighborhood last night in search of a 4-year-old girl who had disappeared shortly before 5 P.M.

The investigation of municipally owned docks, approved by the Legislature on Tuesday, was described here yesterday as "a politically inspired attempt to make capital out of the relatively inactive city-owned Staten Island waterfront."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The deep South had another rainy day today -- the sixth straight for some areas -- and braced for more assaults by swollen rivers.
Construction cranes appear to be too big for their rules.

Shortly after Trygve Lie (Secretary General) and George Marshall (Secretary of State) negotiated the "Headquarters Agreement with the United Nations," Ernest A. Gross became legal adviser to the Department of State.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) -- An attempt last night to send two satellites into separate orbits with a single rocket was only partly successful, the Defense Department reported today. It said the satellites had failed to separate and were in orbit together, with the second stage of the rocket also attached.
The long-ailing intercoastal steamship industry continued yesterday to be a major point of interest here and in Washington.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 -- The first diplomatic contacts between West Germany and Poland were made recently, but they were without results, it was learned today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. Feb. 22 -- Lea Pendleton's goal with fourteen seconds remaining in the game enabled Yale to post a 4-3 Ivy Hockey League victory over Princeton tonight. The Elis had trailed 3 -- 0, in the second period.
Not only has the snow been melting; a heart-warming redhead of dazzling good looks has been wandering the streets with a basket of posies on her arm.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The Labor party made another attempt today to find a solution to the bitter strife within its ranks on defense policy.
Brendan Behan, who in his 37 years has been a revolutionary, house painter, prisoner and playwright, will try his hand at being a "conferencier."
TUCKED away between a couple of Vermont hills is a recently opened inn with the charm of a French mountain air. The food and ambiance are continental but in the manner of a rustic dining room.
The Times and the Public Education Association have objected to Governor Rockefeller's aid to higher education plan because (among other reasons) it would "covertly" aid private colleges.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was understood today to be seeking to increase the United Nations force in the Congo by 6,000 men to fulfill his new mandate to use force if necessary.

The new Soviet aid agreement with Morocco (Times, Feb. 12) points up once again the decline of American prestige in North Africa The United States and Morocco have been joined in ties of friendship since the first days of American independence.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Beneath cloudless skies, in weather that usually doesn't prevail in the Adirondacks until late spring, Hemmo Silvennoinen and Ossi Laaksonen, a couple of Finns, waged a struggle for ski-jumping supremacy today.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The Labor party opened a heavy attack today on the Government's efforts to reform the Northern Rhodesian Constitution.
HONG KONG, Feb. 22 -- Marshal Chen Yi, Chinese Communist Foreign Minister, assailed the United States today for its support of the plan to establish a commission on Laos.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 -- The Brown hockey team held Ivy League-leading Harvard scoreless for thirty minutes tonight before bowing to the Crimson sextet, 4 -- 1.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 22 -- The Westchester Bar Association today asked the Legislature for three additional justices in the Ninth Judicial District.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Jersey City Jerseys will open their International League baseball season at home this year against the Buffalo Bisons on April 18.

RONALD ALLEN BROWN, soft-spoken president of the 3,500-man Flight Engineers International Association, finds himself in the predicament of trying to convince striking rank-and-file members they are in the wrong.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 -- A bill enabling the Government to exercise tight controls over the production and shipment of military arms was unanimously approved today by the West German Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation is planning a merger with the Kawneer Company, maker of aluminum architectural products, including exterior metal walls and store fronts, it was announced yesterday.

Following are the texts of a statement early today by Stephen P. Kennedy announcing his refusal to continue as Police Commissioner and of a statement issued subsequently by Mayor Wagner from Gracie Mansion:
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The state's Protestant churches today withdrew their opposition to the college student-aid program proposed by Governor Rockefeller.

A reader takes issue with the recent National Collegiate Athletic Association report crediting Midwestern colleges with having won the greatest number of national team and individual sports championships.

MIAMI, Feb. 22 -- April Skies strengthened his claim to the sprint championship of the meeting by winning the $29,650 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah today. The 4-year-old gelding, owned by Jerome DeRenzo, beat nine others in the seven-furlong dash, finishing two and one-quarter lengths in front of Tudor Way.
HOMEMAKERS and interior designers agree on the decorating styles suitable for homes, according to a recent survey by the National Design Center.
City College's track and field team won the first indoor meet for New York City municipal colleges at the Fitzgerald Gymnasium on the Queens College campus in Flushing yesterday.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Labor moved today to put its political activity on a year-around basis.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller today signed the bill to extend unemployment insurance benefits by thirteen weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The United States Government's land holdings throughout the world increased by 400,000 acres to 772,000,000 during the year that ended last June 30, the General Services Administration reported today.
The city's new Police Commissioner, Michael J. Murphy, like his predecessor, is a firm believer in raising the professional standards of the force.
"Gigot," Jackie Gleason's original comedy-drama about a mute French janitor, will be directed in Paris this May by Gene Kelly.
Soon after Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced his decision to quit this morning, a voice on a police radio waveband in Manhattan said: "Kennedy is out!"
ATLANTIC CITY, Thursday, Feb. 23 -- A Navy plane carrying the Under Secretary of the Navy, his wife and child and five other persons ditched in a bay here early today. But all were rescued.

ORCHARD STREET, on the Lower East Side, is the city's unofficial street of bargains. Intrepid shoppers flock here from all five boroughs and the bargaining would do credit to the Paris Flea Market or a Near Eastern bazaar.
The population of the New York suburbs now exceeds that of the city for the first time.

Two problems have been in the forefront of discussions among paper company executives at their many meetings here this week: The development of new uses for paper and the improvement of timber utilization.
The increasing use of automated data-processing equipment by business concerns has affected the leasing of office space in Manhattan.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 (AP) The Detroit Pistons snapped a seven-game losing string and bolstered their play-off hopes by beating the New York Knicks, 123 -- 117, in the second half of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight.

All Hallows joined Archbishop Molloy, Bishop Loughlin and Bishop Dubois in the semi-final round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's basketball play-offs at Fordham University's gym in the Bronx yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Jack Gelber's play about drug addicts, "The Connection," got off to an unfortunate start tonight at the Duke of York's Theatre. It incurred the hostility of the first-night audience who ruined the performance with interruptions.

A three-year legal battle over the will of a former Cuban diplomat has been ended by compromise agreements that give a private foundation possession of an art collection valued at more than $2,000,000.
Sales of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company fell to $530,019,036 in 1960 from $539,640,773 in 1959, while earnings were less than half of those of the year before, it was disclosed yesterday.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 22 -- The Northern Rhodesian political crisis worsened today and tension mounted.

"The sad part of this business is that a dog doesn't become a top performer until he is about 3 years old," said Willy Necker in the Coliseum yesterday. "By the time he is 8 or 9 he has slowed up and must be replaced. The dog stars for relatively few years, so anybody who wants to have a dog act must keep training them all the time."

No one has yet defined the chores Joe DiMaggio will undertake when he rejoins the Yankees as a two-week coach at St. Petersburg, Fla., on March 9. But whatever he does, following a decade of retirement from baseball, will be out of friendship for Dan Topping, a co-owner of the club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A new power bloc responsive to Speaker Sam Rayburn won its first victories today in the House Rules Committee, but not without embarrassment.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The French Embassy here kept insisting today that the reported White House bid for the Ambassador's cook did not come within the realm of diplomacy.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Labor's top leaders warned today that unemployment would rise to 8,000,000 by next year if national output stayed at present levels. This would represent an increase of 2,600,000 over the present total.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -- Brazilian warships have captured at sea a contraband cutter carrying eighteen new Chevrolet automobiles, whisky, United States cigarettes and television sets to private smugglers in a port near here.
One of New Jersey's industrial landmarks wil be redeveloped as an industrial park.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 22 -- The Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland said tonight: "I am determined to stop the tide of African nationalism if it lies in my power."
For February, yesterday was as pleasant a holiday as could be expected. Except for children in the public schools. Their main complaint was that they were in the public schools yesterday.

Events today: "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Vladimir Golschmann, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Duo Cassado, music for 'cello and piano, Judson Hall, 8:30; Thelonious Monk Quartet, presented by Jazz Profiles, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Four Negro ministers have filed a suit against Gov. John Patterson, three Montgomery officials and four Sheriffs as an outgrowth of The New York Times libel case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Without debate and by voice vote, the Senate confirmed today the nominations of James M. Gavin as Ambassador to France and David K.E. Bruce as Ambassador to Britain.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 22 -- Burma sent a note tonight to the United Nations protesting against outside support to the Chinese Nationalist guerrillas on her eastern border.

TRENTON, Feb. 23 -- The State Division of Employment Security announced today there was no immediate hope of relief for the 219,800 unemployed in New Jersey. The division referred to the continuing decline in economic activity as "a recession."

Electric power production showed its third consecutive decline in the week ended last Saturday. The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that output totaled 14,315,000,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 14,744,000,000 the week before and 14,333,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago.
BAL HARBOR, Fla., Feb. 23 -- George Meany rejected a plea today for a collective-bargaining code to govern relations between unions and their organizing staffs.
DIBAI, Trucial Oman, Feb. 16 -- About thirty Arabs a year hurry into the British Agency compound here and touch the flagpole in a sign of freedom from slavery.

A ballistic "windshield" is being produced at the plastics plant of the Raytheon Company's Aero/Weapons division in Maynard, Mass., to keep the Army's Davy Crockett missile on target. The company is turning out nose cones and tail fins under a $300,000 pilot production con tract from the Army Ordinance Corps' Picatinny Arsenal at Dover, N.J.

Joseph R. Vogel, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., told the annual meeting here yesterday that earnings in the fiscal year ending on Aug. 31 should show an increase of 25 per cent above those for the preceding year. In the year ended on Aug. 31, 1960, M.-G.-M. cleared $9,595,000, equal to $3.83 a share.

Gaspar Cassado, a Spanish 'cellist who made his New York debut in 1936 and who has appeared here intermittently since then, was heard again in Judson Hall last night. This time he was a member of the Duo Cassado, the other member of which is Chieko Hara, a Japanese-born pianist who is the 'cellist's wife.
TUNIS, Feb. 23 -- The Tunisian Government announced today that Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain would pay a visit here in April.

"THE fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge." It is ancient and proverbial wisdom that children are influenced for good and ill by the character and conduct of their parents, but where does the chain of cause and effect begin? With grandfather or with Adam? In Jean Rikhoff's unusual novel, "Dear Ones All,"* the curse of the Timble family runs through three generations with no sign of stopping there.
Consolidated sales of the F.W. Woolworth Company set a new record and passed the billion-dollar-mark for the first time in 1960, but earnings were off slightly.
PARIS, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Hector, the white rat that rocketed ninety-five miles into the sky above the Sahara yesterday wearing a miniature space suit, returned to Paris today a a national hero.
Three of America's top competitions -- all scheduled for the East -- are in jeopardy because of the lack of new snow. Rain and fog in the northlands have aggravated the situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Kennedy has suffered his first major setback in the field of international relations. He tried to lure into the White House kitchen the Vietnamese cook now working for the French Ambassador in London and he failed because both his planning and his strategy were faulty.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- To explore the economic and administrative coordination of health and medical services, a five-year training program has been established at Harvard University. The Division of General Health Services of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has granted $297,510 for the project.
The St. Louis Hawks, who have clinched the National Basketball Association's title, will face the New York Knickerbockers for the last time this season at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Americans and Canadians ought to "work a little harder at understanding each other," the president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association suggested yesterday.
The Commercial Solvents Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of a complex of four companies that make and market stabilized vitamins for the animal feeds industry.

MANY a prospective gain miner found a very different type of fortune in California. One such was Louis Pellier, a Frenchman who turn from his search for the elusive mineral to something more familiar -- nursery farming.

WHAT doth the strong, hardy little American outdoorsman in these dead winter days when there is nothing to be strong and hardy about? Why, he ties flies, if he can tie flies, and becomes the modern American plague.
OLEAN, N.Y., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- St. Bonaventure extended its season won-lost mark to 21-1 by overwhelming Siena, 99 -- 57, in basketball tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The White House has called for and received pledges of secrecy from its household staff.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy began today a major cultural project -- furnishing the White House with authentic items of the time of its construction.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, which operated in the red last year for the second time in its more than a century of existence, was not able to earn even the fixed charges last month.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 23 -- Ground will be broken here March 6 for a Public Fine Arts Library, the first of its kind in the state.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Northern Rhodesia's leading African nationalist criticized today statements by Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, as "irresponsible outbursts" and "mendacious appeals to racial prejudice."

RIO De JANEIRO, Feb. 23 -- Brazil is ready to establish diplomatic relations with Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania while the Government continues a study of possibly setting up ties with the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- A Federal education official suggested today a ten-year, $150,000,000 program to aid African education, including the sending of 10,000 teachers to that continent.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The United States has no wish to dominate emerging African states or impose its policies on them, G. Mennen Williams said here today.
The American Red Cross will open its campaign next Wednesday to raise $5,500,000 here this year.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 23 -- President Kennedy was urged today by the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church to issue an Executive Order ending discrimination in Federal housing.

THE entire action of "Walk-Up," the new play by Gerald Sanford, which opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse, takes place in a seedy, baleful tenement called, Morgan all on New York's West Side.

HARTFORD, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Norman Rockwell received a Brotherhood Award tonight for having promoted "the universal fact that all men, great and unknown, are members of the one family of man under God."
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The heaviest demand in more than a month today caused old-crop soybean futures to rise the limit of 10 cents a bushel allowed for a single day on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The first two sets of newly approved landing lights will be installed at New York's La Guardia Airport this summer when a southeast-northwest runway is completed. This was announced today by the Federal Aviation Agency.

TO many of the 16,000 persons who will inundate Madison Square Garden tomorrow night for the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor track and field championships, the only thing that matters is who wins the high jump.
John J. Bergen, president of the New York Rangers, yesterday declared that General Manager Muzz Patrick and Coach Alf Pike both would be back guiding the club next season.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh will visit Pope John XXIII at the end of their state visit to Italy in May, Buckingham Palace announced tonight.

ALONG needed innovation in television programing -- an opportunity for those either agreeing or disagreeing with a specific presentation to have their opinions represented on the air -- was introduced last night by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 23 -- Heavy rain today necessitated a change in the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association championships, which were slated to begin tomorrow morning.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The Soviet Union complained tonight that the United Nations Secretariat was withholding information about steps being taken to implement the Security Council's latest resolution on the Congo.

As a Negro I deplore the terrible outbreak in the U.N. during the speech of our Ambassador. But also as a Negro, and being honest with myself, I secretly applaud the demonstrators (although another method would no doubt have been better).
Within minutes after President Kennedy announced the end of the airline strike yesterday five lines began to recall 84,000 laid-off employes.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals built a 32-point lead at the half and coasted to a 144-116 triumph over the St. Louis Hawks tonight. The victory was the Nats eleventh in their last thirteen National Basketball Association games.
Inland waterway carriers expressed hope yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission would adopt a suggestion by a Senate study group on how to handle controversial rate proposals.
Communism is a Judeo-Christian heresy that takes the idea "there's a good time coming" and corrupts it to the wrong ends, Bishop James A. Pike said here yesterday.
A walkout of union deliverers at The New York Times last night halted distribution of the city's four major morning newspapers up to two hours and twenty minutes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen announced today that the Republican leadership would sponsor civil rights legislation in the Senate this year in the absence of any program from President Kennedy.

Anthony Quinn is likely to withdraw from "Becket" on April 1. If there is no hitch, Mr. Quinn will leave for Rome to act the title role in the film, "Barrabas." Shooting is scheduled to start there April 15.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 23 -- A legislator asserted tonight that the Kennedy Administration was seeking a compromise in the New Orleans school desegregation controversy.

"AQUAMEDIA," a useful collective word for the water-color, gouache, tempera and casein mediums, was coined by Mrs. Edith Halpert, director of the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street, where an exhibition of pictures in those mediums is now being held.
Your Feb. 18 article "Britain, France and Italy to shun 1964 Fair in City" brings to mind a sore point in international relations and the International Bureau of Expositions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The actions of the House Rules Committee since its membership was enlarged should make it clear to everyone that the objective of the enlargement was merely to transfer control of the committee majority from Chairman Smith to Speaker Rayburn and the Administration.

American Chemical SoThe ciety, g professional association, Ihas leased space in the new ]building at 733 Third Avenue, corner of Forty-sixth Street, from the Din'st Organization, the bu!lder. Edwin G Roos, vice president of the Williams Real Estate Company, was the broker.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- One hundred and sixty-five of the world's leading stock-car racing drivers completed preparations today for the 1,100-miles of competition scheduled for tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday.

MOST salt-water varieties of fish are plentiful for this week-end and a number of welcome price declines also are noted. These include from 4 to 6 cents a pound off the price of bluefish, sea bass, cod, flounder and large clams.

OPELIKA, Ala., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Trial of a Justice Department suit charging discrimination against prospective Negro voters in Macon County ended today with no indication from a Federal judge on how he will rule.

THE annual Greater New York Championships, being played at the Statler Hilton Hotel, continued last night with an open individual contest. In this kind of game the contestants change partners after each round.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 23 -- Truncheon-wielding policemen broke up a demonstration by 400 persons in the heart of Katmandu today demanding the release of the nation s imprisoned political leaders.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 23 -- Four Japanese students apologized to James C. Hagerty tonight for the Tokyo riots against him last June. The outbreak caused the cancellation of a visit by President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
HAVANA, Feb. 23 -- A four-year economic development plan has been announced by Maj. Ernesto Guevara, president of the National Bank, who is considered to be Cuba's economic czar.

The relatively inactive private financing affiliate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) is taking steps toward becoming a factor in the world market for private equity capital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- One hundred years ago today at 6 o'clock in the morning, President-elect Abraham Lincoln stole into Washington. Almost no one was there to greet him.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 23 -- President Kennedy has invited President Sukarno to visit Washington for talks on "matters of mutual interest" during the Indonesian leader's world tour beginning in April.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Truck freight loadings last week were off 6.3 per cent from the level of last year, with particularly heavy losses in nine scattered industrial centers.

Business news was mixed yesterday but the stock market seemed to have no doubts. Heavy offerings were absorbed in the morning and early afternoon and, when they began to dry up, demand continued and brought a good advance for the day, the most active in more than five years.
Three professors from the Soviet Union arrived at Columbia University yesterday for a five-week stay.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday plans to enter the acetylene business with a multi-million dollar plant at Montague, Mich.
Three veterans' organizations have begun a drive for 1,000,000 signatures protesting proposed legislation that would limit the playing of bingo in the same hall to three games a week.
Leading sales finance companies announced yesterday increases of 1/8 and 1/4 percentage point on most maturities of commercial paper they sell directly to investors.

The reaction to Stephen P. Kennedy's resignation as Police Commissioner yesterday ranged from "too bad" to "hurrah," depending for the most part on whether it was coming from outside or inside the Police Department.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The first of President Kennedy's emergency anti-recession bills emerged from committee today. House action is scheduled for next week.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, of the New York State Supreme Court upheld today the right of the State Superintendent of Insurance to regulate premiums for credit life insurance. In doing so, it reversed decision by State Supreme Court Justice William H. Deckelman.

Light fuel oil stocks declined 3,211,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported today. The decline was only about one-half that in recent weeks and its smallness is the result of the rise in the temperature throughout most of the country.

Events today: "Turandot," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Vladimir Golschmann, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Rafael Puyana, harpsichordist, Town Hall, 5:45; Don Cossack Chorus and Dancers, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Donald Currier, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

Last night the ballroom of the Pierre was a bower of roses for the gala dinner dance to benefit the building and expansion fund of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service. Rose trees with flowers in shades of red, orange, yellow and pink decorated the room and served as centerpieces for each table. Pink balloons floated above the trees.
St. John's, with exquisite shooting, precise passing and crushing rebounding, routed Marquette, 85 -- 69, in the first came of a college basketball triple-header at Madison Square Garden last night.
Mayor Wagner announced last night that he had ordered a dossier compiled for every slum building in the city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Secretary of Defense said today that the nation faced "great uncertainties" in planning to meet military threats.

The Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow, which played season in New York in 195 with spectacular success, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House for a three-weeks season beginning April 1 After the troupe closes there May 6 it will tour for ten days and then return for a further series of six performances in New York, this time in Madison Square Garden, May 16 to 20.

Michael J. Murphy was sworn in yesterday as the city's twenty-sixth Police Commissioner. He succeeded Stephen P. Kennedy, who had dramatically resigned shortly after midnight following a dispute with Mayor Wagner over more pay for policemen.
Four Brooklyn high school students received slight razor cuts yesterday in a scuffle in Madison Square Garden. The boys were treated at St. Clare's Hospital and released.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Paul Harvey, the medalist, won his opening match in the national tournament of golf club champions today, beating Roderick Sears of Bryn Mawr, Pa., 5 and 4. The 30-year-old Harvey, who is from Greensboro, N.C., was four under par.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- House members moved today to give themselves more clerks and larger payrolls at a possible cost of more than $6,000,000 a year.
YAPHANK, L.I., Feb. 23 -- Suffolk County's new $900,000 Honor Prison Farm building on Yaphank Road will be dedicated tomorrow at 11 A.M. A public open house will begin at 1 P.M.
Cotton futures soared 90 cents to $2.05 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

AFTER abusing Dag Hammarskjold and denouncing United Nations policy in the Congo ten days ago, the Soviet Government subsided into benign negativism last Tuesday morning. Valerian Zorin, Soviet delegate, indicated in advance that he would not use his veto against a resolution that gave Mr. Hammarskjold greater responsibilities in the Congo.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller submitted to the Legislature today a measure that would authorize New York City to establish a public defender system to represent poor persons in court.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- For those fashion journalists who saw the press showing of Givenchy this afternoon and will see that of Balenciaga tomorrow it is like being let in on a stale secret.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The price of gold in the free market today fell to its lowest point since the mid-October gold rush, when speculators were laying siege to the dollar, and it moved a shade below the United States official selling price, including handling charges, of $35.08 3/4.

The Police Department set up a special telephone -- WAtkins 9-7307 -- yesterday for the public to call with any information about a 4-year-old girl who has been missing from the Chelsea area since 5 P.M. Wednesday.
No responsible survey has ever shown a need for Federal aid to education, Clarence E. Manion, former dean of the law school at Notre Dame, said yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council decided today to reduce export quotas by 2.5 per cent to 82.5 per cent in order to re-establish a balance of supplies and requirements.

The Moore commission is recommending the re-enactment of a City Charter provision that some observers believe could -- if it were ever invoked -- block some of the most common political fundraising techniques, including the $100-a-plate dinner.
During Thelonious Monks' appearance with his quartet at the Museum of Modern Art last night, he managed to puncture three myths (two personal and one general) and to lay the groundwork for a new one.
The six-day wildcat strike of 3,500 flight engineers left a trail of losses to the commercial airlines, their furloughed employes and to other industries estimated at many millions of dollars.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The Chance Vought Corporation filed today an amended petition in its suit against Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., dropping six of the seven charges against the Dallas company.

ANTOINE sees spring hair styles in terms of absolute simplicity. The 77-year-old coiffeur, who looks not a day over 50 and is justly proud of the fact, has arrived in New York from Paris on the first leg of a tour of all his salons.

WASHINGTON, Feb., 23 -- President Kennedy outlined to Congress today a broad natural-resources program aimed at a better environment and ample water and power for a population he said would reach 300,000,000 in forty years.
The stir in the bond market caused by the Federal Reserve System's buying Treasury securities of other than short term faded yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The chief legal officers of sixty cities met today to lay the groundwork for millions of dollars in damage actions against electrical equipment manufacturers recently convicted of bid-rigging.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- The 144-member National Council of the Christian Democratic party ended three days' of debate today by giving unanimous approval to a resolution supporting the Government of Premier Amintore Fanfani.
MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- The sixth "traditional" Flamingo Breakfast for owners and trainers was the big occurrence at Hialeah today and, as far as the track brass was concerned, it was a success.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- President Kennedy has been picking new Ambassadors with about the same language qualifications as those chosen by former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Less emphasis on the suburbs and more on the cities is planned by Neal J. Hardy, the choice of President Kennedy to head the Federal Housing Administration.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Sunshine brought respite to a thoroughly drenched southland today as rain-swollen rivers spread over new sections of Alabama and Mississippi.

The overwhelming percentage of defendants who are charged with crime in this state ultimately plead guilty rather than go to trial. Most of them are extremely anxious to minimize the long time lapse between arrest and sentence.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Baseball men are doing serious thinking about such possible midseason snags as the flight engineers' strike, which ended today.
The first collective bargaining group set up by doctors in this country held its organizational meeting last night.
Laws permitting the unionization of additional municipal employee will be sought this year, city Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg won committee approval today as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
A floating icebox from Iceland reached port here yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 23 -- The United States Embassy here has forwarded a full description to Washington of American-made arms recently captured by the Burmese Army from Nationalist Chinese guerrilla forces.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Jim Pollard, once a star for the Minneapolis Lakers, today was named coach of Chicago's new team in the National Basketball Association.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- It took the playing of "God Save the Queen" to quiet the audience after the final curtain tonight of "King Kong," the jazz musical from South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn won the best end of a compromise today with his newly enlarged House Committee on Rules.
The biggest account shift thus far this year was announced in a rather cryptic fashion yesterday.

The autobiography of Tuvia Friedman, who spent fifteen years searching for Adolf Eichmann, will be published by Doubleday next Friday under the title "The Hunter." The author was in his late teens, living in a medium-sized Polish city, when the Nazis herded him and his family into ghettos.
The general manager of a Queens luxury apartment described by one of its tenants as the "most expensive slum in the nation" was found guilty yesterday of failing to provide sufficient heat.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Kennedy named today a former Congresswoman from Utah, Reva Beck Bosone, to be the Post Office Department's judicial officer.
Complaints of unfair labor practices were issued yesterday by two regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board against six locals of the International Union of Electrical Workers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- President Kennedy's plea for quick action on a bill to reduce surpluses of corn and other livestock-feed grains was heeded at a Senate hearing today.

Arthur Godfrey announced yesterday he would not continue next season as master of ceremonies of "Candid Camera" over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. He said he wanted to do his own show.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Labor pledged itself today to raise $1,000,000 to aid cancer research.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made a loan of $30,000,000 yesterday to Yugoslavia to help finance construction of a hydroelectric station and transmission lines. The installations are part of a program to double the country's electric generating capacity in the next five years.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Bob Nevin and Red Kelly scored with less than three minutes to play tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

The promise of production of color television sets this fall by the Zenith Radio Corporation was hailed yesterday as the beginning of a multibillion-dollar industry. The statements came from Zenith's biggest competitor and also from a spokesman for 5,000 television retailers from coast to coast.
The Endicott Johnson Corporation, which last month successfully repelled a threatened take-over of its management by the Glen Alden Corporation, announced yesterday a shake-up of its board.

The Republic Aviation Corporation declared a dividend of 50 cents a common share yesterday. It will be payable on March 23 to stockholders of record of March 8. In the previous quarters, the company paid 25 cents a share on the common stock.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet Union declared today that King Savang Vathana of Laos lacked power to negotiate an international settlement of the civil war dividing his kingdom.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 23 -- Cambodia's decision not to join the proposed three-nation neutrality commission for Laos has set back the plan but not wrecked it, according to informed sources here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A study has been completed that should increase the light and decrease the heat in the controversy over patents resulting from Government research and development contracts. A report on the study, written by three professors at George Washington University, may give more comfort to industry than to those who demand that the Government own the patents because it provides the money for the research.

With millions to be saved, or made, merger has become as much of a crusade among railroaders as the rush to convert to Diesel engines was after World War II. While many surprise merger talk have been announced recently, some carriers are dusting off old ideas and resuming talks once ended.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- Many West Germans remain Nazis at heart despite efforts of the country's political leaders to strengthen democracy, an American-based Jewish organization reported here today.
I. MILLER has brewed a handsome collection of shoes in creme de cafe blends that should serve as subtle accents for bright colors this spring.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet Union has told West Germany that any "temporary" solution of the Berlin problem must provide for the eventual transformation of West Berlin into a demilitarized free city, as proposed by Premier Khrushchev in 1958.

Dr. Lester R. Tuchman resigned yesterday as chairman of the Advisory Council of the Department of Hospitals in protest over Mayor Wagner's "refusal to consider" the council's candidate for Commissioner of Hospitals.
A drive to save the Seventy-first Infantry Armory at Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street got under way yesterday.

IF you wish to rediscover the pristine magic of the theatre, go to school. Ideally one should become a boy or girl again and join one of the audiences at a performance of "Romeo and Juliet" now playing the city's schools.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Industrial shares failed to develop a decided trend in the stock market here today and rises and falls, mostly less than a shilling (14 cents), were evenly distributed. The Financial Times industrial shares index rose six-tenths of a point to 323.4.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and Chancellor Adenauer agreed today to explore the possibility of using the Western European Union for heads-of-government political consultations between Britain and the six nations of the European Economic Community or Common Market.
Charlie Donovan, the smallest player on the floor, sparked undefeated Erasmus High to a last-quarter rally and a 71-61 victory over Commerce yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
A falling-off in passenger revenues in 1960 won for Fifth Avenue Coach Lines yesterday a return of $643,563 held in escrow by the Board of Estimate.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 21 -- Officials of the British Administration of Kenya believe the colony will emerge from the next two months of political change more peacefully than was expected.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's message to Congress today on natural resources:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Fishermen in underdeveloped countries will be the beneficiaries of hundreds of outboard motors given to the Food and Agriculture Organization by the Outboard Marine Corporation of Waukegan, Ill.
ROCK HILL, S.C., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A Negro minister and two other persons were arrested here today and charged with breach of the peace during an anti-segregation demonstration.
BEREA, Ky., Feb. 23 -- Nestled in the gently rolling foothills of the Cumberland Range, the bustling little town of Berea presents a dramatic contrast to other towns in the Southern Appalachians.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The airline strike virtually ended today after crippling air travel for six days.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- An air of embarrassment prevailed today in and around the Officers Club of the United States Army, European Command, at Camp des Loges just outside Paris.
The Federal Reserve's departure from its "bills usually" policy early this week has resulted in its purchase of $13,000,000 of United States Government securities of more than one year's maturity.

Badge wearers of the Canadian Boating Federation, from Chief Comdr. Wallace Wood down, are showing understandable elation and pride over two world championship events they will conduct this summer. They are expecting to hold both over the weekend of Aug. 5-8 near Picton, Ont., where Bob Hayward drove the Canadian - owned Miss Supertest to the second Harmsworth triumph last August.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that grand juries investigating governmental officials must either indict them or keep quiet about them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Representative John V. Lindsay eulogized William M. Stucky, Associate Director of the American Press Institute at Columbia University, today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Showmanship has brought together art and science at the Twentieth Century-Fox movie studio and the result is a futuristic nuclear submarine that might startle Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover.

Executives of several large corporations whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission this week that they were sellers of their companies' stocks.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 23 -- A threat of civil disorders hung over Northern Rhodesia tonight as Sir Evelyn Hone, the Governor, appealed for careful consideration of Britain's proposals for revision of the protectorate's constitution.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., has sold privately to an institutional investor a $47,500,000 4 3/4 per cent note due on March 1, 1981, the company announced yesterday. Of the proceeds, $32,000,000 constituted a refunding.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 23 -- The National Council of Churches overwhelmingly approved here today the use of artificial birth-control methods for responsible family planning.
P. Lorillard Company reported yesterday that it experienced a drop in sales and earnings in 1960, but that fourth-quarter profits were the highest in the company's history.
STEWART MANOR, L.I., Feb. 23 -- Japan has problems similar to those of this country in rising school costs and a shortage of teachers for technical schools, three Japanese educators said here today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 23 -- Officials of the Central Treaty Organization are hoping that Secretary of State Dean Rusk will attend the meeting of its Council, which begins April 26.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $86,000,000 to $107,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $121,000,000 from a revised figure a week ago to $775,000,000.
Eastern Air Lines was fined $16,100 yesterday by Judge Paul P. Rao in Federal Court for "unfair and deceptive" advertising of its rates between New York and Miami.

In spelling out the functions of the new investment department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Meany has disclosed objectives that happily combine financial profit with social and economic uplift, an unusual package. The new department will assist unions in the investment of funds in their welfare and pension plans. These have grown by now to the prodigious total of more than a billion dollars.

Every major newspaper in New York City called upon Mayor Wagner to reappoint Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy for a second five-year term. It was an extraordinary tribute to a man who had done an extraordinarily good job. So it is an occasion for public regret that Mr. Kennedy has rejected reappointment.
It is only occasionally that one advertising agency pats another on the back -- at least in a paid advertisement.

THE new city Commissioner of Hospitals, Dr. Ray Elbert Trussell, is described by an old friend as a man "with an uncompromising dedication to the highest standards of medicine." This dedication includes a usual working day of 7 A.M. to 7 P.M., another friend said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A major fight is expected here over the appointment of Joseph C. Swidler, long-time counsel for the Tennessee Valley Authority, as chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

Lumber production in the United States totaled 196,718,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 199,949,000 board feet in the prior week, according to reports from regional associations.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Sparked by Wilt Chamberlain's 49-point outburst, the Philadelphia Warriors scored a 129-121 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., Feb. 23 -- The need for continuing higher adult education is illustrated today in the fact that four-fifths of the jobs in this country demand workers with clearly defined skills, Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- A Republican Representative has complained that the Kennedy Administration is attempting to take credit for a post office built under the Eisenhower Administration.
John Denson, editor of Newsweek, has been named editor of The New York Herald Tribune, John Hay Whitney, president and publisher, announced last night.
City College's baseball team, frozen in the Metropolitan Conference second division for seven years, yesterday opened practice for the 1961 season in temperate Goethals Gymnasium.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Newspaper readers, as well as those persons who actually produce the papers, must accept responsibility for success or failure of the country's press, Lester Markel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Kennedy may take a hand in diplomatic efforts to win support for King Savang Vathana's peace plan for Laos. It was reported today that consideration was being given to a suggestion that the President address a direct appeal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodian head of state, to cooperate in the Laotian King's program.

Erie County, N.Y., borrowed $6,370,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of bonds due serially from 1962 to 1971 at an interest cost of 2.5428 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- President Kennedy has turned down a Congressional suggestion that the United States offer food to Communist China in exchange for the release of Americans held prisoner there.
A gathering of some of the outstanding pioneers in aviation history will honor one of the industry's trail blazers, Elmo Neale Pickerill.
Mayor Wagner sat for two hours last night in a Harlem school gymnasium listening to the complaints of scores of local residents on subjects ranging from jobs to housing conditions.

Four private art collections will be seen April 15 on the twentieth annual tour of homes arranged by the Cornell Women's Club of New York. Proceeds will augment the scholarship endowment fund of the Federation of Cornell Women's Clubs.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -Richard Bridgeman of London entered the semi-final round of the United States amateur court tennis championship today by defeating George Plimpton of New York, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, at the Racquet Club.

GENEVA, Feb. 23 -- Earl E.T. Smith's decision not to accept the proposed appointment as United States Ambassador to Switzerland was received with a mixture of relief and regret today in Bern, the Swiss capital. There was no official comment.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The New York Court of Appeals today denied an appeal by the United Fruit Company from a lower court order directing the company to pay International Railways of Central America (I.R.C.A.) $9,100,000 in damages.
A $7,000,000 arts high school will be built adjacent to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the Board of Education announced yesterday.
Net assets of Fundamental Investors, Inc., were $590,54,010 last Dec. 31, compared with $599,357,454 a year earlier, the mutual fund reported yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 23 -- The executive committee of the National Religious Front voted tonight against going into a new Government with David Ben-Gurion.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Feb. 23 -- A new rift between leaders of the rebel regime in Stanleyville, capital of Eastern Province, was reported today.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement on "responsible parenthood" adopted today by the National Council of Churches. Eastern Orthodox representatives abstained from the vote.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 23 -- The Yugoslav Communists apparently have given up hope, at least for the time being, of establishing more friendly relations with the Soviet-bloc nations.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 23 -- People of all races in Rhodesia are waiting anxiously to see what will be the outcome of an emergency session of the federal Parliament tomorrow.
Futures prices for commodities on the New York exchanges moved irregularly yesterday, with the number of rises about equal to the declines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Feb. 18 were 7 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Friedrich Foertsch will become Inspector General of the West German armed forces April 1, succeeding Gen. Adolf Heusinger, the Defense Ministry announced today. General Heusinger has been named Chairman of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's permanent Military Committee in Washington.
A criminal contempt decision against former Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was reversed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
The Waterfront Commission's probation program for dock workers who have been rejected for employment because of personal background is to be given new emphasis, the bi-state agency said last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 15:

GREENVILLE, Ohio, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Allen Ray Irons died today in a plane crash that killed three other men near here. For him it was a tragic end to four hectic days of anxiety over an injured son, and the expected arrival of another child.
A defensive-driving program at the Esso Bayway Refinery at Linden, N.J., has brought a marked reduction in workers' off-the-job traffic accidents, it was reported yesterday.

The indisposition of Leontyne Price caused her withdrawal from last night's performance of "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan Opera. The role of Leonora was sung instead by Lucine Amara, who had appeared in the role last Saturday night for the first time at the opera house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Navy has instructed officers not to show a film strip exposing communism to public gatherings because "it is not considered appropriate for Navy sponsorship before civilian audiences."
Stephen P. Kennedy never raised the issue of supplemental police pay in three weeks of preliminary discussions leading to the Mayor's offer to reappoint him as Police Commissioner.

IT takes a brave woman to cut into a luscious Indian sari unless she is absolutely sure of what she is doing. As a result, beautiful as the fabric may be, in the Western world it may often lie unused in a woman's drawer.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 23 -- The sudden appearance of an ancient, double-decked Fifth Avenue bus in front of a local garage has created something of a stir here.

Life insurance on the general partners in a syndicate purchasing a motel is a feature of a recent sale-and-leaseback deal in New Mexico. The other partners in the syndicate are the beneficiaries of the life insurance.

The bright promise of leadership exercised by President John F. Kennedy has been taking shape in the brief month since he was inaugurated; and few things he has said or done during these crowded weeks have more clearly revealed his breadth of vision in dealing with a major national policy question than his message to Congress yesterday on the coming crisis in the conservation and development of America's natural resources.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Labor deplored today President Kennedy's advocacy of tax incentives to spur business investment.

Fischer-Landis, realty investors, have bought the twelve-story showroom and loft building at 115-17 West Twenty-seventh Street, west of the Avenue of Americas (Sixth Avenue) from Serena Gross. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

The New York Stock Exchange's decision last year to "underwrite" or make good the losses experienced by clients of one of its member firms, DuPont, Homsey Co., sharply reduced the Big Board's "profit" for 1960. The firm has been suspended and now is in liquidation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- There were more births in the United States last December than during any other December, the Public Health Service reported. today.
ROME, Feb. 24 (UPI) -Giulio Rinaldi, challenger for Archie Moore's world light-heavyweight title, outpointed Freddie Mack of New York in a ten-round bout tonight.

WASHINGTON Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that a group of Coloradoans reaped windfall profits of $131,000 plus a debt-free 6,960-acre ranch by turning the soil bank program into a racket.
The Mike Berger Awards in Journalism were presented to three reporters yesterday at the Graduate School of Journalism Columbia University.

Events today: "Martha" at 2 P.M. and "La Gioconda" at 8. Metropolitan Opera; concert of music for the recorder, flute and harpsichord, New York College of Music, 3; Alice Shapiro, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Serata Musicale, Town Hall, 8:30; Quartetto Italiano, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- John L. Lewis declared today that jobless workers should get unemployment benefits the full time they were out of work.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 24 -- King Baudouin decorated United States Ambassador William A.M. Burden today with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Leopold II, Belgium's highest award. It was the high point of a series of Belgian tributes to Mr. Burden, who ends his mission next week.
Donald Currier, a member of the piano faculty at Yale University, came to Carnegie Recital Hall last night for his second New York solo appearance. He made his debut here in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A British scientist said here today that he had discovered the bones of the oldest member of the human race known to science.
NEW YORK's biggest and oddest antiques fair, which annually takes over several acres at Madison Square Garden, opens today, more diverse than ever but still bearing its unmistakable stamp.

The Orienta Marine Boat Yard in the Orienta Point area of Mamaroneck has been acquired under a long-term lease with renewal option by Nichols Yacht Club, Inc.. The property contains four and one-half acres of land and is one of the largest boating centers on Long Island Sound.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- An all-day Cabinet meeting today ended a week of disputes between the Christian Socialist and Liberal ministers in the coalition headed by Premier Gaston Eyskens.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, the defender, and Jackie Burke shot five-under-par 65's today and tied for the first-round lead in the $20,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- Cecil Harmsworth King said today the main objective of his bid for the Odhams combine was to "eliminate the more absurd forms of cut-throat competition in a field where it must be evident there is ample scope for real economies."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Dr. Leland J. Haworth, director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, is expected to be named by President Kennedy as the fifth member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

The drawing power of Puccini, which has long been recognized by opera houses everywhere, has been reaffirmed by those hardy bellwethers of American operatic sentiment -- the Metropolitan Opera standees.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Cornell lifted its Ivy League won-lost record to 6 -- 5 tonight by beating Brown, 67 -- 65, heading off late Brown rally.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Two Conservative members of Parliament submitted motions today asking Prime Minister Macmillan to complain to President Kennedy about the activities of G. Mennen Williams, United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.

PORTLAND, Ore, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will be the new president of the University of Oregon, the State Board of Higher Education announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The bill to extend unemployment insurance benefits, which the Legislature and Governor Rockefeller approved this week, will become academic if Congress approves the Kennedy Administration bill providing supplementary benefits.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A new, more powerful Atlas missile scored its first flight test success today, blazing 7,000 miles to a target in the south Atlantic ocean.
The police mendicant squad, which for forty years sought to keep drifters, vagrants, derelicts and beggars from annoying strollers, has been abolished and its functions transferred to the precincts.

The Osborne, an eleven-story apartment house at 205 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been sold to the Linland Corporation, which is controlled by Mrs. Sarah Korein, a real estate operator. The reported price was $2,500,000.
Speed and balance triumphed over height yesterday as Lane defeated Morris, 69 -- 50, in a quarter-final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball play-offs at Madison Square Garden.
All major American automobile makers will install seat belt hardware as standard equipment on 1962 models, but not the belts themselves.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The biggest obstacle to a mass organizing drive designed to halt the erosion of union strength was removed here today.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- President de Gaulle once again affirmed his faith in the grandeur of France when he inaugurated this morning the massive new steel-and-glass terminal at Orly Airport, eleven miles southeast of Paris.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States suggested today that there could be no settlement of differences between it and Cuba until the Castro Government permitted freedom of political choice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union whether it is prepared to make arrangements for reciprocal commercial airline service between the two countries.
A dispute that affected deliveries yesterday of The New York Times, and other morning newspapers to some degree, was resolved at least temporarily by an arbitrator's decision later in the day.
A book depicting the White House life of four Presidents and their wives will go on sale Monday. Written by a former White House maid and seamstress, it contains nothing sensational or scandalous.
KNOXVILLE, Iowa, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The president of Community National Bank and Trust Company committed suicide today after he admitted embezzling more than half a million dollars.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The head of the American Zionist Council scored tonight as "false and misleading" the view that Zionism had outlived its usefulness.

Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency, approved yesterday the application for merger of the Philadelphia National Bank and the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank, Philadelphia's second and third-largest banks.

RIO DE JANERIO, Feb. 24 -- Foreign Minister Afonso Arinos de Melo Franco hinted tonight that Brazil might turn to a formula of "two Chinas" in her relations with the governments on Taiwan and on the mainland of China.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- With Balenciaga's press showing this afternoon, the final word on the 1961 spring and summer fashions has been said. Considered the undisputed arbiter of taste and elegance in the world of fashion, Balenciaga has once again proved that no one else can quite compete.
New Yorkers, who have suffered through the hardest winter in years, basked yesterday in sun and warmth. At 3:15 P.M. the temperature rose to 65 degrees, matching the record for the date set in 1930.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Senator A.S. Mike Monroney urged today that extra radar controllers be posted in New York and have the special job of insuring that aircraft did not overshoot assigned circling areas.
If a man makes a better mousetrap than his neighbor, the world will hardly make a beaten path to his door if it has never heard about it.
An Episcopal priest's concern over illiteracy among the children of his East Harlem parish has resulted in a remedial program to help boys and girls overcome serious reading problems.

THE Greater New York Championships, a tournament that has been in progress here since Wednesday, will continue today with a two-session open pair contest at 2 and 8 P.M. and will end tomorrow with a team-of-four contest at 1:30 and 7:30 P.M.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The United States is studying the possibility of new action by the Security Council to condemn political assassinations in the Congo.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 24 -- The Yugoslav Government accused The New York Times today of criticizing anti-Belgian demonstrations in Belgrade "probably in order to distract attention from crimes committed in the Congo that provoked the justified indignation of the world and our own public opinion."
All The New York Times stock averages made 1961 highs yesterday as the market swept forward in another rather general advance. Volume again passed the 5,000,000 mark.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- J. Patrick Lannan, a Chicago financier who has frequently been a master of the "special situation," today threatened a proxy fight against the proposed merger of the Milwaukee Road and the Northwestern.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- At least five persons were dead today from one of the worst floods to hit Mississippi and Alabama in years.

NEW cultural enterprises are flourishing. In Washington a syndicate is opening a school to teach Harvard-Boston accents to bureaucrats (beginners say "The Lawst Hoorar" when they mean "The Last Hurrah"), and Israel is exporting the satirical sketches of Ephraim Kishon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Kennedy continued today his political fence-mending in Congress through a series of meetings with chairmen of Congressional committees.
Two Brooklyn men were arrested last night and charged with possession of $15,000 in counterfeit bills.
As an ardent promoter of the theatre on a national and local basis, Robert W. Dowling has worked ceaselessly in its behalf.
A return high-jumping duel between John Thomas and Valeri Brumel tops the card at the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor track and field championships tonight.

Turner Catledge, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, announced yesterday that the society was joining a campaign for a rehearing by the Supreme Court of the Chicago motion picture censorship case.

Those who have any concern for the United States' reputation in Latin America will fervently hope that Congress does not again this year make the mistake of increasing the Dominican Republic's sugar quota. Secretary of State Herter pleaded in vain last year against such an error at such a critical time as this in our relations with Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Luther H. Hodges, Secretary of Commerce, sought today to allay fears that he was unsympathetic to the Administration's depressed-area bill and should not be permitted to administer it.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 24 -- The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland remained calm today as further developments in the crisis over Northern Rhodesia's Constitution were awaited.

SPAIN'S entry into the international nonobjective field was long delayed but, once made, has provided a number of formidable contestants for the Biennale Stakes and for recognition on both sides of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -President Kennedy asked Congress today to help relieve the overseas drain on United States gold and dollars by cutting from $500 to $100 the amount of duty-free goods that American travelers can bring from abroad.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Three spectacular accidents, a series of breath-taking spins and a speed record marked the two 100-mile late-model stock-car races today.
