WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The White House announced today that in the future no advance notice would be given on President Kennedy's attendance at church.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The leader of 1,200,000 Japanese trade unionists recommended today the establishment of a joint labor-management committee to resolve problems of trade competition between the United States and Japan.
State Rent Administrator Robert E. Herman has discounted as impractical the suggestion of two civic agencies for halting rent gouging by rooming house operators.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 24 -- Indonesia opened the door today to United Nations mediation in the decade-old dispute over Netherlands New Guinea, but on Indonesia's terms.

There was more than a little symbolic about the fog and confusion which delayed Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr.'s departure by air from this city for Moscow. The Ambassador had just completed two weeks of consultations on problems of Soviet-American relations with President Kennedy and other high Government officials.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 24 -- Middle Eastern revolutions are generally accompanied by sharp reversals in foreign policy. Thus, in recent years, revolutionary Egypt veered sharply from its previous pro-Western line and revolutionary Iraq quit the Baghdad Pact to join the neutralist camp.

The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) purchased 12,197 mortgages valued at $155,425,000 in the final quarter of 1960, compared with 18,717 mortgages aggregating $232,337,000 in the third quarter, a drop of 33 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A House subcommittee gave unanimous approval today to an emergency corn and feed grains bill that was changed only in detail from one offered by the Kennedy Administration.
Point and counterpoint come easy to Bobby Gusikoff -- in music or in table tennis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The New Haven Railroad informed the Interstate Commerce Commission today that it would need $1,500,000 more to keep the railroad operating.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The State Board of Regents gave its unqualified endorsement today to Governor Rockefeller's revised plan for tuition aid to college and university students.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 24 -- Hooded figures bearing notes signed "KKK" visited the homes of two school board members this week. A third received a threat on his life in a telephone call last Friday, the district attorney's office announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois assailed as "unfair" today President Kennedy's statement that Eisenhower Administration resources policies took a toll in human life.
A man sits alone in a cubicle, talking, apparently to himself. He talks about the past, his present difficulties, his expectations. A tape recorder takes down his words.

Two unions of service and kitchen workers continued yesterday to picket the Stork Club despite a ruling on Monday by the National Labor Relations Board. The board held that the picketing was an attempt to force recognition of a union, a practice forbidden by the Landrum-Griffin Act of 1959.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Feb. 20 -- In the private homes and the coffee houses of Jerusalem one topic of unending interest is the citizen of Israel, whose composite is likely to bear the cultural marks, the skin color or the profile of a hundred lands.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 -- State and city officials agreed today on a plan for paying teachers salaries tied up by the city's school desegregation controversy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A patent has been allowed for a film "analyzer" that expedites the printing of color motion pictures of missile firings at Cape Canaveral.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Fire broke out in an elevator shaft at the French Embassy tonight. It swept through the attic and caused serious damage to the three-story structure.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- The Soviet Union published today a preview of a radical new constitution that will make the doctrine of peaceful coexistence a new "scientific principle" of Marxist theory.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Whitney North Seymour Sr. of New York City has agreed to serve as the third member of a committee designated by the Legislature this week to investigate a contract for engineering services between the State Thruway Authority and Bertram D. Tallam, a former chairman of the authority.
A record total of 154,065,868 vehicles used the traffic facilities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority last year, according to the authority's annual report released yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The Daily Mirror appeared today to be assured of success in its bid to buy out the Odhams newspaper and magazine chain.
BOSTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -The New England Council forecast and report on ski con-ofrecast and report on ski conditions today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy expressed regret today at the failure of the Louisiana Legislature to provide funds for the New Orleans schools.
Five major airlines restored about 50 Per cent of their flights yesterday on the first full day of service after the six-day walkout of flight engineers.

The Household Finance Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net income of $23,277,072 in 1960, compared with $22,243,118, in 1959, when earnings benefited from a nonrecurring tax credit of $3,010,000.

The Cleveland Pipers, paced by Roger Taylor's 26 points, overcame an 11-point deficit and defeated the New York Tuck Tapers, 103 -- 96, in a National Basketball League game last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

Last week will go down as one of the busiest in years on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was 20,696,610 shares. And although this was below the 23,021,955 shares traded in the week before, it occurred in only four trading days because of the Washington Birthday holiday.
Rapidly improving ice conditions in the Hudson River may end the need to keep the big Coast Guard icebreaker Westwind on convoy duty between here and Albany, a Coast Guard spokesman said yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 24 -- The Mapai reaffirmed today David Ben-Gurion's leadership over the party that rules Israel.
New presidents were elected by several paper industry trade associations at meetings here this week.
A week-long crackdown on construction men for blocking streets with equipment and material has resulted in the issuance of almost 1,000 summonses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Rail freight loadings showed an improvement last week, along with the weather.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Navy said today it had developed a system of keeping time that was ten times more accurate than the most perfect ways available to measure other units, such as weight or distance.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24 -- Bucking a 60 per cent field-goal average by Harvard in the first half, Princeton's basketball team rallied to win, 80 -- 73, tonight.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 24 -- The Middlebury team took the lead as the Eastern intercollegiate skiing championships opened under adverse conditions today.

ANYONE needing a lift -- and who doesn't these dreary winter days -- might stroll into one of the boutiques around town. Helena Rubinstein, Lilly Dache and Charles of the Ritz are only a few of those to be found in New York City.

Mayor Wagner listened for three hours yesterday to arguments on a bill that would close coin-operated laundries on Sunday and require the presence of an attendant during evening hours. He reserved any decision whether to sign it.
Rafael Puyana, Colombian harpsichordist, who made his debut here in 1957, gave a notable Town Hall recital late yesterday afternoon.
THE newly appointed Ambassador to Spain, Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle Jr., once handled eight diplomatic chores at the same time. That was during World War II, on his last diplomatic assignment.
Two brothers who operate a produce market in Newburgh, N.Y., were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading income taxes totaling $72,580 for 1954 through 1958.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -The country's first over-the-air pay television will start in Hartford, Conn., as soon as sufficient subscribers have been signed up. That is expected in about six months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The White House said today that there were better ways to spend the taxpayers' money than sending the United States Army Band on a $200,000 goodwill tour to South America.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Rex C. Ellsworth's Prove It was installed an odds-on favorite today to capture the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap tomorrow. He may be the shortest-priced horse in the famed stakes since Round Table.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy's first full day in office was a busy one yesterday, but without fanfare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A Federal career woman credited by the Post Office Department with saving "millions of dollars" in mail costs was among six women who received the first annual award of the Civil Service Commission tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Problems of peaceful coexistence between the East and the West were illustrated today at a conference of British and Soviet delegates on that touchy subject.
Jesse Owens, who won four gold medals at the 1936 Olympics, received the Sportsmanship Brotherhood's 1960 annual citation "for exemplary sportsmanship" at a luncheon at the Astor Hotel yesterday.

A high level of activity is predicted for the new capital market next week after the lull resulting from the holiday this week. Slated for offering are $276,273,000 of fixed interest securities, most of which are tax-exempt state and municipal bonds.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Stockholders approved today the merger of the Delaware Realty and Investment Company into the Christiana Securities Company, investment company with assets of $3,500,000,000.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Hudson County will start two legal attacks next week in a move to prevent the state from reducing the county's representation in the Assembly from nine to six delegates.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, trailing by 24 points in the first period, rallied to overwhelm the Syracuse Nats today, 144 -- 128, in a National Basketball Association contest before 12,238.

The careful correctness with which Adlai Stevenson, The New York Times and other responsible American sources have commented on the death of Patrice Lumumba obscures the fact that the United States has considerable responsibility for this tragic event.
Commodities futures prices on New York exchanges closed mostly higher yesterday in generally dull trading.
The trial in Israel of Adolf Eichmann has been causing considerable turmoil in television circles.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Collection by the State of Illinois of $18,000,000 annually in sales taxes on items sold to the Federal Government by Illinois suppliers was held unconstitutional today by a three-judge Federal court.

We applaud Mayor Wagner on his appointment of Dr. Ray E. Trussell as Commissioner of Hospitals. We also congratulate Dr. Trussell -- and the public -- on the widened opportunity he will have for effective work in the cause of better health services. The Mayor couldn't have chosen a man more qualified for the job. The hospital situation in New York is in a stagnant low.

CAIRO, Feb. 24 -- An Air Jordan plane landed at Cairo airport today and out stepped Mrs. Eisenhower and Mrs. Kennedy. The airport's red carpet was quickly unrolled and officials rushed to greet the two women while Customs cleared their baggage in about forty seconds.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- After a hesitant start, industrial shares advanced steadily in the stock market here today and scored widespread small rises. The Financial Times industrial shares index rose 3 points to 326.4.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 24 -- Premier Joseph Ileo's Government appeared today to be gradually gaining a measure of political strength outside Leopoldville.

CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 24 (AP) -- An airtight defense, plus a flashy attack, tonight helped the St. Lawrence hockey team shut out Boston College, 3 -- 0. The Eagles were rated the leading college sextet in the East this week.

Parents of the very young can sometimes be heard in public conscientiously and patiently trying to answer a barrage of questions from their offspring. Unfortunately, such rapid-fire queries are often just a method of monopolizing attention and do not reflect a real thirst for knowledge.
The Western Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a rise in earnings despite a drop in its gross revenues for last month.
The age of elegance and personal service seems to be on its way back in the hotel industry.

PRESIDENT KENNEDY is a devotee of fish chowder, according to United Press International. Here is Mrs. Kennedy's recipe for chowder and another of her recipes for a favorite dessert of the Kennedy family.
Three Japanese cranes, one of which is relatively rare, were very formally introduced to the American public yesterday afternoon in the Bronx Zoo.

Police search crews working under floodlights dug through the rubble at the site of the Penn Station South Housing project last night after getting the first clue in the disappearance of a 4-year-old girl who has been missing since Wednesday.
The Great Bay Shore Shopping Center, a ten-acre development at the intersection of the Montauk Highway and Saxon Avenue at Bay Shore, L.I., has been sold by Shore Center, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. warned today of the growing number of Soviet weapons available to Communist China.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP) -Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

Guests in Colonial costume and formal attire and guardsmen of the Seventh Regiment in dress uniforms of the War of 1812 attended the twenty-sixth annual Colonial Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night.
A LONG ISLAND housewife who mounted a sound truck during the depression to explain, with the help of hand puppets, the New Deal agencies is now using puppetry to teach brotherhood to the young.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- In another broad advance, July soybean futures came within a cent of $3 a bushel today as all old-crop deliveries again posted new highs for the season.

Danilo Dolci, author of "Report From Palermo," is expected to arrive from London tomorrow for his first visit to this country. During the next two weeks, he plans to lecture and hold meetings at universities and other public institutions where he hopes to obtain from sociologists and experts in related fields information that will be useful in his work among the poor in western Sicily.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Government withdrew today immorality charges against a Swedish white woman novelist and a Negro political leader and ordered the woman expelled from South Africa.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Four of twelve oil companies convicted by a jury Dec. 30 of conspiracy to fix retail gasoline prices in South Bend asked today that the verdict be set aside.

Premium income of the Travelers Insurance companies, Hartford, Conn., last year totaled $1,180,000,000, an increase of $71,000,000, or 6.4 per cent, above the 1959 level, according to the annual report released yesterday.
Harvard won seven of the eleven events and scored a 56-37 victory over Columbia yesterday in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet at University Hall.

The Building and Construction Trades Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. made two moves last week to reduce the likelihood of strikes. One is focused on the missile field and the other involves the whole range of construction of big industrial plants. Both blaze paths that should be widely followed by other unions and employers.

The thirtieth annual luncheon, bridge and fashion show for the benefit of the Loyola School and the Jesuit seminaries of the New York Province will be held March 23 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Muzz Patrick, the New York Rangers' general manager, last night denied his players were incensed over the retention of Alf Pike as coach for next season.

The wholesale commodity price index rose to 84.8 on Thursday from 84.4 on Tuesday. This is the highest level since the same figure was recorded last Sept. 6. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.8 on Feb. 17, 1960.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 24 -- Penn survived Dartmouth's surge tonight and gained its first basketball victory at Hanover in seven years, 77 -- 69, before 1,000 fans.

DRIED beef, as most grocers agree, does not sell in the quantity it did a decade or so ago. One storekeeper offered this explanation for the decline in sales of the product that also goes by the name of chipped beef:
City College's rifle team snapped a ninety-two match winning streak of St. John's in Metropolitan Intercollegiate Rifle Conference competition last night at the Lewisohn Stadium ranges.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Wallace Goodwin ousted Bill Harvey today in a quarter-final of the national tournament of golf club champions.

The Federal Reserve System did some more shopping yesterday for Treasury securities of more than short term, but the purchases did little to stir the Government market from the inactivity into which it lapsed after the Washington's Birthday holiday.
Mrs. Marjorie Steele Hartford was granted an uncontested divorce in State Supreme Court yesterday from her husband, Huntington Hartford 2d, the A. heir.
Lewis Alcindor, a 13-year-old grammar school student with lofty thoughts on the basketball court as well as in the classroom, outreached Richie Guerin of the Knickerbockers in a jump-off yesterday.
YESTERDAY afternoon's concert by the New York Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall was unadventurous in its program, well bred in its performance -- a soporific combination.

The gold bubble, blown up these past months by speculators without confidence in our dollar, has obviously burst. Last October the more frantic of these speculators were willing to pay at times even more than $40 an ounce for gold in the London free market. Last Thursday the price of gold in that same market dipped to $35.08 1/2 an ounce, a price less even than the $35.08 3/4 official United States selling price.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 -- Carry Back looms as the odds-on choice in the $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah tomorrow. The Florida-bred, owned by Jack Price, has enjoyed the role of favorite all week, but he didn't acquire odds-on status until the entries were released today.

MILFORD HAVEN, Wales, Feb. 23 -- In the third act of "Cymbeline," Imogene declares: "How far it is to this same blessed Milford: and by the way tell me how Wales was made so happy as to inherit such a haven?"

Last Thursday the price of gold in that same market dipped to $35.08 1/2 an ounce, a price less even than the $35.08 3/4 official United States selling price.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 -- Carry Back looms as the odds-on choice in the $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah tomorrow. The Florida-bred, owned by Jack Price, has enjoyed the role of favorite all week, but he didn't acquire odds-on status until the entries were released today.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 24 (AP) -- George A. Garrett's Bonzo became the fifth winning favorite at the Bowie Race Course today by taking the featured seventh race.

May I, as a former member the British House of Commons, b permitted to submit my opinion c what I feel to be a highly unfortunate statement made recently by m fellow Scotsman, Lord Home, before the House of Lords concerning the entrance of Red China into the United Nations.

The Lone Star Boat Club has taken title to the four-story commercial building at 238-40 West Fifty-fourth Street. The parcel was bought from the Urban Property Company through the Cruikshank Company, broker. The plot is 50 by 100 feet.

Representative John V. Lindsay told the New York Young Republican Club last night that if the House had failed to vote enlargement of its Rules Committee last month, the Republican party "would have been stuck with the image of solid coalition with the Southern Democrats."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A "first-class scandal" may be shaping up over the handling of union welfare and pension funds, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. declared today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 12 off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Heart Fund volunteers are scheduled to make their annual door-to-door appeal for funds here tomorrow.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- The French Communist party's Central Committee ousted Marcel Servin and Laurent Casanova, once close collaborators of the party's secretary, Maurice Thorez, from its Politburo today.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- A study indicating a relationship between heavy smoking and premature births was made public today.
SUFFERN, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- An electronics expert here is making nightly broadcasts over local power lines demanding a public referendum on a proposed urban renewal program.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Swedish sports fans were stunned today by charges that Sven (Tumba) Johansson, a three-time Olympic ice hockey star, was accepting undercover payments and should be declared professional.
A former chorus girl tried yesterday for the second time in two years to hold up the same bank. For the second time she was captured before she got out the door, and by the same guard.
HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- The Cuban government reorganized various administrative departments today in a step toward more efficient control of the sland's economy.
ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, said today that he expected one day to assign a reporter to make a trip to outer space.

The directors of Lehn Fink Products Corporation yesterday recommended a three-for-one split of the common stock. They also indicated they would pay a dividend on the split stock of 20 cents a share. This would be equal to 60 cents on the present shares on which the quarterly payments have been 50 cents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today upheld the action of the Civil Aeronautics Board in denying six large irregular air carriers permission to continue operating and ordered another hearing for a seventh.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- This one may be hard to believe. But a pitcher can be too strong for his own good.
VIENNA, Feb. 24 -- The plight of Austria in the situation of "Europe at sixes and sevens" may threaten a major new project of the Kennedy Administration.
A corps of retired educators is being organized by the city school system to utilize their experience and talents.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The General Electric Company has agreed to let its 250,000 stockholders vote on a union proposal that company officers found guilty of having violated the Federal antitrust laws be barred from serving the company.
The second of the season's New York Assemblies was held last night in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East. It was under the chairmanship of Miss Clementine Miller.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 24 -- This country finished the calendar year 1960 with an increase in the gross national product of 5.7 per cent, the Bank of Mexico has announced.

FINALLY Puccini's "Turandot" came to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera. It had been absent since Jan. 8, 1930, and one of the reasons for its absence was the lack of a soprano to sing the title role. Puccini wrote a ferociously demanding part, one that requires extraordinary strength of voice and stamina.

ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Roger Staub of Switzerland, a 1960 Olympic gold medalist, and Barbara Ferries, an Aspen High School senior, scored victories today in the men's and women's divisions of the Roch Cup downhill ski race.

Savings banks alone have been responsible for about half the total increase in mortgage loans outstanding on New York State properties over the last decade, William S. Brennan, First Deputy State Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- Francis Cardinal McIntyre charged today that President Kennedy's proposal to Congress Monday for Federal aid to Education discriminated unconstitutionally against non-public school students.

An investment group, in which Roy M. Cohn has an interest, is planning to purchase the controlling interest in the Tower Acceptance Corporation. Tower operates a chain of loan offices in a number of Southern states.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -President Kennedy and Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies of Australia joined today in public support for King Savang Vathana's peace plan for Laos.
LULUABOURG, the Congo, Feb. 24 -- Chief Sylvain Kalamba, a distinguished-looking Congolese in a black homburg, returned today to find a few dozen of his Lulua tribesmen at the airport to greet him.
A city request for an amendment to the state's fair housing practices bill, now before the Legislature, was sent to Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders yesterday.

Everything from jitterbug dancers to an imitation of Charlie Chaplin doing the Cha Cha was offered during the Knights of Pythias March of Youth program at Madison Square Garden last night. Then the Knicks were brought out, but they didn't produce so many gags as some had expected.
Pinkerton detectives will guard the billion-dollar World's Fair of 1964-65 against burglars, pickpockets, rioters, vandals, dishonest employes and unruly drunks.

Jean-Paul Belmondo may well be the most impressive new, young French film actor since the advent of the late Gerard Philipe, judging by the critical and box-office response to "Breathless," the latest "New Wave" import at the Fine Arts Theatre.

PRUNING equipment should be readied now for an early sally among the back-yard fruit trees. Experts pinpoint the best time for dormant-season pruning of apple and pear trees at six to eight weeks before the opening of spring buds.

VIENNA -- Austria has many things, both old and new, that will appeal to tourists this year. There are special restaurants and modern hotels, new mountain cableways and better roads, the most up-to-date airport in Central Europe, as well as exhilarating cultural and sight-seeing novelties.

AUCKLAND, N.Z. -- After years of comparative isolation, New Zealand has at last begun to take its place on the tourist circuit. This is because the islands have become aware of the importance of tourism in the national economic picture and are making greater efforts to attract visitors and entertain them once they have arrived here.

THE link between the advent of President Kennedy and the professional life of an English script writer, industriously minding his own business in a quiet house in Surrey, seems tenuous, but T.E.B. Clarke is excited about what the new Administration has done for him.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Rex C. Ellsworth's favored Prove It raced to victory in the twenty-fourth running of the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A new appraisal by the space agency finds that while the Soviet Union has scored great achievements in space technology, it is lagging far behind the United States in space research.
PEIPING, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- The Agriculture Ministry has called for new irrigation and water-conservation efforts toward off the threat of drought in northern China.
An introduction to Mrs. Cortright Wetherill immediately becomes a hazard to any previous occupation one might have had, according to her friends.

IN April, 1861, a small, calm, sturdy woman in her fortieth year, her thick dark hair bunched back behind her ears, her long, straight dress free of fashionable crinoline and stiffening, moved quietly among the ragged and bloody men of the Sixth Massachusetts Regiment. Some of them were her former pupils.
A romantic interest in the sea, backed with risk capital Wall Street refused to supply, lies behind a success story that began a quarter-century ago on a family owned island in the Bahamas.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- The attention of everyone interested in the Algerian problem -- a fairly big round-the-world audience -- will be fixed Monday on the Paris meeting between President de Gaulle and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Kennedy Administration has decided to risk a Congressional furor by pressing for sharp reductions in a politically popular school-aid program established ten years ago.

After reading your vivid and graphic account of the mining families in Cabin Creek Valley, W.Va., ("Waiting for Help in a Depressed Area," Feb. 12) I wonder to whom I could address a carton of usable clothing (both children's and adults'), toys and children's books, to be distributed among those who need them most.
The Grossman Clothing Company is celebrating its golden anniversary this year and the man who started the concern is marking his fiftieth year as president.

TOKYO -- The American tourist whose itinerary includes Japan this season will be encouraged by the news that economy-class trans-Pacific air fares have been reduced by 14 per cent and that it now takes only twelve hours to fly from the West Coast of the United States to this country.

Gen. George H. Wingate High of Brooklyn captured the national interscholastic indoor track and field championship yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Coach Don Altman's team scored 10 points, just one more than the favorite, Franklin K. Lane.

Svetozar Gligoric, the chess champion of Yugoslavia, and Arturo Pomar, Spain, tied at 8 1/2 -- 2 1/2, to share top honors in the tournament recently held at the Hotel Pez Espada, Torremolinos, Spain. A field of twelve competed.

Your editorial comment of Feb. 15 regarding the recent antitrust case in the electrical industry may lend unfortunate support to the notion that this action was the outcome of obsolete legal authority. I hope this was not your intention.

OLEAN, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Niagara registered a sensational basketball upset by ending a thirteen-year home-court St. Bonaventure winning streak tonight. The Bonnies had won ninety-nine games in a row here.

The New York Wellesley Club has organized a committee to arrange a theatre party at the April 11 performance of "Mary, Mary" at the Helen Hayes Theatre. The new play by Jean Kerr will open on March 8, with Barbara Bel Geddes in the leading role.

Arthur W. Mack has been appointed treasurer of the Ford Instrument Company, a division of the Sperry Rand Corporation. He had been vice president in charge of finance for the Walworth Company, New York, manufacturer of valves and fittings.
MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- Premier Khrushchev has begun to school the Kennedy Administration in what he means by "peaceful coexistence." The Congo crisis provided the first lesson.
A Soviet spokesman has rebuked Albania for her pro-Chinese, anti-Soviet policy with invective seldom publicly reported in Communist discussions.
PARIS -- Flashing red lights pour color into the swift current of the Seine these cool pre-spring evenings and constitute a symbolic warning to tourists that the beloved Pont des Arts may be doomed.
MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- Carry Back of the Dorchester Farm Stable stepped home the winner by a head in the $129,800 Flamingo Stakes today.

The official Soviet Communist party magazine Kommunist has published a preview of a new Soviet Constitution that Premier Khrushchev will propose at the party Congress next October. One of its central points, apparently, will be to enshrine Premier Khrushchev's doctrine of "peaceful coexistence" as a new "scientific principle" of Marxist-Leninist theory.

THIS story of men in barracks, written by an ex-G.I. private who saw service in the Far East, is a first novel -- but it does not read like one. It is a swift, smooth, polished and intensely interesting narrative of the life of an American soldier and his unit during the course of a year -- from summer to summer -- in post-Korean War Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Kennedy today set import duties on foreign-made bicycles 50 per cent higher than those previously agreed upon in a 1947 agreement at Geneva. The increase was the first by the Kennedy Administration.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 25 -- A local human relations organization is attempting to "prick the conscience" of this township on segregated housing.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- Nikolai G. Igantov, a Soviet Deputy Premier has been appointed chairman of the newly established State Committee of Procurements, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

In a season burning bright with colors there is bound to be one that outshines all the others. This spring pink casts its rosy glow over a wide range of fashions. The gentle flattery of this color gives a come-hither quality to everything from simply cut wools to softly tailored chiffons. Tones from pale camellia to vibrant cyclamen are emphasized by yet more pink in all accessories.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- Just about this time every year, the Netherlands is busy with preparations for the annual tulip show, but no sooner do the great splashes of color on the bulb fields fade than the yearly Holland Festival blooms.

FLORIDA Showcase, a permanent exhibition of the state's attractions for vacationists, prospective residents and business men, was officially opened in Rockefeller Center here last Friday by Gov. Farris Bryant.

GROUCHO MARX is developing a new television show for next season. Having done a quiz show for fourteen years on radio and TV without encountering a single charge of rigging, he believes it's time to move on to something else.
SEATTLE, Feb. 25 -- Ground was broken this week on the Federal Government's $3,500,000 Hall of Science at Seattle's Century 21 Exposition.

Such Stuff as Dreams Are Made on G.K. Chesterton said that "the center of every man's existence is a dream." This appears true enough. Most of us, with the exception of a few people who deny that they dream at all, will agree with the statement.

Ranking in importance with the message on education that he had sent to Congress only three days earlier is President Kennedy's exciting and comprehensive statement on the development and conservation of the nation's natural resources.

MELBOURNE -- The next few years, in the opinion of Australian authorities, will bring about a huge increase in tourism on this continent. There are several reasons for this. The basic facts are that jet planes and new, big, fast cruise ships are making Australia much more accessible than ever before.

McMURDO SOUND is today a very busy place, even though it is half way between the Antarctic Circle and the South Pole. Giant air freighters reach it regularly from New Zealand during the brief summer season bringing in hundreds of men along with supplies to be distributed to lesser settlements, one of them 800 miles farther on at the Pole itself.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 25 -- Andover scored a double sports victory over Exeter today, beating its traditional rival in hockey and wrestling. Andover capped the day by winning the New England interscholastic track and field meet for the twelfth time in its sixteen year history.

BALDWIN, L.I., Feb. 25 -- Baldwin High School clinched a play-off berth in Section I of the South Shore Athletic League today by defeating the Oceanside quintet, 59 -- 53. The game was televised over Channel 7.

IN every country, there is one ideal meal which best displays the culinary art of that nation and, at the same time, is suitable for American tourists. Knowledge of what dishes to select will brighten an overseas trip and bring the gastronomic, highlights of each country to the fore.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- After seventeen years, President Kennedy has identified the man who saved him from death on a South Pacific island.

THE three worried men who wrote this book are convinced of three things: that we are doing badly in the cold war; that, without overstraining ourselves, we could do much better; but that if we don't wake up to this fact swiftly, we are doomed.
The worst winter in many years has struck with such rare violence and impact that it will take weeks and possibly months to assess its full cost to industry, business and the average taxpayer.

George N. Gardner, educational director of Pan American World Airways, has been named to receive the 1960 Frank G. Brewer Trophy.

THESE twelve stories, most of which appeared first in The New Yorker, form a terrifying anatomy of domestic hell chez the English middle classes. Convinced that her characters are diseased, Penelope Mortimer has resorted to vivisection in search of the trouble.

ELY, Nev. -- One of the most unusual blasting operations in the history of western mining is taking place near here under a flank of snow-capped Wheeler Peak. Skilled miners are enlarging a tunnel in the scenic Lehman Caves National Monument to open another grotto to the public, but it is slow, painstaking work.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 25 -- The Kennedy Administration has refused to sustain the formula approved by the Eisenhower Administration for the settlement of the long-festering problem of German assets seized in the United States as a result of World War II.

THE literary reputation of Kingsley Amis has been hampered by two unfortunate circumstances: he was identified at the beginning of his career as an Angry Young Man, and therefore presumably dedicated to arguing angrily in print for the disestablishing of the Establishment; and he wrote a first novel which is certainly the funniest book to come out of England since the war.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- Totenham Hotspur, bidding strongly for both the English League title and the Football Association Cup, took another stride toward league honors today with a 1 -- 0 soccer victory at Manchester City's stadium.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Ohio State clinched a share of the Western Conference basketball championship, defeating Wisconsin, 97 -- 74, tonight for its twenty-second victory in an unbeaten season. The top-ranked Buckeyes have a 12-0 conference record with two games to play.
Belle Acton, harness racing's leading money-winning pacing mare, was sold yesterday for $52,500, a record price for a brood mare, to the owners of the sport's top earner among stallions.
RIMINI, Italy -- A vacationist who chooses the Adriatic coast of Italy will find broad, sunny beaches, night life and luxurious, modern hotels at prices much less than anywhere else in this country.
Confidence continued widespread among investors last week that the economy was on the threshold of an upward move being spawned both by its own adjustments and Government prodding.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 20 -- Recent Arab rumblings about "liberating" Turkey's Hatay Province are proving "very annoying" to Turkish leaders in Ankara. Among those who are annoyed are members of the military government, who have been saying there is "nothing to be concerned about."
A MAJOR national survey, reported on this page last week, has shown that American parents in large numbers feel vaguely guilty and inadequate about their relationship with their children.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Northrup R. Knox of Buffalo won the United States amateur court tennis championship today for the second straight year and the fourth time since 1957.

LISBON, Portugal Feb. 25 (AP) -- Portugal signed a contract with the United States Steel Company today for construction of what is planned to Europe's longest suspension bridge, across the mouth of the Tagus River here.

THE Zurich Municipal Theatre has long been Switzerland's leading opera house -- the only one in the entire country, indeed, that presents a purely musical repertory, as distinct from legitimate theatre.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A measure aimed at unmasking slum landlords who hide behind dummy corporations was submitted to the Legislature today by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Prime Minister Macmillan warned today that the West faced "a period of fiercely competitive coexistence." The Soviet Union, he said, believes such coexistence represents the best way to advance the Communist cause.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Jewish National Fund of America approved a plan tonight for the reclamation of 625,000 acres in Israel that will involve the settlement of 100,000 families at a cost of $250,000,000 over the next twenty years.

Squadron A moved into the semi-final of the Sherman Memorial polo tournament last night by defeating Brookville, 14 -- 9, at the Squadron A Armory, Manhattan. The score was tied six times before a third-period goal by Russ Drowne on a No. 4 penalty put Squadron A in the lead to stay.

VIENNA -- Travelers who visit Czechoslovakia this year will find that the standard of living there is the highest among all the satellite countries behind the Iron Curtain. NEW YORK CITY'S forty-fourth annual salute to spring -- the 1961 International Flower Show -- will open at 2 P.M. on Saturday at the New York Coliseum. More than one-half million blooms and plants will be used to illustrate the show's theme, "Gardens for Outdoor Living."

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Against a background of Soviet-Chinese ideological differences, official maps and atlases published in Moscow and Peiping continue to differ on some international boundaries.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Feb. 25 -- Richard Remsen and John Russell of the Racquet and Tennis Club led the way into the semi-final round of the Piping Rock Club's fourteenth annual squash racquets doubles tournament today.

GENEVA -- Swiss voters go to the polls next week to decide an issue of direct interest to many foreign visitors, the price of gasoline. Georgian furniture, French and Italian pieces and a large variety of decorations will be auctioned Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, at Seventy-eighth Street.

The second annual Boy Scouts Gala has attracted a large number of patrons. Their names have been announced by Mrs. Anthony M. Del Balso, general chairman. The event will take place March 16 in the Grand Ballroom of the Commodore.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's hockey team skated to its eleventh Eastern victory in fourteen games today. The Engineers defeated Boston University, 5 -- 2, at the R.P.I. field house.

TO those who take delight in the gaiety of flowers, winter may seem a bleak season. But at this time of year there is much beauty to be seen outdoors. On a winter walk the gardener can spot papery insect cocoons, abandoned bird nests and a variety of twig types.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- John F. Kennedy is the sixth President since Lincoln whose previous political experience was principally or wholly gained in Congress. WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The last dirty remnants of five big snows disappeared from Washington's streets this week and the city stirred in the first promise of spring. On Capitol Hill, even a hibernating Congress stretched and grumbled as if awakening from a long winter's nap.

IN general we may say that it is news when a celebrated author writes a bad book or an unknown author writes a good one. What to do about the hundreds of books that lie between is something that must frequently trouble a critic's -- or any other reader's -- dreams.
EL CENTRO, Calif., Feb. 27 (UPI) -- Thirty-three farm workers and union leaders indicted for criminal conspiracy and kidnapping were ordered today to enter pleas March 3.
THE author of "Rendezvous at Senlis," which opened last night at the Gramercy Arts Theatre, is the Jean Anouilh of the boulevards.
Governor Rockefeller's scholar incentive program was approved with reservations yesterday by the New York Chamber of Commerce, while delay on it was asked by the Citizens Union.
Market values on the New York Stock Exchange moved upward yesterday in a general advance that neglected only the oils.

EDGEWATER, BEACH, Md., Feb. 27 -- Wild ducks have been having a tough time around here in this brutal winter, but the quail and rabbits are showing what wildlife can do with the help of ingenuity and initiative. They are prospering.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, a leading processor and distributor of food and food products, has agreed to acquire Eagle Food Centers, Inc., which operates thirty-eight retail food stores in Iowa and Illinois.
Thirteen summonses were given out yesterday to builders whose equipment was taking up more space in the street than allowed by a new city ordinance.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The largest daily double of the Bowie meeting was registered today when Sabine Artist and Spry combined for a $1,154.40 pay-off.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The Dodger players were scattered over the field for warm-up exercises. They chirped away noisily as ballplayers will, simultaneously toning tonsils and muscles.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- The Chrysler Corporation asked the Wayne County Circuit Court here today to issue a temporary injunction barring further prosecution of a $5,250,000 damage suit filed against L. L. Colbert, president and chairman, by William C. Newberg, former president.

On the basis of construction in 1960, Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday that contracts for city construction costing more than $100,000,000 would be awarded this year. This would be a record in the city's history.
Four officers of the Fire Department were charged with neglect of duty yesterday in an outgrowth of a Broadway loft fire last November in which three firemen died.

Garnet (Sugar) Hart, a top welterweight contender two years ago, fought in the middleweight division last night against Ted Wright of Detroit at the St. Nicholas Arena. At the finish, he probably wished he had stayed in the lighter class.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Government started a direct and high-powered effort today to bring down mortgage interest rates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- President Kennedy has asked Federal agencies to seek ways of helping the depressed domestic copper mining industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended Tuesday, Feb. 21 to 119.9 (1947-49 equals 100), the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27 -- Brazil has requested United States authorities to prevent the landing in New York shipments of smuggled coffee new en route from Brazilian ports.
A study by the National Industrial Conference Board shows that more of the consumer's spending power will go for durables and services, and less for food and clothing in the years ahead.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The Labor party argued in Parliament today that the British Government's efforts to maintain an independent nuclear deterrent force were senseless in view of the "colossal striking power" of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The State Department said in strong terms tonight that published reports of a policy paper sent by Secreary of State Dean Rusk to the Pentagon were the "grossest distortions of the Department's views."
The New York Central Railroad, which in all of 1960 cleared only $1,038,000, had a net loss of $5,276,918 last month.
The first steps in a drive against prior censorship by the motion picture, television, radio and book industries were announced here yesterday.

The terms for a three-year agreement covering 90,000 dress workers in nine states were reached Sunday night, a union spokesman announced yesterday. The new pact, if ratified by employers, would avert a strike threatened for tomorrow morning.

THEATRE of devastating intensity and utter brilliance is on display this week in the production of Jean-Paul Sartre's drama, "No Exit" on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13. This is a work no theatregoer will wish to miss, a shattering stopover in hell.

The Department of Sanitation, which has orange snowplows, white sweeping machines and a gray-and-blue decor for the rest of its equipment, will test a new color scheme for its refuse trucks and flushers -- "a soft golden yellow."

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27 -- The study-discussion group has proved itself effective in advancing the liberal education of adults, according to three independent studies published today by the Fund for Adult Education.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Republican legislators are expecting the State Rent Commissioner to recommend a new policy for lifting controls from luxury apartments in New York City this week.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 27 -- President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province announced today that he would resume "full liberty of action" immediately because the United Nations had not halted the drive across the Congo by the troops of Antoine Gizenga of Eastern Province.
The Federal Aviation Agency is planning to conduct a series of pilot regional conferences to get the fliers' suggestions on solving common air safety problems.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight champion, and Ingemar Johansson, the challenger, were reluctant today to pursue an argument over the nationality of the referee for their March 13 rematch here.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- British and French officials began to explore in talks today ways of associating Britain with the six-nation European Economic Community or Common Market.
Rent-controlled housing pays a higher return than any comparable investment, the Metropolitan Council on Housing said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Soviet and British delegates attending a private conference on questions of peaceful coexistence agreed today that such coexistence should be based on an expansion of economic and cultural contacts between all countries, regardless of their social systems.

The United States Chamber of Commerce's letter in The Times of Feb. 16 claimed that an increase in the minimum wage, as endorsed in The Times' Feb. 9 editorial, would adversely affect employment and our international competitive position.
A Harvard historian said last night that the States of Israel had no right to try Adolf Eichmann, the former Nazi officer accused in the wartime murder of 6,000,000 Jews.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27 -- A revision of the Westchester County Charter to abolish the last of the strong commissions and centralize greater powers in the County Executive was endorsed, 38 to 6, today by the Board of Supervisors.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 27 -- The military strong man of Laos' Right-Wing Government declared today that he hoped to meet soon with Prince Norodom Sihanouk to solicit neutralist Cambodia's aid in solving the problems of strife-torn Laos.
Mayor Wagner has agreed to serve as chairman of the evening arranged as a tribute to Robert W. Dowling on April 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal judge must give a convicted defendant a chance to speak on his behalf before imposing sentence.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- Cuba has accused the Kennedy Administration of planning a military attack on Cuba prior to the Inter-American Conference scheduled to be held in Quito next May.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- The direction of Moroccan foreign policy under the new King, Hassan II, depends on his ability to persuade the Left-wing Opposition to participate in the Government, the best-informed observers believe.
The Interstate Staff Committee on the New Haven Railroad met all day yesterday to work out details of legislation granting $6,200,000 in tax concessions to the commuting line.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The House Agriculture Committee approved a modification of the Administration's feed-grains bill today by a 25-8 nonpartisan vote.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27 -- Brazil's needs for financial and economic assistance from the United States were discussed for three hours here today by Adolf A Berle Jr., coordinator of Latin American policies for President Kennedy, and a group of leading Brazilian officials.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Dr. F.J.L. Blasingame, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said today that the problem of medical care for the aged could be met "if politics can be abandoned in the interest of humanity."

More than half the country's banks and branches have begun to prepare their checks for handling by electronic check-sorting equipment, according to a survey by the twelve Federal Reserve Banks. One check in five already bears the magnetic ink characters that will tell the high-speed equipment how to sort the check to the bank on which it is drawn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Kennedy Administration told Congress today that it was adopting, for the time being, the budget drafted by the Eisenhower Administration for the space agency.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Frank Stanley Jr., a Negro leader, said today that he expected to see complete integration of downtown Louisville stores within a month. The statement came after day-long conference among integration leaders, city officials and business men.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 27 -- The police used tear gas and long staves today to break up a rowdy procession of more than 5,000 college students who tried to march on the Indian High Commission chancery to protest the killing of Moslems in recent riots in India.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- United Fruit Company today reported earnings of $2,171,094 or 25 cents a share in its statement for 1960, closely paralleling its earlier profit estimate.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 27 -- Mass demonstrations of grief took place in Rabat today following the death yesterday of King Mohammed V.
The election of William P. Corcoran as executive vice president and a director was announced yesterday by Compass Agencies, Inc. He is one of the principal stockholders in the company.
" ACAPULCO" is the title of a weekly television series that began last night over Channel 4.

An argument can be made, in the wake of the Government's antitrust cases against several electrical manufacturing companies resulting in jail terms for seven company officials, that references to "free enterprise" and "free competitive economy" were tossed about with almost embarrassing profusion.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Max Conrad took off today in a twin-engine Piper Aztec that he hoped would carry him around the world in record time.

Never have I been more dismayed than to read in an article by Brooks Atkinson (issue Feb. 17) that lands belonging to the Senecas, in Pennsylvania, by a treaty for which the Indians gave certain concessions, and signed by George Washington himself, were being considered as one of two possible locations for a dam.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27 -- Two tracts of land in the Town of North Hempstead will be acquired by Nassau County for parks, County Executive A. Holly Patterson announced here today.
United States bicycles manufacturers are not impressed by President Kennedy's tariff action on Saturday on imported bicycles. It will not raise prices or reduce imports, they contend.
The General Dynamics Corporation announced the resignation yesterday of John V. Naish, senior vice president of the company and president of its Convair division.
NEWARK, Feb. 27 -- Representatives of the state Department of Labor and Industry and officials of labor groups appealed today for Federal help in resolving the unemployment problem in New Jersey.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Union announced tonight plans to strengthen the economy of collective farms.

" A career as a personal shopper gives one friends the world over," according to a member of the Personal Shopping Service at Lord Taylor. Over the years each woman on the staff has built up an extensive circle of friends who depend on her good judgment for the selection of clothes.
The State Investigation Commission charged yesterday that there had been no real improvement in the Buffalo Police Department since last August.

E.J. Korvette, Inc., has purchased an 18 per cent interest in Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., and an affiliated retail company, Retail Realty, Inc. The purchase was made from Jack and Arthur Schwadron, sons of Louis Schwadron, a co-founder of Alexander's.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., Feb. 27 -- "It sounded like lions roaring, but who ever heard of lions roaring at midnight around here?" asked Frank De Jaeger.
The special school taxing district of Hillsborough County, Fla., announced yesterday that a $6,000,000 issue of bonds would be offered at competitive sealed bidding on March 28.

The Valley National Bank of Long Island, Valley Stream, did not deny cumulative voting rights to a group of minority, shareholders at the annual meeting last month, Judge William R. Brennan has ruled in Supreme Court, Nassau County.
THE part-time cattle rancher who resigned yesterday as chairman of the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council is no stranger to government.
ACCORDING to a sardonic legend, French is such a precise language that all Frenchmen understand one another perfectly.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- President de Gaulle of France and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia announced tonight their agreement that there exist "possibilities and hopes" for a "positive and rapid evolution" in the six-year-old war of rebellion in Algeria.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The labor federation called on Governor Rockefeller today to oppose bills broadening the powers of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- New York State's right to use wiretap evidence, even though it is obtained in a manner contrary to Federal law, was upheld today by the Supreme Court.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The prospect of fresh labor trouble on major airlines developed today as the labor federation rejected the plea of a union of 7,000 stewards and stewardesses for a charter separate from that of the pilots.
The Board of Estimate decided yesterday that it needed more time to decide whether it really had been serious when it asked twice before for Federal money to survey a possible slum-clearance site.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation is negotiating with a major chemical company to establish a joint venture to produce chemicals from waste products. The forest products company announced last March that it had begun pilot plant production of cyanide chemicals from bark, sawdust and other waste materials.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 (AP) -- New Yorkers who tangled with a damaging ice storm and floods over the weekend worked back toward normalcy tonight as utility crews gradually restored electric power and telephone service and swollen streams receded.
Sales of life insurance by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Newark, N.J., fell about 1.7 pet cent last year below the 1959 level, Louis R. Menagh, president, announced yesterday.
BATON ROUGE, Feb. 27 Louisiana, in a compromise move, turned over $2,000,000 today to help pay all New Orleans school teachers, including those at two integrated schools.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- The question of how to implement the Security Council's resolution on the Congo may go back to the Council in a few days.
Steel production held last week at its best level in eight months, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Shortly after the racing committee of the Federation Internatinale de l'Automobile cut engine sizes in grand-prix machines by 40 per cent for the 1961 season, a new racing category was sanctioned called the Intercontinental Formula.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Feb. 27 -- The Parents Councils of the upper and lower schools of the Friends Academy here are sponsoring the third annual benefit for the school's development fund. Proceeds will be used to supplement faculty salaries.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Britain today made the first major move in two years toward settling the trade dispute that threatens to divide Europe into two irreconcilable blocs.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Assembly gave final approval tonight to a bill extending the Sickness Disability Benefits Law to about 300,000 additional wage earners.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller conceded today that school districts in the suburban counties were "in tough shape," but he offered them no hope of additional aid this year.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 -- The Massachusetts State Senate advanced today a project to construct an office building on stilts in Harvard Square.
A hemispheric center has been proposed for the University of Puerto Rico to help guide Latin American revolutions into peaceful and constructive channels.
BOCK is back. In the brewer's world that lusty drink, traditionally mahogany-hued, is more of a harbinger of sprint than all the robins and crocus put together.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa's lawyers, in trying to establish a legal basis on which to regain for him the full control of the Teamsters Union, turned today to a law that the union opposes.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- The Soviet Union foreshadowed today a major effort in the forthcoming session of the United Nations General Assembly to reorganize the United Nations Secretariat.
CHICAGO, Feb 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
HABITS die hard in bridge, as indicated by this deal from the Greater New York Championships, a sectional tournament played here last week.
The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's battle for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad so far has cost it about $29,600,000 in cash.

Recent weeks have been marked by a disturbing flow of news relating to the "American Nazi party." This racist organization received scant news space from the time of its first abortive attempt to hold a public meeting in New York City until the street demonstration held in front of a Boston theatre on the occasion of a motion-picture premiere.
THE Gramercy Chamber Ensemble gave one of its attractive Carnegie Recital Hall programs last night.

I have read with great appreciation your judicious editorials on the Presidential appointments. Yet there is one curious and disturbing feature of the appointments hitherto announced to which you have not called attention. I refer to the almost wholly male character of the present Administration.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27 -- A proposal for a bipartisan charter commission to consider revision of the Nassau County. Charter was rejected by the Republican-controlled Board of Supervisors today.
The St. Louis Hawks and the Boston Celtics, the top teams in the National Basketball Association, will make their last appearances of the season in a double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Ever the person for the befitting gesture, Joseph Papp, the spirited purveyor of free Shakespeare, said yesterday that he would open the new $400,000 amphitheatre in Central Park with three classics that never have been seen there.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Five trustees of Princeton Hospital were elected tonight, but the ballots in one case were so close that the result may be changed by a recount.
There is nothing wrong with the desperate basketball situation at Tennessee A. and I. State University that a nice, juicy losing streak wouldn't cure.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb 27 -- Clothing and uniform allowances for the Suffolk Police Department, the purchase of a hydraulic dredge and two major dredging projects were approved today by the county Board of Supervisors.

The New York Rangers, in desperate straits, yesterday sought to bolster their defense by calling up a highly regarded backliner from the first-place Guelph Royals of the Ontario Hockey Association Junior A league.
The Kennedy Administration was urged yesterday to pursue negotiations with the Soviet Union toward a prohibition of nuclear tests with "determination and utmost vigor."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 -- Yale scored a 3-0 triumph over Brown in an Ivy League hockey game tonight.
Hofstra's basketball team drew away in the last quarter and defeated Queens College, 84 -- 60, last night at the latter's Fitzgerald Gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A bitterly divided Supreme Court upheld in broad terms today the investigating power of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
Eight persons were injured in the crash of two taxicabs during the evening rush hour yesterday on crowded Lexington Avenue beside Grand Central Terminal. The injuries reportedly were not serious.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- Federal Aviation Agency officials said today they were considering extending positive radar control to congested holding-pattern areas near the nation's busy airports.
" Jackpot Bowling," which features Milton Berle as host, will have its last telecast March 13.

If a new City Charter is to be put on the ballot Nov. 7 for referendum of New York voters there is no time to spare. The Moore commission brought in its proposed revision report on Jan. 16. On Feb. 2 Mayor Wagner wrote Governor Rockefeller asking help toward legislation creating a City Charter Commission to review the work already done and to write its own document.
The Gothams, this city's team in the new National Bowling League, have about a 50-50 chance to survive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota said today that his disputed account of a visit with Dwight D. Eisenhower had nnot used exact quotations. Instead, Mr. Mundt said, it recorded the former President's attitudes "as I sensed them."

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Wabash Railroad will sell its wholly owned subsidiary, the Ann Arbor Railroad Company, to the Detroit, Toledo and Ironton Railroad Company, for $3,000,000, it was announced today.

Three state agencies said yesterday that New York City's Commission on Intergroup Relations had never referred to them charges that Negro wholesale liquor salesmen were discriminated against by retailers.

BOISE, IDAHO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Morrison-Knudsen Company said that it would be one of the major contractors on one of the longest clear-span bridges in Europe. This bridge will have a central suspension of 3,318 feet and side spans of 1,540 feet each.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- The proposal to build a $220,000,000 jet airport in the farmland south of this Orange County community won solid backing tonight from the municipal councils of the county's two largest cities, Newburg and Middletown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The White House sent detailed legislation to Capitol Hill today to carry out a portion of President Kennedy's education program -- a $2,300,000,000, three-year aid plan for primary and secondary schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Amid indications of quickening progress in Congress, the Senate Democratic leadership announced plans today for Senate action on one major Administration bill a week through the normally inactive spring.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An emergency meeting of leaders of the Mapai party emphatically rejected tonight David Ben-Gurion's appeal to make Finance Minister Levi Eshkol Premier to avoid new elections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today that it would put into effect April 6 a new three-layer airways system to make airline flying simpler and safer.

WASHINGTON Feb. 27 (UPI) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner has ruled that Union Carbide Corporation, of New York, violated federal anti-trust laws when it acquired a major customer, Visking Corporation, of Chicago, in 1956.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Britain and Iceland announced tonight they had agreed on terms to end their "little war" over Iceland's limits for fishing off her coast.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 27 -- The movements and forces stirring Central Africa seem to have concentrated in this friendly, vigorous town, where Africans and Europeans both agree that the only things that are clear are the problems.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 27 (Reuters) -- Tom Mboya, one of colonial Africa's top nationalist leaders, won an overwhelming victory tonight as vote-counting started after Kenya's eight-day election.

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- A gun fight between a captain of the Cuban revolutionary army and a 21-year-old-youth today may have frustrated an attempt to assassinate Maj. Ernesto Guevara.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today he would not seek reelection in 1962. The Pennsylvania Democrat is serving his fifteenth two-year term.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that its net sales last year were 1.8 per cent lower than in 1959 and that earnings declined 7.8 per cent.

Eighty-eight per cent of enrolled Democratic voters would not support Mayor Wagner for re-election, according to a poll taken in mid-January by the Democratic leadership for all five boroughs. The city-wide sampling, taken in a postcard survey, showed only 12 per cent of party voters checking "Yes" when asked the question:
MOLINE, Ill., Feb. 27 (UPI) -- First quarter sales of Deere Co. have set a record of $106,239,503, the company reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- There was a big flap in Washington today over reports that the Kennedy Administration was changing its military strategy.

A confidential report by the counsel for the League of New York Theatres states that a number of provisions in the league's contracts with every major theatrical union are illegal under the National Labor Relations Act.

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 736 persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week. This was a decline of 122 from a year ago. The bureau reported a total of 1,367 accidents last week.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 28 -- American labor mapped plans today to spend almost $4,500,000 in the ext three years to help build democratic unions abroad, particularly in the newly liberated nations of Africa.

The election of Peter S. Paine as senior vice president of the Great Northern Paper Company and the appointment of Augustus G. Paine, his nephew, to succeed him as president of the New York Pennsylvania Company, Inc., was reported yesterday.

Net earnings of Bridgeport Brass Company for 1960 plummeted to $2,968,127, or $1.65 a share, from $7,131,643, or $4.40 a share, a year earlier, the company announced yesterday. Sales dipped to $142,162,344 from $173,050,019.

CROSS HILL, S.C., Feb. 28 -- Most of the hunting preserve operators in the Southeast have enough birds left to last through the preserve season, which ends March 31. It was not thus last year, when nearly everybody was running short by March 1.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Penn State, striving to finish the basketball season with a .500 record, tonight upset Temple, 63 -- 56. The Nittany Lions, with a 10-12 record and two games to go, were behind most of the first half but took the lead near the end of the period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Surgeon General Luther L. Terry called today for "intensive efforts" by state and local health authorities to get as many people as possible immunized with Salk poliomyelitis vaccine before this summer's polio season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States Consumer Price Index declined slightly last month for the first time since January, 1960, the Labor Department reported today.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Feb. 28 -- The Long Island Rail Road started its quickie breakfast-service car on its maiden trip here at 5:39 A.M. today.
