Kings Point won the first Athletic Association of Long Island Colleges swimming championship yesterday by defeating Adelphi and Queens in Fitzgerald Pool on the Queens campus.

The Supreme Court, dividing 5 to 4, has once again upheld the power of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to make witnesses say whether they are members of the Communist party. The Watkins case of 1957, which implied that Congressional investigations were subject to severe constitutional limits, is a fading landmark.
POTSDAM, Feb. 28 -- The Clarkson Tech hockey team upset St. Lawrence tonight, 6 -- 2, before a crowd of 2,000 and snapped a ten-game Larrie winning streak.

In a major move to strengthen European unity and heal the rift between the two European economic blocs Britain has now advanced a plan officially characterized as a "fundamental change" in its previous position that could transform the whole European scene with far-reaching effect on the whole free world. The details and full implications of the plan must still be explored in further discussions.
American Machine and Foundry Company offered yesterday to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for $39,911,100 of 4 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1981.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller's record budget of $2,388,000,000 for 1961-62 has been scheduled for some minor surgery at the hands of Republican legislative leaders.

Rexall Drug and Chemical C0mpany has placed directly with major insurance companies $35,000,000 in notes due in 1982. The proceeds are to help pay for its share in a joint petrochemical venture with El Paso Natural Gas Products Company, Justin Dart, Rexall president, announced yesterday.

THE deal shown has been widely discussed because it was played on the television bridge show "Championship Bridge," which appears on the American Broadcasting Company network and on some other stations.
PARIS, Feb. 28 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today to increase West Germany's share and reduce the United states' share of certain costs of the alliance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Tax exemption of the interest on state and local government bonds is unduly costly to the Federal Government and unduly beneficial to the wealthy, a prominent group of business men said today.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 28 -- King Mohammed V was buried among his ancestors today, and his son, King Hassan II, was saluted by twenty-one guns as temporal and spiritual ruler of Morocco.
Western Airlines has suspended all flights while it trains new personnel as flight engineers, a spokesman for the Los Angeles-based carrier said yesterday.

The State Commission Against Discrimination was barred by the state Supreme Court yesterday from investigating charges of discrimination in institutions under the jurisdiction of the Board of Higher Education.
FISHGUARD, Wales, Feb. 25 -- March 1 is St. David's Day, when all good Welshmen are especially Welsh. This year Waldo Williams, poet laureate of Pembrokeshire, will again spend it in jail.
Fortune and Anthony Pope pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to five counts of violating the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices rose 1 per cent between mid-January and mid-February.

Bonds called for redemption in February before maturity dropped to the lowest level in three months, despite a sharp increase in retirement of public utility bonds. The total of $29,971,000 compared with $36,865,000 in January and $18,427,000 in February, 1960.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy reported today that crime in the United States reached a record in 1960, with a 12 per cent increase over the year before.
The Greater New York Maritime Port Council, A.F.L.-C.I.O., yesterday announced its support of bills in the Legislature that would curb the powers of the Waterfront Commission.
Large New York syndicates with expert knowledge of real estate and its investment possibilities are bringing about a boom in the market for hotels in many cities.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Vic Stasiuk slapped in two goal-mouth shots early in the first period and the Detroit Red Wings went on to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 1, in a National Hockey League contest before 10,002 fans at Olympia tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A group of United States scientists called on the Kennedy Administration today to announce that the United States will not be the first to use nuclear weapons "under any circumstances."

The chronically ailing Eastern railroads were unusually hard put during January of this year, when their metropolitan New York area operations were disrupted for thirteen days by a strike of New York harbor tugboat employes and by reason of the heavy snow and freezing weather that prevailed.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa accused Mayor Wagner yesterday of using revision of the City Charter "as a crutch to limp out of a political dilemma into which he has gotten all by himself."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- James R. Hoffa won today his three-year battle with the board of monitors assigned to clean up the Teamsters Union.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The Chrysler Corporation asked the Wayne County Circuit Court here today to require its former president, William C. Newberg, and his wife to post a surety bond guaranteeing ultimate payment of at least $225,000 allegedly due the auto concern.

For want of an unobstructed view of the hoop, the New York Knickerbockers lost their fifth straight game last night. Their conquerors at Madison Square Garden were the Boston Celtics. The score was 142 -- 116.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The roof was not put in place atop the clubhouse until only three days before the advance guard of the new Washington Senators reported last week. Hence, carpenters and electricians are still mingling with the athletes. There is a shining, eager newness to the entire operation. Everything is new except the ballplayers. For the most part, they are a trifle on the old side.
RABAT, Feb. 28 -- Moroccan political stability in the immediate future seemed assured today following the swearing of allegiance to the new King.
Three men were convicted in Federal Court here yesterday in a plot to defraud the Bank of America International of $20,000,000.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- The Soviet Union announced tonight that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would head its delegation to the session of the United Nations General Assembly opening March 7.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that considerations of health and family would weigh heavily in his decision on whether to run for a third term. He said his decision would be made "well before June."

LAST month John Dos Passos Celebrated his sixty-fifth birthday. This week his thirtieth book is published. Even without a name on the title page of "Midcentury: A Contemporary Chronicle"* any conscientious reader of modern American literature would have no difficulty guessing its author.

During November, 1960, an international commission of five lawyers made a personal, on-the-spot investigation of civil liberties, due process and the situation of the political prisoners in Spain. The investigation made a story meriting front-page treatment in a number of important newspapers throughout Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Congressional committee was told today that President Eisenhower had ordered the Government's Panama Steamship Line stripped of commercial business, although Pentagon officials had said the line's operation was necessary for proper maintenance of the Panama Canal.
The Soviet position on disarmament is "as rationally respectable as the American position," according to Walter Millis, American military historian and journalist.

Increasingly strident appeals by so-called black nationalist, Muslim and pro-African organizations are being made to the city's Negroes. Some of the appeals are made in terms that would actually promote the segregation of black men and white.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The House of Representatives approved with little opposition today $3,853,000 for fifteen of its committees.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Marine Midland Corporation of Buffalo, a bank holding company, announced today it would acquire the First National Bank of Olean.
John Jaiser, a substitute, scored 14 points in the second half -- including the winning basket -- to lead St. Francis to a 64-61 victory over City College last night in the loser's Wingate gymnasium.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire of Lake Park, Fla., playing in her first tournament since a recent illness, won the medal today in the qualifying round of the Florida East Coast women's amateur golf tournament.

A national phenomenon named Bobby Darin has breezed into the Copacabana and it is now New York's turn to figure out what it is that makes him the hottest young singer in the night clubs today. Fresh from a session at Las Vegas, he will be on display here twice nightly until March 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Teamsters Union has quietly adopted a strict "no strike" policy for its members working at defense sites, including the "top priority" intercontinental ballistics missile bases.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Ella Fitzgerald took over the Olympia Music Hall tonight on Edith Piaf's night off. Although the American did not make Parisians forget their beloved "Sparrow Kid," she brought down the house in her own right.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Kennedy will meet with Kwame Nkrumah. President of Ghana, next week and discuss the Congo situation, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today business should look brighter this spring. He implied it would be brighter still except "we don't do a half job of selling."
The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a Police Department regulation that requires cabaret employes and entertainers to obtain work permits.

THE new Chief Inspector of the Police Department, Francis James Moore Robb, tries not to take his police problems home with him. On the job he is a tough-minded, hard-driving policeman, but when he goes home to his family in Queens, he cultivates tea roses.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 28 -- Harvard won its sixth Ivy Hockey League title in eight years tonight by scoring six goals in the second period and beating Princeton, 9 -- 2.

Almost all the leading 2-year-olds of 1960 and the budding stars of winter racing on both coasts were included yesterday among the 124 nominations announced for the ninety-third running of the Belmont Stakes on June 3.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -- Former Vice President and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon returned home to southern California tonight to a roaring welcome from old friends and Republican party workers.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The world record of 149,601-miles-an-hour average for a continuous 500-mile automobile race, which was set at Daytona International Speedway last Sunday, may stand for years.

The men's shoe industry has been quietly acquiring a "new look" -- not so much in the retail shops as back on the production line. Several new manufacturing techniques recently have been adopted. They add up to a change in

Stocks advanced for the fourth consecutive month in February in the heaviest monthly trading since October, 1958. Last month's volume also was the heaviest for any February in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.
One of the unusual features of the 1961 edition of the annual April in Paris Ball will be its date -- Oct. 20.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- A revised version of the once controversial "Prudent Man" bill passed the Assembly today without debate.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 28 -- Adolf Eichmann is spending the last six weeks before his trial reading literature on the Nazi mass murder of European Jews.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he favored strengthening the conventional defense forces of the non-Communist world while maintaining its nuclear power.

ROSINA LHEVINNE, who is less than a month short of her eighty-first birthday, quite literally took over Hunter College and the National Orchestral Association last night. She played Chopin's E minor Concerto, she made lovely music, she brought tears to the eyes of some of her listeners, she held court after the concert, and then she probably went home to play bridge.
Crosby Smith of the Williams club, the top-seeded player, led the way into the third round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C singles championship yesterday.
YOUNG stargazers may scan the winter sky through high-powered telescopes on Sunday evening at Jones Beach, Field No. 1, a mile west of the tower.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Premier Saeb Salaam said today that a crisis in Lebanon's relations with the United Arab Republic had ended.
While the nation's economy attained new records in production and sales last year, most corporations enjoyed little or no improvement in earnings from 1959 levels, the
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The Labor party called today for the "gradual and phased" withdrawal from abroad of British forces that are not required to fulfill Britain's treaty obligations.
The first settlement in a string of stockholder suits against certain management practices in the mutual fund field may be approved today in State Supreme Court.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt the insurance company's proposed variable annuities from the provisions of the Investment Company Act of 1940, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller quietly warned representatives of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today that direct opposition to his housing discrimination bill could he dangerous to their civil rights cause.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 -- The Government reported today that Argentina had a favorable balance of payments in her foreign transactions of $289,000,000 last year.
The investigation of a $200,000 consultant's contract awarded by the state Thruway Authority to its former chairman, Bertram D. Tallamy, got under way behind closed doors here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Interior Department will enter an election suit in New Mexico in behalf of the Navajo Indians.
President Kennedy's news conference at 10 A.M., Eastern standard time, today will be seen and heard, on tape, over all television and radio networks and many stations at various times during the day.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 28 -- A United Nations spokesman said today that five Communist newspaper men -- a Russian, a Pole and three Czechs -- left Stanleyville hurriedly this morning after they had been expelled by Congolese authorities.

The burial of Morocco's beloved and respected King Mohammed yesterday ended a chapter of history and inevitably opened a new chapter. All authorities are agreed that the future is uncertain and that King Hassan II is facing grave difficulties.
ALGIERS, Feb. 28 -- Two European women were burned to death and at least five persons were wounded today in a flare-up of violence between Moslems and Europeans in the West Algerian city of Oran.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan became involved in a shouting dispute today with a New York business man whom he accused of withholding records from the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- Edward N. Cole, general manager of Chevrolet and a vice president of the General Motors Corporation, reported today that automobile sales had begun to show encouraging improvement.

Leading sales finance companies announced increases yesterday of 1/8 to 1/2 percentage points in interest rates on most maturities of commercial paper they sell directly to investors. Rates on these unsecured short-term obligations were raised 1/8 point on most maturities last week.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Flood victims lined up for Federal disaster relief in some of the South's hardest-hit cities today, while down-stream towns were waiting for the full force of the surging rivers to reach them.
Allegheny Power System, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that operating revenues and net income rose in the twelve months ended on Jan. 31.
Stanley M. Isaacs, Minority Leader of the City Council, demanded yesterday the "fullest investigation" of the "shocking" $26,000,000 cost of this winter's snow removal in the city.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Nikifor T. Kalchenko, chairman of the Ukrainian Council of Ministers, was discharged today as Premier Khrushchev pressed his purge of officials charged with responsibility for recent agricultural failures.

The Transnation Realty Corporation, Henry Goelet, president, has bought the eighteen-story office and showroom building at 260 West Thirty-ninth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. The seller was 260 West 39th Street, Inc.

MAX ERNST will be 70 years old at 9:45 A.M. on April 2, just midway between today's opening of his retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art and the closing on May 7. The artist has supplied the ingredients of a very nice birthday present and the museum has wrapped it up attractively for him.
Yale's undefeated 1960 football team, the Ivy League and Big Three champion, was honored by 600 Old Blues in the ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Kennedy has decided to name G. Frederick Reinhardt as Ambassador to Italy instead of continuing him in his present assignment to the United Arab Republic, as planned earlier.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Habib Bourguiba Jr., Tunisian Ambassador-designate to the United States, said the Kennedy Administration in Washington must choose between making its own policy in Africa and allowing its policy to be "screened" in Paris or elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's special message to Congress today on highways:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Vice President Johnson will have an office suite in the old State Department building, just across narrow West Executive Avenue from the White House office of President Kennedy.
BONN Germany, Feb. 28 -- Two leading West German Social Democrats said today that anti-German sentiments were increasing in the United States.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 28 -- The Constitutional Court at Karlsruhe ruled against the Federal Government today in a verdict that appeared to end Chancellor Adenauer's long fight o set up a Government-operated television network.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to levy higher taxes on the trucking industry to complete, by 1972, the $37,000,000,000 interstate super-highway system.
The Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., plans to acquire the Worcester Paper Box Corporation, Medford, Mass., through an exchange of stock.

Theodore Mann, Jose Quintero's partner in the celebrated Circle in the Square producing group, is going ahead with an entry in which Mr. Quintero will not participate. There is no rift, Mr. Mann explained yesterday, adding that his partnership arrangement permits him to operate independently whenever the occasion arises.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 28 -- G. Mennen Williams, the United States' Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, met today with Joseph Kasavubu, President of the Congo. According to persons who were present. Mr. Kasavubu said he would always be willing to cooperate with the United Nations, provided that officials of the world organization consulted and worked with the Congolese Central Government.
Six persons, including five pedestrians, were injured in an automobile accident yesterday at Park Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- An Army committee of generals recommended today that summary and special courts-martial be eliminated from the uniform code of military justice.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of the Assembly indicated today there was little possibility of adopting a compromise solution to the recurrent controversy over a residency requirement for relief recipients.

ALAN GRISHMAN, violinist, and Joel Ryce, pianist, who made their local debut as a duo last Feb. 29, were just as impressive in their recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. They played with a youthful zest and sensitivity that made their performances exhilarating even when they were not note-perfect or when choices of tempo and style were not wholly persuasive.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold served notice today that the United Nations would acquire the military strength to halt the strife in the Congo.
MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- The Black Helen Handicap will be the main attraction at Hialeah tomorrow as the forty-day meeting nears its conclusion. The meet ends Friday.
The outlook couldn't be more dismal, but the New York Rangers refuse to be counted out in their bid for a Stanley Cup play-off berth.
AGE evidently cannot wither nor custom stale the affection and energy the players of the Comedie Francaise reserve for their founding father, Moliere.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 28 -- Control of Trans World Airlines, Inc., passed today from the hands of Howard Hughes and the Hughes Tool Company to bankers and insurance companies financing the airline's new jet program.

Trading in potato futures on New York Mercantile Exchange aggregated 4,108 carlots of 50,000 pounds each yesterday. This was the highest level since the record volume of 5,184 carlots on March 23, 1960. Prices rose by 4 to 17 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
NEWARK, Feb. 28 -- Property taxes levied by local governments have risen 126 per cent in New Jersey in the last ten years, while the state's population increased 25 per cent.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 28 -- A military-political pact to resolve Congolese problems without "outside" interference was signed today by President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province, President Albert Kalonji of South Kasai and Premier Joseph Ileo of the Congo's Central Government.
Three Eskimos and four Alaskan Indians began an eighteen-month study course yesterday to fit them for civilian and military radio jobs near the Arctic Circle.

Randolph Phillips, a director of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., has brought suit in Federal District Court here to enjoin the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., from conducting a proxy contest for control of the Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company that controls I.D.S.
Many of the 400,000 employes in the downtown financial district will have their working hours changed at the beginning of next year if a new study finds that staggered hours are worth a tryout.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Selective buying of industrials was the highlight of the stock market here today. Most of the blue chips added about a shilling (14 cents) and Imperial Chemical Industries rose 1s 9d (24 1/2 cents).
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- A bill mandating grievance machinery for all non-Federal public employes in the state was filed today with the endorsement of Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney.

Even seen from Europe, the United States balance-of-payments situation, and consequently the monetary policies of the new Administration, are matters of great concern. It has finally been realized that a devaluation of the dollar -- or a "revaluation of gold," as, euphemistically, it is often called -- would do no one any good, since it would inevitably trigger a chain reaction that would force other Western nations to follow suit.

Assistant Chief Inspector Francis J.M. Robb, who was in charge of city policemen guarding the heads of state during their visit to the United Nations last fall, was appointed Chief Inspector yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Democratic lawmakers accused Republicans today of stalling the modernization of State Senate and Assembly districts.
ROME, Feb. 24 -- Italian authorities today started polling music experts on whether the scores of Giuseppe Verdi's and Giacomo Puccini's operas, as available at present, are "unfaithful."

ELIZABETH TAYLOR, the English novelist, not the movie star, will irritate a certain segment of her readers with a statement she makes in her recent book, "In A Summer Place." Miss Taylor mentions pineapple upside-down cake, which she labels as "a deplorable concoction."

Prosperous Switzerland has long been a haven for foreign money, and this is especially true nowadays. In fact, the Swiss banks have been so loaded with funds that starting last August they stopped paying interest on new foreign deposits.
PARIS, Feb. 28 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia indicated today that he believed that the question of peace or continued war in Algeria rested now with the Algerian rebel leadership.
Former General Sessions Judge Samuel R. Pierce Jr. will join the law firm of Battle, Fowler, Stokes Kheel today as a partner.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced a new development in its gas turbine program today that it said would provide the rapid acceleration and engine braking characteristics long sought in the turbine field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Kennedy today nominated Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to be one of five members of the United States delegation to the fifteenth session of the United Nations General Assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain established a National Basketball Association individual season scoring mark tonight in a 123-108 victory by the Philadelphia Warriors over the Los Angeles Lakers.
The forty-ninth annual appeal for the Neediest Cases closed yesterday as contributions reached a record high -- $572,816. The total of contributors also set a record, numbering 14,470.

The Government moved in Federal Courts here and in Miami yesterday to freeze Ingemar Johansson's purse for his third title fight with the heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, at Miami Beach on March 13.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Ralph Terry is a hurler with a peculiar problem. The Yankee right-hander has too many pitches for his own good.

The volume of new securities offered publicly here in February declined for the second successive month from the levels of a year earlier. Bond flotations dropped to the smallest amount for the month since 1955 and stock offerings to the lowest figure for a February since 1957.

Two collections of Mark Twain's writings will be published this month. Coward-McCann will issue tomorrow "The Travels of Mark Twain," edited with an introduction by Charles Neider. The volume contains material from five books: "The Innocents Abroad," "Roughing It," "Life on the Mississippi," "A Tramp Abroad" and "Following the Equator."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 -- The Yugoslav Government submitted to the National Assembly today a number of economic measures designed to widen the powers of the workers' councils to distribute the earnings of their enterprises.
Prices of United States Government securities and high-grade corporate bonds drifted downward yesterday on moderate volume. Bond dealers played a bigger part in trading than investors.
The television industry took on some of the aspects of a bus airport yesterday as shows and sponsors announced estimated times of arrival and departure.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off on near July to 8 points up on other contracts yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The United States will open trade centers throughout the free world as part of an intensified drive for experts to help correct the country's unfavorable balance of payments, it was announced yesterday. The balance of payments is the difference between total receipts from foreigners and total payments to foreigners.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 28 -- Well-informed quarters here gave today the following summary of the situation following yesterday's meeting between President de Gaulle and President Bourguiba, who flew in from Paris this morning:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 28 -- Possibly the most complex problems faced by the Kennedy Administration are those concerned with the task of increasing the annual growth rate of our Gross National Product. The foreign position of the United States is related to the President's success in this endeavor.
City department heads would be prevented from "absolutely and unconditionally" forbidding their subordinates to accept second jobs under a bill introduced yesterday into the City Council.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 28 -- Atlantic County Prosecutor Augustine A. Repetto said today that the state's star witness in the Vincent J. Blaney murder case had admitted that he had escaped from the nearby Absecon jail and had not been kidnapped.

The search for the rape-slayer of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorius ended yesterday with the capture of a 59-year-old drifter on a New Jersey chicken farm. The police said the man, Fred Thompson, had admitted slaying the child here last Wednesday.
Studies of more than 500 young victims of rheumatic fever over the last seven years have destroyed two myths about the disease, it was reported here yesterday.
The Alabama Education Authority borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday on revenue obligations due serially from 1962 to 1981 and callable in 1966.
THE zeal and vigor of President Kennedy were captured vividly in a series of candid still photographic studies on Channel 4 last night.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced today the appointment of a five-man royal commission to investigate the ownership, production and sale of British newspapers and periodicals.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 28 -- The question of how the American republics can best deal with the Cuban situation is expected come under review in Brasilia tomorrow during a conference between President Janio Quadros and Adolf A. Berle Jr., chief coordinator of Latin-American policies for President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The House Rules Committee, newly responsive to the wishes of Speaker Sam Rayburn, cleared the way today for action tomorrow on the first major bill of the Eighty-seventh Congress.

Opposition to the proposed $1,200,000 Puerto Rican Cultural Center here was voiced yesterday in an open letter circulated to the press by nineteen Puerto Rican writers, teachers and professional men living here.
A West Side Democratic club that had been split over an investigation of some of its members hammered out an understanding that enabled it to proceed with its annual election of officers early today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) --The speedy rise in soybean futures prices undoubtedly has set a record, perhaps several, on the Board of Trade the past few days but statisticians have not yet compiled the statistics.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 28 -- The political crisis in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland moderated today.
The 38-year-old president of a general insurance brokerage business was accused yesterday of stealing $225,135 from twenty life insurance companies, twenty-one policyholders and three banks.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Japan is replacing the United States as the world's biggest exporter of transistors and Switzerland has suplanted it as Japan's best transistor customer, the Nikkan Kogyo Industrial Journal reported here today.
Sales and earnings of the Brunswick Corporation rose to new highs in 1960, marking the seventh successive year for which improved results have been shown.

VILLANOVA, Pa., March 1 (AP) -- Frank Reagan, a former college and professional football star, was dismissed today as the Villanova University athletic director. The baseball coach, Art Mahan, became his successor.
The stock market these days is putting on a remarkable and apparently baffling performance. The market's behavior resembles that of a man running furiously and getting hardly any place at all.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 1 -- Middlebury College's hockey team defeated Dartmouth tonight, 17 -- 3, as Phil Latreille set a National Collegiate scoring record.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 1 -- The former acting chairman of the Liberal party in Nassau County and four other party members were indicted by a special grand jury here today on charges of perjury and forgery in filing petitions for the party.
LONDON, March 1 -- Prices of most industrial shares weakened in the stock market here today, along with the oils.
NORWALK, Conn., March 1 -- The chief executives of eight Fairfield County communities agreed today to create a joint planning agency, subject to ratification by their legislative bodies.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 1 -- Prime Minister Keith J. Holyoake left New Zealand tonight on a round-the-world mission that will start with discussions in Washington Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Department of Justice today filed a civil anti-trust complaint in federal district court at Lexington, Ky., aimed at preventing merger of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Lexington with the Security Trust Company.
President Kennedy's policy on the Congo was endorsed enthusiastically yesterday by Henry Cabot Lodge, former Ambassador to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Kennedy said today that Africa should belong to the people who feel they are Africans. Backing up the controversial "Africa for the Africans" statement of G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, the President said with emphasis at his news conference: "I do not know who else Africa should be for." [Question 12, Page 12.]
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Kennedy announced at his news conference today that Chancellor Adenauer had accepted his invitation to visit Washington April 12 and 13.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 1 -- Troops were air-lifted today from Colombo to northern and eastern Ceylon to help maintain order in Tamil-speaking areas.

The investment advisory fee the Lazard Fund will pay to Lazard Freres Co. whenever assets of the fund top $100,000,000 will be reduced on a sliding scale as a direct result of yesterday's hearing in State Supreme Court.

A letter in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association led yesterday to a demand for a Congressional investigation of charges that the Salk Poliomyelitis vaccine is ineffective.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 2:
The National Republican Club will move on April 1 to the Dryden East, a hotel at 150 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 3,095,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported. At the week-end they were 221,098,000 barrels, compared with 218,003,000 a week earlier and 215,623,000 a year ago.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 1 (Reuters) -- G. Mennen Williams raised the question today whether the United States was doing all it should in Africa.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The State Department's chief of protocol questioned today the necessity of spending "staggering sums" entertaining at embassies throughout the world.

The critical financial plight of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was pointed up yesterday in the company's January income statement. The carrier's operating ratio soared to 111.09. This is the ratio between operating revenues and operating expenses.

Chamber Music '61 sponsored a program of contemporary works for violin, voice and piano last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Seven of the eight compositions were either brand new or new to this city and were by Americans.
Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader, started a nation-wide campaign yesterday for a comprehensive socialized medicine program financed the way Social Security is.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Manager Ralph Houk today produced another switch in the training routine of the Yankees. With the arrival of his infielders and outfielders -- as expected, Hector Lopez showed up -- he put be camp on an assembly-line basis.

New York retailers were burdened last month by heavy snows, icy roads and freezing temperatures -- the aftermath of the crippling Feb. 4 blizzard. But they quickly reshaped plans, mapped special promotions, increased store hours and made a surprisingly strong attack on declining sales caused by the weather.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane was named Deputy Mayor by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
A murder charge against a 15-year-old boy was dismissed yesterday in the Brooklyn Felony Court at the request of the District Attorney's office.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, expressed hope today for the establishment of a national television network devoted to educational broadcasts.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 1 (AP) -- Four officials of the privately owned Radio Caribe were arrested today and charged with defamation.
ALBANY, March 1 -- Sentiment was reportedly on the rise in the Legislature today for coupling an increase in aid to public schools with Governor Rockefeller's higher education program.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 1 -- For its third annual benefit fashion show, the Junior League of Stamford will go international, presenting selections from the ateliers of prominent French, Italian, English and American couturiers.

The fact that the Algerian conflict is at last approaching a solution has brought an extremist reaction which could have been expected. Rioting in Oran on Tuesday resulted in the horror of two French women being burned alive in their automobile by a mob of fanatical Moslem youths. The French settlers on their part see this episode as justification for fears that they are being sacrificed.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee made major changes today in an Administration plan to reduce feed-grain production and raise farm income.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy joined briefly tonight in a party honoring one of his long-time aides. But a vanishing gift prevented him from playing his role in a presentation ceremony.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today a sweeping program to help financially ill railroads, including tax relief and direct Federal loans.
ODESSA, U.S.S.R., Feb. 16 -- "In Odessa's free market on a Sunday," a popular saying in this Black Sea port goes, "you can buy almost anything -- including an atom bomb."
ALBANY, March 1 -- Amendments were filed today to correct defects in a new state law requiring school districts to provide bus transportation for private and parochial pupils.
Your editorial of Feb. 23 in regard to the conservation of the threatened forest preserves is highly welcome.

MANY home cooks, especially those of European background, believe that they could not get along without wooden spoons. However, because of the impossibility of removing all the foreign substances that in time become inbedded in the soft grain, New York City health laws forbid the use of wooden spoons in kitchens of public eating establishments.

PERTH, Australia, Feb. 27 -- Francis Edward Chamberlain, Federal secretary of the Australian Labor party and leader of the Left Wing of Australian Labor said today that Labor could defeat the conservative Menzies Government with help from an unusual source -- big business.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 1 (AP) -- Tom Mboya's Kenya African National Union (Kanu), which wants the Mau Mau leader, Jomo Kenyatta, for Prime Minister, emerged from final election returns tonight with majority support in a new Negro-controlled Parliament.
VIENNA, March 1 -- Five hundred diplomats and international lawyers representing eighty-four governments will convene tomorrow for a six-week conference to codify diplomatic practices and immunities.
ALBANY, March 1 -- An open break between the chairman and vice chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Health Insurance Plans temporarily disrupted a committee hearing this afternoon.

BONN, Germany, March 1 -- A campaign attacking Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin for the years he spent outside Germany during the Nazi era is gaining momentum in the campaign for the national election in September.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board proposed today changes in the reserve requirements of member banks in eleven cities.
Cotton futures closed 2 points off on the December contract to steady to 8 points up on the others yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The death knell for the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League race was not sounded last night at Madison Square Garden. The Blues, with Dean Prentice, Camille Henry and Floyd Smith doing all the scoring in the third period, beat the Boston Bruins, 3 to 1.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Radio Corporation of America urged the Government today not to give any one company a preferred position in the field of communication satellites.

A definitive biography of Newton D. Baker, who was Secretary of War under President Woodrow Wilson, will be issued on March 24 by World. Mr. Baker, an outstanding progressive, began his political career as a reform Mayor of Cleveland.

Yields on Treasury bills and other short-term gilt-edge debt investments continued to inch upward yesterday in a bond market otherwise marked by a late-afternoon price pick-up in high grade corporate obligations and by pressure on local Government bond houses to distribute a heavy slate of new issues.

On the surface, at least, the recent observance of Advertising Week, signaling a year-long effort to advertise advertising, to some might suggest just another tedious chapter in the national mania for creating or refurbishing "images."
An 18-year-old youth who was shot when two teen-age gangs clashed in the Bronx Tuesday night died yesterday morning in Lincoln Hospital.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 1 (AP) -- Flooded rivers surged through the south central sections of Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi today, leaving wide trails of ruin behind. Damage was reckoned in the millions of dollars.
MOSCOW, March 1 -- Ilya Ehrenburg, the Soviet writer, has defended Boris Pasternak as a naive victim of the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The House of Representatives, in an endorsement of its Committee on Un-American Activities, gave the investigating group $331,000 today to carry on its work in the current year. The vote was 412 to 6 for the appropriation.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved Thomas K. Finletter today to be permanent United States representative to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after he rejected a proposal to halve this country's NATO troop force.

A 10-year-old Bronx girl who had been missing since Tuesday afternoon was found shortly before 3 o'clock this morning near her home. The child, Donna Marie Michel, was reported unharmed and in good condition.
The Chrysler Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was reducing the number of management seats on the proposed board of directors to be elected at the annual meeting on April 18.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Kennedy gave his official backing today to legislation to restore the lifetime rank of General of the Army to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Profit takers mauled the soybean futures market today, driving all contracts down the limit of 10 cents a bushel allowed in a single day on the Board of Trade.

LAS VEGAS, New March 1 (AP) -- Ray Robinson and Gene Fullmer argued today over the size of the gloves and the color of the trunks they should wear in the National Boxing Association Middleweight championship fight Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Administration will move soon to stiffen enforcement of the policy against racial discrimination in hiring by the Government or its contractors.

David Susskind, moderator of "Open End" and a major package producer of television programs, confirmed last night that he had notified the owners of station WNTA-TV of his intention to submit a bid for the Channel 13 outlet.
Crosby Smith, Al Copeland and Capt. Robert Snyder, the three top-seeded players in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C championship, advanced to the third round yesterday.

New York University, victor in its last four games and hoping for a National Invitation Tournament bid, will face the Georgetown Hoyas in the second game of the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

HONG KONG, March 1 -- The slogan of "letting a hundred flowers blossom and a hundred schools of thought contend" was revived today in an editorial in Hung Chi, fortnightly journal published by the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The highest United States prelates of the Roman Catholic Church met here today to plan what is expected to be a vigorous fight against President Kennedy's school-aid program.

Although Fred Coe and Arthur Cantor were more than business acquaintances, "All the Way Home" brought them together as sponsors of what has been termed "The Miracle of Forty-fourth Street." That accolade was bestowed upon it because the partners saved Tad Mosel's dramatization of James Agee's Pulitzer Prize novel, "A Death in the Afternoon," from an untimely departure.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1 -- Mrs. Marietta P. Tree declared today that much more remains to be done to achieve human rights for all.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Kennedy defended today his nomination of Charles M. Meriwether of Alabama to be a director of the Export-Import Bank.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 1 (AP) -- Gen. Phoumi Nosovan said today Chinese Nationalist troops under attack in Burma had fled into Laos and created a delicate problem for his country.
PARIS, March 1 -- The French Government took steps today to reduce the political and police power of the French Army in Algeria as a new effort began to end the rebellion there by negotiation.
LOS ANGELES, March 1 -- Western Airlines announced today that it would resume partial service tomorrow on the Rocky Mountain segment of its routes after a two-day shutdown because of labor troubles.
A pioneer in the development of teaching machines warned yesterday that overemphasis on "hardware" might obscure the principles on which the machines were based and hamper their development.
HONG KONG, March 1 -- Chinese Communist leaders expressed satisfaction today with results to date of talks with Soviet officials on trade and economic relations.
The city's new Commissioner of Hospitals said yesterday that he was "counting on" the city's voluntary hospitals to help alleviate the crisis in the municipal hospital system.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1 -- President Sukarno ordered banned tonight an anti-Communist political organization and five other groups on the ground that their outlook was not consistent with the declaration of state ideology known as the Political Manifesto.
LONDON, March 1 (UPI) -- Britain regained the Wolfe-Noel Cup from the United States at the Lansdowne Club today when the British women's squash racquets team crushed the Americans, 5 -- 0.

RABAT, Morocco, Thursday, March 2 -- A North African summit conference that brought together the Tunisian and Moroccan chiefs of state and Algerian nationalist rebel leaders issued a communique here early today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 1 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority disclosed that it had received identical bids from five aluminum and two cement companies.

THE French interest in love goes back a long way and in 1735 Rameau wrote an opera-ballet about its triumph in three far places. Because one was Peru and another North America, he called it "Les Indes Galantes."
Chicago, Ill., borrowed $30,000,000 on waterworks revenue bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 3.52776 per cent.

Net income of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., Montreal, and its American and Canadian subsidiaries for the six months ended on Jan. 31 was 16,482,000, or $1.88 a share. This compared with a net income of $15,152,000, or $1.73 a share, in the six months ended on Jan. 31, 1960.

"DISCIPLINE as a useful tool in child rearing is on the way back from the discard heap where it was buried by advocates of permissive behavior," according to Dr. Eleanore Braun Luckey of the University of Connecticut.
TORONTO, March 1 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich scored his forty-sixth goal of the season and Ron Stewart hit for two goals in a 3-1 victory by the Toronto Maple Leafs over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today signed the Brook-Peterson Bill granting nonresident income taxpayers the right to itemize deductions on their tax returns in the same manner as residents.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 1 -- Premier Ileo denied today reports that the signing of a "military protocol" in Elisabethville yesterday implied the "recognition of independence" of Katanga and South Kasi by the Central Government at Leopoldville.
Boston, March 1 (AP) -The New England Council issued the following report today:
Investigations by the state and the city are being made into the operations of the Board of Education's multi-million-dollar school construction program.
THE method of selecting the next American team to play for the world championship is still a burning problem.

MIAMI, March 1 -- Joseph Roebling's Be Cautious won with a daring maneuver today in the Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah. The 4-year-old English-bred daughter of Grey Sovereign went through the hole on the rail and took the $46,300 stakes by three-quarters of a length over Fred Hooper's Teacation.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's special message to Congress today, recommending the creation of a permanent Peace Corps:
Plans are being completed for a dinner dance for the benefit of Childville, Inc. It will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on Saturday.
PARIS, March 1 -- W. Averell Harriman, President Kennedy's Roving Ambassador, arrived here tonight and promptly scotched rumors that his mission to Europe was to prepare a Western summit conference.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren questioned today the right of a state to prohibit a physician from advising, or a person from using, contraceptive devices when health is involved.
MIAMI, March 1 -- The swirling waters of the whirlpool bath gently massaged the right ankle of Manager Paul Richards, the first casualty of the Baltimore Orioles' training camp.
The board of directors of the International Silver Company proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock yesterday.

Your editorials on President Kennedy's natural-resource message call for an additional comment from those of us who have long sought to establish for the nation what you already have in New York City -- a capital budget.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The prospect of a Democratic patronage sweep of the Federal judiciary drew Republican assertions today that the Democrats were politicking with the courts.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Court of Claims today awarded $583,549 to Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation in its suit against the Government for breach of contract in the sale of war surplus aluminum plants.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Kennedy issued an executive order today creating a Peace Corps. It will enlist American men and women for voluntary, unpaid service in the developing countries of the world.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Both parties joined today in the House of Representatives to give quick passage to President Kennedy's plan to extend unemployment compensation.

"Show Girl," the revue starring Carol Channing, will be televised live from the Eugene O'Neill Theatre here to a pay-TV system in Toronto on April 2. It reportedly will be the first telecast of a Broadway attraction from a legitimate theatre.
The Delman shoe salon, elegantly nestled on the first floor of Bergdorf Goodman, has suddenly turned pink. Even the salesmen are sporting pink carnations in their buttonholes.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 1 (Reuters) -- Pier Pasquale Spinelli of Italy was reported today to be the successor of Rajeshwar Dayal of India as United Nations special representative in the Congo.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 1 -- The new people in town have got together to raise $25,000 for the restoration of an old wooden building called the Adams Academy, but some of the old folks in these parts scoffed today at all the doings.

GENEVA, March 1 -- United Nations experts called on the industrialized nations of Western Europe today to make room in their home markets by 1980 for $5,000,000,000 in manufactured products from underdeveloped countries.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Pentagon has completed a reappraisal of defense strategy and has recommended a "general strengthening of our armed forces," President Kennedy said at his news conference today.

PARIS fashion is all set to go underground. In June the Misses Dresses department of Bloomingdale's basement, which is on the subway level, will be selling original, exclu sive Paris designed clothes. They will range from $15 to $25. It is the first time, the store believes, that Paris collection has been designed especially, for the "under the pavement" shopper.

Cottonseed oil futures registered one of the sharpest price declines in recent years on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Final quotations were off 56 to 80 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 1,372 tankcars of 60,000 pounds each, the largest since March 27, 1952, when 1,503 cars were traded.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 1 (UPI) -- Howard Aronson, a motor lodge operator, announced yesterday he planned to build a $4,000,000 racially integrated convention center near Miami, Fla.
Bob Melvin scored 35 points and led Fordham to a 76-72 basketball victory over Queens College on the loser's court in Flushing last night.

President Kennedy's special message to Congress on the nationwide highway construction program is a sound and reassuring document. It supports fully the pay-as-we-go principle that was so hard won in Congress to begin with.

Bertram D. Tallamy, former chairman of the Thruway Authority, yesterday defended the legality of a $200,000 engineering service contract in which he had been named the $200-a-day consultant to the state agency.

Sidney Schwartz, New York realty investor and syndicator, has bought an apartment development on Harbor Island in the Bal Harbour area of Miami Beach. The property, known as the Beaux Arts, is valued at about $2,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, March 1 (AP) -- Duquesne University's unranked basketball team upset St. Bonaventure, 79 -- 74, in overtime tonight. Ned Twyman led the Dukes to their amazing come-from-behind victory over the country's No. 2 ranked team by scoring 31 points.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Rafer Johnson, the Olympic decathlon champion, has volunteered to join the Peace Corps announced today by President Kennedy.

ALBANY, March 1 -- For the tenth time in ten years, sports and commercial fishermen clashed at a conservation hearing today over a bill that would bar commercial fishermen from catching striped bass in the waters around New York City and Long Island.
Life almost certainly exists elsewhere in the universe, but the fact won't help man solve any of his pressing earthly problems, a panel of eminent scientists and scholars agreed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Mr. Day's novel was never a success. Today, however, one of the 2,000 copies of the first and only edition would be a collector's item. The book is about an intellectual cabaret dancer and a Viennese physician who covets his wife's sister.
The New York Board of Rabbis said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's student incentive plan, as revised, did not violate the church-state separation provisions of the Constitution.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net loss of $29,714,509 for 1960. This was after a Federal tax net refund of $18,350,700 and provision for deferred taxes of $218,500. In 1959, the company had a profit after taxes of $9,032,665, equal to $1.55 a share.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy today invited fifteen Congressional leaders of both parties to luncheon at the White House tomorrow, Vice President Johnson will also attend.
SKI SKETCH: Nineteen years ago, Dotty Graves astounded an assemblage at the Olympic jumping hill in Lake Placid by soaring 204 feet. The distance was tremendous for a girl.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- The man who has a tiger by the tail has an easy task compared to Paramount studio, which will soon have a zoo by a lot of tails and is not yet too sure how to handle the problem.

TOKYO, March 1 -- The trouble in the Congo has posed a critical problem for Japan that she had side-stepped for years: How to reconcile her determination not to get involved in any military operation abroad with her moral obligation to come to the aid of the United Nations in time of trouble.

The first thermoelectric refrigerator-freezers to be made on a commercial basis will be installed next May by the Borg-Warner Corporation's Norge division. One will go into each of 500 rooms of a new hotel that is being built in Chicago by the Sheraton Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The fundamental conflict in the Supreme Court over whether the power of Congress to investigate an international Communist conspiracy in the United States is misused, in violation of the Constitution, continues to center on the methods of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Statistically, yesterday's session of the stock market was down a bit, but prices were advancing in the final 150 minutes and the impression seemed general that stocks had behaved well at a time when they might have come under strong pressure.

Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and associates are offering today 464,725 common shares of Berkey Photo, Inc., at $11.75 a share, marking the initial public offering of the photographic film processor's shares.

"Mere crumbs from the tables of an abundant society have made millions of black men angry. That's why there was a riot at the U.N. the other day, and why the black nationalist movement is growing and becoming more militant in New York and everywhere else."
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy flew to Florida today to try to clear up a case of bronchitis aggravated by the chilly Washington weather.
The City Planning Commission approved plans yesterday for widening a 3.3-mile section of Grand Central Parkway in Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Teamsters Union has tentatively scheduled a convention in Miami the week of June 5, a union aide said today.

Clarkson Tech, having beaten two leading contenders for a National Collegiate hockey tourney bid, will clash Saturday with a third contender, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in the final game of the regular season for both teams.
Stanley M. Isaacs, minority leader of the City Council, called last night for a "complete change" in the city administration.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., March 1 -- A group of business leaders who discussed metropolitan area problems here for four days has decided that the most critical need in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region is to improve commuter railroad service and mass transportation within cities.
NEW DELHI, India, March 11 -- Begging became illegal today in Delhi.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- United States membership in a new Western economic alliance encountered unexpected bipartisan opposition in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today. Members questioned the constitutionality of the present draft convention.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman of the General Electric Company, announced tonight a crackdown program to discourage attempts to violate Federal price-fixing laws.

The Kennedy Administration is obviously making a serious attempt to enable the United States to take the initiative away from Khrushchev in the important negotiating areas of the limitation of armaments and the securing of a permanent and effective ban on nuclear testing.

Pennsylvania defeated Columbia, 50 -- 45, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming meet yesterday at University Hall. Penn wrapped up the verdict with a victory in the final event -- the 400-yard free-style relay.
The Northern Illinois Gas Company set new records in most phases of its operations in 1960, according to the annual report issued for publication yesterday.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire of Lake Park, Fla., posted the best first-round score today in the Florida East Coast women's amateur golf tournament.
The appointment of Carl A. Vergari, who has been assistant counsel to the State Investigation Commission since August, 1958, as chief counsel was announced yesterday.

Joseph I. Lubin has assembled the blockfront on the west side of Second Avenue between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets, with the exception of a small parcel with a frontage of twenty feet at 893 Second Avenue.
Curbs were imposed on the rebroadcasting of President Kennedy's news conference here yesterday, and then lifted after a protest by five independent radio stations.
Mayor Wagner charged last night that Governor Rockefeller and the Republican leaders in Albany were giving the taxpayers of New York City an "education runaround."

MONTREAL, March 1 (Canadian Press) -- An offering of not more than 2,150,000 shares of stock of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada to the company's stockholders, in the ratio of one new share for every ten held at the close of business on March 9, 1961, was authorized today by directors.

I have enjoyed the head-a-head between your editorial and Frank D. O'Connor, president of the New York State District Attorneys Association. I write to suggest that there are two omitted essential facts which go to the core of the revision of the grand jury system.

BONN, Germany, March 1 -- Walter C. Dowling, the United States Ambassador, conferred with Chancellor Adenauer today. He was believed to have sought clarification of statements indicating that West German development aid could not be guaranteed beyond 1961.
NEW DELHI, India, March 1 -- A substantial deterioration is evident in the relations between India and Pakistan.

"OUTLAWS,"* by Danilo Dolci, is a book about the overpossessed and the dispossessed in western Sicily. It extends and deepens the story Mr. Dolci told in "Report from Palermo." Not a pretty story. Yet one that will haunt the imagination many days.
BOWIE, Md., March 1 (AP) -- Charles Boland, the Canadian apprentice, again starred at the Bowie Race Course today when he rode three winners for the second consecutive day.
The confessed slayer of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorius was jailed alone yesterday in a cell at the Bronx Detention House for men. He was placed under two-man, round-the-clock guard.

LONDON, March 1 -- Cecil Harmsworth King, who made himself czar of one of the greatest of modern press and magazine empires today, is a curious blend of ambitious, decisive magnate and cultured, reserved gentleman.
DETROIT, March 1 -- Walter P. Reuther called today for a task force led by six Midwestern governors to prod Congress into speedy action on the nation's unemployment problem.

CLIFTON FADIMAN probably has written the ultimate essay on cheese. It appears in his volume "Any Number Can Play" (World Publishing Company, 1957). He quotes P. Morton Shand, who considered a love of cheese inherent in humanity, and Ben Gunn, who isolated on Treasure Island, moaned wistfully that "Many's the long night I've dreamed of cheese -- toasted mostly."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1 -- Some structural changes in the United Nations would make the organization a more effective agency for international peace, the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace said today in its thirteenth annual report.
LONDON, March 1 -- The Daily Mirror publishing group announced tonight that it had gained control of Odhams Press.

EDWARD ALBEE packs a high charge of intensity into the less than an hour required for his play, "The Death of Bessie Smith." What is more impressive, he goes beyond intensity to achieve illumination and compassion.

MONTREAL, March 1 (Canadian Press) -- Quebec Power Company today reported net earnings for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1960, of $1,777,999, or $2.53 a share, compared with $1,681,226, or $2.41 a share in 1959.

WHITE PLAINS, March 1 -- John Stilwell resigned today as vice president, treasurer and a member of the Westchester County Park Commission because of what he said was political intrusions in park management.
The Jewish festival of Purim began last night at sundown.
Identical all-America first teams were chosen yesterday in basketball polls conducted by The Associated Press and United Press International.
Sixty Negro school children from Brooklyn called on 275 white children in a Queens school yesterday.
A boy fell into the East River last night and clung to a piling while a passing couple ran for help. When help arrived he had drowned.
The life led by most leading professional dog handlers is ideal for developing jangled nerves. The hours are long, the meals sketchy, the tension of competition great, the results often frustrating.
Automobile production last month fell well below the January level and 45 per cent from that in February, 1960. It was the worst February since 1952, company figures showed yesterday.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 1 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province canceled today a brief visit to South Kasai as a serious Cabinet crisis was reported in Katanga.
The tentative results of a representation election among members of two ship purser unions at American Export Lines were announced here yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.

A contract for a $300,000 study for the redevelopment of a six-mile section of New York's North River waterfront was signed yesterday by Vincent A.G. O'Connor, Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 1 (UPI) -- An old golfer named Dwight D. Eisenhower visited the baseball training camp of the Los Angeles Angels today and had a high time of it with the players.

The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday two applications by Brooklyn Savings Banks for branches in Nassau County and denied two others. Approved were applications of the Kings County Savings Bank for a branch at Hicksville Road near Jerusalem Avenue in Massapequa, L.I., and of the Kings Highway Savings Bank for a branch at 1260 Wantagh Avenue, Wantagh, L.I.

The little diplomatic window that has been the instrumentality since 1954 for official contacts between Communist China and the United States will, with characteristic tentativeness, be opened again next Tuesday. For the 103d time representatives of the two countries will discuss differences through the window, now in Warsaw after a shift several years ago from Geneva.
PARIS, March 1 -- Western European governments are in much the same position today as the moderately affluent American business man at the time of the annual community chest drive.
The Erie and St. Lawrence Corporation has suspended its containership service between here and Florida after six months of operation, Harry N. Moore, president, announced yesterday.
Advertising is very much a part of a sensitive and explosive world. Even an unintended error can cause the walls to start trembling.
Insiders continue to do more selling than buying of their companies' stocks.
The twelfth national exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today has been arranged as a memorial to Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., a charter member of the organization.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission disclosed today that it had suspended work on examinations for filling postmaster positions in the first-, second- and third-class postoffices. It acted at the request of Postmaster General J. Edward Day.
HAVANA, March 1 -- Dr. Armando Hart, Minister of Education, threatened tonight to nationalize all private schools "if they continue their present activities against the revolution."

Electric power production fell in the holiday week ended last Saturday to 14,239,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 14,315,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The decline was the fourth in as many weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- A three-man division of the Interstate Commerce Commission voted today to allow a 10 per cent interstate commuter fare increase for the New Haven Railroad. The increase is scheduled to go into effect Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Post Office officials said today they planned to continue putting plaques bearing President Kennedy's name on all their buildings dedicated after Jan. 30, despite Republican criticism.

If the noise level in Manhattan is several decibels higher these milder pre-spring evenings, it is because a cheerfully blatant German band is doing its best between the hours of 7 and 11 P.M. to raise the roof at Luchow's.

VIENNA, March 1 (UPI) -- Top figure skaters gave a scintillating exhibition tonight in honoring the memory of the members of the United States team who died recently in a plane crash.
BOSTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers held on to second place in the Western Division tonight by crushing the New York Knickerbockers, 144 -- 107, in a National Basketball Association game.
