The New York City Opera has commissioned Lee Hoiby and William Ball to write an opera for presentation by that company.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Kennedy's controversial nomination of Charles M. Meriwether to be a director of the Export-Import Bank was approved by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by a vote of 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy has asked a teacher at an experimental school in near-by Bethesda, Md., to set up and teach a nursery class at the White House for 3-year-old Caroline Kennedy and her friends.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- Declines in old-crop soybean futures prices ran through another 10-cent limit on the Board of Trade today, but with perhaps a little less force than in the preceding session.
The city will ask for bids today on an underground parking garage for 730 cars at Lincoln Center for Performing Arts.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, invoking for the first time the legal ban against "hot-cargo" labor contract clauses, said today it did not intend to be fooled by subterfuges.

The Boston Fund ended its fiscal year on Jan. 31 with new highs in net assets, share value and number of shareholders. The Boston-based balanced mutual fund's share value rose 13.3 per cent during the year.
A subway-booth attendant paid a $250 fine yesterday because he had fifty-nine stray dogs and fifteen cats.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2 -- An electoral college session in the Argentine Senate tonight for the routine purpose of declaring the Socialist candidate, Alfredo L. Palacios, the newly elected Senator for Buenos Aires was unexpectedly converted into an anti-United States demonstration.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The State Council on the Arts urged today that the state underwrite a share of the cost of presenting theatre, ballet, classical music and art to the public in areas lacking such activities.
LONDON, March 2 -- The Institution of Electrical Engineers announced today that it had awarded the Faraday Medal to Dr. Julius A. Stratton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The Transit Authority has made a determined effort to eliminate seats in favor of standing room in the subway system.
Prospects for overcoming what some call the "crisis" and President Kennedy calls the "disarray" of the North Atlantic alliance are brightening as a result of four hopeful developments.

GENEVA, March 2 -- The council of the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade (GATT) announced today that it had called for a study of Italian restrictions on imports at the request of the United States.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- The two titans of world amateur hockey, Canada and the Soviet Union, scored overwhelming victories here and in near-by Geneva tonight as the world amateur hockey championship opened in earnest.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 2 -- Three men were arrested today on charges of defrauding two Bergen County banks of $345,000 through what Prosecutor Guy W. Calissi described as an insurance policy racket.
Sales and earnings of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3-M) Company rose to record highs in 1960 for the ninth consecutive year, the company reported yesterday.

Lumber production in the United States totaled 196,703,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday, compared with 196,718,000 board feet in the previous week, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago, the figure was 253,634,000 board feet.

The United States monetary gold stock remained unchanged in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The announcement confirmed what President Kennedy told his press conference on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A slightly revised version of the Administration's depressed-area bill emerged today from a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee.

A major move to expand television was made yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The commission said that it would seek Congressional legislation to force manufacturers to equip all new sets to receive Channels 14 through 83, in the ultra high frequencies, as well as Channels 2 through 13, in the very high frequencies.
A case of possible collusion among contractors bidding for school work is being looked into by City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan, the Superintendent of Schools said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold asked today for 25,000 soldiers and a fund of $135,000,000 to keep the United Nations force going in the Congo throughout 1961.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 2 -- Congolese troops in Luluabourg massacred forty-four Congolese civilians Tuesday and yesterday in revenge for the slaying of three soldiers by a rioting mob.

We have always held the editorials of The New York Times in high regard because of their treatment of a wide variety of controversial subjects with the utmost objectivity. But your recent editorial "No Double Standard" does not come up to the caliber of The Times.

UNION, S.C., March 2 -- This was the hard-raining day for theoretical bass fishing and the Pine Hill Game Preserve was a pretty good place to do it. Frank Hill, who operates the preserve, was here for theory and T-Bone Hill, born Toney twelve years ago, was here for the hard practical stuff.
ROME, March 2 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy disclosed today it had warned the governing Christian Democratic party in Italy against collaboration with the Left-Wing Socialists led by Pietro Nenni.
Assistant Chief Inspector Michael E.J. Ledden, a member of the Police Department for thirty-five years, was appointed Chief of Detectives yesterday.
Fred Thompson was indicted yesterday for first-degree murder, rape and felonious assault in the death of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorious on Feb. 22.
Adlai E. Stevenson renewed today a warning that Soviet intervention in the African turmoil might bring on war.

Following are excerpts from an address yesterday by Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, at an official city luncheon given in his honor, as broadcast by Station WNYC and recorded by The New York Times:

The Scott Paper Company announced yesterday that it will take over the assets and business of two wholly owned subsidiaries, the Coos Bay Pulp Corporation and the Marinette Paper Company. Coos Bay produces sulphite pulp in Anacortes, Wash., and Empire, Ore.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 2 (Reuters) -- The Anglican Archbishop of Capetown announced today the resignation of Bishop Ambrose Reeves, an opponent of apartheid, and said he had been "outlawed for obedience to the Christian Gospel as he sees it."
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- The Administration has permanently revoked an export license under which $1,500,000 worth of machine tools could have been shipped to the Soviet Union.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 2 -- Walter Guevara Arze, Opposition candidate in last year's Presidential election, has taken political asylum in the papal nunciature here after having fled from the police for ten days.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Among the young ballplayers working out with the Yankees are the Keller boys, Charlie Jr. and Don. Their father was King Kong, who with Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich once gave the Bombers one of baseball's foremost outfields.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points off on near March to 8 points up on other positions yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
DETROIT, March 2 -- This tough and breezy city has gotten over hard times before and it will do it again, but for the time being it is moaning low.
MILWAUKEE, March 2 (UPI) -- The Department of Justice asked the United States District Court today to invalidate the acquisition of two Milwaukee banks by the Bank Stock Corporation of Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Kennedy are making living in the White House more homelike. A family kitchen, butler's pantry and spacious dining room have been installed in their private quarters.

The tremendous build-up of Communist military strength in North Laos revealed by a New York Times correspondent who has just visited that area can leave no doubt that the Communists plan to take over Laos in the fairly near future. Russia has played a major role in the build-up through the supply by air and road of weapons and supplies of many kinds.

WALTHAM, Mass., March 2 (AP) -- Brandeis University will gain a diversified, five-point program of scholarships and fellowships under grant of $100,000 from Marvin Kratter, New York real estate executive, the university reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- Thomas K. Finletter was approved by the Senate today as permanent United States Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

MARCH came in like a lamb -- and with plenty of it. Due to good supplies and relatively low demand, prices on popular lamb cuts dropped 4 cents this week-end. The meat also is the subject of fairly widespread special treatment by chain stores.
With skiing conditions improved at some New Hampshire and Maine points, as well as in Eastern Canada, week-end enthusiasts were reluctant yesterday to put their hickories away for the year.
Chances are the Metropolitan Opera would like to forget the performance of Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" it put on last night, for the evening was one of those in which too many people had problems.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 2 (AP) -- Studebaker-Packard Corporation said today it had acquired Chemical Compounds, Inc. of St. Joseph, Mo., by purchasing the company's stock for cash, plus contingent payments out of future earnings of the business.

More than 1,400 pounds of papers of the noted actress, the late Mrs. Minnie Maddern Fiske, who died in 1932, have been presented to the Library of Congress. The gift is from Miss Olive Kooken, a 55-year-old sculptor from Union City, N.J.
The McCrory Corporation soon may be operating the third largest chain of retail stores in the nation from the standpoint of units.
BONN, Germany, March 2 -- The United States has been given new assurances that West German development aid to poorer countries will be on a continuing basis and financed from budgetary funds.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Feb. 25 were 11 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 2 (UPI) -- Attorneys for The New York Times filed a motion yesterday for a new trial in a $500,000 libel judgment against the newspaper.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Logrolling raised a threat today to swift passage of a bill to increase the number of Federal judges.

KINGSTON, R.I., March 2 -- St. John's frustrated a late bid by Rhode Island and won, 86 -- 74, tonight for its seventh straight basketball victory and eighteenth in twenty-two starts. A crowd of 4,000 watched.
The Southern Illinois University borrowed $8,100,000 yesterday on issues of dormitory revenue bonds due from 1963 to 2000.

SILVIA BALDI'S career started out in the limelight. And, although she switched from singing torch songs to designing and selling shoes (with some interesting and varied stops in between) she has managed to keep the spotlight still focused on her.

MIAMI, March 2 -- When the second race was over at Hialeah today, a comparative handful of players queued up to collect the $2 daily double return of $2,159.20. As for the rest of the crowd of 16,272, most seemed to be walking around in a daze, asking one another, "How you gonna come up with horses like that?"

CARL RUGGLES will be 85 years old a week from tomorrow, and the Composers' Showcase gave a concert in his honor last night. The venerable American composer, on orders from his physician, did not come from his home in Vermont to attend the program.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The state Labor Commissioner reported today that unemployment in the state was at the highest level since the post-war recession of 1949.

Many patrons of the Green Acres Camp, a project of the New York City Mission Society, have made plans to attend a dinner in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza next Tuesday before the theatre party at "Do Re Mi" at the St. James Theatre.

The letter from Albert Colloms printed on this page March 1 and dealing with political prisoners in Spain was a call to the conscience of all of us. Mr. Colloms was the American member of an international commission of lawyers who made an on-the-spot investigation of civil liberties, due process and political prisoners in Franco Spain.
DETROIT, March 2 (AP) -- Auto production is expected to dip again this week, by about 8,000 units below last week's level, Automotive News said today.

CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks whipped the New York Rangers, 7 -- 1, tonight and clinched a Stanley Cup play-off berth. Chicago is now sure of at least a fourth-place finish in the National Hockey League.

LONDON, March 2 -- Increased demand imparted a firm tone to the stock market here today and most industrial shares registered small rises. The Financial Times industrial shares index rose six-tenths of a point to 328.9.
BONN, Germany, March 2 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin fought back today against attacks on his emigrant past.

" Daishi-san," a historical novel by Robert Lund, will be issued next Wednesday by John Day. The story is based on the life of William Adams. Born in England in 1564, the son of a tenant farmer, he died in 1620 in Japan after having attained the highest, honor reached by a Westerner in that country before or since -- adviser to the Shogun.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 2 -- G. Mennen Williams expressed hope today that the Congolese regime of President Joseph Kasavubu and Premier Joseph Ileo would cooperate constructively with the United Nations in an effort to bring peace to the Congo.

A NEW novel by Rumer Godden is always major news in the world of books and always good news. Few modern writers have maintained as high an average in book after book as the distinguished Englishwoman, whose subtle mind and magically evocative prose have enchanted readers throughout the world.
Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, was accused yesterday of a raiding drive that threatened to "dominate all maritime unions."
SINCE Third Avenue came out from under the El, a host of new little shops has come to light.

Seldom has a man had more honors heaped on his shoulders in a few winter weeks than A.W. (Bill) MacKerer, once of Brooklyn but now at Pompano Beach, Fla., where he is the senior vice president of Chris Craft, the world's largest builder of motor boats.
MIAMI, March 2 -- Everett Clay, the Hialeah official, grinned like a benevolent Buddha when he spotted Johnny Sellers among a group of jockeys the other day.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States has decided to oppose any school-aid legislation that fails to help children attending private schools.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2 (AP) -- Johnny Pott sank a 70-foot shot for an eagle on a 500-yard hole today to tie Julius Bores and Doug Sanders with a 68 for the first-round lead in the $30,000 Greater New Orleans invitation golf tournament.

" The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm" has been announced as the second project to be filmed in Cinerama by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, starting next year, George Pal will produce the film, which will include "biographical segments" dealing with the fairy tale authors to be photographed in Europe.
A BRIDGE riddle that has been and perhaps still is going the rounds of the New York clubs is this:
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The board of directors of Marshall Field Co. has authorized a two-for-one split of the common stock and plans an increase in the dividend rate, it was announced yesterday.

In a demonstration emphasizing that there's still a place in basketball for both small men and tall ones, unbeaten Erasmus Hall High of Brooklyn yesterday captured the Public Schools Athletic League crown at Madison Square Garden.

A firm tone prevailed yesterday in the bond market except among local government debt securities of new issue. That area of the market is congested from a sizable volume and wide variety of fresh borrowings.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Administration leaders in reviewing defense policies, are understood to have been impressed by long-standing Army criticism of the United States' "continued primary reliance on massive nuclear retaliation."
ALBANY, March 2 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a grocer is liable for injuries to the family of a shopper to whom he sells harmful food.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Rockefeller presented today a program of salary increases for the state's 110,000 employes. The increases would range from $120 to $10,000 a year.
An explosion in a power-cable conduit under Forty-fourth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, yesterday afternoon caused one minor injury and shattered windows in the block.
American shipowners have received State Department assurances that it will "do its best" to protect United States flag operators from "unduly stringent" interpretations of India's Sea Customs Act.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 2 -- The Yugoslav Government announced tonight that it was cutting its diplomatic staff in neighboring Albania to an "indispensible minimum" because of alleged maltreatment of its representatives there.
Your editorial of Feb. 25 "Pleasant Thought for the Day" was a short but pithy reminder to all of us that the fight against air pollution is a never-ending one.
WHEN the first passenger subway was opened in 1904, did anyone imagine that it would become a tunnel of gloom? Getting to work downtown in a rush must have elated the first passengers.

WITH affection and admiration, Puerto Ricans have nicknamed their Economic Development Administration much more manageably, "Fomento." In Spanish, fomento means stirring up, a process the administration has done with such success in the last decade that Puerto Rican branches of American concerns now are processing and shipping here such a wide assortment of goods as canned tuna fish and textiles, brassieres and baseballs, electric shavers and underwater cameras.

It was in 1958 that the problem of this country's almost chronic deficit in its annual balance of payments was first recognized as a major problem. Its sudden discovery by the public gave rise to the outcry in many quarters that the United States had "priced itself out of the world markets."
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 2 (Reuters) -- Prince Souvanna Phouma proposed today the withdrawal of "American troops" from Laos and the establishment of a coalition government, including pro-Communists.
A Harlem clergyman warned yesterday of a possible citywide work stoppage and rent strike by Negroes and Puerto Ricans to protest bad housing conditions.

PARIS, March 2 -- The French noted with satisfaction today recognition by North African leaders; including Algerian rebel representatives, that no obstacle now exists to direct negotiations for the end of the Algerian rebellion.
ST. LOUIS, March 2 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit ruled today that the Little Rock, Ark., School Board must speed desegregation of the city's schools.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 2 -- Science departments in fifty- three municipal school systems in seven states received surplus electronic equipment valued at $250,000 this week from the Navy's supply center disposal unit, here.

KATONAH, N.Y., March 2 -- At Katonah Ridge the residents of seventy new ranch and split-level houses felt today that the most provoking words anyone could mention, even in a whisper, were "Interstate Route 87."

A tradition of excellence in the Deputy Mayor's job is continued with Mayor Wagner's appointment of Paul R. Screvane. Henry Epstein, now on the Supreme Court bench, Dr. John J. Theobald, now Superintendent of Schools, and Paul T. O'Keefe have served in this important post at City Hall during the Wagner regime.
Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange advanced about two-third of 1 per cent yesterday. The market made an unbroken advance and ended with a strong spurt into higher ground.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington said today that the Pentagon had wasted more than $675,000,000 on unsatisfactory Navy planes, aircraft radar and aircraft engines.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Mayor Wagner urged the Legislature today to impose stringent checks on landlords who plead "hardship" in seeking permission to raise rents.
DETROIT, March 2 (UPI) -- William C. Newberg, ousted last year as president of Chrysler Corporation, has taken a job as consultant to the Detroit Broach and Machine Company, it was announced today.
A tall, beefy and speedy Georgetown quintet tarried at Madison Square Garden just long enough to pick up its seventh consecutive victory last night, routing New York University, 92 -- 69.
Two warrants for the arrest of Jacob Brownstein, Brooklyn lawyer, have been issued because of his failure to appear for trial for 162 alleged violations in a West Side tenement.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The issue of Arabian American Oil Company discrimination against Jews was sent back to the State Commission Against Discrimination today for another hearing.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- The space agency plans to launch a dozen moon exploration craft and five probes to Venus and Mars in the next few years.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2 (AP) -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today reported higher earnings and higher revenues for 1960. Net income was reported at $52,143,762, $3,648,104 more than in 1959, while operating revenues rose from $327,244,105 to $346,864,422.

OSLO, Norway, March 2 -- The concentration of radioactive cesium 137 in Norwegians is considerably higher than that yet measured in people of any other place, according to Johan Baarli who has just completed an investigation at the University of Lund, Sweden.

Frank J. Lucia, chief of staff of the Department of Sanitation, was appointed by Mayor Wagner last night as Commissioner of Sanitation. He will succeed Paul R. Screvane, who will become Deputy Mayor today.
ALBANY, Friday, March 3 -- Fire broke out in New York State's Executive Mansion shortly before last midnight, forcing Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller to flee down a fire ladder.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- Chicago's Midway Airport led the nation's airports in flying activity in 1960, a Federal Aviation Agency survey showed today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Kennedy was host at luncheon today to sixteen Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders. Mr. Kennedy and Vice President Johnson, former mem bers of the House and Senate, were at lunch with the Congressmen for an hour and a quarter.
The wholesale commodity price index eased to 85.8 on Wednesday from 86 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.5 on Feb. 24, 1960.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $57,000,000 to $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $68,000,000 to $647,000,000.

I am alarmed at the competition in which you ("Depreciation Tax Policies," an editorial on Feb. 13) and Ralph McCabe ("Tax Depreciation Problem," a letter on Feb. 20) seem to have become involved. Specifically:

CONSIDER Hawaii a member of the union in good standing. With the arrival of "13 Daughters" at the 54th Street Theatre last night, it received the recognition that counts on Broadway -- a musical set in its valleys, by its streams and along its golden strands.
BOSTON, March 2 -- In a special supplement to its monthly New England Letter published today, the First National Bank of Boston presented a set of what it called "provocative" questions.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- George Alpert, president of the New Haven Rail road, indicated today that the Government's loan-guarantee program had kept his line in business.
LONDON, March 2 -- The reserves of gold and Convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area declined substantially last month.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today it had arranged to complete housing at five military bases started by a contractor who is reported to have fled to Mexico.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Some members of the Supreme Court indicated today that they might try to avoid handing down a decision on a challenge of Connecticut's law against contraceptives.
Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Brooklyn Democrat, was reported yesterday to be waging an active campaign for appointment as Ambassador to Israel.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Peace Corps established yesterday by President Kennedy produced generally favorable reaction today in foreign embassies and on Capitol Hill.

The eleven majority-owned banks of the Financial General Corporation, including four in New York State, reported yesterday that net earnings after taxes were $3,518,068 for 1960, for 13 per cent more than in 1959. Deposits in the group rose by more than $4,000,000 to $419,892,135 at year-end.

John Thomas, America's stellar high jumper, will have his last chance of this indoor season to defeat Valeri Brumel of the Soviet union in the Knights of Columbus track meet at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, rejected today a Navajo contention that the National Labor Relations Board lacked jurisdiction over a mining plant on an Indian reservation.
PHONGSAVAN, Laos, March 1 -- This small tribal village, a former opium market, is now the focal point for a massive Communist arms build-up in northern Laos.

MIAMI, March 2 (AP) -- The Federal Government today tied up Ingemar Johansson's purse for his coming heavyweight title fight ten more days -- to March 17. By then, it hopes to learn the amount and whereabouts of Johansson's funds available to satisfy a $598,000 income-tax claim.
A provocative study of a 1959 Brooklyn murder case was presented last night on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2.

The Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Elizabeth II, is leaving Delhi after a month's tour of India. Her visit to that country has been imperfectly recorded and inadequately appreciated in the press of the United States.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, the new Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that he favored closing Gouverneur Hospital but would appoint a committee of prominent physicians to make "a final inspection."

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 2 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province is reported to have conferred privately with three French officers about possible French replacements for Belgian commanders of the 5,000-man provincial police force.

In view of the current legislative consideration in Albany concerning the extension of residential rent control in New York, a discussion of the side effects of rent control may be of general interest.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Justice Department has seriously questioned whether the antitrust laws would permit any one company to gain control over a future communications satellite network.
PARIS, March 2 -- West Germany took another money-easing step today.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The United States Government has informed Nationalist China that it opposes the presence of Chinese irregulars in Laos and Burma.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The State Department has asked a $637,000 "crash program" to combat eavesdropping on diplomatic secrets.

Six foreign countries heretofore not represented will send teams to compete in the International Soccer League this year. Turkey, Rumania, Czechoslovakia, Spain, the Irish Republic and Canada will be in the tournament round-robin, which will get under way at the Polo Grounds May 17.
WEST TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 2 (UPI) -- An explosion and fire late tonight killed at least two miners and trapped twenty-two others 200 feet below the surface of the Viking Mine here.

Two spring benefits are planned for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. Blocks of seats have been taken for a concert by the Amsterdam Concertgebouw under the baton of Eugen Jochum at Carnegie Hall on April 19 and the May 4 performance by the Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Trans-Atlantic airlines were reported ready to reduce cargo rates independently starting April 10 if no agreement was reached before then.
" BIKINIS are never worn by the right people," according to Marc Bohan, whose first collection for Christian Dior recently created excitement in Paris.
JERUSALEM, March 2 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi accused Israel's politicians today of having plunged the country into "confusion and chaos."

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The incentive payment the Government will make to growers on 1960 crop wool is expected to be very close to the 1959 rate of 43.2 cents for each dollar they received from the sale of the product.

FOR a belated observance of its twenty-fifth anniversary, Life magazine sponsored a ninety-minute television program last night on Channel 4. Except for Gerald Greens moving essay on war, illustrated by some excellent pictures and narrated by Fredric March, it was a nondescript presentation, not especially inspired as entertainment nor rewarding as journalism.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 2 -- The six winners of the annual Rockefeller Public Service Awards were announced today.

The Federal Reserve gave a somewhat bigger nudge to intermediate-term United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, figures. published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.

Events today: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Telemann Society Orchestra and Chorus, Town Hall, 5:45; Fordham University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:40; Chamber Music of Harold Boatrite, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2 -- The Government announced today that President Tito of Yugoslavia had accepted an invitation to visit Brazil.
" The Million Dollar Incident," a show in which Jackie Gleason is kidnapped, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System of April 21 from 8:30 to 10 P.M.

Nine driving examiners of the Department of Motor Vehicles were suspended yesterday on charges of bribery. Four were indicted by a Bronx County grand jury on charges of bribery and perjury, and taken into custody.
The seven-story elevator apartment building at 2788 Broadway, near West 108th Street, has been resold by clients of Walter Scott Co. to East Side Equities, Inc.
Are talented and trained young people being driven out of the advertising profession because of the climate prevailing within the business ?
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Now we know why the Attorney General keeps a football in his office. He keeps it there to have a football to throw around the office.
BOSTON, March 2 (UPI) --Johnny Bucyk's three goals within six minutes of the second period led the last-place Boston Bruins to a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will speak in Washington on June 1 at a Republican Congressional testimonial dinner.

A strip of land only nine inches wide and 100 feet deep on the north side of West Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue, is one of 604 city-owned properties to be auctioned at a three-day sale starting March 28.
MIAMI, Fla., March 2 -- The Government has begun a pilot program to ease the job worries of Cuban refugees.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Adverse weather throughout much of the South and East last week combined with a holiday to keep rail and truck freight loadings below seasonal patterns.

RABAT, Morocco, March 2 -- President Bourguiba of Tunisia left Morocco today after four days of intense activity here and in France that have strengthened the impression that he is the predominant statesman in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals upheld today a prison sentence given Ernest Mark High of New York for refusing to appear as a witness before the Senate Rackets Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) -- Dr. Robert C. Weaver, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, said today a drop of homebuilding to one of the lowest ebbs since World War II was perpetuating the nation's economic slowdown.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that operating revenues rose in 1960, but net income fell.
The New England Council said yesterday the best immediate solution for the deficit-ridden New Haven Railroad might well be bankruptcy.

Could it be that electronic computers of the International Business Machines Corporation have heart enough to be partial? Yesterday one of them spewed out the news that I.B.M. stock showed the largest rise in points of any common stpck listed on the New York Stock Exchange in the first two months of this year.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 2 -- Four former members of the executive committee of the Liberal party in Nassau County were arraigned here today on charges of perjury and violation of the penal law in filing petitions for the party.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Adolph Zukor, the 88-year-old dean of the movie industry, looked back more than fifty years today to show that censorship is nothing new in his field.

The New York State Harness Racing Commission has revamped several of its rules for 1961. The principal changes are designed to eliminate conflict of interest caused by partnerships and the division of stables among several trainers.

HOLY LOCH, Scotland, Friday, March 3 (AP) -- Young Scotsmen early today scattered a sea blockade being massed by a little band of English pacifists against the arrival here of a United States Polaris submarine tender.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- The Kennedy Administration said in Congressional testimony made public today that it would present a revised foreign aid program. It said that the program would take a sounder approach to the problem of helping other countries.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Kennedy Administration, in an attempt to reach an agreement with the Soviet Union on a prohibition of nuclear tests, is preparing to make a concession on a crucial issue.

PARIS, March 2 -- Thirteen of the nineteen persons on trial were acquitted by a military tribunal today of charges of participation in the European insurrection against France in Algiers in January, 1960.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 2 -- Sir Roy Welensky threatened today to resign as Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland if British proposals for the new Northern Rhodesia Constitution were not altered.
The massive arms and powerful legs of Gary Gubner continued their assault yesterday on local shot-put records.

It has been half a century since Dwight D. Eisenhower, by way of West Point, first entered the Army. It has been about nine years since he gave up commissioned rank in the Army in order to run for President. Now he would like the old rank and the five stars back again, and in this desire his chivalrous successor as President supports him.
Seventh and eight graders will strut and sway Hawaiian style at a dance next Friday at the Town Tennis Club. The theme of the evening will be a "Hawaiian Hoe-Down."

Sales of new life insurance by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company last year fell 12.7 per cent below the level of 1959, according to the company's annual report is sued yesterday. However, new highs were recorded in payments to policyholders and beneficiaries, insurance in force, assets, and the number of persons insured.
THE South African Government was infuriated some time ago by a sign placed at the entrance to the Anglican Cathedral of St. George in Capetown.
The management of the Alleghany Corporation lost a big round in its battle to repel a proxy contest against it by John D. Murchison and his brother, Clint W. Murchison Jr., Texas oil millionaires.

Premium volume of the Allstate Insurance Companies, Skokie, Ill., last year totaled $502,348,000, Arthur Oakes, vice president, reported yesterday. This was a gain of $63,767,000, or 14.5 per cent, over the previous record in 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Christian A. Herter, former Secretary of State, has been appointed to the honorary council of the International Movement for Atlantic Union.
TERROR and fury roared across the stage of the City Center last night as the House of Moliere turned to Racine.
The Federal Aviation Agency has issued a certificate of airworthiness for the new Boeing 707-120B jetliner, this country's first turbofan transport.

TOKYO, March 2 -- Far-Left Socialist leaders and even further-Left student leaders in Japan promised today not to stir up any demonstrations if former President Dwight D. Eisenhower carried out his plan to visit this country in the fall.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (UPI) -- The French-bred Wolfram, star of Florida's grass racing, captured the $28,850 Arcadia Handicap by about a length over the Santa Anita turf course today.

Only the spot March cottonseed oil position closed down yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. Trading was nervous and prices fluctuated over a wide range. Final quotations were 9 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) off to 12 up on 1,238 tank cars of 60,000 pounds a car.

The military weaknesses of the United Nations and the primitive society and tribal loyalties of the Congo were jointly responsible, during the last few days, for another crisis in the Republic's unending series of crises.
BRASILIA, March 2 (UPI) -- Adolf A. Berle Jr. said today the United States considered the Cuban problem a continental issue that could not be mediated by any individual Western Hemisphere nation.
Stocks closed a little higher yesterday after doggedly fighting their way out of a sell-off that came in the noon hour.

ONE of the gayest spring accessories to arrive in New York is the rattan planter at Anne Davis, 220 East Fifty-eighth Street. Shaped like a giant coffee cup (handle included), it comes with attached rattan saucer for $1.
ROME, March 2 -- Let others worry about continents aflame, new frontiers or outer space. Rome does not care as long as it has a good murder mystery.

I have been a Director of the Associated Hospital Plan of Blue Cross for a good many years and have recently served as chairman of the Compensation Committee. The impressions being given the public by uncontested politically inspired statements are so far off that the 7,000,000 Blue Cross members in New York should be given the truth.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- If you happen to be the fleshy sort and inclined to worry about your weight, here's a tip from Jesse Lemar Gonder, a fine young catching prospect now training with the Yankees.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 3 (AP) -- Forest Evashevski, athletic director at the University of Iowa, is considering an offer to become physical fitness director of the nation's new Peace Corps.

BONN, Germany, March 3 -- The West Germany Government declared through its top soldier today that "under all circumstances we must maintain'' and be prepared to use the atomic deterrent power of the Atlantic alliance's frontline troops.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 27 -- It is traditionally dangerous in politics to try to make new friends by abandoning old ones. But that is what a majority of European Rhodesians believe the United States is doing here and elsewhere in Africa.

Offerings of tax-exempt bonds in February aggregated $611,331,377, compared with $621,614,071 for February, 1960, and a revised total of $706,395,833 for January of this year, according to The Bond Buyer. This brought the total for the first two months of this year to $1,317,727,210, almost unchanged from last year's two-month total of $1,317,329,766.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today a major reorganization primarily to cope with the problems of rapid change in the airline industry.
WARSAW, March 3 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski has called upon the Roman Catholic clergy to close ranks and "prepare for the worst" in a deepening struggle for survival of the church in Poland.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 3 -- Sir Patrick Renison, British Governor of Kenya, has decided that four leaders of the two main African parties may visit Jomo Kenyatta to ascertain his views on the present political situation and his intentions.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Kennedy appealed to Americans today to develop and preserve the nation's natural resources.

MIAMI, March 3 -- Fair Gal of the Sunshine Stable adhered to a straight course and won the $25,200 Florida Breeders' Stakes today by a head from Mrs. Anson A. Bigelow's Scan tee Sky. The race was the feature of the final day of Hialeah's forty-day meeting, and 16,540 fans turned out.

Even small children were campaigning actively in West Greenwich Village yesterday against Mayor Wagner's proposal that fourteen blocks of their neighborhood be surveyed as a blighted area for redevelopment.

Governor Rockefeller and his wife, along with the servants, escaped unharmed from the midnight fire that seriously damaged the Executive Mansion in Albany. That is all that greatly matters, although the loss of irreplaceable works of art, some generously left behind by Governor Harriman and others brought by Governor Rockefeller, is occasion for regret and sympathy.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today aluminum exports increased sharply last year while imports declined.

LONDON, March 3 -- A Laborite Member of Parliament accused right-wing Conservatives today of scoffing at President Kennedy's concept of a peace corps. One of the Conservatives, Viscount Hinchingbrooke, spoke of the "extreme naivete of President Kennedy's proposal."

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Farm equipment, lumber, fruit and vegetable and bakery spokesmen urged the Senate Labor subcommittee today to reject or sharply modify President Kennedy's minimum-wage bill.

The outlook in the steel industry continued to be mixed yesterday, as some companies reduced output while others saw signs of an improvement in demand. Logan T. Johnston, president of the Armco Steel Corporation, said that the company's new orders were showing an increase.
The United States Government is now taking action that it ought to have taken a long time ago with regard to irregular Chinese troops in the East Burma-North Laos area.
The Brazilian Government has found itself in the position of providing a test case for its attempts to halt the smuggling of coffee out of Latin America.
Two manufacturers of television sets assailed yesterday a proposal for a law requiring all new sets to be equipped for reception on Channels 2 through 83.
PUTEAUX, France, March 3 -- The biggest exposition of homemaking in French history was opened officially here this afternoon, a day before its gates are thrown open to an eager public.
BOWIE, Md., March 3 (AP) -- Nibrud, owned by Cary C. Boshamer, won the Glendale Purse by two lengths today at the Bowie Race Course. She paid. $9.40 for $2 to win.

WASHINGTON, March 3 --The creation of a Presidential task force to determine national aviation goals for the Nineteen Sixties was announced at the White House today. Air passenger travel is expected to double during the ten-year period.
The American Jewish Congress yesterday urged "prompt action" by the State Commission Against Discrimination in reviewing alleged discrimination against Jews by the Arabian American Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Pentagon agreed today to restudy its plans for sharp cutbacks at the large materiel supply area of the Griffiss Air Force Base at Rome, N.Y. The Rome area has been classified as one with heavy unemployment.

From morning to midnight today athletes of varying ages will be racing around wooden tracks at Madison Square Garden and the 102d Engineers Armory. In the number of the competitors it may well be New York's biggest day in track this season.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Following is the text of a joint communique made public by the White House today after the meeting between President Kennedy and the Prime Minister of New Zealand, Keith J. Holyoake:
School boards were advised yesterday against the purchase of teaching machines until the devices overcame present limitations.
FOUR months may not be an impressive length of time as history goes, but it is a sizable hunk in a symphony orchestra season that starts at the end of September and ends in the middle of April.

The board of directors of the Midwest Piping Company, Inc., approved yesterday an offer by the Crane Company to purchase all the physical assets of the piping and welded-fitting concern for a price estimated at $22.20 a share.
New York City's five Republican county leaders are agreed that their candidate for Mayor need not necessarily be a Republican.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -The House and Senate Armed Services Committees approved unanimously today a bill to restore former President Dwight D. Eisenhower to the five-star rank of General of the Army.
CINCINNATI, March 3 (UPI) -- Frank Robinson, outfielder and first baseman of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team, was indicted today on a charge of carrying a concealed weapon.
NORWALK, Conn., March 3 -- A fire in a transformer substation burned four men here today and disrupted electric power for varying periods here and in Westport, Wilton and New Canaan.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- A woman spokesman for the Republican party said today that President Kennedy had stolen her party's philosophies.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 3 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, Laotian neutralist leader, offered a concession, tonight to the Rightist Government in Vientiane.

RICHMOND, Va., March 3 (UPI) -- William and Mary, sparked by Jeff Cohen's 38 points, upset West Virginia, 88 -- 76, tonight to end the Mountaineers' six-year domination of the Southern Conference basketball tournament.

SALTY will be a key word in fashion during the next five years, according to John Weitz, dynamic young sportswear designer. With the power boat fast taking the place of the sports car as a national status symbol, he believes that everyone will want to look "salty" instead of "racy."
Suffolk County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge was cleared yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn of a conviction for conspiracy to induce another person to commit perjury.

This week in Wall Street could be described, in Shakespeare's words, as "full of sound and fury, signifying nothing." Trading on the Big Board was at a furious pace of 27,102,906 shares. That is the busiest since the week ended on July 22, 1933, when 42,329,633 shares changed hands.
The body of a mother whose 5-year-old son drowned on Wednesday was pulled from the East River yesterday afternoon. Two other sons, one 6 and one 3, are missing, and the police fear they also drowned.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Kennedy and New Zealand's Prime Minister, Keith J. Holyoake, expressed "deep concern" today about what they called Communist China's "hostile and aggressive attitude."

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 3 -- United Nations troops, acting under Security Council authority to use force to maintain order, killed a Congolese soldier today at Banana, 250 miles southwest of here.
WASHINGTON, March 3--A bill to create seventy-three Federal judgeships breezed through the Senate today on a voice vote.
William S. Gaud, a Connecticut resident and member of a New York City law firm, was reported last night to be the likely choice for new United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

B.H. Gordon Co., realty operators, have sold the five-story building containing sixty-five apartments at 1215-17-19 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, to an investor. The property, 150 by 114 feet, was sold through Irving Bira, broker.

DUNOON, Scotland, March 3 -- The Proteus steamed up the gray, wind-whipped Firth of Clyde and into Holy Loch today to become the first tender and depot ship for the United States Polaris-missile submarines that will soon be joining her.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- The February grand jury recommended today the legalization of prostitution, lotteries and off-track pari-mutuel betting in Philadelphia.
Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that he thought it was "absolutely necessary" to have United Nations troops in the Congo.
TOPEKA, Kan., March 3--The two RB-47 fliers who were recently freed by the Soviet Union said today that their jet plane fought back with two tail cannon when it was shot down last July 1.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 3 -- United States tax incentives that stimulate "the expatriation of American industry" to dollar-rich countries should be eliminated, James P. Warburg, author and economist, said here tonight.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 3 (UPI) -- Sugar Ray Robinson said tonight he would pull out of tomorrow night's middleweight title fight with Gene Fullmer unless the promoters provided a ring larger than the "sixteen-foot telephone booth they're trying to put me in."

CHARLES H. GOREN, who is celebrating his sixtieth birthday today, has come to be known throughout the world as "Mr. Bridge." In all countries more bridge players follow his teachings than those of the many other authorities combined.
PARIS, March 3 -- Already two months behind schedule, the present world tariff negotiations in Geneva are approaching the stage of crisis.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 4 points (20 cents) off yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I. March 3 -- Brown University weathered a rally by Columbia and scored a 66-62 Ivy League victory tonight.

TWO antiques shows are simultaneous attractions in New York, an embarrassment of riches that will faze few devotees. The newcomer is the Antiques Fair of Westchester Enterprises, which opens at the Coliseum at 1 P.M. today and will run through March 12.

Four designs have survived the first stage of New Jersey's competition to select an architect for the state's building at the New York World's Fair. The building and its exhibition will be a part of the state's tercentenary celebration in 1964.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3--Asian and African nations moved quickly today to meet Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's request for more troops to keep order in the Congo.
Soviet workers' fear of injury from radioactivity is hindering the application in Soviet industry of valuable new techniques based on nuclear physics.
Senator Barry Goldwater told a cheering, stomping audience last night that the country was caught up in a wave of conservatism that could easily become "the political phenomenon of our time."

The Fred Wittner Company, an advertising and public relations concern, has leased space in the building being constructed by Uris Brothers at 850 Third Avenue, at Fifty-first Street. The lessee which now occupies three floors in the buildings at 581 Fifth Avenue and 26 West Forty-fifth Street, will consolidate its offices on one floor.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 3 (UPI) -- An economy rocket carried a secret package of telescopes and other instruments to an altitude of 1,580 miles today for a close-up look at the earth's radiation fields.
TRENTON, March 3 (AP) -- Formal applications for the sale of New Jersey's only harness racing track, Freehold Raceway, have been filed with the State Racing Commission, it was learned today.
One of the least expected but most rapid economic developments in post-war France is the industrialization of the Riviera

LOS ANGELES, March 3 (UPI) -- A witness at the trial of Frank Carbo and four others testified today he was told that a movie actor, George Raft, would attend a meeting to "straighten out" a scheme by the defendants to get 15 per cent of Don Jordan's purse for a title bout.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 -- Act Two of the Fifteenth General Assembly opens here next Tuesday without the dramatic cast that dominated the fall performance but with the same major theme -- the Congo.
In an editorial on March 2 you state that there will be "no ugly Americans" among the workers of the Peace Corps.

Fred J. Thompson, who was indicted Thursday for the slaying of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorius on Feb. 22, was committed to Bellevue Hospital by General Sessions Judge Thomas Dickens yesterday for psychiatric examination.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House Appropriations Committee refused today to increase the lending authority of the Development Loan Fund by $150,000,000, as requested by President Kennedy.

New York International Airport, which already has its own bank, chapel, hotel, newspaper, medical building, post office, fire and police departments, theatre group, and bus service, began adding street signs and building addresses yesterday.
I have been greatly surprised by the letter from A.L. Colloms published in your issue of March 1.
NEW ORLEANS, March 31 (UPI) -- Doug Sanders shot a seven-under-par 65 for 133 to take a three-stroke lead after the second round of the $30,000 New Orleans open golf tournament today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3 (UPI) -- A Federal court today gave Shelby Jackson, Louisiana's Superintendent of Education, until March 24 to prove that he would not interfere with the Orleans Parish School Board.
A dearth of major corporate securities offerings in the market for new capital next week will be offset by a moderately active schedule of major tax-exempt offerings.
" If the 'Ship American' campaign is carried through to the bitter end, it would hit ,Norway harder than any other country," Nils Dybwad, a Norwegian admiralty lawyer, said yesterday.

Trading activity in potato futures spurted yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. At the day's close, 3,402 lots of 50,000 pounds each had changed hands at prices unchanged to 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) off.
Commutation fares for New Haven Railroad commuters who live in Westchester County will be raised by 10 per cent Monday.
The temperature shot up to 64 degrees at 4:15 P.M. yesterday, setting a record for March 3 in the city.
An argument on whether teachers are members of a craft or a profession enlivened a public hearing held yesterday by the Board of Education's Commission on Inquiry.
JERSEY CITY, March 3 -- A court tonight ordered that a child be given a blood transfusion over the religious objections of the parents.

Mayor Wagner's ban on nonessential driving after last month's snowstorm was successfully challenged yesterday on a legal technicality. The point of law was; in effect, that the Mayor is not a traffic patrolman.
A dissident group in the local branch of the Marine Enginers Beneficial Association has challenged the legality of its district leadership.
Thousands of spring flowers will be on view today when the forty-fourth International Flower Show opens in the Coliseum at 2 P.M.
The appointment of Capt. Milton Breece as operations manager of its marine division has been announced by the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 3 (AP) -- Frank McKinney of Indiana and Ron Clark of Michigan set American and National Collegiate swimming records tonight in the Big Ten championships. Steve Jackman of Minnesota broke a National Collegiate record in the afternoon.
DETROIT, March 3 AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that new car sales may have improved almost 13 per cent in the closing days of February from the midmonth sales rate.
YONKERS, March 3 -- An $80,000,000 "dream city" planned for a woodland tract on the Yonkers-Greenburgh boundary was called a "bad dream for taxpayers" today by the Yonkers Civic Action Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency today banned airliner take-offs under conditions of poor visibility.

THE twentieth-century School of Paris may be receding into history but in doing so it becomes more monumental and impressive in the way that a mountain range reveals its full might only when seen from some distance.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Federal District Court here turned down today last-minute requests for tighter controls over a newly ordered convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 3 -A high-level Government financial team of the United States will arrive here next week on an emergency mission to examine Bolivia's appeal for an immediate special aid program involving $20,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 (UPI)--The United States Court of Appeals today ordered Frank Carbo, the alleged underworld boxing ruler, and three co-defendants freed on bail during their current extortion trial in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Navy investigators ruled today that a combination of factors -- including clouds and an air traffic controller's faulty judgment -- helped cause the collision a year ago of a Brazilian airliner and a United States Navy plane near Rio de Janeiro.
REPRINTED below are two letters that were received by the food news department of The Times.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Memphis man is supplying colleges and high schools with special wheelbarrows for athletes to trundle. Each "muscle wagon" carries a twenty-gallon cylindrical tank in which water sloshes back and forth, forcing the user to lift as well as push.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted today to give the State Department $600,000 to battle new wiretapping techniques said to be threatening file security of United States Embassies abroad.

An armed bank employe chased and captured two robbery suspects yesterday after the two men had stolen $3,862 from a 55-year-old messenger while he was in an elevator at 53 Beaver Street in the financial district.
The Treasury reported yesterday that sales of savings bonds in February exceeded redemptions for the second consecutive month.
An increase of 67 per cent in earnings for 1960 was reported yesterday by the Pabst Brewing Company. The Milwaukee concern also reported a rise of 2 per cent in sales.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House Appropriations Committee called upon the Pentagon today to appoint "at once" a single head to carry out the construction of missile bases.
Christians and Jews over the nation will place special emphasis this coming week on their year-round efforts to help the homeless, the hungry and the destitute overseas.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania kept alive its chances for an Ivy League basketball title tie with Princeton tonight with a 94-63 rout of Harvard at the Palestra.
The Department of Real Estate took steps yesterday to prevent one developer from eliminating competition for a choice Brooklyn parcel that the city will sell at auction on March 15.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The general level of wholesale primary market prices for all commodities held at 119.8 per cent of its 1947-49 average during the week ended Tuesday, Feb. 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- Donald Ross left the Federal Renegotiation Board today, but Herschel Loveless was still waiting to take over the $20,000 post.
The Fordham University Glee Club departed somewhat from usual male glee club tradition in its annual concert in Town Hall last night.
New York University placed first in four of ten qualifying events last night and established itself as the favorite in the Metropolitan Collegiate swimming championships.

JERSEY CITY, March 3 -- Two of this city's best-known apartment buildings, the Duncan Arms and the Gothic Towers, will change hands in a $2,100,000 real estate transaction. The contract was filed today at the Hudson County Register's Office.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 3 (AP) -- Top-seeded Wake Forest routed Maryland, 98 -- 76, tonight to gain the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament. It was the highest score ever run up on a Maryland team and missed tying the tourney record by 3 points.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg reported today that the number of persons drawing unemployment compensation rose by 31,700 to a record of 3,422,300 in the week that ended Feb. 18.
Consumer prices in the United States, as measured by the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, declined in January by one-tenth of 1 per cent -- the first such downturn recorded in twelve months.

MALCOLM MUGGERIDGE is sometimes called "the man who made Punch readers laugh again." The implication that he changed the attitude of that celebrated magazine's parishioners during his recent editorship is an awesome tribute to his power. We see a complementary aspect of it in his novel, "Affairs of the Heart."*
PRINCETON, N.J., March 3 -- Princeton clinched a tie for the Ivy League basketball championship tonight by defeating Dartmouth, 68 -- 54, before a crowd of 2,500.
MORE women hold jobs outside the home than ever before, but the employer is not always content with their presence.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 3 -- Intelligence officials of Nationalist China said today that they feared Burma had made a secret agreement with Communist China requesting Communist troops to oust Chinese Nationalist guerrillas from northern Burma.
LOS ANGELES, March 3--California's dominant but ever-squabbling Democrats are trying to pull themselves together against a possible onslaught from Richard M. Nixon and the Republicans next year.
ALBANY, March 3 -- At least $350,000 worth of paintings from two leading collections were destroyed or damaged this morning in the fire that swept the Governor's Mansion.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The damage to the Executive Mansion by the fire that swept it early today has raised the question whether the century-old structure should be rebuilt or replaced.

LONDON, March 3 -- Encouraged by yesterday's advance on Wall Street, share prices went ahead strongly in the stock market here today. The Financial Times industrial shares index added 2.3 points at 331.2, for a rise of 4.8 points on the week.

Eight savings and loan associations in metropolitan New York and New Jersey are among the 100 largest in the nation, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday. The two largest associations in the country and five of the first ten, however, are situated in California.
Mayor Wagner's seven years in office have been the "best" in the city's history, Paul R. Screvane said yesterday as he was sworn in as Deputy Mayor.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 3 -- State legislators from Nassau County said today they had agreed on a legislative program incorporating sixteen bills that would affect governmental operations in Nassau and its three towns.

The Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex., received yesterday a copy of the stockholders' list of Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company which controls Investors Diversified Services, Inc., and the New York Central Railroad.
MANAMA, Bahrein, Feb. 21 -- On this little island, where little things are important, the ruling sheik is showing his independence in little ways.
The annual May Festival Ball for the benefit of Just One Break, Inc., will be held on May 15 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Soybean futures prices pulled out of their steep two-day slide on the Board of Trade today and finished with substantial gains on all contracts.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 3 -- The property and building of the King School have been sold to Congregation Agudath Sholem and the school has acquired the fifty-acre estate of the late Richard L. Simon at Newfield Avenue.

RABAT, Morocco, March 3 -- The new King of Morocco, Hassan II, solemnly pledged today to follow the example set by the late King Mohammed V, and asked that the people show him the same fidelity given to his father.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 3 -- Hofstra's quintet defeated Drexel, 77 -- 55 tonight and advanced to the final of the Middle Atlantic Conference College Division basketball championship. The Flying Dutchmen will meet Albright for the title.
Drivers and helpers employed by seven magazine wholesalers went on strike early yesterday, halting the distribution of some magazines in the city and on Long Island.
A program of Baroque music was presented in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon by the Telemann Society Orchestra and Chorus with Janet Wheeler, soprano, as soloist.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 3 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey announced tonight that he would send a special message to the General Assembly on Tuesday asking for quick enactment of a law suspending the gross profits tax now paid to the state by the New Haven Railroad. The tax amounts to $1,200,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -The Kennedy Administration is disturbed by Bolivia's deteriorating economic situation. It wants to help the Government, but it wants that help directed at Bolivia's basic ills.
New York and Philadelphia will be the scene of auditions next week for instrumentalists who want study in orchestra and chamber music performance at the Berkshire Music Center next summer.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 3 -- Prime Minister Abubakar Tafawa Balewa hinted today that French nationals might he expelled from Nigeria if France carried out her intention to conduct another nuclear test in the Sahara next month.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 3 -- The United Nations warned President Moise Tshombe tonight that it intended to stay in Katanga Province, by force if necessary and for as long as necessary, until the Security Council decided it should leave.

The Nassau County Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children will benefit Monday from the third annual fashion show and luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. William S. Paley and Mrs. David Rankin Craig Jr. are co-chairmen of the event.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 3 -- A campaign to obtain additional state aid for schools in Nassau County received support today from the county's Republican administration.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., Feb. 14 -- On a cold, gray February day, modern Kiev is barren of beauty but the city is bustling as it works to change its ancient, battle-scarred face.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 3 -- Three persons who were arrested last July 14 in a raid on an alleged numbers game bank pleaded not guilty today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 3 -- The United States and Brazil have "agreed to disagree" on policies toward Cuba.

With Ambassador Llewellyn Thompson's return to Moscow, the stage has obviously been set for the beginning of serious diplomatic contacts between the Kennedy Administration and Premier Khrushchev. Since the relations between the Soviet Union and our country are the fulcrum on which much of the current world situation depends, these initial contacts in Moscow will be extraordinarily important.

THE man selected by President Kennedy to direct a study of the nation's aviation goals is a gregarious native of Mississippi who has moved about the air industry with the restlessness of a barnstormer.

An atmosphere of assurance surged back into the market for United States Government securities yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve's most recent substantial purchases of Treasury obligations of other than short-term maturity.
Elmer Werthiemer, the European impresario who fled to this country in 1952 from Communist rule in Hungary, will resume his managerial career off Broadway this spring.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Representatives from seven newspaper craft unions ended today a two-day meeting on merger prospects with a promise to meet again.
The New York City Community Mental Health program is in a financial "strait-jacket" and will not get out until the state gives it more money, a group of mental health experts said yesterday.
A bank building put up on Tenth Street and Avenue D when John Quincy Adams was President and William Cullen Bryant was the lion of New York literary circles, appears doomed.
Net income and sales of Texas Instruments, Inc., rose to record levels last year, the company announced yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, March 3 -- American Jewish leaders said today that the two elements required by Israel to achieve economic independence were greater financial resources for investment and skilled young American manpower.
SAVANNAH, Ga., March 3 (UPI) -- The city of Savannah has opened its municipal golf course to Negroes and has named a Negro to one of its park comissions, it was disclosed today.
After many disappointments, hopes are soaring that the more than six-year-long war against French domination is coming to an end.
Leontyne Price added another beautiful interpretation to her list of Metropolitan Opera successes last night when she sang the title role of "Madama Butterfly" for the first time with the company.

OTTAWA, Ill., March 3 (UPI) -- A jury found Chester Weger guilty today of bludgeoning to death of Mrs. Lillian Oetting, one of three women murdered in Starved Rock State Park a year ago. The jury recommended that he be sentenced to life in prison.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 3 (AP) -- The bodies of twenty-two men were brought out of the Viking coal mine near here today.

A Commemorative Centenary Volume of Rabindranath Tagore's writings will be published May 8 by Taplinger, entitled "Towards Universal Man." The volume's thirty essays by the Indian poet-philosopher, selected by more than 100 scholars of his work, were translated into English by a group of people chosen by a committee headed by Prof. Humayun Kabir, India's Minister for Scientific Research and Cultural Affairs.

The mass recreation plan and the proposed commercial tree-cutting in our State Forest Preserve were first made clear to the public in your Feb. 23 editorial. Robert Moses, in his reply, published Feb. 27, confirms in full the basis for the apprehension expressed in your editorial.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., United States Ambassador, disclosed today that he had asked to meet Premier Khrushchev "anywhere and at any time" to hand over a message from President Kennedy.
The New York Rangers, their Stanley Cup play-off hopes virtually abandoned, have decided to give some of their farm-hands a taste of National League hockey.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Atomic Energy Commission canceled plans today to build a small atomic power plant at Jamestown, N.Y. The action emphasized the growing problem of finding a safe yet economical site for such plants.

Twentieth Century-Fox, following the current Broadway pattern of adapting musicals from successful dramatic films, plans to feature Frank Sinatra in a new song-and-dance version of their 1945 drama, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."
St. John's, headed for the National Collegiate regional basketball play-offs, and Manhattan will meet in the feature game of the double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Detroit, Mich., is planning the sale of $10,000,000 of school bonds on March 28. The issue will come due serially from 1962 to 1987.

ALBANY, March 3 -- More than 1,000 landlords, apparently resigned to a two-year extension of rent control, demanded today that the Legislature couple any continuation with a plan for the progressive lifting of restrictions.

HAVANA, March 3 -- Bitter fighting has occurred between Government troops and anti-Castro rebels in the mountains around Guantanamo and Baracoa, according to reports reaching Havana today. Casualties late said to have been heavy on both sides.
The sixth annual March of Dimes Humanitarian Award was presented to Bob Hope last night at a dinner in the Commodore Hotel.

RABAT, Morocco, March 3 -- The Moroccan Minister of Information said at a news conference today that there had been "secret contacts" between the French Government and the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government.

DETROIT, March 3 -- Circuit Court Judge Henry L. Beers took under advisement today a request of the Chrysler Corporation for a temporary injunction against prosecution of a suit by its former president, William C. Newberg, against the company's present president and chairman, Lester L. Colbert.

Events today: "Turandot" at 2 P.M. and "Elektra" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; New York Philharmonic, Andre Kostelanetz, conductor, Ozan Marsh, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Odetta, folk singer, Town Hall, 8:30; Florence Brown, folk singer, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Mandolin Orchestra, Samuel Firstman, conductor, William Wolf, tenor, Judson Hall, 8:30.
SALISBURY, England, March 3 (Reuters) -- For the second consecutive night, vandals daubed paint on several prehistoric stone slabs of renowned Stonehenge near here last night.
Valeri Brumel, an 18-year-old Russian, said farewell to the United States last night by creating a world indoor high jump record for the second time in three weeks.
BELIZE, British Honduras, March 3 (Reuters) -- The Left-Wing People's United party emerged today with unchallenged control of this British colony's legislature.
WHITE PLAINS, March 3 -- County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian was criticized anew today for seeking abolition of of the semi-autonomous Westchester County Park and Recreation Commissions.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 3 (AP) -- Attorneys for The New York Times charged today that a jury that returned a $500,000 libel suit judgment against the newspaper and four Negro ministers had been prejudiced.
The State Investigation Commission's right to examine records of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation has been unanimously affirmed by the State Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- A flying surgeon today blamed "the pilot's lack of knowledge and proficiency" for most of the noncommercial aviation accidents that cost 835 lives last year.

HERSHEY, Pa., March 3 (UPI) -- The Detroit Pistons rallied tonight to down the New York Knickerbockers, 129 -- 112. By winning, the Pistons stayed out of the Western Division cellar in the National Basketball Association.
Not so long ago, an advertising agency conducted an experiment to test the efficiency of corporate recruiting for engineers. The results, as reported by The New York Times, were somewhat startling.
Urban renewal will be the "New Frontier" of the Federal Housing Administration, an official of the F.H.A. told a conference of mayors here yesterday.
Columbia University is confronted with a platinum problem.

Five European designers -- Jacques Helm, Jean Desses, Simonetta, Fabiani and Roberto Capucci -- have turned their talents to shoe design. The styles, which are designed in Europe and made in the United States, make up an exclusive spring collection that is being introduced in Chandler shops throughout the country.

PARIS, March 3 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, retiring Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that the United Nations was in danger and that it threatened to become a danger to others.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 3 (AP) -- Three-year-old horses campaigning in California go on display tomorrow in the $145,100 Santa Anita Derby, a major preview of the division in 1961.
CHAMBER music by Harold Boatrite, a young American composer who has studied with Stanley Hollingsworth, Lukas Foss, and Aaron Copland, made up a program presented in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 -- Following are items approved for inclusion on the agenda of the resumed session of the fifteenth session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene here Tuesday, and proposed additional items (explanatory material within parentheses was compiled by the United Nations Office of Public Information):
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- Arthur Schlesinger Jr., special assistant to President Kennedy, told the President today that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was losing his appeal in Latin America.
Norway's Storting (Parliament) has been asked to allow an appeal to be taken to the United States Supreme Court in a thirty-four-year-old $63,000,000 maritime legal dispute.

ATHENS, March 3 -- Within a few days NATO, our most important alliance, will have another Secretary General to start the critical process of revising Western strategy for the decade of nuclear-missiles, Polaris submarines and, perhaps, whirling space platforms.
President Kennedy is moving in the right direction to establish a nation-wide physical fitness program, according to a 65-year-old educator who still does push-ups.

LOS ANGELES, March 4 -- With a handful of political cards of uncertain denomination clutched close to his vest, Richard M. Nixon returned to his native California this week to start a new chapter in the meteoric political career which carried him, in fourteen years, from neophyte Congressman to narrowly defeated Presidential candidate.
A major test case involving the adequacy of coach service provided by the nation's airlines on short-haul routes was argued before the Civil Aeronautics Board last week.

IN the past six weeks, President Kennedy has been trying to grow extra hands that can help him grip the vast work of his office. These now constitute his Kitchen Cabinet, whose form directly reflects Mr. Kennedy's wish to be a President in Franklin D. Roosevelt's style.
NEW DELHI, India, March 4 -- Pakistan appears to be undergoing a searching reappraisal of her strong ties to the West.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The White House named today fourteen persons who will assist R. Sargent Shriver, newly appointed director of the Peace Corps, in organizing its pilot programs. Garden centers look forward to a busy spring. Home gardening activities should be greater than ever because of the severe winter.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Greater freight volume but a drop in revenue from the previous year characterized the operations in 1960 of members of the Inland Waterways Common Carriers Association, Patrick Calhoun Jr., president, has announced.

PARIS, March 4 -- The decision by West Germany to increase the value of the Deutsche mark by 5 per cent was generally welcomed in Europe today. The move was regarded as helping to remove a "fundamental imbalance" in international trade and payments.
PARIS, March 4 -- Britain dipped another toe in the waters of Europe this week, but she continues to tantalize onlookers everywhere on the question of whether she will ever take the full plunge.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 5 (AP) -- The House of Representatives approved without revision today a new budget for the 1961 fiscal year calls for major increases in expenditures for social security, public works and school.

Africa has engaged the world's attention more and more during the past half-dozen years as turbulence and violence have swept over the continent. A combination of currents is involved -- the African nationalist revolt against domination by the white man, the demand for a share in the fruits of the world's economic growth, the competitive pressures of cold war.

THE exhilaration of creativity came to television last week in three programs that for the moments of their magic stemmed to tide of lamentations over the state of the medium. Out of the overworked box in the parlor came electrifying excitement and beauty of art pursued and realized.
