A dinner dance on April 8 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza will benefit the Karen Horney Clinic, a psychoanalytic treatment center at 329 East Sixty-second Street.
BONN, Germany, March 4 -- The Deutsche mark was revalued upward today 5 by per cent in a move to stifle the excessive growth of West German gold and currency reserves.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- A wider emphasis on factual books than had been evident in previous years was shown on the list of "notable books of 1960" selected by the librarians' national professional association.
Former Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams walked out of a panel discussion on municipal corruption yesterday after protesting what he termed a "partisan" speech attacking Mayor Wagner.
THERE is a joke going around among family educators about a sub-urban father who came upon his 8-year-old son lighting a cigarette with a flaming $5 bill.

PARIS, March 4 -- W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador at Large, delivered today a personal message from President Kennedy to President de Gaulle expressing the desire for close personal and governmental relations but proposing no early meeting.

VIENNA, March 4 -- The Communist bloc, including Communist China, granted approximately $3,000,000,000 worth of credits for industrial development and raw materials to under-developed countries from 1953 to the middle of 1960, according to an official study made available here today.
A bizarre example of the power that belief can exert on behavior has emerged from a study just published by a Yeshiva University scientist.

BOWIE, Md., March 4 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Sun Glint flashed to a three-and-one-half-length triumph in the ninth running of the Barbara Fritchie Handicap at Bowie today before the top Saturday gathering of the meeting -- 20,905.
DE KALB, Ill., March 4 -- A common theme runs through much of the political comment in the Middle West today: "I didn't vote for Kennedy, but I think he's doing fairly well."

Fairfield won the Sherman Memorial five-goal handicap indoor polo tournament last night at the Squadron A Armory by defeating the Armory riders, 14 -- 7. It was the twenty-second championship game since 1934.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania basketball team clinched a tie for second place in the Ivy League by defeating Dartmouth, 73 -- 51, tonight.

An editorial in your Feb. 19 issue, contemplating the recent conviction of electrical equipment manufacturers under antitrust laws observes that "a candid realization of the way in which our economy actually operates these days should help us avoid hasty judgments based on outworn stereotypes."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4 -- Yale and Harvard battled to a 1-1 overtime tie tonight in the hockey finale for both teams.
PARIS -- When the vast new air passenger terminal at Orly goes into full operation next Wednesday, there will be considerable change in routine for arriving and departing air travelers here.

Political turbulence in the Congo and elsewhere in tropical Africa has tended to obscure the fact that the governments of most of the countries there are working hard to establish stable societies and expanding economies, Eric Johnston said yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, March 4 -- The entire Federal District police force has been alerted for duty tomorrow, when a pro-Communist Latin-American "peace" conference and the National Anti-Communist party will open simultaneous conventions here.

Foundation projects may be considered successful when they can stand the eventual test of living on their own momentum without philanthropic dollars. The most recent example of a success story is Norfolk, Va., where public enthusiasm has picked up the tab for a television experiment and expanded it well beyond its original borders.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The inauguration of Abraham Lincoln as the sixteenth President was re-enacted today. Under balmy sunny skies that contrasted sharply with the gloomy overcast of the original event 100 years ago, and even more strongly with the bitter cold of the Kennedy inauguration six weeks ago, a group of actors, professors, politicians and a famed poet re-created the first Lincoln inaugural. A crowd larger than the original turned out for the ceremony.

James R. Hoffa had another scalp to hitch onto his heavily freighted trophy belt last week. The hammer-listed president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters got rid of the court-appointed monitors who once had loomed as the greatest threat to his dreams of imperial rule over the country's biggest and strongest union.

Preparations are under way for the ninth annual Art Sale and Collectors Exhibition of the Women's Division, American Friends of the Hebrew University. Proceeds from the event, to be held from April 30 through May 10, will go to the Library Construction Fund of the university in Jerusalem.

The pace of inventory reduction has slowed, an indication that the recession could be near the bottom. United States manufacturers pared their inventories in January by $110,000,000 compared with an average rate of $350,000,000 for the preceding three months, the Department of Commerce announced last week.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The other day a State Department official was asked to describe the policy process under the Kennedy Administration. "It is," he said, "wonderfully chaotic."

LONDON, March 3 -- Anglican bishops, politicians and educators have joined in a public debate here on the question of allowing South Africa to remain in the Commonwealth while her Government practices apartheid.

PARIS, March 4 -- The mood of optimism and Euphoria that followed last Monday's discussion of Algerian peace prospects between President de Gaulle and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia lasted four days.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 4 -- Six Democrats will vie in a primary Tuesday for the House of Representatives seat vacated by Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., March 4 -- John J. Sandler, Secretary of the State Senate, was killed today in an automobile accident on the New York State Thruway. His wife, Celia, was reported in fair condition in Good Samaritan Hospital at Suffern, N.Y.
The Rev. Oberia D. Dempsey, associate pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the City Council seat held by Earl Brown.

AN earlier article here touched on the powers of the human ear that are responsible for stereophonic perception, and how they affect the design and use of stereo sound systems. The interested owner of high fidelity equipment can, with amazement and profit, take a quick look at some other characteristics of his hearing system that are basic to his enjoyment of reproduced sound.

Fallow, considered a leading prospect for international horse show jumping competition, has been presented to the United States equestrian team by Raymond C. Firestone, the president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio.

The forty-fourth International Flower Show opened yesterday in the New York Coliseum, and will run through next Sunday. The theme of the show, "Gardens for Outdoor Living," is reflected in exhibits spaced throughout the Coliseum's second and third, or mezzanine, floors (see floor plans below). The building, located on Columbus Circle, is conveniently served by bus and subway lines.

NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE has suffered almost as much as Herman Melville at the hands of critics with ideological axes to grind. It could hardly be otherwise, considering the dark themes Hawthorne so frequently used, considering also the legend of his hermitlike temperament.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 3 -- Getting an American visa became easier for Belgians on Feb. 13 when the State Department ruled that they could present identity cards in place of passports.

Four Harlem youths, three of them 15 years old and one 16, were accused yesterday in the fatal beating Friday of a 73 year-old storekeeper. A fifth youth, who is 14, was charged with juvenile delinquency.

TO the physical scientist, the word "rays" suggests one of two distinct meanings. Either the word describes the motion of subatomic particles of matter, or the transfer of radiant energy, both being characterized by the fact that the stream of matter or of energy is in a straight line -- constituting a ray -- unless there is some external cause of departure from such a path.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to authorize Mayor Wagner to appoint his own commission to draft a new Charter for New York City.

The economic situation in the district reveals both an element of dependence upon and independence from the national economy, economists reported in a monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Dependence is reflected in high stocks of principal raw materials from this district, including iron ore, lumber and copper.

THE steadily mushrooming swimming pool industry has, in the past year or two, introduced a wide variety of new model pools as well as a number of increasingly popular swimming pool accessories. These new products tend to make pool ownership easier than ever for the average home owner.

RABAT, Morocco, March 3 -- The long-awaited evacuation of French military forces, stationed here for fifty years, was effected without fanfare this week in the wake of the death of King Mohammed V and the accession of his son Hassan II to the Moroccan throne.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Kennedy Administration's campaign to lower interest rates has a twofold goal. On one hand, it seeks a small reduction of rates that are already low. On the other, it hopes for a more substantial reduction of those that are high, especially mortgages.

A noted planner and architect, Victor Gruen, said yesterday he had been asked by city authorities to plan redevelopment projects for the West Greenwich Village area.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 4 -- After twelve years of controversy about its public schools, this city is experiencing a degree of unity that the school superintendent said today was "hard to believe."

Early buying for Easter helped push retail sales last week in this area well above the level of the comparable 1960 period. Department store executives put the gain for the week at 25 to 30 per cent. The major reason, however, for the large year-to-year percentage increase was attributed to a poor 1960 week, in which sales were held down by bad weather.
Parents faced with the almost unbearable decision of how best to care for their mentally retarded children will be helped by a research program started last week by a New York clinic.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the final Government figure on February unemployment would be at "a record high since the great depression," or about 5,500,000.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 4 -- The Thai Seventh Division, supported by the border police, advanced yesterday on about 1,000 Chinese nationalist guerrillas who had fled into Thailand from Burma.

FRIDAY, Feb. 24, was a red-letter day for Covent Garden. On that date the great aquiline head of Otto Klemperer rose out of the orchestra pit and, with a perfunctory nod at the audience, launched into one of the most moving performances of "Fidelio" that London has been privileged to hear.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Princess Shahnaz, daughter of the Shah of Iran, and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont will be among the honored guests at the "Great Lady Ball," to be held at the Everglades Club on March 16. Mrs. Pierrepont was a leader in the establishment of the St. Mary's Pine Ridge Hospitals, beneficiaries of the gala.

SUCCESSFUL rose growing depends on a combination of things: good roses, proper planting and pruning, regular spraying, feeding and watering when needed. Roses reward this care with bloom from the end of May until frosts.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4 -- Princeton captured the Ivy League basketball championship for the second consecutive year tonight by defeating Harvard, 71 -- 59, before a crowd of 2,500 at the Dillon Gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Kennedy is a freewheeling innovator in the exercise of Presidential power.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22 -- The Yugoslav public has been shaken in recent weeks by price rises that threaten to send living costs soaring if not checked soon.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 4 -- Yale's fine sophomores lived up to advance notices today with a crashing performance in the Heptagonal Games Association indoor track championships. The meet was held in a flag-bedecked setting at Cornell University's Barton Hall before a sellout crowd of 4,500. The Elis rolled up 59 points by scoring in eleven of thirteen events. The total was a new high in this competition, which Yale won for the fourth time.
A revival of the study of Latin as a means of strengthening English, "our greatest academic weakness," was recommended yesterday by Dr. Mason W. Gross, president of Rutgers University.
WARSAW, March 4 -- The National Unity Front appealed to 18,000,000 voters this week to cast their ballots next month for a more powerful and affluent socialist Poland.
New York City's Republicans announced yesterday they were establishing a full-time research unit at 11 East Forty-seventh Street for the forthcoming Mayoralty campaign.
With considerable difficulty despite an overwhelming height advantage, Duquesne's quintet defeated Fordham, 75 -- 66, at the Rams' court in the Bronx yesterday.

IN a mixture of disappointments and triumphs, man's drive toward outer space goes forward at an accelerating pace. Now it is expected that, with final tests being conducted, the first manned space flight will come in a few months.
The latest wrinkle in power plants for jet transports -- the turbofan, or fanjet, engine -- is a major step forward in jet economy, airline operators said last week.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- An eight-year struggle to subject the Government's foreign intelligence agencies to a congressional watchdog has erupted again.

UNDER the new postal administration, issues of commemorative stamps will be limited to fifteen a year, and their preparation will "put greater emphasis on the use of professional and technical capabilities of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing."

SPACE and spectacular views are uncommon luxuries in today's apartments. Even generous square footage does not always assure a sense of spaciousness as the tenants of the cooperative home shown here discovered. It was necessary to remove partitions between the living room and the dinette to enlarge the sitting area.

Another good week of retail business has convinced most merchants that a turn for the better has been reached. Their optimism, however, is shaded with caution and they are not losing sight of the fact that even fair weekly figures would look good because they are being compared with a period last year that was seriously affected by very poor weather.
BARTLESVILLE, Okla., March 4 (UPI) -- The Phillips Oilers beat the New York Tuck Tapers, 91 -- 87, in a National Basketball League game tonight.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 4 -- Army capped the most successful hockey season in West Point annals when the cadets outclassed the Royal Military College of Canada, 7 -- 1, tonight at Smith Rink. It was the thirtieth game of the traditional rivalry.
DUBLIN, March 4 -- This must be one of the most pleasant cities in Europe in which to obtain a tourist visa for the United States.
JEANNE MOREAU is neither so beautiful as Elizabeth Taylor nor so famous as Brigitte Bardot, but her professional position is one her more highly-paid competitors might well envy.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 4 -- J.W. Fulbright may have been passed over for Secretary of State, but he came out of the experience with a better chance of winning re-election to the Senate next year.

West Germany has taken a courageous and constructive action by increasing the exchange value of the mark five per cent against other currencies. The move was a difficult one and was resisted for a long time. But now that Chancellor Adenauer and his colleagues have taken the step they deserve the thanks of all other free-world nations, not least of all our own.

Franklin K. Lane High of Queens beat a borough rival, Andrew Jackson, by a point for the team title in the fifty-seventh annual city Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

His novel, in what appears to be a superb and relaxed translation by Zeva Shapiro, is everywhere marked by a vigorous and poetic feeling for language and imagery.

Deposits in the nation's 515 mutual savings banks rose $170,000,000 in January to $36,500,000,000, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The increase contrasted to a drop of $68,000,000 in January, and an increase of $377,000,000 in December.

She is so good at what she does, and what she does is so unimportant, that one is left openmouthed as one sometimes is at the circus, contemplating the infinite care and skill with which a performer balances himself on one finger atop a teetering pile of furniture.

In about a week, barring equipment failures, a strange-looking craft is to take station forty miles east of Guadalupe Island in the Pacific Ocean and begin the first attempt to bore through the ocean floor to the mysterious "second layer."
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- Elizabeth Taylor, suffering from pneumonia, underwent an operation in the London Clinic tonight ad her doctors reported later that her condition remained "grave."

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- If the Kennedy Administration's farm policies reflect the character of its top-ranking officials of the Agriculture Department, they will go quite far toward erasing the farm views of the Eisenhower regime.

AS the scientific and technological revolution of the West marches inexorably over the world, remaking nations and traditions, Western thinkers are evincing a greater interest in the legendary wisdom of the East.
CHICAGO, March 4 -- A violent windstorm with tornadic characteristics struck Chicago's South Side at dusk today. One person was killed and at least eighty-two were injured.

MEXICO CITY -- Migratory birds and tourist directors in Central America habitually look northward around this time of year to determine, first, when or if winter will ever spend itself in the United States and, second, what lack the spring thaw will bring.

WARSAW, March 4 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski has assumed personal authority over the Roman Catholic priests in Poland in a move to counter rising pro-Communist influence among the lower levels of the clergy.

THIS was a week of limited delight and widespread despondency in Hollywood. For last Monday the nominees were announced in the thirty-third annual competition for an Oscar, the most coveted honor of the American movie industry and probably the only laurel that means money in the contract -- if not in the bank -- for the winner.
NEIL SIMON'S new comedy, "Come Blow Your Horn," does not haunt you with wisdom, tenderness and humanity. Shortly after you walk out of the theatre, you hear no faint note of a distant horn.

MANY city dwellers with only a few square feet of planting space have the same enthusiasm for gardening as suburban home owners. Often their plans would do justice to a large estate, but eventually they are brought down to realistic proportions.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 4 -- Columbia won the Ivy League fencing championship today by defeating Pennsylvania 18 -- 9. The Lions shared the title with Princeton in 1960.

FOR centuries now, writers on food have praised the plain and unassuming virtues of polenta, a sturdy and forthright concoction of Italian origin. Served with one of scores of imaginative sauces, it is an excellent dish for the cold days of March.

CALL it Scarsdale, or Winnetka, Brentwood or Catatonia, it's still Suburbia -- and it is beginning to provide almost as much inspiration for writers as the Civil War or the eternal triangle. By the time the centenary of the first home freezer is celebrated, the subject will no doubt have been covered as thoroughly as any hillside by a real estate developer.

BOSTON, March 4 -- This old city, whose ills have been diagnosed by a hundred municipal pill dispensers over the years, survived another crisis this week. But even its most sympathetic critics still believe its future as a major city remains in doubt.

CRUSADERS for traffic Safety were heartened last week when the American automobile industry agreed to install, as standard equipment on all 1962 models, the basic attachments for seat belts.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- After years of criticism, the State Department has moved to lower what many critics have called a bureaucratic barrier to tourist travel to the United States.
A set of five Louis XVI Aubusson tapestries that were brought here by Robert R. Livingston, first Chancellor of New York and Minister to France, will be auctioned here Saturday.
STORRS, Conn., March 4 (AP) -- Brown captured the forty-second annual New England Intercollegiate swimming Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Substantial pressures to defeat or to materially alter the Administration's proposed bill to aid education are building rapidly on at least three fronts.
CHICAGO, March 4 -- Within a month, modern art will have its first substantial home in the Midwest.
LOS ANGELES, March 4 -- Richard M. Nixon remained silent about his personal plans this week, but he gave some hints about the kind of life he expects to lead.

Winning the Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championship just comes naturally for Manhattan College. Last night at the 102d Engineers Armory the Jaspers captured their twelfth straight crown -- without taking one first place in the thirteen-event meet.

Nowhere on the crowded agenda for the General Assembly session resuming Tuesday is there an item on: "The question of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold." Yet the future role of Mr. Hammarskjold tends to overshadow most of the agenda topics that must be tackled when the ninety-nine states return here Tuesday to complete Assembly business.

HAVANA, March 4 -- Cuba is resolutely pressing her campaign in the Western Hemisphere against "Yankee imperialism" and to indoctrinate Latin Americans in the "ideals" of Premier Fidel Castro's revolution.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 4 -- Gene Fullmer pounded out a messy but unanimous fifteen-round decision over Sugar Ray Robinson tonight and kept the National Boxing Association version of the world middle-weight title.

WITH the possible exception of Picasso, few artists today are collectors on the princely scale of Sir Thomas Lawrence, Leon Bonnat or Degas. Still, positive taste being one aspect of the creative gift, most artists have their heroes and, if possible, something to represent them.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4 -- Andre N'Kanza-Dolumingo and Jean Nkadula Luvwezo, Congolese students enrolled at Princeton University, conceded the other day that they were "very demoralized" by events in the Congo.

Greater Cleveland's jobless total is 70,700, or 8.6 per cent of the area's labor force, according to the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation. February claims were the highest for the month since the agency was formed in 1939.
BOSTON, March 4 -- New York University's basketball team connected on 70 per cent of its second-half field goal attempts tonight and defeated Boston University, 69 -- 53.

EARLY March is a restless time for impatient gardeners. It is too soon to remove winter coverings from trees and shrubs. Soil is too wet to be worked. Nonetheless there are pruning, fertilizing and dormant spraying chores to satisfy the urge to get outdoors.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4 -- The "independent" foreign policies of President Janio Quadros are upsetting his old middle-of-the-road friends in Brazil without making him any new friends among the extreme Leftists.

Inner poise is a rare gift. To make itself felt in music is rarer still. Leon Kushner showed that he could establish a musical serenity without letting it get static in his recital in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, and at such moments his playing was extraordinarily beautiful.

Price increases for this year's production of major farm crops seem assured. And with the price rises, the Federal Government may become more involved in agriculture than at any time in the last twenty-eight years of price supports and controls on production.
A Brooklyn rabbi took sharp issue yesterday with some of his colleagues who have urged clemency for Adolf Eichmann, a former Nazi official accused of murdering millions of Jews in World War II.

THE Philippine Insurrection was one of the most tragic ironies in United States history. The idealistic intervention to put an end to Spanish cruelties in Cuba in 1898 led somehow to American perpetration of much the same cruelties in putting down a rebellion among the Filipinos.

SEATTLE, March 4 (UPI) -- Pacific Coast League directors today approved a league rule change allowing substitution of a pinch hitter for a pitcher without removing the hurler from the game.

CLEVELAND, S.C., March 4 -- Hunting in this part of the country, not far from where Daniel Boone started out, has changed noticeably since his day. For the wintering Yankee strolling with his traveler's check, it is a matter of organized convenience -- and money.

Although he was elected only last November, Representative William Fitts Ryan spent yesterday afternoon walking over his district, introducing himself to voters, shaking hands, visiting stores and generally acting like a candidate.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 4 -- Suffolk County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge, cleared of conspiracy charges by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday, plans to seek the dismissal of two indictments still pending against him.

With stores building stocks to a peak for March-into-April selling, there was heavy activity last week in spring coats, resident buying offices reported. "Hot" colors, especially pink, were important, although black and white, separately or in combination, also were wanted.
TEMPE, Ariz., March 4 -- A group of scientists who chase falling stars will converge here on next Friday to discuss meteorites.

Dartmouth College's swimming team defeated Columbia, 68 -- 27, at the loser's University Hall pool yesterday. The Big Green won eight of the eleven events in posting its fourth Eastern League victory against the same number of defeats. Dartmouth has a 7-4 over-all mark.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 4 -- The Kennedy Administration is faced today with a crisis in the seven-year-old United States economic aid program to Bolivia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4 (AP) -- Albania, at odds with the Soviet Union because of Albanian support for Communist China's "tough" ideological line, has jailed two Albanian officials on charges of spying for the Soviet Union, it was reported here today.

ALONG with its miles of ocean beaches, its fishing streams and great fresh-water springs, Florida is now actively publicizing its Civil War sites. Although the state is not commonly thought of as a battleground of the great conflict, it has its quota of Civil War memorials.

BUENOS AIRES, March 3 -- Dr. Alfred L. Palacios, who has been elected the only Socialist in the Argentine Senate, will not go to Mexico to participate in the Leftists' conference for National Sovereignty, Economic Emancipation and Peace, it was reported here today.
JERSEY CITY, March 4 -- Three-year-old John A. Perricone of Elizabeth died early today four hours after physicians had obtained court permission to administer a blood transfusion.

In contrast to the excitement-packed doings at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, the forty-second annual Knights of Columbus track carnival came to a quiet close at the Squadron A Armory yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- Columbia swept to the Ivy League wrestling title today with a 16-15 victory over Penn at the Palestra.

PARIS, March 4 -- Construction crews all over Paris are very lonely. They have their work, they have their foreman and they have their wine and food. But they are lacking a vital element in any building program: there are few sidewalk superintendents.

The men's clothing industry will hold its semi-annual market period March 13 through 24. About 500 manufacturers with offices in the New York area will display fall lines in their private showrooms, according to Leo Ullman, president of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., sponsor of the event.
PARIS, March 4 -- The United States consulate here is now able to issue nonimmigrant visas to French applicants in thirty minutes instead of the eight to ten days it used to take.
The careful control of the use of hypnosis as a medical weapon has been asked by the American Psychiatric Association.

There are a few masterworks in the genre that have appeared on only one side of the Atlantic, and countless admirable and stimulating books that are regularly passed over in favor of dull routine imports.

TEHERAN, Iran -- This land is one of the remnants of the brilliant Persian Empire of the history books and, although it is somewhat off the main tourist route, it is becoming more readily accessible to travelers and it has much to offer them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 -- An Oxford student doing graduate work in romance languages at Harvard University agrees with some broad criticism of Oxford's lecture system. But he counseled this week against generalizations in comparing educational disciplines.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 4 -- Albright defeated Hofstra tonight 45 -- 44, to capture the college division championship of the Middle Atlantic Conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has warned President Joseph Kasavubu that recent outbreaks in the Congo might lead to "graver political repercussions" if discipline was not restored to the Congo Army.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4 -- The stress has been switched from security to "public relations" in granting visas to Brazilians, United States consular officials said today.

MOST basement finishing jobs begin with the erection of partitions or walls which divide the basement into various rooms or storage areas. Consisting of a frame of 2x4's (or 2x3's), partitions are also usually built around the perimeter of the basement to provide a smooth surface against which wall paneling can be more easily installed.

BY starting annual and vegetable seed indoors, the gardener puts winter to rout and aids the plant budget. Advance sowing is important for delicate or slow-growing plants. Modern, easy-to-use equipment assures maximum germination and growth.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Judy Bell of Wichita, Kan., overcame her opponent's early lead with steady play today ond won the Florida East Coast women's amateur golf tournament for the second year in a row.

SEBRING, Fla., March 4 -- A nucleus of the official group that will conduct the eleventh annual sports-car endurance race on Saturday, March 25, has taken over at the traditional headquarters in the Sebring Hotel.

One of the curious anomalies in Communist states is the way their regimes resort to doses of private enterprise when drastic steps are necessary to deal with dire economic situations. Apparently communism, though vaunted as superior to the capitalist system, is not good enough to cope with certain kinds of crises in production.

MIAMI BEACH, March 4 -- Abba Eban, Israel's Minister of Education and Culture, declared here tonight that his nation would emerge "stronger and more resilient" from the "parliamentary crisis" that led to the resignation of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4 -- Representatives of Ghana Airways placed an order last week for two Boeing 707 jet transport planes at a total cost of $17,500,000, including spare parts. Delivery is scheduled for next June or July, at which time the company plans to start regular service from Accra to New York, South America and the Caribbean.

SOME carpenters will find that it always pays to keep a few wood shingles on hand in their scrap wood box. These tapered wooden shingles are handy for all types of jobs which require thin shims, such as spacing of frames when installing door or windows -- or the shimming up of uneven table legs on workshop floors.

THERE is no sign of a recession at Danny Thomas' comedy factory, which is making plans for further expansion. Last week a television production triumvirate (Mr. Thomas, Louis F. Edelman and Sheldon Leonard) sold another situation comedy show. Exclusive of Mr. Thomas' own program, it was the second sale this season.
A cavalcade of 1896 vintage automobiles will travel to St. Luke's Hospital on April 11 with flowers gathered from the ballroom of the Plaza after the annual Parade of the Flowers.

DUNOON, Scotland, March 4 -- About 1,000 opponents of nuclear weapons converged on this Firth of Clyde resort town today to protest the establishment of a base for United States Polaris-missile submarines at near-by Holy Loch.

PARIS, March 4 -- The "Visit U.S.A." traveling workshop came to Paris yesterday, dedicated to the principle -- subscribed to by President Kennedy, among others -- that this would be an excellent year for large numbers of Europeans to go to America.

ALBANY, March 4 -- What a difference a year can make in bowling. This is being proved at the Empire State open tournament at Schade's Academy. In a few short months scoring conditions can so change that even bowlers don't understand what's going on.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 3 -- Politics, through which there runs a vein of violence, is a staple of conversation in Salisbury when Europeans gather for their "Sundowners" these evenings. They sit in the bar at The Colony or in the any rooms of the Meikles Hotel and the talk turns inevitably to politics and to Africans and their rights or lack of rights.
After six months of coastal steaming and stopping at tropical ports in the Java Sea, the 44-year-old first master of the navigable medical center called Hope is back in New York.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP) -- A tricky wind failed to stop Doug Sanders today and the 27-year-old Ojai (Calif.) professional stayed in first place after the third round of the $30,000 Greater New Orleans invitation golf tournament.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 4 -- Congolese troops and United Nations forces traded heavy fire for several hours today at Matadi, a port city on the Congo River 160 miles southwest of Leopoldville.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 4 -- Brookhaven Township dog wardens were armed this week with a potent weapon for their campaign against marauding dog packs and wild dogs.

Affiliated Fund has reported gains in net assets and share value in the January quarter, first period in its fiscal year. The gain in the three months ended Jan. 31 totaled $84,132,090. The world-wide relief programs of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Felix Schnyder, will benefit on March 23 from the gala invitational premiere of the film, "The King and I," at the Rivoli Theatre.

RABAT, Morocco, March 4 -- Secret exploratory contacts between a French Government representative and a representative of the Algerian nationalist Porvisional Government have not been broken off but will continue, it was learned today from an authoritative North African source.
NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP) -- The favored Bass Clef rallied from last to win the $51,700 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds by one length today.
Plans are being completed for the Actors Studio benefit party at Roseland Dance City on March 13.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg ordered the withdrawal today of 2,800 Mexican laborers from eighteen companies in California's Imperial Valley. He said he had acted at Mexico's request.
OTTAWA, March 5 (Canadian Press) -- A large scientific expedition will be sent to Canada's polar regions this year to assess the mineral wealth and learn more about the area for defense.

Save your broken racquets and if you can't find any -- break one. A short-handled racquet is the implement used for a game still not widely known, although it was introduced in the Nineteen Twenties. It is short-handled squash racquets doubles.

FASTER Kodachrome is now on dealers' shelves, Eastman Kodak announced last week. The speed has been increased two and one-half times that of the Kodachrome that has been in effect since the color film's introduction in 1935.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 4 -- Unbeaten Four-and-Twenty raced to his fourth and greatest victory of his brief career today with a wire-to-wire victory in the $145,100 Santa Anita Derby.

Union members should urge Congress to include money for teachers' salaries in any Federal legislation to aid education, Lawrence Rogin, educational director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared here yesterday.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 4, -- The second annual art fair, sponsored by the Horace Greeley High School Parents-Teacher's Association, will open at the school Friday evening, March 24, and will continue through Sunday, March 26.
NORWALK, Conn., March 4 -- Frederick M. Ham, one of four Connecticut Light and Power Company employes burned in a flash fire yesterday, died late last night at Norwalk Hospital.
LAS VEGAS, March 4 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, beaten soundly tonight in his midleweight title fight with Gene Fullmer, locked himself in his dressing room for an hour after it ended.
HARTFORD, March 4 -- The General Assembly is approaching the halfway mark in its biennial five-month session without having approved a major bill or reached agreement on a major problem.
PINE ISLAND, N.Y., March 4 -- Worried onion farmers gazed at the ebony expanse of this area's fertile black dirt this week end and, in their mind's eye, saw nothing but concrete runways.
BUFFALO, March 4 (UPI) -- St. Bonaventure overcame a 10-point half-time deficit tonight to defeat Canisius, 84 -- 72.
CLIFTON, N.J., March 4 -- Clifton officials who have been making the United States Quarantine Station here for a municipal center site have taken their problems to Washington.
TROY, N.Y., March 4 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute scored an 8-3 victory over Clarkson College tonight. The triumph climaxed a 13-2-1 Eastern campaign for R.P.I.

BERLIN, March 4 -- Prof. Hans Ertel, vice president of East Germany's Academy of Sciences, was sentenced here today to fifteen months in prison for having cheated the West Berlin city government out of 62,870 West German marks (about $15,000).

BOSTON, March 4 (AP) -- Bill Russell intercepted a shot, dribbled the ball the length of the floor and drove for a key basket tonight as the Boston Celtics defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 113 -- 110, in a National Basketball Association game.

WITH "The Best Man," "Under the Yum Yum Tree," and "Rhinoceros" on the current playbill, Joseph Anthony has suddenly become Broadway's virtuoso of comedy direction. VERO BEACH, Fla. -- This east coast Florida resort is perhaps best known to New Yorkers as the spring training ground for the Los Angeles Dodgers, lately of Brooklyn. Vero Beach, which has a population of 9,000, is seventy-three miles north of Palm Beach.

MUFULIRA, Northern Rhodesia, March 2 -- The Copper Belt is a tiny enclave of peace in an expanse of troubled Africa. There are many, Africans as well as Europeans, who see it as a source of ideas that could lead to stability on the continent.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4 -- Yale rallied in the second half to down the Columbia basketball team, 68 -- 60, at Payne Whitney gymnasium tonight.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- Winter snows on the streets of the Soviet capital are melting and Muscovites talk of the ottepel, the thaw. But it is too early to speak of a thaw in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

A YEAR or so ago Vicente Escudero opened up a new territory for his presentation of the flamenco arts. He created what he called "A Lecture, Sung and Danced," and proceeded to present it at schools and colleges in Spain and, with the aid of an interpreter, in France also.

THIS Wednesday is the 120th anniversary of the birth of Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. Son of a celebrated father, student and later professor at Harvard, distinguished soldier in the Civil War, author and editor of numerous works on the law, the younger Holmes won fame chiefly through his work as a Supreme Court justice from 1902 to 1932.
HARTFORD, March 4 (UPI) -- A tenth arrest was made today in the investigation of an alleged ring that staged false traffic accidents to collect personal injury and property damage insurance.

Winter weather hasn't prevented Fordham's rejuvenated crew from starting workouts. Warmed by the knowledge that their first four regattas will be raced in Florida, the lightly clad Rams have been drilling diligently off Travers Island until dusk forces them out of the water.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- The House Science and Astronautics Committee disclosed today that it was investigating the widespread use of private organizations to do research for defense agencies.

Three maritime panel sessions have been scheduled as part of New York's thirty-first annual Safety Convention and Exposiion at the Statler Hilton Hotel April 12 and 13. Among the groups sponsoring the sessions are the Navy, Coast Guard, Atomic Energy Commission, American Merchant Marine Institute, the city's Department of Marine and Aviation, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York and the Port of New York Authority.

GENEVA, March 4 -- The titans of world amateur hockey, Canada and the Soviet Union, swept onward today, the third day of the world championship. The United States dropped back. Czechoslovakia whipped the Americans here tonight, 4 -- 1, and is still undefeated, too, but probably won't remain so for long.
LONDON, March 4 -- Consular officials at the United States Embassy in Grosvenor Square today began asking applicants for nonimmigrant visas only four simple questions.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 -- The Alamode Farm's Mail Order ran in front all the way to win the Magic City Handicap at Gulfstream Park today. A record-breaking opening-day crowd of 24,081 fans watched the race, in which Mail Order scored by three-quarters of a length over the Edgehill Farm's Exaltado. Udaipur was third in the field of ten, trailing Exaltado by four and a half lengths.

This year's Renaissance of Italian Youth Foundation Ball will be a Salute to Spring. It will take place in the Ballroom of the Plaza on April 19.
THE first of the year's national championship tournaments will be played at Denver, Colo., beginning next Saturday, March 11, and lasting through March 19.

MANILA -- In the Philippines the local inhabitants greet visitors with "Mabuhay," a word that is pronounced "maboohigh" and means "long life." It also means almost everything else. When one arrives, it means "welcome."

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (A) -- Wilt Chamberlain, a man who has difficulty making foul shots, got two in a row today in the final twenty-three seconds as the Philadelphia Warriors beat the Syracuse Nationals, 116-115. The triumph put the Warriors in second place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern division.

CABARET and other night-spot employes in New York City, swept up recently in a whirlpool of controversy over the merits of a law requiring that they be licensed to work, need not feel lonesome in their plight.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 4 -- Michigan overwhelmed its Big Ten competition today to win its twentieth indoor track championship with 69 points. Dave Mills of Purdue was the individual star with a world indoor record in the 440-yard dash.

Low-price stocks, which provide one of the best thermometers for measuring speculative fever, have confirmed the return of a bull market. It may be merely a bull calf market, soon to become veal, but it is here.

SELECTING rosebushes that will produce an abundance of flowers for cutting presents no problem to the rose arranger. Many beautiful, easy-to-grow varieties -- blends, bicolors and new colors -- have been introduced by rose hybridizers in the last few years.

Robins and crocuses are urban signs of spring, but country folk watch and listen for redwings and pussy willows. The redwing, that blackbird who wears red epaulets, usually arrives ahead of the robins and his loud "O-kal-eee," from the bogside trees and bushes is as clear a summons to the season as anyone could ask. He knows when the swamps begin to melt, and he is usually there to see it happen.

MARCH brings on the flower shows and here in New York the forty-fourth edition of the International Flower Show is attracting visitors, eager for spring, with blooms galore in the Coliseum. First nights have followed one another in unfaltering successsion.

Sunny skies and balmy weather helped to attract crowds to the International Flower Show at the Coliseum yesterday.

"Becket," starring Sir Laurence Olivier and Anthony Quinn, will close March 25 at the Royale. The Jean Anouilh drama, which first opened at the St. James, will have had a total run of 186 performances.

The millinery industry is having its greatest resurgence in twenty-five years. A vigorous promotion campaign by manufacturers and the industry's union has helped to achieve this objective.

The results in Chile's Congressional elections on Sunday can be taken two ways, one optimistic, one pessimistic, and both correct. It is true that the coalition supporting the Government of President Jorge Alessandri retains its majority in both houses of Congress. It is also true that the opposition, especially the Communists and Socialists, made significant gains.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The United States has diverted four naval craft from a goodwill tour to South Africa to be available in case the United Nations forces need help in the Congo. Five hundred marines are aboard the ships.
Major renovations and refurbishing at three New York hotels were announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 6 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said in a television interview shown here tonight that he believed the prospects for normal relations between the United States and Communist China were not "very bright."

International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., (Inco) reported yesterday that earnings for 1960 fell below those of 1959. It added that nickel deliveries during 1961 should roughly equal those of last year.

THE impression when you walk into the exhibition of paintings by the Spanish artist Antonio Saura that opened yesterday at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, is that you are being assaulted.
