May I call attention to your editorial of March 2, "The Folly of Change." I do not see how one can compare amendments made to the Constitution of the United States, such as the Bill of Rights, abolition of slavery or women's suffrage as having anything to do with the basic change of the Constitution itself.
John Ciardi, poetry editor of The Saturday Review, said yesterday that his scheduled appearance next week before the Alabama Education Association had been canceled, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Following is the "summary and conclusion" of a report by the President's Council of Economic Advisers on the state of the country's economic health, as laid before the Joint Congressional Economic Committee today:

The Joint Economic Committee of Congress began yesterday what should be a highly useful series of hearings on the economic situation and its prospects. With the recession now nearly a year old and unemployment apparently at about 5,500,000 people, a peak in our history in this middle of the twentieth century, few subjects of Congressional inquiry could be more important.

THE times we live in are pretty bewildering, but they never seem to be too bewildering for words. Talk, wise or foolish, on what we must do to be saved is in immensely generous supply. As Gerald W. Johnson puts it in his new book, "The Man Who Feels Left Behind"*:

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- Dodgertown, the bucolic training base of the Los Angeles Dodgers, buzzes with excitement these days. The atmosphere hasn't been so charged since 1947-48, when the successive additions of Jackie Robinson, Roy Campanella and Don Newcombe set spinning a cycle of success that produced six National League pennants in ten years.

Ohio State's basketball Buck-eyes, who have swept unbeaten through twenty-three opponents this season, yesterday were ranked first in the final ratings of United Press International's Board of Coaches.
Steel production fell slightly last week, but held at about 54 per cent cent of rated capacity for the third consecutive week.
Jai alai is coming back to New York. This Latin pastime combining the exciting elements of tennis, handball and lacrosse will be played at a $750,000 stadium, or fronton, being built in the Bronx.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 6 -- A wave of friendship for the United States, emphasizing the strength of old ties despite new problems, surged in Brazilian public opinion last week-end.

Greece yesterday decorated Richard Reuter, executive director of CARE (Cooperative for American Relief Everywhere). Alexis S. Liatis, the Greek Ambassador, gave him the Cross of Commander, Royal Order of George the First of Greece.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- High Republicans laid down a hard line against the Kennedy Administration today in talks designed to arouse party enthusiasm for the 1962 Congressional elections.
ALBANY, March 6 -- Relations between the Kennedy Administration and the Democratic state organization in New York seem to be deteriorating rapidly.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury at Jacksonville, Fla., indicted five baking companies today on charges of having rigged bids on bakery products sold to Naval installations in northern Florida and southeastern Georgia.
WASHINGTON, March, 6 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The main bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night was fought in the right month. Like March, it came in like a lion and went out like a lamb.
DETROIT, March 6 -- Car sales soared in the last eight days of February, raising the month's total 1.7 per cent above January's level, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara told Representative Emanuel Celler today that rumors that the Brooklyn Navy Yard was scheduled to be shut down were false.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Kennedy Administration is not receptive to Argentina's tentative offer to mediate the dispute between the United States and Cuba.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy designated today the week of July 2 as National Safe Boating Week and the week of July 23 as National Farm Safety Week.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 6 (UPI) -- Seventy-four passengers and crewmen narrowly escaped death today in mishaps to two airliners that forced a shutdown of Sao Paulo's international airport.
ALBANY, March 6 -- Governor Rockefeller strongly urged the Legislature in a special message today to enact a series of bills to make it easier for cities to start and finance urban renewal projects.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6 -- Top Soviet delegates boycotted an official luncheon given by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today for President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana.
JEWARK, March 6 -- An eight-year-old anti-trust suit against three leading soap manufacturers and an industrial association was dropped here today.
Since the advent of the much publicized business "recession," along with the recent gold jitters, new vigor has been given the antiquated slogan "Buy American."

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 6 -- The Sudan Government charged tonight that the United Nations command in the Congo had been careless in deploying Sudanese forces and announced it was therefore withdrawing its 400 troops from the United Nations force.
Savings as high as $150,000 a school have been achieved through the reuse of architectural plans, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

HOPEFUL, Ga., March 6 -- Some of the swiftest stocked quail ever seen got to flying around on the Riverview Shooting Preserve this morning and native birds were moving this afternoon. A certain number of these were missed for sound reasons.
A PLAY warm and rich with life came to town last night. "Roots" introduced to New York the 28-year-old Arnold Wesker, who belongs to the exciting new wave of British playwrights.
ALBANY, March 6 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz conceded today that he had discussed with Governor Rockefeller the possibility of running for Mayor of New York City.

The curtain at the Longacre Theatre went down prematurely last night during the third and last act of "Rhinoceros." The curtain began tearing in shreds and the lower half, weighted at the bottom with a long rod called a batten, fell to the stage.
The Commonwealth Edison Company and its subsidiaries showed gains in operating revenues and net income for 1960 according to the annual report released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- -- The Supreme Court held today that the Constitution bars the police from driving a spike wired for sound into the wall of a person's home and listening in on his conversation.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The way was cleared today for former Gov. Herschel E. Loveless of Iowa to take a $20,500-a-year position as a member of the Federal Renegotiation Board.
Quick thinking by a Yorkville warehouse manager yesterday afternoon resulted in the capture of two suspects after a warehouse hold-up.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled valid today a Michigan tax on national bank shares which is higher than the state's levy on shares of savings and loan associations.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) -- The Government estimated today that farm population totaled only 15,635,000 in April, 1960 -- about the same as the farm population during the Civil War.
Proceeds of a theatre party at the April 18 performance of "Mary, Mary" at the Helen Hayes Theatre will be turned over to Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
ALBANY, March 6 -- Advisers to the Legislature and members of the legal profession clashed openly today over the adoption of a new Civil Practices Act.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst, the Second baseman who Was released by the Milwaukee Braves this winter, will be signed by the St. Louis Cardinals, it was learned today. Schoendienst played for the Cards from 1945 through part of 1956.

BONN, Germany, March 6 (AP) -- A West German politician said today his recent visit to Washington had convinced him that the United States would use severer methods from now on in dealing with West Germany.
BOSTON, March 6 -- Speculation over the possibility of a deadlock on redistricting in Massachusetts is rising with the temperature.
Three hundred persons yesterday witnessed the swearing in at City Hall of Frank J. Lucia as the city's new $25,000-a-year Commissioner of Sanitation.
The Polaroid Corporation, manufacturer of the Land camera, which develops its own pictures in a few minutes, is considering a move into the office photocopying field.

PARIS, March 6 -- Four directors of one of France's biggest housing companies were behind bars today on a charge of malversation. Three of them were arrested yesterday and the fourth this morning as he stepped off a train from Marseilles.

Defendants in court actions cannot get a fair trial if they do not have well-qualified lawyers to defend them, yet a substantial proportion of those haled into court are too poor to pay for legal counsel.

WHITE PLAINS, March 6 -- Demands that Edwin G. Michaelian either quit as County Executive or Republican county and White Plains chairman touched off a wild display at a meeting of the Westchester Board of Supervisors today.
Sales and earnings of the Coca-Cola Company rose to record highs in 1960, the soft drink company reported yesterday.
ONE difference between the casual and the expert bridge player seems to have been demonstrated in a bidding contest conducted during February by a Belgian newspaper, La Libre Belgique of Brussels.

Representative Abraham J. Multer, Democrat of Brooklyn, proposed yesterday that the term of office of the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board be changed to coincide with that of the President. Mr. Multer is a member of the House Banking and Currency Committee.
TOKYO, March 6 -- Cherry blossoms are in bloom in Tokyo -- pretty pink, plastic cherry blossoms.
Mayor Wagner proposed yesterday that the Federal Government and New York State help local communities and regional bodies conserve vacant land for public improvements.
A RECENT onslaught on the belt departments of stores took some by surprise.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- An official of the Flight Engineers Union said today that a Mexican airliner's crash at New York International Airport Jan. 19 might have been prevented "if there had been a properly certificated and trained crew on board.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 6 (UPI) -- Joseph A, Peel Jr., a former city judge in West Palm Beach, went on trial here today on charges that he had paid $2,000 for the slaying of Circuit Judge and Mrs. C.E. Chillingworth.
WHITE PLAINS, March 6 -- The week-end toll of Westchester automobile fatalities increased to six today with the death of two victims in White Plains Hospital.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Following are President Kennedy's statement and the text of an order he issued today on equal employment opportunity:

LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- Elizabeth Taylor, stricken with pneumonia and anemia, was reported to be still in critical condition but slightly improved late tonight. Her physicians said the actress showed improvement over her earlier evening condition.
Not a hammer or paint brush has been used on the "pioneer" project in the city's program of seizing and rehabilitating slum rooming houses. The program was launched with fanfare a year ago.
The Greek Tragedy Theatre will make its first United States tour this fall. It probably will open at the City Center for a two-week engagement in August.
MEXICO CITY, March 6 -- Vitriolic attacks against the United States and warm support of Cuba continued today at the Leftists' Conference for National Sovereignty, Economic Emancipation and Peace.

Mayor Wagner and other city officials outlined a plan yesterday to reactivate the city-owned piers on Staten Island for $25,000,000 to $35,000,000. This project, they said, would enable Staten Island to derive major economic benefits from the completion of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in 1965.

LONDON, March 6 -- The reticence shown by the Commonwealth Prime Ministers on the subject encouraged the belief today that South Africa would not be barred from continued membership in the Commonwealth.
LONDON, March 6 -- Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, returned to London tonight after a six-week tour of India, Pakistan, Nepal and Iran.
PARAMUS, N.J., March 6 -- A $75,000 bowling tournament will be held at Paramus Bowling, beginning May 11.
The Soviet government appears to have made a quiet but significant monetary concession to the Eastern European satellite states and Mongolia.
GENEVA, March 6 -- A convention of track and field coaches from the Soviet bloc has just ended at Prague.

Since World War II the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training -- better known as O.R.T. -- has trained 350,000 persons, many of them in flight from oppression, others chained by generations of poverty to the bleakest kind of existence. Thus O.R.T. has carried on its great program as a world-wide system of vocational schools designed to build and rebuild human lives through the teaching of modern skills.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Rosalind Russell was trying hard to look dowdy. For Miss Russell, who is conspicuous for elegance in this community that stresses tailored exhibitionism, this was difficult.
The Laotian situation appears to be approaching the "put-up-or-shut-up" stage.
PARIS, March 6 -- A heavy movement of foreign money into the Swiss franc market was the main result today of the week-end revaluations of the German mark and the Dutch guilder.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 6 (AP) -- The adopted children of the late Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard won a round today in a legal battle for a trust fund estimated at $10,000,000 that was established by John D. Rockefeller Sr. in 1917.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to give the Justice Department $1,158,000 more to intensify its campaign against organized crime and juvenile delinquency.
The State of New Jersey indicated yesterday that it was a much-interested party in the fate of a celebrated bird sanctuary in Stone Harbor, N.J.
AMSTERDAM, March 6 (UPI) -- Six officials will decide if John Devitt of Australia or Lance Larson of El Monte, Calif., won the Olympic 100-meter free-style swimming final in Rome last year.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Joshua Wallman, 17 years old, of 23 East Sixty-ninth Street, New York, was named tonight the winner of a $7,500 college scholarship for his scientific talents.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The number of waterfowl observed during the annual winter survey was 11 per cent more than last year, the Interior Department said today. But the nesting grounds are the driest in twenty-five years, the department also said.
JERUSALEM, March 5 -- Israel has decided to continue her programs of technical assistance to Ghana, Guinea and Mali despite the diplomatic embarrassment these countries caused her recently.

What will be the world's largest steam electric generating plant has been ordered by Britain's Central Electricity Generating Board from the English Electric Company at a cost of more than $40,000,000. The new plant will have the highest capacity of any such plant in the world -- 2,000,000 kilowatts, provided by four steam generating units.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 6 -- It won't be long now before the men will be separated from the boys in the Yankee training camp.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 6 -- The United Nations command was negotiating with Congolese authorities today for permission to occupy Matadi, the Congo's only major port.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Secretary of the Interior told Congress today it must act quickly to create a national seashore park on Cape Cod.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 21 points (25 cents to $1.05 a bale) yesterday.

ALBANY, March 6 -- An anticipated Democratic revolt against Mayor Wagner failed to materialize in the Legislature tonight as the Assembly overwhelmingly approved a bill validating the city's sale of an East Side property to the Consolidated Edison Company.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- R. Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, said today that his organization would "take the world by surprise."
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers told Congress today that a noticeable "upturn" in the economy might develop "in the next few months."
A jury was selected in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday for the $1,050,000 negligence suit brought against the city by the father of Arnold Schuster.
Eastern Air Lines, Inc., had a net loss of $3,600,000 last year, its first deficit in twenty-six years. In 1959, the company cleared $7,103,071.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- Ingemar Johansson sauntered into his training quarters today twenty-five minutes late. He greeted some sixty members of his staff and the press with his characteristic sly grin.
VIENNA, March 6 -- The immediate release of $423,000,000 worth of counterpart funds to the Austrian Government will mark the end of a long chapter of United States economic financial assistance here.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 6 -- At this time a year ago a cynical listener to the grandiose claims and egotistical enthusiasm of Charlie Dressen, the new manager of the Milwaukee Braves, was left with only one conclusion.
Early-blooming spring gardeners, thriving in the recent mild temperatures, continued to storm the Forty-fourth International Flower Show at the Coliseum yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, the California Chemical Company and an Indian company have received a license from the Indian Government to build a $51,000,000 fertilizer plant on India's east coast, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the first case brought to it from the wave of sit-in demonstrations at lunch counters in the South.

The city yesterday postponed indefinitely an auction of surplus real estate in a choice downtown Brooklyn location after demands for an investigation had been sent to Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Paul Egan, Mayor of Aurora, Ill., won and lost in the Supreme Court today.

Governor Rockefeller was told yesterday that unless local governments came to the rescue of the Long Island Rail Road it would have to increase its fares 20 per cent. The forecast was in a report by a committee the Governor had named to study the railroad's financial problems.
Patrons for the third annual Pierre Dansant, a subscription dinner dance arranged for March 17 in the ballroom of the Pierre, have been announced by the committee for the event.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by officers of a Philadelphia local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who had been barred from using union funds to defend themselves in civil and criminal proceedings.
RABAT, Morocco, March 5 -- United States diplomatic observers expressed fear today that King Hassan II might seek to hasten the evacuation of United States forces from Moroccan bases.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 6 -- The rise of the Left in Chile's Congressional election yesterday was viewed today by political observers of all parties as a turning point in President Jorge Alessandri Rodriguez' Administration.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 5 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government indicated today that it was enlisting the aid of the United States, Thailand and Laos in withdrawing the Nationalist guerrillas now in northern Burma, Thailand and Laos.

PARENTS and householders will be alerted this week to the importance of uncluttered homes as one way to help prevent fires. The International Association of Fire Chiefs, with the cooperation of local fire safety officials, is starting an intensive spring clean-up campaign in cities, towns and villages throughout the nation.

I was deeply interested in Henry S. Proctor's letter in your issue of Feb. 28, in which the writer stated, in reference to the American Nazi party, "the present-day group is dedicated to a course of action which would serve to fan the flames of divisive hatred among the American people, and to subvert our most treasured institutions."

Premiums written by Liberty Mutual Insurance Company and the Liberty Mutual Fire Insurance Company, Boston, aggregated $389,827,310 last year, for a gain of 8.8 per cent above the 1959 level, it was announced yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange was unable yesterday to permit the opening of trading in the stock of Reliance Manufacturing Company, which on Friday has closed at 24 1/2, up 1 3/8 points on the day.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) -- Moscow already owns blueprints of the precision machine tools that the Commerce Department believes could be of strategic value to the Soviet Union, it was disclosed today.
BOWIE, Md., March 6 (AP) -- Larry Adams won three races in a row at Bowie Race Course today, lifting his total to twenty-six winners out of 102 mounts.
THERE is more shadow than substance to Paul Vincent Carroll's "The Old Foolishness," the present attraction on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- A flurry of selling turned wheat futures downward today in late dealings on the Board of Trade but other grains and soybeans held onto good gains to the finish.

The Syracuse Nationals, one of the fastest teams in the National Basketball Association, will meet the New York Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game, which will start at 9 P.M., will mark Syracuse's last appearance here this season.
MOSCOW, March 6 -- The Moiseyev Folk Dance Ensemble shook Tchaikovsky Hall tonight with a rollicking satire on rock 'n' roll that drew more cheers than ideological smirks from an elite audience.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 6 -- Twelve African leaders met today with Sir Patrick Renison, British Governor of Kenya, to discuss a growing political crisis here.

Firmness prevailed in the bond market yesterday, except for the tax-exempt-interest issues of local governments. The tax-exempts continued under pressure because of the weight of undigested new issues of substantial amount and wide variety.

Trade and commission house buying firmed potato prices in early trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later, hedge selling and long liquidation reversed the price movement. Selling by local houses touched off stop-loss orders.
A series of judicial appointments was viewed yesterday as likely to stem from Mayor Wagner's request to the bar associations to pass upon Louis A. Cioffi as a prospective Magistrate.
Eleven persons, including a physician and two lawyers, were indicted on ambulance-chasing charges yesterday.
One of the foreign relations problems of the Kennedy Administration involves Pakistan, one of the United States' strongest and most valued allies.
Seventeen New Jersey children were injured here yesterday, none seriously, when a chartered bus carrying them to the International Flower Show at the Coliseum struck a Surface Transit, Inc., bus.

LONDON, March 6 -- Prince Frederick of Prussia, now a British subject, was granted an award today by the Foreign Compensation Tribunal for a castle and estate confiscated by the Polish Government after World War II.
John Wayne and Frank Shuster, the slapstick comedy team, will star in their first situation comedy series in this country beginning June 25.
What is believed to be a self-portrait in oil by Walt Whitman has been found in the shop of a downtown art dealer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6 -- The United States and the Soviet Union failed to reach agreement today on efforts to eliminate debate on "cold war" items at the fifteenth session of the General Assembly, which will reopen tomorrow.

PERTH, Australia, Feb. 28 -- Western Australia, which embraces almost a third of this continent and is bigger than Alaska and Texas combined, has failed to maintain the steady post-World War II boom of other Australian states.

Graham-Paige Corporation wound up 1960 with total stockholders' equity of $16,488,306, equal to $1.88 a share, according to the annual report released yesterday. This compared with $17,221,429, or $2.26 a share, at the end of 1959.

Normally, Commander Edward Whitehead, president of Schweppes U.S.A. and star of their advertising program, not only is always properly urbane, but is also usually seen in particularly urbane settings -- a fashionable restaurant, the parlor of a handsome town house.

A recollection of Bernard Shaw's writings, none of which is included in the standard edition of Shaw's work, will be issued March 20 by Hill Wang, entitled "How to Become a Musical Critic." The pieces, "buried" in widely scattered little known publications, a large portion of which were either unsigned or pseudonymous, were tracked down, decoded and identified by Dan H. Laurence.

BROCCOLI, relatively a latecomer to American markets, rapidly jumped to an importance that it justly deserved. Until the Nineteen Twenties, only those of Italian background cooked that member of the cabbage family.

THE train of events that led Robert Sargent Shriver to Washington and a high place in the Kennedy Administration started the night he met his future wife. Mr. Shriver, who announced his plans yesterday as head of the Peace Corps, met Eunice M. Kennedy, sister of the President, at a dinner party here in 1945.
Harry Horwitz has purchased the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street in a Murray Hill investment deal.
ALBANY, March 6 -- A special three-member committee reported to the Legislature tonight that the Thruway Authority's contract with its former chairman, Bertram D. Tallamy, was justified.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- Floyd Patterson took it easy today -- as easy as the heavyweight champion of the world could take it with a title fight only a week away. Except for a jaunt on the road and a few limbering-up exercises, he went in just for relaxation.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved unanimously today the nomination of George F. Kennan as Ambassador to Yugoslavia. He told the Senators he was confident Marshall Tito would remain independent of the Soviet Union and Communist China.
A new bowling alley in Queens has a split-level floor plan to provide the maximum amount of space on a comparatively small plot of 32,000 square feet.

In a region of the United States known as T.V.A., the people consume twice as much electricity at half the price of any other area in the United States. The majority of T.V.A. public power electricity is generated not by water power but from the efficient use of coal.

Eight students who recently spent thirty days in a South Carolina road gang after having staged a sit-in demonstration at a lunch counter, declared here yesterday that they would continue to fight the "segregation evil" if it meant being sent back to the road gang.
DESPITE the freedom of the form of Lonny Chapman's "Cry of the Raindrop," the contents are banal.
Prices of United States Government securities took their most uniform rise in three weeks yesterday, but the trading was light and the gains were limited to small fractions.

Smith Kline and French Laboratories filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 200,000 common shares to be offered to the public through Smith, Barney and Co., Inc., and The First Boston Corporation.

Stocks went through a sharp and unsettling two-hour correction yesterday but scrambled back to close with a loss of but 1 per cent in aggregate market value and in The New York Times combined average.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 7 (UPI) -- The will of former Senator Joseph R. Grundy, long a power in the Republican party, was filed here today and had just one restriction, the money he left cannot be used in any political campaign or to influence legislation.

A most significant development in contemporary affairs is that throughout the world, from Indonesia in the Far East to Ghana and Guinea in Africa to Cuba in the Caribbean, former colonial or semi-colonial peoples have been winning national independence and at the same time setting up dynamically led republics that institute socialist programs in order to bring about rapid economic, social and cultural progress.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- Alpha Tau Omega, national fraternity, announced today that it was ousting its Stanford University chapter for accepting four Jewish students as members.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad wants to be merged into the Pennsylvania Railroad system and has told the Interstate Commerce Commission that if such a merger is not effected, it will oppose the Pennsylvania Railroad's plans to acquire all of the stock of the Lehigh Valley Railroad.
MIAMI BEACH, March 7 -- Just to have something to say on a day that called for no training activity but early road work, Floyd Patterson held a press conference this afternoon.

The latest advances in lighting have been viewed by more than 15,000 prospective purchasers in the New York Coliseum since the National Lighting Exposition opened last Sunday. Before the event closes tonight, more than 20,000 will have seen the 250 displays, Harold R. Meyer, exposition producer and president, predicted yesterday.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would enter Memorial Hospital on March 19 for the removal of a benign tumor near his right ear.

PARIS, March 7 -- The flood of speculative money into Switzerland abated sharply today following a forceful denial yesterday by the Swiss Government that it had any intention of revaluing the Swiss franc.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -President Kennedy announced today the selection of Walworth Barbour, a career Foreign Service officer, to be the Ambassador to Israel.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller's higher education program cleared its first major hurdle today.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Kennedy Administration was reported today to have notified leading Democrats privately that it would channel patronage through the state party organization if Michael H. Prendergast were replaced as state chairman.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Representative Frances P. Bolton described the Kennedy Administration's new Peace Corps today as "a terrifying thing."
The airlines' struggle over trans-Atlantic cargo rates enters a new phase today at an International Air Transport Association hearing here.

Hugo E. Rogers said yesterday that many friends had been urging him to run again for public office this fall. He is "going to hire a hall, get them all together and see if they mean business," he added.

Anastas I. Mikoyan, First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, has told an American business man the Soviet Union would buy much more non-strategic goods from the United States for cash if it were certain of getting delivery.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Kennedy has renamed the ninety-two-foot White House yacht the Honey Fitz.
The National Association for Mental Health announced yesterday the appointment of Philip E. Ryan as its executive director.
HARDLY a Verdi flop remains unresurrected these days. Last night at Town Hall the Amato Opera gave "Aroldo."

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 -- Chilean officials are disturbed by what they consider an overhasty attempt by the Kennedy Administration to line up a group of major Latin-American countries to act on the Cuban problem.

Good musicians make good ambassadors, but the converse is not necessarily true. Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Adrien Meisch, Luxembourg's Consul to New York and Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations, gave a debut piano recital.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 7 -- A 19-year-old sophomore at Stevens Institute of Technology here has created a new record for excellence at the engineering and science college. He got perfect ratings on his semester examinations in mathematics, physics and mechanics.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 7 -- The newly organized Detroit branch of the Rocky Colavito Fan Club disbanded in panic on opening day last season. Prepared to bestow on their freshly acquired slugger the same brand of idolatry that his Cleveland worshipers had been lavishing on him for years, the Detroiters had their hosannas choke in their throats.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 (AP) -- Morris K. Udall, 38-year-old brother of Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall, swept easily past five opponents today to win the Democratic nomination for congress from Arizona's second congressional district.

THE only pilot who has flown four times the speed of sound and soared twenty-six miles is a mild mannered New Yorker who studied to be an electrical engineer, Maj. Robert Michael White, who broke the world speed record yesterday, considers his job of flying the X-15 rocket ship to the fringes of space as demanding as much engineering as flying skill.

HANOI, Vietnam, Feb. 28 -This city on the Red River, which was formerly the business center of French Indochina, then during the war a rest area for French troops, has become the political, administrative and cultural capital of Communist North Vietnam.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today a stepped-up construction program for the State University's $30,000,000 science land engineering college at Stony Brook, L.I.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- Federal Aviation Administrator Najeeb E. Halaby said today that his agency was applying some of the lessons learned from the collision of two airliners over New York last December.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI slowly made his way, on crutches, to the podium of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night. He was keeping his promise to conduct Arnold Schoenberg's "Gurrelieder," which had been scheduled earlier this season but postponed when the conductor suffered a broken hip.
The builders and owners of Washington Square Village, a Title I luxury housing project in Greenwich Village, were sued yesterday by a group of tenants for breach of contract and $500,000 in damages.

With the opening of the local thoroughbred racing season less than two weeks away, preparations are going on steadily for Aqueduct's start on March 20. Bill Welch and his crew were busily engaged yesterday, working on the inner portion of the racing strip.
Two-thirds of the money spent by Catholic Charities last year went toward keeping families together and aiding neglected and handicapped children, the agency reported yesterday.
PARIS, March 7 -- France reached agreement today with four of her former African territories on methods of continuing aid despite their refusal to enter the French Community.

"OUR WORLD AND THE MOON" is the subject of the new sky show at the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street. Show time is weekdays at 2, 3:30 and 8:30 P.M., except on Mondays when there is no evening show.

Jonathan Logan, Inc., which in recent weeks has carried on exploratory merger discussions with several leading manufacturer's of women's apparel, confirmed yesterday that it also had been talking with Reliance Manufacturing.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- The General Assembly delegates who adjourned last Dec. 21 until today might easily have thought they came to the wrong place.
WHITE PLAINS, March 7 -Center barriers may soon be installed along the more hazardous stretches of the Westchester County parkways.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The perennial agreement over what some members of Congress call the "booze fund" enlivened the debate today before the House of Representatives passed a general purposes bill appropriating $803,506,119.
Queens College dedicated its $5,000,000 center for music and speech yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -More than twenty-five countries bought more than $1,000,000,000 of United States gold in the final quarter of last year, when speculation against devaluation of the dollar was at its peak.

The long-awaited American premiere of the Italian-made film "La Dolce Vita" has been scheduled to take place April 19 at Henry Miller's Theatre. The reserved-seat engagement will mark the first time that the Broadway playhouse has housed a movie.
We applaud President Kennedy's forthright attack on discrimination in Federal employment through his Executive Order setting up the new Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Lawyers for The Chicago Tribune petitioned the United States Court of Appeals in New Orleans today for permission to enter the libel case brought against The New York Times in Alabama.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman rebuked both sides in the New Rochelle public school desegregation dispute yesterday for arousing community feeling by deliberately beclouding and misconstruing the issues.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -A late speed-up in selling weakened grain futures prices almost all along the line today on the Board of Trade.
Newbold Morris, Commissioner of Parks, said yesterday that the proposed pavilion in Central Park at Fifty-ninth Street would cost $1,700,000 instead of the $870,000 originally estimated.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- Renewing a battle he lost as a Senator, President Kennedy asked Congress today for authority to give economic aid to Communist nations of Eastern Europe.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The Senate Finance Committee reported out appropriation bills today with $16,469,367 in new appropriations cut from the Governor's budget.

A new production of "Cabin in the Sky," the Negro musical fantasy of the 1940-41 season, is considered a strong possibility for the Phoenix. The report was verified yesterday by T. Edward Hambleton, managing director of the group.
New Jersey's farmers cleared $4,021 a farm last year, the Department of Agriculture has estimated.
LOS ANGELES, March 7 -Maj. Robert M. White, an Air Force test pilot, set an unofficial world speed mark of 2,650 miles an hour today in an X-15 rocket plane.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 7 -- Ralph Houk, a manager who thinks the idea of "ten-man baseball" is rather silly, will become an innovator himself tomorrow when his Yankees engage in their first intrasquad game of the spring training campaign.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- Ingemar Johansson apparently is planning to throw a lot of punches, left and right, at Floyd Patterson when they fight for the world heavyweight title in Miami Beach next Monday night.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg reported today that unemployment rose to 5,705,000 in February, the highest level since 1941. This figure contrasted with a mild rise in employment that set a record for February. Overall employment increased by 207,000 to 64,655,000.

ATHENS, March 7 -- The East Mediterranean region isn't notable for the vigor or duration of its international agreements. An Anglo-French-American declaration freezing arms shipments to Israel and the Arabs became, a nullity within five years.

In your editorial of March 3 on "Our 'Lost' World Markets" you point out that our merchandise account has continued to show an excess of exports over imports. You seemingly conclude that everything is fine so long as this country addresses itself "to the composite categories that make up the whole" of the balance of payments problem.
GENEVA, March 7 -- Max Petitpierre, who has been the Swiss Foreign Minister for sixteen years, said today he would resign at the end of June.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 7 (UPI) -- An antitrust case against Texaco, Inc., which has been pending more than ten years, was dismissed today by United States District Judge James Carter.

Following the example set by West Germany in revaluing the mark upward, in terms of the dollar and other currencies, the Netherlands has now raised the exchange rate of its guilder to escape the "suction" of the stronger German currency on its economy. As a result, the world's money marts have become unsettled by speculation that other nations may follow suit.

FOR dessert last night at the City Center -- it's fourth and final program -- the Comedie Francaise served up Georges Feydeau's "Le Dindon," as frothy a helping of deep-dish bedroom farce as a connoisseur could wish.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Cross-currents stirred by a religious issue cast new doubt today on legislative prospects for the Kennedy Administration's program of aid to education.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 7 to 20 points (35 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday The far months showed the most strength.
The newest park in the city's system -- Columbus Plaza in Brooklyn -- was dedicated yesterday at a ceremony conducted by the Italian Historical Society of America.
BONN, Germany, March 7 -- Chancellor Adenauer gave W. Averell Harriman this message for President Kennedy today: that the United States should assume vigorous leadership of the Atlantic alliance.

PARIS, March 7 -- The Tunisian Minister who has done most of the preliminary work in the recent Algerian peace offensive left Paris today convinced that the moment had arrived for open negotiations between France and the Algerian rebels.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today designated Detroit and seven other localities as testing areas for President Kennedy's new food stamp plan to help the needy and improve nutrition.
Thanks to a tip from a passenger and painstaking detective work by Transit Authority personnel, the mystery of an IRT derailment has been solved.

To please a people accustomed to concentrated foods and time and labor-saving ideas and to raise money for a worthy cause, the National Design Center is arranging what might be called an "instant house tour."
A truce in the bitter Alleghany Corporation proxy contest has been arranged between Allan P. Kirby, Alleghany's chairman, and the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex.

DETROIT, March 7 -- A temporary injunction was approved today to halt William C. Newberg's personal damage suit against L.L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, until the completion of a suit by Mr. Newberg against the automobile company.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 7 -Negro leaders and business men agreed here today to a formula for desegregation of lunch counters and other store facilities. In return for an immediate end to sit-ins and other boycotts, the stores agreed to end discrimination at the time of desegregation of local schools, expected in the fall.
WHITE PLAINS, March 7 -- County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian appointed a Democrat as a County Park Commissioner today.

The New York police were accused yesterday of having made "a sitting duck for gangland" of 24-year-old Arnold Schuster, who was shot to death by an unknown assailant on March 8, 1952, after he had given the tip that led to the arrest of Willie Sutton, the bank robber.
Critics of the city's real estate transactions in the Brooklyn Civic Center area renewed their demands yesterday for official investigations.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The House Education and Labor Committee voted tentatively tonight to step up the legal minimum wage gradually from the present $1 to $1.25 an hour.

MOSCOW, March 7 -- Premier Khrushchev summoned Ambassador Llewellyn E Thompson Jr. today to an undisclosed place in Siberia for a conference on problems dividing the Soviet Union and the United States.

A display of orchids at the International Flower Show this week was nurtured, not in faraway tropic latitudes, but in a second-floor East Side apartment. The exhibitors, both native Hew Yorkers, are 32-year-old Thomas Powell and his wife Betty, 29.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- In politics, as in love, action is what counts in the end. This is President Kennedy's problem in the Middle West. Most of the people who like him are here merely chattering about what a nice competent guy he is, but the people who are against his policies are mobilizing and acting against him.

Although under attachment through libel filed against her, the Brazilian cargo ship Loide Uruguai is expected to sail for Brazil tonight or tomorrow with 4,000 bags of allegedly contraband Brazilian coffee aboard.
Traffic injuries here last week rose by 125 from a year ago. The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 809 persons had been injured, compared with 684 in 1960.
JERSEY CITY, March 7 -- Albany State will meet Maryland State tomorrow night for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics District 31 basketball championship.
LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- Von Clay of Philadelphia twice floored Chic Calderwood, Britain's light-heavyweight champion, and won a ten-round decision tonight at Wembley Stadium.

LONDON, March 7 -- The stock market here was much quieter today after yesterday's surge of buying and profit taking. Investors marked time to see how prices settled before entering into further commitments.

IT is disappointing to have to report that the Splendid Century -- seventeenth-century France -- does not come off quite so splendidly as hoped in the exhibition of that title opening at the Metropolitan Museum today.

TRENTON, March 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today chided New York officials who recently charged that New Jersey was not doing its share toward the elimination of air pollution in the metropolitan area.

The General Public Utilities Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries showed gains in all three major sales categories in 1960, according to the annual report issued for publication today. However, the rates of gain were not as great as those recorded the year before.
PANMUNJON, Korea, Wednesday, March 8 (UPI) -- Communist guards attacked a United States military police captain today in this neutral zone between North and South Korea.

GENEVA, March 7 -- The Soviet Union may have lost the world amateur hockey tournament tonight. And Czechoslovakia may be on the way to winning it. The Czechs beat the Russians, 6 -- 4, in a wildly exciting, wildly improbable game before a full house of 12,000 screaming, applauding fans.

MEXICO CITY, March 7 -- The establishment of a permanent secretariat of the World Peace Council for Latin America was under discussion here today at the Leftists' Conference for National Sovereignty, Economic Emancipation and Peace.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Census figures released today show that the proportion of American Negroes living in the South is continuing to decline.
Two lawyers and two insurance brokers were among ten men who pleaded not guilty in Bronx County Court yesterday to indictments charging ambulance chasing.

A one-story taxpayer on a plot 140 by 60 feet at 1201 to 1215 Jericho Turnpike, New Hyde Park, L.I. has been sold by H. Hinderstein of New Park Realty, Inc., It contains nine stores and was acquired by a syndicate of investors headed by L. Brower. George Michelson of the Kraham Realty Company of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Balter Greenberg were the brokers in the sale.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Walter P. Reuther called today for a labor-led "crusade" to push President Kennedy's antirecession program through Congress.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 7 -- The Government of the Congo threatened today to deprive United Nations military forces of control of the principal airport in the Congo.

Nathan Richmond, builder, has bought a vacant plot of land at the northeast corner of the Grand Concourse and West 206th Street, the Bronx, from the City of New York. The property from 242 feet on the Concourse, forty-two feet on 206th Street and 100 feet on St. George's Crescent.
The people at the Loft's Candy Shops, Inc., are a little puzzled.
ALBANY, March 7 -- A bill to insure that New York City can hold a referendum in November on Charter revision is scheduled for approval in the Senate and Assembly tomorrow.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 7 -- The Soviet Union appears to have gained at least a tentative foothold in the economy of Cyprus in the uncertainty of the first few months since the Island became a republic.
The stockholders of the Greist Manufacturing Company, New Haven, Conn., approved a merger with the Teleprinter Corporation, Paramus, N.J., at a meeting in New Haven yesterday.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 7 -As the Senators in Washington last year, the Twins of Minnesota, surprised everyone by coming home fifth in the American League. After three consecutive eighth-place finishes, that was quite an achievement.

Paperboard production in the country rose to 316,648 tons in the week ended last Saturday from 305,151 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. The gain was the second in two weeks.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 7 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, calling on the defensive genius of Bill Russell, held off a last-period drive by the Cincinnati Royals and gained a 124-121 victory in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

An Easter fashion show and luncheon will be held at the Sheraton-East on April 2 for the benefit of the Girls Club of New York. The seventh annual event will feature millinery, couture furs, accessories and men's and children's hats.

A new color television picture, said to provide an increase in brightness of as much as 50 per cent in pictures, with greater sharpness and contrast, was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.
The competition to buy New York's WNTA-TV has become a four-handed game.

Earle Reynolds, an anthropologist went to Hiroshima as a member of a commission to study the long-range biologic effects of nuclear bombing. His experience there convinced him that further testing of nuclear weapons was a grave menace to future mankind.

It is always useful in a "time of troubles" like this to step back and look around. The temptation, when the Congo erupts, when rioters storm Belgian embassies, when students in Asia stone U.S.I.A. offices, when a young man in Havana overturns his country and upsets a hemisphere, to look at the particular event.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate rejected today attempts to force President Kennedy to withdraw the controversial nomination of Charles M. Meriwether to be a director of the Export-Import Bank.

DETROIT, Marc-h 7 (UPI) -The Detroit Red Wings broke a three-game losing streak and moved closer to a National Hockey League play-off berth tonight by beating the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, before 8.836 fans.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, March 7 -- The General Assembly resumed its fifteenth session today and heard President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana. demand that the United Nations reorganize its military and civilian program in the Congo.

AS long as life consists of a perpetual series of decisions much of life will consist of ethical judgments. Is this the right thing to do and, if not, can I persuade myself that it is, because I want to do it? What ought to be done? What would probably be done by such a man? And how did he get to be the sort of man who would do it ?
You recently published a series of letters on the subject of automobile accidents. It is important to observe that all your correspondents did not deal with the same facets of the problem.

Every business downturn takes on a characteristic all its own. Yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York had a few comments to make in its latest monthly review on how the present recession differed from others. In the first place, it called the recession "so far the mildest of those in the postwar period."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Kennedy Administration is considering asking Congress for authority to show the Soviet Union some of the nation's outmoded atomic bombs to be used in test-detection experiments.

Eleven New York Central and New Haven Railroad trains were delayed up to forty minutes last night when a southbound New Haven locomotive caught fire two blocks north of the 138th Street station in the Bronx.

The twelve-team field for the National Invitation Tournament was completed yesterday when St. Louis University accepted a bid. Ken Norton, chairman of the selection committee, also announced the pairings and seedings for the basketball tournament.
It was man versus crocodilians and serpents yesterday in the Bronx Zoo's biennial weighing project in the Reptile House. Man won in a hard fight.
PARIS, March 7 -- France's most sensational kidnapping case in the last quarter century, the abduction of Eric Peugeot, was marked "solved" today.

The McCrory Corporation, a variety store chain, has purchased 197,670 common shares of the Lerner Stores Corporation, which operates 305 stores selling women's and children's apparel, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington accused the Air Force today of having wasted the taxpayers' money by giving flight pay to officers who remained in the back of the plane while subordinates piloted the craft.

The Commonwealth, which opens its annual conference in London this morning, is always a baffling organization to contemplate. It exists, but defies definition. It is nebulous and flexible, but it is strong. Every member is completely independent and they have some policies that put them gravely at odds with each other -- but they remain united.

NO woman with a Junior figure should have cause to complain about finding clothes in her size range. Abraham Straus joins ranks tomorrow with many other department stores in devoting a whole new section to sizes 3 to 15.
CHICAGO, March 7 -- A five-acre, million-dollar, steel and concrete hog house was dedicated today at the Chicago Stock Yards.

BOSTON, March 7 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, told regional trucking executives here today that his union wanted a contract covering New England to expire at the same time as other contracts throughout the nation, Feb. 1, 1964.
In reply to the Feb. 27 letter by "An American Mother," may I quote to her the decision of the Supreme Court (1925) involving the case of Pierce vs. Sisters (268 U.S. 519):

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 7 (AP) -- The Alabama Court of Appeals set aside today the convictions, of a white college professor, a white minister and seven Negroes arrested while dining together in a Montgomery cafe.

Most United States importers are taking in stride the upward revaluation of the Deutsche mark and the Netherlands guilder, a survey revealed yesterday. The value of the mark was officially raised 5 per cent on Saturday; the value of the guilder, 4.75 per cent on Monday.

A preliminary injunction was issued yesterday on New York Mailers Union 6 of the International Typographical Union by Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson. The order restrains the union from inducing its members to refuse to handle Sunday supplements delivered to The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Mirror and The New York Journal-American by the Neo Gravure Printing Company.

Americans read and hear a great deal about the efforts of the United States to promote understanding of our culture, history and political objectives abroad and encourage amicable relations between Americans and people of other countries. There is perhaps insufficient knowledge and appreciation among Americans of similar efforts in this country by other nations and foreigners friendly to us.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- One of every 100 hunters is a huntress. American hunters are blase to hunting walrus. And nine times as many American hunters dig rock 'n' roll as listen to opera.

LONDON, March 7 (Reuters) -- A witness at a trial in Estonia today pictured a man now in Britain as the chief executioner of a Nazi concentration camp during World War II, the Soviet press agency Tass said.
HAVANA, March 7 -- Premier Fidel Castro made a tentative offer today for negotiations with the United States to settle differences with Cuba.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- The United States proposed today that the United Nations put off the disarmament debate in the resumed session of the General Assembly. However, the Soviet Union promptly called for a full-scale debate.

Directors of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad, at a meeting held here yesterday, declared a dividend of 40 cents a common share, payable March 27, to holders of record of March 17. The company paid 50 cents a share in previous quarters.
An enlarged new botanical garden for Queens is slated to be one of the permanent by-products of the New York World's Fair, 1964-65, in Flushing Meadow Park.
CHICAGO, March 7 -- The president of a union that represents airline hostesses declared today that he had "completed an affiliation" with the Transport Workers Union of America.

David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, called last night for a two-step program to halt any further flow of gold from the United States and alleviate the nation's deficit in its balance of payments.
BOWIE, Md., March 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Edith L. Price's Yes You Will made his debut as a 5-year-old today in the Domino Purse and finished a fast-closing third after being last from the gate.
Taking an old, partly unglued violin in payment for a $35 debt didn't seem like the way to get rich to Irving Kertesz, a West Side manufacturer, but he didn't think he had any choice.

A prediction that mainland investments in Puerto Rico would rise about 130 per cent to 1970, from $1,300,000,000 to $3,000,000,000, was made yesterday by Jesus Diaz-Hernandez, executive director of the Puerto Rico Economic Development Administration.

An informal survey that was made yesterday among the large agencies shows just how much the recession is hurting Madison Avenue and just how much it is causing the agencies to tighten their own belts.
CHICAGO, March 7 -- The Post Office Department is abandoning its $4,500,000 facsimile "speed mail" delivery system, J. Edward Day, Postmaster General, said today.

What appeared to be a lack of respect for the Knickerbockers -- or perhaps it was maudlin sympathy for them -- was a major asset in the New York quintet's 114-113 triumph over the Syracuse Nationals at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -The United States reversed today the order that yesterday sent a small Navy task force toward Congolese waters.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday approved the disbarring for one year of Joseph D. Nunan Jr., a former United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue.
Lynn Burke, the 17-year-old Olympic swimming champion from Flushing, Queens, said yesterday that she intended to turn professional. She hopes to sign with a swimming show.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

John S. Bolles, San Francisco architect, has opened a New York office at 17 East Eighty-fourth Street. There will be a branch of the Bolles Gallery, where the work of West Coast artists will be exhibited, at the same address.
WARSAW, March 7 -- Ambassadors of the United States and Communist China met today for a ninety-minute exchange of views on questions that have long held their Governments in a state of hostility.

Some cancer patients have recently been found abnormally tolerant to tissue transplants as distinctly foreign as baby pig skin, according to a progress report issued yesterday by the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to help finance a $6,870,000 rescue program for the commuter railroads serving New York.
Bill Russell, the rebounding ace of the Boston Celtics, yesterday was named the most valuable player of the National Basketball Association by metropolitan writers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- Following are the texts of statements issued by the United States delegate, Adlai E. Stevenson, and the Soviet delegation concerning questions to be discussed at the resumed session of the General Assembly:

Walter S. Fried, vice chairman of the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board, said yesterday that New York had definitely abandoned the bulldozer approach to housing developments in favor of selective redevelopment.
The Communication Workers of America won the right yesterday to represent 18,000 installation and maintenance employes of the New York Telephone Company.
PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- In a surprise move, Federal Judge J. Cullen Ganey authorized today the release from prison of two Westinghouse Electric Corporation executives four days ahead of time.

The downturn that began about the middle of 1960 in the textiles market is continuing, Robert T. Stevens, president of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textiles manufacturer, said at the annual meeting of shareholders yesterday.
William A. Lyon, president of the Dry Dock Savings Bank, called yesterday for a revision of laws and practices governing savings institutions to make them generally consistent.

Most commodity futures moved in narrow ranges in dull trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Rubber, zinc and lead rose; sugar, hides, copper, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined, and price movements for cocoa, coffee, potatoes and wool were mixed.

ONE of the most difficult plays in bridge is to put up a king when a low card is led from dummy, hoping or expecting that one's partner instead of the declarer has the ace. However, it is surprising how many players encounter in run-of-the-mill tournaments nowadays make that difficult play.

ROME, March 7 -- The National Congress of Italian Monarchists has revealed the existence of Left-Wing tendencies in the movement, which was considered a stronghold of political and social conservatism.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- Most visitors were barred from the United Nations today to avoid possible demonstrations during the speech of President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana.
ALBANY, March 7 -- A bill that would give New York City the right to establish a public-defender system to represent poor persons in court cases cleared the Assembly today.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- The state said today it would seek to prove that Joseph A. Peel Jr. was a "racketeer'' on whose orders two murders had been carried out.
The giant, unfinished aircraft carrier Constellation, struck by a $48,000,000 fire last December in the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn, will be officially commissioned Oct. 28.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- The Senate confirmed today the nominations of Treasury Secretary Douglas Dillon as a governor, and of Under Secretary of State George W. Ball as alternate governor, of the International Monetary Fund, the International Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.

ONCE upon a time Sophie designed a culotte for golfing. That was fifteen years ago. This season she decided to bring it back, copy it exactly and add a jacket. The result is one of the most interesting suits in her new custom collection.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -The head of the Federal Reserve System expressed his views today on the cause and cure of widespread unemployment. They showed a wide variance from those given by the Kennedy Administration.

MADRID, March 7 -- The Theatre Guild American Repertory Company opened its fifteen-week tour tonight with a performance of Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" at the Teatro Espanol. In keeping with Spanish tradition, the curtain did not rise until after 11 P.M.

HOPEFUL, Ga., March 7 -- W.E. Dailey of Saginaw, Mich., all fired up because his wife, Mary Jane, almost outshot him yesterday, went out today and shot three quail on one rise, followed that with a double and then picked off four singles in a row.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Frank B. Ellis, director of the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization, charged today that the civil-defense program was "completely inadequate."
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- The House Information subcommittee asked President Kennedy today to attack the problem of Government secrecy.
The Campbell Soup Company reported yesterday that it had achieved record sales and earnings in six months ended on Jan. 29, the first half of its fiscal year.

THE problem encountered by a child with only a penny to spend for candy is legendary. But adults who are less restricted by their pocketbooks find it almost as difficult to select one French pastry from an assortment or one dessert from an attractive counter display.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Representative Emanuel Celler warned today that foreign steamship lines participating in United States foreign commerce must comply with United States maritime laws.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee gave conditioned approval today to United States membership in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a twenty-nation association of Western nations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- Lawrence T. Reid of Boston has taken over the job of rally board chairman of the Sports Car Club of America. He will have his hands full in 1961; there are sixteen national events on his calendar, some rule amendments to be enforced and a score or more of new concepts in rally organization and conduct to reconcile.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare today abandoned its five-year effort to dispose of Ellis Island in New York harbor for health or educational purposes.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 7 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province in the Congo will propose the creation of a central coordinating agency as a first step toward restoration of a single effective government throughout the Congo.
MONTREAL, March 7 (Canadian Press) -- Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada, Ltd., had net earnings in 1960 of $23,497,740, or $1.43 a share, compared with $16,-
Dean Prentice and the rookies from Guelph return to action tonight when the New York Rangers play the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The State of California has designated April 5 for its next sale of bonds. The borrowing will aggregate $190,000,000, and will consist of $140,000,000 of veterans' aid obligations and $50,000,000 of construction bonds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- Members of the Western division of the Writers Guild of America will be asked to vote on the position taken by their union in connection with a suit filed by a group of writers and actors against the movie industry.
ALBANY, March 8 -- A measure that would establish a broader definition of criminal insanity was passed by the Assembly today without debate.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 8 -- A New Jersey woman and her physician may have had a part in saving the life of Elizabeth Taylor.
Two floors in the office building at 800 Second Avenue, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, have been leased by the U.S. Vitamin Pharmaceutical Corporation.
Two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have acquired an interest of about 22 per cent in the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.
Ocean-going merchant ships made 2,044 trips into and out of the Port of New York last month, according to a report of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Kennedy urged Congress and the country today not to let the church-state issue kill his program of Federal aid to education.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., March 8 -- The Superintendent of Schools here, who was summarily dismissed by the School Board Monday, returned to his office today and said he "expects to show up at the usual hour tomorrow."

STANFORD, Calif., March 8 (UPI) -- The Stanford University chapter of the Alpha Tau Omega fraternity, with strong backing from the university president and the State of California, said today that it would become an independent local fraternity.

If the intimations of your news report of March 1 of the "flap" over military strategy a warranted, it would seem that James Reston's comment in the same issue somewhat underrates, or at least misconstrues, the seriousness of the issue.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- The United Nations General Assembly ground to a virtual halt today, pending a big-power decision on dropping several controversial items from the agenda.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Max Conrad, 58 years old, put his small twin-engined plane down at Miami International Airport early today and claimed a record for circling the globe in a light airplane.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Democrats displayed unaccustomed unity in the House of Representatives today as they won the first voting test on the Kennedy Administration's emergency feed-grains bill.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg told his former labor federation colleagues today to speak up if they did not like the way the Kennedy Administration was going.
A $500 reward for a lost diamond-set platinum lorgnette was paid yesterday to a young factory worker who found it on a muddy midtown street Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed today the appointment of Charles M. Meriwether of Alabama as a director of the Export-Import Bank. The roll-call vote was 67 to 18.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 (UPI) -- John F. Kennedy will be the first President to be depicted as the hero of a motion picture while still in office.
