WASHINGTON, March 8--President Kennedy warned the nation today against boycotts of imported goods, such as the one the clothing workers' union is planning against Japanese cloth.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, proposed today a civil rights program, including a Federal Employment Practices Commission.
NORTH SALEM, N.Y., March 8 -- A museum experimenting with culture in rural areas will unveil plans tomorrow night for its first major building -- a combination concert hall and exhibition gallery.
The southeast corner of York Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street has been purchased by Omar Khayam, Inc., representing builders, as the site of an apartment house.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Representative Earl Wilson, Republican of Indiana, said today that Republicans should stop defending the Eisenhower Administration and become "militant watchdogs of the Kennedy New Frontier."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 8 -- A group of New Jersey conservationists has formed a state committee to assist in the acquisition of land in the Great Swamp of Morris County for a proposed Federal wildlife preserve.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Kennedy avoided answering a question at his news conference today as to whether observation flights on the perimeter of the Soviet Union would continue.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Boncrist Farm's Nashua Blue, slipping through along the rail, beat the favored Beau Prince in today's $10,000 added Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park. Intensive was third and On His Metal was fourth.

Members of the hostess and arrangements committees for the Boys Club of New York spring dance will be entertained at tea this afternoon at the home of Mrs. David Granger, of 640 Park Avenue, chairman of the event planned for April 27 at the Plaza.
MOSCOW, March 8 -- Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., United States Ambassador, flew today to Siberia to confer with Premier Khrushchev on possible means of improving Soviet United States relations.
BUENOS AIRES, March 8 -- Cuba declined today Argentina's offer of "good offices" to bring about a relaxation of tension between the Castro regime and the United States.

LONDON, March 8 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, today dismissed reports "in certain sections of the foreign press" that the pound sterling might be devalued. In a statement to the House of Commons he said the Government did "not consider that the pound is overvalued in terms of other currencies."

Production of electric power posted its fifth consecutive weekly decline last week. The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that output in the week ended on Saturday was 14,226,000,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 14,239,000,000 the week before and 14,370,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, called today for the joint development of the upper Columbia River Basin by the United States and Canada.

The recent declaration by G. Mennen Williams, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, in which he is alleged to have stated that Africa was to be reserved for the Africans, which includes the Union of South Africa and the Federation of the Rhodesias, has come as a great shock and surprise to citizens of this country.
MOSCOW, March 8 -- A complaint of discrimination by the State of New Hampshire against Communist newsmen was published here today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 8 -- President Kennedy's election has given Catholics the status of "first-class" citizens," with the opportunity of greater participation in social, cultural and civic affairs, a leading Jesuit writer said here today.
St. Paul, Minn., borrowed $10,634,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of public schools and other public improvements.

When Mayor Wagner referred to his health recently as "fair" rather than good or excellent it caused some surprise. Now the Mayor reveals that he will enter Memorial Hospital in ten days for removal of a benign tumor near his right ear. He expects to be in the hospital for less than a week, and will recuperate at Gracie Mansion for a few more days, meanwhile carrying on his duties of office.
DARWIN, Australia, March 8 -- The harsh application of a law forbidding the sale of alcoholic beverages to fullblood aborigines threatens a constitutional crisis in Australia's Northern Territory.
DETROIT, March 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks recovered from a slow start tonight and defeated the New York Knicks, 117 -- 94, in a National Basketball Association game.

When President Kennedy recently called for the creation of a special child health unit to study, among other things, the causes of mental retardation, he focused attention on a relatively unacknowledged problem.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced today it has dropped an antitrust complaint against Texaco, Inc., which has been pending in the Federal District Court at San Diego, Calif., for nearly eleven years.

PARIS, March 8 -- France is planning to lower her tariffs unilaterally for industrial products, at least those from her five partners in the Common Market. The move is expected to act as a brake if inflation strikes in France.
Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Calrk last night made "the confession of a former Attorney General" about the list of totalitarian, Fascist, Communist and subversive organizations he compiled.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Kennedy and President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana sought common ground today between the African policies of the United States and Ghana.

To Sir Thomas Beecham music was never a mere time-beating (or time-serving) activity. It was a passionate enterprise into which he poured the fullness of his musical gifts and human personality. Vigor and a certain flamboyance marked all he did. If it was music, it concerned him whether it was the behavior of the audience in the concert hall or the phrasing of a Mozart symphony.

Stocks enjoyed a big, bustling market yesterday, but acted a little unsure of themselves. A few more rose than fell, but the principal averages were down. The New York Times combined average hit the lowest level so far this month.
A lively, smilingly malevolent Barnaba, in the person of Mario Sereni, marked the only novelty in the cast of last night's performance of "La Gioconda" at the Metropolitan Opera.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers Union, singled out a shorter work week today as the most pressing need of his unemployment-plagued union.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Charles Minor Meriwether, approved by the Senate today to be a director of the Export-Import Bank, has been for years a member of that school of Southern politicians that wields more influence out of public office than in.
The Cloak and Suit Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers asked four employer associations yesterday for a 10 per cent wage increase for 45,000 workers.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Rockefeller rejected today as "unsound', the four compromise relief residency bills proposed by Senator Walter J. Mahoney.
The appointment of Ian A. Morrison as executive director of the Greer School was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert S. Beekman, chairman of the board.
TOKYO, March 8 -- Japan told Premier Khrushchev today that his plan for reorganizing the staff of the United Nations would destroy the world organization.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 8 -- Surprises can come in many forms. Tonight a surprise struck the United States hockey team in the final period of its game against East Germany in the world hockey tournament.

A deadlock developed yesterday between the city's Real Estate Commissioner and one of the city's major developers over the proposed tie-in sale of public and private properties in the Brooklyn Civic Center area.
BONN, Germany, March 8 -- The opposition Social Democratic party won from the Government today a public defense of the patriotism of Germans who fought Hitler from abroad.
MIAMI, March 8 -- With rookies supplying the rocket power, the Orioles shot from sixth to second place in the American League standings last year.

Plans to add at least fifteen discount self-service operations this year were announced yesterday by Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., a chain that now has 246 conventional retail outlets in 197 cities in thirty-six states.

GENEVA, March 8 -- Valeri Brumel left Paris yesterday morning for Moscow, having stopped for thirty-six hours to see the sights. He was on his way home after having trounced John Thomas, officially the world's best high jumper, in three straight meets in New York.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -Lar Daly, perennial candidate for office, is suing the large radio networks for nearly $70,000,000 over the equal-time issue.

LONDON, March 8 -- The engagement of Prince Edward, the Duke of Kent, cousin o Queen Elizabeth II, was announced today. He will marry Katharine Worsley, daughter of Sir William Worsley, Lord Lieutenant of the North Riding of Yorkshire, and Lady Worsley.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Kennedy disclosed today that the United States had supplied polio vaccine to Guantanamo City in Cuba to help curb a polio epidemic.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -The National Park Service disclosed today it was considering permitting civilians to hunt deer and elk on national park lands.
Robert A. Groat has been appointed director of sales for Associated Transport, Inc., New York. He had been general sales manager of the Western region.
TRENTON, March 8 -- About one-third of New Jersey's public school teachers are engaged in extra duty assignments for no pay, a survey showed today.
Van Alstyne, Noel Co. and associates are offering today 250,000 common shares of Whippany Paper Board Company, Inc. at $15 a share.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., March 9 -- Four executives of the electrical industry were released from jail here at 12:04 A.M. today after having served twenty-five days for rigging prices and bids.
CAIRO, March 8 (UPI) -- Antoine Gizenga, former Deputy Premier in the Congo when Patrice Lumumba was premier, reaffirmed today his claim to be the head of the legitimate Government in the Congo.
Cotton futures fell 2 to 11 points yesterday, except the new July contract, which rose 10 points on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- The Yankees put their game of "simulated baseball" to the test today. And while it may have been a trifle confusing to the 600 or 700 enthusiasts who regularly attend the workouts at Miller Huggins Field, it was generally scored an unqualified success.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Kennedy said today that the anti-recession speed-up of Federal procurement and construction would result in the placing of $660,000,000 more in contracts in the first half of this year.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, said today that he would meet in Washington Friday with top Government information officers, Congressmen and newspaper representatives for a "full and frank" discussion of Government policies on releasing information.

MONTREAL, March 8 (Canadian Press) -- The Canada Labor Relations Board has ordered a vote among licensed engineers of nearly 200 Great Lakes ships to decide between the Seafarers' International Union and the National Association of Marine Engineers as their bargaining agent, a Seafarers' spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Establishment of public recreational areas along the nation's shorelines before the cost of acquiring such property becomes prohibitive was urged today by witnesses before a Senate Public Lands subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Business Advisory Council, the industry advisory body to the Commerce Department, today postponed indefinitely its first meeting with the new Secretary of Commerce, Luther H. Hodges.

TOKYO, March 8 (Reuters) -- The Japanese Socialist party today rejected its revolutionary program and the more extreme facets of its anti-American policy laid down three years ago by Inajiro Asanuma, party president who was assassinated last October.

The Board of Education's 1961 building program moved along yesterday with the hiring Of private architects to design two new buildings, four additions and an athletic field at a total cost of $9,300,000.
GREENWICH, March 8 -- A proposal to increase teacher salaries here on the basis of merit was made today.

Four local teams will play the regular season's final college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The program will get under way at 7:30, with Fordham engaging Manhattan. St. John's will meet New York University for the fortieth time since 1908 in the feature.
LONDON, March 8 -- A new Constitution granting a much wider degree of self-government will soon be drafted for Malta, Iain Macleod, the Colonial Secretary, announced today.

Simple arithmetic shows that a speed of 2,905 miles per hour is equivalent roughly to almost fifty miles per minute and almost five-sixths of a mile per second. The notion that a human being can travel that rapidly and then term his trip "routine" staggers the imagination even of those who have come to accept 600-mile-an-hour commercial jet flights as commonplace.
William Forbes and James Dunn of Philadelphia, last year's winners, advanced to the semi-finals of the national open court tennis doubles championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -Soybean futures prices shifted over their usually broad range today but trade was considerably more two-sided than for several weeks and prices ended generally within a cent of preceding closes.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that testimony taken recently about Communist infiltration of the Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy concerned only the organization's Greater New York committee and not the national committee.
Mayor Wagner began a series of conferences with representatives of city employe groups at City Hall yesterday to get their views on salary and other needs for fiscal 1961-62.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A staff lawyer of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended to the commission today that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad file a bankruptcy proceeding. He said there were no cures for the line's financial ills.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -Representative Emanuel Celler said today the Federal Maritime Board should be separated from the Commerce Department and turned into an independent regulatory agency.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 8 -- Margaret Varner, the defending champion from Wilmington, Del., and Mrs. Charles Wetzel Jr. of Philadelphia, seeded No. 2, reached the final of the women's national squash racquets championship today.
When Bobby Delaney was only a year old, he suddenly started to hemorrhage. His frantic mother rushed him to near-by Greenpoint Hospital where doctors immediately started to administer blood.

A bloodhound named Dan worked at the Manhattan Savings Bank on Madison Avenue from Monday to Friday last week. His presence led to inquiries about the dogs the State Police keep at Hawthorne Barracks in Westchester County. They trail lost persons and occasional criminals.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Communist China has rejected the Kennedy Administration's first effort for some improvement in relations.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A commercial airliner carrying Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy made a forced landing today but she safely returned to Washington from Palm Beach on her second attempt.
KARRVILLE, N.J., March 8 -- The school bus would not come to the mountain where Mrs. Jean Jost lived, so she bought her own bus.

The state's new wallet-sized driver's license will go into the mails for the first time this April. It will be sent to chauffeurs whose licenses expire on May 31, Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults announced yesterday.
BUFFALO, March 8 -- A $10,000,000 flour mill was officially opened here today by General Mills, Inc. The new plant, employing the Bellera "air-spun" process, has a capacity of 1,200,000 pounds a day.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Legislature approved a series of budget bills today for new appropriations of $2,394,500,000 to run the state government in the fiscal year that starts April 1.

A THREE-CONCERT series of Bach and Mozart sonatas was begun in Town Hall last night by Robert Gerle, violinist, and Albert Fuller, harpsichordist, under the sponsorship of the Clarion Music Foundation.

As a member of the New York State Insurance Committee investigating the Associated Hospital Service of New York, commonly known as Blue Cross, I wish to express my disappointment over your March 4 editorial, which, in essence, supported the policies and administration of that agency.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8 -- The big question in these parts is "How's Ingemar's left?" -- not "When is President Kennedy coming down?" or "How do you like this 80-degree weather?"
LONDON, March 8 -- The conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers opened today and was confronted by the difficult task of deciding whether a member should be expelled because of its racial policy.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Harold Russell, national commander of the American Veterans Committee, today opposed measures for increasing veterans' pensions that are now before the House.
ALBANY, March 8 -- A bill fixing the primary election for Thursday, Sept. 7, was approved in the Senate today and is scheduled for a final vote in the Assembly early next week.
Eric Sevareid, London correspondent for Columbia Broadcasting System News, will be the narrator for an hour-long television report on forces and factors that are changing Britain.
City action on plans for construction of the $16,765,578 baseball stadium in Queens will be deferred until March 23.

PARIS, March -- The French Government will transfer Mohammed Ben Bella, imprisoned leader of the Algerian rebellion, from an island prison to comfortable "controlled residence" near Paris within the next two or three days.

A committee representing the Foster Home Department of the Children's Aid Society has chosen the evening performance of "Mary, Mary" on April 12 for a benefit theatre party. The Jean Kerr comedy starring Barbara Bel Geddes, Barry Nelson and Michael Rennie opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theatre.

The annual report of the Keystone Low-Priced Common Stock Fund S-4 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 informed shareholders that it had established a new industry designation -aerospace -- to list portfolio holdings in the space fields.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy advised New York City Democratic leaders today that the United States Attorney's post in the Southern District of New York was "not a patronage matter."

The number of jobless in the nation reached 5,705,000 in the month of February, according to the official figures of the Labor and Commerce Departments, just released by Arthur J. Goldberg, Secretary of Labor. The 5,705,000 figure, the Secretary notes, is the highest since 1941.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 9 -- Congolese poligical leaders meeting in conference here today urged that the United Natioss refrain from any further action in the Congo without taking into account the Congolese opinion expressed here.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Senator Milton R. Young said today that leaders of an ultra-conservative, semi-secret group operating in many states had falsely accused former President Dwight D. Eisenhower of being a Communist.

In the Yiddish theatre, Menasha Skulnik achieved a reputation for his inimitable musical portrayals. But Broadway has not seen him in an entertainment compounded with songs and dances. The omission will be rectified with his delineation of Menelaus in "Helen of Troy."

Calling investment clubs "classrooms in economics," Thomas E. O'Hara, chairman of the National Association of Investment Clubs (N.A.I.C.), started a campaign yesterday to increase the number of "pupils" and broaden the movement.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 8 -- America's fastest man on skis, Wallace (Bud) Werner, returns to Eastern racing tomorrow. The 24-year-old University of Colorado sophomore will be the Buffaloes' mainstay when the three-day National Collegiate championships get under way at the near-by Snow Bowl. any thought Werner wouldi make a sweep of i the Olympic Alpine events at Scluawi Valley last winter. !

Events tonight: "Turandot," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; New York Philharmonic preview Concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Schola Cantorum, directed by Hugh Ross, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Concert of music by William Sydeman and Peter Pindar Stearns, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

ERNIE KOVACS essayed last night an hour of comedy built on the idea of satirizing the private detective. Even with the added talents of Edie Adams, Pat Carroll and Hans Conried "Private Eye, Private Eye" was a desultory and unimaginative outing.

" THE STONE ARBOR,"* by Roger Angell, is a fine collection of New Yorker stories about the Button-Down-Collar Generation in crucial hours of tension and pleasure. The collegiate backgrounds, the summers at the beach and the winters near Madison Avenue, the sounds of fading, rural ancestral voices are caught with a splendidly casual ease.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Navy Secretary and the Chief of Naval Operations asked Congress today for more money, ships and personnel.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Cariton Welch, defense attorney, said today that Floyd A. Holzapfel, who has confessed killing Judge and Mrs. C.E. Chillingworth, had been indicted for another slaying. He said the state had taken no further action.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (AP) -- Eighteen fish-hating seamen ended a night-long strike today and went back to work on the Swedish freighter Parramatta and the prospect of more pickled herring.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The White House indicated again today that President Kennedy might supplement his weekly new conferences with a series of fireside chats on radio and television.

THERE is a first-rank shoe factory in this city where the highly skilled craftsmen do not stick to their last. About once a month four of the artisans -- all of Italian or Sicilian origin -- repair to a company kitchen and prepare a feast that would probably bemuse Belshazzar.
Talks aimed at averting a port strike by 800 lighter captains on April 5 -- one that could cripple marine operations of seven railroads -- will begin next Tuesday.

IN an age of mass production, custom order inevitably is on the wane. Experienced tailors die out with no new ones to replace them in their painstaking craft. Fewer and fewer customers -- and custom order has always been a limited operation -- are willing to invest the necessary time and money.

MEXICO CITY, March 8 -- A series of about 150 resolutions, generally accusing the United States of colonialism, economic aggression and endangering the peace of the Western Hemisphere, were approved by acclamation at a pro-Leftist conference that ended here tonight.

A woman said to have been wearing very high heels tripped and plunged off the Eighth Avenue IND subway station at Forty-second Street and fell in front of a southbound express train at 2:30 P.M. yesterday. Both legs were severed below the knee.
Howard Werkheiser lives on a 134-acre farm in Kewanee, Ill. -- "the hog capital of the world" -- and has hands about the size of skillets.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- The trend is unmistakable. The ballplayers have gone literary. Yogi Berra and Jim Brosnan have written books and Larry Jackson has just undertaken the assignment of dashing off a regular column for his hometown newspaper in Boise, Idaho. The star pitcher of the St. Louis Cardinals already has scooped the experts by predicting that the Redbirds will win the pennant this year.
A policeman who had charged a Harlem lawyer with defamation of character and injury to his chances for promotion won his case yesterday in State Supreme Court.
BERLIN, March 8 -- W. Averell Harriman said today that President Kennedy did not feel committed to any discussions on the Berlin issue conducted by the Eisenhower Administration.
Willie Suttton describes himself as a bank robber who never informed on a friend, and who limited his friends to thieves, according to testimony yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

ABOUT thirty years ago, newspaper readers had a field day following the details of The Mystery of the Schumann Violin Concerto. It was quite a story, complete with seances, mediums and communication with departed spirits.
An unusually small decline in the inventories of the three major oil products for the week ended last Friday highlighted the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute, issued yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 8 -- The record speed of the X-15 rocket plane in its latest flight was raised today to 2,905 miles an hour by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration after close examination of flight instruments.

After reading A.L. Colloms' letter on civil liberties in Spain and the answer to it by His Excellency Don Mariano de Yturralde, Ambassador of Spain, the first thing that comes to mind is that nearer in time and space is the plight of Cuban political prisoners.

RANGOON, Burma, March 8 (Reuters) -- A 200-man combined force of Chinese Nationalist irregulars and Shah rebels attacked and occupied a village in Shan State in northern Burma yesterday, army sources said today.

Villanova's talented defending champions and Yale's Heptagonal titleholders will battle for the team honors in the fortieth annual indoor Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., was found guilty yesterday of violating the antitrust laws by restraining air commerce between this country and South America.
LONDON, March 8--Sir Thomas Beecham, Britain's greatest and most outspoken conductor, died at his London home early today after a cerebral thrombosis. He was 81 years old.
Following is the text of President Kennedy's news conference yesterday as recorded The New York Times:
The Reliance Manufacturing Company and Jonathan Logan, Inc., called off their merger talks yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -Elton H. Brown, a lively, cheerful, white-haired man, can look back over fifty-five years of association with American inventors. In nature, he says, inventors have changed little since he started work at the Patent Office in 1905, although invention has run through several cycles.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker rode New Policy, the odds-on favorite, to victory today in the $27,850 San Bernardino Handicap at Santa Anita Park.
LONDON, March 8 -- The national and regimental colors of the Fourth United States Regiment, captured at Fort Detroit Aug. 16, 1812, were transferred today to the Welch Regiment.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- U. Alexis Johnson was reported today to be Secretary of State Dean Rusk's choice for Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

INTERCITY bridge matches are becoming increasingly popular. Today a two-day match between Denver and Dallas teams begins at Denver, preliminary to the national bridge tournament that will be played at Denver from this Saturday to March 20.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP) -- Pennsylvania taught Princeton, the Ivy League champion, a basketball lesson at the Palestra tonight by routing the Tigers, 88 -- 63, in the closing league contest for both teams.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Princeton won the annual freshman polar bear track meet today with 73 1/2 points. Pennsylvania was second with 49 1/2 points and Columbia last with 12 points in blustery, windy 37degree temperature at Franklin Field.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, March 8 (UPI) -- The Netherlands Antilles revalued the local guilder today in relation to the United State dollar after a similar step by the home Government.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- More and more the political struggle over President Kennedy's aid-to-education bill is turning on a subtle and difficult legal question: Does the Constitution allow the Government to aid church schools?

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- United Nations authorities have emphasized the vital need to regain their position at Matadi, in the Congo, because thirty-one United Nations supply ships are expected to dock there "in the next three weeks or so."
Rain, sleet and snow brought an unwelcome return of winter to New York and its suburbs yesterday and turned highways slippery.
Market yields on United States Government bonds declined yesterday, but short-term yields declined with them.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, March 8 -- The United Nations Command was rebuffed again today in efforts to negotiate for the return of its forces to Matadi, which they lost in battle last Sunday.

HOLY LOCH, Scotland, March 8 -- The United States nuclear submarine Patrick Henry sailed into Holy Loch today carrying a full load of sixteen Polaris missiles. Four British pacifists in canoes and a rowboat moved out toward the ship to protest her arrival, but they were chased by British launches.
Accounts receivable due manufacturers were 84.4 per cent current on Jan. 1, 1961, compared with 84.5 per cent a year earlier and 83.9 per cent on Oct. 1, according to the Credit Research Foundation.
The president the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau urged city businesses yesterday to contribute $100,000 more to the bureau's budget to help attract foreign tourists to New York.
The New York Rangers lost the game and their most valuable player, Gump Worsley, at Madison Square Garden last night.

Trading in potato futures was dull most of yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices held steady until sthe last half hour of trading. Then the market broke sharply in heavy trading. Final quotations dropped 11 to 18 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,800 car lots of 50,000 pounds each.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8 (UPI) -- The President of the National Association of Real Estate Boards urged the Kennedy Administration today to "restore fiscal responsibility to the operations of the Federal Government."
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 7 -- A number of anomalies greet the vistor to this city, where the East Germans are holding the annual spring fair.
WASHINGTON, March 8--President Kennedy will send a special message to Congress Monday proposing a ten-year program of aid to Latin America for social and economic development.
A detective who holds nine police commendations and a patrolman assigned to the East 126th Street station were arrested yesterday and charged with attempted extortion.
John C. Ryder and Mrs. Evelyn Schwalb have been appointed Republican leaders of the new Twelfth Executive District in the Bronx.

The Navy has awarded a $38,000000 contract to the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation for production of additional W2F-1 Hawkeyes. These are carrier-based, early-warning attack and intercept-control planes.
Two-year unrestricted research grants totaling more than $1,000,000 were awarded yesterday by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation to seventy university scientists.
A promotional experiment with implications of potential importance for department stores throughout the country was begun yesterday by Saks-Thirty-fourth Street.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., March 8 -- An original portrait by the American artist Gilbert Stuart has been presented to The Peddie School by one of its alumni, Dr. Carrol O. Morong, the headmaster, announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- President Kennedy said today that the possibility of establishing a United Nations Peace Corps should be considered.
ALBANY, March 8 -- A bill paving the way for a New York City referendum this fall on Charter revision cleared the Assembly today but ran into a technical snarl in the Senate.

For the United Nations General Assembly, in session again, the most pressing problem is the steadily deteriorating situation in the Congo, where United Nations forces have engaged in open combat with Congolese troops. This situation cries for a solution, yet the United Nations is as badly divided over the question as are the Congolese leaders.

Albert A. List, head of the Glen Alden Corporation, gave a total of $2,600,000 yesterday to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the New School for Social Research and the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.
Net earnings of the Timken Roller Bearing Company last year fell to $19,181,055 from $29,856,040 in 1959, the company reported yesterday.

Britain would consider joining a European common tariff or "harmonized tariff scheme" for manufactured goods and raw materials if certain reservations were allowed, according to Richard Miles, Director of Economic Affairs of the British Information Service.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy had some firsthand contact last Sunday with a couple of New York's juvenile gangs.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8 -Jomo Kenyatta appealed today to Kenya's African political leaders to form a united front on all national issues.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Negro players of the New York Yankees and St. Louis Cardinals tonight received a "personal invitation" from the St. Petersburg Chamber of Commerce to attend a breakfast given by the chamber for the two clubs tomorrow.
MIAMI BEACH, March 8 (UPI) -- Sonny Liston of Philadelphia registered his twenty-fifth straight victory tonight by knocking out Howard King of Reno, Nev., in the third round.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- The United Nations General Assembly was unsuccessful in an hour and a half of voting today on a vacancy on the Economic and Social Council.
It appears that a battle over tea advertising is shaping up that will not resemble an afternoon tea party.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 8 -The proposal of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York to join with six upstate banks in a new holding company won the approval today of its chief rival, the Marine Midland Corporation.

AKRON, Ohio, March 8 (AP) -- Edward O. Lamb of Toledo filed today a libel suit for $500,000 in Summit County Common Pleas Court against J. Penfield Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Rubber Company in which Mr. Lamb holds substantial stock.

The sing-along trend -- promoted with phenomenal success by the record industry in the last three years, recently embraced by television and a staple in a couple of the oldest night clubs in town -- has acquired a new cabaret convert.
The J. Walter Thompson Company yesterday issued the following statement to The New York Times:
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Assembly unanimously approved today and sent to the Senate a bill that would give the state an official song for the first time.
A new Republican publication named The Trumpet blew some sweet notes yesterday for Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz as a possible Republican or Fusion candidate for Mayor.

Riddle Airlines, Inc., and Acrovias, Sud America, Inc., have agreed to merge, Robert M. Hewitt, Riddle president, announced yesterday. The agreement is expected to be signed by both companies today and filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board.

BOSTON, March 8 (UPI) -Two Republican legislators said today the New Haven and the Boston and Maine railroads had paid more than $1,000,000 in salaries and fees to two families or their close relatives and associates in a three-year period.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 8 -A twenty-four-hour strike started today in the nationalized tin mines. The strikers are demanding higher salaries, goods for empty commissaries and protesting because the Government did not send mission to Moscow for talks about a $150,000,000 loan offered by the Soviet Union.

IN "Mary, Mary" Jean Kerr has thrown together a confection that makes one think of sugar and spice. The sugar sums up a syrupy plot that Would fit neatly into the glossy pages of a woman's magazine, and the spice is a generous sprinkling of bright, impertinent lines.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Air Force received virtually exclusive responsibility for military space-development projects, today, over the vigorous opposition of the Navy and Army.

ROME, March 8 -- Mr. Harriman arrived tonight for three days of talks with Italian Government leaders. President Kennedy's Ambassador at Large is winding up his European tour after visits to Britain, France and West Germany.
Insiders are continuing a recent trend to do more selling than buying of stocks, according to the latest insiders' report of the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, March 8 -- Industrial shares failed to develop a trend in the stock market here today, with buying and selling evenly matched. A predominance of small rises among the thirty leading industrial shares making up the Financial Times index lifted it four-tenths of a point to 337.6.

A $228,000 grant for the training of Congolese magistrates and Government officials at the new National School of Law and Administration in Leopoldville was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

HAVANA, March 8 -- Armed civilian militiamen were reported today to have been placed at the Roman Catholic La Salle school in Santiago de Cuba following disorders there between anti-Communist students and supporters of Premier Fidel Castro.

GLASGOW, Scotland, March 6 -- The day after the United States' missile-submarine tender Proteus arrived at her new base in Holy Loch, a motherly, middle-age Scotswoman standing outside the Dunoon post office plucked at the arm of a passing American visitor.
The city moved yesterday to improve facilities for the wholesale meat industry here and keep it from moving to New Jersey.
The machine age in which we live has brought terrifying hazards as well as many difficult economic problems which are far from settled. The simple days of long ago are gone.
Stockholders of both the Manufacturers Trust Company and the Hanover Bank at special meetings yesterday afternoon overwhelmingly approved plans to merge the two institutions.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., March 8 -- Peregrinator, a 6,500 pound granite gargoyle that has become the mascot of students at Oceanside High School, was lowered carefully into an enclosed courtyard of the school here today.
The State Insurance Department announced approval yesterday of increased premium rates for the Blue Shield plan for the payment of doctors' bills in a thirteen-county area around Albany.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Army said today that it envisioned a new fleet of sleek, highly mobile tanks and armored vehicles that would be able to move almost silently.
The New York Young Republican Club and Representative John V. Lindsay, a former president, disagreed again yesterday on a major issue before the country.

Columbia's wrestling team, nurtured by hard work, brotherly sacrifice and profound psychology, will have nine representatives in the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament that begins today at Lehigh.
Renewed efforts to curtail operation of the House Un-American Activities Committee were asked yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

The Washington Post Company bought control of Newsweek magazine yesterday from the Vincent Astor Foundation. The sale ended several weeks of intensive negotiation involving a number of publishing companies.
An early break appeared likely yesterday in the deadlock over the city's proposed tie-in sale of public and private properties in the Brooklyn Civic Center area.
Some day city school children may attend classes on buses, boats, planes and helicopters, a Board of Education official said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 -- Asian countries have initiated a new effort to get the Soviet Union and the Western powers together on terms for a disarmament debate in the General Assembly.
ALBANY, March 9 -- A series of nine bills was filed in the Legislature today to implement the recommendations of the Judicial Conference for an increase in the number of judges on a piecemeal basis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold rejected tonight demands by the Leopoldville Government for equal authority with the United Nations over ports, airfields and other strategic centers.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Kennedy named Dr. Harold Brown today to be director of research and engineering for the Department of Defense.
The State of Michigan announced plans yesterday for the sale of $25,000,000 of trunk highway bonds secured by motor vehicle taxes. Bids on the issue will be received April 4.
RANGOON, Burma, March 9 (AP) -- High Burmese Government officials expressed alarm today at reports that about 1,000 Nationalist Chinese irregulars were moving back from Thailand into northern Burma.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 9 -- For the last fourteen years Romeo Balaguer, vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company in charge of banking relation with North Africa and the Middle East, has done business with the United Nations.

Luis Ferre, Republican national committeeman from Puerto Rico and titular leader of his party there, has called on Cardinal Spellman in a new effort to end church interference in Puerto Rican politics.
DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -- Foreign competition and a reduced demand for iron ore were reported today to be affecting Detroit area shipping and shipbuilding operations.

SAN DIEGO, Calif, March 9 -- A drilling bit at the end of a shaft more than 3,000 feet long struck the ocean bottom off San Diego today, surpassing five-fold the previous record for such an operation.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., 9 (AP) -- The Chillingworth murder trial developed today into a battle over the cross-examination of Floyd Holzapfel. He is the chief witness against Joseph A. Peel Jr., who is accused of masterminding the killings of Circuit Judge C.E. Chillingworth and his wife.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 9 -- Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, Deputy Premier of the Right-Wing Government of Laos, met here today with Prince Souvanna Phouma, neutralist Laotian leader.
Superintedent of Schools John J. Theobald advocated last night that the city's school teachers get a base salary of $10,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- President Kennedy selected Richard R. Hough of Cleveland today to head a task force to study the safe and efficient use of the nation's air space. The group will look into the present system of air traffic control, present and future needs of all users of air space, and research and development programs in this field.

TRENTON, March 9 -- The New Jersey Civil War Centennial Commission voted unanimously today to boycott the fourth national assembly of the National Civil War Centennial Commission in Charleston, S.C., April 11 and 12.

RABAT, Morocco, March 9 -- The first Soviet technical assistance mission to Morocco met with authorities here today to study a project for the construction of a shipbuilding yard on the Mediterranean.
Connecticut Light and Power Company informed its stockholders yesterday that the utility "showed substantial gains" in 1960 despite the general business slowdown in the latter part of the year.

The IND Queens line is losing a straphanger of distinction. Gervais P. Bahizi, permanent representative of the Congo Republic to the United Nations, received the keys to a 1961 Cadillac yesterday. It will be his to use while he is in New York.
The traditional Wall Street ticker tape machine may soon become a thing of the past.

The wholesale commodity price index rose to 86.2 on Wednesday from 86.1 Tuesday. This is the highest point since the same figure was recorded May 31, 1960. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.7 on March 2, 1960.
DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation will close six of its seven car-assembly plants next week, it was announced today. A total of 11,500 employes will be laid off.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- The Yankees' No. 5 uniform was taken out of retirement at Miller Huggins Field today.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Organized labor charged today that the anti-recession programs advanced by President Kennedy and Governor Rockefeller fell far short of what was needed to stimulate the state's economy and restore full employment.

LONDON, March 9 -- Selective demand enabled industrial shares to close with more gains than losses in the stock market here today. The Financial Times industrial shares index rose four-tenths of a point to 338.
SO nice a point of analysis arose in the deal shown that it is a shame the contract was not a good one.
Governor Rockefeller challenged last night a recent statement by Mayor Wagner that the state's school aid formula would cost New York City $10,000,000 in state aid in the fiscal year starting July 1.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 9 -- Margaret Varner of Wilmington, Del., retained her women's national squash racquets championship today by defeating Mrs. Charles Wetzel Jr. of Philadelphia in straight games. Mrs. Wetzel, who had beaten Miss Varner in three previous meetings this season, lost 15 -- 11, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 10.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of New York won an ally last year in its long fight against, the Federal Reserve System's so-called "bills only" rule. The annual report of the system's Board of Governors, published today, showed that the president of the New York bank was joined by the president of the Philadelphia bank in voting against renewal of the rule last spring.

SYRACUSE, March 9 (AP) -- Bill Russell dropped in a one-hander with fifteen seconds left tonight to give Boston a 119-118 victory over Detroit. The loss hurt the Pistons' chances for a play-off spot in the National Basketball Association.

MIAMI BEACH, March 9 -- The last punch thrown by Floyd Patterson in his public training campaign ripped the small punching bag right off its moorings. The crowd of some 400 in the Napoleon room of the Hotel Deauville today gasped at this demonstration of power and then broke out with generous applause.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy shook up an East Harlem precinct yesterday after a detective and a patrolman had been arrested on charges of attempted extortion.

Your editorial dated Feb. 21 in connection with Charter revision for the City of New York, seems to contradict the position you took in your previous editorial dated Jan. 15, 1958, on this same subject.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 9 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates were baseball's world champions in 1960. They won the National League pennant, then implausibly and impossibly beat the Yankees in the world series.

A transitional sugar policy in the present period of disturbed relation with Cuba has to reconcile several related but separable purposes. Ample sugar supplies must be obtained from available sources. Permanent commitments need to be avoided, so that the alternative of renewing Cuban shipments is not entirely foreclosed.

MONTREAL, March 9 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens moved into a tie for first place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the New York Rangers, 6 -- 1, at the Forum. The loss ended the Rangers' chances of making the Stanley Cup playoffs.
The United States Lines fleet of two passenger liners and fifty-three cargo vessels set a company safety record by completing 390 voyages last year with only seventy-three lost-time injuries.
HAVANA, March 9 -- Maj. William A. Morgan, an America from Toledo, Ohio, who is a member of Premier Fidel Castro's Army, went on trial before a military court today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Teen-aged girls were blamed today for most of the juvenile gang wars in New York City.
PARIS, March 9 -- A suit was filed today by five prostitutes against the French national television system for something roughly equivalent to invasion of privacy.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 9 (AP) -- Tennessee State, ranked second in the nation among small-college basketball teams and a rejected bidder for a place in the National Invitation Tournament, was beaten, 92 -- 82, tonight by Winston-Salem Teachers College in the District 29 final play-off for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics tournament.

PLEASANT, competent and ready to come into your kitchen to prepare small party dinners is Miss Maureen Grenier, caterer. Or the obliging young woman will do in her own kitchen hors d'oeuvre for cocktail parties, sandwiches for teas or any of several appetizers and main courses for dinner.
An intensive effort is being pushed by the world's largest breeder of ranch mink to warn the American consumer away from that fur.
GREENPORT, L.I., March 9 -- Two major restrictions were lifted today for the harvest of Long Island's bay scallops.

Anguish that leaves indelible scars too often follows child adoptions hastily arranged on the fuzzy fringes of the law. Much of this heartbreak would be prevented by a bill passed by the Legislature last week.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Philip Leslie Graham, who purchased Newsweek magazine from the Vincent Astor Foundation today, is the embodiment of every young newspaper man's dream of glory.
The Polo Grounds, doomed by the housing project approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, was a stadium made for heroes.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Following are excerpts from the State Department's transcript of the question period of Secretary of State Dean Rusk's news conference today:
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 9 (AP) -- Premier Viggo Kampmann called on the United States Government today to liberalize its shipping and aviation policies.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.

A CAREFULLY edited digest of the recent collections of the Paris haute couture, culled from American purchases abroad, was presented by the Fashion Group yesterday during breakfast and again at luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Kennedy established today another Presidential task force to study the problems of safe and efficient use of air space.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's special message to Congress on housing and community development:
LONDON, March 9 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Macmillan's Government and the Labor party praised President Kennedy's Peace Corps program today.

New York's preview of spring at the Coliseum, which for many visitors to the International Flower Show marks the culmination of a long winter of escape garden reading, has had a record audience to date.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Kennedy Administration won a substantial victory in the House of Representatives today when Democrats from all sections joined to pass an emergency feed-grains bill.

An upstate village is giving the rest of the boating world a lesson in how to build a marina almost without funds. The village is Ilion, on the Erie Canal of the New York Canal System, between Utica and Herkimer.

IN a small gallery supplied for the purpose by the Whitney Museum of American Art, Herbert Ferber, a sculptor, has materialized an idea that has been current for the last several years but has remained mostly on paper for special reasons.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk reasserted today the United States' determination to maintain its position in West Berlin.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 9 -- The United Nations command appeared to have made some important concessions to the Congolese Government today in an effort to pave the way for a peaceful return of its troops to Matadi, a strategic port city.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Former President Harry S. Truman paid a courtesy call at the White House today. Later, President Kennedy dropped in at a downtown hotel dinner where Mr. Truman was guest of honor.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- In their statement on Federal aid to education, the spokesmen for the Roman Catholic Church have raised a serious issue.

The Flintkote Company registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday a proposed public offering of $35,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due in 1981. The marketing of the issue will be managed by Lehman Brothers.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 9 (UPI) -- Walker Inman Jr., who has never finished better than seventh in a pro tournament, sank an 80-yard No. 8 iron shot for an eagle 2 today and took a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the sixth annual $20,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.

TO most 8-year-olds, the future means the day after tomorrow, while the distant future is the week-end after next. But to one youngster and her 10-year-old brother, the future means adulthood, and they are purposefully preparing for it.

Check transactions in the nation's twenty-six leading cities totaled $107,602,864,000 last month, the highest figure for any February on record, although it was off from January's level, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 9 -- A surprise victory by Cordon Eaton of Middlebury Over Wallace (Bud) Werner of the University of Colorado in the downhill provided a stirring opening for the National Collegiate skiing championships today.

"Ed" Collins liked to recall that one of his early jobs before he became a newspaper man was sampling cars of coal. He began with as many tons as a car would hold and wound up with what he hoped was a representative sample of an ounce or so. He said he followed the same procedure in analyzing facts for tile articles he wrote for this newspaper and previously for other periodicals.
Business was light and prices were generally firm in the bond market yesterday except in the congested area of newly-sold local government issues, where heaviness persisted.

ATLANTA, March 9 -- Georgians in costumes of the Old South waltzed through a Civil War Centennial Ball tonight in the Biltmore Hotel on the eve of an anniversary premiere of the film "Gone With the Wind." Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver was the official host and grand marshal.

DORE SCHARY has made a powerful, absorbing drama out of Morris L. West's novel, "The Devil's Advocate." The play bearing the same name, which opened last night at the Billy Rose Theatre, restores one's belief in the potentialities of the Broadway theatre.

BOSTON, March 9 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe's twenty-first and twenty-second goals of the season guided the fourth-place Detroit Red Wings to a 5-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight and a Stanley Cup play-off berth.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose by $44,000,000 to $94,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $162,000,000 to $515,000,000.
WHEN President Kennedy remarked the other day that a million new automobiles are languishing in the warehouses, I felt not only depressed, but also guilty.

Although no date has been set for the resumption of the Twentieth Century-Fox film," "Cleopatra," Spyros P. Skouras, studio president, reiterated in London yesterday that Elizabeth Taylor, now recuperating from double pneumonia in the British capital, was still under contract to Fox and that she definitely would appear in the movie.

DUNELLON, Fla., March 9 -- This gopher hound was lying asleep in the sandy woods road running through a great pasture of oaks and pines, dotted with lakes, ponds and bay heads. She seemed to be a cross between a German shepherd and a black-and-tan.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (UPI) -- Darling June raced to her fourth victory of the Santa Anita meeting as she captured the $15,000 Riverside Handicap for fillies and mares today by two and a half lengths.

The expected impasse has resulted from the latest meeting, at Warsaw on Tuesday, of ambassadorial representatives of the United States and Communist China. The test provided by this meeting, the first to take place since the Kennedy Administration assumed office, of whether improved relations are possible between Washington and Peiping following President Kennedy's election, has turned out to be negative.
One of the more controversial matters in the field of advertising of late has been advertising for children.

This appears to be the season for last ditch fights and eleventh-hour reprieves on Broadway. Theatregoers are by now familiar with the remarkable comeback of the Tad Mosel drama, "All the Way Home." And, with Mrs. Isaac Stern's recent battle on behalf of "The Wall," which kept it alive for another six weeks.

Hide futures prices continued to climb on to new high ground yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. Short covering and commission house buying touched off stop-loss orders. Trading was influenced by another 1-to-1 1/2-cent-a-pound rise in actual hides.

GENEVA, March 9 -- United Nations economic experts suggested today that one way to ease the strain on the United States dollar would be for the Bonn Government to "freeze" the dollars spent in West Germany for defense purposes by the United States.

The Selective Service college qualification test will be given April 27 at approximately 500 colleges in the nation. Col. Paul Akst, city director of Selective Service, said yesterday that application blanks and information bulletins with sample questions might be obtained by students at the nearest local board.

The New York Committee for Democratic Voters, anti-De Sapio insurgents, organized a new "general committee" last night to unseat any Democratic county chairmen who might fit its description of "bosses."
A North Atlantic air cargo rate war appeared almost certain yesterday as a result of an International Air Transport Association commission decision to permit "open" rates starting April 10.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 9 -- The White Sox infield was drawn in on the grass this morning, rehearsing plays to the plate. Tony Cuccinello, the coach, pointed his fungo bat in the direction of Nellie Fox.

Bally, Inc., importer of women's shoes and exporter of leather and allied products, has leased the store at 673 Madison Avenue on the northeast corner of Sixty-first Street. The store, which was leased through Murray Kay, vice president of Pease Elliman, Inc., is scheduled to open Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked Congress today for funds to get started immediately on a stepped-up war on organized crime and racketeering.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday exceeded 6,000,000 shares for the third time since 1933, but the day ended inconclusively. Many more stocks rose than fell and Standard Poor's index of 500 stocks showed a small gain.

Supporters of the Encampment for Citizenship will have a theatre party at the April 4 performance of "Mary, Mary" at the Helen Hayes Theatre. Proceeds will enable needy students to attend the six-week summer encampment for discussions on major national issues.

MOSCOW, March 9 -- Premier Khrushchev and Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr. conferred for four hours today at the Siberian city of Novosibirsk. They discussed international issues confronting the Soviet Union and the United States.

The directors of Simpsons-Sears, Ltd., voted yesterday to pay an initial dividend of 25 cents a share on all classes of stock on June 1. The company has 331,875 class A shares, 2,000,000 class B shares and 2,000,000 class C shares.

LONDON, March 9 -- The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, told the Prime Ministers of the Commonwealth today that a world disarmament agreement was possible within the foreseeable future provided both East and West offered moderate compromises.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Kennedy announced today a state visit to the United States in May by President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia, who has played a key role in attempting to start negotiations to end the Algerian war.
Norman Mailer pleaded guilty in General Sessions Court yesterday to stabbing his wife, Adele, Nov. 20 after a party in their apartment at 250 West Ninety-fourth Street.
The little turbaned Arab who has been connected with the sale of Sanka Coffee since 1928 is dead -- or, at least, his relationship with the company is ended.
BONN, West Germany, March 9 (Reuters) -- The first public offer of Volkswagen shares is already oversubscribed, the Ministry for Federal Assets announced today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 11 points yesterday, with October and new May establishing new highs for the season. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Rockefeller has added $90,000,000 to the nest egg the state is setting aside for the fiscal year that will begin April 1. With the $75,000,000 already required under law, this will give the state a $165,000,000 nest egg.

UNITED NATIONS, March 9 -- Soviet officials here from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko down are surprised and angered by President Kennedy's unsolicited appeal for Radio Free Europe at his news conference yesterday.

PROMINENTLY printed in large type across the front of the jacket of Richard Yates' brilliantly dismal first novel, "Revolutionary Road,"* is one of the most sublime specimens of unintentional humor and muddled thought in the recent history of book, promotion. "Revolutionary Road," it says, "locates the new American tragedy squarely on the field of marriage."

ALBANY, March 9 -- The State Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill enabling Mayor Wagner to appoint a Charter revision commisison and hold a referendum on a new Charter for New York City in the November general election.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today he had invited radio, television and newspaper representatives from all fifty states to attend two foreign policy briefings here next month.
TRENTON, March 9 -- The nomination of Richard J. Hughes as Democratic candidate for Governor and a three-way race for the Republican candidacy were assured today as the deadline for entries passed.
