The cities teacher organizations, frequently at odds on policy matters, united yesterday in support of legislation to improve retirement benefits. Their views were presented at a two-hour public hearing before State Senator MacNeil Mitchell, chairman of the Senate Committee on the Affairs of New York City.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 9 (AP) -- Kentucky combined a balanced attack with a tight defense tonight and defeated Vanderbilt, 88 -- 67, in a play-off game to qualify for its twelfth trip to the National Collegiate basketball tournament.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- Britain's tennis officials demanded permission today from the International Lawn Tennis Federation to make the 1962 Wimbledon championship an open tournament.
TRENTON, March 9 -- The state Commissioner of Banking and Insurance today approved an average increase of 15.7 per cent in New Jersey Blue Shield subscriber rates.

A group of dissident tenants of Washington Square Village, who early this week filed a $500,000 damage suit against the owners of the housing project, were in turn sued by the owners yesterday for defamation.

At a place called The Gaslight in Greenwich Village coffee is for quaffing with existentialist obscurantism, guitars are for poetry readings and the delicate finger-snap is the mark of thundering applause -- and yesterday the orthodox forces of the Fire Department were beginning to regret they had ever tangled with its bearded set.

Universal Match Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc., have resumed merger negotiations that were broken off in January. Universal Match also announced yesterday that it was negotiating with a "medium-size" electronics concern looking toward acquisition.

The Legislature has now authorized Mayor Wagner to appoint a City Charter Commission whose revision of the basic structure of New York's government can be submitted to referendum of the city's voters on Nov. 7, 1961. With almost complete unanimity the Democrats opposed the Charter bill, ostensibly on the grounds that home rule was being invaded, and that the request for Charter revision should have originated with the City Council rather than the Mayor.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Neighborhood rivals stirred up strong currents of excitement and natural animosity last night during a collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Garden.
ROME, March 9 -- W. Averell Harriman said today he was certain that "Italy will play her part" in assisting under-developed countries.
With the jocular observation that "Israel is an American colony," Robert Frost left last night to give a series of lectures on American culture and civilization at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
Five publishers and a magazine distributor filed damage claims against the city totaling $600,000 yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain poured in 67 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to a 135-126 victory over the New York Knickerbockers at the Arena.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The joint role of the United States and Latin America in the latter's development was emphasized today by Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
About 7,000 street holes in Manhattan were repaired during February, Manhattan Borough President Edward Dudley said yesterday.

A proxy fight for control of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company controlling $5,500,000,000 of assets, became a certainty last night after failure of a last minute peace-making attempt by an interested third party.

DETROIT, March 9 (UPI) -- Mr. Reuther, in a telegram to Senator Harry F. Byrd, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, accused Senator Curtis of trying to slander him by having the question of rigging raised at a committee hearing today.

As the United Nations General Assembly heads into a new debate on the Congo it would seem that its first task should be to establish and proclaim just who and what is the legal Government of this newly independent state. The lack of a generally recognized Government has further bedeviled an already difficult and confused situation.

Winter is almost over now and this fact alone makes spring seem more elusive than ever. These final bleak days are the dregs of a season that has been difficult at best and there are still traces of snow in the suburbs that remind the commuters of just how bad it has been.

Dr. James R. Killian, chairman of the corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, warned last night against an "interregnum" in private support for secondary schools now that President Kennely has requested increased aid for public schools.
City officials pressed the Legislature anew yesterday for a law permitting them to take over and repair slum tenement buildings whose owners abandon responsibility.

Lumber production throughout the country totaled 196,044,000 board feet, compared with 196,703,000 board feet in the prior week, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 236,643,000 board feet.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The State Senate approved today Governor Rockefeller's plan to give students at New York colleges up to $300 a year. After a debate that ran well over three hours, the Senate passed the bill by a vote of 47 to 7. Three Republicans joined four Democrats in the opposition.

The lights are turned down in the posh Persian Room at the serene and stately Plaza Hotel. The audience, personifying good manners and gracious living, waits quietly. Into the spotlight steps a tall man with something of a droll grin.
A management consultant's report implies that the state is treating the city unfairly in such important activities as public health, hospital, probation and water services and welfare work.

Sales of the Borden Company this year are expected to top $1,000,000,000 for the first time and earnings are expected to be ahead of the record results achieved last year, Harold W. Comfort, president, said yesterday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 9 -- The Government of Northern Ireland is facing a major setback in its long seesaw struggle against unemployment.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The United States is expected to lift a ten-year-old ban on imports of crabmeat from the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- George Meany said today that a plan to pay a union official $250,000 to resign while accused of corruption was "a clear case of legalistic highway robbery."

WHEN women about the country turn on their television sets Sunday to get their first glimpse of Macy's copies of imported European fashions, they will be blissfully unaware of the whirlwind activities the show involved.

TOKYO, March 7 -- About thirty-five miles south of Tokyo, a monument to Japan's first taste of military glory is being built, hard by a United States naval base and with funds and encouragement from the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service said today that tip sheets offering advice on "average'' income tax deductions were misleading taxpayers into thinking such deductions were automatically accepted by the service.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 9 -- Congolese leaders meeting here tacitly agreed today to scrap the formula for a central government for the Congo and to recognize the existence of its component states.

BRIDGETON, N.J., March 9 -- The plight of Southern New Jersey, which during February had an unemployment ratio of 11.9 per cent, or 5 per cent higher than the national average, was outlined today at two hearings of a Senate Labor subcommittee studying employment and manpower.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that any effort in the United Nations to unseat the delegation of Nationalist China and replace it with one from Peiping would create "a very serious problem."
NORRISTOWN, Pa., Friday, March 10 (AP) -- The last of seven high electrical industry executives jailed for violations of antitrust laws was released from prison early today.
Jack Paar last night challenged Ed Sullivan to a rating war from 8 to 9 P.M. on any Sunday night Mr. Sullivan chooses.

Sales and earnings of the National Cash Register Company rose to new highs last year, Robert S. Oelman, president, reported yesterday. The company is a producer of business machines and equipment and data processing equipment.

Day-to-day holdings of foreign banks in the New York City banks jumped $134,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday in the wake of Germany's upward revaluation of the mark. At 1,213,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported, demand deposits of foreign banks at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks were at their highest level since the week ended on Dec. 30, 1959.
Student editors from thirty states converged yesterday on Columbia University for the opening of the thirty-seventh annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

THE recent blustery weather made spring seem far behind, but a glance at daffodil-bedecked flower shops offered some reassurance. Food shops also provide welcome reminders that wintry days must soon come to an end.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A bill to raise the present minimum wage from $1 an hour to $1.25 in two steps over twenty-eight months was approved today by the House Committee on Education and Labor.
President Kennedy's propose measures for bolstering the economy are all to the good, but does anyone have any faith that they will actually do the trick?

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Senator Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, asked today whether Walter P. Reuther had induced the automobile industry to lay off men last month wih the idea of "beefing up" unemployment totals.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- President Kennedy said tonight he would attend a fundraising ball May 27 to be given by the Democratic National Committee in honor of his birthday. He told a Democratic arrangements committee that he did not mind that his birthday fell on May 29.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Key Democrats in Congress began an intensive search today for a compromise in the growing dispute over Federal loans for parochial and other private schools.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers took issue with President Kennedy yesterday on the question of boycotting foreign imports.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Foreign cruise liners operating in the rich United States cruise business should be brought under United States regulation, a merchant marine leader proposed here today.
The Musicians Emergency Fund will celebrate its thirtieth anniversary with a concert and supper at the Plaza on April 10.

LONDON, March 9 -- William Gibson's "The Miracle Worker" was cheered at the Royalty Theatre tonight. The end of the fight scene between Helen Keller and Annie Sullivan "brought the loudest ovation I have ever known at a first night," Ronald Hastings plans to say in The Daily Telegraph tomorrow.
Four years of labor peace in the city's fur industry were assured yesterday by a new union contract.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 9 -- A group of mothers here is petitioning the Board of Education to keep their children from being transferred to another school.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Kennedy is engaged in a delicate and extensive probing operation -- in the Soviet Union, in Communist China and in the countries that have been more or less neutral between the power blocs.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Kennedy Administration indicated to Congress today that there would be no substantial change in the United States position when the atomic test ban talks resume in Geneva March 21.

Events today: "Wozzeck," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Concert Artists Guild, Town Hall, 5:15; Concert of works by Keith Robinson, Carnegie Recital Hall, 6; Albert and Roland Valdes-Blain, guitarists, Town Hall, 8:30; Behre Piano Associates, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended March 4 were 26 per cent above the year-earlier level.

The 150 Realty Company, a nominee of the Tenney Corporation, has contracted to buy the twenty-three-story office building at 150 Nassau Street from the 568 Broadway Corporation. The property, which will be syndicated, was leased back to the seller.
GENEVA, March 9 -- The Soviet Union's campaign for more high-level staff posts for its citizens in the United Nations and its specialized agencies suffered a major setback here today.
The Soviet Union has filmed "Death of a Salesman," one of the classic plays of the modern American theatre, without the knowledge of the author, Arthur Miller.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to build public housing on the site of the Polo Grounds. It approved plans of the New York City Housing Authority to erect a 1,700-family, low-rent project there.
MOSCOW, March 9 -- The Soviet Union orbited and recovered today an earth satellite that carried a dog.
NEW DELHI, India, March 9 -- The Dalai Lama appealed to the United Nations General Assembly today "to help restore the independence of Tibet."
BOSTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The New Haven Railroad's president, George Alpert, said today that going into bankruptcy was no way to run a railroad.
A nation-wide study of academic background and personal abilities of all of the Ph.D's produced in one year shows that physics and mathematics have captured most of the talent.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A slight increase in rail and truck loadings last week was reported today by both industries.

The New Brunswick Electric Power Commission in Canada has completed a private placement with institutional investors of $15,000,000 of 5 1/4 per cent twenty-five-year sinking fund debentures. Principal and interest of the debentures are unconditionally guaranteed by the Province of New Brunswick.

THE exhibition, "Spanish Latin-American Artists," at the David Herbert Gallery, 14 East Sixty-ninth Street, brings together paintings and sculpture by contemporaries that reveal what strides have been taken in recent years by the advance guard in Spain and in the former Spanish empire.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Republican Congressional leadership contended today that the Administration had lost its "sense of urgency and hurry." It added that there was a resurgence of Republican strength around the country.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- What do unemployment statistics mean and how does the Labor Department get them?
WILMINGTON, Del., March 9 (UPI) -- Overseas business of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in 1960 rose 21 per cent to $363,000,000 from $300,000,000 in 1959, according to the annual report mailed today.
An old and familiar Brooklyn landmark is soon to disappear. The Board of Estimate voted $230,000 yesterday to demolish the ninety-six-year-old Brooklyn Supreme Court Building.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 8 -- The Czechoslovak national hockey team, playing with a ferociousness that was thrilling to watch, turned aside repeated Canadian thrusts in the final minutes tonight and held on for a 1-1 tie.

The Soviet may be preparing to start a trade war by dumping sugar on the world market, according to Sir Edmund Bacon, chairman of the British Sugar Corporation, Ltd. London. Speaking yesterday at a meeting of the Sugar Club here, Sir Edmund said that the Soviet Union now controlled about one-third of the world's supply of sugar and was increasing her output each year.
-[ Cen. AJfred lf. :Gruenther,! lJ. S. A., retired, predicted.yes-i terday that the Soviet Union' mignt take over medical .aid programs In the Congo and Morocco because Russia has "doctors galore."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 9 -- Bob Kaufmann, a 19-year-old junior, broke his meet record in the 200-yard individual medley tonight in the twenty-first annual individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Heavy general selling popped open a generally dull grain futures market in the final minutes of trading today and turned prices sharply lower on most contracts.
A Protestant leader praised President Kennedy last night for continuing to oppose Federal assistance to non-public schools.
WILLIAM SYDEMAN and Peter Pindar Stearns, composers who teach at the Mannes College of Music, had some of their works played in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
VIENNA, March 9 -- The expectation that the United States Government will soon transfer complete control of $423,000,000 in schillings to Austria has provoked a fight.
Jackie Robinson, a ballplayer known for his fight, charged yesterday that Richard M. Nixon had given up on the Negro vote in the 1960 Presidential election.
COLUMBUS, Ga., March 9 -- Federal District Judge William A. Bottle told the University of Georgia today it could not exclude Negro students from campus facilities on racial grounds.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Kennedy presented a massive housing program today. It seeks to revitalize cities, provide more middle-income and low-income housing and combat the recession.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said last night that television was an infant factor in politics and would never supplant the printed word.
Nine warrants for the arrest of John E. Hand were issued in Housing Court yesterday after several persons had tried unsuccessfully to plead in his stead.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today a revised system of import allocations for residual oil. He said the system was aimed at making the residual oil field more competitive, and would let new importers into the fuel market.
A call to the American people to reorganize military power or face either destruction or communism by 1962 is made by Alexander de Seversky in his new book, "America: Too Young to Die."
The New York Committee for Democratic Voters kept Mayor Wagner guessing yesterday weather it would support him if he sought renomination.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Marquess of Salisbury, a Right-Wing critic of the Government, resigned today from the presidency of the Hertfordshire Conservative Association over the question of Northern Rhodesia.
Lillian Hellman has been named winner of this years Creative Arts Medal, awarded annually by Brandeis University.
The boards of directors of the McCrory Corporation and the H.L. Green Company announced jointly yesterday that they had approved an agreement in principle for the merger of Green into McCrory.
Preliminary plans were made public yesterday for "a city within a city" -- a $225,000,000 middle-income housing project over the New York Central tracks west of the Lincoln Center development.
Organization and insurgent Democrats opposed each other at a City Council committee hearing yesterday over the issue of Charter revision.

The furious pace of trading on the stock exchanges that has marked recent weeks has pushed up the price of memberships. Yesterday, a seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold for $180,000, an increase of $5,000 from the price paid last Monday, and the highest since Feb. 21, 1934.

The sensationally heralded "Latin-American Conference for National Sovereignty, Economic Emancipation and Peace" has come and gone in Mexico City without making a sensation. It can be considered a failure.

THE hero of this deal, which occurred in a tournament at Poughkeepsie, must remain unsung. West and East were respectively George Schoenbrun and Myron Fleishman of Poughkeepsie, who reported the hand, but while they admired the declarer's play they did not know his name.
Earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation fell to a ten-year low in 1960, the company reported yesterday.
Earnings of the J.J. Newberry Company in the year ended last Dec. 31 were below the 1959 level despite an increase in sales, the retail variety chain reported yesterday.

LONDON, March 10 (UPI) -- A joint expedition by the academies of science of the Soviet Union and Communist China has discovered new species of prehistoric beasts in the Gobi Desert, known to scientists as the graveyard of the dinosaurs.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Former President Herbert Hoover has declined an offer from President Kennedy to serve as chairman of a citizens advisory committee for the Peace Corps.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee approved with little enthusiasm today a State Department recommendation to cut United States sugar purchases from the Dominican Republic.
A dispute over 4,000 bags of allegedly contraband Brazilian coffee, which led to legal action Monday against the freighter Loide Uruguai, was settled yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 11 (UPI) -- Skindivers brought up the bodies of three Navy airmen today. The men died when their patrol bomber crashed in Lake George on a training mission Thursday night.
LISBON, Portugal, March 10 (Reuters) -- The Portuguese Overseas Ministry tonight reported more disorders in its West African territory of Angola.

HARTFORD, March 10 (AP) -- Gov. John N. Dempsey said today Connecticut had taken a "giant step" toward helping the New Haven Railroad with its financial problems and expressed the hope that the other states served by the line "will unite to keep the railroad going."
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Charles Morgan of St. Petersburg won the midwinter international Snipe regatta title today.
MOSCOW, March 10 (UPI) -- Soviet scientists disagreed today over whether the return of a dog-carrying satellite yesterday had cleared the way for man's great venture of orbiting the earth.
Visitors to New York City may one day be able to tell which borough they are in by the color and position of street signs.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 10 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia Warriors tonight became the first National Basketball Association player to score more than 3,000 points in one season. But his 32-point performance failed to keep the Detroit Pistons from winning, 120 -- 103. Chamberlain brought his year's total to 3,016.
Another light week is in prospect in the market for new capital. Debt obligations of major size total only $53,585,000 and this total is made up of four tax-exempt issues.

Only one thoroughbred, Mrs. Susie A. Ketchell's Dare Do Well, checked into Aqueduct yesterday. The arrival of the 3-year-old colt increased the number of horses in stalls at the Big A, awaiting the March 20 opening of the local racing season there, to forty-three.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 10 -- The Israeli Government's agreement with Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation of New York to record the Eichmann trial and make the material available to networks on a nonprofit basis has been approved by the court.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The president of the New Haven Railroad urged Congress today to extend the authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to guarantee loans to railroads for at least two years. The carrier has already received several such loans.
WARSAW, March 10 (AP) -- The United States tonight defeated a Soviet saber team, 9 -- 7, in the opening round of the annual Warsaw international saber fencing tournament.

Once again conservative thinking is threatening the fullest realization of a creative idea. We have failed to consider the benefits of making those who work in the Peace Corps draft exempt because we are afraid of attracting "draft dodgers. "

SYDNEY, Australia, March 10 -- The United States has scored a propaganda victory here through Communist China's rejection of President Kennedy's proposal that both countries admit each other's journalists.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 10 (AP) -- The Inter-American Press Association's scholarship fund awarded six scholarships worth $2,500 each today to journalists and journalism students in the United States and Latin America.

WITH the many sprigs of green popping up, spring is not far off. And now is the time to seek new accessories to help create a fresh table setting for the coming season. Some of the prettiest are the rose-patterned, French porcelain oven-to-table pieces at Henrietta Tischler, 837 Madison Avenue.

The Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex,. who have announced their plans to conduct a proxy contest against management of the Alleghany Corporation, up until late last night still had not mailed out formal proxies to the big holding company's shareholders.

When passengers on the outbound American Export Lines Constitution sit down to eat today they will be able to order fresh asparagus and strawberries picked in California yesterday or Dungeness crabs plucked from Pacific waters yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., March 10 (AP) -- A nation-wide investigation into price-fixing on electric equipment sold by companies prosecuted in Federal antitrust cases has been started by electric utility concerns.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 10 -- Richard M. Nixon said tonight that he did not intend to run for Governor of California next year.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate passed an emergency feed-grains bill today by a partisan vote of 52 to 26. The measure is based on proposals by the Administration, but differs sharply in detail.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican of Pennsylvania, charged today that Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, was trying to evict him from his minority committee room suite into "one stinky, little room."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Kennedy has urged Premier Khrushchev to help demonstrate that the big powers can reach peaceful and mutually acceptable agreements on disputes such as those in Laos and the Congo.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 10 -- The appointment of a resident of this town as Ambassador to Guinea has inspired a town-wide $2,500 fund drive to provide a scholarship to the United States for a student from the new African nation.

May I comment on your editorial of March 1 concerning the Supreme Court's decision upholding the right of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to demand answers from persons appearing before it.
DETROIT, March 10 (UPI) -- John Farah, a 22-year-old St. Paul bowler, was the new American Bowling Congress all-events leader in the regular division with a 1,853 total today.

Most of the film revival programs flourishing on the local scene promotionally stress, when the occasion warrants, a particular director as a well-known veteran or "giant" of the medium. The downtown Bleecker Street Cinema, which next month next month will celebrate its first anniversary, is about to try a variation on this approach.

DETROIT, March 10 --L.L. Colbert, chairman and president of Chrysler, received an increase in basic salary of $150 last year despite the fact that the auto concern cleared its first profit in three years in 1960, a proxy statement showed today.
Ground will be broken in late April for a five-level Catholic center at New York University.
Retail sales are beginning to inch upward, apparently because of the early Easter holiday this year, which occurs on April 2 as compared with April 17 last year.

HAVANA, Saturday, March 11 -- A Cuban military tribunal convicted Maj. William A. Morgan last night of having helped rebels trying to overthrow the Castro regime. It sentenced him to death by firing squad.
The six-month-old attempt by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., to acquire control of American Export Lines ran into another snag yesterday.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 10 -- Congolese leaders meeting here agreed today to make Leopoldville the "neutral" capital of a future confederation of Congo states. This would give Leopoldville a status similar to that of Washington, D.C.
A slight, soft-spoken West Virginia school teacher arrived here yesterday on a mission he hopes will bring a little gaiety to the impoverished coal-mining town where he works.
What was that old song about two guitars?

LOS ANGELES, March 10 (UPI) -- The defense won permission today to buy a tape recording of Jackie Leonard's conversation with Frank (Blinky) Palermo, in which the boxing promoter allegedly demanded $25,000.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- "If we can come up to opening day of the championship season in the same correspondingly sound condition we're enjoying right now on the eve of our exhibition schedule, I certainly will be more than pleased"
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy left today for a week-end at Middleburg, Va., where she will entertain her sister and brother-in-law, Prince and Princess Stanislaus Radziwill.

The Bates Manufacturing Company, Fruit of the Loom, Inc., and Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. have been barred by the courts from further violations of securities regula tions in their attempts to give Bates control of Fruit of the Loom.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., March 10 -- What was described as the country's first school bus to be equipped with safety seat belts began operating here today.

Commissioner Vincent A. G. Connor told a legislative hearing yesterday that future commercial waterfront operations of the Department of Marine and Aviation would be "marked by the end of deficit financing" and the attainment of "annual surpluses."

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, the Nuclear Development Corporation of America, of White Plains, N.Y., and the Mallinckrodt Chemical Works announced jointly yesterday the formation of United Nuclear Corporation, a $25,000,000 company.
A thirty-day jail sentence and a $700 fine were imposed yesterday on the agent of a tenement found to be so hazardous that the Fire Deprtment suddenly ordered seven families to leave it.

ROME, March 10 -- Nobody yet knows whether Averell Harriman is to be a kind of Colonel House or Harry Hopkins for the Kennedy Administration. And "nobody" includes both Ambassador Harriman and, one may presume, the President himself.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration chopped off today a remaining segment of United States exports to Cuba.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A Puerto Rican labor leader told the Senate group that the Roman Catholic Church had tried and failed to coerce his commonwealth into giving aid to church schools.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10 -- A one-party government "in the initial stages" will be "necessary" for stability in Kenya when the African majority takes power, Tom Mboya said today.

THE Welsh seem to regard England as a large and somewhat dangerous world beyond Wales. They venture across the border with a trace of truculence in their panache, not at all certain that the English natives are going to be friendly.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa, President of the Teamsters Union, issued a call today for a union convention July 3 that is expected to confirm his control of the nation's biggest labor union for another five years.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 2 to 8 points (10 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday. Profit-taking cut some of the better gains.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Kennedy Administration gave assurance today that it would be at least as firm as the Eisenhower Administration in maintaining Western rights in Berlin.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- A revised Government report added a bearish kick to old-crop soybean futures prices today and they continued their downward trend while the new crop months rose.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 10 -- An athlete who fled his native Hungary became an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League champion tonight.
PARIS, March 10 -- There was no school in nine departments of France today, but only the students were happy about it.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10 (AP) -- Wilma Rudolph, Tennessee State's Olympic triple gold-medal winner, today ran the fastest indoor 220 yards ever recorded by a woman. She was timed in 25 seconds in a trial heat in the Amateur Athletic Union's women's national indoor track and field championships.
John D. Rockefeller 3d and George Meany urged support yesterday for the Lincoln Center project.

Why Russia invaded Finland in 1939 and why Russia did not crush and occupy Finland is told in "The Diplomacy of the Winter War," by Max Jakobson, which Harvard University Press will issue March 27. The author, a Finnish foreign service officer, is a former newspaper man who served as press attache of the Finnish Embassy in Washington from 1953 to 1958.

Both President Kennedy and Secretary of State Rusk have spoken out vigorously and properly this week against the boycotts of Japanese goods planned by some unions. As the President pointed out, such unilateral action by private groups seeking to serve their own interests conflicts with the national interest, and in any case points the road to chaos.
Ed Sullivan and Jack Paar are trading verbal blows, but it appears that the only ones who will be hurt are the performers in the middle.
Machinery droned and cold air suddenly swirled into the cavernous halls of the Coliseum last night as the day's final visitors left the International Flower Show.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 10 (AP) -- Battering through thick ice, the United States icebreakers Glacier and Staten Island have started toward the open sea after being held fast for twenty-nine days off the coast of the Thurston Peninsula in the Antarctic, according to the New Zealand Press Association.

EIGHT of the thirty-five painters and sculptors exhibiting work at the National Institute of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 155th Street, will be chosen as recipients of awards. Judging from the general excellence of submissions, representing many different styles and aspects of contemporary art, final judgments will not be easily arrived at.

A little more than 100 years ago, Carl Franz Bally, who was in the ribbon business, went from Switzerland to Paris to buy some shoes for his wife. So entranced did he become with the designs that he resolved to experiment with shoes himself.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- The Board of Rabbis of Northern California, serving forty-six Jewish congregations, has called upon President Kennedy to "exert the full powers" of his office toward abolition of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

A New York County grand jury yesterday indicted nine women for welfare fraunds. They were accused of accepting a total of more than $15,800 from the Welfare Department in relief payments while receiving incomes they had not reported.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Walter P. McConaughy, Ambassador to Korea, as reported today to be President Kennedy's choice for Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs.
The Transit Authority yesterday encouraged amateur artists to draw in subway stations -- some subway stations, that is.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 10 -- The Right-Wing Government of Laos announced today its willingness to accept a policy of "strict neutrality" to end the nation's civil war.

BONN, Germany, March 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer expressed today the concern growing in West Germany that Adolf Eichmann's trial in Israel next month will produce a new wave of anti-German feeling throughout the world.
Something of a boom in the Bard is under way. Shakespeare, presented free by professional troupes or aspiring actors in high schools in the metropolitan area, has become quite ubiquitous this season.
PATERSON, N.J., March 10 (AP) -- A diabetic in insulin shock, who was thought to be drunk was held in jail more than twenty-four hours before his true condition became known, the police said today.
The northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Forty-sixth Street has been bought as the site for a twenty-story office building.

TAKE one young and pretty housewife. Add an incipient attack of boredom. Mix well and you have the start of a novel or a case for psychiatrist. Multiply by three and you have a new fashion manufacturing concern.

President Kennedy's Peace Corps, as described this week by its director, R. Sargent Shriver, is still in its early formative stage, with its future still to make. Mr. Shriver's enthusiasm for the idea is understandable and laudatory. American foreign policy has always had its content of idealism, and the concept of a Peace Corps to aid, with unselfish skills, the world's under-developed areas is in harmony with the American dream.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Dr. Peter Schlumbohm of New York obtained a patent this week for what he regards as a major advance in room coolers. His method reduces the air temperature by evaporating water and for the first time, he says, does it without increasing the humidity.
An average life span of 100 to 120 years, a world without war and the solution of the food and population problems were predicted for the year 2000 yesterday.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, March 10 (Reuters) -- Rain halted play today after an English cricket team had scored 15 runs for the loss of one wicket in the third and final unofficial test match against New Zealand.
LONDON, March 10 -- Queen Elizabeth declared today that her six-week tour of Asia had "marked a new stage in the history of the Commonwealth."
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer forged into the second-round lead of the $20,000 Pensacola open golf tournament today with a seven-under-par 65.

A troupe of hopefuls has been rehearsing scenes from "Peter Pan" in basements in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The most hopeful of all the members of the group, the Fine Arts Theatre Workshop, is its director, Miss Margo Eden.
FOR avid do-it-yourselfers -- whose number is now legion -- here is a shopping and service guide.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Democratic National Committee and five of his predecessors lunched together today. They elected their senior colleague, James A. Farley, to head a former chairmen's association.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A recommendation for a national conference to discuss crime and violence on television and in movies was put before a Senate subcommittee today.

New York City's highly successful indoor track season will come to a rousing close tonight in Madison Square Garden with the fortieth annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America championships.

The deadlock over the city's proposed tie-in sale of public and private properties in the Brooklyn Civic Center area was broken yesterday at a conference in the office of Real Estate Commissioner Ferdinand Roth.

The Mesabi Iron Company reported yesterday that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue had ruled that two trusts to which Mesabi planned to transfer all its assets would not constitute associations taxable as corporations.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- The exhibition baseball season began today and the Detroit Tigers took the opportunity to score fourteen runs against the Chicago White Sox.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, looking beyond its Saturn vehicle, ordered studies today of rockets with thrusts of 6,000,000 to 12,000,000 pounds.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller submitted a bill to the Legislature today providing $36,500,000 in raises for state employes.
Mayor Wagner continued his talks with spokesmen for city employe organizations yesterday prior to entering his budget retreat Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits introduced today three bills to encourage foreign travel in the United States.
A lending corporation allegedly set up to help Vincent J. Squillante get control of the private carting industry was ordered dissolved in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday.
BOWIE, Md., March 10 (AP) -- Taking the lead immediately after the gates opened, John J. Mack's Cyprian Cat won the featured Centerville Purse today and paid $8.60 for $2.
KANSAS CITY, March 10 (AP) -- The largest research project ever undertaken to study tornadoes, line squalls and severe local storms was announced today by the Weather Bureau. It will begin Wednesday.
Late last year in Saint-John Stockholm when the Nobel Prizes were awarded, four scientists were among the five recipients, two from the United States, one from Britain and one from Australia.
ATLANTA, March 10 -- Negro students and their supporters declared tonight that they would continue to boycott merchants here until lunch counters were desegregated.
A Jersey City woman was stabbed in the head and robbed of $18 yesterday afternoon in the Hudson and Manhattan railroad station at Twenty-third Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

A public offering of 85,000 common shares of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., was made yesterday at $18.75 a share by Emanuel, Deetjen Co. and associates. A simultaneous offering of 35,000 common shares at the same price was made by the company to four officers of the retail chain.
RALPH PAIEWONSKY (pronounced Pie-wonsky), whose nomination as Governor of the Virgin Islands came before the Senate Interior Committee yesterday, is an heir to a vast island family empire.

MANY women today believe that in hiring an interior decorator they surrender all their rights to make decisions on the decor of their homes. Some justification for this feeling exists. There are interior designers whose style is so strong that it makes an indelible mark on the rooms they execute.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 10 -- The Security Council agreed today to debate the situation in Portuguese Angola. The decision, urged by Asian and African nations, was reached without a record vote and with no formal objection to the agenda item, proposed last month by Liberia.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 10 -- Early acceptance of a "mutually satisfactory" agreement for the return of United Nations forces to the port of Matadi was predicted today by the Congolese Government and the United Nations command.
TOKYO, March 9 -- Japan's business and political leaders are taking a new look at the country's relations with Communist China and South Korea.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- The Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank asked the Federal District Court today to dismiss the suit brought by the Government in an effort to block its merger with the Philadelphia National Bank.

Works by Keith Robinson that have been performed in New York in recent years were combined with a few brand-new ones in the first program to be devoted exclusively to this composer's music. It was given in Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- Istvan Rozsavolgyi of Hungary won the Bankers Mile in 4 minutes 4.7 seconds tonight, but an 18-year-old high school senior stole the show in The Chicago Daily News Relays.
Another day of wild swings on the stock market ended with another virtual stalemate. Stocks opened higher, rose until noon, dipped, rose and, fell again.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 10 -- Archbishop Makarios outlined today a five-year program of development for Cyprus that will rely heartily on technical and economic assistance from countries in the Western camp.

RABAT, Morocco, March 9 -- A question asked these days in Morocco is, "When will the new King get married?" Bachelors are regarded in Islamic society as frivolous folk and, in contrast with the Christian ideal of celibate holiness, an unmarried Imam of the Faithful and Prince of Believers is anathema.

SYRACUSE, March 10 (AP) -- Two ex-champions, Carmen Basilio and Don Jordan, will fight in a ten-round bout tomorrow night that could affect title shots for both. The match will be nationally televised (Channel 7 in New York).

MIAMI, March 10 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright of Dallas and Jo Ann Prentice of Birmingham, mastered the Miami Springs golf course with 71's today and shared the first-round lead in the $7,500 Miami women's open.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will send a personal representative to Brussels next week to press his demand that Belgium withdraw all her military and civilian nationals from the Congo.

DURHAM, N.C., March 10 (AP) -- Twenty-five faculty members from Duke University and North Carolina College joined students from the two colleges tonight in picketing theatres that practice segregation.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Joseph A. Peel Jr. did not plot the Chillingworth murders, his attorney told the court today.

VALPARAISO, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- A Bomarc missile intercepted a pilotless QB-4T jet bomber at an altitude of more than seven miles over the Gulf of Mexico today. It was the second successful launching of the tactical weapon, known as the IM-99-B, Bomarc, by an Air Force team.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 10 (UPI) -- Mario Sosnicki, 25 years old, of Floral Park, L.I., was sentenced today to two to three years in the New Jersey State Prison for conspiring to extort money from a doctor.
PORTLAND, Me., March 10 (AP) -- Patricia Morelli of Cathedral High School here has qualified for the science fair at Southwestern Maine Regional High School.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP) -- An unemployed Negro maintenance man, out hunting a job, found $240,000 in tens and twenties in the street today -- and called the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
A student at the Rabbinical Seminary of America in Queens was arrested yesterday and charged with having set five fires there in the last three weeks.
As reported in The Times of March 1, two leading West German Social Democrats, after their return from this country to Bonn, observed that anti-German sentiments were increasing in the United States.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union was accused yesterday of unfair labor practices by a union of its staff employes. The charges were filed with the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board here.

Stockholders were given new rights yesterday in a record quantity. Rights, that is, to subscribe for additional shares in the world's biggest corporation -- the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Spokesmen for two Protestant organizations and a Jewish group urged Congress today to reject demands for Federal loans to parochial and other private schools.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 10 -- Braden Thad Turner of Lehigh and thirty-five other gentlemen with leverage, wisdom and all their muscles in the right places advanced to the semi-finals tonight in the fifty-seventh annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament at Lehigh.

Just as the Patterson family was about to hang up another championship belt in its trophy room in Mount Vernon, N.Y., last night, young Raymond Patterson was beaten up at Madison Square Garden by a stiff-punching chap with little or no respect for family tradition.

The bond market held firm in a quiet trading session yesterday, with local government obligations the only section showing a lag in demand. By and large, all parts of the market were in an equilibrium induced by a preference of both dealers and investing institutions to sit by to appraise developments of the next fortnight.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 10 -- A victory by Wallace (Bud) Werner of Colorado; some top-drawer strategy by Coach Willie Schaeffler of Denver and an overly sensitive binding marked the National Collegiate ski championships today.

Phil Latreille of Middlebury College, the national intercollegiate hockey scoring leader for three consecutive seasons, will get a tryout with the New York Rangers. He will don a Blues' uniform against Detroit tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
Zionist leaders declared yesterday that recent criticism of the movement had only served to strengthen Zionism as a major force in winning moral and financial support for Israel.

WHEN the restlessness of spring invades the kitchen, the home cook begins searching for a different dessert for her sweets-loving family. It must be hearty enough to meet the needs of the youngsters who are bubbling over with energy in their new-found freedom out of doors.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- Long gone are the days when heavyweight fighters preparing for a world championship bout put all their efforts toward becoming tough and mean.
ALBANY, March 10 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller sent to the Senate today his renomination of Francis T. Mylott as a member of the Public Service Commission for a ten-year term, at $22,486 a year.

ALBAN BERG'S "Wozzeck," absent a season from the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera, returned there last night. The evening also marked the return of Karl Boehm. Mr. Boehm, who conducted the performance, had to leave the United States last December for emergency eye surgery in Vienna.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Representative H.R. Gross charged today that President Kennedy's new Peace Corps was being turned into a haven for draft dodgers.
Mayor Wagner authorized yesterday the cancellation of a city contract with the Broadway Maintenance Corporation for the maintenance of 52,000 on-the-street parking meters.
ROME, March 10 -- W. Averell Harriman will fly from here to Teheran, Iran, Sunday for talks with Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi.

The grim outward aspect of Hanoi observed by a correspondent of The Times during a brief visit there last week reinforces evidence from other sources of the dreariness and austerity of conditions in Communist North Vietnam.

A phalanx of students from the city's high schools looked over department stores and resident buying offices yesterday with a business-like purpose. They wanted to know if retailing was their cup of tea.
NEW HAVEN, March 10 -- Yale University will assist educational institutions in Latin America in dealing with the problems of housing and urban and regional development.
GENEVA, Switzerland, March 10 (AP) -- Lavrenti Chernyshev, the coach of the Soviet Union's team, today picked Czechoslovakia as the winner of the world ice hockey championship.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System's News Department, which in recent days has had rather more than its share of intramural distractions, boasts two reasons, among others, for scorning the journalistic blues.

LONDON, March 10 -- Industrial shares maintained their recent steady tone in the stock market here today. But British Government securities weakened. Small and scattered selling of gilt-edge issues persisted and falls of 1s 3d (17 1/2 cents) were general with, in some cases, losses of 2s 6d (35 cents).
Trading on the New York commodities exchanges yesterday was featureless. Prices fell for about half of the commodities listed and rose or were mixed for the other half.

The City Club of New York criticized administration of the Sanitation Department yesterday as wasteful and antiquated.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- The Teamster picketing of West Coast ports was started to protest what the union said was a loss of jobs for its drivers and dock swampers because of restrictions on multiple cargo-handling in pact between waterfront employers, represented by the Pacific Maritime Association, and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. ordered a check yesterday to find out why a department officer had not signed a formal complaint in a court action against a Greenwich Village cafe.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $45,728,000 of temporary loan notes on March 21 to finance fourteen low-rent projects subsidized by the Public Housing Administration as well as the rehabilitation of eight existing buildings.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 10 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received a warm homecoming today from members of the Human Rights Commission.
HONG KONG, March 10 -- The Chinese Communist leadership has staged a massive retreat along the entire economic front of the "great leap forward."

CHICAGO, March 10 (UP) -- A cosmetics expert today warned against using detergents to shampoo hair.

KUWAIT, March 3 -- A walk along Fahad al-Salam Street shows how oil is making Kuwait that rarity among nations, an over-developed country.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices decreased 0.1 per cent to 119.7 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended Tuesday, March 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Lilly, a 19-month-old hippopotamus, left Central Park Zoo yesterday for life with the circus. The leave-taking was merry enough, with plenty of photographers to take her every pose, and a crowd of hippopotamus watchers to attend the transfer.
Three pacers from Australia and New Zealand are expected to set harness-racing records this month without setting a hoof on a track.

Philip L. Graham, president of the Washington Post Company, which purchased a controlling interest in Newsweek on Thursday, said yesterday he would become chairman of the board and chief executive of the news magazine.

NOW that spring is almost here, gardeners are eagerly awaiting the season of daffodils and tulips. Mid-March finds the garden calendar crammed with activities designed to aid property owners in planning the home grounds -- short courses, lectures, symposiums and educational displays.

Checks cashed last month in the district were $8,400,000,000, a decline of three-tenths of 1 per cent from a year ago. This was the first monthly loss shown in recent years in a diversified business area. Department store sales soared 46 per cent in week ended March 4 from a year ago, when a severe blizzard closed many stores two or three days. For the first two months the district gain is 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A business rival accused Ralph Paiewonsky, Virgin Islands rum producer who is Governor-designate of the islands, under oath today of cheating both the United States Government and the individual rum drinker by illegal handling and labeling of his rum.

A New York architect last week came to the defense of brick as a material for building facades. He said that despite the current popularity of glass and metal as sheathing for high-rise structures, brick will continue to be used on many buildings.

Box holders and patrons have been announced for the annual opera benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, to be held March 23 at the Metropolitan Opera House. The committee for the event, at which Verdi's "Don Carlo" will be sung, includes Mrs. Rodman A. De Heeren and Mrs. Joseph A. Meehan.

David Norman of Montreal, the United States open champion, and Peter B. Read of the home club gained the final of the annual national amateur racquets competition yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

OCALA, Fla., March 11 -- Competing in a live-quail shoot, such as the one that started on the Ocala Hunting Preserve today, has its hazards, most of them psychological. There are other hazards, too, as will be seen presently.

DENVER, Colo. -- As the first national bridge tourney of 1961 gets under way here, the winning of the championship contests takes on added significance because of a prospective event that tournament players long considered impossible.

WASHINGTON, March 11--President Kennedy's 7-year-old nephew, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., made an official White House call today to present to his uncle a seven-inch salamander. The son of the Attorney General, the President's brother, wrote the President a note about two weeks ago saying: "I would like to see you soon."
