These questions are being debated with special intensity at the nation's business schools -- the institutions whose responsibility it is to train tomorrow's business leaders.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 11 -- Congolese leaders were reported tonight to have reached virtual agreement to reconstitute their country as either the Confederation or the Community of Central African Republics.

MOST of the principals at the famous Scopes evolution trial of 1925 are now dead: William Jennings Bryan, the silver-tongued Presidential aspirant and religious fundamentalist chief prosecutor of the young teacher who had broken a state law prohibiting the teaching of evolution in public schools; the renowned lawyer, Clarence Darrow, who served as main counsel for the defense; and even H.L. Mencken, whose reports on the trial were always lively and never unbiased.

THE listener with pedestrian tastes would do well to walk away from most racing-car recordings. Unless you can thrill to these torque toccatas, rear-end ratio rondos or cylinder symphonies, leave them to the connoisseurs.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- Burnley, using ten substitutes and only one regular, played one of the most exciting games of the English Soccer league season today while being tied by Chelsea, 4 -- 4.
TANANARIVE, March 11 (AP) -- Congolese political leaders blocked out eight states today for their proposed confederation. The states would be organized roughly along tribal lines.

Cambridge and Oxford University Presses will publish a new translation of the New Testament this week. It will permit people of the twentieth century to read the accounts of Jesus in everyday English in the same way that the people of the second century read them in everyday Greek.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 11 -- Officials said today that they still maintained close contact with Tibetans who revolted against Peiping's control two years ago. They have been told, they said, that Tibetan guerrillas along the Chinese-Indian border were planning a "spring offensive" in the form of hit-and-run harassments of the Communist garrisons' communications and supply lines.
Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said here yesterday that he had "full confidence" in President Kennedy's attitude toward the problems of Berlin.
May I comment on the suggestion of establishing a "Bach Church" in New York? Musically, it would be a fine idea to hear the Cantatas of Bach performed on the days on which they were meant to be sung.

In "Seven Who Set Our .Destiny' (Feb. 19), written by my friend and former colleague, Prof. Richard B. Morris of Columbia University, no mention is made of Thomas Paine. No doubt Professor Morris was thinkg only of the political and constitutional debates and contributions of 'The Seven Who Set Our Destiny."
LONDON, March 11 -- Torn by a principle, the British Commonwealth is now well into one of the gravest crises of its history.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 11 (UPI) -- A bail bondsman friend of Joseph A. Peel Jr. testified at the Peel murder trial today that the defendant, a former West Palm Beach City judge, had nervously blurted out an admission he "did the job" on Circuit Judge C.E. Chillingworth.
A reopening of the controversial Pacific air routes case is under consideration by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11 -- Some Kenyans see beyond the present political morass the goal of an East African Federation at the center of an economic bloc stretching from the Sudan to Southern Rhodesia.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 11 -- The Little Rock school board, told by a Federal court to allow "more than token integration" in the city's public schools, is divided over how to go about it.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- The final big benefit of the social season here will be the fourth annual Polo Ball for the benefit of the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund. The event will be held on March 26, in the Celebrity Room of the Royal Poinciana Playhouse.
Thirteen community leaders were named yesterday to posts on the Committee for the 1961 Scouting Exposition, which will be held at the New York Coliseum on the week-end of Nov. 17 through 19.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The 3-year-old girl who says "hi, daddy" to the President of the United States is getting a lot of fun out of life in the White House.

YOUNG American men and women have shown an enthusiastic response to President Kennedy's creation of a Peace Corps of unpaid volunteers to serve overseas in areas of great need. In the first year's pilot program, 500 to 1,000 young Americans will be trained in their special skills and languages, then sent abroad to work and live side-by-side with the people who need their help.

ONCE, James and John were pals, sharers of everything -- parties, pretzels, toads, even chicken pox -- but not anymore. James, in John's estimation, has now become king of the sand-throwers and crayon grabbers -- in short, too bossy!

Joseph Silverstein, 28-year-old violinist of the Boston Symphony, won the Naumburg Award last October. The award is valued at $25,000 because it includes New York appearances, recording and management contracts, American and foreign tours, in addition to cash.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Kennedy's weekly routine would baffle Khrushchev and astonish de Gaulle. He works hard all week curing the incurable and fixing the unfixable, and then on Saturday night goes to big, splashy full-dress dinners where people laugh at his troubles.
ST. LOUIS, March 11 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks celebrated Cliff Hagan Night with a season-ending 130-7 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors tonight. The Hawks held Wilt Chamberlain to 17 points.

HOW do records get from the manufacturer to the customer? The commercial aspects of a business whose product has artistic and cultural values tend to be whispered about rather than openly discussed. When the competition reaches cut-throat proportions (and it has in the record industry), it is easier to get one of Mr. Khrushchev's shrimps to whistle than to extract a straight story from someone whose business is marketing art and entertainment.

A THOROUGHLY trained scholar, Arthur P. Whitaker knows his Spain. Any book by him must and will be read by Hispanists and students of the Franco regime. The qualities that one finds in his work are solid research and carefully pondered opinions, hedged about with pros and cons and all the possibilities of a given situation.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 11--In his first political appearance since leaving office, Richard M. Nixon outlined today a program for a Republican party comeback on national and state levels.

MIAMI BEACH, March 11 -- Floyd Patterson slipped off quietly and alone -- or so he thought -- for a few extra licks of training today for the defense of his world heavyweight championship on Monday night against Ingemar Johansson.

" Does there have to be so much talk about the recession?" This is a question that merchants are asking with increasing frequency as they watch their sales figures nervously. The thing that worries them is a possible psychological reaction against spending if there should be too much stress on the problem of unemployment.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will give three performances under the auspices of Bamberger's at the Mosque Theatre in Newark on Friday and Saturday. Friday evening's program will consist of "Swan Lake" in a new three-act version, and "Scheherazade."

TOPEKA, Kan. -- This is Centennial Year in Kansas, and the year-long birthday, party is expected to bring millions of tourist into the state. About 570 separate centennial events, ranging from songfests to Indian powwows, already are scheduled, and there will be more as the year advances.

At the turn of the century, a young debutante who had been doing some serious thinking passed along to her friends the idea that "privilege carried with it a responsibility to the community." Having fun, she said, was not the end-all of life, and it was time they started doing something for others.

As a new collector of art trends in America for many years now, I feel that Mr. Canaday is destructive and intolerant of an art movement that has swept the world. For once we are the leaders and neither the followers or borrowers of foreign culture.

To commemorate the diamond jubilee of the founding of the Berkshire Farm for Boys, the Spring Benefit Committee of the organization has arranged a theatre party to the April 25 performance of the Jean Kerr comedy "Mary, Mary" at the Helen Hayes Theatre. Dinner parties in the Maisonette of the St. Regis will precede the performance.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 11 (Reuters) -- Jafar Sharif-Imami presented a fifteen-member cabinet to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi today after being reappointed Premier of Iran.

AS much as it can spank anybody, the American motion-picture industry can spank Joseph E. Levine for Judas goating it down a path of commerce that may take it -- or elements of it -- to the brink of ruin.
OSLO, Norway, March 11 -- The sign in the lobby pointing to the elevators says: "To Trygve Lie's Office."

JOHN F. KENNEDY reads books and takes them seriously. Not content with books alone, he also collects their authors. The recent works of his advisers -- among others, Richard E. Neustadt, Robert Triffin, Walt W. Rostow and Arthur Schlesinger Jr. -- form a kind of reference library for his convictions and intentions.

A YOUNG man has now spent three years making a movie about the Indians on Bunker Hill. On Jan. 4, Kent MacKenzie, a 30-year old film maker, marked the third anniversary of his work in fashioning a feature called, "The Exiles," from the lives of several hundred American Indians who live on Bunker Hill.
HAVANA, March 11 -- Maj. William A. Morgan of Toledo, Ohio, who served in Premier Fidel Castro's revolutionary army, was executed by a firing squad shortly after 10 o'clock tonight.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 11 -- Willie Shoemaker and Don't Alibi teamed today to win the $113,100 San Juan Capistrano Handicap over the Santa Anita Park turf course. The heavily favored combination of Johnny Longden and Geechee Lou finished out of the money.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., March 11 (AP) -- The Air Training Command of Lowry Air Force Base, Colorado, won the Air Force world basketball tournament today by defeating last year's winner, Continental Air Command, 85--81.
Many segments of the toy industry will concentrate on the past this year and others will stress the future. The two major themes in the play world will be the Civil War and space and science.
The wildlife domain of Africa was described yesterday by a noted camera-naturalist as crumbling because of tribal customs and political upheavals.

ON March 21, 1960, Sharpeville, South Africa, was added to the dark roster of place-names where massacres have occurred. The world reacted in horror the next day when photographs showed the bodies of Africans, young and old, crumpled on village streets and bordering fields.

THE last time Ferhat Abbas, who has been Premier of the provisional Government of the Algerian Republic since its formation in 1958, tried to speak in the old Algerian Assembly some six years ago, he was howled down by the European members and forbidden to continue by the European speaker.
Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan urged yesterday that the city go slow with any Charter revision.

TORONTO, March 11 (UPI) -- Goals by Red Hay and Murray Balfour of Chicago helped knock the Toronto Maple Leafs out of the first place in the National Hockey League tonight as the Hawks and Leafs struggled to a 2-2 tie.
Mayor Wagner yesterday charged Governor Rockefeller and the Republican leaders of the Legislature with "shocking and calloused" disregard of justified demands for more state aid to education here.

It's proxy time down in Wall Street, and many brokers are singing their annual spring blues about the proxy crop that grows bigger each year. While some of the paper work arising from the processing of proxies can be mechanized, much of it remains a highly seasonal, hand-picking operation.

SYRACUSE, March 11 -- Carmen Basilio warmed up for a middleweight title challenge next month by taking a unanimous decision from Don Jordan tonight in a nationally televised ten-round bout. Basilio weighed 156 pounds and Jordan. 151 1/2.

THIS is the week when the spring pot begins to boil over, after a disinclination even to allow its tepidity to be disturbed for the last several weeks. The New York City Ballet returns on Tuesday to remain for four weeks; Martha Graham, the Molseyev Dance Company from Russia, and, if a suitable theatre can be found, the American Ballet Theatre, are all lined up for virtually immediate action.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 11 -- Lehigh won the team title in the fifty-seventh annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament tonight.

Post time for New York State's longest season of thorougbred racing -- 220 days of action, spread over three tracks -- is still eight days away. Yet, already, there are those, fortified with fresh money, who are fearful of being shut out when the daily-double windows close at 1:20, come Monday, March 20, at Aqueduct.
LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- The Cincinnati Royals kept alive their hopes for a play-off berth by defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 108 -- 105, in a televised National Basketball Association game today.

MITCHELL WILSON'S ninth novel is reported to be an international publishing "first": the first novel to be published simultaneously in New York and Moscow. In 1958, this author decided to write a book about an American scientist in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had started an investigation to see if 213 of the nation's leading department stores accepted illegal kickbacks from clothing suppliers.

A bitter proxy duel for control of Alleghany Corporation appeared certain last week after the collapse of efforts to reconcile the dispute between Allan P. Kirby, the big holding company's chairman, and the Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- The populations of Arizona and California have grown nearly ten-fold in the twentieth century, the Census Bureau reported today.
The resignation of William A. Ettel, assistant to the Commissioner of Hospitals, was announced yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, March 11 -New Haven's adoption of a new plan of public school organization in conjunction with a $13,000,000 building program for the Nineteen Sixties has been urged by a study committee.
DeWitt Peterkin Jr. has been elected a director of the Stauffer Chemical Company here. He is vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
The teachers salary fund of the Rockland Country Day School in South Nyack, N.Y., will be aided by the March 21 performance of "Camelot" at the Majestic Theatre.

The scholarship fund of the National University of Ireland Club will receive the proceeds of the annual St. Patrick's Day banquet, to be sponsored by the club's board of directors. It will take place in the Jade-Basildon Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 11 (AP) -- Ohio state walloped Illinois, 95 -- 66, today and became the first Big Ten basketball team since 1919 to end its regular season undefeated.

THIS should be a Sabbath of great satisfaction for playwrights Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee. It is the day for the announcement of the establishment of the annual Margo Jones Award, an idea they had and one to which they have enlisted some of the more prominent of the theatre's playwrights and devotees.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 11 -- Antoine Gizenga is apparently still in control of Stanleyville, seat of the Leftist rebel regime in Eastern Province. An American diplomat said here today that Mr. Gizenga had received him in Stanleyville last night and that the city was calm.

ATLANTA, March 11 -- Negro students agreed today to refrain from further picketing and sit-in demonstrations against white merchants. But a settlement that promised an end to the city's year-long lunch-counter desegregation dispute still appeared to be in jeopardy.

THE curtain will rise on Tuesday at Broadway's Lyceum on a barely furnished stage. The designer-director, Hilton Edwards, conceived the setting as "an empty, elegant space instead of a room." On a sofa to one side will sit, also elegantly, a man in a dinner jacket; substantially built, handsome, black-maned, authoritatively at ease.

The spring-like temperatures last week were in contrast to sleet, snow and near zero weather a year ago, and the dollar volume reported by retailers showed the effects of the comparisons. In the 1960 week volume at stores dwindled, while this year business, although at a moderate pace, was able to record sharp gains.
The drug-resistant germ problem appears to have taken a turn for the worse.

Tony Jackson of St. John's, a 6-foot-4-inch forward, received two honors yesterday from the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association. He was one of two unanimous choices for the all-metropolitan first team and was picked for the Haggerty Award as the outstanding local collegiate player.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 11 -- The swimming area for Plainview-Old Bethpage's $1,000,000 park development will open in August, Town Councilman Edmund A. Ocker announced this week.

OSLO, Norway, March 11 (AP) -- Soviet Union star led in the Holmenkollen ski jump after the first half of the competition today and a Norwegian took the fifty-kilometer (about thirty-one miles) cross-country race. Two leaps tomorrow will complete the jump.

MILWAUKEE, March 11 (AP) -- George Kerr, a University of Illinois student from Jamaica, British West Indies, bettered the accepted world indoor record for the 1,000-yard run tonight, defeating Ernie Cunliffe of Stanford in the tenth annual Milwaukee Journal Games at the Arena.

Yachts in the Annapolis-to-Newport race that begins on June 17 will be required to have their numbers sewed on both sides of spinnakers, according to Julian K. Roosevelt, the chairman of the New York Yacht Club race committee.
COPENHAGEN -- "Don't tell us of America's picturesque villages," the Danish travel agency president said, "when Europe is full of them."

DESPITE dire warnings several years ago that record companies were overplaying their hands by releasing jazz albums in such at relentless flood that buyers must soon become sated or hopelessly bewildered, the market for jazz disks has shown steady growth during the last two or three years.

EXCEPT under very special conditions, I hold no brief for revivals per se. The hurly-burly of Broadway is not a suitable climate for the great literature of the theatre. The dearth of actors and directors endowed with a sense of style and tradition leads me to believe that the majority of "revivable" plays are best left on the library shelf.

TWO seasons ago, Reuven Frank, a producer for National Broadcasting Company News, was in charge of a series of six television programs called "Kaleidoscope." The first five shows were generally well received, but the final telecast, entitled "Our Man in the Mediterranean," was outstanding.

San Francisco's Nob Hill is the home cuisine, testing laboratory and writing sanctum for two of yachting's amateur cooks who have done an inestimable service for pleasure boating. By mid-season they seem certain to be praised and adulted on so many harbors, rivers and lakes that dozens of yacht clubs everywhere will want to make them honorary members.

A trend to link supermarkets and discount operations in a single location is gaining rapidly, it was asserted last week by Sidney R. Rabb, chairman of Stop Shop, New England-based chain with a volume of $300,000,000 a year.

THIS year a welcome breeze is stirring in summer furnishings. Suburban patios and city terraces will blossom freshly with outdoor versions of the traditional and softened modern designs that interior decorators have been adopting with such enthusiasm in recent years for inside the home.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced tonight that it had filed a motion for an injunction and temporary order to restrain ten Louisiana legislators from taking any action to interfere with the Orleans Parish (County) school board.
In "Have Parents a Right to Know?" (Feb. 12), Dorothy Barclay asks, "Should parents be told a child's I.Q.?"
The New York Knickerbockers ring down the curtain on the 1960 season this afternoon when they face the Detroit Pistons at 3 P.M. in Madison Square Garden in a National Basketball Association game.
The speech pattern of President Kennedy is being used by a speech teacher at City College as an example of how not to talk.

An estimated total of 230,000 gardening and flower enthuiasts will have visited the Forty-fourth International Flower Show at the Coliseum by the time it closes tonight, officials predicted yesterday.

LONDON -- The coming season's American tourists who intend to sample the British way of life will surely want to drop into a typical pub for a noggin or a print. But if they also want to avoid being shocked, rebuffed or left with their thirst, they should have at least a little preparation for their adventure.
The Rev. Dr. David J. Seligson urged yesterday that organized religions take the initiative in advancing liberal causes to assure equality of opportunity.

THIRTEEN "Playhouse 90" dramas, selected from a series that ran on television for three years, will be repeated this summer by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Scheduled for Tuesdays from 9:30 to 11 P.M., the repeats will begin July 4 and continue through Sept. 26.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Kennedy ordered today the discontinuance of seventeen interdepartmental committees that had been set up for high-level policy making. All but one had been established in the Eisenhower Administration.
NORWALK, Conn., March 11 -Dona Felicia Rincon de Gautier, Mayor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, is spending the week-end seeing at first hand the way her compatriots in this area are living.

A few leaders in the electric utility industry say that action on their part and not talk is the best way to induce the Kennedy Administration to keep its hands off their in dustry. This, they believe, is particularly true for the ever-present threat of the linking of power systems into a giant Federal transmission grid.

For his piano recital in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, Herbert Stessin brought in a rather unusual program that included excerpts from Hindemith's "Ludus Tonalis," Mendelssohn's Fantasy in F sharp minor, three pieces by Faure, and two by Chopin.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The State Health Department today denounced two bills to force its Public Health Council to hold public hearings before making changes in the state Sanitary Cade.
A husband-and-wife team of social workers, recently back from a tour of Africa, believes the United States can best help Africans by teaching them to help themselves.

MOSCOW, March 11 (AP) -- The pro-Western Laotian Government failed to gain its objectives in the Cambodia conference with former Premier Souvanna Phouma and "suffered a diplomatic defeat," Tass, official Soviet press agency, said today.

MIAMI BEACH, March 11 -- It is not unlike a baseball game that has gone into extra innings after each side has connected once with a tremendous home run. Ingemar Johansson, batting right-handed, belted his in the third inning of the original match. Floyd Patterson, batting left-handed, crashed one in the fifth inning of the return.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 11 --White, delicate, and reportedly quite tasty, the sego lily seems doomed to extinction in Utah.
NEWARK, March 11 -- Slates were filed in Essex County this week for the April 18 primaries and the general election on Nov. 7.

The crisis in cosmology that has confronted astronomers around the world in the last few weeks is not really a crisis at all in the view of two leading proponents of the steady-state theory of the origin of the universe.
An $800,000 damage suit by the Cuban Government against a United States freighter threatens the owners with "imminent" bankruptcy, a company official has declared.

Improvement was noted in some areas of Cleveland business activity in the week ended March 4. Auto sales recorded pronounced gains and unemployment eased slightly, but steel production experienced a setback. New car registrations increased 50 per cent to a total of 1,643.

MONTREAL -- The problem of speeding a traveler between the airport of a large city and the heart of the city itself, or vice versa, is a common one today throughout the world. Montreal is no exception and the Canadian Government, in attacking the problem, is seriously studying the use of rail transportation to eliminate present delays.

United States Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman will be honorary chairman of the dinner for the ambassadors of the nations participating in the annual United States World Trade Fair this year. The dinner will be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on May 2, the eve of the fair's opening.

A SPECIALIST in German history, Louis Snyder nearly thirty years ago (under the pseudonym Nordicus) wrote the first book about Hitler published in the English language -- "Hitlerism: The Iron Fist in Germany."

DETROIT, March 11 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther said today that it was "sheer hypocrisy" for Henry Ford 2d to propose holding the line on wages while the Ford Motor Company paid $33,600,000 in bonuses to its executives and top employes.

Retail trade in this area soared last week under the impetus of favorable weather and the early Easter buying this year. Dollar volume for department stores ran 6 to 12 per cent above the 1960 level, merchants estimated. Good gains in sales were reported in apparel, furniture and major appliance departments.

TEL AVIV -- With the formal opening on Tuesday of the Sheraton-Tel Aviv Hotel here on Israel's Mediterranean coast, visitors to this slightly Americanized corner of the country will enjoy the best of two worlds.

TWENTY year ago, a minute of recorded classical music cost the buyer about fifty cents. Today it costs him ten cents or less -- this in an era when prices are double what they were two decades ago. Noting this phenomenon, a record company executive asked: "What other industry functioning both in 1941 and today can make a comparable claim?"
Sponsors have been announced for the Cornell Art Tour on the afternoon of April 15.

A new illness called the "garage door syndrome" has been discovered by a doctor in Atlanta. It is pain, often developing at night and severe enough to suggest a heart condition to the sufferer, but actually stemming opening an overhead garage door too energetically.
A couple of Western badmen met their downfall early yesterday when they attempted a frontier style of hold-up of Freddy's Lounge, at tavern at 361 First Avenue, at Twenty-first Street.

The stage has been set for a major battle between Mayor Wagner and the Democratic party organizations in New York City by the enactment this week of state legislation clearing the way for a referendum this fall on charter revision.
LOME, Togo, March 10 -- Premier Sylvanus Olympio criticized the United States today for what he called its lukewarm support for the United Nations in the Congo.

YOUNG readers and animal lovers should find "One Man and His Dog" a delightful story. Although the adventures of the dog's master keep intruding, this is basically the tale of an Alsatian (which some people call a "police dog") that survived a series of wartime ordeals.

ITS annual town-meeting season on Cape Cod, and the voters of Wellfleet a few weeks ago had to plod through uncommon banks of snow and ice; the Cape boasts that the moderating influence of the sea produces a moderateness of climate somewhat resembling the temperament of the inhabitants and protects them from heavy snows, though not from gales and thundering surf.
In ninety of the 100 underdeveloped countries natural resources are adequate to sustain their peoples at decent levels of living, Paul G. Hoffman told scholastic editors yesterday.
The recent zonal chess matches between Spain and Switzerland for the Europe Cup ended with the Spaniards winning, 12 -- 8. The matches were played at Barcelona in two rounds of ten games each.

But it does seem that the male reporters at President Kennedy's press conference might show a modicum of courtesy -- such as they show each other -- toward the female reporters, and not push and shove so ruthlessly in their determination to get the floor.
The plight of Cubans who have fled to Florida to escape the Castro regime has become a major concern of Christian groups in this country.

Horace Greeley may have said "Go West, young man" in 1854, but Mayor Wagner has refused to let the life-sized stone statue of the famous editor of the old New York Tribune make a trip to Seattle in 1962. It is in City Hall Park, just northeast of City Hall.

LONDON, March 8 -- Partial blindness because of operations for cataract and other diseases or injuries is being corrected here by the permanent implantation of very thin plastic lenses behind the outer transparent wall, the cornea, of defective eyes.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- Twenty citizens of as many foreign nations will meet here tomorrow for a ten-day seminar with American academic leaders, public officials and journalists.

For many New Yorkers the fact that their city is one of the great ports of the world always comes as a mild surprise. Fenced in by the walls of subway tunnels and the towering cliffs of buildings, they can go months without ever glimpsing the water that interlaces the city to such a great commercial and cultural advantage.
Puccini's "La Boheme'' was given its thirteenth performance of the season by the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon, but there was certainly nothing unlucky about it.

BARI, Italy -- This city and its province in the southeast of Italy are busily preparing for what they hope will be their biggest year for tourists. The optimism stems from two facts. The first has been gradually apparent over several years, but was amplified more fully last year because of the Olympic Games.

In one of the most dramatic finishes to team competition in a track and field meet in years, Yale edged Villanova, 30 -- 29, last night in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America's fortieth annual indoor meet at Madison Square Garden.

An appeal to President Kennedy to give "high priority" to the issue of peace between the Arab States and Israel was made here last night by Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the World Confederation of General Zionists.
A ranch house with upper and lower levels has been opened at Americana, a development of fifty-one dwellings at the foot of Hewlett Avenue in Merrick, L.I. The house is priced at $25,990.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The college engineering curriculum is reported to be on the threshold of a fundamental change of direction, from emphasis on technical training to a "liberal arts" philosophy.
NEWARK, March 11 -- Michael Vito Limongello, a 37-year-old jewelry maker, was charged early this morning with the robbery-murder of David Spatz, a diamond merchant.

COLUMBIA, Mo., March 11 -- Missouri ended Kansas' chances of gaining a tie for the Big Eight basketball title today by upsetting the Jayhawks, 79 -- 76, in a rough game. Two players were ejected and fans battled on the floor.

Tipton of New York and Edgartown, Mass., have an- i nounced her engagement to l Augu.stus Frederic Kinel. He is the son of Mrs. Louise Sandal ors of New York and Dr. Au- i gustus Braun Kinzel of New. York and La Jolia, Calif.

The ticket sale is proceeding briskly and many good locations are still available for the closed-circuit Heart Fund telecast of the Floyd Paterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight championship tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The prolonged, costly and controversial project to develop an atomic-powered airplane faces a new delay of several years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- West Chester (Pa.) State College won the eastern intercollegiate women's swimming championship for the second straight year by scoring 56 points today in the sixteenth annual meet in the University of Pennsylvania's Hutchinson Pool.

KATMANDU, Nepal -- To the American tourist, Nepal offers an idea of what it would be like to travel backward in time, an idea popular in cartoon strips. There is little of the new in Nepal, and what there is new is limited to the capital city of Katmandu.

An American lawyer who charges there are 6,000 political prisoners in Spanish jails offered yesterday to go to Madrid at his own expense if the Spanish Government would give him permission to visit some prisons and talk to some prisoners.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., March 11 (AP) -- Two pacifists were taken into custody at the Portsmouth Naval Base today after an unsuccessful attempt to board the new Polaris missile submarine Abraham Lincoln.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 11 -- Led by Chris Selbeck, a Norwegian-born resident of Canada, and Jim Shea, the team captain from Lake Placid, N.Y., the University of Denver clinched the National Collegiate ski championship today.

Plans are nearing completion for the thirtieth annual luncheon, bridge party and fashion show for the Loyola School and the Jesuit Seminaries of the New York Province. It will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on March 23.

Is the high fidelity business in a new phase? Generalizations on this subject demand a constant skepticism. The hi-fi industry, so far, has been too busy growing up to measure itself or its market accurately. Nor has anyone dug very deeply into the motivations of its various kinds of customers.
A 24-year-old apprentice bricklayer finished last, but first, yesterday in a union bricklaying contest here.
Events in Washington, Harrisburg and Providence will make next week-end a particularly active one for dog exhibitors.

In his perceptive delineation of Secretary of Labor Goldberg as a "Trouble-Shooter on the New Frontier" (Feb. 12), A.H. Raskin notes the Secretary's "ingenuity and integrity." He will need both in a time when a group of labor organizers refer to a leading -- to its embarrassment -- as their employer and insist on a union of their own!
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 8 -- Although nearly seven months have passed since Cyprus achieved independence, there are still no real signs that a sense of nationhood is developing.

THIS is an audacious and distinguished book. Edmund Stillman and William Pfaff have accomplished what so many Americans lately have tried, but failed to communicate: an informed revaluing of the national foreign policy. I use the word "revaluing" advisedly.

Some light appeared on the business horizon in the Chicago area during February, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed. Improvement in both order backlogs and production combined with firmness in price and inventories was noted by members of the group. There was only slight improvement in the employment situation.
LOS ANGELES, March 11 (AP) -- Waterfront workers returned to work today at Los Angeles-Long Beach Harbor, ending a four-day tie-up.

A NEGATIVE has been added to the Polaroid quick-print process and a wide-angle model to the Rolleiflex camera line. These developments will be among the highlights of the thirty-seventh annual national convention and trade show of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association that opens today in Convention Hall, Philadelphia.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 8 -- This middle-sized Hoosier city, where bituminous coal smoke is pungent in the night air, is the center of Indiana's waning coal industry.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York will start its 1961 general campaign simultaneously with a new three-year "Adopt-a-Project" drive at the appeal's twenty-third annual inaugural dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Wednesday night.

A two-level ranch model with two living rooms has been introduced at Woodside, a colony of forty-three houses on Park Avenue, off Prospect Avenue, in Park Ridge N.J. The dwellings, which are priced at $26,490, will be ready for occupancy this spring.

LONDON, Sunday March 12 -- Julius Nyerere, Chief Minister of Tanganyika, said in a cabled dispatch to The Observer today that his country would not apply for British Commonwealth membership when she achieved independence shortly so long as South Africa remained a member of the Commonwealth.
The world' s shipbreakers broke their own records as well as ships last year, according to a study made public yesterday by a British concern of shipping analysts.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 -- President Kennedy should draw nearer Latin America and listen more closely to its people before "speaking in the name of the Western Hemisphere," Gen. Lazaro Cardenas, former President of Mexico, declared last night.
BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- The American League president, Joe Cronin, today announced twenty-three changes in the 1961 schedule. All but three of them involve Kansas City home games.

ON Tuesday, the mills of the gods having ground sufficiently -- or gnashed their teeth -- the National Book Awards will be given for 1960's best work of fiction, non-fiction and poetry. Prizes are $1,000 plus citation.

" Offspring of a liberal and expansive benevolence, ranging far beyond the confines of a single town" -- so read the statement of purpose for the Massachusetts General Hospital when it was founded in 1811. In the years since that time, it has grown to national eminence while still retaining a very distinctive Bostonian identity.

" MEET THE AUSTINS" is indeed a very apt title. For this gentle, perceptive book is, rather than a true novel, a group of vignettes relating to the Austin family: teen-age John; 12-year-old Vicky; Suzy, who is 9; little Rob; plus a doctor father, an ever-patient mother, a French poodle, a great Dane and assorted cats.

REVIVALS have proved the riskiest kind of theatrical undertaking. One reason is that audiences generally are more interested in new works than in seeing familiar ones performed again. This urge seems to be part of our national craze for the latest and newest models, whether in Thunderbirds, electric typewriters or atomic toaster.

A WRY broadcaster once observed that there never is any difficulty in persuading an educator, clergyman or newspaper man to go before the camera; the problem is how to get him off. Certainly, one of the noticeable consequences of the TV age is the eagerness of members of the Fourth Estate to shed the comparative anonymity of life behind a typewriter and mount the stage that holds the passing show.
NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (AP) -- The police ran ballistic tests today to try to determine which of two guns had killed W. Ray Scheuering, managing director of the Municipal Auditorium.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., March 11 -- Plans for setting up a Nassau-Suffolk center for the performing arts were made this week by representatives of sixteen cultural groups meeting at Levittown Hall.

MONTREAL, March 11 (UPI) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion closed in on one of hockey's most important records tonight when he scored his forty-seventh and forty-eighth goals of the season to spark the Montreal Canadiens to 7-5 victory over the Boston Bruins.

PARIS, March 11 -- When West Germany and the Netherlands increased the value of the mark and the guilder last weekend, they took an action which will probably influence interest rates in America, jobs in Britain, prices in France and similar matters in all of the world's industrial countries.

MRS. STEVE PARKER, a red-head, blue-eyed actress identified on the screen as Shirley MacLaine, and her husband, a producer with a considerable expertise and affection for Japan, are in this old city heading a company of players to set the record straight (they hope) about modern Japan.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica March 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Jules Brulatour of New York were found dead in their room at the Sunset Lodge Hotel today.

The stockpile of Government-held cotton is disappearing rapidly. From a peak level of some 12,500,000 bales in which investments exceeded $2,000,000,000 five years ago, Government holdings will be reduced to an estimated 1,000,000 bales, or even less, by the end of the season on July 31.

The annual spring festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church will be held May 4 and 5 at the Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Weeks of no borrowing by district city banks at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis are rare, according to bank economists, but there were two of them recently: The weeks ended Jan. 25 and Feb. 1. Liquidity of city banks continued to reflect larger liquidation of loans than is usual for this season and a somewhat less than usual deposit outflow.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The outlines of President Kennedy's initial approach to the problem of Negro rights became clear this week with the issuance of his executive order on equal job opportunities.

It does not take much listening to the first three offerings of the Shakespeare Recording Society (an offshoot of Caedmon) to realize that the resources of stereo have been exploited to the hilt.

THE Hamburg State Opera's Week of Contemporary Musical Theatre had all the earmarks of a festival with actually being one. Eight modern works were produced on successive evenings; all eight are in the permanent repertory of the Hamburg Opera, which is emerging gradually but steadily as the leading German opera house.

PHOTOGRAPHS and photographic essays on the National Urban League's theme, "America's Many Faces," have been selected, the league announced last week. Under the chairmanship of Edward Steichen, director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, the jury picked 223 pictures and seven essays by 133 photographers from a field of more than 50,000 pictures submitted by nearly 6,000 photographers.

CALIFORNIANS were pleased but not at all surprised by the recent news that, because of changes in population, their delegation in the House of Representatives will go up from 30 to 38 while New York's is being reduced from 43 to 41. They confidently expect to pass New York in numbers in the near future and to be the most populous state in the nation.

MADRID, March 10 -- Nearly three full pages, including the entire cover, of yesterday's issue of Arriba, daily newspaper of the Falangist movement, is devoted to a bitter attack on The New York Times.
