With St. Patrick's Day just over the horizon, the Emerald Society of the New York Police Department pointed proudly yesterday to the role of Irish Americans in policing the city.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Kennedy Administration is conducting a drive to recruit Negro college graduates for Federal jobs.
Phyllis Diller, who is installed for a four-week run at the Bon Soir in Greenwich Village, is the leading member of that rare breed of night-club entertainer -- the female stand-up comic.
MIAMI BEACH, March 12 -- "Fight? What fight?"
LONDON, March 12 (UPI) -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana rejected today a demand by President Joseph Kasabubu of the Congo that he stop interfering in Congo affairs.

KITCHAWAN, N.Y., March 12 -- The electronic era has brought a new taxpayer to Westchester County that pays 14 per cent of the taxes in some communities and adds $25,000,000 a year in salaries to the economy.

IN the shadowy world of boxing William Denis Fugazy is an extraordinary fancy Dan. He simply does not fit into any category normally associated with this half-world of operators and these operated on.
MESA, Ariz., March 12 -- No matter how many coaches the Chicago Cubs use, and they now have eight, the I.B.M. machine will never replace Ernie Banks.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Frank B. Ellis, newly, installed Federal civil defense chief, has asked the states for prompt action on statutes for continuity of government.
The Zionist Organization of America voted yesterday to convene a national conference soon to plan a way to promote the teaching of Hebrew and other aspects of Hebrew culture.
Most experts agree that cash and life insurance should be the base for any person's financial planning.

Playing like Stanley Cup contenders instead of a club that had missed the competition for the third straight season, the New York Rangers whipped the Detroit Red Wings, 7 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
A second series of fellowships for studies in the creative arts was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
A Slightly built, keen-eyed and professorial-looking octogenarian received plaudits here yesterday from ranking officials of the labor and Socialist movements of this country and others.

CHICAGO, March 12 (UPI) -- Bernie Geoffrion of Montreal scored his forty-ninth goal of the season, one short of the National Hockey League record, as the Canadians downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-2, tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A panel of the President's Science Advisory Committee has recommended that spending on high-energy physics be quadrupled over the next decade to maintain United States leadership in exploring the heart of the atom.

ROME, March 12 -- The past few days have been extremely instructive to our friends abroad. They are now beginning to get a more detailed view of the Kennedy Administration's foreign-policy plans. The over-all diplomatic picture has been etched by the President's roving Ambassador, Averell Harriman.
Edward Tatnall Canby makes listening to cappella choral music an easygoing, educational, pleasurable experience. What more could a listener want?

TULSA, Okla., March 11 -- An imagination that could sail a fleet of barges into landlocked Oklahoma was a prerequisite for a two-day meeting of the Arkansas Basin Development Association here this week-end.
PITTSBURGH, March 12 -- Steel Spokesmen and steel order books continue to reflect the mild optimism in the industry.

WARSAW, March 12 (AP) -- Communism may lose "the struggle for the mind of man" unless its philosophy comes to grips with the problem of the human individual and his fate, Adam Schaff, a leading Polish Marxist philosopher, said in two recent articles apearing in the weekly Przeglad Kulturalny (Cultural Review).
All street signs in the city should be made uniform, a report to be submitted to the Legislature said today.
More Americans are expected to go to Europe this year than ever before, the American Express Company said last week.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 12 -- The expertly drilled Yankees were still having trouble today adjusting themselves to whatever it is they are supposed to be doing at the moment.
TUNIS, March 12 -- The Algerian Provisional Government will meet here this week with a reported goal of turning secret talks with the French Government into formal, publicly announced negotiations.
NICOLAI Gedda is an artist of superb control and sensitivity in concert as much as in opera.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11 -- East and Central Africa clamor for the world's attention. But Africans and Europeans alike are so wrapped in their own problems that they pay little attention to the world and its problems.

The Apco Oil Corporation is offering holders of class A and class B stock of the Union Texas Natural Gas Corporation the right to subscribe for $10,072,300 of Apco Oil Corporation 5 3/4 per cent subordinated debentures due 1981 and 503,615 common shares of Apco.

RIO DE JANIERO, March 11 -- President Janio Quadros has isolated himself in his marble palace in Brasilia to carry out his program for saving Brazil from economic chaos and leading it to a position of world power.

The foreign exchange market was in a complete state of confusion during the past week. Rumors of revaluation and devaluation were circulated freely. The U.S. dollar in terms of other currencies was under constant pressure and lost ground. British pound sterling, weak in the early part of the week, rallied sharply on the announcement by Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that Great Britain had no intentions of devaluing the pound.
SATURDAY night's performance of "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera House brought a late-season debut with the appearance as Gilda of Nerina Santini, young Italian coloratura soprano.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today he thought the bottom of the recession had been reached and the economy could start to move upward. He painted a hopeful picture and gave these other views in a television-radio interview:
BONN, Germany, March 12 -- The West German Government has protested orally in Washington against the Administration's official reaction to the 5 per cent revaluation of the Deutsche mark last week.
A large New Jersey concern recruiting Puerto Rican farm laborers has been accused of illegally attempting to hire workers and barred from further activity, pending an explanation.
Columbia University has named Elizabeth S. Gill associate dean of nursing at the School of Medicine. Miss Gill also has been named director of nursing at the Presbyterian Hospital.

Legislation that will have a major effect o nradio and television ratings and advertising has now been reported out of committee and may come to a vote in the State Assembly the early part of this week.
GENEVA, March 12 -- The Canadian national hockey team, the Smoke-Eaters from Trail, B.C., methodically destroyed the Soviet Union tonight, 5 -- 1, and won another world amateur championship.

The American Marketing Association has selected Harold L. Zellerbach, chairman of the executive committee of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and chairman of the Zellerbach Paper Company, this year's winner of its Charles Coolidge Parlin Memorial Award.

More than 6,000 Masons heard the United States urged yesterday to take the initiative in a new quest for world peace. They were attending the sixteenth annual Masonic breakfast at the Astor and Commodore Hotels.

MIAMI BEACH, March 12 -- Floyd Patterson looked invincible during his final tune-up drills before his first fight with Ingemar Johansson in June of 1959. He flitted about the ring with certainty, throwing combinations with blinding speed and deadly accuracy. Ingo showed nothing and used his vaunted right only when he was steering his fiancee, Birgit Lundgren, around the dance floor.
Wagner's "Parsifal" will be given its first performance of the season by the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, March 22.

Twenty-five years ago, in the Reich Sports Field Stadium in Berlin, a University of Pittsburgh freshman named John Youie Woodruff found himself pocketed at the start of the Olympic 800-meter run and buried in the pack.

President Kennedy's sensible approach to expanded assistance for colleges and universities undoubtedly will be greeted by one old argument which ought to be laid to rest. The opponents of increased Federal aid (direct or indirect) for our nation's colleges, when backed into a corner, usually resort to the allegation that Federal aid inevitably means Federal interference.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A former New England lawyer reminisced in his office the other day about New England courts.
ALBANY, March 12 -- The proportion of the personal income of New York residents required to support public schools rose by more than 61 per cent in the last ten years.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Gains in the quality of the nation's housing in the Nineteen Fifties were reported today by the Census Bureau. Rundown dwellings, however, still numbered in the millions.
The State Commission Against Discrimination has ruled that it has no jurisdiction in a case involving a Mohawk Indian woman who complained she was being discriminated against by tribal chiefs.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Kennedy Administration has put two prominent specialists in international economics to work part-time on statistical aspects of the balance of payments.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Rockefeller accused Mayor Wagner tonight of misrepresenting the facts about state aid to New York City to confuse the public.

A city official said yesterday that since a Roman Catholic could now be elected President "it is about time that we got rid of the notion that Catholic school children are not entitled to the same things as public school children."

THE charm and good fortune of the Irish survived fairly entertainingly at times last night in "O'Halloran's Luck," an original musical fantasy starring Art Carney. But at other moments, rather more numerous in the final tally, it seemed that all the leprechauns had gone out for a coffee break.
GENEVA, March 12 -- Four iron-nerved mountain climbers completed today the first winter ascent of the sheer north wall of the 13,000-foot Eiger, near Interlaken, in the Alps of central Switzerland.

Allan P. Kirby, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, said he had purchased in the open market on Thursday and Friday of last week 308,300 shares of common stock and 52,600 common stock purchase warrants of Alleghany.
A bleak picture of crises facing the city was made public yesterday in reports to the Moore state commission, along with complaints that long-range planning on programs and financing was lacking.

Twelve and one-half acres of land at Tiffany Street and East Bay Avenue in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx have been sold by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. Peter I. Feinberg, the buyer, plans to develop the tract as an industrial park.
A top Soviet oil specialist has declared that the Soviet Union is increasing both its oil production and its proved oil reserves more rapidly than the United States.
The administration of Monmouth College was charged yesterday with having "little appreciation or understanding of the academic profession and professional standards of the scholarly disciplines."

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Crystal River, Fla., closed with a 34, 33 -- 67 today to win the $20,000 Pensacola open golf tournament with a thirteen-under-par, 72-hole total of 275. He won $2,800.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin is expected to suggest to the Kennedy Administration that any new Soviet-bloc pressure against Berlin be met by the Allies with a proposal for the unification of East and West Berlin.
The director of Baptist work among the Spanish-speaking people here accused local churches yesterday of neglecting their responsibilities to the Puerto Rican population.
KYRENIA, Cyprus, March 12 -- The people in Cyprus who still hope to achieve enosis, or a political union with Greece, regard their cause as virtually lost.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The head of the Peace Corps said today that any prospective member who expected a "joy ride" ought to "get off the train right now."
CAIRO, March 12 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has advised the Algerian nationalist leaders to hold peace talks with General de Gaulle.

HAVANA, March 12 (UPI) -- William A. Morgan, formerly of Toledo, Ohio, who died with "extraordinary valor" before a firing squad still swearing allegiance to Fidel Castro, was buried today in a traitor's grave.
GENEVA, March 12 -- The slight increase in the value of the West German mark and the Netherlands guilder was largely ignored by the Swiss stock markets last week.

Arguments on the terms of a proposed reclassification of the common stock of the United States Foil Company and a merger of United States Foil with Reynolds Metals Company were postponed yesterday by the Supreme Court of Delaware to April 28, according to a statement by Reynolds Metals.
Aristo Artists, an organization devoted to presenting young singers, gave four of them an opportunity to sing in Town Hall last night.

LONDON, March 12 -- Revaluation of the West German mark increased the hope last Monday that Britain's exports would now show a substantial increase. As a result, the stock market enjoyed one of the busiest weeks in the last twelve months.
The Federal highway program is rolling across the country, leveling hills and homes, filling in valleys and ponds, and dividing communities by means of vast level barriers of concrete.

The business recession may be at or near its bottom, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its Monthly Survey released for publication today. The bank cites the failure of consumers to fall victim to recession psychology, hints of a better balanced inventory situation, firmness in capital spending, and a cushioning of the impact of unemployment on income and spending.
CLEVELAND, March 12 --Big profits are a thing of the past for operators of independent Great Lakes fleets. In a few years they may be fighting for survival.
Dr. Aureliano Sanchez Arango, a former Cabinet minister, called on Cuban exiles last night to choose a Cuban Supreme Court Justice in exile as President of an anti-Castro provisional government.

Some features of some governmental agencies make a person think of the rural citizen who was asked what he and his neighbors did during the slack season and who replied: "Sometimes we set and rock and sometimes we jest set."
JOHN HONEYMAN, a New Jersey patriot who worked as a spy on behalf of the Continental Army during the American Revolution, was the hero of "The Secret Rebel," shown Saturday night over Channel 4.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $82,322,087,881. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 12 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a communique issued today by Congolese leaders at the close of their talks here:
Some light counterpoint to the wit of Shelley Berman was offered last night at Carnegie Hall by the Cumberland Three, a folk-song group.
LONDON, March 12 -- The Marquess of Salisbury is ending all his official ties with the Conservative party organization in protest against the British Government's African policy.
Archbishop Molloy of Queens won the team title yesterday in the eleventh annual Fordham Prep relay carnival on the Little Rams' outdoor board track in the Bronx.
Cotton prices in the domestic market improved last week and closed higher. Future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up twenty-two to forty-seven points at the close of trading on Friday.

ROME, March 12 -- Cordial applause drowned out a few catcalls at the world premiere of Renzo Rossellini's "Uno Sguardo dal Fonte" at the Teatro Dell'Opera of Rome last night. The opera is based on Arthur Miller's "A View From the Bridge."
Plans for Crotona Park Houses, a state-aided New York City Housing Authority development in the Bronx, are scheduled to be filed today with the Department of Buildings.
Volume in the over-the-counter market last week was extremely heavy, but at the close of trading on Friday prices on average showed only a modest gain.
The lowest monthly customs collections for the Port of New York in two and a half years were reported here yesterday by Robert W. Dill, collector of customs.

Each year large quantities of clothing -- bidding for millions of consumer dollars -- are placed on the market. These articles are subject to undue shrinkage, tearing and fading. Although consumers are told the content of a specific garment, there are no labeling safeguards to inform the consumer of the performance he may expect.
President Sukarno of Indonesia has decided to dissolve the Indonesian Boy Scouts and form another association with himself as the chief.

Arthur Larson, an exponent of "the New Republicanism," urged yesterday a "very sharp increase" in the President's role in foreign affairs. Senator Barry Goldwater, of "the New Conservatism," said the President had too much power in that area already.
A project that has been helping to rehabilitate troubled families that appear in the city's Family Courts has been lauded by the presiding justice and given a new grant by a social welfare group.

BUFFALO, March 12 (AP) -- Jeanne Ashworth of Wilmington, Mass., captured the North American indoor speed skating senior women's championship today for the second year in a row. Terry McDermott of Essexville, Mich., took senior men's honors.

" Impulse," Alexander. H. Cohen's jazz revue, will open April 1 at the Royale. The house is adjacent to the Golden on Forty-fifth Street, where Mr. Cohen's show, "An Evening With Mike Nichols and Elaine May" is flourishing.

The trial of Adolf Eichmann will not be merely the trial of "a psychopathic butcher" but a trial of the moral and ethical principles of Christianity and Judaism, a Unitarian minister told his congregation yesterday.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 12 -- Of the six clubs that fancy themselves as contenders for the National League pennant, none, perhaps, has more glowing strong points or glaring weaknesses than the Milwaukee Braves.

The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company last year had a consolidated net income of $6,549,889, or $2.24 each on the 2,921,261 common shares outstanding. Sales and revenue amounted to $64,410,474. Sales and earnings include those of the Macmillan Company, which was merged in 1960.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 12 -- Richard M. Nixon told confidants over the week-end that he had no plans at present to run for the Presidency in 1964 or 1968. But he conceded that his seeking election was not beyond the realm of possibility.

LONDON, March 12 -- The Commonwealth heads of government will begin their second week of meetings tomorrow with the most difficult item on their informal agenda. This is the question whether South Africa, with its policy of apartheid, or strict racial segregation, should be readmitted to the Commonwealth after it becomes a republic May 31.
A serious international dispute has developed over Canadian charges to airlines flying through Canada's extensive air-traffic control zone over the Atlantic.

Earned premiums and membership fees of the State Farm Mutual Auto Insurance Company, Bloomington, Ill., rose 8.6 per cent to a record of $469,117,621 in 1960, Edward B. Rust, president, reported yesterday.
BOSTON, March 12 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored a 5-0 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a National Hockey League game interrupted twice by fights.
President Kennedy is seeking to imbue industry and union leaders with a sense of urgency about the need for "pro-public" wage and price policies.
Fifteen hundred cheerleaders brought their own cheering sections to Fordham University's gymnasium in the Bronx yesterday and shattered the calm of a Sunday afternoon.

DENVER, March 12 -- A New York pair, Tobias Stone and Morton Rubinow, won the National Men's Pair Championship in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here today. Mrs. H.A. Woods and Mrs. May Belle Lang of El Paso, Tex., won the Women's Pair Championship.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 (AP) -- Los Angeles deprived Cincinnati of a possible National Basketball Association play-off berth today by handing the Royals a 123-122 defeat before 5,645 fans in the league's final regular-season game.

Seldom has there been such unanimous, well-informed opposition to a legislative proposal as was revealed at the recent joint Codes Committees' hearing at Albany. The issue was where the power should lie to make the rules of civil procedure for the state's courts.

We would like to comment on the March 4 letter of Mariano de Yturralde, Ambassador from Spain, in which he endeavored to refute the charges concerning political prisoners made by Albert L. Colloms in a letter published March 1.
The city's air-pollution rate dropped sharply during Mayor Wagner's ban on non-essential vehicles in the city because of the heavy-snow storm last month.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Relations between Governor Rockefeller and Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo are attracting attention and analysis as this year's legislative session enters its final phase.

The forty-three-story office building being erected in the blockfront on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets will be known as the Sperry Rand Building.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The nation's capital was beginning to see some signs of spring this week. The trees along its avenues coming to life and there was talk of cherry blossoms and vacations.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy presented 410 citations to policemen yesterday for meritorious service.

The New York Sinfonietta, which is conducted by Max Goberman, gave a concert in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. The program consisted of Haydn's Symphony No. 3 in G, Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 1 and two concertos by Wivaldi.
Two big bouts will compete for attention tonight on the air waves.

Books by and about Fidel Castro are scheduled for publication this season by Lyle Stuart. Next month there will be Fidel Castro's "History Will Absolve Me," which summarizes his program for Cuba. It will be issued in a paper-bound edition.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A thorough overhaul of "disjointed, overlapping and ambiguous" conflict-of-interest laws was recommended today in a staff study issued by the Senate Subcommittee on-National Policy Machinery.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A major new theme in President Kennedy's foreign-aid program will be the idea of giving more help to countries that most effectively help themselves.
TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, March 12 -- A new confederation of sovereign states to replace the Congo Republic was established here today.
ALBANY, March 13 -- A stopgap increase of $22,500,000 a year in state aid to local school districts will be recommended tomorrow by the Joint Legislative Committee on School Financing.
The Kennedy Administration has acted to speed the delivery of Pravda and other Soviet publications to newspapers, libraries and other subscribers in the United States.

CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -Old-crop soybean futures prices resumed them downward trend in broad strides today on the Board of Trade. Loses ran to more than 6 cents a bushel and extended the setbacks to about 30 cent a bushel in spots over the last week or so.
A contract settlement between seven harbor railroads and Local 1463 of the Transport Workers Union, representing about 600 harbor railroad workers, was reached yesterday.
A treatment has been worked out for wool that, according to its inventor, produces a fabric combining many of the best qualities of wool and synthetics.

MIAMI BEACH, March 13 (AP) -- George Weiss, the retired general manager of the New York Yankees, will be appointed president of the new New York club in the National League, The Associated Press learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The words used in both the majority and dissenting Supreme Court opinions in Everson v. Board of Education (1947) amply support their interpretation by President Kennedy. The nine justices united in employing the firmest terms of English speech to hold that direct financial Government aid to church-administered schools was positively forbidden by the phrase in the First Amendment that Jefferson described as "a wall of separation between church and state."

A leader in the fight against Mayor Wagner's proposal for redeveloping West Greenwich Village accused city authorities yesterday of using a "puppet organization" to make it appear that residents approved the project.
New York City has borrowed $25,000,000 on tax anticipation notes dated March 15, and due April 28. Lawrence E. Gerosa, Controller, announced yesterday. The interest rate was 2 per cent.

MIAMI, March 13 -- Smoky Burgess stepped up to bat as a pinch-hitter in the opening game of the exhibition season here the other day and rammed the first pitch for a clean single. A pinch-runner relieved him of the burden of carrying his 192 pounds any farther and Smoky was through for the afternoon.

A first-degree murder indictment against a 31-year-old father was dismissed yesterday on the motion of the prosecutor. The defendant was on trial in Kings County Court, charged with the shotgun slaying of an 18-year-old girl on March 27, 1960.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- An embattled member of Congress sat behind a locked door in the Old House Office Building today.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- The Administration told Congress today it could expect revamping of the $1,100,000,000 space program submitted by former President Eisenhower.
PEORIA, Ill., March 13 (AP) -- A $750,000,000 damage suit against the General Electric Company was dismissed today by a United States District Court.
The General Instrument Corporation announced plans yesterday to acquire the Pyramid Electric Company.

DUNELLON, Fla., March 13 -- It could be argued that the Withlacoochee River bass were not in the humor to strike at fly-rod bugs today but could be induced to take large live minnows. But it would be the casuistic case of an advocate, not the rigorous conclusion of a scientist based on clinical proof.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The House of Representatives ended hearings today on President Kennedy's $389,500,000 bill to revive industry in America's chronically depressed areas.

JERUSALEM, March 12 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi told the Speaker of the House today that he had found no reasonable possibility that any member of the Knesset (Parliament) would be able to form a new Government.
The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and one of its leading physicians will receive the Morris Morgenstern Foundation Award today for advancing "the principles of human dignity and freedom."

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 13 -- The State Highway Department will pay Bergen County $584,500 for land costs and other expenses to the county resulting from the construction of the Bergen-Passaic Expressway through Overpeck Marine Park.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, March 14 (AP) -- Sweden's honeymoon with professional boxing apparently ended when Floyd Patterson stopped Ingemar Johansson tonight for the second time in a heavyweight title fight.
Capital and exploratory expenses by Texaco, Inc. will again be above the $500,000,000 mark this year according to the company's pamphlet report for 1960.
DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -- The Bowlers Journal team, which rolled a poor 2,682 series last night, came to life in the minor events competition at the American Bowling Congress tournament today.

New highs in premiums written, investment income and assets were set last year by the Home Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday by Kenneth E. Black, president. Policyholders' surplus and share earnings, however, showed decreases.
City Center's drive for new friends and special fund-raising entertainments will be discussed this evening at a reception given at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mitchell Felt at 911 Park Avenue.

Assets of Textron, Inc., reached $272,000,000 at the end of 1960, reflecting an increase of $61,000,000 over the 1959 level, stockholders at the annual meeting were told yesterday by Rupert C. Thompson Jr., chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Paul G. Hoffman, first administrator of the Marshall Plan, said today he would like to see an international peace corps eventually.

Tournament time is at hand. More than 15,000 basketball fans are expected to turn out for the triple-header that will open the National Collegiate A.A. Eastern regionals at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Cyprus yesterday joined that exclusive and unique club known as the Commonwealth. There are now twelve members, with another -- Sierra Leone -- due to enter next month. If Southern Rhodesia is counted, the Commonwealth has more nonwhites than whites among its populations.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 10 -- Irish linen, famed the world over, is fighting a stiff battle in foreign and domestic markets against competition from synthetic fibers and fabrics.
ALBANY, March 13 -- A Republican controversy over broadening or restricting the jurisdiction of the State Commission Against Discrimination is brewing in the Legislature.
The Jan. 28 crash of a Boeing 707 jet airliner on a training flight near the tip of Long Island has set in motion a broad reappraisal of training procedures.
LONDON, March 13 -- All five defendants pleaded not guilty today at the opening of their trial on charges of conspiracy to violate the State Secrets Act.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal for salary increases for all state employes ran into a snag at a conference of Senate Republicans today. No one, the conferees decided, should get a raise of more than $5,000 a year.
For years a solemn-faced bear named Smokey has been lecturing people about the damage they inflict on the nation's forests by causing forest fires.

GENEVA, March 13 -- In the United States, the playing of The Star Spangled Banner before games and matches has become so automatic that fans scarcely notice it. This is nationalism in sports at its most subtle.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The White House said today that twenty-five United States private citizens who were in Moscow for a scientific conference last November urged the release of the two RB-47 fliers as "a healthy first step" toward improving Soviet-United States relations.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 13 -- A flood after a cloudburst last night caused at least seven deaths here.
A bright new scarf is a perfect pick-up for a winter-weary wardrobe. With a little imagination and a twist of fabric, a basic dress, suit or classic sweater can take on a new look.

MIAMI BEACH, March 13 -- Floyd Patterson has dedicated himself to boxing since his early teens and has studied the ring art with a seriousness comparable to that of a former heavyweight king, Gene Tunney. The 26-year-old Patterson, the first man in boxing history to regain the heavyweight title, also has the distinction of being the youngest fighter ever to win the title.
A record city budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 was predicted yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

The five-and-one-half-story apartment building at 10 to 22 Fairview Avenue, near 192d Street, has been sold by William H. Gladstone to a client of Aaron M. Schreiber, lawyer, for cash over mortgages totaling $232,000.

The New York Times has reported the basic conflict between the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and the Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System concerning the economic approach toward the solution of persistent, chronic unemployment.

Jack Rohan, once an assistant basketball coach at Columbia, is to become the Lions' head coach, it was learned last night. Rohan's appointment is expected to be announced today after a meeting of Columbia athletic officials.
A prominent real estate broker has proposed that leaders of the industry here form an agency to suppress slum operators "who are giving us all a bad name."
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating proposed today that the Federal courts be given discretion to treat narcotics offenders as sick persons rather than criminals.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Welfare Abraham A. Ribicoff said today he "absolutely opposed" including non-public school aid in the Administration's $2,300,000,000 bill.
HAVANA, March 13 -- The Cuban Government charged today that a Cuban sailor was killed when a "pirate" ship attacked the nationalized Texas Company oil refinery in Santiago de Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The White House announced today that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had been selected to develop and build a high-speed, long-range turbojet transport to carry troops or supplies around the world.

Events today: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Aksel Schiotz, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30; Canticum Musicum Thaddeus Cylkowski, conductor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Manhattan Percussion Ensemble, Paul Price, conductor, Hubbard Auditorium Manhattan School of Music, 8:30; New York Philharmonic, Andre Kostelanetz, conductor, Ozan Marsh, pianist, Paramount Theatre, Stapleton, S.I., 8:30.
The quarter-final play-offs in the National Basketball Association open today at Los Angeles and Philadelphia. Both are three-of-five-game series.
Threatening letters received by Arnold Schuster after he had helped the police capture Willie Sutton, the bank robber, were read yesterday to a jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

James Reston is to be highly commended for his wise, sympathetic view of the Catholic demand for Federal help for their schools, as well as for so gently recalling to Catholic minds the priority of the general welfare. How could those who claim to stand in the Aquinas-Maritain tradition have forgotten this priority?
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Although steel officials are reporting signs of a possible improvement in the industry's prospects, production figures still fail to justify optimism.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave President Kennedy a three-page list today of women she said were qualified for top government jobs.
ON the back jacket of "Ordeal by Ice" the bearded countenance of Farley Mowat (son of Angus McGill Mowat) proudly scowls at something not visible in the picture.
DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -Auto production cutbacks have been so severe that even the four medium price lines which sprouted compact models for 1961 have been unable so far to match 1960 output.

PARIS, March 13 -- Meetings of the French Cabinet and the Algerian rebel Provisional Government this week are expected to produce major new developments in the maneuverings to and the six-year-old Algerian rebellion.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- Nicaragua and Honduras agreed today on a formula to settle their border dispute.

The Duchess of Windsor, Mrs. Arthur A. Houghton and Salvador Dali, judges of the second annual Pini di San Miniato European Scholarship Award, will be honored at a small reception given by the Parsons School of Design, 410 East Fifty-fourth Street, at 5:30 P.M. on Friday.
Six new warrants were issued yesterday against a slum tenement agent who was sent to jail for thirty days and heavily fined in Housing Court Friday.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 13 (AP) -- What was described as one of the largest group life insurance agreements ever written, covering 575,000 employes of more than 300 American railroads, was announced today to stockholders of the Travelers Insurance Company at their annual meeting.

The recession that came in quietly like a lamb last year is going out like a lion, gobbling up quite a few businesses. Yesterday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported that failures for the week ended last Thursday totaled 318, compared with 290 in the 1960 week.
Net income of Motorola, Inc., fell last year by $1,537,424 from that of 1959, despite a sales increase of $7,522,702, according to the annual report.

THE worm in Esther Kaufman's horseradish is that memories do not make a play. Although she has drawn on recollections of her youth for "A Worm in Horseradish," which opened last night at the Maidman Playhouse, she has not created a work that belongs in a theatre.
A Queens magistrate yesterday upheld Mayor Wagner's ban against nonessential driving after the city's recent heavy snowstorm and fined three motorists $5 each.

The first volume of a six-volume history of the United States, "The Making of America," will be published on March 21 by Hill Wang. Called "The New Nation, 1800-1845," the book deals with the first half of the century that saw the "triumph" of Jeffersonian democracy and with the "tragedy" of sectional bitterness and distrust.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- George V. Allen, former head of the United States Information Agency, received a crate of lemons today for suggesting that United States diplomats serve lemonade at some social affairs.
The Real Estate Board of New York insisted yesterday that it had done everything possible to make suitable housing available for African delegates to the United Nations.
John M. Schiff, investment banker, yesterday was named the winner of a new award created by the New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration.

MIAMI BEACH, March 13 (AP) -- Feature Sports Incorporated, the promoter of the Ingemar Johansson-Floyd Patterson title fight, today was reorganized. Thomas A. Bolan, a New York lawyer, will become its new executive director.

TWO rays of California sunshine shone on gray Fifth Avenue yesterday morning as Sister Magdalen Mary and Sister Mary Corita of Los Angeles arrived at W J Sloane for an exhibition and sale of their students' work in arts and crafts.

The $355,000,000 World Trade Center proposed for the bi-state Port of New York would have a stimulating influence on the whole metropolitan area. The location chosen, a sixteen-acre site in lower Manhattan, bounded by Old Slip, Fulton Street and Pearl and Water Streets, is logical -one might almost say mandated by circumstances, historic and present.
Two 17-year-old Japanese visitors -- here under the New York City-Tokyo sister city affiliation proclaimed last year -- were welcomed at City Hall yesterday by Deputy Mayor Paul R. Screvane.
A red-brick brewery with a 138-year history, not all of it virtuous, will be torn down to make way for the new approach to the Manhattan Bridge.
" The Bengal Tiger," a comedy melodrama set against the Sepoy Rebellion of 1857-58, is planned for filming on location in India late this year by John Wayne and Howard Hawks.

Growth that exceeded the rate anticipated only a few years ago has forced many companies to decentralize their offices soon after they consolidated them in the skyscrapers that have sprung up in Manhattan during the postwar period.

THE controversy between Jack Paar and Ed Sullivan has become a highly distasteful brawl. Both men have indulged in invective and have seemed bent on destroying each other. It must give pause to any thoughtful citizen when the networks allow their coast-to-coast facilities to be used for no better purpose than personal abuse.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- State Department officials expressed "guarded hope" today that a truly neutral Laos with a broadly based Government might emerge from negotiations between former Premier Souvanna Phouma and the Right-Wing regime of Premier Boun Oum.
RICHLAND, Wash., March 13 -- A Federal mediator said tonight that labor and management had agreed to continue operation of the Hanford atomic products operation until March 31.
LEOPOLDVILLE, March 12 -- The United Nations command and the central Govern ment continued negotiations today for the return of United Nations troops to Matadi, strategic port on the Congo River.

Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a 3.5 per cent gain in 1960 revenues but this was offset by a 1.5 per cent decline in net income. The revenue gains were recorded in all classes of service but were offset somewhat by cool summer weather.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 13 (UPI) -- The defense of Joseph A. Peel Jr. won court permission today to hear the secret tape recordings that led to the charges on which he is being tried here.

Prices for domestic sugar declined yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in sympathy with actuals. All positions dropped to new lows for the lives of the contracts except July, which equalled the old low.
Peter J. Crotty of Buffalo called on President Kennedy at the White House yesterday. His visit was viewed here as tantamount to White House endorsement of him for New York State Democratic chairman.
HAWTHORNE, N.J., March 13 -- A father tried to kill his four children and himself last night but all were saved by his 10-year-old son.

I was concerned to read in The Observer of March 5 that American newspapers have found amusing the protests made by the people of Britain on the Polaris base in Holy Loch near Glasgow, and describe such protests as coming from a small minority.

A further shrinkage in the yields on Treasury bills and other prime short-term issues was the major development yesterday in the market for gilt-edge debt investments. Outside of the short-term area, little business was done in the Government market.
A twenty-five-foot tree was uprooted from one spot in Flushing Meadow Park yesterday and replanted in another to fill a gap in an avenue of red maples.
Following is the text of a statement on Federal aid to education issued here yesterday by Cardinal Spellman:
SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (AP) -- The four-day tie-up of San Francisco's port ended today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 13 (AP) -- Former Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos said today that peace in his wartorn homeland depended on whether the United States Government would truly support genuine neutralism in Laos.
LONDON, March 13 -- Customers were lining up in book stores today to order a New Testament translated from Latin and Greek manuscript into contemporary English. It goes on sale tomorrow.
The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center received a gift of $1,000,000 yesterday from the Charles Ulrick and Josephine Bay Foundation.

WHAT with Joan Sutherland, Leontyne Price and Birgit Nilsson, the ladies have tended to take over the vocal world this year. Not the least of the contributions was made last night in Carnegie Hall by the Spanish soprano Victoria de los Angeles.
Alice Esty has made a habit of commissioning composers to write music for her to sing.

Another day of some wide swings in the stock market ended yesterday with a small but fairly well distributed gain. Oils and drugs were generally up. So were electronics, but here the list was spotted with a number of rather large losses.

Last night's scheduled debate between Jack Paar and Ed Sullivan on performers' fees was canceled after each accused the other of backing out. The development was like a Broadway-bound show that gets good notices in New Haven but decides not to open in New York.
MIAMI, March 13 (AP) -- A Federal judge today rejected a demand by Government tax collectors that the Swedish heavyweight Ingemar Johansson, return $250,000 to this country from a Swiss bank.
Cardinal Spellman repeated yesterday his opposition to any program of Federal aid to education that excluded private and parochial schools on the elementary and secondary levels.

BOWIE, Md., March 13 (AP) -- Dropping to the allowance ranks after failing in stakes events, Gerald S. Moore's Cotocton Prince won the $5,000 Calvert Purse at Bowie race track today. He paid $31.60 for $2 to win.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 13 points up to 3 points off yesterday. October and December were the only months showing losses.
MIAMI BEACH, March 13 -- "They did not count correctly, I think."
ALBANY, March 13 -- New life was injected into a series of apparently dead measures today to increase the number of members of the state's judiciary by up to thirty-eight.

KANSAS CITY, March 13 (AP) -- West Virginia State lost a 17-point lead, then rallied in overtime today to beat Whitworth of Washington, 90 -- 89, in the first round of the National Association of the Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship.
BONN, Germany, March 13 -The Netherlands has begun to retreat in her battle with the five other countries of the Common Market on how to proceed with Western European trade integration.
Navy and Pennsylvania will start the forty-five-game Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League schedule at Philadelphia on April 8, it was announced yesterday.

EVEN with most of the audience still blinking the sleep out of its eyes at Ohrbach's early morning press show of copies of European fashions, it was a tremendous success. The event managed to gather all the excitement and glamour of a formal first-night gala.
DENVER, March 13 -- Play for the Vanderbilt Cup national open team championship began today in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here, with sixty-four teams entered.

THEODORE LETTVIN, who was heard last night at Town Hall, is a prize-winner who has fulfilled the promise for which his original prize -- a Naumburg in 1948 -- was bestowed. And last night he gave another fine recital.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Treasury's short-term bill rates tumbled again on today's sale of new issues, and the difference between the ninety-one-day and the 182-day rate was unusually narrow.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 13 (AP) -- Reports of rape, pillage and degradation of nuns by Congolese soldiers in Kivu Province have been received by the United Nations here.

THE contribution in flavor and texture that dried figs can lend to cakes and pies is one seldom explored by home cooks. Those old-fashioned favorites among cookies, fig newtons, sometimes are served but almost inevitably they have been purchased ready-made.
A leader of world Zionism urged American Zionists last night to launch "an ideological offensive" to increase their influence in American Jewish life.

A train fire combined with a freakish track accident injured eight firemen and delayed about 55,000 passengers on the New York Central and New Haven systems last night at the peak of the homebound rush. A later breakdown extended the delays to seven hours.

MIAMI BEACH, March 13 -- Seating was not segregated tonight at the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight championship fight -- a condition on which Patterson had insisted before signing to defend his title in the Southern site.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13 -- A week-long effort, led by the United States, to avoid or at least defer acrimonious debate in the General Assembly and to shorten the prospective agenda virtually collapsed today.
ST. LOUIS, March 13 (UPI) -A St. Louis taxicab drivers union was fined $1,000 today on a charge of contributing union funds to the 1956 election campaign of Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon.
United States imports fell in January to the lowest point in nearly two years.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg warned yesterday that an economic upturn would not result in an immediate betterment of the nation's "grave unemployment problem."

PARIS, March 13 -- The dollar and the pound sterling were a little healthier on European exchanges today. The dizzy spell following the revaluation of the Deutsche mark and the guilder appeared to be wearing off.
ALBANY, March 13 -- The Rockefeller Administration bill providing for a $40,000,000 expansion of medical care for the needy aged sailed through the Assembly today.
A PRESCHOOLER recently scrutinized a picture of Charles A. Lindbergh's plane "The Spirit of St. Louis" and asked his father, "What's wrong with this plane?"

A five-week study of the life insurance business in the United States was begun here yesterday by a group of Japanese business men. The group is headed by Kiyoshi Matsuki, managing director of the Yasuda Mutual Life Insurance Company of Tokyo.
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, March 13 (Reuters) -- New Zealand moved into position today to clinch an unofficial cricket test series against an English team.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (AP) -- General Electric Company announced today it would spend about $30,000,000 instead of the previously announced $14,000,000 for its space technology center in nearby Valley Forge, Pa.
Soviet astronomers have observed evidence that they believe shows the composition of the Venus atmosphere to be similar to that of the earth.
The defense lawyer for Herman F. Marks, former executioner for Fidel Castro, said yesterday he would seek a writ of habeas corpus in Federal Court to gain Marks' release from detention.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 13 -- The central Government regards the outcome of the conference of Congolese leaders in the Malagasy Republic as a victory and a return to unity for the Congo.

The Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex., who are seeking to wrest control of the Alleghany Corporation from its chairman, Allan P. Kirby, yesterday were pledged the support in their fight of Abraham M. Sonnabend, an old Kirby foe.

PARIS, March 13 -- Glass skyscrapers, concrete slabs of apartment buildings, satellite cities, new schools, hospitals and traffic speedways, enlarged green spaces and all the other elements of a modern capital will be the Paris of 1970 if the Government has its way and enough money.

LONDON, March 13 -- The British Commonwealth elected the new Republic of Cyprus as as its twelfth member today, but then the Prime Ministers' conference fell into bitter dispute over the continued membership of South Africa.
The winners of the American Library Association's John Newbery and Randolph Caldecott Medals for the most distinguished children's books published in 1960 were named yesterday.

The Duke of Windsor, fresh from a posh dinner party, and Dave Rosenthal of the Bronx, who still had heartburn from a quick orangeade, sat 100 rows apart at Madison Square Garden last night and watched two plebeian types smack each other around a closed-circuit television screen.

Several New York hotels and office buildings were decked for Christmas yesterday and retailers milled about them checking 1961 lines of toy manufacturers. Attendance and selling at the fifty-eighth annual American Toy Fair, which opened for a ten-day run, was exceptionally good, producers said.

Conflicting views on Government subsidy for the theatre were expressed by Robert E. Griffith and Harold S. Prince, members of the successful Broadway producing team, at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk in Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Forty-fourth Street.
DALLAS, March 13 (AP) -- A Ford Falcon maintained its lead after 1,407 miles today in the Class A Division of the Mobilgas economy run by averaging 33.69 miles per gallon.
The Humane Society of New York's hospital and free clinic for animals will benefit from the thirteenth annual Spring Frolic, to be held in the Pierre's Bailrocin on April 14.

ROME, March 13 -- A decree by Pope John today changed the status of the suburbicarian dioceses -- the seven old episcopal sees nearest Rome that are traditionally in charge of the highest-ranking Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address by President Kennedy at a White House reception tonight for Latin-American diplomats:

TORONTO, March 13 (Canadian Press) -- Don Ross of Toronto won a ten-round, unanimous decision over Joey Durelle of Baie Ste. Anne, N.B., at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight in a fight billed as a welterweight elimination.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- Merryman II remained the 10-1 favorite tonight to win the Grand National Steeplechase March 25 for the second straight year. Bookmakers left the odds unchanged in a callover at the Victoria Club.

Is it not ungallant of James Reston to suggest that the Roman Catholic Bishops retreat from their just stand on the grounds that it interferes with the general welfare? One-seventh of the elementary and secondary school children of the country is not an insignificant segment of the general school population.

A new electronic computer data processing service for back-office accounting of smaller brokerage houses was announced yesterday by the Service Bureau Corporation. The organization is a wholly owned subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Windows have been features of architectural design since earliest times and many strange and remarkable uses have been made of them for decoration, ventilation and illumination.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 13 -- The rescue of a ramshackle Revolutionary War building from bulldozers was proposed tonight to the Pleasantville Village Board.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) --President Kennedy told Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin today that the United States was determined to preserve the freedom of the Communist-encircled city.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -President Kennedy will ask Congress tomorrow to authorize a $1,000,000 purchase of oral poliomyelitis vaccine to be held in reserve by the United States Public Health Service for emergency use in police epidemics.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The world's biggest trading partners are meeting for their sixth annual review of trade and economics.

City Council President Abe Stark ruled himself out of consideration yesterday as a possible candidate for Brooklyn Borough President in the event John Cashmore decides not to stand for re-election this year.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Miss Loula B. Lasker, New York philanthropist, established through her will a $300,000 trust fund for graduate studies in housing and city planning.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 13 (AP) -- Government sources expressed surprise tonight at President Kennedy's references to the Dominican Republic in his speech to Latin-American diplomats in Washington.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 13 -The Yankees were sharp today. It took them only a couple of minutes to see right through the Minnesota Twins' label on the opposition.
TRENTON, March 13 -- The Assembly voted and sent to the Senate today a bill that would increase the minimum range of public school teachers' salaries from $3,200 to $6,200 to $3,800 to $7,800.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- At President Kennedy's request, each Government department is now giving him twice-weekly reports on its current problems and impending decisions.
ALBANY, March 13 -- The bill validating the sale of a New York City site to the Consolidated Edison Company squeaked through to final passage in the Senate today by one vote.

HONG KONG, March 13 -Communist China rejected tonight President Kennedy's statement that Peiping's hostility toward the United States was responsible for the two countries' failure to agree on an exchange of newsmen.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Attorneys for James R. Hoffa contended today that a grand jury that indicted the labor leader on a charge of mail fraud had been improperly selected. They called on Federal District Judge Joseph P. Lieb to dismiss the case.

JERUSALEM, March 13 -A million-dollar repository for archaeological finds that shed new light on the Bible or ancient Middle East history is to be established here, President Itzhak Ben-Zvi announced today.
LOS ANGELES, March 13 -Richard M. Nixon's affiliation with the law firm of Adams, Duque Hazeltine, was announced here today.

MIAMI BEACH, March 13 -- Floyd Patterson knocked out Ingemar Johansson in the sixth round of their scheduled fifteen-round fight for the heavyweight championship of the world tonight. The titleholder, floored his Swedish rival with two smashing rights to the jaw and Referee Bill Regan counted 10 over Johansson.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The United States Government seemed today to have mixed feelings about the agreement of Congolese leaders to replace the Congo Republic with a confederation of states.

Avco Corporation and twelve electric utilities announced yesterday that they will spend $1,200,000 this year in further work on a new method of generating electricity. BOSTON, March 13 (AP) -- Union employes of the New Haven Railroad will march on the State House Wednesday to urge legislative tax relief for the railroad, but train service will not be affected.

CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- The useful life of a brood mare is only ten years, the United States District Court ruled today. The decision was worth $76,052 to a race horse breeder.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Kennedy set forth tonight a ten-point, ten-year economic and social development program for Latin America to meet the challenge of "a future full of peril, but bright with hope."

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr said yesterday that the department would move tomorrow to reinstate a formal complaint against the Gaslight Cafe that failed in Municipal Term Court last Thursday because a department officer's signature was missing.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- A federation of farm organizations and a multibillion-dollar Federal rural housing program were proposed today at the National Farmers Union convention.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -Three United States Senators today urged prompt Congressional approval of a compact for development of the Delaware River basin.

The Broadway Maintenance Corporation moved yesterday in Queens Supreme Court to restrain the city from canceling an $800,000-a-year parking-meter contract.

A feeling of keen satisfaction exists among the City Center officials who were instrumental in offering the civic playhouse as a haven for foreign troupes. Their visits have proved not only artistically satisfactory, but also mutually profitable.

The United States Rubber Company announced yesterday price increases of 5 per cent on first-line passenger tires and 2 1/2 per cent on highway-type truck tires. The increases are effective April 1.

At last we have a President who demonstrates some real awareness of the billboard nuisances. In his message to Congress of Feb. 28 he reminded the nation that our highways were not created to be a present to outdoor advertisers but a means of getting around and of seeing the country.

Late-winter snow flurries fell in the metropolitan area yesterday, but by nightfall the snow had turned to a mixture of sleet and rain. The Weather Bureau said the rain would stop today, with the temperature rising to about 50 degrees.

Brendan Behan will not be an invited guest in the St. Patrick's Day parade this Friday, parade officials said last night. The Irish playwright had announced as he arrived on the Queen Elizabeth yesterday afternoon that he would march in the parade as an honorary member of the Gaelic Society of Fordham University.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13 -- The United States challenged South Africa today to assure the United Nations that it would abide by an expected decision of the International Court of Justice on the administration of South-West Africa.
The out-again-in-again position of the New York entry in the new National Bowling League was "in" last week. The club owners hope it remains that way.
With advertisers keeping a careful eye on the national economic trend, Marplan, the research division of Interpublic Inc., about to issue a cautious report called "The Case for Early Recovery."

A HAVEN for at-home fashions for cool spring evenings is the Phoenix Pan American Shop at 793 Lexington Avenue. Ankle-length heavy cotton skirts from Mexico are as bright as any fire burning on the hearth.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 13 -- Maritime unions will seek a new approach to the allocation of operational subsidies for the American merchant marine, a labor leader said here today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Pied d'Or, the odds-on favorite, closed strongly and captured the featured seventh race at Gulfstream Park today. Matthias finished second with Alhambra third.

MIAMI BEACH, March 13 -- Miles of mink moved through Miami Beach and by twilight Convention Hall flickered with diamonds on sun-tanned flesh. It had been a gorgeous day in the 80's -- ideal for swimming, drinking or just lolling under a palm tree awaiting the moment when two young men would climb into the ring and attempt to massacre each other for money -- and a vacation.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 13 (AP) -- Belinda Lee, 26 years old, a British actress, was killed today in an auto crash, the California highway patrol reported.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Ceremonies commemorating the 100th anniversary of the start of the Civil War are embroiled in a racial controversy.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Factory employment, which is the most severely hit in any recession, continued to fall sharply in February, but total employment and unemployment were not significantly up or down, the Labor Department reported today.

FACED with the difficulty of raising annual scholarship funds, one group of inventive parents came to grips with the problem and turned it into an art show. That was fourteen years ago. THE flowers that bloom in the spring have been anticipated in Hattie Carnegie's new custom-order collection. Magnificent floral prints, pulsating with color, highlight a vibrant collection notable for its soft and feminine ways.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to appropriate promptly the full $500,000,000 it authorized last September for a Latin-American "social progress fund."

Myles J. Ambrose, executive director of the Waterfront Commission, yesterday urged public as well as business support of measures before the New York and New Jersey Legislatures that would increase the powers of the bi-state agency.
