YONKERS, March 14 -- Although the barn area at Yonkers Raceway was not to be opened officially until tomorrow morning, there were seventy standardbred horses on the grounds today. The harness-racing season will get under way here Monday night.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- More taxes to keep the Federal superhighway building program on schedule were urged today by a battery of Kennedy Administration officials, who said that operators of heavy trucks should pay a larger share of the cost.
BRING that camera in a little closer. Now, friends, we want you to meet the new director of the United States Information Agency. Ed, look this way, please, and stop scowling.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The Democratic minority in the state Senate today frustrated a move designed to assure the election of Republican supervisors in White Plains.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- The chairman of the Massachu setts Legislature's Joint Committee on Transportation said today the I.C.C. had advised him there would be no basic change in train service if the New Haven went bankrupt.
Riding behind cargo bins might not be a particularly chic or luxurious way to fly to Europe. But it would be attractively inexpensive.

The Fire Department and the New Haven Railroad issued conflicting statements yesterday on whether there had been an hour's unnecessary delay in restoring service after Monday night's train fire in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Following is the text off a message from President Kennedy to Congress on Latin-American aid:
Prices of most United States Government obligations and other prime-debt securities moved slightly downward yesterday in inactive trading.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Administration forces in the Senate won a narrow but important victory today that virtually assures passage of the $393,000,000 Depressed Areas Bill.
TRENTON, March 14 -- The State Highway Department received bids today to restore the state's only covered bridge and to build a fieldstone one next to it.

MIAMI BEACH, March 14 -- George M. Weiss, who stepped down as general manager of the New York Yankees last October today was appointed president of the unnamed New York Metropolitan Baseball Club. The new club will begin operations in the National League next season.

Opposition to Federal aid to private and church schools was expressed yesterday by a leading Protestant, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling of New York City and Philadelphia. Dr. Poling, a Reformed clergyman, is the editor of The Christian Herald, a monthly nondenominational magazine published here.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Navy said today that when a United States warship is in a foreign port, in South Africa or any place else, "all officers and men are granted liberty with no discrimination whatsoever in regard to race, color or creed."

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Prices of old-crop soybeans futures worked steadily higher almost from the start of trading today and finished with the limit net gain of 10 cents a bushel allowed for a single day on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The House of Representatives approved and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing President Kennedy to make Dwight D Eisenhower a five-star General of the Army again.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 14 -- The sister team of Mrs. M. Scott Carrott of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. J. Newton Hunsberger of Philadelphia scored in straight games today in the opening of the United States women's squash racquets doubles championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

NOBODY knows just what makes a writer. But judging by their autobiographies most writers discovered the joy and excitement of books as children, and many of them were blessed with at least one remarkable parent. Their imagination captured by literature and their experience enriched by intimate contact with an interesting example of human personality, such children often grew up to be writers by some sort of natural right.

DETROIT, March 14 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman scored three goals in the first fourteen minutes of play and scored again in the closing minutes to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-2 victory over the New York Rangers at Olympia tonight.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher said last night that he would resign as president of City College if the Legislature did not establish a City University.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 14 -- The newly constituted Congo confederation demanded formally today that the United Nations halt the reinforcement of the international force in the Congo by Indian troops expected to arrive shortly.

TUNIS, March 14 -- A spokesman for the Algerian Provisional Government said tonight that the war with France was still going on. This declaration appeared to be a response to French pressure for an immediate cease-fire in advance of formal peace negotiations.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement read by Msgr. Frederick G. Hochwalt, director of the Education Department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, at a Senate subcommittee hearing today on the Administration's education aid bill:
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Administration urged the Supreme Court today to step into the problem of unequal state legislative districts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14 -- Belgium charged today that 2,000 Europeans had fled Kivu Province in the Congo in the last seventy-five days because the United Nations had failed to keep order there.

Dr. Albert B. Sabin, a primary developer of oral polio-myelitis vaccine, expressed disappointment yesterday at the White House plan to order $1,000,000 worth of the vaccine as a reserve against epidemics.
A. and D. Harrison, Inc., has bought the property at 305 to 315 West Thirteenth Street in Greenwich Village from the Three Hundred Five West Thirteenth Realty Corporation.

Basketball stars recently elected all one-thing-or-another performed for the most part as advertised at Madison Square Garden last night during the opening round of Eastern regional competition in the National Collegiate tournament.

The New York World's Fair of 1964-65, stressing the international aspect of its $500,000,000 venture, announced proudly yesterday that Morocco had become the twenty-fifth Government to sign up for the fair.
Twelve hours before Arnold Schuster was shot to death in 1952, a threatening note was found under the door of the clothing store at 5507 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, where he worked with his father.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- Gilbert Dewart, a United States glaciologist, left the south polar research station at Mirny yesterday on his way home after completing his program of studies with the Soviet Antarctic expedition.
Mayor Wagner will meet tomorrow with officials of five other large cities to plan a campaign for more state aid for education.

ST. LOUIS, March 14 (AP) -- Universal Match Corporation of St. Louis announced today an agreement for a merger with Universal Controls, Inc., of New York, which was canceled last January, has been reinstated. Universal Match would be the surviving corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A threatened boycott by members of an electrical workers union against the installation of Japanese electronic parts has been suspended for ninety days.
BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following reports and weather forecast today:
Patrons have been announced for the March 24 benefit performance of the Vienna Choir Boys at Town Hall.

The noted Polish Communist philosopher Adam Schaff has obviously entered ground that is dangerous and treacherous for any Marxist in his latest writing. Rather belatedly, M. Schaff has discovered that there is a gap in Marxism. It has nothing to say about the "meaning of life," about the fate of the individual in the face of the mysterious universe.

Ever since 1948 Latin Americans have been reproaching the United States because they received no benefit from the Marshall Plan. Now they have a Kennedy Plan, as broad in scope, as important and potentially costly in what it seeks to do, and like the Marshall Plan it is a response to a desperate need whose satisfaction will benefit the United States as well as the recipients and partners.
Ed Sullivan no sooner announced yesterday that he would say no more on his dispute with Jack Paar than Mr. Paar offered him a full say on his show with no conditions attached.

Wilt chamberlain of Philadelphia broke ten records during the professional National Basketball Association's regular season. Elgin Baylor of Los Angeles and Oscar Robertson of Cincinnati also had a hand in record smashing.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- President Kennedy told Congressional Democratic leaders today he planned to submit his recommendations for farm legislation Thursday.

The Thiokol Chemical Corporation and Baltimore Paint Chemical Corporation are discussing a merger, it was learned yesterday. A spokesman for Baltimore Paint confirmed reports that talks between the two companies had been in progress for the last few weeks. If negotiations should prove successful Thiokol would acquire Baltimore Paint.

THE official and personal designer for the wife of the President of the United States is a counterpart of the royal dressmaker. The present holder of the post is a man who could also perform as a court jester. Oleg Cassini is the dress designer who once sent a model down a runway attired in a hooded dress made of burlap. When the mannequin pulled the hood over her head, potatoes rolled out.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 (UPI) -- Jackie Leonard, a former Hollywood boxing promoter, testified today at the Frankie Carbo conspiracy-extortion trial about pressure brought to bear on him at a Chicago meeting attended by Carbo, Al Weill, the former manager of the heavyweight champion, Rocky Marciano, and a Chicago promoter, Ralph Gambina.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved Edward R. Murrow as director of the United States Information Agency today after some members sparred with him about the agency's mission.

Many persons have asked how it was possible for late-model stock car to set a world record speed average for a continuous 500-mile auto race. All records previous to this year had been made on the two-and-a-half-mile brick and asphalt track at Indianapolis.
The latest translation of the New Testament appeared yesterday to be headed to the top of best-seller lists in the English-speaking world.
The naming of Harry Brandt, motion picture theatre executive and civic leader, as chairman of the Joint Defense Appeal Twentieth Anniversary Campaign was announced yesterday.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 14 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators negotiated the first triple play of the spring season today but it couldn't save their three-game winning streak.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority received bids yesterday on $25,000,000 of serial bonds to finance public works projects.
The Omnibus Banking Law, permitting New York City banks to expand into Nassau and Westchester Counties, was ruled invalid yesterday.

HAVANA, March 14 -- Premier Fidel Castro threatened today to set up a Puerto Rican government in exile and exile governments for all Latin-American countries that opposed his revolution. He also indicated that Cuba would promote revolutions in retaliation against United States "aggressions."
Production of raw steel during February fell slightly to 6,233,000 tons from the 6,416,004 tons turned out in January, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 14 -- The trend toward fragmentation of the Congo appeared to have spread today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Kennedy has suggested to Premier Khrushchev that formal negotiations on general disarmament be resumed Sept. 11.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14 -- A program to rebuild African education was announced today.

LONDON, March 14 -- The British Commonwealth conference adjourned in a deadlock tonight after the leaders had fought for seven hours over a compromise plan for South Africa to continue as a member in the Commonwealth after it becomes a republic.

Cocoa futures prices soared yesterday after marking time at an eleven-year low for about a week on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices rose 57 to 70 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 935 lots of 30,000 pounds each, the fifth largest this year.

Plans were announced Yesterday for an initial public offering of shares of Commonwealth International and General Fund, the fourth member of the Commonwealth group of funds. The offering will be made on April 12 at a price of $12.50 a share.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. is slated for a series of short-term special assignments rather than a full-time job in the Kennedy Administration.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 14 -- The International Maritime Workers Union, formed by the nation's two leading seaman's unions to organize American-owned ships flying "flags of convenience," won continued life today.

LONDON, March 14 -- Stock market prices again moved irregularly here today. Industrials were helped late in the session by the February trade figures. The steels reversed yesterday's trend by finishing higher, and electrical and engineering shares responded to selective demand.
Injuries in city traffic last week totaled 818 persons, the Police Safety Bureau announced yesterday. This was down from the comparable 1960 week, when 862 persons were injured.

ATHENS, March 14 -- Modern Greek history is almost as studded with men on horseback that of ancient Greece was featured by draped statues of Athena. Even since World War II, two Generals and one Admiral have headed governments.
The City Council amended its Charter-revision bill yesterday to remove a provision that would have delayed the submission of a new Charter to the voters until 1962 at the earliest.

Stocks declined yesterday, returning to the levels of mid-February. The drop was the fifth in the last six trading sessions. The decline was orderly and moderate, lowering aggregate market value by less than one-half of 1 per cent.

The labor dispute and strike threat at the Hanford atomic products operation on the Pacific Coast are giving a revealing test of the labor relations policies of the Kennedy Administration -- one which also raises some leading questions for future answers.
Mayor Wagner charged again last night that the Legislature had failed in its duty to the city.

RAHWAY, N.J., March 14 -- Beginning Thursday, the speed limit for heavy trucks on Route 1 between Rahway and Edison will be reduced to forty-five miles an hour, the State Highway Department announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee deferred action today on the emergency unemployment aid bill to give members a chane to draft amendments.

As operator of the York Playhouse in the off-Broadway area, Warner LeRoy has produced three plays there and directed two of them. Having gained all this know-how, Mr. LeRoy finds himself ready and eager to join the Broadway producing fraternity.

TRENTON, March 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner moved today to get under way nearly $300,000,000 in state and local governmental construction in an effort to improve New Jersey's economy and reduce unemployment.
Six former insurgents and a Negro have been added to the Bronx County Republican executive committee in a move to revitalize the party organization there in line with Governor Rockefeller's wishes.
A strike of 800 lighter captains in the port on April 5 appeared likely yesterday.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The State Senate today unanimously approved a bill outlawing the use of lie detectors in the screening of job applicants or as a condition for continuing employment.
The Nature Conservancy has announced the appointment of Walter S. Boardman, former superintendent of schools of Oceanside, L.I., as its executive director.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 14 (AP) -- George Alpert said today that proposals for reorganizing the debt-ridden New Haven Railroad under the Federal Bankruptcy Act were "just nonsense."

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- A representative of the Corp of Engineers said today that an active conservation program was needed now in the Delaware River basin if industry and about 21,000,000 residents were to avoid a water shortage within ten years.
Two midgets were arrested yesterday morning for walking under a subway turnstile.

Nine major musical organizations, nearly a dozen major soloists and more than two dozen composers will be represented at the second Inter-American Music Festival in Washington from April 22 to April 30.
A system for dealing with grievances by policemen was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy. The Mayor said it was "long overdue."
OUT of the life and works of Oscar Wilde and out of his own sympathies and dramatic skills Micheal MacLiammoir has created a vivid and memorable evening in the theatre.

Eversharp, Inc., announced yesterday that its president, Patrick J.R. Frawley, had increased his share ownership in the company to about 13 per cent. The increase was effected through a series of security exchanges and sales with the Imperial Trust Company of Quebec, which functions largely as a holding company for R. Howard Webster, his family and associates.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The United States leadership of the Roman Catholic Church registered its opposition today to separate legislation authorizing loans for private schools.
In his letter published March 8 Corliss Lamont objects to the fact that Castro's regime is called Communist.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- New Orleans port interests supported today a petition by Seatrain Lines, Inc., that is seeking to force more than 100 railroads to publish joint water-rail rates on some types of traffic moving between the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.
OTTAWA, March 14 (Canadian Press) -- Trans-Canada Air Lines reported today a loss of $2,607,350 on its 1960 operations, the first deficit in ten years for the publicly owned airline.

Two more volume will be added to Indiana University's Civil War centennial Series on April 12, the centennial of the firing on Fort Sumter, bringing the total to twenty-one. The new ones are "Prologue to Sumter" and "Soldier Life in the Union Confederate Armies." both edited with introductions by Philip Van Doren Stern.
After twelve years, a distinguished American composer stepped into the movie spotlight yesterday.
The Walden School Scholarship Fund will benefit from "Saturday Night at Ten," a program of music and drama, at the school's auditorium, 1 West Eighty-eighth Street, on Saturday.
The repeal of "oppressive" laws that dissuade Americans from joining or supporting the Communist party will be one of the party's goals this year, Elizabeth Gurley Flynn said yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 14 (AP) -- Robert A. Peak and Virgil W. Smith were committed today to two to fourteen years in prison in the original Indiana highway scandal trial of 1957.

A new non-resin textile finish said to be far superior to present treatments for wash-and-wear items will be used in the fall line of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation's white broadcloth shirts. The finish, developed by the General Aniline and Film Corporation in conjunction with Van Heusen and called Ganalok, will be guaranteed for the life of the shirts.

The proposal that Representative Abraham Multer made, suggesting a change in the term of office of the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board so that it will coincide with that of the President, is worthy of sincere consideration."

DENVER, March 14 -- The national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League continued here today with the second of nine rounds in the Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four contest this afternoon and the final round of the three-session national open mixed pair contest tonight.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 -- Little Alvin has stepped boldly into Stoneham Forest armed with wit, patience and quiet guile.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Kennedy praised the committee for International Economic Growth today for its work over the last three years in enlarging public understanding of international economic problems.
Following is the text of an order issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy establishing grievance machinery for the Police Department.

When Aksel Schiotz completed Schubert's "Die Winterreise" last night at Town Hall, the audience burst into applause. Then, as the applause continued, people began to stand up. By the time the Danish haritone returned for his seventh bow the whole audience was standing and many were cheering.

This week will mark the start of an unprecedented effort by the Weather Bureau, in cooperation with several other Government agencies, to study tornadoes and other severe local squalls and better to forecast their coming. The constant threat of these storms in the season just beginning, and the devastation caused by them when they strike can't be fully appreciated by most of us who live in the East and haven't been hit by one.

The Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation introduced yesterday what it said was the first of six molecular electronic components that would cut computer costs drastically. The company is a subsidiary of the Fairchild Camera Instrument Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Quota controls on imports of textiles, garments, man-made fiber staple, filaments and yarn were recommended today by a special Senate Commerce subcommittee on textiles.
ROME, March 14 -- A nationwide controversy over a television show ridiculing fascism indicates anew how emotionally Italians still react to reminiscences of the Mussolini regime.
LONDON, March 14 -- The Government has reminded Argentina that the Falkland Islands Dependencies are regarded as British territory.

A Bronx grand jury that has been investigating charges of possible bribery involving nine Bronx inspectors of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity concluded its investigation today. No action was taken against any of the men.

COLLECTING tea cups or demitasse spoons are fairly popular hobbies for women. Mrs. Helen Britt, director of home economics for the Nestle Company, collects cups, too, but hers are quite different. In the first place, she accumulates coffee cups and in the second place she restricts her selections to specimens from the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) reduced the interest yields offered on its assortment of special short-term notes yesterday. The move followed similar reductions by major finance companies.

This year's heavy trading of securities has caused many brokerage concerns to eye financial-district service centers of two big manufacturers of computers. The Wall Street houses are expected to use the centers increasingly in an attempt to cut the stiff clerical overtime costs resulting from forty-three days of New York Stock Exchange turnover of 4,000,000 shares or more.
The Health Commissioner of New York City spoke yesterday of a "drug" that she said could cure half of the present cases of cancer if used correctly.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Government sought more than $12,000,000 in damages today in the first of a series of suits stemming from the electrical antitrust prosecutions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (UPI) -- The Syracuse Nationals beat the Philadelphia Warriors 115 -- 107, in the opener of their five-game National Basketball Association Eastern Division play-off series before 4,391 fans tonight.
A three-for-two split of the common stock of Holt, Rinehart Winston, Inc., was proposed yesterday by the board of directors of the publishing company.
A plea for rapid city and Federal action on low-cost housing in Greenwich Village was issued yesterday by Micove, a civic group.
LONDON, March 14 -- For the second consecutive month Britain's balance of trade has shown an improvement.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- The Barnes Foundation outlined today the details of an arrangement under which the general public will be admitted to its art collection in suburban Merion for the first time.

The Westminster Kennel Club was fined $500 by the American Kennel Club yesterday for its part in the hasty judging that spoiled the best-in-show and best-brace-in-show selections at Madison Square Garden last month.

The Tidewater Oil Company confirmed yesterday that it and the Pan American Petroleum Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), had made a joint bid for the properties and assets of the Honolulu Oil corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The first ocean-going hydrofoil ship will be named the HS -- for hydrofoil ship -- Denison.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 14 -- The appointment of Chief Inspector Andrew N. Kirk as Nassau County Police Commissioner was announced here today by County Executive A. Holly Patterson.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- R.L. Sturges' Reparo, a 66-1 shot, scored a nose victory over August Sun today in the feature at Gulfstream Park before a crowd of 14,632. He paid $135.90, $51.50 and $16.80 for $2 to win.

General Telephone Electronics Corporation plans to spend at least $2,000,000,000 over the next seven or eight years on expansion programs, Donald C. Power, chairman and chief executive officer, told stockholders in the 1960 annual report mailed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The United States and other countries are urgently considering sending increased military aid to the Government of Laos.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today a measure extending the coverage of the state's Disability Benefits Law to concerns and institutions with only one employe.
Prices of the cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points off to 4 points up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.

Nominations for the Swift Stakes -- the opening-day feature at Aqueduct on Monday -- closed at midnight last Monday. The indications are that the number of nominees will exceed eighteen, the number named for the event last year.
PLAINVIEW, Tex., March 14 (AP) -- The Wayland Flying Queens will stay in the air. Wayland Baptist College today decided to retain its girls' basketball team.

MADRID, March 14 (UPI) -- The Moroccan Embassy said today that eleven oil technicians who were kidnapped by nomad raiders from a Sahara camp Saturday, had been found safe by a Moroccan Army patrol. Three are Americans.
ALBANY, March 14 (AP) -- Reports received today by the State Commerce Department:

BOWIE, Md., March 14 (AP) -- Outrunning several candidates for the $30,000-added Governor's Gold Cup to be run on Saturday, Hill-n-Dale Stable's Polarity, who is not eligible for the week-end feature, won the $4,500 Easter Seal Purse today at Bowie Race Course.
The fight for control of Fruit of the Loom, Inc., ended yesterday with the Bates Manufacturing Company yielding to the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14 -- President Janio Quadros has launched a drastic program for economic recovery through sharp curtailment of Government subsidies for essential imports including petroleum and wheat.
MOSCOW, March 14 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev predicted today that the Soviet Union would soon send one of its astronauts into orbit, well ahead of the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14 -- In most European countries consumption of electric power continued to rise consistently in 1959 and up to mid-1960, according to the Economic Commission for Europe. Quarterly statistics for the period show increases up to 13 or 14 per eent, the commission said in its latest review of the field, as compared witch the corresponding months a year earlier.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 14 -- Rumania's Finance Minister declared today that his country had no plan to revalue its currency in the wake of the recent Soviet changes in the ruble. He also implied that none of the other Soviet-bloc nations was likely to follow Moscow's lead.

YANKEETOWN, Fla., March 14 -- This little fishing village is along the Withlacoochee River, about three miles from where the river joins the Gulf of Mexico. The village is only a short distance from Crackertown and not far from Red Level.

PARIS, March 14 -- Because the French Government has not satisfied the pay demands of its more than 1,000,000 employes, a substantial number of Parisians went without water and other amenities this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Glen Echo Amusement Park in near-by Maryland decidede today to drop its ban on Negro admissions when it reopens March 31. The management announced that the park would operate "on a completely non-segregated basis for the first time" this spring and summer.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Canada has assured the United States that the new tariff legislation pending in Ottawa is not a strategem to tighten curbs on imports.

MIAMI BEACH, March 14 -- The Hammer of Thor performed an act of sabotage last night. It wrecked the delicately attuned fighting machinery of Floyd Patterson in the first minute of his rousing brawl with Ingemar Johansson before a wildly excited gathering in Convention Hall.
The Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) expects to reduce its capital spending to about $73,000,000 in 1961 from $80,300,000 in 1960, according to its annual report released yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 14 (UPI) -- "Well, gentlemen, it appears somebody goofed."
Blood will be collected by the Red Cross today at City College, 137 East Twenty-second Street.

SEOUL, Korea, March 14 -- Premier John M. Chang sat motionless in a deep chair and talked of his problems: a divided country, unemployment, a staggering economy, an exploding population and too much expectation of better times.

AS the last of its matinee series of the current season, the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy presented a staged reading yesterday of two poems by Conrad Aiken, "The Coming Forth by Day of Osiris Jones" and "The Kid," at the Theatre de Lys.

VALLETTA, Malta, March 14 -- For many centuries the island fortress of Malta has stood astride the main sea route into the western Mediterranean, barring the path of Turks and Germans, Italians and French.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board awarded two long-contested transcontinental air routes over the Southern United States to National Airlines and Delta Airlines today.

LOUISVILLE, March 14 (AP) -- John Turner sparked a fading Louisville attack in the last half tonight and led the Cardinals to a 76-70 victory over Ohio University in the first round of the National Collegiate Mid-East regional basketball tournament.
General Electric and Westinghouse announced yesterday that they would defend the suits against them.

Earnings of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the three months ended on Jan. 31 showed a slight increase from the level of the fiscal 1960 period, despite a decline of almost $6,000,000 in sales, the company reported yesterday.
John Patrick (Jack) Rohan was named head basketball coach at Columbia yesterday. He is the fifteenth man to fill the post.
The $1,000 National Book Awards were presented here yesterday to William L. Shirer, journalist and historian; Conrad Richter, novelist, and Randall Jarrell, poet.
A one-cent American postage stamp issued in 1901 for the Pan-American Exposition brought $1,200 yesterday amid the tradition pencil-twitching, head-bobbing bidding system of philatelic auctions.
MILWAUKEE, March 14 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg told a meeting at the Milwaukee City Hall today that economic recovery was a bipartisan and nonpartisan task.

Paperboard production rose in the week ended last Saturday to 323,093 tons from 316,648 the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. Last week's figure was the highest reported this year.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The United States Judicial Conference recommended to Congress today the creation of ten Federal judgeships in addition to the fifty-nine it recommended last year.

Classwork for nearly 4,000 high school boys and girls here alternates with taking care of hospital patients or working in Wall Street offices, printing shops or behind the scenes in department stores.
Three changes in cast provided a fresh-looking "Aida", at the Metropolitan Opera last night.

LONDON, March 14 -- Henry Houghton, a civil servant who is accused of having conspired to violate the Official Secrets Act, offered to "turn Queen's evidence" if he did not have to stand trial. This was disclosed today by the chief detective who arrested him.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- The thirty-three-member House Republican Policy Committee, in a challenge to President Kennedy, threw its support today behind a conservative minimum-wage bill sponsored by Republicans and Southern Democrats.
Some tickets still remain for the Roman Revel, a dinner dance to he held Sunday in the Columns of the Savoy Hilton as a benefit for the Retarded Infants Services.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14 -- The Soviet Union has made a counter-proposal to a United States suggestion that the disarmament debate at the current session of the General Assembly be kept as brief as possible.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A sudden, unexpected population explosion among Alaska red salmon and the winter's heavy snowfall here figured in requests to Congress by President Kennedy today for $136,000,000 of supplementary funds for the 1961 and 1962 fiscal years.
Canticum Musicum's Carnegie Recital Hall program last night ranged over no fewer than four centuries.
MIAMI BEACH, March 14 -- Floyd Patterson said today that he would not fight Sonny Liston until he was convinced that the Philadelphia heavyweight was free of questionable connections.
THE National Broadcasting Company took a look at state legislatures, their problems and their weaknesses in a revealing one-hour report on Channel 4 last night.
The letter from Max M. Turshen published March 9 incorrectly attributes to me certain "admissions" that make it necessary to correct the public record in these matters.

Events today: "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Robert Gerle, violinist, and Albert Puller, harpsichordist, Town Hall, 8:30; Nathalie Boshko, violinist, and Vladimir Padwa, pianist, Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifth-third Street, 8; Jack Ossewaarde, organist, St. Bartholomew's Church, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Kennedy said today the United States would return to the Geneva negotiations for a ban on nuclear testing with proposals that could lead to a safe and fair treaty. The President declared in a statement that the United States was "determined to do all that is possible to conclude a safeguarded agreement on a sound and equitable basis."
PARIS, March 14 -- The strike of the eighty-member chorus of the Paris Opera has entered its seventh week and has reduced the program to a series of concerts, ballets and operatic excerpts.

AFTER an absence of two months, the New York City Ballet returned to the City Center last night and picked up exactly where it left off. You would never know it had been away. No opening night fol-de-rol, no novelties, no nervousness; just a cozy sort of homecoming, with a house full of friends and family.

This choler is brought on by the gentleman's bland over-simplification of the pros and cons of T.V.A. debated endlessly for twenty-five years by well-informed people on both sides of the argument.
The New York City Nursing Home Association yesterday appointed Theodore Charnas coordinator of a program aimed at self-regulation.

Reynolds Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange and other security exchanges, announced yesterday that it was paying an Easter bonus of one week's salary to all clerical employes who had been with Reynolds since Oct. 1, 1960.

After an intermission to enable the Kennedy Administration to review the issues involved, discussions are about to be resumed on the question of disarmament. Debate will begin in the United Nations General Assembly, where the Soviets still insist on Premier Khrushchev's illusory proposal for total disarmament in four years, without either adequate controls or a peace settlement.

A leading dealer in commercial paper announced a cut of one-eighth percentage point yesterday on the interest rate on these unsecured obligations of industrial and finance companies sold in the open market.

The Moore commission has approved a long-range plan that it says would make possible an increase in the city's capital spending while gradually reducing the debt.

JERSEY CITY, March 15 -- Last-minute adjustments made today in Jersey City's 1961 budget proposals resulted in a cut in the anticipated property tax increase.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- There is an intriguing flavor in the appointment of George Weiss as the president of the freshly minted baseball team that will represent New York in the National League next season.

The Duro-Test Corporation, maker of electric light bulbs and electronic equipment, reported yesterday that sales and earnings in the six months ended on Jan. 31 were above those of the 1960 period. Sales climbed to $8,275,422 from $7,643,394, while earnings rose to $306,494, or 97 cents a share, from $207,606, equal to 65 cents a share.

Shelagh Delaney, the Lancashire girl who became a success at 19 with her first play, "A Taste of Honey," and an international figure now at 22, held her first American news conference yesterday.

Mayor Wagner signed a local law yesterday for the licensing and regulation of automatic coin-operated public laundries.

Some 7,000 years before Christ, man first began to use textiles as we know them today. Commodity futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on New York Exchanges. Potatoes, cocoa, copper and sugar rose; hides, cottonseed and soybean oils declined, and price movements for lead, rubber, wool and coffee were mixed.

A downward drift in prices prevailed yesterday in all parts of the market for gilt-edge debt investments except in Treasury bills. In the bill list demand and supply were in equilibrium in an active and broad trading session.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, direct beneficial owner of more than 10 per cent of the outstanding common stock of the General Cable Corporation, has reduced its holdings in the company.

Mrs. Blanche Reeg of Wantagh, L.I., who shows her own Scottish terriers, said yesterday that an amateur handler could be as good as a professional. The requirements are the right dog and willingness to devote the time and work needed.

Four popular musicals will be revived at the City Center at the customary bargain prices ($1.95-$3.95) prevailing there. "Show Boat" will open the season on April 12. It will be followed by "South Pacific," April 26; "Porgy and Bess," May 17, and "Pal Joey," May 31.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Jacques Chaban-Delmas, Speaker of the French National Assembly, advised the Kennedy Administration today that France and other allies should be consulted in advance on major policy decisions affecting East and West.

LONDON, March 15 -- Britain has embarked on an ambitious new official publishing venture to tell her story abroad more effectively.

The largest senior high school construction and plant improvement program in the city's history is under way, the Board of Education reported yesterday.
CONCORD, N.H., March 15 (AP) -- A man described as one of the "behind-the-scenes principals" in an alleged $750,000 international stock swindle was sentenced today to three years in prison.

HOUSTON, March 15 (UPI) -- Houston threw a tenacious man-to-man defense against Marquette tonight and swamped the Warriors, 77 -- 61, in the first round of the Midwest regional National Collegiate basketball play-offs.
Common-share earnings of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation ran 40 per cent higher in 1960 than in the preceding year, according to the annual report released yesterday.
The Hertz corporation announced yesterday it had record earnings and sales last year.

The annual award of the Tuition Plan, Inc., was given yesterday to John Hersey, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, for outstanding service to education. His recent novel, "The Child Buyer," dealt with the problem of the gifted child and his place in today's educational system.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Mrs. Laussat Clement and Mrs. Charles Classen, both of Haverford, Pa., began the defense of their United States women's squash racquets doubles championship today with a 15 -- 9, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 9 victory over Mrs. Thomas O'Neil of Philadelphia and Mrs.. Hallet Johnson of Princeton, N.J., at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
WHITE PLAINS, March 15 -- The attempt of a former manager of public housing here to be a Good Samaritan to low-income tenants boomeranged on the tenants today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Senate approved tonight a $394,000,000 program of loans and grants designed to rehabilitate chronically depressed areas. The vote was 63 to 27.

Honolulu, Hawaii, borrowed $5,649,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

LONDON, March 15 -- The Crown produced as exhibits today a collection of cameras and high-powered radio equipment found in a modest suburban house alleged to have been the hub of a spy ring. The exhibits were produced on the third day of a trial of five persons accused of conspiracy to violate the Official Secrets Act.

Finn Larsen of Denmark looked at Carlos Dodsworth Machado of Brazil yesterday and said: "It's frightening." He was referring to a data-processing machine emitting a businesslike hum as it selected 200 prospective jurors for duty, starting next Monday.

The Waterfront Commission won a six-month battle with the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday in its efforts to investigate reports by dock workers of alleged violations of their seniority rights by dock bosses.
Aqueduct, where thoroughbred racing will be presented on Monday, and Belmont Park, where training also is in full swing, buzzed with activity of horses and horsemen yesterday.
The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation yesterday realigned the top management of its chief subsidiary, the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, and picked a new president for itself.

A book on the Nixon-Kennedy debates, to which leading figures in the television industry and the communications field are contributing, is planned for fall publication by Indiana University Press. To be called "The Great Debates," the volume will include the four television talks, discussions of the history, background and political significance of them and four studies on the effects they had on voters.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Kennedy expressed the hope today that the rate of unemployment could be cut to 4 per cent. This is a widely but not universally accepted standard for a satisfactory rate.

The Universal American Corporation has entered into an agreement to acquire the controlling interest in Van Norman Industries, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., March 15 (AP) -- George A. Garrett's Bonzo captured the Federal Purse by three-quarters of a length before 8,779 fans today.

Passage of Governor Rockefeller's "scholar-incentive" plan by overwhelming majorities in both houses of the Legislature is a political victory for the Governor but a setback for those who believe as we do in the absolute separation of church and state in accordance with the New York Constitution.
