A bipartisan appeal for "drastic, emergency action" to provide more state aid to education was made yesterday by Mayor Wagner and the Mayors of Yonkers, Rochester and Buffalo.
Robert Moses declared yesterday the State Power Authority "could produce atomic power 25 per cent cheaper than private companies."
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- A former employe of the Republican National Committee was charged today with stealing campaign contributions mailed to the committee.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- President Kennedy will combat price-rigging by United States business concerns by publicizing identical contract bids to Federal agencies.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Soybean futures gave speculators another good run for their money today in fairly lively dealings on the Board of Trade, but the grains dragged along with scarcely a perceptible trend.
A new breed of pleasure boatman has been created during recent years. For want of a better name, he is known as a "trailer-sailor."

Stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America will be asked to approve reimbursement of directors, officers and other employes for legal expenses "under certain circumstances." The proposal is on the proxy statement for the annual meeting on May 2.

Buffeted by the "wind of change" that is sweeping across Africa, the French Government and the Algerian rebels appear to have achieved a major breakthrough on the road, if not yet to peace, at least to peace talks to end a war which has become an intolerable burden for Algeria, for France and for the whole West.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The Legislature sped toward enactment today a bill incorporating the provisions of the 1960 Omnibus Banking Law and validating actions taken under it.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A Republican task force on how to take more big-city votes away from the Democrats will get down to business here tomorrow.
Ireland will have added reason for celebration this St. Patrick's Day -- rapidly growing industrialization that is bringing new prosperity to the "old sod."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 -- The Soviet Union demanded today an immediate session of the General Assembly on the Congo situation.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- The Great Lady Ball, a benefit for St. Mary's and Pineridge Hospitals here, took place tonight in a setting of glitter and gold at the Everglades Club. Dinner tables were set up in the orange Gardens.
The Special Studies Project of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, which has issued six reports on problems and opportunities confronting the United States, may and two more.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The number and scope of the national welfare programs proposed to Congress by President Kennedy in the less than two months he has been in office foreshadow that he will break the Presidential record in this field of government.
PARIS, March 16 -- All good things must come to an end.

COUNT the Phoenix Theatre's new production of Hamlet" one of its distinguished achievements. And give pride of place to a young actor, Donald Madden, and the director, Stuart Vaughan, in the credits for this accomplishment.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 16 -- Connecticut's public libraries are 1,000,000 volumes short of the number needed to meet minimum standards, Raymond C. Hagel said today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A Roman Catholic spokesman assured Congress today that the church claimed no authority to compel its members to support the hierarchy's position in the dispute over Federal aid to education.

MADRID, March 16 (AP) -- Seven Spanish intellectual leaders were acquitted today of charges of having conspired to overthrow the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco. An eighth defendant was sentenced to a year in prison and fined 25,000 pesetas ($400), which means he goes free under a general amnesty.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate gave President Kennedy an important legislative victory tonight as it passed an emergency unemployment compensation bill. The vote was 84 to 4.

MONTREAL, March 16 (UPI) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion scored his fiftieth goal of the season tonight to tie the league record of Maurice Richard as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2.

While world attention has been focused in recent months on the Communist threat to Laos, Communist aggression against neighboring South Vietnam on a larger scale than in Laos has not received much public notice, at least in this country. In fact, warfare now going on between government forces and Communist guerrillas in South Vietnam is the biggest armed conflict anywhere in the world today.

Mayor Wagner's recent announcement that he would undergo an ear operation on Monday has brought a flood of letters to him at City Hall wishing him a speedy recovery. The letters have come from persons in all walks of life.

The election of Janusz Ilinski as chairman and chief executive officer of the Carlyle Hotel was announced yesterday by Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, which operates the hotel.
David Sarnoff, chairman of Radio Corporation of America, said yesterday he would like to help collate the mountains of current medical information into a "national medical clearing house."

An agreement has been reached by Botany Industries, Inc., and the Hat Corporation of America under which Botany would acquire the Weber Heilbroner chain of men's stores and the Greenfield Company, which has similar stores in St. Louis and Clayton, Mo.

CLEVELAND, March 16 (UPI) -- Milton G. McInnes, president of the newly merged Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, said today that the carrier had benefited little from the consolidation in the first quarter of 1961.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 16 -- A contingent of Indian troops landed at Ndjili, the Leopoldville airport, last night and today to join the United Nations force in the Congo.
LONDON, March 16 -- It was obvious to British Ministers and officials today that South Africa's decision to withdraw from the Commonwealth had created more problems than it had solved.

SYRACUSE, March 16 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals scored a 115-114 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors tonight to take a 2-0 lead in the semi-finals of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division play-offs.

This year marks the seventy-fifth anniversary of the beginning of the settlement movement in the United States. University Settlement, the nation's first, still serves its neighbors on Manhattan's lower East Side.

Sidney Schwartz, New York realty investor and syndicator, announced yesterday he had bought the Beverly Hotel at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street, diagonally opposite the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy acted today to permit the entry into the United States of eight Chinese children adopted by seven Chinese-American families. The children are in Hong Kong.

NEITHER international censure nor an assassin's bullets have succeeded in altering the views of Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd, Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa, on racial segregation. Nothing in the story of his tempestuous career indicates that he will be stayed in his intention of taking his country out of the British Commonwealth of Nations, a price he s willing to pay for apartheid.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A space tracking station in California's Mojave Desert has established a clear radar contact with the planet Venus, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk are fully engaged in a calculated effort to make water flow uphill. In one of the bolder experiments of the Administration, they are trying to reverse the erosion of the State Department's authority that has taken place over the last twenty years and give the department control over all elements of foreign policy.

As chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee which recommended, and as sponsor of, the bill now before the Governor with respect to amendment of New York State's adoption laws, I am constrained to answer a letter published March 15.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Harvard University will soon receive a $1,000,000 trust estate to train young men for Government service.
Prices of cotton futures moved 2 points off to 6 up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near months were unchanged.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The Assembly reversed itself today and approved Mayor Wagner's plan to build an $18,000,000 baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Mayor Wagner declared today in a statement to the Legislature that proposed amendments to the Condon-Wadlin Law would foment strikes of public employes rather than reduce them.

Foreign governments and central banks sold gold to the United States in the week ended on Wednesday for the first time since July, 1959. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that an $11,000,000 inflow brought the monetary gold stock to $17,384,000,000.
A measure granting tax relief of $1,200,000 a year to the New Haven Railroad was approved in Connecticut yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 -- An investigating commission's report issued today sharply criticized Belgian authorities in the trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.
CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Treasury's surprise proposal to go ahead at this time with a third major advance refunding operation -- one patterned after those introduced to the market last year under the Eisenhower Administration -- caused a lot of discussion in financial circles yesterday but stirred little trading.

The 1961 Brunner Award, an annual $1,000 prize given by the National Institute of Arts and Letters for excellence in architecture, will be awarded to Ieoh Ming Pei, of I.M. Pei and Associates of New York.

Many prominent grownups put the Boy Scouts on the receiving end of a good deed last night. They attended the second annual dinner dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Commodore for the benefit of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America.
" THE LIGHT THAT FAILED," Rudyard Kipling's first novel, emerged as a generally attractive television hour last night on Channel 2's "Family Classics" series.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 -- South Africa was rebuked by the General Assembly today for her policy on South-West Africa.
The Religious Zionists of America indicated yesterday it was considering withdrawal from the American Jewish Congress.

The most important legislation before Congress at this moment -- and the most important that is likely to be before Congress for a long time -- is President Kennedy's triple-barreled proposal for Federal aid to education. The heart of this program is the plan to give approximately $3 billion over the next three years in direct Federal grants to the states to improve their public elementary and secondary schools.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- The development of prefabricated, modular panels that will enable home builders to erect inside and outside walls simultaneously was announced today by the Johns-Manville Corporation.

Earnings of the Gillette Company in the first quarter of 1961 are expected to be about $10,000,000, compared with $8,413,262 in the 1960 period, Boone Gross, president, said at the annual meeting in Boston yesterday.
DETROIT, March 16 -- New car sales in the first ten days of March were 19.1 per cent higher than in the Feb. 1-10 period, but were considerably below those for early March a year ago.

Worcester, Mass., borrowed $3,600,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised on serial bonds maturing from 1961 to 1980. The issue was sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a price of 100.529 for 3 per cent obligations, an interest cost of 2.93 per cent.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $45,000,000 to $49,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $207,000,000 to $637,000,000 from a revised figure a week ago.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Opposition broke out in the House of Representatives today to the Pentagon decision that awarded virtually all space research projects to the Air Force.

Events today: "Elektra," "Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein and Gregory Millar, conductors, Marni Nixon, soprano, Glenn Gould, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Marta Pariente, pianist, Town Hall, 5:45, Carmel Quinn's Irish Festival of Stars, Carnegie Hall, 8; Ars Nova Orchestra, Robert Mandell, conductor, Nancy Chase, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Stoddard Lincoln, harpsichordist, Carnegie Recital Hall 8:30.

The operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group last year had a combined net income of 177,485,000, or $496,958,000, the parent companies announced yesterday. This compared with 175,535,000, or $491,498,000, in 1959.
Faced with the threat of a cargo rate war, three United States airlines agreed yesterday on joint trans-Atlantic rate reductions up to 63 per cent.

LONDON, March 16 -- Ethel Elizabeth Gee, one of the five persons being tried on charges of having violated the Official Secrets Act, took the stand today in her own defense. Her testimony followed completion of the Crown's case.

Eugene B. Mapel, vice president and director of marketing for the Chase Manhattan Bank, yesterday equated marketing morality with enlightened self-interest, and said that dishonest advertising inevitably led to a dishonest business.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- Following are the highlights of President Kennedy's farm message today:
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended March 11 were 9 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

RECENT western storms already have taken a toll of certain food supplies. Adversely affected were shipments of eggs and most meats except beef, but no increased costs have been registered at retail levels. Vegetables and fish also suffered, causing a slight increase in the price of such items as bluefish, cod steak, haddock fillet, eggplant and tomatoes.

IT has been almost two years since the Metropolitan Opera staged Verdi's "Don Carlo." Rudolf Bing revived it in 1950 as his first all-out effort as general manager, and it remains one of the most impressive productions of his regime.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Gov. Michael V. DiSalle of Ohio has been selected by President Kennedy for a two year term on the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.
LONDON, March 16--South Africa sought today to maintain her economic links with the British Commonwealth despite her decision to withdraw as a member.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16--George Weiss took issue with the Yankees today over a statement made yesterday by Dan Topping. In it, the Yankee president maintained that if "a conflict of interests" arose between Weiss and the Yankees, Commissioner Ford C. Frick would have to make the final decision.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 16 -- South Africans seem to be recovering slowly from the first shock of hearing that their country would not be a member of the British Commonwealth after May 31 when the Republican Constitution becomes effective.

DENVER, March 16 (AP) -- The poised and aggressive St. Lawrence team won the opening game of the National Collegiate hockey tournament tonight, scoring a 6-3 victory over its upstate New York rival, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
Constantine (Cus) D'Amato s conviction last April for failing to answer a subpoena issued by the State Attorney General was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

LONDON, March 16 -- The British Commonwealth, now in the throes of a major crisis, evolved from the British Empire by a process that, if illogical was practical enough to forge a community that girdled the globe and withstood the test of a world war.

LISBON, Portugal, March 16 (Reuters) -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that Portugal viewed with the "greatest apprehension" the United States vote in the United Nations in favor of an inquiry into conditions in the Portuguese territory of Angola in West Africa.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, March 16 -- The heads of tribal areas in the interior continued today to put in their claims to independence within the framework of the confederation announced last Sunday at the Tananarive conference.
WASHINGTON, March 16--The eight-month decline in industrial production came to a virtual halt in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Plans to build a $64,000,000 cement mill in Ravena, N.Y., twelve miles south of Albany, were announced jointly yesterday by the Cerro Corporation and the Newmont Mining Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Informed sources said today that it was by a hurried decision that the United States sided in the United Nations with critics of Portugal's handling of her African territory of Angola.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Commenting on the farm message, Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, predicted that Congress would "take a very long look" at the proposals.

ROME, March 16 -- Pope John XXIII held a secret consistory and a public one today preparatory to the proclamation of a new saint of the Roman Catholic Church. The proceedings centered on Bertilla Boscardi, a member of the Institute of the Teaching Sisters of St. Dorothea at Vicenza, who died in 1922 at the age of 34.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- President Kennedy's farm proposals drew enthusiastic whoops and applause from delegates to the National Farmers Union convention today and quick endorsement from leaders of two of the nation's biggest farm organizations.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- There is the usual flock of rookie "phenoms" cavorting about Florida's major league baseball camps. They'll continue to grab headlines until the established pitchers start firing curves and the established hitters begin to time the ones that don't break sharply enough.

KINGFIELD, Me., March 16 -- Two skiers from the Pacific Coast, Annibale Orsi Jr. of Stockton, Calif., and Ingrid Simonson of Yakima, Wash., handled the unfamiliar terrain of Sugarloaf Mountain like seasoned campaigners today and scored impressive triumphs.

Most commodity futures moved in narrow ranges in dull trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Copper, rubber, potatoes and cottonseed oil rose; hides, the world sugar contract, cocoa and wool declined, and price movements for coffee and domestic sugar futures were mixed.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Following are excerpts from a statement on Federal aid to education made before a House Education subcommittee today by the Rev. Dr. Gerald E. Knoff, executive secretary of the Division of Christian Education of the National Council of Churches:

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Margaret Varner of Wilmington, Del., and Betty Shellenberger of Philadelphia rallied after losing the first two games to reach the semi-final round of the United States squash racquets doubles championship today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

What was billed as a mere double-header looked like four basketball games in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden last night. In each case, last-minute developments turned incipient disaster into success.

FASHIONS styled to cheer as well as to flatter mothers-to-be create a colorful springtime spectrum in Lane Bryant's maternity department. The new collection, designed by Helene Scott and priced from $5 to $40, will be shown to the public at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow on the fourth floor.
The leader of the annual British protest marches against nuclear weapons spurred a drive here yesterday to organize a similar March for Peace the week before Easter.

The St. Patrick's Day parade will step off at Forty-fourth Street at noon today and march up Fifth Avenue to Ninety-sixth Street until sometime after dusk. The avenue's center line has been painted green for the occasion.
The first major increase in years in this country's deep-sea ore fleet is projected in a plan filed with the Federal Maritime Board by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

After the recent period of consolidation, stocks moved ahead smartly again yesterday. It was a broad, general advance in heavy trading. On average, prices on the New York Stock Exchange scored the biggest gain since Oct. 26.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 (UPI) -- Bill Casper of Apple Valley, Calif., and Jack McGowan of Toledo, Ohio, shot eight-under-par 63's today and shared the first-round lead in the $22,500 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 200,435,000 board feet, compared with 196,044,000 board feet the week before, according to reports received yesterday from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 250, 088,000 board feet.

A meteorite that fell in France a century ago, which has just been subjected to modern analysis, has been found to contain chemical compounds closely akin to the chemicals in the living processes of plants and animals on earth.
NORWALK, Conn., March 16 -- The first community college in the state will be opened here this fall under permissive legislation of the General Assembly.

The judicial invalidation of the 1960 omnibus banking law, permitting New York City banks to expand into Nassau and Westchester Counties, and the necessity for second passage a year later to cure procedural defects in enactment are a telling commentary on the confusion that is commonplace in the New York Legislature toward the end of each session.

THE children should have a fine time at the new movie at the Music Hall. It is Walt Disney's "The Absent-Minded Professor" and it opened there yesterday as the main attraction on the spring-vacation program, which includes the annual "Glory of Easter" pageant and a bright stage show.

DETROIT, March 6 (AP) -- Dick Weber of St. Louis salvaged the prestige of the St. Louis Budweisers at the American Bowling Congress tournament today when he took first place in the classic all events and second in the singles of the division.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- A twin-engine turbojet carrying two executives of the Pillsbury Company crashed into a Piper Cub seventy-five feet above the Pompano Beach Airport today. The pilot and co-pilot of the Piper were killed.

The two-story commercial building at 614 to 624 East Fourteenth Street, between Avenues B and C, has been, purchased by an investing client of George Ross, lawyer. It was sold by the 614 East Fourteenth Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by the William K. Langfan Company, broker.

MRS. NELLIE GREVE of Emmeloord, The Netherlands, is like the boy who put his finger in the dike. Last Monday evening, she bought a $3 straw hat in Stern's. The purchase itself is unsignificant, but it may augur the end of the gold outflow.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The United States Public Health Service advised Congress today that it might take six months before the new oral polio vaccine was available for the general public.

A statement made Wednesday by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, in which he advocated Federal aid for both public and private schools, brought expressions of "indignation and disapproval" from a group of citizens' organizations yesterday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 16--South Africa's decision to withdraw from the British Commonwealth brought expressions of shocked regret today from much of the white population and jubilation by African nationalists in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Government will soon abandon its eleven-year-old program of intercepting mail entering the country from behind the Iron Curtain.

Borrowings by businesses at the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City jumped $370,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said the increase was the largest since it began reporting such figures in 1938.

MICHELANGELO, a little man with a broken nose, a ragged beard and a truculent temper, is generally regarded as the greatest artistic genius the world has known. Although he wrote 495 letters that have survived, as well as many poems expressing his tempestuous emotions, and was the hero of numerous contemporary anecdotes, the sources of Michelangelo's genius remain mysterious.

FIFTH AVENUE will not be alone in toeing the green line today. Few parts of the city will be out of earshot of the St. Patrick's Day parade. Third Avenue bars will do record business and even places not normally noted for their green tint will honor the Irish in their own way.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Presidential press conference is getting bigger and noisier all the time and, under Kennedy, is turning into an exercise in physical fitness.
BOSTON, March 16 (AP) -- The New Haven Railroad cannot pay $1,000,000 in 1960 property taxes in time to meet a March 31 appeal deadline, its president, George Alpert, said today.
PARIS, March 16 -- A stalemate has developed among the fifteen member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in their search for a successor to Paul-Henri Spaak as Secretary General.

Four safe deposit boxes in banks here were sealed by the Government yesterday in a move to collect $1,959,179 in wagering and income taxes from Abraham Minker, the reputed gambling overlord of Reading, Pa. The boxes had allegedly been rented under fictitious names by Minker's wife and daughter.

ALBANY, March 16 (AP) -- The Legislature's Committee on Health-Insurance Plans said today that it would conduct hearings throughout the state next fall to determine what the Blue Cross was doing to help keep hospital costs down.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee voted today to create sixty-seven new Federal judgeships.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The Assembly passed by a narrow margin and sent to the Senate today a proposed constitutional amendment to permit the leasing of about 230 acres of forest preserve land for a private ski development in the Catskills.
William S. Ginn, highest-ranking of three General Electric Company executives who recently served jail sentences for illegal rigging of prices and bids, resigned from the company yesterday.

In 1956 Count Rene de Chambrun, a lineal descendant of the Marquis de Lafayette, took possession of his family inheritance, the fifteenth-century chateau of La Grange. There, hidden in one of the tower attics, he found letters, documents and other personal possessions of Lafayette collected by him during the last years of his life.

SITTING by her living-room window Edith Hamilton, age 93, was engrossed in a familiar chore. She was reading galley proofs. They were the proofs of the twenty-eight introductions she has written to the complete works of Plato, which will be published in the Bollinger Series in one volume.
SHANNON, Ireland March 14 -- Six year-old Harumi Suzuki won a prize the other day for singing a song in Irish at her school in Limerick.

The fifth annual young Artists Series, presented this season by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in its Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, was brought to a close last night with an admirable recital by Eric Friedman. The 21-year-old violinist had not given a recital here Since he made his impressive debut in Carnegie Hall four years ago.

THE New York City Ballet really got going last night at the City Center, with a program that could not conceivably have been given by any other company in existence and with a mastery in performance that may also be unique.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy took another step yesterday in an attempt to ease the city's traffic problem.

Four Soviet musicologist who have been inspecting cities, communities and schools in this country since Feb. 26, arrived in New York Wednesday night. They will remain here until their return to the Soviet Union March 26.

Perry Como has decided to carry on. Instead of forgoing a weekly television show, which he once contemplated, he will continue to star on "Music Hall" next season over the National Broadcasting Company network.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Mayor Wagner urged today that city and state agencies be given concurrent jurisdiction over housing discrimination violations in New York City.
Four seats on the New York Stock Exchange were sold yesterday, the largest number for any day since Dec. 30,1952, when four also were sold.
A NEW phase in the evolution of entertainment may have opened last night with a stunning production of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera, "The Consul," on pay-as-you-see television.

MOSCOW, March 16 -- The chief of the Soviet Olympic Committee indicated today that Moscow would push with renewed vigor for the admission of Communist China, North Korea and East Germany into the International Olympics Committee and the Olympic Games.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 -- A switch in tactics as well as policy attended yesterday's decision by the United States to vote with Asian and African nations against its allies on an issue of "colonialism."
A new play, "Not In Our Stars," by Leonard Lee, has caught the fancy of Martin Goodman, who plans to produce it on Broadway next season with the Marquis de la Passardiere.

ONE of the constant, always pleasant surprises is how good certain artists under the black weather of fashionable taste can be at less official moments. For example, Londoners have recently discovered in an exhibition at Burlington House the remarkable quality of Landseer's painterly talents before he was corrupted by money and social success.
The temperature in New York City at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon was 39 or 40, or maybe 42, or even 44 or 45 degrees.
Eight Nobel Prize laureates will gather at Columbia University on April 11 to receive the Alexander Hamilton medals for 1961.
TRENTON, March 16 -- The Port of New York Authority is seeking quick authorization by the New York and New Jersey Legislatures of its plan to take over the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.
TRENTON, March 16 -- A deadlock that has blocked legislation in the state Senate for more than a month is expected to be broken Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Kennedy proposed today that farm production and marketing programs be developed by farmers themselves and by the Agriculture Department, rather than by Congress.
WASHINGTQN, March 16 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's message to Congress today on agricultural problems:
The development of a machine very much like an automatic pinsetter used in bowling was announced yesterday in the interest of speeding up textile output.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 16 -- The familiar look has gone from Route 4 in Fort Lee, and unfamiliar sounds and odors emanate from the meadows over the hills to the west.

Outside a door on the fourth floor of a five-story brownstone on the East Side is a sign reading: "All hardware must be checked here." The visitor turns an old phone, which prompts a pretty girl to peer through a slot in the door. She inquires: "Who sent you?"
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Saudi Arabian Government has told Washington that the United States will have to end its military operations at Dhahran Airfield next year.
GIBSONTON, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- A twenty-two-foot python escaped from its cage at a zoo today and apparently fatally crushed a snake handler in its flight for freedom.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 16 (AP) -- Wittenberg, South Dakota State, Southeast Missouri and Mount St. Mary's won semi-final berths today in the National Collegiate small-college basketball championship.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- A compromise stop-gap feed-grains program for this year was approved by a Senate-House conference committee today over objections of some Republicans.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Merger talks between the Chicago and North Western Railway and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific (Milwaukee) Railroad bogged down today on the question of "who gets what and how much."
Joseph Emanuel, a stock broker, and Peter F. Crosby, convicted on an oil stock swindle, were indicted here yesterday on charges of stealing $700,000 worth of stocks from an 85-year-old widow.
Northwest Orient Airlines has ordered six jetliners from the Boeing Airplane Company at a cost of $36,772,000, including spare parts.

WOMEN often give interior designers major headaches and sometimes drive them into bankruptcy. These are the women who tramp the streets with decorators for days shopping for home furnishings and then never pay for the service -- or women who purchase chairs through a decorator and return them when their husbands do not approve.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 16 -- Moise Tshombe has begun negotiations for a meeting with Antoine Gizenga and Gen. Victor Lundula, leaders of the Communist-backed Congolese administration that has its headquarters in Stanleyville.
LONDON, March 16 -- The British Labor party's civil war entered an explosive phase tonight when five Left-Wing Members of Parliament were expelled from the Parliamentary party.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday announced it was against proposed state laws to create thirty-eight new judgeships unless political deals were barred in the selection of incumbents.
DUBLIN, March 16 (AP) -- Prime Minister Sean F. Lemass predicted tonight that the long and bitter history of Irish partition might soon be over and the divided country united.
The wholesale commodity price index was 86.4 on Wednesday, unchanged from a nine-month high set Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.7 on March 9, 1960.
Consumption of newsprint in this country last month was 5.8 per cent lower than in February, 1960, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON March 16 -- The Atomic Energy Commission took the first step today to separate safety and regulatory functions from its operational and promotional duties.
ALBANY, March 16--A four-year Republican deadlock over the issue of a residence requirement for persons receiving relief payments appeared to have been broken today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 (AP) -- Gina Lollobrigida tonight won a Golden Globe as the world's favorite actress at the annual dinner of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. Two males -- Rock Hudson and Tony Curtis -- tied for the world's favorite actor award.

GREENBELT, Md., March 16 (UPI) -- Thirty-five years ago today, on a farm near Auburn, Mass., a man bearing the derisive nickname of Moony touched a blowtorch to a slender object ten feet high, which he said was a rocket.
In his letter published March A.S.A. East failed to include some pertinent observations and thereby conveyed the idea that South Africa was a rather tolerant country.

The Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex., who have started a proxy contest to wrest control of the Alleghany Corporation from its chairman, Allan P. Kirby, disclosed yesterday their opposition slate of directors for the big holding company.

This is a world in which great power groups and vast populations contend for the mastery of the future. But it is not one of these numerically or geographically great nations that is marching its ceremonial contingents up Fifth Avenue today. The city rejoices to honor a small people, defenseless by today's standards in everything but character and courage, renowned only -- and isn't this sufficient?

Considering the nationalist state of mind, it should not be too surprising that Kwame Nkrumah, President of Ghana, has nonchalantly endorsed the Soviet demand to remove "the question of Hungary" from the U.N. General Assembly's agenda.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The weekly surveys by the rail and truck industries issued today reflected a slight rise in the general economy.

LONDON, March 16 -- Between $400,000,000 and $500,000,000 of the world's stock of monetary gold was lost to speculators and hoarders in last year's "gold rush," according to calculations just made by experts here.
The Universal Oil Products Company had a net income of $3,548,485, or $1.23 each, last year on 2,890,580 shares outstanding, according to the annual report for 1960. Gross revenues were $72,516,716.

" Shadows," one of the few locally made features to attain commercial release without the sponsorship of a major producing company, a distribution commitment or the cooperation of union technicians, has provided a stepping stone toward future film careers for three of its participants.

Joint hemispheric action must be used to bring every one in the New World into the twentieth century, Dr. Arturo Morales-Carrion, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, embellished by a loquacious Leo Durocher, breezed into Al Lang Field today and forthwith did a thorough job on the Yankees.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission issued a provisional operating license today to the Federal space agency for its research and testing reactor near Sandusky, Ohio.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 16 -- The appointment of W. Harry Lister as Nassau County Commissioner of Welfare was announced today by County Executive A. Holly Patterson. Mr. Lister has been Mayor of Rockville Centre since 1945.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 16 -- The "point of no return" is rapidly approaching for the nation's domestic off-shore shipping trades, Senator E.L. Bartlett declared today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Truck lines and labor predicted disaster today if Congress approved President Kennedy's highway tax recommendations.
" THE STORY OF ST. PATRICK" was told in warm and reverent tones last night over WNEW-TV (Channel 5).

PARIS, March 16 -- Last November's decision by the International Bureau of Expositions to endorse the 1962 Seattle Fair and not New York's 1964-65 Fair is irrevocable, the bureau's director said today.

DENVER, Colo., March 16 -- The Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four contest, the principal event in the national championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, entered its seventh and eighth rounds today.

The mother of the late Arnold Schuster testified yesterday that the police had made light of letters and telephone calls threatening young Schuster after he helped capture Willie Sutton, the bank robber.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate ratified today the treaty making the United States a member of the new twenty-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The vote was 72 to 18.
For the third year in a row, Andy Hebenton was voted the Players' Player Award of the New York Rangers hockey team yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- A striking king mackerel snatched rod and reel from the hands of an angler aboard the Little Jewel in the Gulf of Mexico today, but it wasn't the angler's fault.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Kennedy paid tribute today to Italy's contributions to freedom and independence.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 16 -- The Cleveland Indians had a lot of luck last year, but virtually none of it was good.
The Republican Advisory Council of One Hundred set up a planning committee last night to direct an eight-month campaign for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Senate investigators said today a nuclear test ban petition filed by Dr. Linus Pauling had been exploited by Communists as part of "the Kremlin's fraudulent 'peace' offensive."
THE myth of racial superiority wreaks psychological havoc upon white and Negro children alike, a child psychiatrist told an audience made up predominantly of white parents this week.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, March 17 -- A spokesman for the Congolese Government indicated today that it would be two or three weeks before United Nations forces were permitted to return to Matadi, the vital port city on the Congo River.

Isaac Stern, Van Cliburn, Harry Belafonte and the Philadephia Orchestra with its conductor, Eugene Ormandy, will take part in "Carnegie Hall Salutes Jack Benny" at Carnegie Hall on April 3. Mr. Benny will also appear, performing with Mr. Stern in a work for two violins and orchestra.
Sales of the nation's major retail chains rose 2 per cent in February above the level of the 1960 month, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
The fingerprinting of all applicants for school-bus driver will soon be required by the Board of Education.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- The American Medical Association's newspaper compared its fight today against the Administration's medical-care program to the "struggle to prevent the spread of incipient cancer."

A college basketball scandal involving numerous nationally known teams broke here in 1951. In its widespread repercussions, it could be compared to the Chicago "Black Sox" scandal that shook major league baseball in 1919.

Chancellor Adenauer has announced he fears that the Eichmann trial may make the world believe the Nazis represented typical German thinking during their power. Can he hope that the world would believe anything else?
ST. PETERSBURG, March 17 -- The Yankees, who seem to be making an exhaustive study on ways and means of losing ball games, concentrated on doing it in extra innings today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The planning board of the National Security Council recommended to President Eisenhower last June 29 that the Government stop intercepting mail from behind the Iron Curtain. But the Administration took no action.
LONDON, March 17 -- The main European central banks have secretly agreed on a major new experiment in the world monetary system.

LOUISVILLE, March 17 (AP) -- John Havlicek rescued Ohio State in the closing seconds tonight as the undefeated Buckeyes edged Louisville, 56 -- 55, in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate Mideast regional basketball tournament. Jerry Lucas, Ohio State's All-American, as held to 9 points.
NEW DELHI, India, March 17 -- Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman held out strong hope tonight for increased Western economic assistance to the under-developed countries of Asia.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that a Brooklyn "bishop" had sent out women dressed as nuns to collect money that in many instances the "bishop" appropriated for himself.
ALBANY, March 17 (UPI) -The following ski conditions were reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., March 17 -- James Bostwick of New York defeated Charles H. Symington Jr. of Tuxedo today as the Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis tournament opened at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club. The scores were 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

CLEVELAND, March 17 (UPI) -- Jim Beatty's blazing kick beat the world record-holder, Ernie Cunliffe, in the 1,000-yard run tonight in a highlight of the twenty-first annual Knights of Columbus track meet.
TUNIS, March 17 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of the statement issued by the Algerian Provisional Government today on negotiations with France:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 17 -- A Federal judge ordered Escambia County to submit a plan for integration of its public schools today.

EVEN those who confuse grouse with quail might find a trip to the National Audubon Society a Fifth Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street a worthwhile experience. Here, on the first floor of the lovely old house in which the society is housed, is a gift shop that offers intriguing-accessories as a service to wild life enthusiasts.
George Seaton is one of the town's most energetic film visitors from the West Coast.
GRAND FORKS, N.D., March 17 (AP) -- Rinks from Illinois, New Hampshire, Nebraska and Massachusetts were eliminated in the men's national curling championship today.

Prices in the bond market fluctuated narrowly yesterday as the investment community gave further study to the Treasury's surprise move to extend the maturity structure of the public debt by an advance refunding operation.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers may come close to last year's record production of crops this year unless weather conditions interfere or producers change their plans.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 17 -- Len Chappell, the fastest-moving mountain in North Carolina, led Wake Forest to a 78-73 upset victory over St. Bonaventure tonight in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate Eastern regional basketball tournament.

JERUSALEM, March 17 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, arrived in Israel tonight and is expected to participate in discussions on the establishment of a Liberal party.

NEPTUNE, N.J., March 17 -A conditional grant of $75,000 to Fitkin Memorial Hospital by the Fannie E. Rippel Foundation has become effective, J. Marshall Booker, president of the hospital, announced today.

A list of about 1,500 Nazi "war criminals and collaborators" who may share responsibility for the killing of 6,000,000 European Jews in World War II has been prepared by the World Jewish Congress at 15 East Eighty-fourth Street.

Last year, at considerable expense, the city installed tile on the walls of the Franklin Roosevelt Drive underpass, south of Ninety-sixth Street, ostensibly to improve visibility. Also installed was a series of new overhead lights.
JERSEY CITY, March 17 -A jovial, beaming Brendan Behan was the St. Patrick's Day guest of this city today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Following is the text of the statement given today by Robert E. Van Deusen on behalf of the National Lutheran Council before a House Education and Labor subcommittee.

Mayor Wagner has done right to order -- on the recommendation of Hospital Commissioner Ray E. Trussell -- that the in-patient services of Gouverneur Hospital be closed down. The Mayor's decision, however, transcends in importance this particular move.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will meet here tomorrow. It will be the first meeting between the top diplomats of the two major powers since the Kennedy Administration took office.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 2 to 5 points (10 to 25 cents a bale) yesterday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Tudor Way will oppose eight other horses in the $100,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap at a mile and a quarter tomorrow, with the big gray horse a probable 1 to 2 favorite. The race will have a gross value of $114,000 if all nine start.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 17 -- Abbie Rutledge, an instructor at Adelphi, won her opening match in the Middle Atlantic badminton championship tonight by defeating Judy Peiffer of Wilmington, Del., 11 -- 2, 11 -- 1.

LAWRENCE, Kan., March 17 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Bearcats rolled to their nineteenth consecutive victory tonight, defeating Texas Tech, 78 -- 55, in the first round of the National Collegiate Midwest regional basketball play-offs.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17 -- While one major business machines corporation was announcing dedication plans today for a large research center in Westchester County, another said it was moving out.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, with the backing of his principal African and Asian advisers, mapped a further effort today to rebut Soviet charges that he was not following United Nations instructions in the Congo.

DENVER, March 17 -- The teams headed by Charles H. Goren, Robert Jordan and Edward Kantar tonight reached the final of the Vanderbilt Cup contest at the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament.
Ever since the end of World War II Chinese restaurants, especially those other than the Cantonese, have become so popular in town that the New Yorker becomes almost nostalgic for American food.
Despite an injury to its top epee competitor, New York University won two team titles in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships yesterday at the Concourse Plaza.

The legitimate theatre, if it is to develop as a cultural and artistic force, must ultimately rely on government assistance, Dimitri Rondiris, Greek director, told an audience of professional Performers at the Morosco Theatre the other night.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 17 (UPI) -- A one-third interest in one of West Germany's leading paint manufacturers has been acquired by the Glidden Company.
The Boeing Airplane Company reported yesterday that its earnings in 1960 were almost double those of 1959, despite a decline of $94,230,166 in sales.

It has now become clear that President Kennedy meant what he said at his news conference Wednesday when he stated the United States would support the Government and the people of Laos in the maintenance of their independence and neutrality.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 17 (AP) -- A state judge turned down today a request by The New York Times for a new trial of a libel suit that resulted in a $500,000 judgment for a Montgomery city official.

The instrumentalists who have to perform in the Music-in-the-Making concerts with little or no rehearsal had an ideal work for their purposes in last night's concert in the Great Hall of the Cooper Union. It was Morton Feldman's ". . . Out of 'Last Pieces,'" which was played for the first time.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Commerce Department announced today cooperation with state and local agencies to speed the award of Government contracts to areas of chronic unemployment.
John E. Hand, a longtime Democratic political figure, was fined $950 and given a suspended thirty-day jail term in Housing Court yesterday.
Marta Pariente, a young woman from Argentina and a pianist of talent, made her local debut late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
A new college basketball scandal was disclosed here yesterday. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office said that it might spread from coast to coast and dwarf the 1951 scandal.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he was confident that the Senate would pass and Governor Rockefeller would approve the bill authorizing the leasing of park land for an $18,000,000 baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park.

Trading ran as much as eleven minutes ahead of the recording ticker in the excited early hours of yesterday's stock market. Aggregate market values rose about five-eighths of 1 per cent in an advance that embraced the whole market.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 17 -- After centuries of economic stagnation and isolation, industrialization in Nepal has begun at the top -15,000 feet up in the Langtang Valley of the Himalayas, bordering Tibet.

The third annual International Stamp Exhibition, commemorating the golden anniversary of official airmail service in this country, opened yesterday at the Trade Show Building, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- President Kennedy exchanged views with nearly 100 internationally minded business executives today on the nation's foreign economic policy. But the exchange was off the record.

LONDON, March 17 -- Henry F. Houghton, a civilian clerk at a British naval installation, testified today that he had been threatened by a mysterious stranger and told to deliver secret information to him.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 17 -- Supporters of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd were preparing today to give him "a massive welcome" on his return Monday from London.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -Old crop soybean futures withstood several flurries of profit selling on the Board of Trade today and finished with gains of 3 cents or more a bushel, but the new crop months and grains were weak.

William Bloome, a New York sports writer, will become administrative steward for the New York State Harness Racing Commission on March 20. The announcement yesterday by the commission office here said his salary would be $15,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Congress was told today that the taxes it was considering for the superhighway system might make so many motorists switch to compact cars that "the magnificent highways will be monuments to fiscal folly."
Governor Rockefeller's plan to rehabilitate Albany and bring it into the twentieth century has revived a touchy question: Which is the state's oldest community -- Albany or New York City?

THE New York Philharmonic's "Keys to the Twentieth Century" continues. Yesterday afternoon's program had two keys -- Bartok's "Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta" and the first United States performance of "Improvisation on Mallarme, No. 2" by Pierre Boulez.

Stoddard Lincoln, harpsichordist, was the featured performer in a chamber-music concert presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in the Young Masters Series. He was assisted by a string quartet composed of Louise Behrend and Nancy Cirillo, violinists; Eugenia Dengel, violinist, and David Everhart, 'cellist.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Following his defeat by President Kennedy on the unemployment compensation bill last night, Senator Harry F. Byrd canceled scheduled committee confirmation hearings today on five of the President's nominees.

BONN, Germany, March 17 -Premier Khrushchev insisted on discussing the German situation when he met Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., the United States Ambassador, last week, according to reports received here by Western diplomats.

The National Mediation Board will try Wednesday to head off a strike of 800 lighter captains against seven port railroads. The walkout, originally set for April 5, has been postponed until 12:01 A.M., April 12.
The National Basketball Association said yesterday that it would distribute $125,000 to league teams for their finishing positions during the regular season and play-offs.
Relations between Nicaragua, a Central American republic with a population of 1,424,000, and Brooklyn, a North American borough with a population of 2,738,175, are deteriorating.

CAIRO, March 17 -- There are two particular reasons why Europe is concerned about distorted rumors that the United States contemplates major changes in strategic policy. One derives from a feeling that sometimes Washington miscalculates on Russia.

William F. Rickenbacker, 33-year-old son of Edward V. Rickenbasker, board chairman of Eastern Air Lines, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for refusing to answer a "special questionnaire" sent by the Census Bureau last year.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 17 -- Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona looked like Texas' favorite son today as he campaigned through the state for the single Republican in a field of seventy-one Senatorial candidates.

Two prominent Soviet musicologists went to hear Benny Goodman at an East Side nightclub early yesterday morning. They were taken to task by Mr. Goodman, who said he had not been allowed to play in the Soviet Union.
LONDON, March 17 -- Industrial shares advanced confidently in the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -Dr. Albert B. Sabin warned Congress today that the Soviet Union would be in a position to exploit the new oral poliomyelitis vaccine as a "cold war" weapon if the United States did not accelerate mass production of the vaccine.

Dear McNulty: The St. Patrick's Day parade here, in spite of fables contrary, is a thing of great propriety. It came throbbing up Fifth Avenue yesterday, and there wasn't a shillelagh in it. There was a mace or two, but they appeared to be of a severely ceremonial character.

IN many cakes milk is necessary to moisten the dry ingredients and produce a semi-liquid batter. For Jewish housewives who observe the dietary laws this means that cake cannot be served for dessert at many meals. Dairy foods such as milk and butter cannot be eaten at the same time as meat.
A quasi-official citizens' advisory group recommended yesterday that the city drop the controversial proposal to redevelop fourteen blocks in western Greenwich Village.

First-round action in the National Invitation Tournament will be completed this afternoon with a double-header at Madison Square Garden. Temple meets Army in the basketball opener at 2:15 o'clock. De Paul and Providence are paired for the second contest.
Transfer of the New York State Barge Canal System to Federal jurisdiction was urged here yesterday by Representative Frank E. Smith.

Expansion of the national money supply by Federal Reserve System moves is probably playing a bigger role in stemming or reversing the business recession than is commonly realized, according to Beryl W. Sprinkel, economist for the Harris Trust and Savings Bank.

The New York Antique and Art Dealers Association is sponsoring a lecture by H.D. Molesworth of the Victoria and Albert Museum, London, on Thursday at 8:30 P.M. The lecture will be held in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- The Soviet Union signed an agreement today with the American Council of Learned Scientists for an exchange of lectures, seminars and research programs in the humanities and social sciences.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- The defending titleholders, Mrs. Laussat Clement and Mrs. Charles Classen, and the 1960 runners-up, Mrs. Donald Manly-Power and Mrs. John Newlin, were eliminated today in the semi-final round of the United States squash racquets women's doubles championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
An effort to arrange a new airline meeting on cargo rates across the North Atlantic and avert a possible rate war has been undertaken by the International Air Transport Association.
DETROIT, March 17 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons stayed alive in the Western Division playoffs of the National Basketball Association by whipping the Los Angeles Lakers, 124 -- 113, tonight.
LONDON, March 17 -- "The Music Man," with Van Johnson playing the lead, opened here last night at the Adelphi Theatre.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17 -- Belgium was accused today of having participated in the defiance of United Nations authority by local officials in the Central African trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.

ALBANY, March 17 -- A bill raising salaries of state employes $32,500,000 a year was introduced today in the Senate and Assembly. The Rules Committees pared $3,500,000 from the total asked by Governor Rockefeller.

Events today: "Tristan und Isolde" at 1:30 P.M. and "Il Trovatore" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; New York Philharmonic, Young People's Concert, Carnegie Hall, noon: Delia Calapai, pianist, Town Hall, 2:30; Emmett Vokes, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein and Russel Stanger, conductors, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Amphion Choir, Town Hall, 8:30; Helmi Bethlem soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall 8:30.
TUNIS, March 17 -- The rebel Algerian Provisional Government announced tonight that it had "taken steps" to bring about official peace talks with the French Government.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17 -- Officials of the Seafarers International Union outlined their plans today for a defense against charges brought by the International Transport Workers Federation.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -A former Lithuanian police sergeant now living in Chicago declined tonight to talk about a Soviet charge that he committed war crimes during the Nazi occupation of Lithuania.
The report just issued by the City Planning Commission on the proposed program for erecting municipal garages in midtown Manhattan is a landmark in city planning.
A theatre party at the April 18 opening night performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company at the Metropolitan Opera House is being sponsored by the Citizens for the All Day Neighborhood Schools.
The industrial parcel at 451 South Jefferson Street, Orange, N.J., has been purchased by Orange Properties, Inc., who plan to operate it as an industrial center.
SEOUL, Korea, March 17 -Mong Yong, the handsome, brave young lord, comes charging to the rescue of his beloved Choon Hyang just as the wicked old lord is about to chop her pretty little head off.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 17 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was honored tonight by the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation for his leadership in the development of physical fitness for American youth.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Equipment patented this week enables police to make up a composite picture of a wanted criminal's face by putting plastic features together. As a robbery victim picks out the most likely looking eyes, nose, lips, brows, chin lines and other characteristics, the identification expert lays, one over the other, transparent sheets carrying drawings of the chosen features.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that Gouverneur Hospital on the Lower East Side would be closed as outmoded and inadequate.
A SORT of Shakespearean smorgasbord was served last night on Channel 4's "Bell Telephone Hour."

ALBANY, March 17 -- As Governor Rockefeller signed the new omnibus banking bill today, legislative leaders proposed to create a special committee to study the State Supreme Court decision invalidating the 1960 Bank Law.

Some 1,300 checks drawn on the Chase Manhattan Bank's branch at Jamaica Avenue and Forest Parkway, Queens, whirred through an automatic check sorting machine yesterday four floors below ground at the bank's new headquarters at Nassau, Liberty and William Streets here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -M'hammed Yazid, who has pleaded, agitated and labored for Algerian independence, is a man of restless temperament.
A rabbi who played a major role in the resistance to Nazism will be decorated with the French Legion of Honor emblem tonight at a dinner in the Park Lane Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -Personal income declined in February for the fourth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today. The Labor Department had later and brighter news. It said that unemployment among workers covered by unemployment insurance had declined for the second week in a row, following a five-month rise.

CONCERT NO. 3 of "Concerts 3" took place last night at Town Hall. The series, under the direction of Robert Mandell, has featured a variety of chamber orchestra music, mostly of the less familiar type.
BOWIE, Md., March 17 (UPI) -- Larry Adams rode three winners at Bowie today and Garden Fresh scored a length and one-half victory in the $4,500 feature.
BANMETHOUT, Vietnam, March 17 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem began his re-election campaign today with the most auspicious portent possible in any Southeast Asian state.
Future productions of "The Untouchables" will not use fictional characters as hoodlums with Italian names.

HISTORY in the making and our national heritage are expected to attract thousands of local families to the nation's capital during the spring vacation. Listed below are some of the sites that have been found of special interest to children and parents over the years.

Senator Walter J. Mahoney, the Republican leader, is trying to write into New York law an amendment giving the State Commission Against Discrimination jurisdiction over the employment and promotion of teachers in public schools and colleges. He would thus annul the effect of a decision recently handed down by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich, which supported the Board of Higher Education and ruled against SCAD in the Queens College case.
DENVER, March 17 (AP) -- A powerful first-period attack enabled Denver's defending champions to post a 6-1 triumph over Minnesota tonight in a National Collegiate hockey semi-final.

Mikhail Tal of Riga, Latvia, appeared to hold the upper hand yesterday in his second game with Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow in their twenty-four-game match for the world chess championship. The game was adjourned after forty-one moves, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.
The horses and swans at Aqueduct were relatively inactive yesterday, but the men there were busy as beavers.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- President Kennedy called today for immediate Government action to give "every possible personal encouragement" to Cuban scholars and professionals in exile in the United States.
New York University announced plans yesterday for the construction of a new $4,000,000 school of Education building at the university's Washington square campus.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- President Kennedy, who banged his forehead against a table when he leaned over suddenly to pick up something yesterday, had five stitches taken in the wound and was still wearing a patch over the cut today.
The younger generation of Finnish distance runners paid tribute to the old at the Helsinki Restaurant on Lexington Avenue yesterday.
West German foreign policy will continue to be Western-oriented no matter which party wins the coming West German elections, Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said here last night.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican national chairman, said today that his party should not only cultivate the Negro vote with vigor, but should also bring more persons from minority groups into the party organization.
Mechanical trouble caused by cold weather interfered with subway operations yesterday during the morning and evening rush hours.
A round-the-clock police guard has been posted for the parents of Arnold Schuster, who was slain nine years ago after he had helped the police capture Willie Sutton, the bank robber.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday dismissed charges against three chiefs and a captain who had been accused of neglect following a fire that killed three fireing last November. The blaze occurred on Nov. 18 in a structure at 463-7 Broadway at Grand Street.

Only two books are published today. One is "Greek Sculpture," with the text by Pierre Devambez and photographs by Robert Descharnes. It is issued by Tudor at $5.95. The other volume is "Lore of the Wreckers," by Birse Shepard.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The United States has increased its military assistance to the Government of Laos and has sent additional technicians to help train the Laotian Army.
NORWALK, Conn., March 17 -- A master plan for the development of Norwalk to accommodate a population of 96,000 persons was made public today by the Planning Commission.

THE New York City Ballet, having devoted itself thus far in its season at the City Center to ballets of a modern and even esoteric nature, last night restored two of its war horses to the repertory, and all but raised the roof with both of them.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 (UPI) -- Bob Goalby, using an ancient putter he bought for $2 in a Miami pawn shop, shot a course-record 62 today and took the lead in the St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 17 -- Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino and a majority of the Republican executive committee of the Town of Hempstead agreed today that the leadership and policies of the county organization must be revitalized.
The president of the Long Island City Savings and Loan Association was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday and charged with embezzling $54,000.

Prices of Maine potato futures staged a sharp decline in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. They closed unchanged to 15 points (hundredths of a cent a point) off on a turnover of 2,625 carlots, 50,000 pounds to a car.
"THE WIND OFF THE ISLAND,"* by Ernie Bradford, is a good trip in a small boat. Anyone who enjoys being afloat vicariously will like it.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 17 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. today ordered sixty-four Negroes registered immediately as voters in Macon County and said that all qualified Negroes must always be allowed to vote.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth ended their conference today with a call of new efforts to achieve the world disarmament.

THE danger that public policy could become "the captive of a scientific-technological elite," emphasized by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in his farewell address, has been underscored in recent years by developments in the Pentagon.
A bill effecting a general revision of the city's electrical code was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Allow me to express deep appreciation for your editorial of March 13 entitled "Who Should Make Court Rules?"

WASHINGTON, March 17 -The dew was still on the grass and the grass was as green as shamrocks when His Excellency Thomas J. Kiernan, the Irish Ambassador, rode up the White House driveway today. He took a gift for President Kennedy -the coat of arms of the Kennedy clan, with something added to commemorate a great deed and the man who did it.
ALBANY, March 17 -- The state Health Commissioner moved today to scuttle a bill in the Legislature providing for the licensing of chiropractors.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 17 (UPI) -- A judge ruled today that the Indiana Legislature was unconstitutional and had been since the Nineteen Twenties. He called the situation "a degree of anarchy within our Government."

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., has agreed to purchase the oil holdings of the Rio Tinto Company, Ltd., in exchange for 3,000,000 British Petroleum ordinary shares of 1 par value each, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Kennedy intervened today in the case of a Negro woman who said she had been denied equal housing with other delegates at a forthcoming meeting of the Civil War Centennial Commission at Charleston, S.C.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 17 -- Insistent rumors that the resignation of Venezuela's Finance Minister, Dr. Tomas Enrique Carrillo Batalla, was imminent, together with delays in an expected announcement on modifications of exchange control, have pushed the price of the free-market dollar here up to 4.60 bolivares and higher.

Charles H. Silver, president of the New York City Board of Education, made a trip to Washington to testify for Federal aid to education. Of a seven-page statement delivered to a Congressional hearing, nearly six pages were devoted to advocacy of Federal support for non-public schools. It was "unthinkable," Mr. Silver declared, that Federal aid should go only to public schools.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Deputy Defense Secretary Roswell L. Gilpatric testified today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as a body, had not been consulted in the controversial decision to award most space-research responsibilities to the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -The United States will complete a civil air terminal at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, even though the Air Force will be denied use of the airfield after April, 1962.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended Tueesday, March 14, reaching 119.9 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury in Louisville, Ky., indicted two officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters tonight on charges of embezzling $9,400 in union funds.

HAVANA, March 17 -- The Ministry of the Armed Forces announced today the arrest of a Roman Catholic priest who is accused of having served anti-Castro forces in the Escambray Mountains as chaplain for the last four months.

The Lower Cape May Regional School District, N.J., has sold $1,596,000 of bonds due from 1962 to 1987 to John Nuveen Co. and associates at interest cost of 4.18187 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 2.75 to 4.15 per cent.

After fifteen years as chairman of the Board of Directors of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway at 120th Street, New York 27, Benjamin Strong has stepped down from that post, although he will continue to serve as a director. SEOUL, Korea, March 17 -Allied delegates walked out of a military armistice meeting at Panmunjom today in protest against the North Korean Communists' disregard for established procedures.

HOLY LOCH, Scotland March 18 (AP) -- The Navy disclosed tonight that a Briton made an unauthorized dive beneath the Proteus, secret supply ship of the Polaris-armed nuclear submarine force on this side of the Atlantic.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- Mrs. John Gulick, director of the second annual Princeton Antique Show of the Wellesley College Club of Central New Jersey, has announced final arrangements for the event. It will take place at the Princeton Country Day School at Broad-mead on Tuesday and Wednesday, March 28 and 29, from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M., and on Thursday, March 30, from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 18 -- An 18-year-old freshman at Rutgers University has become a target of attacks for a satirical poem on bigotry masked by patriotism. The poem was published recently in a campus magazine.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 18 -- Because George Sisler was ailing during the spring training exercises of 1957, Branch Rickey appointed another eminently qualified expert to serve as batting coach of the Pittsburgh Pirates, himself. WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The positive national leadership which President Kennedy is exerting with fabulous vigor is the more extraordinary because he has employed it as much in the area of small problems as of large ones. Whatever the size of the parts he encounters in his intensified overhaul of Government machinery and product, the President makes a check to determine whether they should be retained, altered or replaced.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Under the vigorous managerial leadership of Solly Hemus, the St. Louis Cardinals rose from seventh place in 1959 to third place in the National League in 1960. Their fifteen-game won-lost improvement was the most striking advance in the majors.

MIAMI BEACH -- If ever there was a season for the operators of Miami Beach hotels to be jolly, this is it. Down here, they do not speak of January, February, June or July per se; instead, they lump the various months of the year into neat little packages known as the "season" and the "off season."

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 18 -- This week the proposed Congo confederation began to come into focus. Congolese leaders and foreign diplomats were studying the five fundamental resolutions the participants in the Tananarive conference adopted in planning their new political structure.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Soon now the first lovely long-tail, a red-billed tropic bird, will swoop down on Bermuda on his annual migratory flight from the West Indies. Arriving about the same time will be a flock of college students, on their annual migration here from the cold North.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- The first reaction experienced by visitor returning to Nassau after a year's absence is one of reassuring sameness. The ever-startling colors of the water, the subtle, heady fragrance of the southeast, trade wind, the bustle of traffic past the Bay Street stores in the hot, white sunshine and the incredible jumble of pigs, goats, fruit and people on the native boats at the wharves all are nostalgically familiar.

THE next international stamp exhibition to be held in the United States is tentatively set for May, 1966, in New York. It will be under the auspices of the Association for Stamp Exhibitions, of which John R. Boker is president.

WHEN "Cloud 7," a comedy by Max Wilk, opened on Broadway in 1958, it ran into stormy critical weather and drifted away after eleven performances. IN his new novel, "The Agony and the Ecstasy" (which is the April choice of the Book-of- the-Month-Club), Irving Stone returns to the area of his first success. It was with "Lust for Life," a fictionalized biography of Vincent Van Gogh, that he first attracted the attention of the reading public.

Last week was a red-letter one with gold trim for the United States. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported that for the first time since July, 1959, there was an inflow of gold from foreign governments and central banks.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 18 -- About 4,000 high school seniors are preparing for matriculation examinations in "do-it-yourself" groups and 25,000 students in lower classes of academic high schools are enjoying an unscheduled holiday as a strike by 1,500 teachers enters its third week tomorrow.
RABAT, Morocco, March 18 -- The drought that has afflicted the south and east of Morocco now threatens farm production and livestock throughout the country.
